editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
I Have carefully, though not curiou≈øly, di≈ørobed that worthy Knight, and excellent Doctor in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, Leonard Phioravant out of his Italian Ve≈øture, and put him into our Engli≈øh habit, that ≈øuch an excellent Piece may not lye cloy≈øtered in the Precinct of one Principality, but that our own Nation may participate of the Honie, this Laborious Bee hath brought to his Hive: If all reli≈øh not at the fir≈øt gu≈øt, the fault is not in the Work, but their judgements that under≈øtand him not, nor the jewels pre≈øented unto them. Avicen King of Arabia in the Arabick, Hippocrates and Galen in Greek, and Plinie and Cel≈øus in Latine; be≈øides many Engli≈øh and French, have te≈øtified their love to their native Countries, by publi≈øhing in their own Languages ≈øuch rare Trea≈øures as the≈øe. Nor fear I detraction from any for the≈øe my Labours, unle≈ø≈øe it be from ≈øome runnagate Varlets, that carry all their cunning in a Chirurgians Box in their Pockets, and their learning in a
Cap-ca≈øe behind at their backs; who through Ignorance, neither regarding the quantity, nor quality of tho≈øe excellent Medicines, abu≈øe, and ≈øophi≈øticate them in making them up, but this mu≈øt be obtruded unto the Men, not the Medicines; for prevention whereof hereafter, that honourable Society of London Phy≈øitians have cho≈øe out a Chymick Artificer, whom they have placed in their own Colledge, and over whom they have ≈øet di≈øcreet, and learned over≈øeers to oblige the publike for their care to their Medicines hereafter. So wi≈øhing you the happy fruition of health is intended you by the≈øe labours; I re≈øt,

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: HAving taken upon me to write a breif Treati≈øe of Chirurgery, in the which I will write the meer verity, and that with as much brevity as may be, becau≈øe the truth u≈øeth but little room, for the Philo≈øpher writeth, that the truth is ≈øuch a light as all men doe hide, covering it with divers abu≈øes, as the Poets many times doe; for when they write one of their tales, they goe about to hide it, and thus to our purpo≈øe: Tho≈øe that write great volumes cannot choo≈øe many times but hide the truth; for in much matter there entereth both good and bad, and therefore I will write no more then is nece≈ø≈øary, declaring what Chirurgery is, and in what order it ≈øhould be u≈øed with all his accidents, ≈øhewing what Wounds are, with Impo≈øthumes and ∆≤lcers, how they ingender, and when they are ingendered, how to cure them and di≈ø≈øolve them: A di≈øcour≈øe which will plea≈øe many, becau≈øe it is onely truth, and of great importance: Let every one therefore know, that Science with experience doe appear to be one thing, and at this pre≈øent every one is certain thereof, that the experience of Phy≈øick as well as of Chirurgery, cannot be good without Science or Method, as a man may term it; but I ≈øay, that Experience is better then Science in the≈øe two Arts, that is, in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, for Science onely ≈øheweth the vertue, the which may be done with Practi≈øe that hath no Theorick; of which I have written ≈øufficiently in my Caprici Medicinale, and that this which I write is truth, I will prove it, for I ≈øay, that none can help with the onely Method, but alwayes it is nece≈ø≈øary, that there be ≈øome experience or practi≈øe, therefore tho≈øe that doe delight to under≈øtand, let them follow this my ≈øhort Treati≈øe, in the which I will treat of things mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to be known, and will ≈øhew how ea≈øie it is to work in that Art, declaring all the difficult matter, ≈øo that every one may ≈øee and perceive it plain, and afterwards I will ≈øhew how to make many new Medicines, as well for Wounds, as for the other ≈øorts of ≈øores, which have not been u≈øed neither of old Doctors nor of new; the which Remedies are of ≈øuch vertue and ≈øtrength, that the world will wonder at them for their notable quick working, and hereafter I will write what Chirurgery is.

div.head: Short Amimadver≈øions upon the Book lately Publi≈øhed by one who ≈øtiles him≈øelfe NOAH BIGGS, Helmontii P≈øittacum.
div.p: YOu ≈øet a bigg Saile to a little Ve≈ø≈øell: I beleeve your Arke doth not like Noah's, containe all the vitality of Rationals, and Sen≈øibles.

You write Pag. 205. concerning Ma≈øtication. Seeing all Aliment ought to pa≈ø≈øe into a liquid Reduction, or tendance to Chilificative mutation, or Alimentall conver≈øion, therefore Ma≈øtification is to be highly commended.

You have like the great Fi≈øh, that ≈øwallowed Ionah, received in Van Helmont, though not dige≈øted him; and the ≈øame taxe may pa≈ø≈øe on you, which ≈øomtimes did on a Noble Courtier, devora≈øti, non edi≈øti. It was the judgment of
Doctor Charlton; a Learned Phy≈øitian, a favourer of Van Helmont, that he had a better Faculty, Evertere opiniones Veterum, quam extruere, & ≈øtabilire Novas.

When was ever Practice among≈øt the Phy≈øitians ≈øo narrowly confined, as they kept them≈øelves to one Author? Do not ≈øome of them follow Minfect, others Hartman, others Grulingius, others will have their pre≈øcriptions made after Quercetan, Faber, or Poterius, ≈øome after Begvinus, Millius, Billich, Burgravius, Becherus, or other Authors; And ≈øome di≈øgu≈øt all, which are not Paracel≈øian, or accord with Ba≈øilius, Valentinus his Ma≈øter, and are plea≈øed to practi≈øe after their Medicines, with the additions of their own Experiments, out of their reading, and judegment on their ≈øeverall Authors. I would gladly know who ties him≈øelfe to Sennertus, Riverius, or any one Modern Author, as if univer≈øall Learning were contained in the ≈øphere of one Microco≈øme: Yet you are ≈øo much for Helmont, as if he were the great Luminary of the World. I confe≈ø≈øe, I honour Van Helmont, but if you do no cures out of the tract of his Method, I beleeve you mu≈øt ≈øtudy more knowledge in his Medicines then barely how to Tran≈ølate them, or otherwi≈øe you
will faile in the honour you a≈øpire unto, and from teaching others, come your ≈øelfe to learn from tho≈øe you unworthily vilifie.

You ≈øay Pag. 12. The Schooles are ignorant of the Quiddities, and Dihoties of things, do you your ≈øelfe under≈øtand either your own, or the e≈ø≈øence of the lowe≈øt inferiour Animals? Pag. 15. Why did you not by the golden Trident of Chymicall Theoremes, whom as a Lady of Honour you have courted, devoutly ki≈ø≈øed, and profe≈ø≈øe your ≈øtrict ob≈øervance to, becalm this Sea of di≈øtraction? And as you ≈øay, Pag. 16. write in that, in which there is no beaten path, which you think mo≈øt honourable, becau≈øe he that leades hath this advantage above others, if others follow him, he hath the glory of the fir≈øt undertaking, if not the excu≈øe of prejudice: But had not Van Helmont traced out this Path to you, I could think you would have acquie≈øced to the ancient opinions, and not have a≈øpired to be reckoned among≈øt the publick Benefactors of Civill and Humane life.

Pag. 35. You have a jerke at Bartholomeus Carichterus, but I beleeve your own learning and judgment will hardly bring you to be a Phy≈øitian to ≈øo great an Emperour as Maximillian the
Second. For your threefold Character you give of a good Purge, Pag. 80. I hardly beleeve your Patients will be ≈øo happy as to meet with ≈øuch from you. The London Di≈øpen≈øatory hath variety of medicines, ≈øome following one Author, and ≈øome another, for which purpo≈øe it was ≈øo enlarged, as thought nece≈ø≈øary in re≈øpect of the ≈øeverall variety of judgment, and practi≈øes of our Modern Phy≈øitians.

You ≈øay, Pag. 11. reading is no way conducible to knowing: If you had never read Van Helmont, you had never written in this ≈øtile. You ≈øay, Pag. 11. The di≈øea≈øe known is not the halfe way to the cure, but if you know not the di≈øea≈øe, I conceive you would hardly, or blindly come to the cure of them. You write, Pag. 15. The Phy≈øitians like to the ≈øelf-conceited Laodiceans, while they pre≈øume they keep the keyes of the Science, they neither enter them≈øelves into the Clo≈øet, and inner Parlour of Nature, nor admit, willingly, others that would. But ob≈øerve your own incircum≈øpection and levitie: For had you peru≈øed their Pharmacopoea, publi≈øhed 1650. A Capite ad Calc√®m, you could not have committed ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe an error, (nor did their former want pre≈øcriptions of Chymick medicines) but if you

And had you but ca≈øt your eye on their carefull expre≈øsion, in fine Pharmacopoeae, you would have been ≈øilent, or written more temperately, which I mu≈øt expo≈øe to your knowledge in their own words.

Ne nos (Amice Lector) in hac operis ≈øu≈øcepti meta, ≈øimulque cum calamo no≈øtro curam depo≈øui≈øse tui videamur, certior ut fias, cupimus, nos etiam ≈øaluti tuae, publicaeque utilitati, nihilo ≈øegnius invigilare, adeoque officinam Chymicam, ≈øeor≈øum in horto Collegii erigendam cura≈ø≈øe, artificemque Idoneum accer≈øivi≈ø≈øe, eidemque in≈øtruendo & corrigendo Collegarum periti≈øsimos de≈øtina≈ø≈øe, ut medicamenta, quanto efficaciora, tanto cautius, quanto difficilliora, tanto diligentius, quanto pretiofiora, tanto ≈øincerius componerentur. Bartholinus in his Phy≈øicall exercitations, hath a tract again≈øt that opinion; where, by his authorities, experiments, and rea≈øons, you might be ≈øomewhat ≈øtaggered, if you do not jurare in verba Magi≈øtri: again≈øt whom Doctor Heers, in his tractate de Fontibus ≈øpadanis, ca≈øteth forth bitterrer language then I will throw upon you; yet I de≈øire you to remember what Doctor Metcalfe of Cambridge not long ≈øince ≈øaid, on the cen≈øures of ≈øome nimble-tounged Scholars on the grave Academians: You young men think us old men fooles, but we old men know you are ≈øo. I wonder whether gaine put you not at fir≈øt (when other Trades failed you) to write, or rather tran≈ølate Phy≈øick in your mother tongue: and it ≈øeemeth you rather know how to tran≈ølate Latine, then transferre it into a Sentence, as you do legere, & non intelegere, neglegere e≈øt. But I will admit the excu≈øe, tis the Compo≈øitors overfight. You ≈øay, If any want wi≈ødome, let him aske it of God, not of the Colledge of Phy≈øitians; and yet you undertake to teach them; for you ≈øay, You intend to lay down ≈øome Rules, whereby a man may as well prevent a ≈øickne≈ø≈øe before it comes, as remedy it when it comes, and that you will write of the pre≈øervation of man, even from his conception to his grave: a great undertaking, and I beleeve too high
Mr. Culpeper for your reading, and will ≈øcarce be gained out of your tran≈ølating ≈øome fragments of Galens, and ≈øome pieces of modern Anatomy. You ≈øay, Phy≈øitians of our times keep our under≈øtanding in as great bondage as Pharoah kept the Hebrew Midwifes bodies, I pray did the other Phy≈øitians before them walke in your tract? but why tran≈øcend you the text with your fooli≈øh additions? what bondage do you read of either the Aegyptian Midwifes, or women ≈øuffered under Pharaoh them≈øelves, though the males were overcharged with rigor. You confe≈ø≈øe God hath given you ≈øome little ≈øparkes of Knowledge, and you will not wrap up your talent in a napkin and bury it in the ground: Truly I thinke you need not hide any you have; and for that of rayling you will not. You de≈øire others to judge charitably of you, for Charity and Hone≈øty you ≈øay alwaies walk hand in hand together, and think ill of no man: If your own rule be your judge, you are neither Charitable nor Hone≈øt: you ≈øay in your Epi≈øtle to the Reader, The water may be muddy in the ≈øtream, which is clear in the Fountain, but yours is clear in neither: You ≈øay, The Tran≈ølators have given us a Tran≈ølation of the Bible (≈øuch a one as it is) but have given all the proper names in Scripture in pure Hebrew words in an Engli≈øh Character, and yet all the Scripture was written for our in≈øtruction: Had you been as well ver≈øed in the

You ≈øay,
Had not the Prie≈øts formerly ab≈øconded the my≈øteries of Truth from us, Sermons would have been ≈øo cheape that they would have been cried about ≈øtreets for three halfpence a dozen; You might have done well to have expre≈ø≈øed your ≈øelfe, whether you meant our Prie≈øts, or the Romane, for I dare ju≈øtifie a few of the Sermons of our late reverend Divines, as Andrewes, Hierons, Hol≈øworth, Adams, and many others which I could name, are of farr greater worth and e≈øteeme, then your di≈øpen≈øatory, unle≈ø≈øe with ≈øome ignorants and women: Though you undervalue Sermons at a le≈ø≈øe rate then ≈øparrowes, when your learned labours are prized at five or ≈øix ≈øhillings a piece. div.head: A SHORT DISCOURSE OF THE SECRETS OF THE Mo≈øt Famous Knight and Excellent Phy≈øitian and Chirurgion, Lord PHIORAVANT ‚Ä¢ .
CHAP. I. What thing infirmitie is, and whereof it proceedeth.
div.p: SIckne≈ø≈øe or Infirmitie is no other thing then a di≈øtemperature of humours in the bodies of creatures, as well rea≈øonable as unrea≈øonable, which are ≈øubject to ≈øickne≈øs and to death. And the≈øe doe not proceed of any other thing, then of the divers and ≈øundry di≈øorders committed many waies, which di≈øorders every man might very well defend him≈øelf from, if he would. And the≈øe di≈øorders which are thus committed are very many, whereof I will name you a few, and will tell you al≈øo of the infirmities which follow them.

There are many which di≈øorder them≈øelves in their eating,
and in the varietie and ≈øuperfluitie of meats, and ≈øo corrupt them≈øelves; and of ≈øuch corruption engendreth ill di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øtomack, and lo≈ø≈øe of appetite, and thence cometh the Itch, and di≈øea≈øes of the legs, and other like matters, which commonly proceed of much repletion‚ñ™ Others di≈øorder them≈øelves in the exce≈øs of Lecherie, of which di≈øorder cometh debilitie of the Reins, want of the ≈øight, weakne≈øs of the brains, and oftentimes di≈øea≈øes about the Yard, and other kinde of infirmities hanging upon the French ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. Some di≈øorder them≈øelves in fi≈øhing, ≈øtanding much in the water; and of this acce≈ø≈øe cometh coldne≈ø≈øe of the Nerves, pains of the legs and feet, and ≈øuch other things which ≈øuch acce≈ø≈øe cau≈øeth. Other ≈øome di≈øorder them≈øelves in hunting, in ≈øuch ≈øort, as they take heat, cold, wearine≈øs, hunger and thir≈øt; of which di≈øorder there followeth Agues, Opilations, Rheums, Numne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øuch like things; which, with ≈øuch di≈øorder and great travell, commonly are wont to bee cau≈øed. And in divers other manners men may di≈øorder them≈øelves, which at this time I will omit, becau≈øe I will not be over-tedious to the Reader. It ≈øufficeth, ≈øo that I ≈øhew the ≈øub≈øtance of the thing, and to doe it, that every one may under≈øtand it. If then the cau≈øes are infinite, by which infirmities or ≈øickne≈øs come, and the remedies a great many more then enough to cure them: I mean therefore to ≈øet down in the Chapters following the infirmities, together with the remedies, with the which they may be healed, beginning with the infirmities which men have from their birth unto their death, di≈øcour≈øing of them one after an other. And fir≈øt I will ≈øpeak of Infants and children, which happen into the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øoon as they are born.

div.head: CHAP. II. To help the falling ≈øickne≈øs in young Children.
div.p:
THe Falling Sickne≈øs is a di≈øea≈øe, the which in young Children is cau≈øed of great humiditie in the head, and the cure thereof according to our Order, is with drying things
which di≈ø≈øolveth that humiditie, and the Remedie is this: Take our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, and ≈øpread it on a cloth the breadth of two fingers ≈øquare, and ≈øtrew thereon the powder of Cantharides: the which of his own quality and nature is attractive, and bringeth forth great quantity of water: then lay this Cerot in the nuke of the neck, and there let it lye at the lea≈øt eight or ten daies, taking it off every day, and making it clean, then lay it on that place again. Likewi≈øe you ≈øhall annoint the head with Oleum Petroleum, the which is very drying and penetrative; becau≈øe it cometh forth of a Mine under the earth, the which continually doth boil, and ≈øo cometh forth with the water, and then is ≈øeparated. This Oil hath a marvellous vertue in him≈øelf, that it defendeth the fire, for if a man annoint his hands therewith, he may wa≈øh his hands with molten Lead pre≈øently, and never hurt him: and that cometh through a certain hidden vertue in that Oil. Al≈øo you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this Oil will burn being ≈øet on fire, and yet it will not hurt or ≈øcald any thing which it falleth on, or toucheth it.

div.head: CHAP. III. To help young Children of certain gro≈ø≈øe Scabs, that come in the head and face.
div.p: THe≈øe gro≈ø≈øe ≈øcabs that come in the head and face, are cau≈øed of abundance of fatne≈øs, and moi≈øture of the milk of the Nur≈øe; for the child being tender and weak of complexion, is not apt to dige≈øt that ≈øuperfluous humour, and ≈øo Nature driveth it forth in that order, with great abundance of humiditie, And the be≈øt remedie is, That you ≈øhall give the child every morning one ≈øcruple to drinke, of our Elixar vitae, becau≈øe it is a friend to Nature, and nouri≈øheth the bodie, and drieth up ≈øuperfluous moi≈øture, and ≈øo the child ≈øhall be holpen. Al≈øo you ≈øhall annoint the child with our Magno liquore, the which is temperate of nature, and doth penetrate, and ≈øo cau≈øeth ≈øolution of that humour.

div.head: CHAP. IV. To help young Children of the Rupture.
div.p: THe Rupture is cau≈øed two waies, the one through weakne≈ø≈øe of the place, and the other through much crying, and the remedie is thus: You ≈øhall make a Tru≈ø≈øe fit for the childe that ≈øhall come very clo≈øe, and then let them u≈øe our Electuarie of Con≈øolida majore, the which is written in my di≈øcour≈øe of Chirurgerie, with divers of my Medicines: And al≈øo you ≈øhall give the child to drink the powder of Alkimilla in wine; and every night you ≈øhall annoint the Rupture with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum, made of Turpentine and Waxe: the which is ≈øo peircing, that it warmeth the place that is broke, and helpeth it to ≈øiccatrize. And ≈øo u≈øing the≈øe three Medicines, thou ≈øhalt help him quickly, for this have I proved an infinite of times, and alwaies have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, thanks be to God.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the ≈ømall Poxe that come to Children.
div.p:
THe Small Pox are cau≈øed of ≈øuperfluous choller and flegm, the which is mixed with the bloud, and ≈øo continuing a certain time it doth encrea≈øe ≈øo much, that Nature cannot bear it, and ≈øo driveth it forth with a great accident of a Fever, the which commonly doth continue four or five daies together, and then cometh forth certain wheals or bladders full of corruption, which within three daies will break and run forth, and many drie. You ≈øhall under≈øtand that there are ≈øome ≈øo weak of Nature that they cannot come forth, but remain within, and ≈øo having no evaporation outwardly, it doth choak them, and ≈øo die, and that is the cau≈øe why ≈øo many creatures from four yeers old to ten doe die without help. And therefore I con≈øidering the true cau≈øe of the di≈øea≈øe, I have al≈øo found out the true remedie to help them, and that is this. When the child feeleth that Accident, give him pre≈øently one drachm
of our Aromatico to eat: The which hath ≈øuch force and vertue attractive, that it joyning unto the ≈øtomack draweth unto it all the humours that offend, and carrieth them forth both by vomit and ≈øege, and ≈øo leaveth Nature ea≈øed, and the partie out of danger. Then after that anoint him four evenings with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and lay him down to ≈øweat, and ≈øo he ≈øhall be well.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Fer≈øa or Mea≈øels that come to young Children.
div.p: THe Mea≈øels that cometh to Children, commonly cometh after the ≈ømall poxe one yeer or two, or three, and is cau≈øed of the afore≈øaid cau≈øe; and there is no other difference between them, but that the per≈øon is of more age and ≈øtrength, and both come with an accident of a Fever, but in this cau≈øe they come forth thicker, and they dry without breaking or running. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, this many times cau≈øeth death, if it be not holpen quickly, and with the remedies appropriate. You ≈øhall under≈øtand that this doth not come with ≈øo great vehemencie as the other doth. You ≈øhall onely defend the heart and pre≈øerve the ≈øtomack from corruption, and putrefaction, and ≈øo you ≈øhall help them quickly. The Remedies are the≈øe: You ≈øhall give them four or five mornings this drinke: Take Julep of Violets, ‚Ñ• ii. Ro≈øewater, ‚Ñ• iiii. Oile of Vitriol four grains, mixe them and drink it cold: for this is a rare Medicine.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Waxing Kernels, which are called of ≈øome Scrophulae.
div.p:
THe≈øe Kernels that commonly come in the throat of young Children, are cau≈øed of ≈øuperfluous melancholy humours corrupted, and are a kinde of Ulcer, very hard to be holpen, and evill to have, for when they are broke they cau≈øe exce≈ø≈øive pain, becau≈øe thereunto runneth great abundance of humours,
and are ≈øo hot and corrupt, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to help them with outward Medicines onely, becau≈øe they proceed of an inward cau≈øe. Therefore if thou wilt help them, fir≈øt remove the Cau≈øe, and then cure the Effect.

Fir≈øt therefore thou ≈øhalt give them our Sirrup again≈øt Melancholick humours, written in our di≈øcour≈øe of Chirurgerie, and then give him a Do≈øe of our Aromatico fa≈øting, and that will evacuate the ≈øtomack of choler and flegm, and drie up tho≈øe humours that run to the ≈øores. The Medicines that you ≈øhall u≈øe to the ≈øore, are two: The fir≈øt is our Co≈øtick, which being laid on the ≈øore, doth mortifie it in four and twentie hours, and taketh away the corruption. Note, that you may not take away the Askar, untill ≈øuch time as it falleth out of him≈øelf, then lay thereon the black Cerot of Godfredo de Medic. the which Cerot is written al≈øo in Galen. And in ≈øhort ≈øpace it will be holp, as I have proved divers times.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of divers ≈øorts of Scabs, and their Remedies.
div.p:
SCabs proceed of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes; Neverthele≈ø≈øe, they all are cau≈øed of putrefied blood, as you may ≈øee by daily experience. But the ≈øaid putrefaction may be cau≈øed of divers accidents, as by eating much moi≈øt and fat meat. It may be cau≈øed of a corrupt humour of the French Pox, and of divers other cau≈øes, which I will leave at this time. Therefore if thou wilt help any of the afore≈øaid cau≈øes, it would be nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe Purgations, and Unctions: The Purgations are two, and the Unctions al≈øo two. The fir≈øt Purgation is half an ounce of our Electuario Angelico, which take in the morning fa≈øting thereon at the lea≈øt four hours: then take for ten daies together our Soluble Sirrup; the do≈øe is from ‚Ñ•. iiii. to ‚Ñ•. vi. And then if the Scabs come of the Pox, you ≈øhall annoint them five or ≈øix nights with our ∆≤nguento magno, and they ≈øhall be holpen. But if the ≈øcabs come of any other cau≈øe, you ≈øhall annoint them with ∆≤nguento de Lithargiro ≈øimple, after they are well purged. The Unguent is
made with Vineger, with the Oil of Ro≈øes, and with Litarge.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Again≈øt Worms in Children.
div.p: THis is a rare ≈øecret again≈øt the Worms, the which I have u≈øed a long time, and alwaies have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. Take the ≈øeed of Levant, the which is ≈øweet, and is called in Italian Sementina, and the ≈øeeds of Carduus Benedictus, and of a certain Herb growing on the Sea, called Carolina, ana: ≈øtamp it very fine, and give thereof one drachm in honey, and it will kill the Worms, al≈øo thou ≈øhalt under≈øtand that I have a great ≈øecret again≈øt the Worms, the which I will ≈øhew thee; for it may be u≈øed more ≈øafer then any of the≈øe Hearbs above named: You ≈øhall annoint all the bodie over (leaving no part) with our Balm Artificiall, and give the Patient thereof to drink í. i. with Wine or Broth. Thou ≈øhalt under≈øtand, though the child have no Worms, yet the Medicine will doe him great good, becau≈øe it helpeth again≈øt all manner of di≈øea≈øes that may happen unto children, and al≈øo to other per≈øons.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of certain Warts or Carvoli, that come on the Yard of a man.
div.p:
VVHen Children have pa≈ø≈øed the fore≈øaid di≈øea≈øes, and that they come to the age of fourteen yeers, or fifteen, or more, and that they begin to fall among women, many times by ≈øome accidents, they get the≈øe Carvoli, or Warts on the Yard. And they are of divers kinds, for ≈øome come on the very skin, and ≈øome come on the fle≈øh or end of the Yeard. Some are as though they were burnt or ≈øcorched, and other like Ulcers, and other like Warts. Tho≈øe that come as though they were ≈øcorched are of ≈ømall importance, and may be ea≈øily helped, for if you touch them once or twice with our Aqua reali, they will be whole. Tho≈øe which are Ulcerated are evil to heal,
yet you ≈øhall u≈øe no ≈øtrong Medicines thereto, but onely dre≈ø≈øe them with our Magno liquore, and in ≈øhort time they will be whole. Tho≈øe that are like Warts are very evil to be help'd, for you mu≈øt mortifie them with our Co≈øtick, one after another. But if they be not mortified at once, touch them again, and again. if need require; and when they are mortified, help them onely with our Magno liquore, untill they be whole: And with this Order I have cured a number.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Running of the Reins.
div.p: THe running of the Reins mo≈øt commonly cometh of the much u≈øe of women, or becau≈øe tho≈øe women are corrupted with a certain di≈øtemperature of heat, that is able to corrupt a man u≈øing with her. And of this running there may grow divers di≈øea≈øes, as you may ≈øee by tho≈øe that are troubled therewith, if they be not helped as they ought to be. One of the di≈øea≈øes that may come of this, is great pains in the back, becau≈øe it doth weaken the vertue of the Reins. There may come al≈øo a great burning in the Yeard, and botches in the Groin, and ≈øuch like, all which are hard to bee di≈ø≈øolved. The cure of this di≈øea≈øe is, You ≈øhall take three times our Pills called Pillolae Aquilonae, every third day once, that being done, he ≈øhall u≈øe this Electuarie ≈øeven or eight daies together.

Take a certain ≈øhell which is ≈ømooth, and is called of ≈øome Calcinelli, and of ≈øome Toninole, and of ≈øome Telline; Take them and burn them, make it into fine powder, and take thereof ‚Ñ• i. the buds of Cankers or wild Eglantine that the Ro≈øe cometh of, it is called in Italian Ro≈øe canine, ‚Ñ•. di. Hy≈øope of the Mountain í. ii. white honie crude ‚Ñ•. vi. Make thereof an Electuarie without fire. The do≈øe is, ‚Ñ•. i, in the morning fa≈øting, and at night before meat. Note, that when you u≈øe this Medicine, you ≈øhall eat no Pork, nor Fi≈øh, nor ≈ølimie things.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of a Botch which is cau≈øed of a corrupt humour, which is a kind of Pox.
div.p: I Would here ≈øhewe the cau≈øe more plainer, but that there are divers which have ≈øhewed it plaine enough: but I will ≈øhew thee the true ≈øecret and remedy to help them. Fir≈øt, Thou ≈øhalt give them ten mornings together our Soluble Sirrupe, and then take our Aromatico three times, that being done, and that the botch is open, you ≈øhall dre≈ø≈øe it with our Magno liquore upon a tent, and lay upon the ≈øore our Magistrale Cerotte, and with the≈øe two medicines thou ≈øhalt help it from the beginning to the ending, as I have ≈øeen the experience divers times.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of Pellarella that cau≈øeth the haire to fall off.
div.p:
PEllarella, or Morphewe, is a kind of Pox, and is one of the fir≈øt Pre≈øagia of that di≈øea≈øe, and is a corrupt humour, and ≈øo drying, that in ≈øhort time it mortifieth the haire of the head and beard, and eye-browes, and cau≈øeth them to fall off. You ≈øhall under≈øtand that this di≈øea≈øe is ≈øuch a thing, that it cannot be helped by any meanes, except it be taken in time, before the haire be mortified. Neverthele≈ø≈øe I will ≈øhew a ≈øecret unto the World, to know when a man hath that di≈øea≈øe or no, and in what time he may help it that they ≈øhall not fall. The ≈øecret is this, Thou ≈øhalt under≈øtand, that the beginning of Pellarella, is one Carvoli or more that cometh upon the Yeard, the which ≈øeemeth to be of little importance, becau≈øe they are holpen with ea≈øe, but within ten, or fifteen daies after they are whole, there will come a certaine alteration in the throate, which will not ≈øuffer him to ≈øwallow his meat, which doth indure commonly eight or ten daies, and ≈øo goe away by it ≈øelfe without any medicine, and in that time the haire is mortified, and then within two or three moneths the haire will fall: ≈øo that
this is the cau≈øe why they cannot be help'd when they fall away, for the time was pa≈ø≈øed before, and the rootes mortified. Therefore if thou wilt keep thy ≈øelf from running into ≈øuch a great danger, thou maie≈øt do it ea≈øily if thou take it in time: and the remedie is this. When you have had any of the≈øe Carvoli, and that after there cometh an alteration in the throate, then pre≈øently purge, and u≈øe a defen≈øive unction that the haire may not mortifie. You ≈øhall purge him nine dayes every morning with our Sirupo Magi≈øtrale, and fa≈øt thereon four houres. The do≈øe is from ‚Ñ• iii. to ‚Ñ• vi. that being done, you ≈øhall give him ‚Ñ•. di. of Electuario Angelica, according to the recept, and in the mean time annoint all his face and head with our Magno liquore, and doing thus, it is not po≈ø≈øible that the haire ≈øhould fall off. This is a ≈øecret, the which few men have known, and never written of any before this time, and is of ≈øo great importance, that it were nece≈ø≈øarie to be known for an univer≈øall health, that every man might keep him≈øelf from this di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. Of Scabbes that come through the Pox.
div.p: THe Scabbes that come through the Pox, are of divers ≈øorts; as you may ≈øee by experience: yet all may be helped with one order of medicine, becau≈øe they proceed of no other thing then of the evill di≈øpo≈øition of that di≈øea≈øe. And the≈øe mo≈øt commonly do proceed and come after Pellarella, and this is the cure. You ≈øhall give him our Soluble Sirrup every morning warm, with two ounces of Mel Ro≈øarum, and lay him down to ≈øweat, and cover him well, and then at night annoint him with Vnguento di Lithargiro, and thus doing five, or ≈øix daies, he ≈øhall be helped. For with this order I have helped an infinite number, to my great honour, and ≈øatisfaction of the Patient.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of certaine Tumours, or ≈øwellings in divers parts of the body.
div.p: SWellings, which u≈øe to come to man, are called Tumours again≈øt nature, and may come of divers cau≈øes, as by cold, and they do cau≈øe inflammations without paine, and mo≈øt commonly they come in the articular parts: There are others which are cau≈øed of hot humours, and tho≈øe are called Ri≈øepelli: There are other that come of the Pox, and the≈øe come in the head, and on the legges and armes, and are of evill dige≈øtion, becau≈øe they are engendered of corrupt, vi≈øcous, and crude humours. You ≈øhall under≈øtand that the≈øe three kindes do differ in qualitie, and are al≈øo helped with ≈øundry medicines. Tho≈øe that come of cold, are windie humours, and may be helped with bathes of hearbes, and hot unctions that have virtue to di≈ø≈øolve the wind. The hearbes to make the bath, are the≈øe: Nettles, Mallowes, Pelletory of the wall, Bran and A≈øhes, and make thereof a bath; and then annoint them with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum, made of Turpentine and Wax. Tho≈øe that come of hot humours, you ≈øhall wa≈øh with Aqua Vitae, becau≈øe it openeth the pores, and di≈ø≈øolveth that heat. Tho≈øe that are come of the Pox, are evill to heale, and his cure mu≈øt be with great purging: and the chiefe≈øt thing that you can give him, is our potion of Lignum Vitae, becau≈øe it doth make thin tho≈øe gro≈øs humours, and di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øwellings, if it be taken according to the order of the recept, the which is written in this Book. And ≈øo with this order thou ≈øhalt help them perfectly.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of Ache in divers parts of the body.
div.p:
AChes, that come to divers parts of the Bodies, do ≈øpring of divers cau≈øes, as it is ≈øaid before of the Swellings, or Tumours: but for the mo≈øt part now in this our time, they are
cau≈øed of the Pox, and tho≈øe kinds of Aches are evill to be helped, becau≈øe they are engendered of vi≈øcous humours, and putrefaction of the bloud, and of evill di≈øpo≈øition of the Liver. And the cure of tho≈øe Aches, is to purge the body, and purifie the Liver: and that thou ≈øhalt do with our Soluble Sirrupe, taking it ten dayes: and then take our Electuario Angelica, or Pillole Aquilone, and then u≈øe your wine of Lignum ≈øanctum, and ≈øweat therewith as much as thou can≈øt, for it is warm and drie, and apperative, and provoketh ≈øweate, and ≈øo they ≈øhall be helpt. But if it happen that this will not help, then annoint them three or four times with our Vnguento magno, and without all doubt by Gods grace, they ≈øhall be helped and ≈øound of that di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Cough in the ≈øtomack.
div.p:
THe Cough cometh divers and ≈øundry waies to the ≈øtomack, as by cold, and that is one of the mo≈øt common cau≈øes that may be, and is of ≈ømall importance, becau≈øe it will goe away of it ≈øelfe without medicine. There is another kind of Cough that troubleth much old folke, and that is of a Catarrhous humour. The third kind of Cough written of by us, is that which cometh to tho≈øe that have the Fever Hectick. Al≈øo there is another kind which is cau≈øed of the French Pox. And the≈øe are the foure kindes of Coughes that do commonly happen vnto men and women. The fir≈øt kind of Cough that happeneth unto man through cold, is ea≈øie to be helped, for nature of it ≈øelf will help it without any other helpe: but if thou wilt helpe nature thou maie≈øt with ea≈øe, and that ≈øhall be with eating drie and apperatiue meates, and drinking good wine, and ≈øo the Cough will goe away quickly. But the Cough which cometh to old folk, is cau≈øed of a Catarrhous humour, which is nothing el≈øe but debilitie of nature, for lack of naturall heat, the which cau≈øeth the ≈øtomack that it cannot dige≈øt his meate in ≈øuch order as it ≈øhould, but ingendreth tho≈øe ≈øuperfluous humours, that cau≈øe the Cough. And this mu≈øt be helped with
keeping of diet; that is, to eat little meat, and to u≈øe thing that warm the ≈øtomack and help dige≈øtion, and this thou ≈øhalt doe in this order. Take í. ii. of our Aromatico, which hath vertue to evacuate the ≈øtomack, and then u≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, and annoint the ≈øtomack with our Balm artificiall, and ≈øo ≈øhalt thou help this kind of Cough. The third kind of Cough, which is cau≈øed of the Fever Hectick, is of evill nature, that I dare ≈øay nothing nor ≈øhew a Medicine, becau≈øe the mo≈øt part that are troubled therewith, go to Church and never return again to their hou≈øes, as you may ≈øee by experience. The fourth kind of Cough is devili≈øh and evill to help, becau≈øe it is cau≈øed of the Pox, and doth not onely hurt the ≈øtomack, but cau≈øeth great pains to the partie be≈øide. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, thou ≈øhalt under≈øtand that this is ea≈øie to he helped by Gods grace, for them that know the true ≈øecret, which is thus: You ≈øhall give him eight or ten daies together our Soluble Sirrup, then take two drachms of our Aromatico, and then perfume him with Cinabar five or ≈øix mornings, or ≈øo long untill that he feel pain in his gums, and then hee ≈øhall be whole. For this is a great ≈øecret, to help that kind of Cough cau≈øed of the Poxe, as I have proved a thou≈øand times with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the white Scab that cometh in the Head.
div.p:
THis Scab is of an evill corruption in the ≈øuperiour parts, which is cau≈øed of abundance of moi≈øture, and heat of the Stomack, which ≈øendeth the≈øe vapours up to the head, and ≈øo goeth out that way. This is of two kindes, the one is hot and dry, and that is with a certain white cru≈øt, without any other kind of putrefaction: the other kind is hot and moi≈øt, and that cau≈øeth a certain cru≈øt, which is full of matter under it; ≈øo that as they differ in qualitie, they differ al≈øo in cure. Tho≈øe that are hot and dry, mu≈øt have Medicines that cool the heat, and extingui≈øh the drine≈ø≈øe, and this thou ≈øhalt doe with Sirrup of Citarch, and purge often with Ca≈øsia, and u≈øe
cooling things, as Succorie, Melons, Lettice, and ≈øuch like. The other kinde which is hot and moi≈øt, you mu≈øt fir≈øt help the heat, and then dry the humiditie, which you ≈øhall doe with vomiting, and purging, and keeping diet, and eating of drying meats. The fir≈øt drying ≈øcab you ≈øhall annoint onely with our Magno liquore, which without help of any other thing, will cure it after they be purged, as is before ≈øaid. The ≈øecond kind you ≈øhall help, after the bodie is purged with our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, ≈øtrewing thereon Cantharides in fine powder, which have vertue attractive; by which means it mundifieth the head of that ≈øuperfluous humiditie, and then annoint him with our ∆≤nguento magno, and in ≈øhort ≈øpace it will be whole, becau≈øe it is cold and drie. And ≈øo by this means thou maye≈øt heal the≈øe two kinds of Scabs, as I have done divers times, having re≈øpect to the cau≈øe. Ye ≈øhall under≈øtand that this di≈øea≈øe is many times taken from the Nur≈øe, the which is infected with the Pox, and ≈øo her milk being corrupted, it corrupteth the child, and therfore there mu≈øt be good con≈øideration thereof in the cure.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of Ri≈øipella.
div.p:
THis Ri≈øipella is an inflammation with ≈øwelling and redne≈ø≈øe, the which commonly cometh in the face, arms and legs, and in no other places of the bodie, and it is cau≈øed of alteration of the blood, as I will ≈øhew you an example by a pot that you ≈øeeth your meat in: When it is ≈øet on the fire, and is full of liquor, lacking one or two inches of the top, and when it beginneth to boil through the great heat of the fire, it runneth over the pot: and ≈øo by the like example we may ≈øay, that Ri≈øipella is a great alteration of the blood, through ≈øuperfluous heat; and this occa≈øion of heat proceedeth of great quantitie of flegm, that is in the ≈øtomack; for becau≈øe a≈ø≈øoon as they have vomited the flegm, they are helped of Ri≈øipella, for I have ≈øeen the experience thereof divers times. Therefore give them of the juyce of Elder-Roots
‚Ñ•. iiii. and of Honie of Ro≈øes ‚Ñ•. ii. in the morning fa≈øting, for this purgeth the Stomack of flegm, and cooleth the blood, then hold the parts over the fume of hot water, and bathe it with pure Aqua vitae, di≈øtilled without flegm: for this is one of the mo≈øt excellent Medicines that can be found, becau≈øe it is aperative and attractive, and pre≈øently di≈ø≈øolveth that alteration, and taketh away the pain. Al≈øo it would be good to u≈øe five or ≈øix mornings to drinke ‚Ñ•. i. of Julep of Violets, with ≈øix grains of Vitriol, for this mundifieth the ≈øtomack, and cau≈øeth dige≈øtion, and of him≈øelf is mo≈øt whol≈øome, for that it mortifieth all hot di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Squinancie.
div.p: THe Squinancie is a certain alteration in the throat, which is cau≈øed of a flatuous or windie humor, and this cometh with ≈øuch a vehemencie, that if it be not holpen quickly, it will choak him, for it ≈øtoppeth the conduites where the breath cometh through, and letteth a man to ≈øwallow his meat, and the Remedie is this: Take of our Electuario angelica, ‚Ñ•. di. and then touch the throat within with our Aqua reale three or four times, and without annoint it with Oleum Philo≈øophorum of Turpentine and Wax, becau≈øe it is very drying: And thus u≈øing the afore≈øaid remedies, thou maye≈øt help them without letting blood, or any other thing in ≈øhort ≈øpace: for herewith I have cured a great number. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that oil of Lin≈øeed is very appropriate to that matter, if you give the Patient four ounces. Al≈øo the tooth of a Bore made in powder, and drunk the quantitie of í. ii. in Lin≈øeed oil helpeth the Squinancie. The≈øe I have proved divers times.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Emerodes that come in the Fundament.
div.p: THe≈øe in Naples be called Moricole, and in Venice, Maroelle, and in Spain, Almorane; and are an alteration of blood in the Emorodiall veins, which many times come forth in the lower parts with great pain, and the≈øe are cau≈øed of putrified humours of the bodie, and corruption of the blood, which corruption many times cometh of the Pox, or ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes. There are al≈øo divers kinds, but principally two: The one ≈øort is within the fundament, and cau≈øeth great pain when they go to ≈øtool: The other ≈øort cometh forth of the fundament, and are not ≈øo painfull as the other are. To cure them that are within the Fundament, you ≈øhall give the Patient eight or ten mornings our Syrupo Magi≈øtrale, and then let him take of our Aromatico, í. ii. and u≈øe Gli≈øters wherein is put half an ounce of Aqua reale at a time, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them. The be≈øt remedie for tho≈øe that come forth is to make inci≈øion, or to make a little hole in them, that the blood may come forth which is putrified, and ≈øo by evacuation thou ≈øhalt help them. Al≈øo thou ≈øhalt under≈øtand, that vomiting is nece≈ø≈øarie in the cure of them both, becau≈øe it openeth the veins. Al≈øo oil of Eggs, and oil of Frankincen≈øe, and oil of Lin≈øeed are very profitable to annoint them therewith to ea≈øe the pain.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. A goodly and ea≈øie way to help all ≈øorts of Fevers according to our Order.
div.p:
THe Fever Quotidian or continuall Fever, or any other kind what≈øoever, do proceed onely of two principall cau≈øes, that is, of corruption and putrefaction, as you may perceive how that when the Fever is entred, the Patient is all corrupted, beginning at the ≈øtomack, the which is fir≈øt corrupted. For proof you may alwaies ≈øee that a≈ø≈øoon as a man is ≈øick, pre≈øently
he loo≈øeth his appetite and cannot eat; afterward it corrupteth the blood, for by experience, if you let them blood, it is alwaies found corrupted, and not as it is in a ≈øound bodie. It corrupteth al≈øo the ≈øen≈øes, ≈øo that the ≈øick is not ≈øtable ≈øenced, nor cannot ≈øleep, or re≈øt by any means whil≈øt he hath that accident. That it is cau≈øed al≈øo of Putrifaction you may ≈øee by them, that have the Fever. For alwaies when the Fever cometh, pre≈øently the ≈øtomack doth putrifie, and ≈øpitteth forth filthy ≈øpittle: Al≈øo it doth putrifie the bodie, becau≈øe their Excrements that they void are putrified and ≈øtinking more then others, and their Urine putrified and alterated from his naturall cour≈øe. Then ≈øeeing the Fever is cau≈øed of corruption and putrifaction, there are four things nece≈ø≈øarie to be done in the cure thereof. The fir≈øt is, to evacuate the ≈øtomack: The ≈øecond, to purge by urine: The third, to evacuate the bodie: And the fourth is, to purge by ≈øweat: Which four operations may be done one after another with great ea≈øe, and will re≈øtore the Patient to his health. But you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that all cannot be holp, for that God almightie hath made us to die, and when that time cometh, medicines will doe no good, but if that time be not yet come, by the help of God, with the≈øe Medicines he ≈øhall be re≈øtored to his former health. The fir≈øt thing, as I ≈øaid, is to take a vomit, which doth evacuate the ≈øtomack of choler and flegm, that doth much offend the bodie di≈øea≈øed: After that, evacuate the bodie with tho≈øe things that the Phy≈øician thinketh mo≈øt convenient for that purpo≈øe, for there be many purgations to di≈ø≈øolve the body, and to evacuate malign humours: After that, make him purge by urine. Fourthly, and la≈øt of all, give him medicines that open the pores, and that provoketh ≈øweat. And thus with the≈øe four operations, the mo≈øt part ≈øhall be holp of that infirmitie with great ea≈øe, and in ≈øhort time: And as I have ≈øaid, this is a mo≈øt true order that never faileth, except (as I ≈øaid before) when the Lord will call them. And as for the≈øe medicines, you ≈øhall find them written in this book ≈øeverally with their u≈øes and quantities.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Another cure of the ≈øaid Fevers.
div.p:
IF thou wilt help the ≈øaid Fevers according to our order: when the Patient is greatly alterated therewith, thou ≈øhalt u≈øe five waies wherewith thou ≈øhalt ea≈øily help them, the which are the≈øe. The fir≈øt as I ≈øaid before is Vomit: the ≈øecond evacuation of the body: the third evacuation by urine: the fourth to provoke ≈øweat: and the fifth by unction. Neverthele≈ø≈øe each of the≈øe alone is ≈øufficient to help the ≈øaid Fever: but yet u≈øing them all five, there is no doubt but thou maie≈øt di≈ø≈øolve any evill ≈øort of maligne Fever, except as I ≈øaid before, God will call them out of this World: but to the purpo≈øe of the cure. Fir≈øt thou ≈øhalt ≈øet on five or ≈øix boxing gla≈ø≈øes, according to the complexion and age of the infirmed: then the next morning give him one do≈øe of our Electuario angellica, with Sirrup of Sorrell, and water of Sorrell. Then the next morning following give him ≈øome Sirrup appropriate for that di≈øea≈øe, and put thereto ‚Ñ•. ii. of Sirrupo Magi≈øtrale, with Rhabarbe: that being ended, give him three or foure times Julep of Violets with Oyle of Sulphur, made per Campana, the do≈øe of the Julep is ‚Ñ• ii. and of the Oyle of Sulphur four or five graines mixed together, and this you ≈øhall take in ≈øtead of Sirrup betimes in the morning, and it will make them ≈øweat and purge by urine, which are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øick: and in the mean ≈øea≈øon you ≈øhall annoint them every night with Magno liquore, which will make them re≈øt well, and take away all their paines throughout the body, and ≈øo by this meanes the Fever ≈øhall be perfectly taken away. Al≈øo take great heed that you take no more blood then is nece≈ø≈øary, neither let them keep any ≈øtraight Diet, but let them keep a good regiment of Life. But when this Feaver doth come through ≈øome other cau≈øe, then it were nece≈ø≈øary to remove the principall cau≈øe, if thou wilt cure them: For if it be cau≈øed of a Catarre, of nece≈ø≈øitie you mu≈øt di≈ø≈øolve the Catarre fir≈øt; and then help the Fever. Al≈øo if the Fever be cau≈øed of a wound, it were nece≈ø≈øary fir≈øt to take away the pain of the
wound, and then the Fever will depart. And thus in every kind of Fever, it is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to know the originall from whence it is cau≈øed: And this is the true way to cure the≈øe infirmities, which I have proved infinite times.

div.head: CAAP. XXIIII. Of the continuall Fever.
div.p:
THere are many kindes of Fevers, therefore I will mention of them that are mo≈øt known unto the world, and fir≈øt of the continuall Fever, that is of tho≈øe that are onely hot, and continue in one order both day and night, the which is caus'd of alteration and corruption of the humours in the body, which engender ≈øo much corruption in the ≈øtomack, and in the blood, that they cau≈øe that accident of Fever: And the very order to cure it is this. In the beginning of the alteration let him keep a good diet, and drink no wine: and that is done becau≈øe that corruption is apt to corrupt all that entereth into the body during that alteration, and therefore meates of great ≈øub≈øtance or nouri≈øhment, are ≈øooner turned into greater putrifaction in the body: But when the third day of the Fever is pa≈øt, then take of our Aromatico í. ii. which will evacuate the ≈øtomack of that corruption: and that day that you take this Aromatico, drink as much crude water as you will: which is done becau≈øe the ≈øtomack ≈øhall remaine cleare wa≈øhed of that corruption, which being done, you ≈øhall give him three or four mornings our Soluble Sirrup, and give him good meates, and let him drink Wine, becau≈øe it cannot hurt in any wi≈øe, for it cannot putrife in the body: For the ≈øirrup doth evacuate every day the corruption: and when the blood is alterated of that putrifaction, it goeth to the veines, and ≈øo di≈øper≈øeth through the whole body. It would be good to ≈øet on boxing gla≈ø≈øes to take away blood, and al≈øo to u≈øe drying unctions, as our Bal≈øaemo artificato, and Oyle of Turpentine and Wax, and thus doing (if the Patient be not called of God) thou ≈øhalt helpe him within ≈øhort ≈øpace. And this is the true ≈øecret to u≈øe for
that Fever, which I have revealed unto the world, that every one might have it at their plea≈øure.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. A great Secret that helpeth the continuall Fever.
div.p: THe≈øe Fevers that are not accidentall, that is, not cau≈øed of a wound or impo≈øthume, or other kind of infirmitie apparent, are cau≈øed of a certaine humour between the skin and the fle≈øh, which would have exhalation: as you may ≈øee by experience in this kind of Fever, how that ≈øweats and boxing is very appropriate to their ≈øolution. And in this ca≈øe I will ≈øhew thee a great remedie, with which after convenient purging thou maye≈øt helpe in manner all tho≈øe kindes of Fevers. And this is the remedie: Take Oippa ofir, the which is a ≈øimple well known to all the world, take of that hearb a ≈ømall quantity, and ≈øtampe it a little, and lay it upon the wri≈øt, and bind it hard, and there let it lye untill it have made a bli≈øter full of water, which you ≈øhall break, and there will come forth great abundance of water, and by that place the Fever ≈øhall be di≈ø≈øolved. And the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it evacuateth that humour which engendereth the accident: then the cau≈øe being removed, the effect will cea≈øe, and the Patient ≈øhall be whole.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Of the Fever Tertian.
div.p:
THe Fever Tertian doth not continue in one manner, but cometh and goeth, and is cau≈øed of chollerick humours: for a≈ø≈øone as the fit cometh it moveth choller, and in many it provoketh vomite. There are two ≈øorts of tho≈øe Fevers, The one cometh with an accident, fir≈øt cold, and then hot: and the other ≈øort cometh alwaies hot, when the accident cometh: and ≈øometimes that accident cometh twice a day, and that is called a double Tertian, which is hard to helpe, becau≈øe letting blood, the diet, and purging of the body are all hurtful and
contrary to that di≈øea≈øe, therefore I will open to thee a ≈øecret wherewith thou ≈øhalt help them. Thou ≈øhalt give him three hours before the fit í ≈øs. of Eleborus niger in powder, with ‚Ñ•. i. of Mel Ro≈øarum: and after it drink ‚Ñ•. i. of common water, and this you ≈øhall take twi≈øe, and then u≈øe this potion ten dayes every morning. Take Julep of Violets ‚Ñ•. i. fine Aqua vitae ‚Ñ•. di. Oyle of Sulphur, that is perfect iiii. graines, and mixe them together, this mundifieth the ≈øtomack, and purgeth by urine, and provoketh ≈øweate, and warmeth the blood: which effects are nece≈ø≈øary to the ≈øolution of that Fever, giving you great charge that you keep no ≈øtraight diet in any wi≈øe, becau≈øe it weakneth the ≈øtomack, cooleth the blood, and hindereth nature, ≈øo that the Patient can ≈øcarce be helped. But with our order thou ≈øhalt help the mo≈øt part of that Fever.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Fever of Repre≈ø≈øion.
div.p: THis Fever is an alteration of the blood, which is cau≈øed of being over hot, and then cold and this is called a Fever propter accidens, and is not holp as the other Fevers are: for thou ≈øhalt help onely the Repre≈ø≈øion, and the Fever will go away without any other help. Thou ≈øhalt give the Patient of our Aromatico, í. ii. that being done, give him two Sirrups every day, the one in the morning, the other at night two houres after Supper, as hot as you may ≈øuffer to drink, and the≈øe are the Sirrups. Take Sirrup of Quinces, Stecados, Mel Ro≈øarum, ana, ‚Ñ•. i. new Mu≈øte boyled, ‚Ñ•. vi. and in the mean time while you take this Sirrup, it were nece≈ø≈øary to make a moi≈øt bath with hearbs, as Nettles, Mallowes, Egrimonie, Carduus Benedictus, Ro≈øemary, Origanum, and Calamint, ana lb. iii. Commin, Anni≈øeede, Coliander, Sileri montani, ana lb. i. then boyle all tho≈øe in a great Kettle with water, and then let the Patient ≈øit over the fume, and cover him with clothes untill he ≈øweat. And thus you ≈øhall do three times one day after another: and thou ≈øhalt helpe him perfectly, as I have had experience.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of the Fever Hectick.
div.p: THis Fever is a vi≈øcous and putrified humour in the ≈øtomack and lunges, the which is cau≈øed of a debility and weakne≈ø≈øe of nature that cannot dige≈øt the offen≈øive humours. There are divers ≈øorts of this Fever, neverthele≈ø≈øe they are all evill to be holpt, and are counted uncurable. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee ≈øome excellent remedie very whol≈øom, that may plea≈øure them, although they are nigh their death. The fir≈øt medicine that ≈øhall do them good, is our Electuario angellica, of which you ≈øhall give halfe an ounce in the morning fa≈øting, for this pre≈øently joyneth unto the ≈øtomack, and draweth to it all the offen≈øive humours, and carrieth them forth by vomit and ≈øeege, and ≈øo leaveth the ≈øtomack ea≈øed and clean, that the Patient thinketh him≈øelf whole: But yet the ≈øtomack beginneth againe to fill with a great ≈øuffocation, that will not let the Patient take re≈øt, ≈øo that this medicine may well ea≈øe them, but not helpe them quite. Al≈øo our Elixar vitae doth much good in this di≈øea≈øe, and al≈øo our Balme artificial: if you annoint the ≈øtomack therewith at night when you go to bed. Al≈øo u≈øe our di≈øtillation for the Hectick: the≈øe may all helpe a little but not cure. The Fever Hectick may come al≈øo of a Catarre, of the Pox, and ≈øuch like cau≈øes, and then they require medicines according to the cau≈øe: as if the Fever be cau≈øed of a Catarre, let them u≈øe our Magno liquore to drink, the do≈øe is one ounce at a time, with halfe an ounce of Mel Ro≈øarum, and the≈øe u≈øe for a moneth at the lea≈øt. And if it be cau≈øed of the Pox, let him take Sar≈øaparilla, or Lignum vitae, Pillole Aquilone, or ≈øuch like that will helpe the Pox: and thus doing, the cure will have good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: but when it is cau≈øed of debility of Nature (as is ≈øaid before) they ≈øpit blood untill the end.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. A new order wherewith thou mai≈øt cure and help the mo≈øt part of the Fever Hectick.
div.p:
MAny have thought that the Fever Hectick is altogether de≈øperate and uncurable, and that by no meanes it might be re≈øolved: But becau≈øe it is cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry accidents, I ≈øay that many kindes may be helped and cured: For I find it may come of infinite cau≈øes, as afore≈øaid. There is one kind that cometh through the weakne≈ø≈øe of nature it ≈øelf, and that beginneth to de≈øtroy the Lunges, and that kind I find to be incurable, becau≈øe it is cau≈øed of the evill nature of the man, and not through any accident, and in that ca≈øe I beleeve it cannot be di≈ø≈øolved by any meanes. Al≈øo there are many other Hecticks cau≈øed of the French-Pox, of which I have ≈øeen and cured an infinite, and they are ea≈øie to cure: For curing the Pox, the Fever will be di≈ø≈øolved. There is another kind that dependeth of a ≈øalt humour, and ≈øome other of a Catarre, and of many other things: Therefore if thou wilt help the ≈øaid Fever, it were nece≈ø≈øary to know the true cau≈øe whereof it dependeth, the which in my judgement is hard to be known, if that the Patient him≈øelf do not tell it: and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for the Phy≈øitian to examin them well, and to enquire whether they have had any kind or ≈øpice of the Mal France≈øe before, whereof the ≈øaid Fever might have his original: and ≈øo doing, he with his judgement may be re≈øolved of the nature of that infirmity: and if it chaunce that the ≈øaid Fever had his originall of the Pox, the Phi≈øician may re≈øolve it with medicines appropriate for that di≈øea≈øe, with purging him ≈øtrongly, and giving him Lignum Sanctum, or Sal≈øa pariglia, and al≈øo perfume him with Olibanum Sinaber and Mirrha, ana: and ≈øo by the help of God, and meanes of the≈øe medicines thou ≈øhalt help them all, or at lea≈øt the mo≈øt part of that kind of Fever Hectick. But if the Phi≈øician find that kind of Fever to be cau≈øed of a Catarre, then u≈øe the medicines that help the Catarre, and ≈øo the Fever ≈øhall be whole. But when he
findeth it to be of the weakne≈ø≈øe of Nature, in that ca≈øe there is no help that is ≈øure. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I have cured ≈øome of them with great difficultie, and with Medicines of great efficacie: And that was with giving them every morning one drachm of good Sope in tablets according to our invention, and that they u≈øed for a moneth together: the which Sope hath vertue to drie that abundance of ≈øpittle, and to heal the Lungs ulcerated, and it al≈øo ≈øtrengthneth the Stomack marvellou≈øly: After that I cau≈øed them to u≈øe our di≈øtillation of a Hen for the Hectick, and this they did continually drink: Al≈øo I cau≈øed them to u≈øe our Balsamo artificiato to annoint therewith every night after Supper, the which is peircing, and comforteth and augmenteth naturall ≈øtrength, and comforteth much the infirmed: Al≈øo I cau≈øed them to u≈øe Aromatico Ro≈øato, the which comforteth the weak Stomack. And by this meanes I have help'd ≈øome of them as it well known.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of the Fever Quartane.
div.p:
THe Fever Quartane is a motion of a certain accident cold and hot, which is cau≈øed of melancholie humours corrupted and putrified, the which every third day doth cau≈øe that accident to come, and beginneth with great cold and continueth a good while, and then cometh hot. And this Quartane both the ancient Doctors, and the≈øe in our time doe count in a manner uncureable. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I that have ≈øought alwaies to help tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes which were counted uncurable, among≈øt the re≈øt have found the true and perfect cure for the Quartane Ague, and to di≈ø≈øolve the melancholie humours, which is done with three Medicines that are rare and marvellous to di≈ø≈øolve any Quartane. The fir≈øt is, Mercurie Precipitate without corro≈øive, giving thereof ten grains, with half an ounce of Sugar Ro≈øate, and that day eat little meat; that being done, take a pound of Iva Artetica, and boil it in eight pound of white wine, and common Honey one pound, untill a
third part be con≈øumed, and of that drink morning and evening ≈øix ounces warm one hour after ≈øupper: And in the mean time annoint every night his Reins with our Balsamum artificiall. Thus doing thou ≈øhalt help any Quartane. I have al≈øo found other rare waies to cure this Fever Quartane, as hereafter followeth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. The Order to help the Fever Quartane of all ≈øorts, in ≈øhort time.
div.p:
THe Fever Quartane is cau≈øed of a melancholie humour as afore≈øaid, with a continuall di≈øtillation of the head, de≈øcending to the ≈øtomack, and augmenting the evill di≈øpo≈øition of the body; and by rea≈øon of that di≈øtillation, provoketh much ≈øweat when the accident of the Fever cometh: And likewi≈øe that di≈øtillation cau≈øeth ≈øuch cold in the Marrow of the Reins and Back, and an infinite of other di≈øorders which trouble the bodie greatly. But to avoid all the≈øe inconveniences, and to di≈ø≈øolve wholly that accident of the Quartane according to our order, becau≈øe I have helped more then any Phy≈øitian of our time. I will ≈øhew thee how with the≈øe Remedies following thou ≈øhalt help them, though not all, yet the greater part truly mo≈øt miraculou≈øly, and the Order to di≈ø≈øolve it is thus. You ≈øhall give the Patient a do≈øe of our Aromatico in the morning to eat, and drink thereon two or three ounces of good wine, and fa≈øt thereon ≈øix hours, and this Medicine is mo≈øt convenient the day of the fit, becau≈øe the infirmitie removeth great quantitie of humours, and the medicine evacuateth them; and thus giving it three times in the day of the fit, it will work a great operation. But if the Fever be in a per≈øon of melancholie complexion, then it is where it would be; for you may ≈øee that in a melancholie per≈øon, the Fever hath more force, then in any other complexion, which proveth, that the Fever, and that complexion are mo≈øt like: But in that ca≈øe you ≈øhall cure them in this Order: You ≈øhall give him ten or fifteen daies out
Sirrup again≈øt the melancholie humour, which is written in this Book, which you ≈øhall take two hours before day hot, and then ≈øleep one ≈øleep thereon, and thus doe every morning, and every night annoint all the parts of the body with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and he ≈øhall be holpen. But if it happen that this doth not cure him, let not to give him this remedie, which mo≈øt ≈øurely (God willing) will help him, and that remedie is our Aqua Bal≈øami, of which he ≈øhall take every morning two Drachms fa≈øting, and ≈øo continue untill the Fever be gone quite: ≈øo that of force u≈øing all the afore≈øaid remedies, the Fever mu≈øt needs depart. And the rea≈øon is this, that our Aromatico evacuateth the ≈øtomack of all impediments by vomit, and letteth the de≈øcen≈øion of the head, which cau≈øeth the accident. Our Syrrup evacuateth the melancholie humour, and di≈ø≈øolveth it by his proper qualitie. Our Bal≈øamo the which is ≈øubtile and penetravive drieth and comforteth the place offended, in ≈øuch order, that it ca≈øteth forth all the matter that may offend Nature. Our Aqua bal≈øami al≈øo being drunke, doth dry the evill humours, and augment ≈øtrength, in ≈øo much that it quite extingui≈øheth the ≈øaid Quartane. And this may be u≈øed in all manner of per≈øons, and in all times of the year without any doubt of inconvenience: and it is a new remedie that never was ≈øet out before of the Ancients, which I have u≈øed to the great profit of the Patients.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Another di≈øcour≈øe a marvellous ≈øecret again≈øt the ≈øaid Quartane.
div.p:
THe Fever Quartan is cau≈øed of melancholie humours, which hath his fit coming every third day, fir≈øt cold with great thir≈øt, and then cometh the heat, which remaineth with ≈øome longer then with other ≈øome, and the cau≈øe, hereof is hard to be known. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I ≈øeeking out continually naturall things, and the qualitie of the accidents, I doe find that this Fever beginneth alwaies in ≈øome particular
place, as in the head with a certain pain round about it, or in the no≈øe and ear, or in the Reins and Legs: And therefore he that can find out the place where fir≈øt beginneth the accident, may ea≈øily help them, becau≈øe the Fever is di≈ø≈øolved with two things onely, that is, exhalation and ex≈øication, and herein con≈øi≈øteth the ≈øecret. The order to make the Exhalation ≈øhall be thus: Make a Cerot of Frankincen≈øe, Pitch, Wax, Turpentine, Myrrh and Aloes, upon the which Cerot you ≈øhall put the powder of Cantharides, and then lay it upon the place where they feel the Fever come fir≈øt, that is on the particular part where the accident cometh, and this you ≈øhall change twice, except the fir≈øt day of the Fever. And to make the ex≈øication, give him every day in the morning to drinke, ‚Ñ•. di. of our Aqua bal≈øami for twelve daies, and with the Bal≈øamo artificiato annoint every night his Stomack and Reins, and ≈øo he ≈øhall be helped, giving you charge al≈øo that before you u≈øe the≈øe Medicines, that he take three times our Aromatico, and ≈øo he ≈øhall be quite helped.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. A ≈øecret to help all Fevers in their beginning.
div.p:
VVHen the Fevers are new begun or taken, and that the putrefaction is not yet confirmed, then may it be helped with great ea≈øe, but after they have taken their beginning, they are hardly helped. Therefore when the Fever is new begun, you ≈øhall give them í ii of our Aromatico fa≈øting in the morning: and the next day about the ≈øame hour you ≈øhall give them ‚Ñ•. i. of our ∆≤egitabile Sirrup: and the third day you ≈øhall give them four Drachms of our Electuario angelica with broth, the which taketh away the Fever altogether. And this operation intendeth onely to the continuall Fever, Quotidian, Tertian, and putrified or pe≈øtilentiall, but not to the accidentall, or Hectick, nor Quartane: For the≈øe three kinds are much differing from the re≈øt, becau≈øe the accidentall is cau≈øed of another infirmitie anterior or going before. The Fever Hectick
is cau≈øed of weakne≈ø≈øe of nature, and the Quartane is cau≈øed of great quantitie of melancholicke humours, and they are cured by contrary meanes unto the fir≈øt. The accidentall are cured with helping the principall infirmitie: The Hectick is cured by helping of Nature, and pre≈øerving the Liver and Lungs from putrefaction: The Quartane is cured with Vomits, Unctions, Cerottes, and drying drinks, and the≈øe are great ≈øecrets to be known: For in this Chapter con≈øi≈øteth a great part of Phy≈øick, and Chirurgery if you con≈øider well thereon.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIIII. A Secret of one Simple that helpeth in manner all Fevers.
div.p: THere are an infinite of medicines that di≈ø≈øolve the Fever, but above all other this ≈øeemeth to me of great authority, becau≈øe it helpeth it with ≈øuch ea≈øe, that it is to be wondered at. With this remedie through the Divine goodne≈øs, I have cured a great number, and the Secret is this. You ≈øhall gather in the Moneth of August a certain hearb, which the Italians do call Oreula, which you ≈øhall drie and make into powder, of the which you ≈øhall give the ≈øick as much as will lie upon a ≈øixpence, with water or wine, and give it warm in the morning, and fa≈øt thereon three or four houres, and thus doing, the Patient ≈øhall be helped with great ea≈øe, and in ≈øhort time: for this is a great ≈øecret which may be u≈øed in all times and in every occa≈øion, and alwaies it worketh an operation in one manner.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Of the Gout.
div.p:
THe Gout which cometh to men, is a di≈øtemperature and alteration, which is cau≈øed of corrupt and undige≈øted humours, and al≈øo of feeding on meats that nouri≈øh much, and then to u≈øe no exerci≈øe, as you may ≈øee by the mo≈øt part of them that be troubled with that di≈øea≈øe. Al≈øo this di≈øea≈øe, both of the old and new Doctors hath been counted uncurable,
as it is known to every one: But yet I, which have done nothing el≈øe but ≈øought out the nature and qualitie of things, have found divers inventions in ≈øundry Arts, as thou maye≈øt read in my Caprici Medicinali, and ≈øo among≈øt the re≈øt, I have found (through the help of God) the true and perfect Secret to help the Gout, ≈øo that it ≈øhall never come again: Of which di≈øea≈øe I have cured a great number in divers Cities of the world, as in Palermo, in Sicilia, in Me≈øsina, and in divers places of Calabria, in Naples, in Rome, and in Venice, as it is well known unto the mo≈øt part of the Inhabitants of tho≈øe Cities.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. A Note concerning the Cure of the Gout, taken out of a Letter which this Authour wrote unto a certain noble Seigniour, the Duke of ∆≤rbine.
div.p:
FIrs;t you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the Gout of what kind ≈øoever it be, either hot or cold, or of any other temperature, they all come of one onely cau≈øe, although they work divers Effects, which Effects come through the complexions of them that have that infirmitie: As for example, to ≈øhew it more plainly, you may ≈øee that in fat men, the Gout cometh alwaies with inflammation and redne≈øs and great pain: In lean per≈øons it cometh alwaies with pains, but with le≈ø≈øe inflamation. In cholerick and melancholie per≈øons, it cometh with tumours, and that is Nodo≈øa. And the cau≈øe of this infirmitie is, of an evill qualitie ingendered in the ≈øtomack, in the Liver, and in the blood: And the cure thereof, is to ea≈øe the ≈øtomack of that evill, and to purge the Liver and the blood, and to mittigate the pain: All which thou maye≈øt doe with the≈øe three Remedies following, viz. our Pillole Magi≈øtrale, our ∆≤nction for the Gout, and our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutivo: for the Pills doe di≈øcharge the ≈øtomack, and our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutivo purgeth the Liver and the blood, and our ∆≤nction taketh away the pain, for if you remedie the cau≈øe which is onely one, the effect will cea≈øe. As concerning the Gout you ≈øhall cure it in this Order: Fir≈øt, when you feel the pain begin to come, you ≈øhall take two do≈øes of tho≈øe Pills in the morning fa≈øting, one day
after another, or if you will, re≈øt a day or two according to your ≈øtrength, that being done, you ≈øhall take every morning í. ii. of our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutivo in half a Porringer full of the broth of Veal, and a little Sugar, and this take five hours before meat; and keep no ≈øtreight Diet, but eat rea≈øonably, and every night after Supper annoint the grief with our Unction for the Gout, and thus through the help of God, and the vertue of the≈øe Medicines, the Gout ≈øhall be cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. Another Di≈øcour≈øe upon the ≈øame infirmitie of the Gout, and the Order to cure it, taken out of his Book called, The≈øaurro della Vita Humana.
div.p:
ALthough the wi≈øe & learned of the world, have alwaies beleeved that the Gout is of divers kinds, yet they have all been deceived; for that infirmitie is one onely, and cometh of one onely cau≈øe, although in ≈øome it come in manner of Phlegmone, and in ≈øome other like Ri≈øipilla, and in other Nodo≈øa, and in other with pain without alteration, and in ≈øome other in divers manners; all which is cau≈øed through the diver≈øitie of complexions, for that one man is flegmatick, the other ≈øanguine, the other cholerick, and the other adu≈øt, and thus by the≈øe means, many have thought the Gout to have been of divers kindes, whereas indeed it is onely one, and is cured with one onely order, and di≈ø≈øolved altogether for ever; for that infirmitie is cau≈øed of no other then of rotten humours cau≈øed of indige≈øtion, and to ≈øay truth, we ≈øee that the ≈øaid infirmity never commeth in manner, but unto tho≈øe per≈øons that feed well on meats of great nouri≈øhment, which for want of exerci≈øe, that Nature might dige≈øt it, they wanting naturall heat, cannot have their orderly dige≈øtion, and for that cau≈øe the humours doe ingro≈ø≈ø≈øe out of mea≈øure, and ingender that infirmitie, and then Nature that alwaies ≈øeeketh to ea≈øe her ≈øelf of that which offendeth her, driveth forth that humour unto the extream parts, as the hands, and feet, or other particular
parts, and this is the Gout: And the≈øe humours many times are cau≈øe of Mal france≈øe, and this is all the ≈øecret. He therefore that is adverti≈øed by me, ≈øhall be mo≈øt cunning in curing of it.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. What order mu≈øt be u≈øed in curing of the ≈øaid Gout.
div.p: SEeing the Gout (as I ≈øaid before) are gro≈ø≈øe humours undige≈øted coming of the afore≈øaid cau≈øe, it were mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, if thou wilt cure them to do three operations. The fir≈øt of them is Phlebothomie, which mu≈øt be done under the tongue, cutting overthwart one of tho≈øe two veines: For that Phlebothomie evacuateth the ≈øtomocall humours that are cau≈øe of that corruption. The ≈øecond operation that is to be done, is to a≈ø≈øubtiliate the gro≈øs and rotten humours, and to evacuate them quite. The third operation that is to be done, is to pre≈øerve nature in good temperature, and to help the dige≈øtion, and thus doing, the ≈øaid infirmity ≈øhall be extincted. If therefore thou wilt helpe the Gout, and after they are helped, keep the Patient in good temperature and pro≈øperity of life, it were nece≈ø≈øary to do the≈øe three operations. After the fir≈øt is done, as I have ≈øaid, it were needfull to come to the ≈øecond, which is to a≈ø≈øubtiliate the gro≈øs humours, which will be done with four remedies. The fir≈øt of them is our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, which ≈øubtiliateth the humours, and evacuateth them downwards. The ≈øecond remedie is our Electuario angelica, which evacuateth the humours hanging in all parts, and leaveth nature ≈øo ea≈øed, that it may well prevaile. The third remedie is a Fomentation, which drieth up the humidity of the head and ≈øtomack, and by meanes of that operation the di≈øea≈øe ≈øhall remaine extincted. The fourth and la≈øt remedie is our Bal≈øamo again≈øt the paines, with which you ≈øhall annoint upon the place grieved, for it mittigateth the paines greatly. And thus with the≈øe four remedies thou ≈øhalt help the Gout perfectly, as I have often times done in Venice, and at Rome, and in divers other places of Italy, well known there unto all men.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX. The Order to pre≈øerve a man from the Gout, when he is once helped.
div.p: AFter that a man through the divine goodne≈ø≈øe of God ≈øhall be helped of the Gout, he may if he will pre≈øerve him≈øelf in health, with the≈øe three noble Remedies. The fir≈øt of them is our Vegitable Quinte≈ø≈øence, the which doth cau≈øe good dige≈øtion, warmeth the ≈øtomack, and defendeth it from corruption, by which Effects it will return Nature in manner as it was in youth, and it pre≈øerveth the ≈øight and the hearing, and divers good operations which are all nece≈ø≈øarie. The ≈øecond Remedie is our Oleo incompo≈øtibile, with which you ≈øhall annoint the ≈øtomack, and that will cau≈øe dige≈øtion, comfort the heart, provoke ≈øleep, and keep the ≈øtomack, that therein ≈øhall breed no evill qualitie of humours. The third Remedie is, our Pillolae aquilonae, which doth evacuate the humour hanging, alwaies when it ingendereth in the ≈øtomack, they clean≈øe the head, and are by their nature again≈øt all ≈øorts of pains. And thus with the≈øe three Medicines, every one may pre≈øerve him≈øelf from that infirmitie, as it is daily proved, and ≈øeen in Venice, and in divers other places in Italy.

div.head: CHAP. XL. The cure of a certain Gentleman that was troubled with the Gout, and a great Stitch in his ≈øide.
div.p:
THe Cure of this man was with the≈øe five Remedies following, that is, with our Aromatico, Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, Pillole angelica, Oleo incompo≈øtibile, and Quinta e≈ø≈øenti Vegitabile: For you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that our Aromatico taketh away the pains of the Stomack, ≈øo that the other Medicines may work their operations the better. Our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, taketh away the cau≈øe of the infirmity, and the Pills take away the evill qualitie. The Unction taketh away the pain: And the Vegitabile Quinte≈ø≈øence, pre≈øerveth them that
it commeth not again. The Dia Aromatico mu≈øt be taken in the morning fa≈øting, the do≈øe is í. ii. at once. The Quinta-e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva you ≈øhall take with broth of a Capon and Sugar fa≈øting, without any ob≈øervations, the do≈øe is two or three drachms at a time. Our Pillole Angelica you ≈øhall take two hours before ≈øupper, the do≈øe is from í i. to í. ii. The Unction you ≈øhall annoint after Supper upon the ≈øore places, ≈øo often untill the pain be gone. Our Vegitabile Quinte≈ø≈øence you ≈øhall drinke every morning half an ounce, and thus continuing thou ≈øhalt be perfectly whole by Gods help.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon the Sciatica, and his remedie.
div.p:
THe Sciatica is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it is upon the bone which is called Scio, and of that it taketh the name Sciatica, the which is cau≈øed of an evill qualitie in the Stomack and Liver, the which you may ≈øee by the cure; for if ye cure the Stomack, and help the Liver, the Sciatica will cea≈øe, and by this means thou maye≈øt ≈øee whether I ≈øay the truth or no.
