Seeing then that the Sciatica is cau≈øed as is ≈øaid before, ye ≈øhall under≈øtand that it is ≈øo cau≈øed, by rea≈øon that the ≈øtomack cannot well dige≈øt that which it ≈øhould, and ≈øo it cau≈øeth crude and undige≈øted humours, of the which Nature would be di≈øcharged, he ca≈øteth them forth of the ≈øtomack, and having no other way to come forth of the Stomack but by the ordinary waies, they doe pa≈ø≈øe, and of force they mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe by tho≈øe powers that pa≈ø≈øe by the Liver, and ≈øo the Liver which is able both to re≈øolve the good and the evill qualitie, remaineth ≈øtill infected of that indi≈øpo≈øition, and not being able to dige≈øt them according unto the order of Nature, they ingro≈øs and become maligne, and then Nature the which with all indu≈øtrie would di≈øcharge him≈øelf of that burthen, ≈øending them to the higher parts, ≈øendeth them downwards, and when they come unto Scio, where they mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe with difficultie by certain ≈ømall mu≈øcles, they ingro≈ø≈øe in that place, and cau≈øe inflamation and pain, the
which Inflamation or ≈øwelling, after the bodie is well purged, is re≈øolved with Ve≈øicatores Vento≈øos, and attractive Cerots and ≈øuch like things. Al≈øo attractive Gli≈øters are mo≈øt whol≈øome, becau≈øe they di≈øcharge the humour in the lower parts, and comfort the Sciatica. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, ye ≈øhall under≈øtand that there are certain and true appropriate Medicines to re≈øolve it with brevity, the which are the≈øe that follow. Fir≈øt, when the Patient is in mo≈øt extream pain, let him blood under the tongue, the which is ≈øuch a ≈øingular remedie, that it cau≈øeth the world to wonder thereat: after that purge him with our Soluble Sirrup, ≈øix or ≈øeven daies, that being done, take away the water which cau≈øeth the pain, then comfort the Patient with the Oil that is ≈øeparated from the flower of flowers, and di≈øtilled in a Retort, then all this being done, the Patient ≈øhall remain helped to thy great honour. And therefore he that will cure the Sciatica, it were nece≈ø≈øary that hee con≈øider well of the nature and qualitie of the infirmitie, and when they are ≈øatisfied to be the Sciatica, in that ca≈øe cure them according to this our Order, the which by the grace of God, and vertue of the≈øe Medicines, they ≈øhall remain helped of that indi≈øpo≈øition, for this is a great Secret.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. Of the Pains of the Mother.
div.p:
THe Pains of the Mother which women are troubled withall, is an alteration in the Matrix, that may come of divers cau≈øes, as of cold, of moi≈øtne≈øs, of dryne≈øs, of melancholike humours, of flegmatick, and of cholerick, the which is to be proved divers waies. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee the Secret to cure it generally, and the order is thus. You ≈øhall give the Patient a do≈øe of Pillolae Aquilonae fa≈øting, and ≈øleeping thereon one ≈øleep, for the≈øe Pills doe purge the Matrix, then take Electuario Angelica half an ounce, which purgeth the blood and choller: That being done, take Cantharides in powder ‚Ñà i. Galingale, and the roots of Mercury, ana. di. ‚Ñà. mix them altogether, and put it into a little piece of Sarcenet,
and binde it like a button, and put it into the Matrix as high as you can, and there let it remain four and twentie hours without moving of it, for it purgeth divinely; and herewith thou mai≈øt cure any great impediment in the Matrix: That being done, they ≈øhall u≈øe our Sirrup again≈øt the pains of the Mother, the which comforteth and purgeth all humours in the bodie that offend the Mother: And this is a great ≈øecret which was found out by me. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that who≈øoever would know the truth of this di≈øea≈øe, it were nece≈ø≈øarie for him to be expert in Philo≈øophie, becau≈øe it is an operation of naturall things, the which cannot be well under≈øtood without great knowledge in naturall Philo≈øophie.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. Of the pains in the head.
div.p:
THe pain in the Head is a di≈øea≈øe of the brains, which is cau≈øed of putrified humours in the ≈øtomack, the which is like unto a pot that boileth, cau≈øing the vapours to a≈øcend, which if they be evill, the fume is evill to the ta≈øte and ≈ømell; but if there boil any good thing therein, the fumes are plea≈øant both to the ≈ømell and ta≈øte. And ≈øo likewi≈øe our ≈øtomack being filled with good juyce, filleth the brain with good fumes; but being filled with evill corrupt humours, it hurteth the brain, and cau≈øeth pains of the head. The like pains of the head may come of alteration of the blood, and to helpe that accident, you mu≈øt fir≈øt remove the cau≈øe principall, which is done with purging, and evacuating of the ≈øtomack of tho≈øe putrified humours; which thou ≈øhalt do with our Aromatico, giving it to the Patient two or thre times, every five daies once. The do≈øe is í ii. and then the pain will cea≈øe, of what cau≈øe ≈øoever it doe come; this done, take the juyce of a Beet root one ounce, Oil of bitter Almonds one drachm; mix them well together, and ≈ønuffe it up into the no≈øe every morning untill it come into the mouth, for this doth purge the head marvellou≈øly; this being done, it would bee
" good to take our Soluble Sirrup four or five mornings cold, and ≈øo the Patient ≈øhall be holpen.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV. Of deafne≈øs of the Ears.
div.p: DEafne≈ø≈øe in the Ears doe proceed of divers cau≈øes, as of a Catarre, cold, and humiditie of the head. But of what cau≈øe ≈øoever it come, I will ≈øhew thee a true ≈øecret to cure them quickly. Fir≈øt purge them eight or ten daies with our Sirupo Magi≈øtrale, and then take our Pillole Aquilone, three times, and then perfume them five mornings with this: Take Synabar ‚Ñ•. i. Olibanum, and Myrrh, ana one ≈øcruple, mixe them and divide it in five parts, the which you ≈øhall occupie at five times, ≈øtanding over them with your mouth open, that the fume may enter in, for it drieth and re≈øolveth the evill humours in the head that himder the hearing; and thus doing thou ≈øhalt be helpt. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it would be good to put the fat of a ≈øilver Eel into the ear, which hath a principall vertue to comfort the hearing. Al≈øo our Aqua bal≈øami being put into the ear, comforteth the ≈øight and hearing marvellou≈øly, and all impediments in the head, and evill humours it de≈øtroyeth through his qualitie and nature, and augmenteth the good, in ≈øuch order that u≈øing of it thou ≈øhalt ≈øee great marvells: for the≈øe are the true ≈øecrets for that di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XLV. Of the Infirmities of eies, and their cau≈øes and cures.
div.p:
THe Infirmities of the Eies cometh of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes, of the which I will make mention, e≈øpecially of tho≈øe that are of mo≈øt importance, and mo≈øt dangerous to hurt the ≈øight. There is one that is called in Italian Razoni, and that is cau≈øed of the heat of the blood, and his effects are certain ≈ømall wheals that run round about the eye-lids, and this Infirmitie is of ≈ømall importance, for onely with linament
of Tutia they may be healed, annointing them three or four times. There is another kind of infirmitie in the eyes that cometh to many, and is cau≈øed of moi≈øture and heat in the head, and that is a redne≈øs with watering and great burning: And although this be trouble≈øome, yet it is not dangerous to heal. For with purging the head and bodie, and with Boxing gla≈ø≈øes, and with certain Unctions appropriate they ≈øhall remain whole. There is another kinde of infirmitie in the eie, and that is when the ball of the eie waxeth out of mea≈øure in greatne≈ø≈øe, and this is called Dilatatio pupillae, the which is very hard to heal. For my part I never ≈øaw but one remedie that did pre≈øerve it, and that is our Bal≈øamo Artificiato, of the which you ≈øhall put every night one drop into the eie, and it will doe thee great plea≈øure, becau≈øe it is temperate hot, and hath a penetrative vertue and re≈øolutative, by the which meanes it doth hinder the relaxation, and pre≈øerveth the eie. There is yet another ≈øort of infirmitie that cau≈øeth the eie to be full of pain, and cometh all thick and filthy, and blindeth it, and this indi≈øpo≈øition is cau≈øed of Morbo Gallico; and although it ≈øeem foul and uncurable: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it is ea≈øie to be cured if you help the principall cau≈øe, and fume the head with Cinabar, Myrrh, and Olibanum, they ≈øhall be quickly helped. There is another infirmitie that cometh in the eie, the which is a cloud that ingendereth in the point of the eie upon the ball, and hindereth the ≈øight, and that is ea≈øie to be helped, for if you drop therein one drop of our Balm twentie or thirtie daies together, it will re≈øolve it throughly. There are divers other infirmities which doe trouble the eyes, the which I will let pa≈ø≈øe till another time.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI. Of the pains in the Teeth.
div.p:
THe pain of the teeth is an accidentall di≈øea≈øe, which cometh of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes, of the which cau≈øes, I will ≈øhew the chiefe≈øt. It cometh ≈øometimes of a Rheum in the head, or of a Catarr, or of humiditie in the
head, and divers other wayes. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, let it come which way it will, it proceedeth of the head and ≈øtomack, the wihch ≈øendeth up vapours, and then fall down again, and cau≈øe that pain, and the remedie is this: Fir≈øt, give them our Magi≈øtrale Syrupo five or ≈øix daies, the which purgeth the blood, and evacuateth the bodie; that being done, take our Electuario angelico, three times according to the receipt, for this evacuateth the ≈øtomack and purgeth the head; and then take our Aqua reale, and hold it in thy mouth a Pater-no≈øter while, and then ≈øpit it forth again, and with this order thou ≈øhalt help all manner of pains in the teeth, except they bee rotten ≈øtumps; and then the be≈øt way is to take them forth with an In≈øtrument: but if thou wilt not take them forth and ea≈øe the pain, thou maye≈øt touch them with Aqua fortis untill the marrow be mortified? that being done, you ≈øhall hold our Aqua bal≈øami two or three times in your mouth in a day, untill the pain bee gone, and ≈øo with this order thou maye≈øt keep them without pain. Al≈øo I will ≈øhew thee another ea≈øie way. Take Henbane ≈øeed, and mix it with white Waxe, then ca≈øt it on the coals, and hold thy mouth over it to receive the fume, and then thy pain will cea≈øe if they be rotten teeth; and this it doth by ≈øtupefaction. Al≈øo it will be good to hold in thy mouth Ma≈øtick, Pellitorie, and Allom, after ye have purged, for this draweth down the matter.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII. Of a ≈øtinking breath.
div.p:
THe ≈øtinking breath is a putrefaction the which is cau≈øed of the ≈øtomack, being corrupted and foul, as you may ≈øee by experience of tho≈øe that have that infirmitie, and the remedie is this. You ≈øhall give them of our Aromatico í. ii. fa≈øting, every third day for three times, and then u≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence for a moneth continually; The do≈øe is í. i. every morning, and after ≈øupper two houres, for this comforteth the ≈øtomack and the heart, and taketh away the ≈øtinking: That being done, take five or ≈øix mornings together, every morning
f oyle of Turpentine one ≈øcruple with white Wine, and ≈øo they ≈øhall remain helped.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII. Of ≈øpitting of blood.
div.p:
THe ≈øpitting of blood is an alteration of blood in the veins, which alteration is ≈øo much, that Nature provoketh it to the ≈øtomack, from whence it had his Originall, and doth not come of a vein broken as many have ≈øaid, as thou mai≈øt well ≈øee the truth; for if the vein were broke, the blood would come forth at one time or in≈øtant without any tarrying, and they would die quickly, the which cometh not by ≈øpitting of blood, for they ≈øpit none untill the alteration cometh: and this is cau≈øed of a kind of Fever that cometh inwardly, that ingendereth that alteration, and when his fit cometh, the blood doth alter, and the veins ≈øwell, and the blood doth come forth at the proper mouthes of the veins, and ≈øo they ≈øpit it forth; and when they ≈øpit blood, it is the beginning of the Fever Hectick. the which when it is confirmed, is uncurable and mortall: But if thou wilt take it at the beginning when they ≈øpit blood, it may be helped with ea≈øe, and that thou ≈øhalt doe with giving them three or four times of our Petra Philo≈øophale twelve grains, with halfe an ounce of Sugar Ro≈øate, every third day once; that being done, let him take every morning Oil of Vitriol iiii. grains, with Julep of Violets ‚Ñ•. i. becau≈øe there is no better medicine in the world that di≈øpo≈øeth the alteration of the blood, then our Petra Philo≈øophale, and the oil of Vitrial mittigateth the heat and extingui≈øheth the accident. You ≈øhall note, that this which I have written is not under≈øtood of many as I under≈øtand it. And likewi≈øe the Medicines to u≈øe in that ca≈øe hath not been put in practi≈øe of any man, and the cau≈øe is this. That ≈øince Phy≈øick hath been in u≈øe untill this time, the Phy≈øicians have not under≈øtood of other then the Theorick, and none they cured of practi≈øe and experience, and that is the cau≈øe that ≈øo few have found the truth. But I that continually doe travell in practi≈øe,
have found rare things, as I will ≈øet forth to the world hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. XLIX. Of di≈øea≈øes of the Liver.
div.p: THe ≈øickne≈ø≈øe of the Liver is cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry accidents of the bodie, as you may ≈øee by experience, when a man is never ≈øo little ≈øick, by and by the Liver is alterated, and doth no more work well, and that is becau≈øe the Liver is the receptacle of the blood and of the Gall, and the ma≈øter which ruleth and governeth our bodies, and di≈øtributeth the blood into the veins, and doth purifie it, ≈øeparating the ≈øharp and evill parts, and ≈øending it to a certain bladder, which we call the Gall; and when it is ≈øo full that it can receive no more, it runneth over, and ≈øo cau≈øeth the body to become yellow, and thereupon the Urine is yellow, and is ≈øo evill, that in ≈øhort time it dryeth that bodie, ≈øo that the Liver being di≈øpen≈øator both of the good and bad qualities of the humours, it cannot be but through the infirmities of the bodie. Al≈øo when the Liver is over hot and drie, it cau≈øeth the Patient to be lean and dry, and with great heat: and when the Liver is troubled with humiditie and cold, it cau≈øeth the Patient to become full of ≈øores and ≈øcabbs, and the≈øe are the effects that come of the Liver when it is di≈øtempered. But if thou wilt help it from that indi≈øpo≈øition, it were nece≈ø≈øarie to evacuate the body and ≈øtomack of ≈øuperfluous humours, which thou ≈øhalt do with our Soluble Sirrup, giving it eight or ten daies together cold, and then purge the Stomack with our Aromatico fa≈øting in the morning; that being done, you ≈øhall u≈øe remedies that help the Liver, which a ‚Ä¢ many, as Citrake, Liverwort, Scolopendria, Cycorie, and ≈øuch like; and ≈øo ob≈øerving this order thou ≈øhalt help them. For I have had an infinite of experience of it.

div.head: CHAP. L. Of di≈øea≈øes of the Lungs.
div.p:
THe infirmities of the Lungs are of two kindes, that is cold and moi≈øt, and hot and drie, the which infirmitie is cau≈øed of evill temperature of the body. You ≈øhall note, that when the Lungs is infected with cold and moi≈øt, it will ea≈øily turn to that kind of Hectick that cau≈øeth the Cough, and to ≈øpit matter at the mouth. But when it is grieved with heat and drine≈ø≈øe, it is in danger to turne to a Ti≈ø≈øick, the which di≈øea≈øe cau≈øeth a man to become lean and drie, and keepeth back his breath, and ≈øo the one with another they are mortall di≈øea≈øes, ≈øo that there can ≈øcarce be found any remedie; and therefore I will begin with the fir≈øt kind, and then with the ≈øecond, and then the third, and then with the fourth and la≈øt, for the which there is no redemption or hope of life. But for the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, there are a number of remedies that doe help, the which be the≈øe. Fir≈øt, give the Patient of the juyce of the Roots of blew Lillies, ‚Ñ• ii. with Mel Ro≈øarum, ‚Ñ•. i. in the morning fa≈øting, and that u≈øe three times, every third day once: That being done, let him u≈øe our Elixar vitae for thirtie or fortie daies together morning and evening; the do≈øe is í. ii. at a time, and al≈øo put therein every time half an ounce of our Magno liquore, and drinke it a little warme, for this is a perfect remedie, with which I have cured an infinite number in my daies. And of all the Medicines that ever I found, I never had any like this, becau≈øe the juyce of the Lilly-root hath vertue attractive that mundifieth the ≈øtomack, and the Elixar vitae comforteth and re≈øolveth all Ulcers in the Lungs, and the Magno liquore di≈ø≈øolveth the Catarr, and healeth the ≈øtomack, for I have proved it a number of times, as is ≈øaid before. I remember me that in the year of our Lord, 1557. I being in Rome cured a young man which was a Painter, that was in the hou≈øe of the Cardinall de Medici, the which had his Lungs ulcerated, and did ≈øpit great quantitie of blood, and had a great Catarr and Cough, and did ≈øpit al≈øo matter, in the which there was no hope of life. I cau≈øed him to
u≈øe the afore≈øaid remedies, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time he was helped, and not onely he, but a great number more at ≈øundry times.

div.head: CHAP. LI. Of the Spleen.
div.p: THe Spleen is never ≈øick but through other di≈øea≈øes, as you may ≈øee by experience, how that tho≈øe that have the Fever Quartane, for the mo≈øt part have their Spleen alterated and hard, and this proceedeth of evill temperature of the bodie and Liver, that cannot dige≈øt the humours, and ≈øo Nature ≈øendeth them forth in the weake≈øt parts that are mo≈øt apt to receive them. So that the Spleen is like a ≈øpunge, and very apt to receive that humiditie, that Nature cannot di≈ø≈øolve otherwi≈øe, and ≈øo by this rea≈øon it is mo≈øt apt to be ≈øick or di≈øea≈øed: therefore if thou wilt cure it, fir≈øt cure the di≈øea≈øe which cau≈øeth that alteration, for that being once helped, Nature of it ≈øelf will help the Spleen without any other Medicine, and therefore ≈øtrive not to help the Spleen with particular Medicines, for it is vain; but look what kinde of di≈øea≈øe the Patient is troubled with, and cure that, and then the Spleen will heal well enough. And this is the true way to cure the Spleen.

div.head: CHAP. LII. Of the Flux of the bodie.
div.p:
THe Flux of the bodie is a di≈øtemperature of the guts and ≈øtomack, which is cau≈øed al≈øo of an evill di≈øpo≈øition in the Stomack, as well as of all other interiours, and is very trouble≈øome to the Patient, and hard to be helped. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee a ≈øecret and that is this. Take of our Petra Philo≈øophale twelve grains, which doth evacuate the humour hanging, and di≈ø≈øolveth the Flux. But when it is a hot Flux with a Fever in the Summer, let him ≈øtand two hours after ≈øupper in a bath of ≈øalt-water of the Sea that is cold: for
it is of great effect. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that our Petra Philo≈øophale mu≈øt be taken with Sugar Ro≈øote di. ‚Ñ•. Al≈øo when you have done the afore≈øaid things, you ≈øhall take our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholy humours five or ≈øix mornings. And ≈øo u≈øing this order, thou ≈øhalt help any kind of cruell Flux, as I have proved infinite times.

div.head: CHAP. LIII. Of Co≈øtivene≈ø≈øe in the body.
div.p: THis di≈øea≈øe is cau≈øed of great drine≈ø≈øe and adu≈øtion in the body, through the which cau≈øe there cometh many di≈øea≈øes: and that is, that our meat lyeth long in the body: and of that cometh indi≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øtomack, paines in the head, Flux of Urine, alteration of bloud, augmenting of choller, and ≈øuch like. Therefore if thou wilt help the≈øe inconveniences, it were nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øeek the principall cau≈øe, and to cau≈øe the body to be loo≈øe: and that thou ≈øhalt doe with our Sirrup Magi≈øtrale, u≈øing it according to rea≈øon every morning. For it evacuateth the lower parts, and cooleth the Liver, and purgeth the bloud, and con≈øumeth choller, and helpeth dige≈øtion. And with this onely ≈øhalt thou help them perfectly.

div.head: CHAP. LIV. Of the Flux of ∆≤rine.
div.p:
THe Flux of Urine is an alteration of the pores, and opening of the reines, cau≈øed of indige≈øtion in the body, as you may ≈øee by experience. This Flux weakeneth the ≈øtomack, and the reines, and taketh away the ta≈øt, and letteth ≈øleep: ≈øo that many times of the≈øe effects come cruell di≈øea≈øes, as Gonorhea, the Strangury, Ulcerations in the Yeard, and ≈øuch like: and therefore if thou wilt help the afore≈øaid di≈øea≈øe, u≈øe this Medicine. Let him take of our Aromatico two drachmes, and drink thereon a little water, and then let him u≈øe of this Sirrup
every morning warm ‚Ñ•. iiii. Take Sage, Carduus Benedictus, Egrimony, Betony, Citrake, Scolopendria, Cicorie, of each one handfull, red Saunders, Box, ana ‚Ñ•. iiii. Alloes, Epatick, Coloquintida, Sinne, Turbit, Hermodactiles, ana ‚Ñ•. i. cour≈øe Sugar one pound and a half, commom Hony one pound: then lay all the afore≈øaid things to infu≈øe in five and twenty pound of White wine the ≈øpace of twelve houres: then boile them clo≈øe untill half be con≈øumed: then ≈øtrain it without expre≈ø≈øion, and put thereto a carrect of Musk di≈ø≈øolved in ‚Ñ•, iiii. of Ro≈øewater: and of this take every morning three or four ounces, and fa≈øt thereon at the lea≈øt four or five hours, and in the mean time that you u≈øe this Sirrup, you ≈øhall not eat Hogs fle≈øh, nor Fi≈øh, nor ≈øalt things, nor Rapes, nor Raddi≈øh, nor Par≈øly, nor any other aperative thing: This being done, take Hy≈øop of the Mountain that is dried lb. ii. and boyle it in thirty pound of White wine, and put thereto one pound of Hony, letting them boyle till the fourth part be con≈øumed, and then ≈øtrain it, and drink it continually for fourteen or fifteen dayes. And by this means thou ≈øhalt have help God willing.

div.head: CHAP. LV. A di≈øcour≈øe upon the retention of ∆≤rine, and his cure.
div.p:
THe cau≈øes of the retention of Urine are many, among the which, there are three principally above the re≈øt, and are ≈øo manife≈øt, that every one may under≈øtand them: and are the≈øe. Stones, as well great, as gravell, vi≈øco≈øity in the Reins and Bladder, and alteration in the pores: And thus through tho≈øe three accidents, mo≈øt commonly they cannot make water: the which if thou wilt help, it will be ≈øomewhat hard, becau≈øe you mu≈øt under≈øtand the cau≈øe thereof, the which is not ea≈øily done of every man: for he that knoweth not the cau≈øe, can le≈ø≈øe help the effect, and he that knoweth not the effect, can le≈ø≈øe help them. And therefore, I ≈øay, he that will help tho≈øe that cannot make water, becau≈øe of the ≈øtone in the bladder, he mu≈øt ≈øeringe them to take forth the Urine: but if thou wilt help
tho≈øe that cannot make water through the gravell, you ≈øhall give them our Pillole Aquilone: and then give them a Flint≈øtone made in fine powder, to drink with water of Saxifrage, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee thereof miracles. And if thou wilt help them that cannot make water, becau≈øe of vi≈øco≈øity, give them our Aromatico, and annoint the reins with our Bal≈øamo Artificiato, and al≈øo his Te≈øticles, and ≈øo by the≈øe means you ≈øhall help them quickly of that accident: as I have proved divers times.

div.head: CHAP. LVI. Another di≈øcour≈øe upon the retention of ∆≤rine; and his remedies.
div.p: THe retention of Urine is cau≈øed divers wayes, as by over-much heat, or over-much cold, or through too much drine≈ø≈øe, or too much moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe. And therefore he that will cure this infirmity, mu≈øt fir≈øt know the cau≈øe, and al≈øo the vertue and quality of his Medicines wherewith he will cure them: for if he doe otherwi≈øe, he ≈øhall walk in the dark, and be as a Diviner: for many have written receipts, wherewith they ≈øhew to help many infirmities, without giving any rea≈øon at all. But to the purpo≈øe of the retention of Urine, as as I have ≈øaid, that it may come through four principall cau≈øes. So will I ≈øhew it in four Chapters, and al≈øo their remedies wherewith they may be helped.

div.head: CHAP. LVII. Of the retention of ∆≤rine that cometh through heat, and his remedies.
div.p:
THe retention of Urine which cometh through heat, is that which ingendereth the ≈øtone and gravell, for through that ≈øuperfluous heat it ingendereth. And this is one of the four cau≈øes of the retention of Urine, the which is helped with In≈øtruments and Medicines concerning the ≈øtone. The mo≈øt certain Medicine is, to be cut and take it forth. Neverthele≈ø≈øe,
there are many Medicines that may plea≈øure them of our invention: As concerning the gravell, there are many things that di≈ø≈øolve it, of the which I have ≈øpoken of in divers places: As concerning the remedy of the cau≈øe, that is ea≈øie: for by purging the ≈øtomack and the body, the heat will be di≈ø≈øolved, and the body left in good temperature. And the purging of the body ≈øhall be done with our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholy humour, and to u≈øe our Aromatico, and Electuario Magi≈øtrale, de Althea with Sulphur. And thus much concerning that heat.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII. Of the retention of ∆≤rine through cau≈øe of drine≈ø≈øe, and his Medicine.
div.p: THe retention of Urine through drine≈ø≈øe, is, becau≈øe the Reines and the Conduits where it pa≈ø≈øeth are to much dried, and that drine≈ø≈øe is cau≈øe of adu≈øtion of the Liver, the which mu≈øt be helped with taking away a little bloud: and to purge the body with Ca≈ø≈øia, Sirrup de Pomis, de Succuria, de Lactutia, de Malvis, de Siterache, and ≈øuch like, that cool and take away the adu≈øtion of the Liver: then annoint the Reines, the Members, and Yeard with Hogs grea≈øe, becau≈øe that fat doth mollifie and moi≈øten: and give him to drink Sero lactis, becau≈øe that inlargeth and moi≈øteneth, and provoketh Urine without burning.

div.head: CHAP. LIX. Of the retention of ∆≤rine that cometh through cold, and his remedies.
div.p:
THe alteration of Urine that cometh through cold, is that kinde which maketh a man that he cannot make water, without the help of ≈øome warm thing laid upon the body, and upon the bottome of the belly, and the cure thereof is to vomit tho≈øe cold humours out of the ≈øtomack, and to purge the
body with ≈øolutives of warm Nature, and with warm Decoctions, with the Decoction of Lignum Sanctum, of Carduus Benedictus, and of Ro≈øemary, and annoynt the back with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum, de Terebinthina, & Cera,, or Oyle of Frankincence, or ≈øuch like things that warm the coldne≈ø≈øe. And ≈øo by the≈øe means the Patient ≈øhall be helped of that retention of Urine.

div.head: CHAP. LX. Of the retention of ∆≤rine through cau≈øe of moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe, and his remedy.
div.p: THe retention of Urine cau≈øed of humidity, is that which cau≈øeth the pores to ≈øwell through moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that the Urine cannot pa≈ø≈øe, as tho≈øe ≈øay, which are troubled with the carno≈øity: which carno≈øity is not alteration of the pores through cau≈øe of humidity. For the way to cure this kind of retention, is to purge the body with drying Medicines, as Turbite, Scamonie, Euforbium, Eleborus, and ≈øuch like: and to u≈øe drying Unctions, as ∆≤nguento de Lithargirio, or Bal≈øamo, water of Frankincence, Oleum Benedictum of our invention, and ≈øuch like things, and then eat dry meats; and drink good Wine; and thus the humidity ≈øhall be di≈ø≈øolved: So that hereby every one may have the under≈øtanding of the cau≈øe, and the effect of the ≈øame, and the Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. LXI. Of the difficulty of ∆≤rine, and of what it is cau≈øed, with the order to cure it.
div.p:
THere are divers kindes of difficulty of Urine, and are al≈øo cau≈øed of divers cau≈øes, as afore≈øaid, of the which one is cau≈øed of a corrupt humour of the French Pox, and this is one of the chiefe≈øt cau≈øes that may be in that matter. For we ≈øee manife≈øtly, that the ≈øaid kind of infirmity corrupteth the blood, ingendereth evill qualities in the Liver, and di≈øtempereth
all the body of tho≈øe that are troubled therewith. Al≈øo we may ≈øee, that tho≈øe which are infected with that kind of di≈øea≈øe, mo≈øt commonly have Warts, or Carvoli, Pellaria, Botches, Scabs, Tumours, paines of the Stomack, in the Armes and Legs, with a number of other more ≈øtrange accidents that come through that di≈øea≈øe, But when that infirmity infecteth inwardly, it worketh the≈øe effects: It bringeth Emeroides, paines in the Entrals, Fluxes of the body, continuall ≈øpitting, Gonorrea, or running of the Reines, ≈øuch like effects. All the which cau≈øe difficulty of Urine, of the which difficulty, there u≈øeth to ingender the Stone, Gravell, Vi≈øco≈øity, Stitch in the ≈øide, and divers other mi≈øchiefs very hurtfull unto the body. The difficulty of Urine may al≈øo be cau≈øed of divers other infirmities, as of a rotten Catarre, de≈øcention of the head, of the evill quality of the Liver, and ≈øuch like, as by exce≈ø≈øive cold, or heat of the Reines, but let it be as it will, I know the≈øe are hard matters to be helped, becau≈øe it behooveth certain manuall practi≈øe in that faculty, the which I cannot ≈øhew in writing: although I have great and high ≈øecrets for that indi≈øpo≈øition, as concerning the Phy≈øick part, the which thou maye≈øt find in divers places of my works. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe I will not leave this Chapter unperfect, I will here name unto thee a mo≈øt excellent rare man of that Profe≈ø≈øion, the which is both Doctor and Knight, and is mo≈øt excellent in cutting out the Stone, and the Rupture, and can remedy the great difficulty of Urine, and heale the Rupture, and heale the infirmities of the eyes, and ≈øuch like things mo≈øt excellently, and his name is called Pra≈øtecio Stelin Venetiano: the which is at this pre≈øent dwelling in Venice. And this I have written of that Doctor, becau≈øe he is one of the mo≈øt excellent that may be found in that Art.

div.head: CHAP. LXII. To help tho≈øe that have great burning of their ∆≤rine.
div.p: THis infirmity may come of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will treat of ≈øome of the principall, and of mo≈øt importance; and al≈øo will ≈øhew the true order to help them with ea≈øe and brevitie. The fir≈øt cau≈øe a≈ø≈øigned by me is the Stone in the Bladder, and this is in a manner uncurable. The ≈øecond cau≈øe is, the running of the Reins, the which is taken by companying with women corrupted with the Pox. The third cau≈øe is, the proper French Pox, the which is that kind that is called Gonorrea. The fourth kind is a certain corruption that is called Stranguria, the which moveth continually to make water. The fifth cau≈øe is the Gravell: there are al≈øo other cau≈øes, as ≈øcorching in the Yeard, carno≈øitie, and ≈øuch like things, the which I will leave for troubling of the Reader. The fir≈øt cau≈øe which is the Stone, is helped by two remedies, the one is with cutting and taking it forth of the bladder, the other remedie is written in this book. The remedie for that which is cau≈øed by the running of the Reins, ≈øhall be to take three mornings our Aromatico, becau≈øe it re≈øolveth that heat, and extingui≈øheth the burning. The remedie for that which is cau≈øed of Gonorrea, is none other then to cure the principall di≈øea≈øe, and to annoint them with our ∆≤nguento magno, and perfume them, and ≈øo they ≈øhall remain whole. That which is cau≈ø≈øed of the Strangurie, is cured by great purging, and by taking oftentimes our Aromatico. That which is cau≈øed of the Gravell, is cured by taking oftentimes our Electuario Angelica, and u≈øing to drinke Wine di≈øtilled with Cherrie ≈øtones, and Medler ≈øtones. That which cometh through carno≈øitie, is cured with an Unguent made of oil of Sulphur, and Vitriol, Aqua reale, Oil of Frankincen≈øe, and new Wax, all Medicines devi≈øed by us, giving you charge, that before you begin to cure them, to ≈øeek out the right cau≈øe from whence it proceedeth, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help it with brevitie and great ea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. LXIII. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon the carno≈øitie in the Yeard, and the Order to cure it.
div.p: ALthough we have ≈øomething touched this Infirmitie before in the Chapter of the burning of the Urine. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, in this place, I mean, ≈øomething to di≈øcour≈øe thereof, becau≈øe that Chirurgions may not be void of ≈øuch a noble Secret, to doe them honour in their cure of the like di≈øea≈øe, for there are many troubled with that infirmitie: You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this carno≈øitie is an infirmitie who≈øe originall dependeth of the corruption of the French-Pox, and to ≈øhew it plainer, it is an Ulcer in the neck of the bladder where the Urine entreth into the Yeard. And therefore, if thou wilt help that infirmitie, cure the principall di≈øea≈øe, and the carno≈øitie will heal; but if thou wilt cure them with the Candle, take that Unguent which is written for the carno≈øitie in the Chapter of the burning of the Urine; but if thou wilt cure the principall di≈øea≈øe, give him three times, Pillole aquilone, and then take our Sirrupo Solutivo, ten or twelve daies together; that being done, let him take twentie daies the Wine of Lignum Sanctum, written hereafter in this Book, and tho≈øe which under≈øtand not this Chapter well, let him look over this Book, and he ≈øhall finde tho≈øe Medicines with their U≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. LXIIII. Another Cure for the ≈øaid Carno≈øitie.
div.p:
THat Carno≈øitie which hindereth the Urine that it cannot come forth, is a certain kinde of matter that is ingendered in the mouth of the bladder as is ≈øhewed before, the which is like in all points unto the Emeroids, that come in the neck of the Inte≈øtivall about the Fundament, and becau≈øe it is a gro≈ø≈øe matter and ulcerated, the Urine pa≈ø≈øeth with great difficultie, and great burning and pain unto tho≈øe that are
troubled therewith, the which inconvenience if thou wilt help, it were nece≈ø≈øary that the bodie were well purged, and that they keep a diet, and drinke the decoction of Hypericon, with a little Honie, and u≈øe to eat drie meats, and then make certain ≈ømall long Candles with Wax, and Frankincen≈øe, like unto ≈øearing Candles, then make this Unguent. Take red Lead, white Honie, of each an ounce, fre≈øh Butter two ounces, white Wine as much as will ≈øuffice to incorporate all the afore≈øaid together in a liquid form, then boil it on a ≈øoft fire, and have readie ten or twelve quills fre≈øh pulled out of the wing of a fat Pigeon; and note that when ye take them forth of the wing, that they may be full of blood in the ends, then take one of the quills and ≈øtir the ≈øaid Unguent upon the fire continually while it boileth, and when one quill is dried take another, and ≈øo doe untill the wine be con≈øumed, then take it from the fire and keep it, and when ye will occupie it, take one of tho≈øe Candles, and upon the end put the ≈øaid Unguent, and put it into the Yeard untill it touch the carno≈øity, and this doe from time to time untill the Candle pa≈ø≈øe without pain, and then the Patient ≈øhall be whole; for this is a great Secret and hath been proved many times.

div.head: CHAP. LXV. A Di≈øcour≈øe as concerning tho≈øe that cannot hold their water, and his Remedie.
div.p:
THis Impediment cometh of two principall cau≈øes, the one is, through heat and moi≈øture of the bodie, and this is commonly in young children, which commonly doe be pi≈ø≈øe them≈øelves, becau≈øe they are by Nature hot and moi≈øt. The other cau≈øe is through opening of the Pores where the Urine doth pa≈ø≈øe; the which are ≈øo ≈øtretched or opened, that they cannot retain the Urine, becau≈øe the Urine is a voluntary motion, and a naturall motion together, they are hard to agree together, becau≈øe the naturall motion maketh his voluntarie motion; ≈øo that Nature fir≈øt moveth the man, and thereof cometh the motion; for if a man would make water, and
that Nature doth not move the motion, he cannot pi≈ø≈øe; for ≈øometime Nature doth not give his naturall motion becau≈øe of ≈øome impediment, for when a man cannot hold his water, it is a ≈øign that Nature hath no retention; and to redre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, it were nece≈ø≈øarie to reduce Nature into good temperature, ≈øo that it may retain the Urine; the which thing thou ≈øhalt doe with purging the bodie, and the ≈øtomack wherein is the matter that cau≈øeth that retention of Urine. And to purge the bodie you ≈øhall u≈øe our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholy humour: And to purge the ≈øtomack, you ≈øhall take our Electuario angelica, and to re≈øtrain the pores, you ≈øhall u≈øe the decoction of wild Hy≈øop, with the powder of Mastick, for you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the purging taketh away the cau≈øe, and the decoction of Hy≈øop with the Ma≈øtick, doth re≈øtrain the pores, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes thou ≈øhalt remedie quickly that infirmitie.

div.head: CHAP. LXVI. To break the Stone in the Bladder and al≈øo the Gravell, and to cau≈øe it to avoid by ∆≤rine.
div.p:
THere is found a certain bird called Solone, of Albertus Magnus in his Book of Secrets; the which birds are very plenteous in Rome, and are called Palmum bellae, and in Lumbardie, Sa≈ø≈øarvoli, the which in Engli≈øh I ≈øuppo≈øe, is called a Ring Dove, or Wood-colver, or the Stock Dove, which Birds are ≈øubject to the Stone, that if you keep them in a Cage, and feed them with ≈øuch meat as they commonly u≈øe, being deprived of their medicine, within the ≈øpace of four or ≈øix moneths at the mo≈øt, there will ingender a Stone in the belly ≈øo great, that their meat cannot pa≈ø≈øe through them, and ≈øo choaketh them, and they die, and that is becau≈øe the poor Bird cannot goe and help him≈øelf with that Medicine which Nature hath taught her. For tho≈øe that are at libertie in the field, flie unto the Sea-≈øide, and there they find a certain kind of ≈ømall ≈øtone very hard, the which ≈øtone hath vertue to di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øtone in the bodie of the Bird, and this Bird knoweth
it by the in≈øtinct of Nature, and eateth great abundance of them, and ≈øo di≈ø≈øolveth the ≈øtone in their bellies, and live a long time after it without any trouble of the Stone. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this ≈øtone is unpo≈ø≈øible to be found in any other place, then in the belly of the ≈øaid bird, becau≈øe they are very little, and mans rea≈øon cannot di≈øcern them from other Stones, the which being beat in powder, with the flowers of Elders, and Cinnamon, of each a like, and given to drink with broth, in ≈øhort time it will di≈ø≈øolve the Stone, and cau≈øe them to avoid it with their Urine mo≈øt miraculou≈øly: But if you ask me the rea≈øon, I know not what I ≈øhall an≈øwer, but I hold it to be his proper hidden qualitie and vertue. For truly this I have taught to many, and have ≈øeen the experience thereof ≈øundrie times, and it cured the mo≈øt part that did u≈øe it. For truely the vertue of Stones are very great unto tho≈øe that know them. I ≈øaw once two Stones in Rome of ine≈øtimable vertue; The one was a round Corall like unto the Serpentine Purphire, but therein was much green, and was of that vertue that being laid upon the fle≈øh of a man or woman, it cau≈øeth them to pi≈ø≈øe great abundance, ≈øo that it were to be wondred at. The other Stone was of Dia≈øper, but bright and thorough ≈øhining with certain white veins, and was of ≈øuch vertue, that being laid on a wound, pre≈øently the blood ≈øtenched ≈øo that there fell not down one drop, The which Stones were in the hand of an old Spaniard, who ≈øaid, he brought them out of India, from Nova Hi≈øpania. I have ≈øeen al≈øo divers and ≈øundry Stones of mo≈øt ≈øtrange vertues. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that tho≈øe Stones of the Bird mu≈øt be gotten in this order. You ≈øhall get a number of the ≈øaid Birds, and take the ≈øtones out of their bellies, and wa≈øh them clean, and keep them to thy u≈øe. The quantitie is as much as you can hold upon a Sixpence, as well of the Stones as of the other matters: You ≈øhall drinke the ≈øaid quantitie ≈øeven or eight mornings together, and let your Diet be according, and drink good wine, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time you ≈øhall be helped.

div.head: CHAP. LXVII. Of the Gravell in the Reins.
div.p: THe Gravell (as is ≈øaid before, is a di≈øea≈øe of the Urine undige≈øted, which is cau≈øed of ≈øuperfluous heat of the reins and blood, the which ≈øometimes doth ≈øtay it ≈øelf in the Conduites, and cau≈øeth great pains; and ≈øometimes it doth ingro≈ø≈øe ≈øo in the Bladder, that it letteth the Urine, and this is an evill di≈øea≈øe to be troubled with, and the remedie is to purge often, and u≈øe that water again≈øt the Gravell that is written in my di≈øcour≈øe of Chirurgerie, for it is one of the mo≈øt excellent remedies that can be found for that di≈øea≈øe; and the order to u≈øe it is al≈øo written after the Receipt, and the be≈øt Purgation that you can u≈øe for that purpo≈øe is our Pillole Aquilone.

div.head: CHAP. LXVIII. Of a certain Scab or Itch that cometh over all the bodie.
div.p: THis Di≈øea≈øe cometh in all places of the bodie, and in Naples it is called Prurito, and in Rome, Ro≈øura; in Venice, Pizza; and in Spain, Lomezon: And it is a ≈øalt humour that cometh forth of the veins, and ≈øo di≈øper≈øeth through the whole bodie between the fle≈øh and the skin, and hath in it ≈øuch an heat, that they cannot abide it, and is cau≈øed of alteration of the blood, the which is corrupted and di≈øtempered; and the remedie is, to purge the ≈øtomack, and to purifie the blood, which thou ≈øhalt doe with giving them three times our Pillole aquilone every third day once; that being done, make this Bath: Take Nettles, Mallows, Pellitorie of the wall, Agrimonie, Sage, and Coleworts, ana. lb. iiii. the Bran of Wheat almo≈øt a peck, common A≈øhes half as much: Mix them altogether in a great kettle of water, and let it boil an hour, and then take it from the fire and ≈øit over it, and cover thee with clothes, that thou maie≈øt ≈øweat an hour, then dry thee with warm clothes, and then wa≈øh all thy bodie with pure Aqua vitae, and this thou ≈øhalt u≈øe three times at the lea≈øt, for the oftner the better, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt be perfectly whole.

div.head: The Second Book of the Secrets of PHIORAVANTE.
CHAP. I. What Chirurgery is.
div.p:
CHirurgery is a manuall Art, with the which the Chirurgian doth cure Wounds, Ulcers, and Impo≈øthumes: And this was found of Husbandmen, and Experimenters of naturall things. For there is no Art in the world, that hath more need of the knowledge of divers things then this Art. It is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to the knowledge of naturall things belonging to Chirurgery, to have skill in Husbandry. It is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to under≈øtand the Art of Painting, whereby you may ≈øet broken bones in their places, and to joyn or clo≈øe wounds well. It were needfull al≈øo to have skill in the Art of Joyning, whereby he may make In≈øtruments for broken bones in the Armes, or Legs, or Hands, or other parts. It would be al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to have the Art of a Smith, whereby he may make his In≈øtruments. It is cheifly needfull to be expert in the Art of an Apothecary, to make his Unguents. And la≈øt of all, it is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to know the Art of Alchimie, whereby he may di≈øtill his Oyles and Waters appertaining unto Chirurgery. Al≈øo it is nece≈ø≈øary to have a good judgement, and to help in all cau≈øes of Chirurgery, and to have a light hand in working. And when the Chirurgian is expert in all the afore≈øaid things, he may help without any ≈øu≈øpition of any thing. And hereafter I will ≈øhew thee what Wounds, Ulcers, and Impo≈øthumes are, and all other things appertaining to Chirurgery, and the order to cure them: a di≈øcour≈øe grounded on true rea≈øon
and approved by experience, ≈øhewing to all men, which are the true and perfecte≈øt Medicines, and which are fal≈øe and naught: writing and opening the true ≈øecrets of Chirurgery, with a new order found out by me, to exerci≈øe the ≈øame Chirurgery with more ea≈øe and brevity, ≈øo that every one may be ≈øatisfied: For they are true, and are Medicines, with the which thou maye≈øt doe much good to the ≈øick: and great honour will redound to the Chirurgian, if he u≈øe it according to our order: for they are Medicines proved of us infinite times in divers places of the world, as well in the Feilds as in the Cities, or on the waters‚ñ™ in the warres, where we healed Wounds, Gun≈øhot, Ulcers, Impo≈øthumes, and other di≈øea≈øes appertaining unto Chirurgery: and alwayes (thanks be unto God) I have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, as it is well known in mo≈øt parts of Chri≈øtendome. And ≈øo I make an end.

div.head: CHAP. II. The order to be u≈øed in curing Impo≈øthumes of divers ≈øorts, taken forth of the ≈øhort di≈øcour≈øe of the Chirurgery of this Author.
div.p:
THere are divers kinds of Impo≈øthumes that come unto mans body, and are cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry accidents, and therefore they mu≈øt be cured in divers orders, and with ≈øundry Medicines, according to his nature: for ≈øome Impo≈øthumes are cau≈øed of contu≈øions or brui≈øed fle≈øh: Some are certain humours, of which Nature would di≈øcharge her ≈øelfe, and ≈øo ≈øendeth them forth: ≈øome are cau≈øed of cold; other≈øome are melancholy humours, and others are cau≈øed of the Pox: And the≈øe are the kinds of Impo≈øthumes that mo≈øt commonly doe come, and I will ≈øhew thee the order to cure them one by one, and then after I will ≈øpeak of that ≈øort which is cau≈øed of contu≈øions, becau≈øe it is brui≈øed fle≈øh: for every contu≈øion doth putrifie and turn into matter, unto which it were nece≈ø≈øary to lay Ma ‚Ä¢ ur ‚Ä¢ tives, and bring it to ≈øuppuration, and as ≈øoon as thou perceive≈øt there to be any
matter, then pre≈øently launce it: and his Medicine ≈øhall be the yeolk of an Egge mixed with our Magno liquore, and with that dre≈ø≈øe it as well within as without, without any other thing, for it will help any great Tumour: but you mu≈øt make your Unguent fre≈øh every day, and with new Egges. Furthermore, as concerning tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes that come through the indi≈øpo≈øition of Nature, and are certain Sborine (a word ≈øo called in Italian) by which Nature would prevail: and tho≈øe would be left unto Nature, untill ≈øuch time as they break alone, and then thou ≈øhalt dre≈ø≈øe them with this Unguent. Take Oile of Ro≈øes ‚Ñ•. vi. Litarge of gold finely ground, Turpentine, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. Storax liquida ‚Ñ•. i. New Wax ‚Ñ•. iii. boyle them on a ≈øoft fire untill it be black, which if it be too hard, you may put thereto oyle of Ro≈øes, and make it in form of an Unguent, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe tho≈øe kinds of Impo≈øthumes: and lay thereon the Cerotte of dia Palma, and ≈øo with the≈øe Medicines thou ≈øhalt work miracles. As concerning the≈øe Impo≈øthumes that are cau≈øed of cold, you ≈øhall u≈øe hot Medicines and attractive, as the Cerotte called Oxicroxi, which is a perfect Medicine in the≈øe kinds of Impo≈øthumes: al≈øo our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and Aqua bal≈øamo, and ≈øuch like things which are by nature temperate hot, are very convenient. But tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes that have their originall of the French Pox, are evill and maligne, becau≈øe their originall is maligne and evill. The cure of the≈øe is with great purging, and to let the Impo≈øthume increa≈øe of it ≈øelfe, and when it is ready to launce, then launce it, and make this Medicine. Take ∆≤nguento magno ‚Ñ•. ii. Magno liquore ‚Ñ•. i. Precipitate di. ‚Ñ•. mixe them well together, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe the Impo≈øthume, and lay thereon our Magi≈øtrale Cerotte, and it will be perfect whole in ≈øhort time: Letting you to under≈øtand, that in all the afore≈øaid cures, if you will cure them perfectly, it were nece≈ø≈øary that the body were well purged of tho≈øe corrupt humours that hinder the cure, and to u≈øe defen≈øives appropriate to that kind of Impo≈øthume: as the oil of Frankincen≈øe, of Turpentine, of Wax, of Hony, Aqua vitae, and ≈øuch like, which every one is a ≈øufficient defen≈øive, annointing it round about the Impo≈øthume: And hereafter I will ≈øhew
thee the cure of the≈øe Impo≈øthumes particularly by them≈øelves.

div.head: CHAP. III. What Impo≈øthumes are.
div.p: IMpo≈øthumes are certain Tumours or ≈øwellings, that come in divers parts of the body: the which are cau≈øed of blood and choller putrified, which cannot pa≈ø≈øe through the pores, and therefore ingro≈ø≈øe in that place, and ≈øo cometh to putrifaction, and that is an Impo≈øthume: which thou ≈øhalt help in this order. Fir≈øt purge the body to take away the humours which would goe to the Impo≈øthume: which thou ≈øhalt doe with our Magi≈øtrale Sirrup, taking it eight dayes together: that being done, give him our Aromatico: this being done, thou ≈øhalt quickly help the Impo≈øthume, as I will ≈øhew thee hereafter, with their perfect cure.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Impo≈øthumes that come in the Groine.
div.p:
THe Impo≈øthumes that come in the Groin are of three kinds, of which one is called in Venice, Pannochi, and at Rome, Tinconie, and at Naples, Dragonello, and in Spain, Incordio. To the≈øe after the body is purged, as is afore≈øaid, you ≈øhall lay a Maturative plai≈øter, the which is made thus. Take Mar≈øh Mallowes, common Mallowes, the mother of Violets, the leaves of Coleworts, Wheat flower, Auxungia, Oil of Lillies, of each alike, and boyle them together, and then ≈øtamp them in form of an Ointment, and lay it on the Impo≈øthume untill it look red and is ≈øoft, for then it ‚Ä¢ s apt to be launced: Giving you charge, that when you launce them you go not too deep; but onely that the matter may come forth, and then put therein a little tent, and annoint it with our Magno liquore, for becau≈øe it is the be≈øt Medicine that can be found for wounds: for it mundifieth, incarnateth, and
≈øiccatrizeth without any other help, and lay upon the Impo≈øthume our Magi≈øtrale Cerot, and never change your Medicines untill you be whole; for this is the true ≈øecret found out by me to help the≈øe Impo≈øthumes, which I have proved infinite times.

div.head: CHAP. V. The ≈øecond kind of Impo≈øthume that cometh in the Groin.
div.p: THe ≈øecond kind of Impo≈øthume in the Groin is called Glandulae, both this and the afore≈øaid are cau≈øed of humours infected with the Pox, and the≈øe Impo≈øthumes ≈øeldome come to maturation; but if it doe, it will be long fir≈øt, and it is evil to heal, becau≈øe it requireth great cure and terrible medicines. But if thou wilt cure them perfectly, it were nece≈ø≈øary to cure the principall cau≈øe, and that is the Pox. But when the≈øe Impo≈øthumes are broke, the be≈øt remedie will be this. Take Waxe, Litarge of gold; Oil of Frankincen≈øe, ana. and boil them together untill it become black: and therewith dre≈ø≈øe the≈øe Impo≈øthumes, for this is a perfect remedie, and a great Secret.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The third kind of Impo≈øthume that cometh in the Groin.
div.p:
THe third kind of Impo≈øthume that cometh in the Groin, is cau≈øed of much travell or heat of the blood, and the≈øe are called Anguinaglie, and they u≈øe to come with a great accident of a Fever, cold and then hot, and in ≈øeven or eight daies at the mo≈øt, they come to maturation, and then launce them, and his medicine ≈øhall be this: Take Turpentine well wa≈øhed, the yolk of an Egg, and oyle of Ro≈øes, as much of the one, as of the other, and mix them well together, and with this onely thou ≈øhalt help them, becau≈øe it dige≈øteth the Impo≈øthume, and mundifieth and incarnateth with great ≈øpeed; giving you
great charge that the bodie be well purged fir≈øt with our Magi≈øtrale Sirupe.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Impo≈øtumes under the arms.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øtumes are cau≈øed of gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, the which Nature cannot dige≈øt by any other part, and the≈øe commonly are called Topinaxia, becau≈øe they are like to a Molehill. And although this ≈øeem to be a great matter, yet it cau≈øeth little pain, and may be holpen with ea≈øe. Fir≈øt purge the bodie with Soluble Medicines, and then lay on this plai≈øter untill it be ripe. Take grated bread, leaven of bread, Cow Milk, Oil of Lillies, ana, and boil them together and lay it on; for this hath vertue attractive and putrifactive, by meanes whereof it will bring it quickly to maturation; and when it is ripe, open it with a launce, and dre≈ø≈øe it the fir≈øt time with the white of an Egg and Salt beaten together with a tent, and lay on a ≈øtopine wet with the white of an Egg, the which thou ≈øhalt let lie at the lea≈øt four and twentie hours, and then dre≈ø≈øe it with dige≈øtive untill it be incarnated, and then lay thereon a plai≈øter of Dia aquilone magno di Me≈øue, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them quickly.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Impo≈øtumes in the throat.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øtumes are of divers and ≈øundry kindes, as you may ≈øee by experience; for ≈øome are Scrophule, others are melancholie humours, others are cau≈øed of the Poxe, and others are cau≈øed of heat, or of cold; the which are all cured ≈øundrie wayes, as I will ≈øhew thee hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Impo≈øtumes in the throat cau≈øed of melancholie humours.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øtumes in throat cau≈øed of melancholie humours are hard and crude, and are long before they come to maturation, and you may not in any wi≈øe cut them, becau≈øe the place is full of Muscles, Arteries, Vene capillari, Cartilagines, Sinnews, and ≈øuch like; the which although there come an Impo≈øtume there, it ≈øhall not hurt them; but if yee cut them with an In≈øtrument you may offend them greatly, and for that cau≈øe you may not cut them by any means, but leave it unto Nature, the which will cau≈øe it to break, and then u≈øe this remedie. Fir≈øt, you ≈øhall take our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholie humour for twelve daies, continually in the morning, fa≈øting; that done, you ≈øhall give him our Pillole Aquilone, and help the Impo≈øtumes with ∆≤nguento negro di Godfredo di m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i, written in the Antidotary of Galen, Cap. 45. for that is miraculous to help tho≈øe kinds of Impo≈øtumes, as I have proved it divers times.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Impo≈øtumes in the throat coming of the Pox.
div.p:
THe Impo≈øtumes that come in the Throat which are cau≈øed of the Pox, are commonly of evill qualitie, becau≈øe they are much alterated, and cau≈øe great pain, and the≈øe likewi≈øe are dangerous to be cut for the afore≈øaid cau≈øes: but when they are broken, they goe creeping over the bodie, healing in one place, and breaking out in another, and the≈øe are evill to be helped, for them that know not the perfect ≈øecret, and the order to cure them is this. You ≈øhall give them eight or nine mornings our Soluble Sirrup; that being done, you ≈øhall give them our Aromatico twice, and then let them u≈øe Sar≈øa Parilia, or our wine of Lignum vitae, and let them ≈øweat ten or twelve daies together, and then perfume them with Sinabar, Myrrhe, and Olibanum, the which fume you ≈øhall
u≈øe onely at the mouth, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help any crude kind of Impo≈øthume coming in the throat: for this Secret never faileth, as I have proved divers times.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of Impo≈øthumes in the throat coming of hot humours.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øthumes in the throat coming of ≈øuperfluous heat, are cau≈øed of the bloud being alterated with heat, and becau≈øe of that alteration, it ingendereth gro≈øs vapours and vi≈øcous in Vena Capillari, the which through their gro≈øsne≈ø≈øe and want of dige≈øtion cannot di≈ø≈øolve, and ≈øo ingender that kind of Impo≈øthume in the throat, becau≈øe in that place there is much blood, and le≈ø≈øe fle≈øh then in any other place, but yet the≈øe be not trouble≈øome to help, and his cure is thus: You ≈øhall purge him with aperative things, and refri≈øcative that purge the blood; and when the Impo≈øthume is open, you ≈øhall dre≈ø≈øe it with a dige≈øtive untill it be mundified, and then dre≈ø≈øe it with ∆≤nguentum de Tutia untill it be ≈øiccatrized: Al≈øo you ≈øhall cau≈øe them to keep diet ordinary, and to drink no wine but onely this drinke: Take Citrake, Liver-wort, and Scolopendria, ana a handfull, Anni≈øeed ‚Ñ•. i. common white-Honey one pound, then put them all to infu≈øe in four and twentie pound of fair water, and let it boil untill a third be con≈øumed, and then ≈øtrein it without expre≈ø≈øion, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, and this ≈øhall be his common drink: but let him eat no ≈øalt, nor ≈ølimie meates in any wi≈øe, neither Hogs fle≈øh, nor other hot meats that may alter the blood: And this doing you ≈øhall be quickly helped, for the drink cooleth the blood, and purgeth it, and helpeth the Liver of all infirmities, as I have proved divers times.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of Impo≈øthumes in the throat cau≈øed of cold.
div.p: IMpo≈øthumes in the throat cau≈øed of cold humours are ≈ømall and without pain, and this goeth creeping by little and little untill ≈øuch time as it breaketh of it self, and are an evill kind to help, becau≈øe all Unguents are an enemie unto them, and all cold meats. Therefore if thou wilt help them, let the Patient u≈øe twentie daies together our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, which purgeth all cold humours, and warmeth the blood, and cau≈øeth the Impo≈øthume to heal with ea≈øe; and when they are broken, you ≈øhall help them with our Balm artificiall, which doth ≈øubtiliate the humours, and mundifie the Impo≈øthume, and incarnate and heal: And this Order of curing is effectual and of great profit for them that ≈øhall u≈øe them. And of this opinion are many excellent Phy≈øicians, and chiefly M. Decio an ancient man, who hath been an experimenter a long time both in Phy≈øick and Chirurgerie, with a number of others, which I will leave to name untill another time.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of Impo≈øthumes in the throat coming of hot humours.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øthumes coming in the throat of hot humours, is a kind that cometh with redne≈ø≈øe, and cau≈øeth great pain, with an accident of a Fever, and in ≈øhort time they come to maturation, and break, and then the matter will come forth, and the pain will cea≈øe; and the≈øe kindes are not evill to heal, and the remedies are the≈øe. A≈ø≈øoon as they are broke thou mu≈øt pre≈ø≈øe it out with thy hand, that being done, you ≈øhall have Oleum Benedictum of our invention, annointing the Impo≈øthume within, and lay thereon our Magi≈øtrale Cerot, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help tho≈øe kindes of Impo≈øthumes. For this is our Secret never written before of any man.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of Impo≈øthumes in the Eies.
div.p: IMpo≈øthumes in the eies are like certain white bladders that come about the no≈øe, and the matter that is within them is like the white of an Egg, and the≈øe are cau≈øed of humiditie and moi≈øtne≈øs of the head, and becau≈øe they have a conference with the head, they are evill to heal, for they turn to watering Fi≈øtula's, which, when they come to Fi≈øtula's, continue for ever. But if thou wilt cure them perfectly that they never come again, you mu≈øt fir≈øt purge the head with our Aromatico, and that you ≈øhall doe every five daies once for three or four times; that being done, thou ≈øhalt annoint the head with Oil of Frankincen≈øe the ≈øpace of a moneth, and into the eie where the Impo≈øthume is, thou ≈øhalt put once a day one drop of our Balm artificiall, which will help it and dry the Impo≈øthume, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt be helped. For this is the true Secret wherewith thou maye≈øt help tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes, never known before of any man, and they are much contrary to the Medicines of Me≈øue, by which our Phy≈øicians now adaies make their Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of Impo≈øthumes in the Eares.
div.p:
IMpo≈øthumes in the eares are cau≈øed of cold and vi≈øcous humours, which ingro≈ø≈øe in that part of the bodie, and cau≈øe great pain untill ≈øuch time as they are broken, and the≈øe Impo≈øthumes are evill to heal. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee a Secret to take away the pains, and to help it quickly, and that is thus. There is found a certain kind of ≈øhell in the Sea, the which is of the length of an hand, and ≈øomewhat more, the which, in Venice, and in I≈øtria, in Dalmatia, in Puglia, and in divers other places of the Adriatick Sea, are called A≈øture, which is like unto a pair of bellows, the which hath a certain beard, like the hair of a mans head, and it
hath a certain attractive vertue, that if they put it into the eare, pre≈øently they take away the pain, though it be never ≈øo great or extream: the which vertue cometh through the ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe of it. For this I have proved divers times, and did learn it of our old Fi≈øhermen, which knew it by experience. But if it chance that one be troubled and cannot get that thing, they ≈øhall take Cantharides in powder, and put it into the eare, the which will work the ≈øame effect, becau≈øe they be attractive and mundificative: And the≈øe are two naturall remedies, found out by true experience, and doth more good then any other that I could find.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of Impo≈øthumes in the Mouth.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øthumes are of divers kinds, and may breed of divers cau≈øes: but let them come of what cau≈øe ≈øoever they will, they cau≈øe great pain to them that have them, for that they cannot ≈øwallow their meat without pain. And therefore I will ≈øhew thee a generall cure for all Impo≈øthumes in the mouth, and that is thus. You ≈øhall take our Pillole Aquilone twice: that being done, take our Aqua bal≈øami, and hold it in your mouth as long as you can, and this doe three times in a day: then take the juyce of Beet roots ‚Ñ•. i. oil of bitter Almonds í. i. then ≈ønuffe it up at the no≈øe untill it come into the throat: And thus doing, thou ≈øhalt help any Impo≈øthume in the mouth, as I have proved divers times. For the Pils clen≈øe the head, and evacuate the ≈øtomack, and hindereth the alteration, the water of Balm doth cure and mittigateth the pain, and the juyce with the Oil mundifieth tho≈øe ≈øecret places at the no≈øe and mouth.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of Impo≈øthumes in the Joynts.
div.p:
THe≈øe Impo≈øthumes in the Joynts are evill, and of hard and crude dige≈øtion, becau≈øe they are cau≈øed of great abundance
of gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, the which through their gro≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe cannot pa≈ø≈øe the Joynts, and there remain and come to Impo≈øthume, and the≈øe cau≈øe extream pain, becau≈øe thereunto commeth great abundance of matter, and the remedy is thus. Fir≈øt give him a generall purgation, and let him bloud on the common vein, and then lay on this plai≈øter. Take Mar≈øh Mallowes, common Mallowes, Pellitory, and the Mother of Violets, and boyle them in water till it be con≈øumed, then ≈øtamp them, and put thereto Leaven of bread, Barly flower, Hens greace, and Hogs greace, according to thy di≈øcretion, and ≈øet them on a ≈ømall fire untill they be incorporated, then lay this on once a day untill it be ripe, and when it is red and ≈øoft open it, and dre≈ø≈øe it with our Magno liquore, and lay thereon our Magi≈øtrale Cerotte: and ≈øo with the≈øe two thou ≈øhalt help them, except the Impo≈øthume be of the Pox, for then it will doe ≈ømall good.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of inward Impo≈øthumes.
div.p: THe≈øe Impo≈øthumes inwardly are evill to know, and uncertain to cure, becau≈øe the Patient him≈øelf cannot tell in what place they be, though he feel the pain: and therefore all that we rea≈øon of in that matter, may be to the contrary. For where a man cannot ≈øee with the eye, nor touch with the hand, the matter is doubtfull whether it be, or no ‚Ä¢ and therefore it is be≈øt to ≈øay little, For the≈øe Impo≈øthumes may come of divers cau≈øes, and yet cannot tell of what certain cau≈øe, and therefore you cannot know which is the true Medicine to help them: but by experience you may doe them ≈øome good; For (as I ≈øaid before) Impo≈øthumes never come but through di≈øtemperance of Nature, and alteration of the bloud. Therefore if thou wilt help them, help fir≈øt the principall cau≈øe, then give them eight or ten mornings our Magi≈øtrale Sirrup, and then take twice, our Aromatico: that being done, u≈øe morning and evening our Vegitabile Sirrup, and herewith thou ≈øhalt help them.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of ∆≤lcers, and what they are.
div.p: VLcers are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, and are ingendered of many cau≈øes, as hereafter I will ≈øhew. But fir≈øt I will write of tho≈øe kinds of Ulcers that are cau≈øed of Wounds. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that wounds in what part of the body ≈øoever they be, being impo≈øthumated or cancrenated, they change their names, and are no more called wounds, although their originall was a wound. For when it is cancrenated, it is called ∆≤lcera corro≈øiva, becau≈øe it goeth eating and creeping on the fle≈øh: but when the wound is impo≈øthumated and full of matter, it is called ∆≤lcera putrida, that is putrified, and it is becau≈øe it is filthy and ≈øtinketh. But when it is neither cancrenated, nor yet apo≈øthumated, but that through ≈øome evill di≈øpo≈øition the wound is clo≈øed, and that there cometh in it evill qualities without alteration, then is it called ∆≤lcera ≈øordida, becau≈øe therein is evill qualitie, and it appeareth but little, but it is evill to heal. There be other ≈øorts of Ulcers al≈øo, which are cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry kinds of Tumours: and the mo≈øt evill and mi≈øcheivious are tho≈øe that are of Tumours cau≈øed of the Pox: for unto tho≈øe there runne abundance of evill humours that augment the Ulcer, and they be the wor≈øt ≈øort, for they cannot be healed by them≈øelves, except the body be well purged and evacuated of all the humours that are offen≈øive. There is another kinde of Ulcer that cometh of an Impo≈øthume as well hot as cold, and tho≈øe are more gentle and ea≈øie to be helped, if you know the Medicines that are apt to help and di≈ø≈øolve tho≈øe kinds of Ulcers. The≈øe are the three kinds of Ulcers that commonly happen unto men and women through divers cau≈øes, as before is ≈øaid, ≈øo that the≈øe are the principall cau≈øes of tho≈øe maligne Ulcers.

div.head: CHAP. XX. To help ∆≤lcers of all ≈øorts.
div.p: SEeing that Ulcers are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, it were nece≈ø≈øary to know of what kind and quality they are, ≈øo that thou may≈øt help them in form and order convenient. And fir≈øt I will write of the corro≈øive Ulcers, as of a wound cancrenated, of Mal di formica, and of other ≈øorts of Ulcers that goe creeping upon the fle≈øh. The cure of the≈øe kinds of Ulcers is, to apply quickly our Cau≈øtick to mortifie the evill, which thou ≈øhalt doe thus. Wet a little Bumba≈øt in our Cau≈øtick, and therewith wa≈øh all the ≈øore, and then leave it ≈øo open four and twenty houres without binding it fa≈øt, and when four and twenty houres are pa≈øt, wa≈øh the ≈øore with ≈øtrong Vineger, and water of a like quantity, with charge that there remain none of the Cau≈øtick in the ≈øore: then lay thereon Butter wa≈øhed with a Colewort leafe, untill the asker or dead fle≈øh fall: then take our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, with a little Precipitate ≈øtrewed thereon, and then annoint it with Magno liquore, and lay it upon the ≈øore: for this Cerot helpeth all manner of coro≈øive Ulcers without any other help, and every plai≈øter will ≈øerve three or four dayes, taking them off every four and twenty houres, and making them clean, and then lay them on again. And as for the filthy Ulcer that I have ≈øhewed of in this Chapter, you ≈øhall dre≈ø≈øe it onely with our ∆≤nguento magno, the which, without any other help, will heal them quickly. But you mu≈øt every four dayes touch them with Aqua fortis drawn from Precipitate, which water draweth forth the offen≈øive matter, and leaveth it purified and clean. And in all other ≈øorts of Ulcers, our Balm artificiall, our Magno liquore, Oil of Wax, and Turpentine, the black Cerot of Godfredo di me di, our Cerot Magi≈øtrale with Precipitate, are able to help, be they never ≈øo evill. And hereafter I will write of Ulcers particularly with their cures.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of ∆≤lcers, that come in the feet, of corns, or of chaps.
div.p: ULcers that come in the feet may come of divers cau≈øes, and are al≈øo of divers kinds, as of chaps, of corns, and ≈øuch like. When they are chaps they come of an hot matter and fiery, as you may ≈øee by experience: For the Patient feeleth great heat in his feet, and is alwayes thir≈øty, the which giveth manife≈øt ≈øignes that the humour is hot: and their cure is with cooling purgations, as our Sirrup again≈øt melancholy humours, taking it ten dayes together: then take our Pillole Aquilone twice, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt take away the heat in the feet: and to help the crepature or chaps, make this Unguent. Take oil of Ro≈øes, Vineger, and liquid Pitch, ana, and boyle them untill the Vineger be con≈øumed, and ≈øo being warm, wet a cloth therein, and lay it thereupon, and in ≈øhort time it will be whole: but if they be cornes, you ≈øhall cut them unto the quick, and then lay thereon a cloth wet in Oleum benedictum, which doth comfort and dry, and quickly take away the pain. But when they are ≈øcratching, or as it were ≈øcorched, you ≈øhall lay thereon ∆≤nguento de Lithargiro crudo, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them, as I have ≈øeen the experience.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of ∆≤leers in the Legs
div.p:
THe≈øe Ulcers in the Legs are of two kinds, that is, filthy, and corro≈øive. The filthy Ulcers are cau≈øed of cold and moi≈øt humours: The corro≈øive are cau≈øed of humours hot and dry: and the≈øe are tho≈øe Ulcers that goe creeping in the fle≈øh, healing in one place, and breaking out in another. The filthy Ulcer is ≈øtinking and full of matter, and cau≈øeth little pain, and their cure is with our Balm artificiall, which hath vertue to penetrate, dige≈øt, mundifie, and incarnate, and heal, when that the body is fir≈øt well purged: but tho≈øe that are cau≈øed of heat and drine≈ø≈øe, you ≈øhall cure with the remedy
written in the Chapter next above≈øaid, and then dre≈ø≈øe them with our Magi≈øtrale Cerot, and put thereon a little Precipitate, and annoint it with Magno liquore, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them. But if ≈øo be it chance the ≈øaid Medicine doe not heal it, you ≈øhall perfume them five times with Sinabar, Incen≈øe, and Myrrhe, and without all doubt thou ≈øhalt heal them.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of ∆≤lcers that come in the Knees.
div.p: THe≈øe Ulcers in the Knees are gro≈ø≈øe humours that cannot pa≈ø≈øe by the Joynts downwards, and ≈øo remain in tho≈øe places, and cau≈øe a fa≈øtidious Ulcer, which putteth the Patient to great paines, by rea≈øon of abundance of humours that cometh there. And the cure of this Impo≈øthume ulcerated is thus, purge the body with our Soluble Sirrup, ≈øeven or eight mornings warme: and then give him di. ‚Ñ•. of Electuaria Angelica, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them quickly: then dre≈ø≈øe the Ulcer with ∆≤nguento magno, puting therein a little Precipitate and Magno liquore, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time it will heal.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of ∆≤lcers in the Groin.
div.p: THe≈øe Ulcers for the mo≈øt part are Tumours, or Botches, the which through the evill di≈øpo≈øition of Nature, and evill Medicines are ulcerated. And of that may come many infirmities, which I will leave to treat of at this time, and I will ≈øhew thee a remedy. Give the Patient ≈øeven or eight mornings our Soluble Sirrup cold, and then give him our Aromatico, and after let him u≈øe Lignum Sanctum according to our order, and dre≈ø≈øe the Ulcer with this Unguent. Take ∆≤nguento magno ‚Ñ•. ii. Magno liquore di. ‚Ñ•. and common Precipitate í. ii. Mix them well together, for this is the true ≈øecret of our invention, never made before of any man, the which I have proved infinite times.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of ∆≤lcers in the Armes.
div.p: THe≈øe Ulcers are not of ≈øo evill nature as tho≈øe in the Legs, becau≈øe thereunto come not ≈øo many humours, and the≈øe are commonly cau≈øed of the Pox, the Cure is this. Purge them well with our Magi≈øtrale Sirrup, ≈øeven or eight mornings together, then take Pillole Aquilone, and then annoint them with ∆≤nguento magno every night until the Ulcers remain whole and without pain. Thus have I u≈øed divers times.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Of ∆≤lcers that come in the Brea≈øt and Shoulders, and in the Back and Belly.
div.p:
ULcers that come in the fore≈øaid parts, are all cau≈øed of Impo≈øthumes of evill qualities, that have not been well healed of the Chirurgians, which knew not how to remove the cau≈øe, and by that meanes the Impo≈øthumes are become malign Ulcers. He therefore that will cure the≈øe Ulcers, it ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øarie for him to do that which was not done; that is, to remove the cau≈øe fir≈øt, and then the cure will follow with more ea≈øe and ≈øpeed, ≈øo there be good regard and con≈øideration had thereof. And yet among≈øt Ulcers there is one kind that will receive no curation, and they are called Cancri, that are crude and of evill dige≈øtion, and go creeping along the fle≈øh, and have a root as it were a Plant: And for tho≈øe kinds there is found no better remedie to mittigate them, then is our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia Vegitabile, for if you put it therein, and lay a cloth wet in the ≈øame thereon, it taketh away the pain, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that it is to be wondered at, and will not ≈øuffer it to putrifie; it taketh away the ≈øtinking, and comforteth the place very much. As concerning the other kind of Ulcer, you mu≈øt fir≈øt find out the cau≈øe before you can help it, and the cau≈øe being found, the cure is ea≈øie to find and ≈øure. He therefore that will be diligent, ≈øhall not
onely heal tho≈øe kindes of Ulcers, but al≈øo all other Ulcers.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of ∆≤lcers that come outwardly in all the bodie.
div.p: THe≈øe Ulcers are a kind of fat ≈øore that cau≈øeth abundance of matter, which cometh through ≈øuperfluous humiditie of the bodie and blood, and the≈øe are evill to heal, becau≈øe their Originall cometh of the inward parts, and the cure is thus: Give the Patient fourteen daies our Potion of Lignum Sanctum, the which is ≈øoluble and drying, and purgeth the blood, that being done, annoint the Ulcer with ∆≤nguentum de Lethargiro ≈øimple, and ≈øo they ≈øhall be helped perfectly.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of ∆≤lcers in the Head.
div.p: ULcers in the Head are of divers kinds, as of Wounds, Contu≈øions, Swellings, Scabs and white Skalls, and ≈øuch like, which come of ≈øundry cau≈øes, and are holpen divers wayes. For the Wounds Ulcerated, are mortified with our Ca≈øtick, laying it on four and twenty hours, and then wa≈øh it with ≈øtrong Vinegar, untill all the Ca≈øtick be come forth, and after help it with our Magno liquore: The like cure is done in Contu≈øions ulcerated, but the Swellings doe differ much, for that they are cau≈øed of the Pox, and thou ≈øhalt cure them with Soluble Medicines: Viz. Take Sar≈øa-Parilia, and then perfume him five or ≈øix times with Sinaber. The Scabs or Cru≈øts are helped with taking three times our Electuario angelica, and then annoint them every night with Magno liquore. The white Scab is holpen with our Magi≈øtrale Cerot laying on Cantharides, and ≈øo let it lie three dayes, then take it off, and lay on another like the fir≈øt, and let it lie other three daies, and then annoint the head with Oleum Benedictum continually.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of ∆≤lcers in the mouth, their Kinds and Remedies.
div.p: ULcers that come in the mouth are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, for ≈øome proceed of heat in the head, others of cold, others are humours Gallico. Tho≈øe that come of heat in the head, are as it were ≈øcorched with great burning within them, and the cure thereof is in letting blood in the veins under the tongue, and the next day give him one do≈øe of our Electuario angelica, and let him wa≈øh his mouth with Planten water, wherein is boiled Tutia prepared, Roch Allum, and Honie of Ro≈øes, and this is the true order to cure tho≈øe kind of Ulcers with ≈øpeed. Tho≈øe Ulcers which are cau≈øed of cold, are a certain hardne≈ø≈øe alterated, which cau≈øe little pain; and the cure of the≈øe is to drinke our Vegitabile Quinta e≈ø≈øentia, with Mel Ro≈øarum: and dre≈ø≈øe the Ulcer with Oil of Sulphur and Tartur mixed: And herein con≈øi≈øteth a great Secret worthy to be known, and is of our invention. Ulcers that are cau≈øed of Morbo Gallico, if you will cure them, you mu≈øt fir≈øt remove the cau≈øe, as I have ≈øaid divers times, and touch them with our Ca≈øtick. and let the Patient hold his mouth open a good while after, that the Water may run out: And then make a Lavatory of Aqua vitae, Honey, and Oil of Vitriol, aad therewith wa≈øh the mouth, for the≈øe are great Secrets which bring both health to the Patient, and honour to the Profe≈ø≈øor of this Art.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of Wounds and their kinds, and of their ≈øecret Remedies.
div.p:
VVOunds are of divers and ≈øundry kinds. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, they con≈øi≈øt in two, that is Simple, and Compound. The Simple wounds are tho≈øe, where the fle≈øh is onely offended. The Compound are tho≈øe, where there is offence of fle≈øh, ≈øinews, veins, and bones, and the cure of either of them is in three manners. The fir≈øt is a cure pertaining to
Nature and not to Art, and that is it which Dogs and other Animals doe u≈øe, who being wounded, u≈øe no other Medicine then to keep the wound clean with their proper tongues, and keep a Diet, and the re≈øt is left unto Nature which worketh well without pains of Medicine, and this is the fir≈øt. The ≈øecond is that which is called Canonico, in which there be four operations. The fir≈øt is, Dige≈øtion. The ≈øecond, Mundification. The third, Incarnation. The fourth, Siccatri≈øation. The third order is of our invention, and is done in this order, that is; When≈øoever a man hath a wound either ≈øimple or compound, the fir≈øt thing that is to be done therein is, to joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and ≈øtitch them, and dre≈øs them with divers ≈øorts of drying Medicines, as I will ≈øhew thee hereafter in the cure of Wounds, in ≈øundry parts of the bodie.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. What Medicines are fitte≈øt to heal Wounds outwardly with ea≈øe, and in ≈øhort time.
div.p:
HAving declared alreadie what wounds are outwardly, it is nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo to ≈øhew the true order to cure them with as much ea≈øe, and brevitie, as is po≈ø≈øible to be done: And fir≈øt, I will begin with ≈øimple wounds that are onely in the fle≈øh, without offence of vein, ≈øinew or bone. Although the≈øe ≈øorts of wounds are not to be helped with artifice, but onely to joyn the parts together, and if it be nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo to ≈øtitch them, and ≈øo leave it unto Nature, the which in ≈øhort time will heal it, neverthele≈ø≈øe if thou wilt help it with artifice the fa≈øter, you ≈øhall annoint it once a day with oile of Frankincen≈øe made by Di≈øtillation, as is ≈øhewed in this Book. But tho≈øe wounds where there are veins cut, have need to be ≈øuccoured pre≈øently with ingenious artifice, and perfect Remedies to ea≈øe and heal them with the mo≈øt ≈øpeed that can be, becau≈øe the veins may joyn together, without greater offence of the wound, and this Mi≈øterie thou ≈øhalt doe in this order: The fir≈øt is to joyn the wound together quickly, and ≈øtitch
it clo≈øe as they u≈øe to ≈øow bags, and not to leave great wide ≈øtitches as they mo≈øt commonly do; that being done, dre≈ø≈øe it upon the wound with our Magno liquore, wetting therein a cloth, and laying it on as hot as you may ≈øuffer it, then ≈øtrew thereupon our ≈øecret powder, and al≈øo round about it, for that ≈øubtiliateth the matter that runneth to the wound, and taketh it forth with great ea≈øe, and without pain of the wound, and therefore this is one of the mo≈øt ≈øafe≈øt Remedies in that ca≈øe, that Nature with Art can make, and hath been proved an infinite of times by me, and alwaies have had goodly experiences thereof.
