Al≈øo under≈øtand that the≈øe wounds, where the bones and ≈øinews are cut, have need of great artifice, for they are of great importance. But when there is offence onely of the ≈øinews, you ≈øhall ≈øtitch them pre≈øently, and doe as I have ≈øaid before of veins that were cut, but dre≈ø≈øe them not with Magno liquore, but in ≈øtead of that take Oleum Benedictum, and oil of Frankincen≈øe, of each alike, becau≈øe the≈øe Oiles doe comfort marvellou≈øly tho≈øe ≈øinews that are cut. If it chance ≈øo, that a ≈øinew had a puncture, or cut half away, in that ca≈øe it is nece≈ø≈øarie to cut it overthwart, le≈øt it ≈øhould bring a Spa≈øm in the wound. But in ca≈øe afterward that the bone be offended, and that there be ≈øome part to come forth, it were nece≈ø≈øary to leave the wound open untill the bone be come forth, and then incarnate it; and this thou ≈øhalt doe with our Bal≈øamo Artificiato, and lay thereon the Cerot of Godfredo di medi, the which helpeth with great ≈øpeed. And this is the order wherewith thou maye≈øt help all tho≈øe ≈øorts of wounds before named, and the defen≈øive to u≈øe in the≈øe wounds is this. Take perfect Aqua vitae made of good Wine, and put therein Hypericon, Millefolly, Viticella, Betonie, and with that Infu≈øion wet clothes, and lay them for a defen≈øive round about the wound, and thou ≈øhalt have good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. Wounds in the head are helped in the order, as tho≈øe in whom the Sinews are offended. There are divers other ≈øorts of wounds, which may be healed with the afore≈øaid remedies, as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed particularly.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Of Wounds in the Head, with offence of the brain, and how to cure them.
div.p:
VVOunds in the head, where there is offence of the brain, are mortall: and there is no Phy≈øician that will take them in cure, but he counteth them dead men without any hope. But I by the grace of God and gift of Nature, have found the order to cure and heal them in ≈øhort time. I remember that when one was wounded in the head in the famous Citie of Naples, yea, although the brain were not hurt, but that the skin were cut unto the bone, they counted him mortall, but I dre≈ø≈øed them, and clo≈øed their wounds, and helped them in ≈øhort ≈øpace, ≈øo that they wondred thereat; and that order I u≈øed for the ≈øpace of ≈øeven yeers that I tarried there, and cau≈øed them to walk in the ≈øtreets, as it is well known unto all tho≈øe that dwell there. And among a number of other, I cured a Portingall that was called, Il Seignior Diego di mena, of whom I took away all the bone of the forehead, and every day he came to my lodging to be cured, which I did with great ≈øpeed, ≈øo that it cau≈øed every one to marvell thereat. Afterward I went to Rome in the time of Pope Paulus the iiii. Carafa, and alwaies I cured in the ≈øame order, and did miracles, of which I call to te≈øtimonie the Romanes. And among the re≈øt, I cured a certain Gentleman called M. Ale≈ø≈øandor (I cannot remember his Sirname) who was wounded in divers places, and I cured him quickly. After that I cured, and that in ≈øhort time, a young man that was in manner cut in pieces, and of that M. Jacomo da Perugia, M. Ale≈ø≈øandro da Civita, M. Daltilo Hebraeo, all learned Doctors can te≈øtifie, for they were pre≈øent. And ≈øuch like cures I have alwaies done in Venice: But among the re≈øt I will not leave to write of a great chance, the which is true, and is thus: There is in Venice a rare Poet and Orator and Hi≈øtoriographer, well known unto the world called M. Dionigio Antanagi, who through his evill de≈øtinie was wounded in the head, ≈øo that it penetrated the fle≈øh and the bone, and entred half a finger breadth into the brain, and there that vertuous
man fell to the ground as a dead man, and he lifted him≈øelf up to ri≈øe, but he could not, but fell down again, and there came a dimne≈øs over his eyes, with a vomiting and and a Fever, and the blood would not ≈øtint, and he lay in extream pains, which were all mortall ≈øigns: then I being called unto that cure, becau≈øe he and I were of great familiaritie, and pre≈øently I ≈øhut the wound, and put therein our Aqua bal≈øami, and I annointed all his head with our Bal≈øamo artificiato; that being done, pre≈øently the blood ≈øtenched, and the pain went away, and the night after he took his re≈øt, and in the morning the Fever was al≈øo gone: After that, I dre≈ø≈øed him with Magno liquore, wetting clothes therein, and upon the cloth I ≈øtrewed the powder of Hypericon: And this Medicine I u≈øed eight daies, in the which time he came forth of his bed; and ≈øhortly after he was perfectly whole, and before ≈øix moneths were pa≈øt, it was ≈øo ≈øiccatrized, that no man could perceive any wound. And of this I have to te≈øtimony Venice, Rome, ∆≤rbine, Caglie, and all Italy. To conclude this Chapter, I ≈øay, that wite the afore≈øaid order, thou maye≈øt cure any ≈øuch ≈øort of wound.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. Of Wounds in the Head, with Fracture of the Bone.
div.p:
VVOunds in the Head, with Fracture of the bone, of the common Phy≈øicians and Chirurgians, are counted difficile to be healed, becau≈øe thereunto belongeth great art or cunning, for they open the fle≈øh and ra≈øpe the bone, with many other things, of which here I account it ≈øuperfluous to treat of, becau≈øe that many be helped without them. For alwayes when the Phy≈øitian or Chirurgian, doth defend the wound from alteration and corruption, nature it ≈øelf will work very well, and heal it without any other aid; but with our Medicines they may be helped with much more ≈øpeed, becau≈øe they let the alteration, and defendeth them from Putrifaction, and mittigateth the pain, and the order to cure tho≈øe kinds of wounds is thus: The fir≈øt thing that is to be done in tho≈øe wounds is, to joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and
dre≈ø≈øe them upon the wound with our Oleum Benedictum, and upon the oile lay clothes wet in our Magno liquore, as hot as you may ≈øuffer it, and ≈øo with the≈øe Remedies thou ≈øhalt help them quickly, becau≈øe our Oleum Benedictum taketh away the pains, and keepeth it from putrifaction, and repercu≈ø≈øeth: Our Magno liquore dige≈øteth, mundifieth, and incarnateth, and healeth. And therefore this is the be≈øt Medicine that can be u≈øed in the≈øe kinds of wounds. For hereof I have had an infinite of experiences, the which have been counted Miracles, and therefore I have let the world to under≈øtand thereof, that they may help them≈øelves, if occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve; therefore he that will follow this our order in curing, ≈øhall work Miracles on the earth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Of Wounds in the Head, where the bone is not offended.
div.p: VVOunds in the head where the bone is not hurt, are not of ≈øo great Importance, but are ea≈øie to be helped; for you ≈øhall need to doe nothing, but to keep it from putrifaction, and defend it from inflammation, which are ea≈øie to be done, and ≈øo Nature will work well with great ≈øpeed. To keep the wound from putrifaction, you ≈øhall annoint it round about with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina & Cera. And to keep it from Inflammation, you ≈øhall wa≈øh it with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and upon the wound dre≈ø≈øe it with our Magno liquore. Thus doing thy cure ≈øhall pro≈øper happily, and you ≈øhall not need to take away any blood, nor yet to keep any diet, nor yet to keep the hou≈øe, but to goe where you thinke good, without any perill or danger. And this Order I have u≈øed a long time, as divers Cities can te≈øtifie.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Of Contu≈øions‚ñ™ or brui≈øes, as well in the head, as other places.
div.p:
COntu≈øions, or brui≈øes in the head, or any other place of the body, of the antient Phy≈øitians hath been counted
dangerous to heal. For, they ≈øay, that Contu≈øions mu≈øt be brought to putrefaction, and turned into matter: which opinion I doe not allow: For by me tho≈øe Contu≈øions or brui≈øes, are very ea≈øie to be di≈ø≈øolved without maturation: And that I doe with our Oleo benedicto, and Magno liquore, as much of the one as of the other mixt together, and made very hot as you may ≈øuffer it, and then wet clothes therein twice a day, and in three or four dayes at the mo≈øt, they ≈øhall be re≈øolved: and this it doth, becau≈øe this remedy a≈ø≈øubtiliateth the humours, and openeth the pores, and draweth forth the matter that is runne unto the place offended, and ≈øo by tho≈øe means they ≈øhall be helped. With this remedy I have cured hundreds when I was in the warres in Africa, in Anno 1551. when the ≈øaid City was taken and de≈øtroyed by the Camp of Charles the fifth Emperour.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. Of Wounds in the neck, and the order to be u≈øed in curing them.
div.p: VVOunds in the neck are very perilous, and hard to be cured, and long before they will heal: and this cometh becau≈øe in it are all the ligaments of the head, as bones, ≈øinewes, veins, fle≈øh, and skin, all in≈øtruments that hold the head and the body together, without the which a man cannot live: and therefore tho≈øe wounds are ≈øo perilous to be healed, ≈øeeing thereunto runneth ≈øo great quantity of humours, that they will not ≈øuffer the wound to be healed. The true way therefore to help the≈øe wounds, is to ≈øtitch them well in his place, and dre≈ø≈øe it upon the wound with clothes wet in Oleum benedictum one part, and Magno liquore three parts mixt together, as hot as you can ≈øuffer it: and upon the cloth lay the powder of Mille folie: and this thou ≈øhalt doe once in four and twenty houres, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them quickly; giving you great charge, that you change not your Medicine, for this mundifieth, incarnateth, and healeth the wound without any further help: For I have proved it an infinite of times.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. Of wounds in the armes, and their importance, and Medicines.
div.p: VVOunds in the armes are dangerous, for that there al≈øo are a great number of Sinewes, Cartiligines, Veines, Muskles, and other dangerous things, as it is well ≈øeen in wounds of the armes, how that many times thereunto runneth abundance of humours, and there cometh alteration, inflammation, and impo≈øthumation, which hurteth the Patient much. Therefore in this ca≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee a rare ≈øecret, wherewith thou ≈øhalt help any ≈øort of wound in the arme, without any alteration, and with little pain, and the ≈øecret is this: Dre≈ø≈øe the wound upon the upper parts with our Magno liquore very warm, without any tenting at all: and this doe once a day and no more, and in any wi≈øe change not your Medicine: For with this thou maye≈øt help all wounds in the armes with great ≈øpeed: and it is one of the greate≈øt ≈øecrets that can be u≈øed for wounds in the armes, and proved by me infinite times.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. Of Wounds in the breast, as well peircing through, as other.
div.p:
ALl wounds in the brea≈øt are trouble≈øome, and very dangerous, as well they that peirce into the body, as others. And the cau≈øe is, for that the parts of the brea≈øt are compounded of Skin, Cartilages, Sinewes, Fle≈øh, and Bones. So that it cannot be but trouble≈øome and perilous. For where the ≈øinew parts be hurt, there ari≈øeth ever great pain, which for the mo≈øt part bringeth Fevers, and other accidents, and therefore is evill to cure. The cure of them is with our Bal≈øamo and Quinta e≈ø≈øentia. For the one taketh away the pain, and the other keepeth from alteration. But when they are peircing into the body, they are mo≈øt dangerous, becau≈øe the Chirurgian cannot tell certainly what part within the body
is offended or hurt. Either the Liver, or the Lungs, or the Milt, or any other particulars. Moreover, there is another matter which maketh it dangerous, which is, when they are penetrating, the matter that proceedeth from the Wound falleth into the body, as well as out. And remaining in the body cau≈øeth putrifaction, then Fevers follow, and commonly death. Wherefore in this ca≈øe, cau≈øe the Patient to vomit, and to keep ≈ølender diet, becau≈øe the humour ≈øhould not alter to the dammage of the wounded. And to pre≈øerve him from putrifaction, you ≈øhall annoint all his body over with our Bal≈øamo, and let him drink our Quinte≈ø≈øence morning and evening. And this done the cure ≈øhall pro≈øper, or el≈øe there is no hope by any other meanes.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX. Of Wounds in the belly, and in the reines, and their affects and Medicines.
div.p:
VVOunds in the belly are doubtfull, and very uncertain to cure, becau≈øe it is unpo≈ø≈øible to know how they are, or of what importance they be: for although yee may ≈øee the Orifice where the Weapon went in, yet yee cannot know what offence it hath done in the interiour parts, and therefore they are bard to be helped, and wor≈øe to judge of, and for that cau≈øe I will not ≈øtand long in rea≈øoning thereof: for I have determined not to ≈øpeak of things uncertain and doubtfull, but onely of things that may be proved by rea≈øon and experience. And becau≈øe tho≈øe wounds be uncertain, I will write nothing of them, for fear of hiding the truth: but I will write of tho≈øe in the reines or back, and fir≈øt I will ≈øhew what the reines are, becau≈øe every one may comprehend my rea≈øon. It is to be under≈øtood, that our bodies are made all of ≈øen≈øible things: as inwardly, the Stomack, the Heart, the Liver, the Lungs, the Belly, the Milt, the Guts, with a number of other things which are not common, or known to all men, as tho≈øe which I have ≈øpoken of. The re≈øt of the man is made of Cartilagines, of Veines, of Muskles, of Fle≈øh,
of Skin, and other particulars of ≈ømall importance to know, becau≈øe the wi≈øe, learned, and reverend, my Lord Canan Ferrare≈øe, hath writ thereof better then ever any in the world hath done, and therefore if you beleeve not me, beleeve his writing ≈øet forth in print. But to return to our purpo≈øe, I ≈øay, that God hath compounded the m ‚Ä¢ n naturally of all the≈øe things that I have ≈øpoken of: and becau≈øe they are ≈øoft and tender, he hath placed the bones in the midde≈øt of them to ≈øtrengthen them, and to keep them ≈øtreight, &c. And from the ≈øhoulder to the thigh, he hath made a great pillar, of many peices of bones joyned together: On the one part whereof groweth the ribs, which holdeth the fle≈øh, skin, and other particulars farre from the interiours: and upon that bone on the outward ≈øide, are the magi≈øtrall ≈øinewes that de≈øcend from the head, and bind all the back together, and reacheth down unto the feet. Therefore (this being true that I have ≈øaid) wounds in the head are very dangerous in all his actions, and their cure very hard, becau≈øe all tho≈øe ≈øences that give nouri≈øhment, pa≈ø≈øe by the reines downward to the lower parts: and mo≈øt commonly when a man is wounded in tho≈øe places, he remaineth lame on the leg that is on that part, and being, as it is, hard and dangerous, the cure of it, according to the Canons of the Ancients, is al≈øo perilous; becau≈øe in tho≈øe places where ≈øo many particulars doe meet and communicate, there ought not in any wi≈øe to be putrifaction, or dige≈øtion, but to pre≈øerve: You may not bring it to maturation, but to keep it from it; you may not incarnate, but with ≈øpeed heal it up: and ≈øo in this order the cure ≈øhall ≈øucceed well, and without danger. And this I will ≈øhew unto every one, becau≈øe he ≈øhall profit by our doctrine to the glory of God, and health of the wounded. When one is wounded in tho≈øe parts, I coun≈øell that the Chirurgian pre≈øently ≈øhall clo≈øe the wound with all his diligence, putting thereupon of our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia, and in≈øtead of a defen≈øive our Bal≈øamo, and upon the wound lay a cloth wet in our Magno liquore, and upon the cloth ≈øtrew our ≈øecret powder for wounds, and following this order, he ≈øhall be reputed for an excellent Chirurgian above all other: and this is the meer
truth as by mo≈øt evident proof thou ≈øhalt more largely find.

div.head: CHAP. XL. Of Wounds in the Legs, and tho≈øe parts.
div.p: VVOunds in the Legs are in manner of the ≈øame qualitie as tho≈øe in the armes, becau≈øe the Legs are of their proper qualitie and Nature compounded of the like ≈øub≈øtance that the Armes are, that is, skin, fle≈øh, muskles, veins, ≈øinews, and bones. And the≈øe when they are offended, or wounded, are very perilous, becau≈øe unto them runneth great quantitie of humours. And in the Legs are certain deadly places as a man may ≈øay: As the hinder part of the Caulf of the Leg: And the middle of the inner ≈øide of the thigh: The Ancle and the foot are all places trouble≈øome and curious to heal, when they are wounded. And therefore to heal them according to the manner of the Ancients, it were great trouble to the Chirurgian, and pittie to ≈øee the pain of the Patient. Wherefore in no wi≈øe u≈øe not the Medicines of the Ancients, but when thou ha≈øt occa≈øion, joyn unto the skill of thy Art, the u≈øe of the≈øe Medicines, our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia, Bal≈øamo, Magno Liquore, Oleo Benedicto, Oleo di Ra≈øa, Oleo Philo≈øophorum, any of the≈øe, or ≈øuch like, which are incorruptible, which by their proper qualitie a≈ø≈øubtiliateth contu≈øions, pierceth to the bottome of Wounds, keepeth the fle≈øh in his naturall caliditie and humiditie, pre≈øerveth from putrifaction, and naturally maketh the fle≈øh to joyn and grow together, and that in ≈øhort ≈øpace. Therefore con≈øider well which worketh better effect, ours or the Ancients: And u≈øe them at thy di≈øcretion.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. Of wounds that pierce into the bodie, and of their danger.
div.p:
VVOunds that pierce into the bodie are very perilous and mortall, becau≈øe the mo≈øt part of them cannot be cured by ordinary means, and e≈øpecially when the interiours are
ulcerated: In that ca≈øe the Phy≈øitian not ≈øeeing it, nor knowing the truth of the wound, cannot apply convenient Medicines, therefore he ≈øhall be much le≈ø≈øe apt to heal them, and therefore you mu≈øt ≈øtand to the benefit of Fortune. And of this I will di≈øcour≈øe nothing, for that it will be hard for me to ≈øhew that thing, that I cannot ≈øee with mine eies, nor touch with my hands: And becau≈øe this di≈øcour≈øe cannot be approved of the truth, and of experience, I will not meddle therewith in any wi≈øe: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will write of tho≈øe ≈øorts of wounds that are penetrative, and yet not offend the Intrals, for tho≈øe may be helped with ea≈øe, as I have cured a great number, and among the re≈øt in Anno 1551. in the moneth of June (as I remember) the 17. day, being in the Armie of Naples to go to Africa, there happened a great chance which was thus: The Captain Generall of the Gallies of Fiorenza, named Il Seignior Giordano Or≈øino ≈øitting at the Table with divers Captains and Gentlemen, among the re≈øt there was one Captain falling in talk with another, ≈øitting at the ≈øame Table, took a loafe of bread, and flang it at his face, then Seignior Giordano ≈øeeing that little re≈øpect of the Captain, ro≈øe from the Table and took him by the collar, and gave him five Stockadoes in the brea≈øt to have ≈ølain him, and left him lying: That being done, the ≈øaid Seignior Giordano repented him, and ≈øeeing that he was not yet dead, called for me being in the Galley with Don Gar≈øia de Toledo my General, and when I came, I found the poor Captain almo≈øt dead; whom I dre≈ø≈øed with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and twice a day I gave him to drinke of our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia, and gave him meats of good nouri≈øhment, and I never put tent into the wound, and in three daies he was helped, and of this the whole company, that was in the Gallie can te≈øtifie, and e≈øpecially the ≈øaid Seignior Giordano who did the fact. Then afterward in Affrica I cured an infinite number that were wounded in divers manners. And of the≈øe Experiences I have done and do yet daily, in ≈øo much that if I ≈øhould write of them, it would be tedious, and therefore I will ≈øtand no longer about matters concerning wounds, becau≈øe I have written a Di≈øcour≈øe upon Chirurgery, and Il Capricio Medicinale, in the which I have declared many things mo≈øt profitable in the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon old wounds which are not yet healed, with their Remedies.
div.p: WHen that wounds are evill healed, and that therein cometh Impo≈øthumation, and that the part wounded be indurated and full of pain. Then u≈øe this Secret of our Invention, which was never yet ≈øeen or heard of by the Ancients, nor yet in our time but of us. When thou finde≈øt ≈øuch a ca≈øe, wa≈øh the wound well, and make it clean round about, and then wa≈øh it with our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia Vegitabile, and bath it well through, for that the ≈øaid Quinte≈ø≈øence doth open the pores, and a≈ø≈øubtiliateth the matter, and cau≈øeth the humour to come forth. This being done, annoint all over with our Magno liquore, and this doing, within three daies the Patient ≈øhall feel great ea≈øe, and in ≈øhort time after he ≈øhall be whole. This is one of the noble≈øt Medicines that can be made, for it taketh away the hardne≈ø≈øe, healeth the wound, and comforteth the place offended.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. A rare Secret to heal wounds of Gun-≈øhot, Arrows or ≈øuch like in the wars, when they require ha≈øte.
div.p: IF thou wilt cure tho≈øe wounds, pre≈øently joyn the parts together, and wa≈øh it with our Aqua Cele≈øtis and Oleum Bal≈øami of our invention, and lay a cloth wet in the ≈øame thereon.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV. To heal a Wound quickly.
div.p: VVA≈øh the wound well with our Aqua Bal≈øami, and clo≈øe it up, and thereupon lay a cloth wet in the Oile of Frankincen≈øe, and ≈øo by this means thou ≈øhalt help any great wound quickly, for I have proved it infinite times, to my great honour.

div.head: CHAP. XLV. To help a Wound quickly, that is in danger of any accident.
div.p: VVOunds in ≈øome parts of the bodie, are very dangerous of life, and ≈øpecially where the ≈øinews be cut or pierced, or veins or muskles hurt, or bones broken, and by an infinite of other particulars, which being open, or evill healed, the Patient may be in danger of life, becau≈øe the winde entreth in, and they cau≈øe pains and inflammation, and therefore to avoid all the≈øe afore≈øaid matters, ≈øo that the wound ≈øhall have no detriment, u≈øe this remedy. Fir≈øt, joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and lay thereon a cloth, wet in our Balm, and bind it fa≈øt that the air get not in, for it is very hurtfull. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand that the≈øe are two of the excellente≈øt Medicines that may be found, becau≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate the bloud, and taketh it forth, and taketh away the pain, and the Balm doth warm and comfort the place offended, and will not ≈øuffer any matter to run thereunto by any means, for this is mo≈øt true, as I have proved divers and ≈øundry times, and alwaies have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI. To ≈øtay the Flux of Blood in Wounds.
div.p:
VVHen there is a Flux of Blood in any wound, by rea≈øon of ≈øome vein that is cut, and that the Chirurgian would ≈øtop it. It is nece≈ø≈øary that he put into it our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and then to ≈øtitch it up very clo≈øe and hard, and upon the wound ≈øtrew the blood of a man dried, made in powder, and lay upon the blood a cloth wet in our Balm artificiall very warm, and upon that bind the wound very ≈øtraight with ligaments. div.head: CHAP. XLVII. Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: FIr≈øt, ≈øtitch the wound clo≈øe, then ca≈øt thereon mans blood, and bind it ≈øomewhat hard, ≈øo let it remain 24. hours, and when you unbinde it, take heed you remove nothing, and ca≈øt thereon more dried blood, and annoint it round about with Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina & Cera, and binde it up again other four and twentie hours, and then bind it gently, and annoint the wound with Oyle of Frankincen≈øe, and in ≈øhort time it will be perfectly whole.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII. A Defence to be laid upon wounds.
div.p: TAke perfect Aqua vitae, of good wine, what quantitie you will, and put therein Hypericon, Millefolie, Viticella, and and Betonie, ana, then let it ≈øtand certain daies clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and when ye will u≈øe it, wet a cloth therein, and lay it round about the wound. CHAP. I. div.p:
THere hath alwayes been a great que≈øtioning among the Philo≈øophers, whether that one Med ‚Ä¢ cine might help again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes or no. The which I affirme, and will approve with ≈øufficient rea≈øon, that the Petra Philo≈øophale, made of our invention, may help again≈øt all the infirmities that cometh unto mans body‚ñ™ and two onely rea≈øons I will ≈øhew thee with brevity: The fir≈øt of them is this, that all ≈øorts of infirmities have their originall and beginning of the Stomack, and to know the truth, yee may ≈øee manife≈øtly, that if the body be never ≈øo little infirmed, the ≈øtomack is al≈øo grieved: For yee may ≈øee how the Animals tere≈øtriall, never help them≈øelves of other infirmity then of the ≈øtomack, and when they will help them≈øelves, they eat hearbs, the which cau≈øeth them to vomit, and this doth ≈øignifie that they have no other infirmity, then the afore≈øaid; ≈øo by the experience of the Animals, I approve that the infirmity is cau≈øed of the ≈øtomack, and this is the fir≈øt rea≈øon. The ≈øecond is, that all the Medicines, wherein our Petra Philo≈øophale is put, as ≈øoon as they are come into the ≈øtomack, it draweth unto it all the evill humours of the ≈øtomack, and al≈øo of the
whole body, and mixeth with them, and ≈øo nature ≈øendeth them forth by vomit, or by ≈øeege, or both, and ≈øo the ≈øtomack ≈øhall be evacuated of that matter, and the body remain free from all impediments of infirmities, ≈øo that by this rea≈øon I affirm, that our Petra Philo≈øophale may help again≈øt all ≈øorts of infirmities. And to know the truth, I have proved it by experience in all manner of infirmities, and alwayes have found it to doe much good unto all men, and hurt none unto my knowledge, and the order to make this Petra Philo≈øophale, is thus.
Take Sal Niter, roche Allome, Vitrioll Romain, of each two pound.

div.head: CHAP. II. To make our Balm artificiall, with the order to u≈øe it, and wherefore it ≈øerveth.

Beate all tho≈øe afore≈øaid things together, and put them into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and put thereto ≈øix pound of rectified Aqua vitae without flegme, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand eight dayes, and then di≈øtill it by Sand, and there will come forth a white water

The fir≈øt water is mo≈øt excellent to clear and pre≈øerve the ≈øight of the eyes, al≈øo the face being wa≈øhed therewith, it maketh it very fair, and pre≈øerveth it youthfully, it keepeth back age, it breaketh the gravell in the reines, and provoketh Urine, the which is ≈øtopped through carno≈øitie, it helpeth all manner of wounds, in what place of the body ≈øoever they be, if yee wa≈øh them with the ≈øaid water, and wet therein clouts and lay thereon, for his operation is ≈øo ≈øtrange, that it ≈øeemeth rather divine then humane. div.head: CHAP. III. To make our Aromatico, the which helpeth again≈øt all manner of infirmities, of what qualitie ≈øoever they be.
div.p: ARomatico Leonardo, is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it was compounded and made by his invention, and is a miraculous Medicine, that ≈øerveth again≈øt all manner of di≈øea≈øes, of what qualitie ≈øoever they be, for it worketh this operation, that is, a≈ø≈øoon as it joyneth to the ≈øtomack, it draweth to it all the evill humours of the bodie, and imbraceth them, and carrieth them forth by vomit and ≈øeege, and ≈øo leaveth Nature unburdened, the which may prevail to his plea≈øure becau≈øe it hath no impediment, and by this rea≈øon I approve that our Aromatico helpeth again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes; as is ≈øaid before, and the order to make it is thus.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. To make our Electuario Angelico, and the order to u≈øe it, and in what di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: ELectuario, Angelico Romano is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it was compounded of me in the Citie of Rome, in the time of the Pope Paulo quarto, and becau≈øe this compo≈øition worketh divinely, I called it Angelico, and is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt many di≈øea≈øes, it is good again≈øt all ≈øorts of Fevers, giving it Per-minorativo, and for the Stitch in the ≈øide it is mo≈øt rare, becau≈øe it taketh away the vi≈øco≈øitie in the Stomack, and openeth the Pores, and is good again≈øt the Gout; for if they take it every third day once, in ten daies they ≈øhall be helped. Petra Philo≈øophale, ‚Ñ•. iii. our Quinte≈ø≈øence of wine ‚Ñ•. ii. purified Honie as much as will ≈øuffice to make it in form of an Electuarie, mixe them on a ≈ømall fire in an earthen-pan, and when it is made, keep it in a

div.head: CHAP. V. Our Sirrup Solutivo, with the Order to u≈øe it.
div.p: SOluble Sirrups made in decoction are very whol≈øome and of great facultie, and ≈øpecially in the crudity of humours, and the rea≈øon is this, becau≈øe it di≈øper≈øeth the matter, and evacuateth it with great ea≈øe, and without danger or trouble of the Patient, and the order to make it is thus.

BEcau≈øe the Poxe is a di≈øea≈øe contagious, putrified, and corrupt, and worketh many evill Effects, as I have written in my Caprici Medicinali. Therefore it were nece≈ø≈øary to prepare

Coloquintida, í. vi. Sugar ‚Ñ•. viii. then let it boil till half be boyled away, and that there remain vii. pound, then ≈øtrein it, and put it in a gla≈ø≈øe with xii. grains of Musk, and keep it very clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and this is the Sirrup, the which ye ≈øhall take twice a day, that is morning and evening; then make this drink following, the which ≈øhall be the common drink at all times to your meat.

≈øimples in manner uncorruptible, and is mo≈øt miraculous for tho≈øe that are corrupted, or ≈øtrucken with the Pe≈øtilence, becau≈øe it is mo≈øt penetrative, and of nature drying, and comforteth all weak parts in mans bodie, of what infirmitie ≈øo ever they be, and the order to make it is thus.

Take new yellow waxe, ‚Ñ•. xii. clear Turpentine, ‚Ñ•. xviii. Benjamine, ‚Ñ•. ii. Fine rectified Aqua vitae, ‚Ñ•. xxx. common a≈øhes, ‚Ñ•. vi. mixe them, and put them into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and then di≈øtill it in a winde Furnace, untill the ≈øu≈øtance be come forth, and in the Receiver thou ≈øhalt find three things: The fir≈øt is Water, the ≈øecond Oil, the third flegm, the which thou ≈øhalt ≈øeparate one from another, and keep them clo≈øe ≈øtopt in a gla≈ø≈øe, the which is mo≈øt excellent in time of the Pe≈øtilence, as well for unction, as for to help the ≈øores, for if you put it into a ≈øore or botch that is broke, pre≈øently it taketh away the pain, and being mixed with other of our Medicines, as I have ≈øhewed in my Regiment of the Pe≈øtilence, it helpeth them with great ≈øpeed. If any annoint all his bodie with this Oyle twi≈øe a moneth, it will pre≈øerve him youthfull, and in health a long time, it pre≈øerveth al≈øo dead fle≈øh or fi≈øh, that is put therein from corruption. Al≈øo if any be wounded in any part of the bodie, let him annoint it with this Oyle four or five times, and it ≈øhall be whole: Al≈øo if any cannot make water, give unto him í. ii. of this oyle to drinke, and pre≈øently he ≈øhall make water. It is al≈øo good again≈øt the Stitch in the ≈øide and Pluri≈øie, and Worms, and the Cough and Catarre, and again≈øt the Pe≈øtilent Fever, and ≈øuch like indi≈øpo≈øitions, if ye drinke a little thereof; it hath a number of other vertues, the which I will leave unto the Experimentors.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Our Magno liquore, the which is of great vertue.
div.p:
THis is of my invention, and the order to make it, is thus Take ≈øweet Sallet oile twentie pound, white wine two pound, boil them together untill the wine be con≈øumed, then
put it in a ve≈ø≈øell of ≈øtone, and put thereunto the≈øe things following:

Take the flours of Ro≈øemary three pound, Lignum aloes, ‚Ñ•. vi. Olibanum, Bdellium, ana. ‚Ñ•. x. then ≈øtop it very clo≈øe, and bury it in the ground four foot deep, and this would be buried in the beginning of Augu≈øt, and there rema ‚Ä¢ n untill the moneth of March, then take it forth of the ground, and ≈øet it in the Sun, and put thereto the≈øe matters following, Sage, Ro≈øemary, Rue, Betonie, Millefolie, Comferie roots, Tamaro, Viticella ana, one handful: Galingal, Cloves, Nutmegs, Spikenard, Saffron, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Sarcocolla, Sanguis Draconis in grain, Ma≈øtick, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. Aloes Epatica, Frankincen≈øe, ana ‚Ñ•. viii. yellow Wax, Auxungia ana ‚Ñ•. xviii. Colophonie one pound, Hypericon with the ≈øeed and all two pound. Musk í. i. mix the≈øe all well together, and boil them in Balneo, untill the herbs become dry, and have no more ≈øub≈øtance, then take it forth, and ≈øtrain it, and put thereunto for every pound, í. vi. of our Balm artificiall, and when the moneth of September cometh, put thereunto two pound of the fruit of the herb called Bal≈øamina, the which are red, and then it is ended, the which thou ≈øhalt keep in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, for the older it is, the better it is, and is of ≈øuch vertue, that it helpeth the Etici, and Hidrop≈øie, if ye give them every morning í. ≈øs. with ‚Ñ•. i. of Sirrup of Ro≈øes warm, the ≈øpace of fortie daies, as I have proved: And this is the true and perfect Unction, that helpeth Petecchie, a di≈øea≈øe ≈øo called in the Italian: If any were wounded, and had cut veins, ≈øinews, and bones, let him joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and dre≈ø≈øe it with this Oyle very hot upon the upper parts, and in ≈øhort time it ≈øhall be whole, without any alteration. It helpeth al≈øo the white Scall if ye annoint it therewith: It helpeth coldne≈ø≈øe in the head, and Catarrs, if ye annoint it within the no≈øtrils at night when ye go to bed: If yee annoint the Stomack therewith it cau≈øeth perfect dige≈øtion of the meat, it provoketh Urine where it is let through carno≈øitie or Gonorrea, or ≈øuch like matter; It cau≈øeth hair to grow, it pre≈øerveth the beard black, and it is good again≈øt Worms, and all the≈øe Experiments are true, and proved of me divers and ≈øundry times, in the afore≈øaid infirmities, and al≈øo in divers
others, the which I leave untill another time: Yee ≈øhall note, that if yee annoint any all over that is greived with the Pox with this Oil, it will increa≈øe his pain, and ≈øo by that meanes yee may know whether he be infected or no.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Pillole Aquilone of our invention.
div.p: THe≈øe Pills are above all other in operation, as the Eagle is above all other Birds, and therefore I thought good to call them Pillole Aquilone, and the order to make them is thus.

Take con≈øerve of Damask Ro≈øes made with Hony ‚Ñ• iii. Lignum Aloes í. i. Oyl of Vitriol twelve graines, Cinnamon elect ii ≈øcruples. Petra philo≈øophalis of our invention. ‚Ñ• ≈øs. Sugar-candie ‚Ñ• ii. Mix them, and make thereof a pa≈øte with Syrupo Aceto≈øo and keep them in a gla≈øs. The Vertue of the≈øe Pills I will not at this time write: but onely I ≈øay they help again≈øt all ≈øorts of infirmities, and hurteth none in any wi≈øe. The Do≈øe is from í. i. to í. ii. in the morning fa≈øting, but ye may not gild them in any wi≈øe, but drink after them a cup of water or wine, to carrie them down, then ≈øleep thereon, and that day eat little meat. and light of dige≈øtion.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, the which is of marvellous operation in divers matters.
div.p: THis Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva evacuateth the body with great ea≈øe, and without any detriment, and it purgeth all parts of the body that are troubled with gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, it re≈øolveth ≈øwellings, and taketh away the paines, it pre≈øerveth the ≈øight, and killeth wormes, and cau≈øeth a good appetite, with many other good qualities, the which I will leave at this time, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Aloes, Cinnamon, Turbite, Aloes Epatica, ana ‚Ñ•. i Coloquintida
‚Ñ•. ii. Cloves, Saffron, of each í. i. Musk of Levant í. i. Julep of Violets one pound. Mix all the afore≈øaid matters together in a gla≈ø≈øe, and put therein two pound of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand twelve dayes, and then ≈øtrain it, and put it into a ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, this may be taken with broth, wine, or with what ≈øirrup or potion yee will, the quantity is from í. ii. to ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. in the morning fa≈øting, without keeping of any diet at all, and it ≈øhall work well without any trouble.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Pillole Magi≈øtrale, the which is good again≈øt divers infirmities.
div.p: THe≈øe Pills are of great vertue, and ≈øpecially again≈øt all kind of paines coming of corrupt humours, for they purge the putrified humours, and pre≈øerve the body from corruption: and the order to make them is thus.

Take Olibanum, Ma≈øtick, Mirrh, Sarcocolla, Aloes Epatiee, Elleborus niger, Saffron, Turbith, Colloquintida, ana q. v. Stamp them finely, and for every ounce of the afore≈øaid matters, put thereunto two Carets of Musk, and then incorporate it with Hony of Ro≈øes, and Aqua vitae, of each alike, and this pa≈øte thou maye≈øt keep for ≈øix moneths in a ve≈ø≈øell of Lead, the quantity is from í. ii. to í. iii. in the morning fa≈øting, and drink thereon a little wine. The≈øe pills are mo≈øt excellent to take away the paines of the Gout, and to pre≈øerve a man from it, they are al≈øo good for tho≈øe that have the French Pox, becau≈øe they evacuate the gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, and maintain the body in good temperature, and u≈øing them in tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes, it pre≈øerveth the body in good ≈øtate. They are al≈øo good for women that are troubled with paines of the Mother, and retention of their Termes, for the≈øe are aperative, and provoke them, and purgeth the Matrix of all impediments contained therein: They ≈øerve again≈øt the Megrem, and all paines of the head, and al≈øo again≈øt all kind of putrified Fevers, as I have ≈øeen the experience thereof ≈øundry times.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. To make Aqua reale, vel Imperiale, the which maketh the teeth white pre≈øently, incarnateth the Gums, and cau≈øeth a good breath.
div.p: THe teeth being black and ru≈øtie, and full of filth, and the Gums putrified or corrupt, are the wor≈øt things that may be ≈øeen in man or woman, and are al≈øo very unwhol≈øome; and the Remedie to make the teeth white, and to help the gumms, is thus: Make this water, and u≈øe it in this order as I will ≈øhew thee.

Take Sal Gemmae, Roch Allum, Brim≈øtone of each two pound, Borax ‚Ñ•. x. Pearl beat fine, Corall, each ‚Ñ•. ii. Pure di≈øtilled Vinegar ‚Ñ•. iiii. Put all the afore≈øaid matters in a Goord, with his head and receiver, and give it fire according to Art, and at the la≈øt there will come forth a white water like Milk, the which after it hath ≈øtood a while, will waxe clear. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this water is above all other waters in the world, to help Ulcers in the mouth, and to incarnate the gums, and to make the teeth white, and cau≈øeth a good breath in tho≈øe which are troubled with the afore≈øaid matters. For of this water I have made great quantitie, and it hath been carried into Spain, into Almain, into Poland, into Con≈øtantinople, and in divers other Countries, as though it had been a Divine thing, and not material.

For truly this experience doth cau≈øe the world to wonder at it, the u≈øe hereof I have written in this Book, and hereafter I will write it again in ≈øome of my Books, where occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve to u≈øe it in cures.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the hidden Secrets of Frankincen≈øe.
div.p:
THe Pine is a tree, the which by nature is uncorruptible, and the gum that runs from it is of great vertue and ≈øtrength, becau≈øe it pre≈øerveth tho≈øe things wherein it is put, and when
his Elements are ≈øeparated out of that Gum, the Phy≈øician may work ≈øtrange things therewith, again≈øt mo≈øt part of infirmities that happen unto mans bodie, if he apply them where they are convenient: For the water being drunke helpeth winde in the ≈øtomack: Al≈øo it helpeth the white Skall, and all ≈øuch like ≈øcabs, if ye wa≈øh them therewith morning and evening. It drieth up Ulcers, al≈øo it is of marvellous vertue again≈øt chilblains and kibed heels, and chapps, and ≈øuch like, in the hands or feet that come through cold, being u≈øed thus. You ≈øhall fir≈øt perfume the parts that are ≈øore over the fume of hot water, ≈øo that they may ≈øweat, then drie them and wa≈øh them with the afore≈øaid water, and annoint them with the Oil, and put on a pair of gloves or ≈øuch like, and in very ≈øhort time they ≈øhall be whole. The aire helpeth much in wounds in any part of the bodie, becau≈øe it pre≈øerveth the fle≈øh from putrifaction, and keepeth it from alteration, and taketh away the paine and healeth the ≈øore: Al≈øo it pre≈øerveth the face if it be annointed therewith. Moreover, it is marvellous in old di≈øea≈øes inwardly, if ye give them thereof every morning í i. with ‚Ñ• ≈øs. of our Sirupo Vegetabile. The fire cureth ≈øores and ≈øuch like, and the earth remaineth in his ≈øtate. Ye ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the≈øe are great ≈øecrets of importance, the which I have revealed of this Gumme, and happy ≈øhall he be that u≈øeth them in the time of need: And the order to make this Oile is thus.

Take as much Frankincen≈øe as thou wilt, and put it into a Retort of gla≈øs, with the fourth part of common A≈øhes, and ≈øet it to di≈øtill, and give it fir≈øt a ≈ømall fire untill the Oyle change colour, then pre≈øently change the Receiver, and augment the fire untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth. Ye ≈øhall under≈øtand that this Oyle is be≈øt fre≈øh, for when it is old, it will waxe thick, and cannot pierce ≈øo well.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Oyle of Honie, and the order to make it.
div.p:
THat which mo≈øt men call Oyle of Honey, is not an Unctous Oyle like unto other Oyles, but rather a certain
Element, the which is neither oyle nor water, although it be clear, and this ≈øerveth not much in Chirurgery, becau≈øe it is not convenient in ≈øores, but much rather it is a perfect remedie in things appertaining to Phy≈øick, becau≈øe it comforteth the Stomack, and fortifieth the vertue, and extingui≈øheth all ≈øorts of Fevers. It helpeth the Collick, it di≈ø≈øolveth the Stone in the Reins, and provoketh Urine, and al≈øo maketh the hair yellow as gold, if ye wa≈øh it therewith, and the order to make it is thus.

Take pure Honey two pound, and put it into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe, that holdeth at the lea≈øt fifteen or twentie pounds, and ≈øet it in a Furnace, and give it a fire of the ≈øecond degree, and fir≈øt there will come forth a clear white water, and when it changeth colour, change the receiver, and give it ≈øtrong fire untill all the fumes be come forth, the which is the Oile, and that keep by it ≈øelf as a precious Balm again≈øt malign Infirmities that are cured with Phy≈øick.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. To make our great Cerot, the which is of marvellous vertue.
div.p:
TAke Galbanum, Armoniacum, Oppoponax, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. Olibanum, Verdigrea≈øe, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Bdellium, Gum Arabi, Lapis ematites minerale, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. Turpentine, Frankincen≈øe, ana ‚Ñ•. iiii. Oleum Philo≈øophorum of Turpentine and Waxe, ‚Ñ•. iii. common Oyle four lb. new waxe ‚Ñ•. vii. beat all tho≈øe that are to be beat, and ≈øearce them, then di≈ø≈øolve the Gums in di≈øtilled Vinegar according to Art, then vapour away the Vinegar untill it come thick, then take thy Oyle and Waxe, and melt them together, then put in the re≈øt, and ≈øtir them untill it be boyled, and to know when it is boyled, is this. Fir≈øt, in the beginning it will begin to ri≈øe marvellou≈øly, and then fall down; then let it boil untill it begin to fume or ≈ømoak, then ≈øtrein it into a ve≈ø≈øell of Copper, and pre≈øently put therein ‚Ñ•. iiii. of Precipitate, and ≈øtir them well together untill it be cold, then make it in rowls, and keep it as a precious Jewell in Chirurgerie, becau≈øe it mundifieth, incarnateth, and healeth all
≈øorts of Ulcers, better then any other Cerot that ever I could finde.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. A Magi≈øtrall ∆≤nguent that healeth all manner of ≈øores.
div.p: THis Unguent is mo≈øt rare in the cure of Ulcers when they are already mundified, becau≈øe it incarnateth, drieth, and ≈øiccatrizeth, and the order to make it is thus.

Take common Oyle one pound, Litarge ‚Ñ•. ii. new Wax, ‚Ñ•. iii. Turpentine, ‚Ñ•. vi. boyl them as the afore≈øaid Cerot, and when it is boyled, put thereto ‚Ñ•. iii. of the dead cope of Aqua fortis, the which is made of Vitriol Romain, Roche Allom, and Salt-Peter, and ≈øtir them well together, and keep it to thy u≈øe. Ye ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the maker mu≈øt be expert in the Art, lea≈øt he overboil it, or boil it too little, for if it be not in order as it ≈øhould be, it will not work his effect.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. A Magi≈øtrall Cerot of our Invention again≈øt the white Scall.
div.p:
THis Cerot is of great vertue, and of marvellous experience, to re≈øolve the white Scall, becau≈øe it is penetrative, mundificative, and re≈øolutive, and cau≈øeth the hair to grow that is fallen away, to the great content of the Patient and honour of the Phy≈øician, and it is made in this otder. Take Frankincen≈øe that is ≈øtrained from his filth, what quantitie you will, and di≈øtill it in a Retort, and give it fire at the lea≈øt fortie hours, then let it cool and break the gla≈ø≈øe, and in the bottome thou ≈øhalt finde a black ma≈øe, the which make into powder, then for every pound of the ≈øaid powder, put thereto one ounce of Waxe, and four ounces of the ≈øaid oyle that ye di≈øtilled, and half an ounce of the heads of Bees, the which are ea≈øie to be had in Summer: Mix all the afore≈øaid things in a Ve≈ø≈øell of Copper, and with a ≈ømall fire make them in form of a liquid Unguent, and when thou wilt
u≈øe it, ≈øhave the head, and wa≈øh it, and lay thereon this Cerot upon a fair cloth warm, and every two days change it, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt ≈øee ≈øtrange effects of his vertue, as I have done divers and ≈øundry times to my great honour. This ≈øerveth al≈øo again≈øt breaking of bones, di≈ølocations, and for Scabs ulcerated, becau≈øe it drieth, and comforteth, and re≈øolveth all the evill qualities; giving you charge in the di≈øtilling, becau≈øe the fire many times con≈øumeth it ≈øo, that in the bottome there remaineth nothing that good is, and therefore beware in the making.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. To make a divine and ble≈ø≈øed Cerot again≈øt divers infirmities.
div.p: ULcers are of divers ≈øorts, and are cau≈øed of ≈øundry cau≈øes, as of Choller, Bloud, Flegme, Melancholy, and for that cau≈øe the Medicines would be agreeable; neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee a Cerot of ≈øuch a temperature, that it will ≈øerve to help any ≈øore in any place of the body, of what quality ≈øoever it be, except it be Scirro, or Noli me tangere, the which are in a manner counted uncurable, of the common Practitioners: but not by me, for I have cured them, and the order to make it is thus.

Take oil of Frankincen≈øe one pound, oil of Sulphur ‚Ñ•. i. Vitrioll rubified ‚Ñ•. iii. Precipate ‚Ñ•. i. fre≈øh Butter ‚Ñ•. iii. and as much Wax as will ≈øuffice to make it in form of a Cerot, the which will have all the afore≈øaid intentions: becau≈øe the Precipitate doth mundifie the Ulcer; the oil of Frankincen≈øe taketh away the pain, and incarnateth; the oil of Sulphur clean≈øeth; the Vitrioll drieth; the Butter mundifieth; and the Wax con≈øolidateth, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that any one may perceive his vertue.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. To make a miraculous Emplai≈øter for Flegmon, or Eri≈øipella.
div.p: THis Flegmon or inflammation, called Saint Anthonies fire, is a tumour cau≈øed of the alteration of the bloud, by rea≈øon of ≈øuperfluous heat, and this mo≈øt commonly cometh unto Cholerick and Sanguine bodies, that are full of fle≈øh, and have much bloud: And the Eri≈øipella is cau≈øed of a windy humidity, and of a hot humour, and to ≈øhew it, yee may ≈øee how that Flegmon is no other then bloud that runneth to the place offended: And when it cannot find way to re≈øolve, it putrifieth and turneth into Sanius matter, ≈øo that by this yee may ≈øee that to be true which I have ≈øaid. Al≈øo Eri≈øipella is a wind hot and moi≈øt, for when it cometh to ≈øuppuration, then cometh forth nothing but wind and water, and this is the true proof by demon≈øtration, and therefore ≈øeeing that the≈øe two infirmities are in a manner alike, or little differing: this Medicine ≈øhall be appropriate as well to the one as to the other, becau≈øe it re≈øolveth and cooleth, and the order to make it is thus.

Take fine Clay that hath no ≈øtones nor gravell in it, and ≈øearce it very fine, and put it in a pot, and for every pound thereof put thereto ‚Ñ•. iii. of Oil of Frankincen≈øe, that cometh forth la≈øt in the di≈øtillation, and as much of our Quinte≈ø≈øence as will ≈øerve to make it in form of a liquid Unguent, and this yee mu≈øt mix without fire, and then lay it upon a cloth, and warm it over the fire a little, and lay it upon the Flegmon, or Eri≈øipella, but fir≈øt ere yee u≈øe this remedy unto tho≈øe that have Flegmon, yee ≈øhall give them a do≈øe of our Electuario Angelica, and in Eri≈øipella give them a do≈øe of our Aromatico, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them perfectly, as I have proved divers times, and may be u≈øed although yee take no bloud; but if yee take bloud, let it be in augmentu, and not in ≈øtatu, nor in declinatione, becau≈øe it would ≈øo weaken Nature, that afterward it cannot defend it ≈øelf to drive forth the humour peccant, that is cau≈øe of the di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. To make a re≈øolutive Plai≈øter of great vertue.
div.p: THis Plai≈øter is to re≈øolve tumours and hardne≈ø≈øe, if it be layed thereon very hot, and when it is cold to lay on another: and this yee ≈øhall doe untill the hardne≈ø≈øe be re≈øolved, and it is made in this order.

Take common A≈øhes that are well burnt and white, and finely ≈øearced one pound, Clay beat into fine powder half a pound, Carabe ‚Ñ•. iii. mix all the≈øe in an earthen di≈øh on a ≈ømall fire, with Oil of Ro≈øes in form of a liquid Unguent, and that yee ≈øhall lay upon the place greived as hot as yee may ≈øuffer it, and change it morning and evening, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee it work a marvellous effect. Moreover, when that Petecchi cometh forth of a di≈øea≈øed, let him be folded in the ≈øame remedy very hot, and in 24 houres he ≈øhall be helped, if he be fir≈øt well purged, for this is a great ≈øecret that I have revealed. This word Petecchi is, as it were, certain ≈øpots like tho≈øe which we call Gods Tokens, the which commonly come unto tho≈øe that have the Pe≈øtilent Fever.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. To make a maturative Plai≈øter of great vertue.
div.p: THis Maturative doth open an Impo≈øthume without In≈øtrument and pain, and the order to make it is thus

Take the yolks of Eggs ‚Ñ•. ii. white Salt finely ground ‚Ñ•. i. Snails with their Shells ≈øtamped ‚Ñ•. ≈øs Hens dung that is liquid, and red like Hony ‚Ñ•. i. Mix all the≈øe well together without fire, and when you will bring an Impo≈øthume to ≈øuppuration and break it, lay on this plai≈øter morning and evening a little warm, and in ≈øhort time it will draw forth the Impo≈øthume, and break it, and heal it, without any other help. Keep this as a ≈øecret.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. A compo≈øition of great vertue, again≈øt all ∆≤lcers and Sores.
div.p: TAke Oil of Vitrioll that is perfect, as much as you will, and put it in a gla≈øs, with as much oyle of Tartar made by di≈ø≈øolution, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand ten daies. Then take í. i. of that and ‚Ñ•. i. of pure Aqua vitae, and mixe them together, and therewith wa≈øh the hollow Ulcers, and they will heal in ≈øhort time. It helpeth any crude kinde of ≈øcab or ≈øore that is cau≈øed of the evill qualitie of Nature.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. A ≈øtrange compo≈øition of great vertue.
div.p: THis Compo≈øition is divine in his operation, becau≈øe it healeth many indi≈øpo≈øitions in our bodies, when it is applied rightly, and the order to make it is thus.

Take water of Carduus Sanctus one pound, Oyle of Honnie, one ounce, oyle of Sulphur, í. ≈øs. Mixe them together, and let it ≈øettle till it be cleer: for this helpeth Ulcers in the mouth, and maketh the teeth fair and white, if yee wa≈øh them therewith. It cau≈øeth a ≈øweet breath, and pre≈øerveth the Gums, and maketh the hair and beard fair, if ye wa≈øh them therewith. And this it doth becau≈øe the water of Carduus Sanctus pre≈øerveth where it is applyed: Al≈øo the oyle of Honie hath a vertue pre≈øervative and retentive of the hair, and the oyle of Sulphur mundifieth, and clen≈øeth, and incarnateth, ≈øo that by the≈øe means the ≈øaid water hath the≈øe vertues afore≈øaid.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. To make an ∆≤nguent of great Vertue again≈øt ∆≤lcers.
div.p:
THis Unguent hath a great vertue in healing all ≈øores that are putrified and corro≈øive, except they be Cankers or Noli me tangere, the which are counted among the uncurable
cures: But when they are other ≈øores, this will heal them quickly, and the order to make it is thus.

Take a good quantity of Calex vivae, and put it into a great Tub, and cover it with water four fingers high, and ≈øtir it well together, then let it ≈øettle, and thereon will come a thin ≈øcum the which ye ≈øhall gather together with a Scummer, and keep it untill ye have ≈øufficient quantitie, then take oyle of Lin≈øeed, oyle of Nuts, oyle of Almonds, and of the ≈øaid ≈øcum that is gathered, of each one pound, then di≈øtill it in a Retort, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, then ≈øeparate the oyle from the water, and then make this compo≈øition.

Take of the ≈øaid oyle di≈øtilled one pound, Tallow ≈øuch as they make candles of, Hogs grea≈øe, new Wax, Mercurie precipitate of each two ounces, fine Aqua vitae iii. ounces, mix them all together in a Copper pan on a ≈øoft fire, untill the Aqua vitae be con≈øumed, and that it remain a liquid Unguent, then take it forth, and keep it in a clo≈øe ve≈ø≈øell, that it take no ayre: and this ye ≈øhall apply cold unto Ulcers, upon a fine linnen cloth, for fir≈øt it doth mundifie, and then incarnate, and la≈øt ≈øiccatrize, it helpeth ≈øores, ≈øcabs, ≈øcrophule, mall de Formica Setole on the Nipples of womens brea≈øts, Emeroids, pains in the privie members, and ≈øuch like, for it is temperate.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon ≈øundry ≈øorts of ∆≤nguents, and their qualities.
div.p:
THere are many ≈øorts of Unguents that are found out, of which I beleeve that many Chirurgians are greatly abu≈øed of their operation, but for that which I doe finde, that ≈øome ≈øorts of Unguents are occupied for one effect, and they work another; as for example, ∆≤nguento Camphorato which many doe occupie to cool hot ≈øores, in ≈øtead of cooling heateth them more then they were before, which cometh by means of the Camphire which is a hot ≈øub≈øtance, as I will prove by ≈øufficient rea≈øon that it cannot be denied. For you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that into ∆≤nguento Camphorato, is put Camphire and
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
oyle, both hot materials, as for experience: Take Camphire and lay it by the fire, or ≈øet it nigh a candle, and thou ≈øhalt perceive, that a≈ø≈øoon as it feeleth the heat, it will flie into the fire and burn fiercely; and the like will the Oyle do; for if you wet a cloth therein and hold it over the fire, pre≈øently it will burn, which are manife≈øt ≈øigns that they be both hot, becu≈øe they are friends unto the fire; whereas if they were cold and moi≈øt, the fire would not burn them with ≈øuch force. As for example, take water, earth, ≈øtones, and mettals that are cold and moi≈øt, and lay them on the fire, and you ≈øhall ≈øee that the flame of a candle ≈øhall not be able to kindle the fire with ≈øuch ea≈øe as it doth with the Camphire and oyle. So that you may ≈øee that Camphire and Oyle are hot and friends unto the fire which is mo≈øt hot, and earth, ≈øtones, and mettalls, are moi≈øt and cold, and are enemies unto the fire, and therefore I conclude, that ∆≤nguento Camphorato is very hot, and cannot by any meanes cool hot Ulcers. Al≈øo ∆≤nguentum Apo≈øtolorum is a compo≈øition in which there is put Verdigriece, a materiall which is mo≈øt enemie unto the ≈øore, for laying it thereto cau≈øeth great pain, as you may under≈øtand of tho≈øe that have proved it, and in my judgement this is no Unguent to be laid on a ≈øore, becau≈øe they cannot ≈øuffer it, neither is it po≈ø≈øible to heal the ≈øore with that Unguent, for that it corrodeth the fle≈øh and will not let it heal. Al≈øo ∆≤nguento de minio is a mixture not very profitable for Ulcers, becau≈øe it is too much drying; for applying it unto a ≈øore that is not mundified, it drieth it in Superficie, ≈øo that if Nature ≈øend humours unto tho≈øe parts, and they find no exhalation or vent by rea≈øon of that drying, it will cau≈øe the gathering of abundance of humours, and be a means of greater mi≈øchief: But if the ≈øore be well mundified and clean≈øed, you ≈øhall have little need of that Unguent, becau≈øe Nature will doe it alone without any other help, ≈øo that this Unguent is of ≈ømall profit to be u≈øed of any. But to the contrary, there are many ≈øorts of Unguents which are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to dre≈ø≈øe ≈øores, as ∆≤nguento di Ra≈øino, which by his Nature is friendly to the ≈øore, becau≈øe it mundifieth and healeth, helping Nature that it may work with greater ≈øpeed. The Diachilone
commune is al≈øo an Unguent very profitable to mundifie or purge ≈øores, and likewi≈øe to ≈øiccatrize them. The Unguent of Litarge is refri≈øcative and drying, and healeth ≈øcabs, and cooleth the heat of the fle≈øh alterated. ∆≤nguento Ro≈øato doth mittigate the pains of foul Scabs. And thus di≈øcour≈øing from time to time, there are many ≈øorts of Unguents very hurtfull, and not to be u≈øed, and al≈øo there are many ≈øorts that are whole≈øome and good, without which in a manner they cannot work. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it were nece≈ø≈øary to know how and where to apply them rightly.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Medicines appropriate again≈øt all kindes of Poy≈øons, as well Vegetables as Minerals.
div.p:
THere are an infinite number of Poy≈øons, and they are differing in their operation, but yet they work in manner one effect, as you may ≈øee by experience in tho≈øe that are poy≈øoned, for after that they be dead, they are ≈øwollen and become black, and in their Stomack is abundance of aquo≈øitie: And the cau≈øe is this, that if a poy≈øon have power to kill or ≈øtrangle a man or woman, of nece≈ø≈øitie it mu≈øt be corro≈øive, and being corro≈øive, it will work this effect, that is, a≈ø≈øoon as it arriveth at the ≈øtomack, it beginneth to make alteration and quickly congealeth the blood, and enflameth the parts round about it, it draweth unto it great quantitie of water; and it cau≈øeth the congelation of the blood on the one part, and the inflammation of the ≈øtomack on the other part, and the gathering of the water on the other part. And in a manner all poi≈øons work one effect, and there are great number of the≈øe Poi≈øons, of which I would ≈øhew their qualities, but that I fear I ≈øhould cau≈øe ≈øuch as are ignorant to know them, and therefore I leave them. But I will write the order wherewith thou ≈øhalt help all tho≈øe poy≈øons that are curable, with as much facilitie as is po≈ø≈øible. Poy≈øons, as I ≈øaid before, do work three evill Effects, they inflame the ≈øtomack, congeal the blood, and draw unto them great quantity of water, which three
things being in a man killeth him out of hand; and the nece≈ø≈øarie≈øt cure in that matter of poy≈øon is this. Fir≈øt cau≈øe the poy≈øoned per≈øon to vomit ≈øo much as he can, and as ≈øoon as he can, and that thou ≈øhalt doe with ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of our Electuario Angelica, which provoketh vomit, and evacuateth the ≈øtomack of the poy≈øon, and of the matter drawn by the poy≈øon into the ≈øtomack, and it is excellent again≈øt all kind of poy≈øons; that being done, annoint all his body with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, the which will keep the bloud liquid, and will not ≈øuffer it to congeal by any meanes: after that let him take every morning í. iii, of our Pills again≈øt poy≈øon, which are written in my di≈øcour≈øe upon Chirurgery; and when he hath taken tho≈øe Pills, let him drink thereon a little good wine: and after let him drink the decoction of Diptamo bianco, and dre≈ø≈øe his meat with hearbs that are good again≈øt poy≈øon, as there are a great number: And this doing, by the help of God thou ≈øhalt help all tho≈øe that are curable, for it is a rationall Medicine and experimented, which worketh incredible operations.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. A water that pre≈øerveth the Face and Teeth.
div.p: THis water is miraculous, for if yee wa≈øh the face therewith, and rub the teeth, it will make the face ≈øhining and bright, and the teeth like fine Ivory, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Mother of Pearl in powder one pound, the juyce of Lemmons pre≈ø≈øed with their pills and all three pound, put them in a gla≈ø≈øe, and let it ≈øtand fifteen dayes, then put thereto ≈øo much ≈øtrong di≈øtilled Vineger as there was of the juyce, and di≈øtill it in a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe, with a ≈ømall fire, untill the ≈øpirits doe appear, then pre≈øently change thy Receiver, and keep it, wherewith thou ≈øhalt wa≈øh thy face and rub thy teeth: Note, that when yee will occupie that water, it were nece≈ø≈øary that the face were wa≈øhed ≈øo clean as is po≈ø≈øible, and to rub the teeth with a clean cloth, for with this I have ≈øeen many goodly experiences in tho≈øe matters.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. To Clarifie and take away ≈øpots out of the Face.
div.p: TAke Lac virginis two parts, pure Oil of Tartar one part, fine Aqua vitae ≈øix parts, mix them, and when thou goe≈øt to bed annoint thy face therewith, and in the morning wa≈øh thy face with the decoction of Bran, and dry it well, then annoint it with the Oil of Almonds, and ≈øo u≈øing this order, in ≈øhort time thy face will be bright and clear without any ≈øpot. For this Compo≈øition is of marvellous vertue to pre≈øerve the fle≈øh, and to defend it from all impediments of Nature, and pre≈øerveth the head from many infirmities.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. The order to make a goodly Remedy, to cau≈øe the hair to grow.
div.p:
THe beard and hair commonly doe fall through two cau≈øes, the one is, when the Patient hath a Pe≈øtilent Fever, that is, Mal di Mazzucco, for when they are cured, all their hair will fall away, and many times mo≈øt of them doe change that ≈øubtile skin, called of the Doctors Epiderma, and this is one of the cau≈øes: The other cau≈øe is, when they accompany with unclean women, and that they get tho≈øe Carvoli on the Yeard, the which as ≈øoon as they are cured, there cometh an alteration in the throat, ≈øo that they cannot well eat their meat, then after that in ≈øhort time the hair will begin to fall, and the≈øe are the two cau≈øes of falling of the hair. In that which commeth after Mal di Mazzucco, ye ≈øhall need nothing el≈øe but to annoint the head when yee goe to bed, with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum a little warm, and that will cau≈øe the hair to grow, re≈øtore the ≈øight and hearing, the which tho≈øe commonly doe lo≈øe when they are ≈øick, through their long ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. But when the hair doth fall through the other cau≈øe, yee mu≈øt u≈øe forcible Medicines to cau≈øe it to come again, and that thou ≈øhalt doe with this Cerot. Take Turpentine, Ship-pitch, Ro≈øin of the Pine tree, and new Wax, and make thereof a
Cerot, the which ≈øpread upon a cloth, and ≈øtrew thereon Cantharides in powder, then lay it upon the head, and there let it remain five dayes without moving it, and when yee take it away, take Magno liquore, and our Oleum Philo≈øophorum, of each alike, and therewith annoint the head once a day very hot. And while yee u≈øe this Unction, take Sinaber ‚Ñ•. i. Olibanum, Mirrh, and Colles, of each two ≈øcruples, and grinde them together, and divide them in ≈øix parts, and every night when yee goe to bed, perfume the bed with one of the≈øe parts, the which thou ≈øhalt doe in this order: Take Coals in a Chafing-di≈øh, and ca≈øt it therein by little and little, and then cover thy head with a cloth, and receive the fume, and then goe to bed with the ≈øaid cloth about thy head, and this thou ≈øhalt doe ≈øix evenings, and continually u≈øe the Unction untill it be helped, the which will be in ≈øhort time.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX. To make our Sirrup of Bayes.
div.p:
THis Sirrup being well made, is of marvellous vertue for tho≈øe women that are troubled with pains of the Mother, and pains cau≈øed of wind and cold, becau≈øe the Bayes of their nature are hot and drying, and re≈øolveth the wind, and warmeth the cold, and drieth the humidity, ≈øo that who≈øoever doth u≈øe this Sirrup oftentimes, ≈øhall be free from the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and gravell in the Reins, becau≈øe it doth mundifie the Reins, and re≈øolve the humour hanging, and therefore this would be u≈øed in Polonia, and Almaign with great profit, becau≈øe tho≈øe Countries are cold, and they feed on mo≈øt meats which are contrary to tho≈øe afore≈øaid infirmities, and the order to make it is thus. Take a branch of Bayes weighing one pound, and put it in a gla≈ø≈øe with eight pound of white Wine, and two pound of purified Hony, and di≈øtill it in Balneo three hours, then take it from the fire, and keep that by it ≈øelf, then take that which remained in the gla≈ø≈øe, and di≈øtill it by a filter three or four times untill it be clear, then take two pound of Sugar, and clarifie it with the white of an Egge,
and then mix it with that which yee di≈øtilled by a filter, and give it a little walme or two, but not too much, then when it is boyled, before it be cold, put therein the ≈øaid water that yee di≈øtilled in Balneo, and aromati≈øe it with ≈øix graines of Musk, and ‚Ñà. i. of Cloves, and another of Saffron, and í. ≈øs. of Cinamon, and ‚Ñ•. iii. of Ro≈øewater, and then keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and it will pre≈øerve a long time: The do≈øe of this Sirrup is from ‚Ñ•. i. to ‚Ñ•. ii. and no more. And therefore if any will ≈øweat for any indi≈øpo≈øition in the body, let them take four ounces as warm as they may ≈øuffer, and lay them down to ≈øweat, and it will re≈øolve great infirmities.

div.head: CHAP. XL. The order to make a Sirrup of Cinnamon and Ginger.
div.p: THis Sirrup is exceeding hot, and pre≈øerveth a weak ≈øtomack through cold, re≈øolveth the Cough, and the Catarre cau≈øed through want of naturall heat: but yee ≈øhall note, that if the indi≈øpo≈øition were of a hot and dry cau≈øe, in any wi≈øe ye ≈øhall not u≈øe this. It cau≈øeth dige≈øtion, and provoketh venereous acts, and killeth many that oppre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves therewith, for they will doe more then Nature is able to carry, and ≈øo fall into a di≈øea≈øe called Apoplexia, and die, or el≈øe live with great pain; and therefore I would wi≈øh tho≈øe that have no great need thereof, not to u≈øe it for Lechery ≈øake, for better it were to leave it in Va≈øe ≈øpermatico, but as for tho≈øe that have need thereof, it will revive them if they were in a manner dead, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Ginger, Cinnamon, of each one pound, beat them in powder, and infu≈øe it in half a pound of Ro≈øewater, and there let it remain four or five daies, and then put thereon ‚Ñ•. iiii. of the water of a Herb called Mortella, in the Italian tongue, and ≈øix pound of the be≈øt white wine, and di≈øtill them altogether untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth; then take as much white Honey as the matter purified weigheth, and while it is yet hot on the fire, put therein the ≈øaid Water which
you di≈øtilled, and ≈øix grains of Musk powdred with Sugar, and incorporate them well together, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, and when ye will u≈øe this, ye ≈øhall take it in the morning warm, fa≈øting thereon four or five hours, becau≈øe it may pierce the better, and doe his operation; the quantitie that you ≈øhall take ordinary is ‚Ñ•. i. but if it doe not work his operation well, augment the quantitie, and take ≈øomewhat more or le≈ø≈øe according to thy ≈øtomack, and the time ≈øhall be two or three weeks, or more or le≈ø≈øe, according as thou feele≈øt thy ≈øelf, for it is of ≈øo much vertue that it will not be credited, except it be of tho≈øe that have ≈øeen the experience thereof, therefore keep it as a thing of value.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. Our Sirrup of a Capon, that is made with Con≈øumato.
div.p: THis Sirrup is a re≈øtorative of great vertue, never ≈øeen or heard of before, and is of ≈øuch vertue that it is able to ≈øu≈øtain a ≈øick per≈øon many dayes without taking any other meat, becau≈øe it is of fle≈øh and blood, for the fle≈øh ≈øu≈øtaineth the fle≈øh, and the blood ≈øu≈øtaineth the blood, and the order to make it is thus.

Take a great fat Capon that is well-fle≈øhed, and pull it while it is alive, and take forth onely the gutts and the belly, and when he is dead, ≈øtamp it in a Morter gro≈ø≈øely, and put it in a di≈øtilling gla≈ø≈øe with twentie pound of good white wine, and ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of Salt, and four ounces of Sugar, and ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of Cinnamon, then di≈øtill it in Balneo untill the two thirds be con≈øumed, then keep that which is di≈øtilled, and that which remained in the gla≈ø≈øe ≈øtrain through a cloth, and pre≈ø≈øe out all the juyce of the fle≈øh with a Pre≈ø≈øe, then pa≈ø≈øe all that through a filter, and then with Sugar make it in form of a Sirrup, but boil it not too much, then put therein that which ye di≈øtilled from the Capon, and aromati≈øe it with Cinnamon half a dram, Saffron one ≈øcruple, Musk four grains, Ro≈øewater ‚Ñ•. ii. then keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and this hath no do≈øe, becau≈øe it is taken onely to ≈øu≈øtain a weak nature; you may put
it in broth, or in any other meats, or by it ≈øelf, and alwaies it will work his operation, in ≈øtrengthening tho≈øe that are weak.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. A Magi≈øtrall Sirrup of Quinces, the which is Re≈øtorative.
div.p: THis Sirrup of Quinces is of great vertue, becau≈øe it re≈øtoreth ≈øtrength, helpeth dige≈øtion, comforteth the Stomack, and maketh the heart merrie, as you may ≈øee by the Ingredients; it comforteth al≈øo the ≈øight, and quickeneth the memorie: And the order to make it is thus.

Take of the be≈øt Quinces you can find, and cut them in ≈ømall peeces, with ≈øeed and all three pound, Cinnamon half an ounce, Cloves, Saffron, of each a ≈øcruple, Lignum Aloes, ‚Ñ• i. ≈øs. Bengewine ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øtamp all the≈øe and infu≈øe them in ≈øeven pound of ≈øtrong white wine, then di≈øtill it in Balneo, untill all the liquor be come forth, and when it is in manner done, take it from the fire, and put it into an earthen ve≈ø≈øell well glazed, and put therein that which ye di≈øtilled, and mix them well together, then ≈øtrain it hard through a Canvas, and pa≈ø≈øe it by a filter, or a linnen cloth, and make it as clear as you can po≈ø≈øible, then take that, and with refined Sugar, make a Sirrup according to Art, and when it is made, aromati≈øe it with Musk, and Ro≈øewater, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, that it take no air, giving your charge that it be not over-boyled. And this thou ≈øhalt give unto tho≈øe that cannot dige≈øt their meat, becau≈øe it warmeth the ≈øtomack, with a temperate heat, the which re≈øolveth the cruditie of humours, that are in the ≈øtomack, and di≈øpo≈øeth Nature to dige≈øtion, for becau≈øe the Quinces by nature are hot, and helpeth it to dige≈øt, the Cloves and Saffron make the heart merrie, and the Lignum Aloes, pre≈øerveth from Corruption, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that all the≈øe being together, worketh wonderfull effects in the bodie of many, the quantitie thereof is ‚Ñ•. i. in the morning, and two hours after ≈øupper cold.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. A Magi≈øtrall Sirrup of Lignum Sanctum.
div.p: THis Magi≈øtrall Sirrup is of ≈øuch vertue in his operation, that it will help the Mal' France≈øe, if it be made according to the order, and taken as it ≈øhould be: And the order to make it is thus.

Take Lignum Sanctum ra≈øped ‚Ñ•. vi. the Bark of the ≈øame ‚Ñ•. iiii. and lay it to infu≈øe in twelve pound of good white wine, with one pound of white honey, then di≈øtill it untill ye have received three pound, then take it from the fire, and keep the water by it ≈øelf; then take that which remained in the gla≈ø≈øe, and di≈øtill it by a filter untill it be clear, then put thereto the water that ye di≈øtilled away, and for every pound of that water put thereunto ‚Ñ•. iii. of Julep ≈øimple, and mix them well together, and keep it in a Bottle of gla≈ø≈øe well ≈øtopped, for this is marvellous in the cure where Sweatings is needfull: For if ye give five or ≈øixe ounces of this, as hot as he may ≈øuffer it, and cover him in the bed, he ≈øhall ≈øweat marvellou≈øly, the which ≈øweating re≈øolveth cold tumours, pains, and divers other indi≈øpo≈øitions, that are to be re≈øolved by ≈øweat. And as for the cure of the Pox, this is a mo≈øt ≈øoveraign remedie, when there are tumours, or pains, or inflations. But when there are Ulcers, Scabbs, or Inflammations, in that ca≈øe you may not u≈øe it by any means, becau≈øe it is very hot, and will cau≈øe greater inflammation. And therefore if any will u≈øe this Sirrup to cure pains, ≈øwellings, or inflammations, it were nece≈ø≈øarie fir≈øt to take our Aromatico, written in this Book, with divers other Medicines of our Invention, that being done, let him take ≈øeven or eight times our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo,, and then begin to take this Sirrup, and ≈øweat thereon morning and evening: His meat ≈øhall be ro≈øt Mutton, or a Bird, Rai≈øins, Dates, Almonds, and ≈øuch like, but he mu≈øt not eat too much. His bread ≈øhall be Bisket, and his drink good wine at meals, and if it doe happen that he be bound in the body, yee ≈øhall give him every week once our Sirrupo Solutivo, and ≈øo continue with his ≈øweating untill he be helped.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV. A Sirrup of Juniper Berries.
div.p: THis Sirrup of Juniper Berries is of great vertue, becau≈øe it is one of tho≈øe fruits that continueth green all the year: of the which hearbs I have written a di≈øcour≈øe in my book called La Phy≈øica del Phioravante, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Juniper Berries when they begin to wax black four pound, and ≈øtamp them, and infu≈øe them in twelve pound of ≈øtrong white Wine ≈øix dayes, then di≈øtill it with two pound of white Hony, and ‚Ñ•. i. of Cinnamon, untill yee have received two pound, then take it from the fire, and ≈øtrain out the Fe≈ø≈øes that remained with a pre≈ø≈øe, then ≈øtrain it by a filter again, then with Sugar make a Sirrup in good form, and when it is boiled, put therein the ≈øaid water di≈øtilled from the berries, and ≈øo without fire incorporate them well together, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut that it take no air: the do≈øe is an ounce and a half to be taken warm. This is excellent for tho≈øe that are troubled with wind, or coldne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtomack, becau≈øe it warmeth, drieth, and helpeth dige≈øtion, and therefore this would work miraculous effects in Almaign, becau≈øe it is a cold Region, and that they eat many moi≈øt meats, the which Nature cannot well dige≈øt: It is al≈øo appropriate again≈øt pains of the Mother, becau≈øe it provoketh men≈øtrua, and purgeth the Matrix, and helpeth dige≈øtion, and cau≈øeth ≈øleep, with divers other vertues.

div.head: CHAP. XLV. To make a Sirrup of the Bran of Wheat.
div.p: THis Sirrup is of marvellous vertue again≈øt divers infirmities, for by nature it is hot, and provoketh ≈øweat, and urine, and ≈øerveth very much again≈øt the French di≈øea≈øes, if you can u≈øe it in his time and place, and it is made in this order.

Take Bran one pound, and infu≈øe it in twelve pound of
white Wine, and ≈øo let it remain two dayes, then boil it in a gla≈ø≈øe with a Head and Receiver, untill the third part be con≈øumed, the which yee ≈øhall re≈øerve to mix with it afterward, then ≈øtrein that in the gla≈ø≈øe, and pa≈ø≈øe it by a filter, and when it is clear, put thereunto the afore≈øaid which yee re≈øerved: Then take Hony and Sugar, of each alike, and therewith make a Sirrup according to art, and when it is made, aromati≈øe it with a little Cinnamon, Cloves, Saffron, Lignum Aloes, and Musk, according to thy di≈øcretion, and for every pound of the ≈øaid matter, yee ≈øhall put thereto half an ounce of our Vegitable Quinte≈ø≈øence, and it ≈øhall be fini≈øhed, the which keep clo≈øe ≈øhut, for it is of ≈øuch vertue, that it will not corrupt, the do≈øe is from ‚Ñ•. ii. to three, to be taken warm, and then lie down to ≈øweat, for this will re≈øolve all infirmities that may be re≈øolved by ≈øweat. It is very profitable for tho≈øe that are troubled with any old indi≈øpo≈øition, as the Cough, the Catarre, indi≈øpo≈øition of the Stomack, and ≈øuch like: Yee ≈øhall note, that this would not be u≈øed in the Summer, for becau≈øe it is too hot for that time.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI. To make a Sirrup of Sar≈øa parilla, of our invention.
div.p:
THe Sar≈øa parilla is a Root that cometh from the Indies, the which is hot and drying, of the which Phy≈øitians make Sirrups and Potions for divers infirmities, wherein it is needfull of drying by ≈øweat: but untill this time they have all abu≈øed them≈øelves in the order, becau≈øe all hot and dry things are ≈øpirituall, and ≈øo in making their decoction the ≈øpirits goe away in fume, and the decoction remaineth ≈øenza anima, and vertue, in re≈øpect: yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the Sar≈øa parilla is a root miraculous in his operation, becau≈øe it warmeth the cold, and drieth the humidity, and re≈øolveth tumours, and healeth ≈øores, and helpeth paines, when it is made according to our order, and becau≈øe it is a Medicine in ≈øo common u≈øe, I will ≈øhew thee the order to make this Sirrup, that ≈øhall have
both anima, and vertue, in ≈øo much that the world ≈øhall wonder at it: and the order to make it is thus.

Take one pound of the be≈øt Sar≈øa parilla that yee can find, and cut it very ≈ømall, and put it in a gla≈ø≈øe with one pound and a half of Hony, and ‚Ñ•. i. of Cinnamon, and ‚Ñ•. ii. of Lignum Aloes, and put them in twelve pound of white Wine, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand four and twenty houres, and then di≈øtill it, untill yee have received three pound of water, giving you charge, that the Receiver be great, and lute not the mouth but ≈øtop it with Tow lea≈øt it break, then take it from the fire, and let it wax cold, and when it is cold, pour forth that which is clear, and put it unto the water that yee di≈øtilled fir≈øt, and keep it clo≈øe, for it is a ble≈ø≈øed Sirrup: this being done, put upon the Fe≈ø≈øes twenty pound of white Wine, and one pound of fine Sugar, and let it boil half an hour, and then ≈øtrein it, and when the Phy≈øitian will give it, he may give ‚Ñ•. viii. at a time as hot as he may ≈øuffer it, and then lay him down to ≈øweat as much as he can. And with his meat let him drink the la≈øt decoction, and thus the Phy≈øitian ≈øhall reap honour, and the Patient health, and therefore if any will have his intent, let him not break this our order in any re≈øpect.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII. To make a Potion of China as it ought to be.
div.p: THis China is a root like unto the root of Canna, the which is brought unto us out of India, from an I≈øle called China, from whence it took his name China, and there are of two ≈øorts: the one is white and heavy, the other is great, and red, and light, and of this I have made no experience at all: But of the other I have had great experience, and by the help of God have re≈øolved great and terrible di≈øea≈øes, and the order to condite them after our order is this.

Take ‚Ñ•. vi. of China, and ‚Ñ•. iii. of Lignum Aloes of the be≈øt that yee can finde, and ‚Ñ•. iiii. of Pollipodie, and ‚Ñ•. i. of Coloquintida, beat all the≈øe gro≈ø≈øely, and put them into a di≈øtilling gla≈ø≈øe, with twenty pound of good Wine, then give
