it fire untill ye have received three pound of water, then let it cool, and ≈øtrain it, then put therein the water that yee di≈øtilled fir≈øt, and incorporate them well together, and of this give ‚Ñ•. iiii. at a time warm, then ca≈øt away the Fe≈ø≈øes, for they are unprofitable. But the Sirrup is of ≈øuch vertue, that it re≈øolveth tumours, ≈øores, pains, and all other indi≈øpo≈øitions cau≈øed of the Pox. It ≈øerveth al≈øo for Doglie Artetich, for pains of the Gout, and for many other indi≈øpo≈øitions cau≈øed of cruditie, and coldne≈ø≈øe of the humours, becau≈øe it is of nature hot and drying, and his vertues are to drie: I have ≈øeen of this Sirrup great experience in divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII. A Potion of Alchachengie, and wherefore it ≈øerveth.
div.p: THis Herb Alchachengie with his fruit is aperative, and mo≈øt profitable for tho≈øe that cannot make water, by rea≈øon of alteration of the pores that are altered through cold, for this is hot and drying, by the which means, it re≈øolveth the alteration of the afore≈øaid cau≈øe, and cau≈øeth the Urine to pa≈ø≈øe with ea≈øe; It helpeth the dige≈øtion, and comforteth the ≈øtomack, when it is grieved through winde or cold: And the order to make it is thus.

Take that Herb, with Root, Leaves, fruit and all, and lay it to infu≈øe in the water of Mallows, with the Herb Pelitorie, and there let them remain five or ≈øix dayes, then put thereunto cour≈øe Sugar, and let it boil one hour and no more, and then ≈øtrain it, and put thereunto a little Cinnamon, and then it is fini≈øhed: and when you will occupie it again≈øt difficulty of Urine, give them thereof ‚Ñ•. iiii. and keep them warm in bed, and they ≈øhall feel great ea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XLIX. A Pectorall Potion, of our new Invention.
div.p:
THis Potion is appropriate again≈øt the indi≈øpo≈øition of the Brea≈øt and Stomack, and is of a marvellous operation, becau≈øe
it is aperative, ≈øoftning the ≈øtomack, and mundifieth the brea≈øt, and maketh the heart merrie: And this is mo≈øt ≈øoveraign for the Cough, Catarr, and all the other indi≈øpo≈øitions, that come unto the brea≈øt through cruditie, and vi≈øco≈øitie of humours, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Pomi Calimani, and Pomi Apiae, of each one pound, Quinces half a pound, common Honie, ‚Ñ•. iiii. fine Sugar one pound, ≈øweet white wine ten pound, water of Buglo≈øs four pound, boil all the≈øe together in a Copper Ve≈ø≈øell, that is well tinned within, untill the Apples doe begin to fall in pieces, then take it from the fire, and ≈øtrain them through a ≈øtrainer, without pre≈ø≈øing of the Fe≈ø≈øes, then put into that two drachms of Cinnamon, and then ≈øtrain it by a filter four or five times, untill it be clear, then keep it in a ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, that it take no aire. The quantity is ‚Ñ•. iiii. as warm as ye may, take it in the morning, fa≈øting at lea≈øt five or ≈øix hours after it, and if it be po≈ø≈øible ≈øleep thereon in your bed, for it is a thing of great vertue, in re≈øolving the indi≈øpo≈øition of the brea≈øt and ≈øtomack.

div.head: CHAP. L. To make a Potion of Camedrios, and Iva Artetica, which di≈ø≈øolveth all Fevers that come with cold.
div.p: THe Herb Iva Artetica, as I have ≈øhewed in another place, is of marvellous vertue, al≈øo the Camedrios is of great vertue, and is hot and dry by nature. The Iva is good again≈øt the accident of the Fever, and the Camedrios di≈ø≈øolveth the melancholie humour; and therefore when a decoction is made of the≈øe two Herbs, it will work a marvellous effect in the cure of the ≈øaid Fever, becau≈øe it provoketh ≈øweat, and a≈ø≈øubtiliateth the gro≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe of the humour, and extingui≈øheth the accident of the Fever in ≈øuch ≈øort, that the Fever ≈øhall re≈øolve with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and the order to make that Potion is thus.

Take Camedrios, and Iva Artetica, of each one pound, and dry them in the ≈øhadow, Lignum Aloes ‚Ñ•. i. the ≈øeed of Walwort
‚Ñ•. iiii. common Honey ‚Ñ•. vi. fine Sugar one pound, ≈øtrong white wine xvii. pound: Mix all the≈øe together in a di≈øtilling gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand three daies, then di≈øtill forth three pound, and let it cool, and ≈øtrain it through a Searce, and put thereunto the water that ye di≈øtilled out before, then pa≈ø≈øe it by a filter three or four times untill it bee clear, then keep it in a Gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut that it take no aire, and it will la≈øt a long time without corruption, and when any will take it again≈øt the ≈øaid Fever coming with cold, give him every morning fa≈øting ‚Ñ•. v. warm, and let him lie down to ≈øweat as much as he may, and fa≈øt thereron at the lea≈øt four hours, and take heed yee eat no things that are cold, and moi≈øt, for they will hinder the cure very much, and at night when he goeth to bed, give him ‚Ñ•. iii. warm, and if it hap that in his ≈øleep he ≈øweat, dry him well with warm clothes, and thus doing, in ≈øhort time he ≈øhall be delivered of that infirmitie, for this I have u≈øed divers and ≈øundry times to my great honour, and profit of the Patient.

div.head: CHAP. LI. To make a Potion that is good again≈øt all Infirmities.
div.p: THis is a Magi≈øtrall Potion, the which helpeth again≈øt all Infirmities, by rea≈øon that it de≈øtroyeth all the evill qualities in our bodies, it comforteth Nature, helpeth dige≈øtion, provoketh Urine, and loo≈øeth the bodie, the which things are mo≈øt comfortable to our bodies, and the order to make it is thus.

Take the ≈øeed of Quinces, ‚Ñ•. x. the Pills of Citrons, ‚Ñ•. vi. Balm, Nettles, of each, ‚Ñ•. iiii. beat all the≈øe gro≈ø≈øely, and infu≈øe them in twelve pound of ≈øtrong white wine, and there let it remain ≈øix daies, then di≈øtill it with ‚Ñ•. vi. of Honey, and ‚Ñ•. xv. of Sugar, untill ye have received two pound of water, then take it from the fire and let it cool, and ≈øtrain it by a filter, and then put therein the fir≈øt water, and eight grains of Musk, di≈ø≈øolved with a little Ro≈øewater about ‚Ñ•. ii. and then for every pound of the ≈øaid matter, put thereunto ‚Ñà. i. of Oyle of
Vitrioll, and incorporate them well together, then keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped that it take no air, and of this yee ≈øhall take ‚Ñ•. i. in the morning cold, and fa≈øt thereon; for who≈øoever doth u≈øe this in his health ≈øhall ≈øeldome be ≈øick, but live in health. For in this compo≈øition there entereth the ≈øeed of Quinces, that re≈øolve the evill quality of the Stomack, and make the heart merry: The Pomcitrone pills pre≈øerve and help dige≈øtion: The Balm purifieth the bloud, healeth the Liver, cau≈øeth good dige≈øtion, and comforteth the Heart: The Nettles warmeth, provoketh Urine, and mundifieth the Reins, and re≈øolveth the malignity of the Sinews: The Wine comforteth Nature, ≈øtrengtheneth the Head, and ≈øu≈øtaineth the ≈øtrength: The Musk is warm by Nature, and re≈øolveth the windine≈ø≈øe, and purgeth the bloud: The Oil of Vitrioll healeth all the Scoriaciones of the Mouth, the Brea≈øt, and Stomack, and pre≈øerveth the body from all corruption: So by this yee may ≈øee of what importance this Compo≈øition is, through the vertue of the Simples that are therein: ≈øo to conclude, I ≈øay, that this is one of the be≈øt Compo≈øitions that can be made, becau≈øe of his nature: It letteth alteration in our bodies, and helpeth again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes or infirmities, and prolongeth life.

div.head: CHAP. LII. An Infu≈øion with Wine mo≈øt precious again≈øt the Gout.
div.p: THe Gout is a putrified and rotten di≈øea≈øe, as I have written of in divers places, and the cure thereof is hard, becau≈øe it were needfull to help many inconveniences before yee come to the cure. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it is a ≈øtrange thing to ≈øee divers, that after they are cured they have no care to pre≈øerve them: ≈øo that look which way they got it, that way it will come again, but if they would u≈øe defen≈øives and pre≈øervatives, they may remain well, and therefore I have devi≈øed this Wine, the which they ≈øhall continually drink: for as long as they u≈øe this Wine, the Gout ≈øhall never trouble them, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Vino negro that is ≈øweet and plea≈øant, about twelve gallons, and put it in a ve≈ø≈øell that is well ≈øea≈øoned, and in that Wine put fine Lignum Aloes in powder ‚Ñ•. iii. Pollipodie of the Oak ‚Ñ•. iiii. Sena of Levant ‚Ñ•. ii. Musk di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øewater ten grains, common Hony two pound, then let it repo≈øe untill it be clear, and then begin to drink thereof; for this Wine purgeth, the which if it purge too much, yee ≈øhall refrain it now and then, according as yee find your body: This doth not onely help the Gout, but all kinds of pains cau≈øed of corruption of humours, becau≈øe it drieth, re≈øolveth, and pre≈øerveth, the which are convenient to pre≈øerve the body.

div.head: CHAP. LIII. Another artificiall Wine, again≈øt the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and gravell.
div.p: THe ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and the gravell in the Reins, are ≈øomewhat of kin together, becau≈øe they are cau≈øed of one cau≈øe, that is, of vapours corrupt and rotten, and of gro≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe, and evill qualities of the humours, the which, one with the other, ingender that infirmity, which in ≈øome men is no other then an evill indi≈øpo≈øition inwardly, the which is very hard to be helped, for if thou wilt re≈øolve it, it were nece≈ø≈øary, fir≈øt to remove the evill quality, and then cure it, and after they are cured to pre≈øerve them, that the ≈øaid indi≈øpo≈øition return not again, and in ≈øo doing thy cure ≈øhall have good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and therefore I have made this Wine to pre≈øerve thee from that indi≈øpo≈øition, and the order to make it is thus.

Take as it were a Hog≈øhead or a Barrell of good white Wine, that containeth about eighteen gallons of Wine, in the which yee ≈øhall put Carduus Benedictus ‚Ñ•. ii. Saxifrage ‚Ñ•. vi. Walwort ‚Ñ•. iiii. Pollipodie ‚Ñ•. iiii. Cinnamon ‚Ñ•. i. Spikenard half an ounce, Lignum Aloes ‚Ñ•. ii. fine Sugar three pound, then let it repo≈øe three or four dayes, and then begin to drink it, for yee may u≈øe it with ≈ømall wine, or water, or in what order yee will. And in the mean time that yee take this drink, yee ≈øhall not eat fat Pork, nor any other fat meat, nor Butter,
Milk, Chee≈øe, or Pie-cru≈øts, or ≈øuch like things, that are of gro≈ø≈øe and hard dige≈øtion, becau≈øe they will let the operation of this wine. For who≈øoever doth u≈øe this wine, ≈øhall never be troubled with tho≈øe kinds of infirmities, becau≈øe it doth lo≈øen the belly, mundifie, clean≈øe, and pre≈øerve from all evill qualities. I call to remembrance that in the City of Naples, where I dwelled ≈øix yeares, I cau≈øed divers and ≈øundry per≈øons to u≈øe this Wine, and they found ≈øuch profit thereby, that it was to be wondered at, for in that City‚ñ™ there were many troubled with the ≈øaid indi≈øpo≈øition, in re≈øpect of Hogs fle≈øh, fi≈øh, and ≈øuch other moi≈øt things as they commonly eat in that City, and therefore who≈øoever u≈øeth this Wine ≈øhall not be troubled with the ≈øaid infirmities.

div.head: CHAP. LIV. To make a Quinte≈ø≈øence of marvellous vertue.
div.p: THe Quinte≈ø≈øence is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it is an e≈ø≈øence taken from the Elements without corrupting the ≈øaid Elements; and therefore it is called Quinta e≈ø≈øentia: for it is an e≈ø≈øence above the four Elements, the which hath a marvellous vertue in pre≈øerving, and con≈øerving all things from putrifaction, and is of ≈øo much vertue, that drinking thereof every morning half an ounce when they ri≈øe out of their bed, it pre≈øerveth them for ever in health. It healeth wounds and all ≈øores, wa≈øhing them therewith. It pre≈øerveth all fle≈øh, fi≈øh, and fruits, that is put therein, and the order to make it is thus.

Take good ≈øtrong Wine fourteen pound, common Hony one pound, Anni≈øeed, Coriander, Lignum Aloes, Calamus Aromaticus, of each ‚Ñ•. iii. Ro≈øewater ‚Ñ•. iiii. Beat all the afore≈øaid things gro≈ø≈øely, and infu≈øe them in the ≈øaid Wine two daies, and then put them in a Goord of gla≈ø≈øe, and di≈øtill it by Balneo, ≈øo long untill the water that cometh forth doe burn, and when it will not burn, di≈øtill no more, then keep that which is di≈øtilled in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped that it take no air, and ≈øo keep it untill thou have occa≈øion to u≈øe it, for it is a mo≈øt rare
liquor, becau≈øe, as I have ≈øaid before, it re≈øolveth all the indi≈øpotions that happen unto mans body. For of this Compo≈øition the antient Doctours had ≈ømall knowledge, nor of many things more written in this book. If any man de≈øire to have this Quinte≈ø≈øence more perfecter, let him take a tenth part of good Hony, with a little fine Cinnamon, and di≈øtill it again by Balneo, and the Flegm will remain all in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell, and the Quinte≈ø≈øence will be ≈øo fine, that the air will take it away, and therefore he that can make this well, ≈øhall work ≈øtrange cures therewith, ≈øo that the world will wonder thereat:

div.head: CHAP. LV. To make Diatartaro, the which is marvellous in divers infirmities.
div.p: THis Diatartaro is good again≈øt pain of the ≈øtomack, of the body, and for tho≈øe that are ≈ølipticke of body, that cannot goe to ≈øtool, and ≈øuch like matters, becau≈øe it is of nature temperate and lenitive, and hath vertue to heat and di≈ø≈øolve the evill quality, and it is made in this order.

Take Pears of what ≈øort yee will, and cut them in four peices, then boil them in water till they be ≈øoft, and that the water be almo≈øt con≈øumed, then pa≈ø≈øe it through a ≈øtrainer, and put thereunto as much white Hony purified as it weigheth, and thereof make an Electuary in good form, and when it is made, aromati≈øe it with Musk, then for every pound of the ≈øaid Electuary, put thereunto ‚Ñ•. i. of perfect oil of Tartar, made by di≈ø≈øolution after it is calcined white: But yee ≈øhall note, that the Oil mu≈øt be put in when the Electuary is cold, and ≈øo mix it together, then keep it in a glazen ve≈ø≈øell: The do≈øe is from ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. to an ounce in the morning fa≈øting, and eat no meat in four hours after: for this, as I have ≈øaid, will cure the indi≈øpo≈øition of the Stomack, pains of the Milt, pains of the Body that have continued long, pains of the Mother, and ≈øuch like things that are cau≈øed of cold and moi≈øt humours.

div.head: CHAP. LVI. A Compo≈øition of great value to comfort the Stomack.
div.p: AMong all the compo≈øitions that the Apothecaries have, this is one of the be≈øt and mo≈øt perfecte≈øt, becau≈øe it comforteth the ≈øtomack that is weak, and ≈øpoyled through a long and fa≈øtidious infirmitie, for it is of a temperate heat, and helpeth to dige≈øt, cau≈øeth ≈øleep, and comforteth the brea≈øt, and the compo≈øition is this.

Take the be≈øt Honey that ye can get, and clarifie it with Ro≈øewater and the white of an Egg, as ye would doe Sugar, and ≈øcum it very well, then take as much fine Sugar as yee have of Honey, and incorporate them together on a ≈ømall fire, and when it is come to the thickne≈ø≈øe of an Electuarie or thereabout, for every pound of the ≈øaid matter, yee ≈øhall put ‚Ñ•. i. of our Quinte≈ø≈øence Vegitable, and ‚Ñ•. ii. of Oyle of Almonds newly made, and ≈øtir them well together being cold, then put thereto a little Musk and Cinnamon to give it a plea≈øant ≈ømell, then keep it clo≈øe: The quantitie is ‚Ñ•. i. more or le≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ according to the ≈øtrength of the ≈øtomack; yee may temper it with good broth if ye will, and fa≈øt thereon four hours at the lea≈øt, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee ≈øtrange effects of this compo≈øition.

div.head: CHAP. LVII. To make a ≈øtomachall Emplai≈øter to cau≈øe dige≈øtion where it wanteth.
div.p:
THere are many cau≈øes that hinder dige≈øtion, as through coldne≈ø≈øe of the Stomack, through heat, through moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe or dryne≈ø≈øe, or through ≈øuperfluous choller, or flegm, or melancholy, of the which things the Phy≈øitian cannot certifie him≈øelf which it is, ≈øo by that meanes many proved divers Remedies for that indi≈øpo≈øition, and cannot find the way to help it. And therefore I will ≈øhew thee a plai≈øter that hath all the≈øe four principall intentions; that is, to help dige≈øtion, ≈øtrengthen the ≈øtomack, make the heart merrie, which things
are all nece≈ø≈øarie to pre≈øerve a man within good temperature and health, and the Remedie is this.

Take the≈øe Hearbs gathered in their times and dried, that is, Sage, Ro≈øemary, Wormwood, Balm, Saint Johns-wort, Nettles, of each as much you will, beat them finely, and ≈øearce them: then take for every pound of that powder of Cinnamon, ‚Ñ•. i. half an ounce of Cloves, and as much Lignum Aloes, and ten grains of Musk di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øewater; then take for every pound, of good Honie ‚Ñ•. ii. and as much Vinegar, and make them into the form of a liquid Plai≈øter, and when thou wilt occupie it, ≈øpread it upon a cloth warm, and lay it to the ≈øtomack, and in the mean while eat re≈øtorative meats, and drink ≈ømall wine.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII. A rare Secret to help the Eyes.
div.p: THis is a great Secret for tho≈øe that have lo≈øt the ≈øight of their Eyes, and was never written of before of any man, but of me, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Swallows and ≈øtamp them feathers and all in a Morter, then take for every pound of that, ‚Ñ•. iiii. of bread, and four pound of white wine, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand ≈øix daies to infu≈øe, then di≈øtill it by Balneo untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, then keep that water in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and ≈øet it in the Sun twentie dayes, and then u≈øe morning and evening to drop it in the eyes, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee ≈øtrange operations of the ≈øame Experiment, for it taketh away the dimne≈ø≈øe of the eye, quickneth the ≈øight, and comforteth the brain, that it cannot be hurt by any means.

div.head: CHAP. LIX. To make a Liquor to comfort the Smelling, and to pre≈øerve the Head.
div.p:
THe Smelling is one of the five Sen≈øes of our Bodie, of the which four-footed bea≈øts have great u≈øe; for they will not
receive any thing into the bodie before they have ≈ømelled unto it, and then if it be again≈øt their nature, they will not eat it, and therefore this ≈ømelling is that which pre≈øerveth the hearing, the ≈øeeing and the ta≈øte; for if the no≈øe take an evill ≈ømell, all the other ≈øen≈øes have part: For if yee ≈ømell to Onions or Scallions, the ta≈øte will be troubled, the eyes will weep, the eares will al≈øo be troubled: And to the contrary, when a man ≈ømelleth a good ≈ømell, it comforteth the eyes, the hearing, and ta≈øte, and for that cau≈øe I have made this liquor, to comfort the Smelling, for by that the whole bodie is comforted, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Lignum Aloes ‚Ñ•. ii. Anni≈øe ≈øeed, ‚Ñ•. iiii. Calamus Aromaticus ‚Ñ•. i. Calaminte dried, three ounces, common Honey two pound, ≈øtrong white wine twelve pound, let all the≈øe be infu≈øed for four dayes, and then di≈øtill it in Balneo, and when yee di≈øtill it, put into the Receiver ≈øix grains of Musk di≈ø≈øolved in two ounces of Ro≈øewater, and di≈øtill away but three pound, the which keep in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and when yee will comfort the ≈ømelling, wa≈øh the face and beard therewith, and thou ≈øhalt ≈ømell a ≈øavour of marvellous effect, the which comforteth Nature marvellou≈øly: It comforteth the Stomack, and helpeth a ≈øtinking breath: It helpeth the mouth being ulcerated, and tho≈øe that have the Rupture in ≈øhort time, if yee wa≈øh it twice a day therewith. It helpeth al≈øo women that are troubled with di≈ø≈øention of the Matrix, if ye wet a cloth therein and lay it upon the Mother, in ≈øhort ≈øpace it ≈øhall receive great health. Al≈øo it helpeth tho≈øe that are troubled with the Meagrum, or pains in the Head coming of cold or winde, if ye wa≈øh the Head with the ≈øaid Liquor, pre≈øently they ≈øhall feel ea≈øe, with divers other vertues, the which I will leave untill another time.

div.head: CHAP. LX. A Decoction of the Vine, and wherefore it ≈øerveth.
div.p:
THis Decoction is a compo≈øition of our Invention, and may be made in the ≈øame order as ye doe with Lignum vitae,
or Sar≈øaparilla, and hath no le≈ø≈øe vertue again≈øt contagious di≈øea≈øes, and hath ≈øo great vertue in drying and re≈øolving, that it is to be wondred at, and may be u≈øed in all cau≈øes in ≈øtead of Sar≈øaparilla, or Lignum vitae, or China, and this I have found out by great travell and experience, and the order to make it is thus.

Take the Roots of the Vine, or the ≈øtalks, and cut them ≈ømall, then take thereof two pound, and infu≈øe them in ≈øtrong Vinegar untill they be covered, then put thereunto xii. pound of common water, and one pound of white Honey, and boil them untill the con≈øumption of the third part, ≈øo that there remain eight pound, then ≈øtrain it, and put thereunto ‚Ä¢ ≈øs. of Julep ≈øimple, then keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut to thy u≈øe, for it ≈øerveth again≈øt many di≈øea≈øes or infirmities, and for tho≈øe that have lo≈øt their appetite, if they take thereof four ounces morning and evening warm, and fa≈øt thereon four or five houres, in ≈øhort time they ≈øhall recover it again. It is al≈øo good for tho≈øe that are troubled with the Collick: It al≈øo ingendereth Milk in womens brea≈øts; it cea≈øeth pains of the Matrix, and al≈øo the Cough, Catarr, and paines of the Reins, and ≈øuch like, the which I will not ≈øpeak of at this time. Al≈øo of the ≈øeed of the Grape I have made an oyle by Expre≈ø≈øion, as they make oyle of Lin≈øeed and other ≈øeed, the which is of ≈øo much vertue, that it helpeth in manner again≈øt all indi≈øpo≈øitions, and e≈øpecially again≈øt Ulcers and Wounds by his proper qualitie, for unto this oyle yee can neither attribute heat, not drine≈ø≈øe, moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe nor cold, but onely a temperate thing, the which thou maye≈øt know by his experience. If ye u≈øe to eat of this oyle, it mittigateth and healeth all the indi≈øpo≈øitions of the bodie, for it is of ≈øo much ≈øu≈øtenance and vertue, that it pre≈øerveth the bodie in temperature: And the≈øe have I found out by experience.

div.head: CHAP. LXI. To make a compo≈øition of the Hearb Mercurie.
div.p:
THis Hearb Mercurie is of ≈øo much vertue that the tongue cannot expre≈ø≈øe it, and many Philo≈øophers have a≈ø≈øigned
unto it Cele≈øtiall vertue, becau≈øe it pre≈øerveth a man in a youthfull ≈øtate a long time, and from infirmities: It maketh the heart merrie, the which it doth by his ≈øecret and hidden vertues, and the order to make the ≈øaid compo≈øition is thus.

Take the Juyce of this Hearb in May when it is with flour, and ≈øtrain it through a filter untill it be clear, then take of that juyce i. pound, Julip ≈øimple half a pound, fine rectified Aqua vitae without flegm ‚Ñ•. vi. Pure Oyle of Vitriol, í. ii. fine Musk two Carrets; Mix the≈øe together in a gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtop it very well, and ≈øet it in the Sun fortie daies together, and look that yee take it in every night: that time being expired, you may u≈øe it when ye will, and the order to u≈øe it s thus. Ye ≈øhall take in the morning ‚Ñ•. i. with two or three ounces of the broth of a Capon, or other fle≈øh, and fa≈øt thereon four or five hours at the lea≈øt, and thus u≈øing it two moneths together, it will be unpo≈ø≈øible to have any infirmitie a long time after, by the vertue of the ≈øaid compo≈øition. Among the re≈øt I ≈øaw once a Gentleman that had the Pal≈øie one and twentie moneths, the which by u≈øing of this compo≈øition the ≈øpace of ten moneths was perfectly whole. Another Compo≈øition al≈øo I have made, the which is of marvellous vertue, and is in this order.

Take the Hearb Mercurie when it is floured, and accompany it with Wine and Honey, then di≈øtill it, and ≈øeparate the Elements according to Art, and thou ≈øhalt have a mo≈øt rare Medicine, wherewith thou maye≈øt help many infirmities. But fir≈øt I would coun≈øell you, ere you u≈øe this, to prepare the bodie with taking once our Aromatico, the which clean≈øeth both the ≈øtomack and body, and thus doing thou ≈øhalt reap fame.

div.head: CHAP. LXII. A Medicine of Lappaciole Minor, the which is marvellous in curing any ≈øort of Catarre.
div.p:
THere are four kinds of the≈øe, according to the writing of Dio≈øcorides, but that which the Author doth write of in this
place, is that which Dio≈øcorides calleth Xanthium, and in the Shops it is called Lappa Minor, and Lappa Inver≈øa, and in the Italian Lappaciole Minore, and in Engli≈øh it is called the Ditch-Bur, and Lou≈øe-Bur. Take that hearb with the root and all, what quantity yee will, and di≈øtill thereof a water, the which keep unto thy u≈øe, and when yee will u≈øe it again≈øt the Catarre, take of that water four ounces, with white crude Hony half an ounce, mix them well together, and drink it in the morning warm as ≈øoon as yee ri≈øe, and fa≈øt thereon four or five hours, and u≈øe a rea≈øonable diet in your meat and drink, and eat nothing that may offend the Catarre, and ≈øo u≈øing this remedy for a moneth together, thou ≈øhalt help any ≈øort of Catarre perfectly, by vertue of that hearb. For this I have experimented divers and ≈øundry times in poor and ≈øimple Catarres. But ‚Ä¢ if they come of the Pox, or Hectick, in that ca≈øe it may plea≈øure them much, but yet not cure them. Yee ≈øhall note, that it would be nece≈ø≈øary for the Patient to take a do≈øe of our Aromatico before he take the ≈øaid Medicine, becau≈øe our Aromatico di≈øpo≈øeth the Catarre to ≈øolution, whereby it may be the ≈øooner cured.

div.head: CHAP. LIII. Of Pollipodie, and his vertues.
div.p: THis hearb is well known to mo≈øt men, and hath great vertue again≈øt old greifs, and opilations, and all indi≈øpo≈øitions that come through di≈øtemperment of humours, becau≈øe it evacuateth the body, clean≈øeth the head, and purgeth the bloud: and the order to make it is thus.

Take Pollipodie two ounces, Sene one ounce, Lignum Aloes half an ounce, mix the≈øe well together in a ≈øtone morter, then take white Wine as much as yee will, and for every pound of Wine put thereto ‚Ñ•. i. of that mixture, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand four and twenty hours, and then drink it, for it will purge without any pain, tho≈øe that have any indi≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øtomack, weakne≈ø≈øe of the legs, and faintne≈ø≈øe of the body, and ≈øuch like. For yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, the Pollipodie purgeth
Flegm, and the Sene purgeth Choller, as by the vi≈øco≈øity is known: The Lignum Aloes pre≈øerveth nature, ≈øo that by the ingredients yee may know the vertue of this compo≈øition. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this root would be gathered when the Sunne is afarre off; and that the cold time of the year doth begin to draw on, for then they are of mo≈øt force.

div.head: CHAP. LXIV. Of the Olive, and his vertues.
div.p: TAke common Oil, the which is made of the Olive, two pound, Frankincen≈øe one pound, Turpentine one pound, di≈øtill them together in a Retort two dayes long, then ≈øeparate the oyle from the water, and keep each alone, then take forth the Fe≈ø≈øes out of the Retort, the which is a miracle of Nature, becau≈øe it ≈øerveth again≈øt all Infirmities, where it is applyed. It helpeth broaken bones wonderfully, and the≈øe ≈øecrets I have found out by experience. There is al≈øo drawn out of the wood a liquour by di≈øcention, the which is black of colour, and is of marvellous vertue again≈øt paines. A little of this Oil being mixed with Oil of Sulphur, helpeth all putrified and corro≈øive Ulcers that are cau≈øed of putrifaction of humours. The Lye made of the A≈øhes of Olives, pre≈øerveth the beard and hair in their naturall colour, if yee wa≈øh the head often therewith. Of this Oil I have made a great di≈øcour≈øe in my Chirurgery.

div.head: CHAP. LXV. Of Ciperous, and his vertues.
div.p:
THis hearb being put into new Wine, when it worketh in the Hog≈øhead, giveth it a plea≈øant ≈øavour, and who≈øoever u≈øeth to drink of that Wine, it will defend him from all interiour pa≈ø≈øions that are cau≈øed of vento≈øity, and helpeth tho≈øe that are troubled with the Rupture, becau≈øe it re≈øolveth the wind,
and hath a re≈øtrictive vertue. It purgeth the bloud marvellou≈øly, and cau≈øeth dige≈øtion, and of this I have ≈øeen the experience. Al≈øo I ≈øaw one, that in the moneths of April, May, and June, took the roots of Ciperous and beat them to powder, and made thereof a plai≈øter, and laid it upon the Rupture, changing it every day once: and al≈øo he eat of the ≈øaid roots, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time he was helped; and that experiment I have ≈øeen divers times. Al≈øo if yee take tho≈øe nodes or knots that are on the roots, and ≈øtamp them, and boil them with common Oil, Frankincen≈øe, and yellow Wax, untill it become black of colour, it will cure wounds marvellou≈øly, it mittigateth the pains in all old ≈øores, it cureth all pains coming of humidity and wind: Moreover, if yee annoint the body with the ≈øaid Oil, and drink the Wine wherein hath lien infu≈øed the ≈øaid root, it will pre≈øerve it marvellou≈øly. And among all other things that I ≈øaw of this Ciperous; there was a Merchant called Nicolo Carbolo, the which was of the age of thirty yeares, and was troubled with a kind of ≈øcab like a Leper, and had carried it long, the which I cau≈øed to make this Oil, and he did not onely annoint him therewith, but al≈øo drunk thereof every morning ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. with wine, ≈øo that in ≈øhort time he became ≈øo whole and ≈øound, that it was to be wondered at.

div.head: CHAP. LXVI. Of Rew, and his vertues.
div.p:
TAke Rew when it is ≈øeeded, but yet not dry, and ≈øtamp it in a Morter, and for every pound of Rew, put thereto ‚Ñ•. vi. of Turpentine, and as much of the yolks of Eggs hard ≈øod, and incorporate them well together; then put it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and ≈øet it to putrifie in warm dung five and twenty dayes, then di≈øtill it by a Retort according unto art, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, the which will be both Oil and water, the which yee ≈øhall ≈øeparate. The water ≈øerveth again≈øt all pains of the belly that are cau≈øed of cold and moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe; the do≈øe is í. ≈øs. in ≈øome warm broth,
and may be taken at any time. Al≈øo giving it to any that hath a ‚Ä¢ ever coming with cold, it will help him in ≈øhort time: yea, ≈øome have been cured at once or twice taking the ≈øame. Moreover, the Oil is mo≈øt ≈øoveraign again≈øt cold greifs, as well inward as outward, it pre≈øerveth tho≈øe greatly, that take every morning a drachm with ≈øweet wine, and fa≈øt thereon four or five hours. Al≈øo for outward griefs it is mo≈øt excellent, if yee annoint them therewith cold, becau≈øe it re≈øolveth and drieth all evill qualities of our bodies: be≈øides the≈øe experiences, I have made an Oil of the ≈øeed of Rew by expre≈ø≈øion, the which is of ≈øo much vertue, that if yee annoint the head therewith, it cau≈øeth a good memory unto tho≈øe that have lo≈øt it, or are weak by rea≈øon of humidity, or cold.

div.head: CHAP. LXVII. Of Wormwood, and his vertues.
div.p: THis hearb Wormwood is of great vertue, if yee can u≈øe it well: for if any lean per≈øons or evill coloured u≈øe the ≈øame, it will bring them to their perfect health and colour, and the order to make it is thus.

Take Wormwood and di≈øtill it in Balneo, then put thereunto Oil of Vitriol, as much as will ≈øuffice to make it tart, and thereof u≈øe every morning one ≈øpoonfull fa≈øting, and in ≈øhort time it will re≈øtore thee to perfecter health than ever thou wa≈øt before, and bring thy colour again.

div.head: CHAP. LXVIII. Of Gratia Dei, and his vertues and operation in divers infirmities.
div.p:
THis Gratia Dei is an hearb well known unto mo≈øt men, and is like unto Germander, and bitter in ta≈øte, and it ought to be gathered in July and Augu≈øt, and mu≈øt be dried in the ≈øhadow, hanging ≈øo that it may touch nothing, and
then ‚Ñà i. of this powder will provoke vomit, and ea≈øe Nature. It helpeth al≈øo putrified Ulcers, if ye make a decoction thereof with Lye, and then wet clothes therein, and lay them upon the ≈øore; for as it cau≈øeth to vomit and evacuateth the ≈øtomack, ≈øo neither more nor le≈ø≈øe it cau≈øeth the Ulcer to vomit, or purge, and healeth it with great ≈øpeed: It helpeth much tho≈øe that are Phrenzie, by rea≈øon that it mundifieth the ≈øtomack and bodie from ≈øuch putrifaction.

A mo≈øt excellent compo≈øition of this Hearb. Take thereof in fine powder, ‚Ñ•.i. Cinnamon, í.i. Cloves, ‚Ñà. i. Wheat flower one pound, Zucche compo≈øt condit. ‚Ñ•. iii. Oranges condited, one ounce, beat them altogether, and make thereof a pa≈øt with Honey, and form it like a loaf, and ≈øet it in an Oven to bake, but take heed it doe not burn, and when thou wilt u≈øe it, give thereof one ounce, and it will purge gallantly, and is very delectable to be eaten. This Purgation is divine in many infirmities, but above all other again≈øt Scrophule, the white Scall, and Scabs, becau≈øe it evacuateth onely the ≈øuperfluous humiditie, and drieth, and is appropriate for the≈øe infirmities: For ye ≈øhall note, that all Soluble Medicines doe not ≈øerve in one infirmitie, becau≈øe one is Cholerick, the other Sanguine, one Flegmatick, and the other Melancholie, and for that cau≈øe it is nece≈ø≈øary to find the proper Medicine for the infirmitie. The Rhabarb purgeth Choller: The Eleborus Melancholie; the Ebulus or Wallwort Flegm, and the Gratia dei the bloody, ≈øo that every one hath his propertie.

div.head: CHAP. LXIX. Of Wallwort and his Vertues and Operations.
div.p:
VVAllwort is an Herb‚ñ™ well known, and groweth in a fat ground, and hath leaves, flouers, and ≈øeed like Elder, and is of ≈øuch vertue that it is to be wondred at, for if it were brought unto us from farr Countries, it would be accounted above all other hearbs, but being ≈øo familiar among us, we make no account thereof. This Herb called Wallwort or Dainwort, by his propertie and nature provoketh vomit
and di≈ø≈øolveth the bodie, if ye drinke the juyce thereof, or eat the Hearb green: The water di≈øtilled of this Root being drunke, and applied outwardly with wet clothes unto the Gout, it taketh away the pain. If ye give the juyce of this Hearb with Sirrup of Aceto≈øe to drink, it will help frantick Fevers. The pouder of his leaves hath great operation in all ≈øorts of putrified Ulcers, becau≈øe it taketh away the pain, mundifieth, and incarnateth, with divers other vertues, the which if I ≈øhould write them they would not be credited, and therefore I leave it to the Experimentor.

div.head: CHAP. LXX. Of Millefolie or Yarrow, and his great vertue.
div.p:
THis Hearb Millefolie, is well known unto mo≈øt men; and of many is little e≈øteemed, becau≈øe it groweth ≈øo commonly among≈øt us. This Hearb being green, is a miraculous and divine remedie, to help any ≈øorts of fre≈øh and bleeding wounds, if ye ≈øtamp a handfull thereof, and lay it thereupon the lips being clo≈øe joyned together, within the ≈øpace of four and twentie-houres it ≈øhall be perfectly whole. If yee drinke three ounces of the juyce of this Hearb with new Milk, morning and evening, it will help Gonorrea in ≈øhort time. It is al≈øo an excellent remedie for tho≈øe that have their Liver and Lungs ulcerated, for this I have proved divers and ≈øundry times in Goats, the which are troubled with a certain infirmitie, the which is called Bi≈ø≈øole of the Goat-keepers, for they are certain Impo≈øthumes that doe ingender in the Liver and the Lungs, and cau≈øeth them to die. I then ≈øeeing that in the interiour parts of the Goats, made this experience, I took Millefolie made in powder, and gave it unto the Goats with Salt, and for the mo≈øt part they were helped; and after that I cured a number of men and women of that di≈øea≈øe, for of that infirmity there die a great number in the world. And with the ≈øaid order afore≈øaid, thou maye≈øt ≈øave a number, but it mu≈øt be mixed with Sal artificiato Leonardo. Tho≈øe that are Ettici and Te≈øici die commonly through Impo≈øthumes
and Ulcers that are cau≈øed in the Liver, for of this I have ≈øeen above an hundred. For after they were dead, I have cau≈øed them to be opened to ≈øee the experience. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this Hearb Millefolie hath a great propertie to heal tho≈øe Ulcers. And therefore the Chirurgian that under≈øtandeth not Phy≈øick, can ill help tho≈øe Ulcers inwardly, becau≈øe he cannot apply his Unguents and Plai≈øters, as he doth outwardly. And tho≈øe kind of Ulcers cannot be known, but of tho≈øe which have ≈øeen them, and have ≈øeen the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their di≈øea≈øes, and therefore I may well di≈øcour≈øe thereof, becau≈øe of them have pa≈ø≈øed a great number through my hands, and I have ≈øeen them with mine eyes. So that I conclude, that all which I have ≈øaid is two things, the one is, to ≈øee the thing in fact, the other, to have approved Medicines to help them. A mo≈øt excellent compo≈øition of this Hearb, the which helpeth wounds in very ≈øhort time.

Take this Hearb when it is floured, and readie to ≈øeed, and put thereunto Bdellium, Frankincen≈øe, and common oyle, and make thereof as it were Mu≈øtard, then di≈øtill it with a gentle fire, with great diligence, as ye di≈øtill our Oleum Benedictum, and thou ≈øhalt have a rare Secret again≈øt all manner of wounds, ≈øo that it cau≈øeth the world to wonder at his operation.

div.head: CHAP. LXXI. Of Gentian and his Experiments, approved by mee many times.
div.p:
THis Hearb is well known, and his vertue is mo≈øt in the Root, and is a miraculous and divine remedie for tho≈øe that have pains within the bodie cau≈øed of winde, and al≈øo for tho≈øe that have the Stitch in the ≈øide, if yee give the powder thereof in ≈øweet white wine, for pre≈øently it taketh away the pain, becau≈øe his nature is to di≈ø≈øolve winde, the which is cau≈øed of oppilations of the Pores through abundance of humiditie, and the Gentian hath vertue to drie and di≈ø≈øolve wind,
and ≈øo Nature doth evaporate the vento≈øitie: And this is the rea≈øon why the Gentian doth that effect.

div.head: CHAP. LXXII. Of Imperatoria and his great experience that it doth again≈øt pains of the Mother.
div.p: THis Hearb is of great vertue in his operation, if his Root be made in powder, and given to eat with Honey unto a woman that is troubled with the Mother, either through cold or heat. For if they be grieved through cold, the Imperatoria which is hot, doth di≈ø≈øolve it, and they ≈øhall be delivered. If it be through heat, the heat is alwaies windie, becau≈øe the heat is none other thing, then a humour retained in tho≈øe parts, the which this hearb by his proper vertue and qualitie doth re≈øolve. So that whether it be cold or hot, this vertuous hearb helpeth them with great ≈øpeed, for this I have proved an infinite number of times. Moreover this hearb hath great vertue to comfort the ≈øtomack, and cau≈øeth dige≈øtion, and to pre≈øerve all the bodie, and for that cau≈øe the Ancients have called it Imperatoria.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIII. Of Cardo Sancto and his vertues particular, the which I have proved.
div.p:
THere are many kind of hearbs, the which are called Cardi, but unto that which they call Cardo Sancto; they have added Sancto, becau≈øe the people ≈øhould know, that it is an hearb of great value in certain di≈øea≈øes, ≈øo that it is to bee wondred at for his operation. And that which I have ≈øeen, thereof will I write in this place, that is, if yee ≈øtamp this hearb when it is green, and lay it upon the wound, it will heal it miraculou≈øly, and with great ≈øpeed. Al≈øo the juyce or powder of the ≈øaid hearb being given to drink unto tho≈øe that have worms, pre≈øently it helpeth them. This Herb being dried
and infu≈øed in Aqua vitae, and given to drink to any that is grieved with any grievous pains, in ≈øhort time he ≈øhall bee whole. This Hearb is al≈øo good for the ≈øight of the eies: If ye make a pa≈øt thereof with Bread and Honey, and di≈øtill it with white wine, it is mo≈øt excellent. It hath al≈øo two great Vertues to pre≈øerve humane bodies, the which I have proved, the one is outwardly, and the other inwardly, and they are made in this order.

Take Carduus Benedictus when it beginneth to flour, and ≈øtamp it gro≈øly, and infu≈øe it in common oyle and Aqua vitae, with a little Frankincen≈øe, and there let them remain, untill they be macerated, then boil them and ≈øtrain it, then take thereof a third part, and put thereto a little Virgin waxe, and let it boil, untill it begin to fume, and turn to a black colour, then ≈øtrain it, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, that it take no aire, then if yee take one drachm of the oyle with ≈øweet wine cold, it will re≈øolve any infirmitie, and pre≈øerve them that u≈øe it in health; with the black liquor yee ≈øhall annoint all the body when yee go to bed, cold, the which doth not onely re≈øolve the evill qualitie, but pre≈øerveth a man in good ≈øtate. It maintaineth the hair black, ≈øo that it ≈øhall not waxe white: It killeth worms in the bodie, with divers other things, that I will leave untill another time.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIV. Of ≈øweet Marjoram, and of his Secrets the which I have proved.
div.p:
MArjoram hath great and rare vertues, the which I have proved, becau≈øe others might know them and u≈øe them, when occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve. And fir≈øt I will write of the juyce, the which is of ≈øuch ≈øtrength and vertue, that one ounce thereof being mixt with one drachm of Oyl of bitter Almonds, and one ≈øcruple of Ma≈øtick in powder, being ≈ønuffed up at the no≈øe, untill it come unto the mouth, it purgeth the head of all pains, di≈ø≈øolveth tumours, quickneth the ≈øight, and cau≈øeth ≈øleep, and helpeth the head of all infirmities: Al≈øo Marjoram
put into Vinegar, with Cloves and Cinnamon, and make thereof an Epithema, it di≈ø≈øolveth the evill di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øtomack, and quickeneth the appetite, and provoketh ≈øleep, and being eaten in Sallets, it comforteth the Stomack marvellou≈øly, with divers other vertues, the which I have not ≈øeen.

div.head: CHAP. LXXV. Of the Hearb called Laciola, or Ophio Glo≈ø≈øen, of ≈øome Adders tongue, or Lancea Chri≈øti.
div.p: THis Hearb is of marvellous vertue, for if it be laid upon a wound, either green or drie, it healeth it marvellou≈øly, and with ≈øpeed, and that it doth by his hidden and ≈øecret vertue. The decoction of this Hearb healeth wounds inwardly, and al≈øo other offences, it helpeth the Rupture in young children, being new done, if yee lay it thereon, and bind it hard with a Tru≈ø≈øe, the≈øe Vertues I have ≈øeen of this Hearb.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVI. Of Hypericon or Saint Johns-wort.
div.p: THere is an Oyle made of the Seed of this Hearb by expre≈ø≈øion, the which being annointed upon a wound, it doth heal it with great ≈øpeed. It is al≈øo excellent for tho≈øe which have the Pitechie that is, a certain di≈øea≈øe ≈øo called in the Italian tongue, it is al≈øo mo≈øt excellent again≈øt all Poi≈øons. This Hearb is al≈øo good again≈øt ≈øcabbs, if ye annoint them with the juyce, and drinke his decoction, becau≈øe it quencheth and cooleth the ≈øuperfluous heat. And this it doth by his proper qualitie, and hidden vertue.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVII. Of Nettles, and his vertue in many operations.
div.p: THis hearb is commonly known among us, and is of marvellous vertue, and his effects are uncredible. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will not let to ≈øhew one experiment of it, the which is marvellous, and is this: Take a Capon, and pull away all his feathers from his brea≈øt, and beat him with Nettles, and he will call in the young Chickens, and govern them like the Hen. Nettles being dried and made into powder, and given to eat unto a man, it will provoke venereous acts, being u≈øed to be eaten in meats, it purgeth the Matrix, it helpeth ≈øcabs, if you wa≈øh them with his decoction, and mittigateth all pains coming of cold, making a bath thereof; his decoction helpeth the tooth-ach, with many other vertues that I have not proved. But truly I beleeve, that if any would give him≈øelf to ≈øeek experience in this hearb, he ≈øhould ≈øee ≈øtrange things. For I have alwayes ≈øeen that in the≈øe kind of hearbs, that naturally will not be touched, God and Nature hath given great vertue.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVIII. Of Hy≈øop of the Mountain.
div.p: THis hearb hath great vertue, for if his decoction be given to drink unto tho≈øe that have the flux of Urine, in ≈øhort time it will help them: The like doth his decoction in wounds impo≈øthumated, for if yee wa≈øh them therewith, it will mundifie, and re≈øtrain, and bring it pre≈øently to be whole. Al≈øo if yee make powder thereof, and lay it upon a fre≈øh wound, it will help it pre≈øently, and that it doth by his great e≈øtranged vertue. It helpeth the Cough, being infufed in Wine and drunk.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIX. A great ≈øecret of a kind of Betonie.
div.p: THere is found in the field a certain kind of Betonie, the which is the length of an arm or more, and as big in the ≈øtalk as a Goo≈øe quill, and it is four ≈øquare, and the leaf is much like unto the Oaken leafe, and his flour is much like the colour of a Violet, and his ≈øeed is black, and much lik unto the grains of Gunpowder, and this hearb in Lumbardie is called Betonica, and in the Realm of Naples it is called Centra galla, and of this hearb I have ≈øeen great vertues and experience, and e≈øpecially when it beginneth to flour untill it be ≈øeeded: for if yee di≈øtill it with ≈øweet Wine, and receive thereof onely the fourth part, it will re≈øtore the ≈øight unto tho≈øe that are almo≈øt blind: It comforteth a weak ≈øtomack very much, if yee drink thereof every morning three or four drachms. The Fe≈ø≈øes which remain in the gla≈ø≈øe being mixed with Hony and a little Zedoaria, helpeth women that are troubled with the Mother, if they drink thereof every morning ‚Ñ•. viii. warm. This hearb being bruie≈ød with Wine and Salt, and laid upon a fre≈øh wound every three dayes once, helpeth the ≈øame with ≈øpeed: Al≈øo if yee put one of his ≈øeeds into the eyes, and there let it remain ≈øo long as yee may ≈øuffer it, it will clear the ≈øight marvellou≈øly, for it hath been proved many times. It helpeth tho≈øe kind of Scabs the which are mo≈øt evill to be helped, being mixed in this order.

Take the juyce of this hearb, although it be ≈øomewhat drie and hard to get forth, and for every ounce of that juyce, put thereunto ‚Ñ•. iiii. of the Oil of Frankincen≈øe that cometh forth la≈øt in the di≈øtillation, and boil them a little together untill it begin to fume, then take it from the fire and ≈øtrain it through a cloth, and when yee goe to bed annoint all the ≈øcabs therewith cold, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee a mo≈øt ≈øtrange cure, never written of before by any man, the which I have proved divers and ≈øundry times, and is a ≈øecret to be u≈øed on noble per≈øonages, becau≈øe it doth his effect without letting of bloud, and purging, mo≈øt wonderfull to behold: So that it is to be
accounted rather a divine Medicine then humane; for truly I have done more cures with this hearb then with any other that ever I u≈øed.

div.head: CHAP. LXXX. Of the effects of Wine, and what cometh thereof.
div.p: FIr≈øt I will ≈øpeak of Wine and his qualities. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that Wine is a liquour the which changeth into divers kinds differing from his own nature: And fir≈øt it changeth into Vineger of it ≈øelf without any artifice, the which can never be turned into Wine again. Al≈øo they ≈øeparate from Wine Aqua vitae, the which being ≈øeparated cannot be turned into Wine again. Al≈øo Wine maketh, by ≈øetling it ≈øelf, a certain ≈øtone called Tartar, the which can never be turned into Wine again, nor yet into Vineger. And thus when the workman doth tran≈ømute or change it, it cannot be turned again into his fir≈øt quality. Wine is very apt to corrupt, and to change into other kinds, but after that it changeth or tran≈ømuteth, it is uncorruptible: for when it is turned into Vineger, it is apt to con≈øerve all things. Vegetable and Animall that is put therein, but not the Minerals, for by nature it is enemy unto them. There is al≈øo ≈øeparated from Wine Aqua vitae, the which is con≈øervatrix of all Medicines; for when it is circulated and made into a Quinte≈ø≈øence it becometh cele≈øtiall, as I have ≈øhewed in my other books, and therewith thou maye≈øt help many infirmities, becau≈øe it mittigateth all pains, and di≈ø≈øolveth in a manner all infirmities, and e≈øpecially when it is compounded in this manner.

Take of that Quinte≈ø≈øence four parts, Oil of Sulphur and Vitrioll of each one part, Julep of Violets ≈øixty parts: Mix them all together, and it will be of ≈øuch vertue, that if yee give í. i. thereof to drink to one that lay at the point of death, it would recover him, becau≈øe it breaketh choller, pre≈øerveth the ≈øtomack, cau≈øeth an appetite, and helpeth any ≈øort of Fever, and pre≈øerveth both men and women in lu≈øty ≈øtate, if they
u≈øe it oftentimes; for the≈øe experiences I have ≈øeen divers times. Al≈øo of the Tartar yee may may make Oyle, the which is of marvellous vertue, both in Phy≈øick, Chirurgerie, and Alchimie. There is al≈øo drawn forth of Tartar, his ≈øpirit and oyle in this order, as Andernacus writeth, the which is mo≈øt profitable again≈øt ≈øundry infirmities, and the order to make it is thus.

Take white Tartar and beat it to powder four pound, and put it into a ≈øtone pot or gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and ≈øet it in a furnace to di≈øtill with a great Receiver clo≈øe luted, lea≈øt all the fumes come forth or break the gla≈ø≈øe, then give it fir≈øt a ≈ømall fire, and ≈øo increa≈øe it as though thou woulde≈øt draw a ≈øtrong water, and ≈øo continue it untill there come forth no more ≈øpirits, then let it wax cold, and take forth the liquor, and put it into an upright gla≈ø≈øe with his head and receiver, and di≈øtill away the water in Balneo, then take that oyle which is in the bottome, and di≈øtill it in Sand or A≈øhes, and there will come forth at the fir≈øt a yellowi≈øh oyle, and ≈øo by little and little it will change colour, and become blacker and blacker, and thick like unto a Balme, or a Sirrup. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the fir≈øt Liquor ≈øeparated in Balneo, is called Liquor fecularum vini, or Spiritus Tartari, the oyle which yee rectified in Sand, is called Oleum fecularum vini, ≈øive Mumia fecularum vini the which is mo≈øt effectuall and profitable in curing all running Ulcers that goeth creeping upon the fle≈øh, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that come Ex lue venerea, for this Mumia doth ≈øo cure tho≈øe malign Ulcers, that their malice can hurt no more, but ≈øhall be quite extincted: Being drunke with wine, it doth break and expell the Stone in the Reins and Bladder, it provoketh Urine and purgeth Ulcers. Furthermore, í. i. of the liquor or ≈øpirit of Tartar, being drunke with water of Fumitorie or Hirundinariae or ≈øuch like, as is mo≈øt convenient for Pu≈øtulas gallicas ex anthemate ericipelas, the Drop≈øie, Water betwixt the skin and the fle≈øh, Fevers, Men≈øtrua, and all ob≈øtructions of tho≈øe parts; it will work all tho≈øe effects more effectuall if it be taken with water of Triacle, the which is made as hereafter followeth. Al≈øo yee ≈øhall under≈øtand that this ≈øpirit of Tartar mu≈øt be rectified four or
five times from the calces of his Fe≈ø≈øes in Balneo, to take away his ≈øtinking ≈ømell, and then it will be the purer and more effectuall, and this is the making of Aqua Theriacalis.

Take Triacle of Alexander that is perfect good‚ñ™ ‚Ñ•. v. red Myrrh, ‚Ñ•. ii. Saffron, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. mix them together in a gla≈ø≈øe, and pour thereon, ‚Ñ•. x. of the ≈øpirit of Wine, and then ≈øet them clo≈øe ≈øtopped to dige≈øt, then di≈øtill it according unto art; ≈øometime they put into this water ‚Ñà. ii. of Camphire e≈øpecially when it is u≈øed in hot burning Fevers and InflaÃÑmations, and and then it is called Aqua theriacalis camforata, this Compo≈øition following being drunk, hath a ≈øingular piercing vertue. Take Spiritus calcanthi, ‚Ñ•. i. Liquoris fecularum vini correcti, ‚Ñ•. iii. Aqua Theriacalis ‚Ñ•. v. give thereof í. i. in ≈øtrong wine or other convenient liquor both for the afore≈øaid defects, and al≈øo to prevent and cure infinite other di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXI. Of the qualitie of Vinegar, and his Secrets.
div.p:
VInegar is made of wine, and of water. Whereas there is wine, they make it of wine, but in tho≈øe Countries where there groweth no wine, they make it of beer and ale, in ≈øtead of wine, the which Vinegar is very ≈øtrong. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it hath not the vertue and qualitie of that which is made of wine, becau≈øe his nature is to pre≈øerve tho≈øe things which are put therein, as is ≈øaid before. If yee doe di≈øtill Vinegar in Balneo untill it remain drie, and then burn tho≈øe Fe≈ø≈øes untill they come white, and then lay them in a moi≈øt place, it will turn into Oyle, the which is of ≈øuch vertue for mans bodie, that it is not to be credited, for if yee give thereof a ≈ømall quantitie to drink, it will di≈ø≈øolve the Gravel, and Stone in the Bladder. And therefore this is a worthy ≈øecret to be known, the which was never revealed before to any man: As for his other vertues, they are known to all men. Di≈øtilled Vinegar being mixed with a little oyle of Tartar and Aqua vitae, pre≈øerveth the face, and maketh it fair, but if it were not a ≈øin to offend God, I could ≈øay ≈øuch great and ≈øtrange things of di≈øtilled
Vinegar, that it would cau≈øe the world to wonder at it, but for troubling my con≈øcience, I will hold my peace for this time, and leave this to be ≈øufficient, which I have written already.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXII. Of the Fe≈ø≈øes of Wine, and of his Secrets that I have found out.
div.p: THat which is called Allum du Fe≈ø≈øe, is the Fe≈ø≈øes of Wine burnt, the which I have ≈øpoken of in other places, but here I will ≈øhew thee a great and rare Secret, never written before by any man, the which ≈øhall be to the honour of the Phy≈øitian, and this is the Secret.

Take the Fe≈ø≈øes of Aqua fortis, made with Roch Allom, Sal Niter, and Vitriol two pound, Allum du Fe≈ø≈øe two pound, mix them well together, and put them into a Furnace to calcine, untill it become to a hard ≈øtone: and when it is calcined, make it pre≈øently into powder, and ≈øet it four or five nights in the ayre, and it will turn moi≈øt, then take ≈øix pound of pure Aqua vitae without flegm, and put therein the ≈øame powder, and ≈øo let it remain eight daies, every day ≈øtirring it once, then pour of that part which is clear, and keep it as a precious Jewell, then take the Fe≈ø≈øes and calcine them again, as yee did at the fir≈øt, and make them in powder again: And this powder mundifieth all filthie and ≈øtinking ≈øores, and with this water thou maye≈øt help them, if that the workman can apply it with rea≈øon. Al≈øo with this water may be done great cures in Phy≈øick, if it be given as it ought to be. Al≈øo of the ≈øaid powder there may be made Pills and Potions, that worketh miracles in the world, as I have ≈øeen divers times.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXIII. Of Verjuyce made of Grapes, and his Secrets.
div.p:
VErjuyce is the Juice of unripe Grapes, the which is kept to dre≈ø≈øe and ≈øea≈øon meats, to give them a better ta≈øte,
and it is of great vertue, and appropriate for many things. But when it ≈øhall be di≈øtilled with Hony, and Allum du Fe≈ø≈øe in a Limbeck of gla≈ø≈øe, it will be a miraculous remedie for Impo≈øthumes that are very hot. It maketh women fair and ≈øhining, if they wa≈øh them therewith. But if this be mixed with oyle of Talk, it will re≈øtore the ≈øight unto tho≈øe that are almo≈øt blind. Al≈øo two drachms of di≈øtilled Verjuyce, with two drachms of the juyce of Betonie, and four ounces of Milk being u≈øed, will make a man very luxurious, and help a weak back. Al≈øo Verjuyce being di≈øtilled, will bring an appetite unto tho≈øe that have lo≈øt it. And all the≈øe are with great rea≈øon, for yee ≈øhall under≈øtand that the Verjuyce without any other Artifice, doth mundifie the ≈øtomack, and loo≈øe the bodie, and purifie the blood: The Honey is Cordiall, and is hot by nature, and di≈ø≈øolveth winde, the Alum du Fe≈ø≈øe drieth, and de≈øtroyeth all the evill humours: The Talk is bright and ≈øhining, and his whitene≈ø≈øe doth penetrate very much: The Betonie comforteth the ≈øtomack, and is windie: The Milk is aperative and nutritive, and therefore con≈øider well thereon, and thou ≈øhalt find it rea≈øon and experience that I have ≈øaid.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXIV. Certain Secrets of Animals, and fir≈øt of the Oxe.
div.p:
THe fat of the Oxe is very appropriate to Unguents, to help all manner of ≈øores, becau≈øe it comforteth the place offended, and mittigateth the pain; but when this grea≈øe or fat ≈øhall be di≈øtilled with Turpentine and Wax, it will work Miracles in divers operations, of the which I will not ≈øpeak in this place. There is in the throat of divers old Oxen certain knots or kernels as a man may term them, the which are of the bigne≈øs of an Olive, ≈øome are bigger and ≈øome le≈ø≈øer, according to the age of the Oxe. Take of tho≈øe kernells, and hang them up to drie in the ≈øhadow, and make thereof powder, and of that powder give every morning, ≈øs. ‚Ñ•.
unto tho≈øe that have the Drop≈øie, and in ≈øhort time they ≈øhall be helped. Al≈øo the ≈øinnews of an Oxe being dried, and made lint to make tents or ≈øtoppings, is mo≈øt excellent, and will work great effects, and this is one of the Secrets, the which I never meant to reveal untill death. The blood of a young Bull that is not gelded, being drunken as it is warm, is mo≈øt ≈øtrong poi≈øon, there are al≈øo divers other things, the which I would write of this Bea≈øt but for tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øake.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXV. Of the Goat.
div.p: THe fat of the Male Goat before he is gelded is of much vertue, becau≈øe it comforteth all members that are offended, as well inwardly as outwardly: If yee annoint any that hath the Flux with the ≈øaid grea≈øe, it will doe him great plea≈øure. Al≈øo the dung of the Goat is mo≈øt excellent to mollifie ≈øinnews that are indurated in any place, and therefore this dung being put into Unguents appropriate, of force mu≈øt work great Effects.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXVI. Of the Hor≈øe and his Vertues.
div.p: THe Dung of the Hor≈øe is of great vertue, for if a man were lame, and indurated through gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, let him be buried in fre≈øh warm Hor≈øe dung two hours, and in ten or twelve daies he ≈øhall be helped. The fat of the Hor≈øe is very hot and penetrative, and e≈øpecially that in the neck, where the Main groweth. Al≈øo the fat being di≈øtilled with the ro≈øin of the Pine tree and Myrrh, is miraculous again≈øt ≈øhrunk ≈øinnews.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXVII. Of the Dog and his Secrets.
div.p: THe Dog is an amiable Animall above all other unto man, for he under≈øtandeth in a manner what a man doth ≈øay; and from the Dog is taken many whol≈øome things for man, for of the skin they make Gloves, and ≈øuch like, the which are whol≈øome for them that wear them. The fat of the Dog is very hot and piercing, and di≈ø≈øolveth all pains that come of cold. The dung of a Dog is profitable to dre≈ø≈øe Leather withall, al≈øo his blood mixed with Hogs grea≈øe, and the A≈øhes of a Vine, di≈ø≈øolveth all manner of ≈øwellings, that come in divers parts of the bodie.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXVIII. Of the Cat and his Vertues.
div.p: THe Cat is very hot, above all other animals, that appertain unto the hou≈øe, and his fat is of ≈øuch heat, that it is uncredible to be ≈øpoken of, and he is never in love, or goeth a catterwalling, but in the colde≈øt weather. The Brain of the Cat is of ≈øuch a heat, that if any doe eat thereof, it will make him mad; if yee annoint certain places of the hou≈øe with the fat, it will cau≈øe the Mice to run away, fearing lea≈øt the Cat were there, and that is by a hidden propertie. There ingendereth in the fle≈øh of a dead Cat certain putrified Worms, the which afterward become a kinde of Flie, that are called Taphaeni, the which is a very great enemie to the Oxe, and all other Cattell, for they will run away from them, for if they be bitten therewith, they will in a manner be mad.

div.head: CHAP. LXXXIX. Of the Hare and his Secrets.
div.p:
THe blood of the Hare being dried in the Furnace, and made into powder, helpeth tho≈øe much, which are troubled
with the ≈øtone and gravell, giving it to drink with the juyce of Pelitory. The hair of the Hare ≈øerveth to ≈øtench bloud in wounds. The Te≈øticles of the Hare dried in a Furnace, and made into powder, and being drunk, provoketh venereous acts. The Gaul of the Hare being di≈øtilled with Hony and Aqua vitae, is a miraculous remedy for the ≈øight of the eyes, putting therein every night one drop when yee goe to bed. There is yet a great vertue in the Hare, that if I ≈øhould reveale it, the world would wonder at it, and therefore I omit it unto the ingenious.

div.head: CHAP. XC. Of the Frog and his ≈øecrets.
div.p: THe≈øe Frogs are of great vertue in divers operations; for their fat helpeth the Lepro≈øie if ye annoint them therewith, and is a mo≈øt miraculous thing for tho≈øe that are burnt, or ≈øcalded with water; for if yee annoint them therewith, it will help them quickly, and leave no ≈øcar. But if this fat be di≈øtilled with Mirrh, and Aqua vitae, and accompanied with Aloes, and the juyce of Bra≈ø≈øica Marina, called Soldanella, and thereof made Pills, they will be of ≈øo much vertue, that one ≈øcruple or two of tho≈øe Pills being given oftentimes unto one that hath the Drop≈øie, they ≈øhall be helped quickly, and hereof I have had great experience, to my great honour and profit of the Patient.

div.head: CHAP. XCI. A di≈øcour≈øe upon certain ≈øtones, and their qualities in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery: and fir≈øt of the Marble ≈øtone.
div.p:
THere are a great number of ≈øtones that the Maje≈øty of God hath created in the world, of the which I will make mention of ≈øome, as well Minerall as Artificiall, becau≈øe the Phy≈øitian as well as the Chirurgian, may be ≈øerved therof in their affairs, although it be hard to have knowledge of tho≈øe
things, becau≈øe they are much differing one from another, and grow in divers parts of the world: yea, and although they be brought unto us, yet they are ≈øo unknown, that we cannot know the thou≈øand part of their vertues and qualities. And to begin, I will write of the Marble, the which is a white ≈øtone, like unto Sugar when it is broken, and it is of great vertue in Chirurgery, for when it is brought into calkes, thereof may be made an Unguent of great vertue in this order. Take of that calkes, and lay it to ≈øteep in fair water, ≈øo that it may be covered four fingers, then ≈øtir it eight or ten times a day, and then let it wax clear and ≈øettle, then pour it off, and put on more, and doe as yee did before, and when the water is ≈øettled clear pour it off again, then take of that calkes what quantity you will, and with Oil of Ro≈øes make it into an Unguent, the which is marvellous for ≈øuch as are troubled with heat, for it drieth, and cooleth, and ≈øetteth it in good di≈øpo≈øition, ≈øo that with ea≈øe it may be healed.

div.head: CHAP. XCII. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon Lapis Ematites, and his vertues in Chirurgery.
div.p:
THis Lapis Ematites is a ≈øtone like unto the Mine of Iron, the which if it be ground into powder will be red like unto Sinaper, and thereof thou ≈øhalt make an Unguent in this manner. Take Oil of Ro≈øes four ounces, Auxungia two ounces, new Wax half an ounce, Turpentine one ounce, Lapis Ematites in mo≈øt fine powder three ounces, mix them well together in a Copper pan with a ≈ømall fire, untill it begin to give certain fumes, or ≈ømell, and it will be black, then take it from the fire, and alwayes ≈øtir it untill it be cold; and then it will be hard like a Cerot, the which is miraculous in healing corro≈øive Ulcers. Al≈øo this ≈øtone being in fine powder, and made into a Lineament with Vineger, Oil of Ro≈øes, and a little Litarge, helpeth Scabs, and quencheth their heat, and cooleth the blood. Al≈øo two drachms of this powder being eaten with Sugar ro≈øate, helpeth tho≈øe which have inflammations
in their ≈øtomack with ≈øpeed. This ≈øtone hath al≈øo divers other vertues, the which I will leave at this time.

div.head: CHAP. XCIII. Of the ≈øtone of Iron, which ≈øome call Loppa.
div.p: THe≈øe ≈øtones which the workmen take from the Forge, that are called Loppa diferro, are of great importance, if we may beleeve the Alchimi≈øts, becau≈øe they ≈øay, that this ≈øtone is the beginning of their Stone, &c. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this ≈øtone is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary both in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, when it ≈øhall be well prepared as it ought to be: and his preparation is in this order. Take that ma≈ø≈øe of matter and ≈øtamp it, and ≈øearce it very fine, and then put it into a ve≈ø≈øell that is apt to re≈øi≈øt the fire, and ≈øet it in a gla≈ø≈øe Furnace for twenty or thirty dayes, and then it will be a red ma≈ø≈øe, the which yee ≈øhall beat into an impalpable powder, the which if thou wilt u≈øe in Phy≈øick thou mai≈øt di≈ø≈øolve in Vinegar, and when it is di≈ø≈øolved keep it for inflammations of the Liver and Stomack, the which thou maye≈øt give with any kind of Sirrup appropriate, for this is a miraculous Medicine again≈øt the flux of the body. Al≈øo if yee make an Unguent of the ≈øaid powder with Oil of Wax, of Frankincen≈øe, and Eggs, it will work ≈øtrange operations in Contu≈øions and Di≈ølocations of bones, laying it thereon very warm, becau≈øe it re≈øolveth all alteration, mittigateth the pain, and comforteth the place offended. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that it was never made of none but of us, which ever ≈øeek new Medicines and goodly experiences, to plea≈øure the world with that Art.

div.head: CHAP. XCIV. Of Lapis Judaicus and his form, and wherefore it ≈øerveth in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery.
div.p:
THis Lapis Judaicus is a certain ≈øtone, the which is like unto the ≈øimilitude of the Cuckows Egge, and is of a grayi≈øh colour
and rough, and within it is another ≈øtone like unto a Nut, and this ≈øtone is of a great vertue in his operation; for if it be beaten into powder, and di≈ø≈øolved in di≈øtilled Vineger, and then mixed with Sirrup of Saxifrage, and given to drink to tho≈øe that are troubled with gravell, it will cau≈øe them to avoid it in their Urine: and to break the ≈øtone, they ≈øhall mix the powder with Hony, and lay it on plai≈øter-wi≈øe upon the Reines, and it will break the gravell with ≈øpeed. Moreover, this Stone hath two rare vertues, the which I will not write of in this place, but I would coun≈øell tho≈øe that carry them upon their bodies to have two, a Male and a Female, and look upon them every day once, for of this ≈øtone I have ≈øeen great experience.

div.head: CHAP. XCV. Of Lapis Lazuli and his operation.
div.p:
CErtain wi≈øe men in the world that have made great con≈øideration of this ≈øtone, ≈øay, that this is the ≈øtone of gold, becau≈øe it is mixed with Azure, white and yellow, and al≈øo other colours; but I find that in many places of the world, they have the Mine of gold, and yet they find no Lapis Lazuli; and therefore it is a ≈øigne that it groweth in places where Nature doth produce it in that form. And for that which I have ≈øeen of Lapis Lazuli is, that if yee give it inwardly it provoketh vomit, and helpeth the Quartain Ague: And I have proved to calcine it in the Furnace where they bake Bricks, and when it was calcined to di≈ø≈øolve it in Aqua vitae: the ≈øolution helpeth many infirmities, giving it inwardly, and e≈øpecially maligne Fevers. Al≈øo being put in maligne ≈øores, it bringeth them to ≈øo good a temperature, that it is miraculous, and not credited, except of tho≈øe that ≈øee the experience. And at this time I am ≈øeeking to bring it to a certain perfection, the which ≈øhall work miracles, and hitherto I have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, for thereof I have ≈øeen great miracles that cau≈øeth the world to wonder: And yet of late I have found an Oil made of the ≈øame Stone, that provoketh ≈øleep, and cau≈øeth
quiet re≈øt, and is marvellous for the ≈øight of the eyes, annointing the head, the eyes, and the ≈øtomack therewith when yee go to bed: For of this I have ≈øeen an infinite of experiments, and I ≈øwear by that I am, that with all the travell that I have had, I never found a better thing then this Oil; for if yee annoint the Gout therewith, pre≈øently it taketh away the pain, and inflammation, or alteration, but the rea≈øon thereof I know not, becau≈øe as yet I had no lei≈øure to con≈øider thereof: But by the grace of God, at the next impre≈ø≈øion I will ≈øet forth ≈øome notes of their experience that I have ≈øeen in the Art.

div.head: CHAP. XCVI. Of the Flint-≈øtones and their vertues.
div.p: THe flint is a ≈øtone, the which if it be ≈øtricken with Iron or Steel it will give fire, and his vertues are great both in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, and al≈øo in divers other Arts. Fir≈øt in Phy≈øick it hath vertue to di≈ø≈øolve the gravell in the Reins and Bladder, if ye give thereof two drachms with unriped Wine, and this it doth by his proper quality and hidden vertue. In Chirurgery it hath great vertue, for being ground into mo≈øt fine powder, and made into an ointment with Oil of Ro≈øes, and Wax, it mittigateth all inflammations, and taketh away the pain of the ≈øore, becau≈øe it cooleth and drieth Moreover, this ≈øtone is u≈øed of tho≈øe that make Gla≈ø≈øe, to make their compo≈øition with their A≈øhes and Magane≈øe. There are yet a great number of vertues, the which I leave unto the Experimentour.

div.head: CHAP. XCVII. Of the white ≈øtone which ≈øome call Allum, Scaleola, or Ge≈ø≈øo.
div.p:
THis Allum, Scaleola, or Ge≈ø≈øo is u≈øed much in Italy to make Lime of, I ≈øuppo≈øe it to be that which is called Muskovie Gla≈ø≈øe, or Lapis Specularis; this is very nece≈ø≈øary both in
Phy≈øick and Chirurgerie, becau≈øe it is by vertue attractive and drying, and helpeth much again≈øt burning Fevers, tempering it when it is burnt like flower with Vinegar, and when it is tempered, lay it pre≈øently upon the Reins, and lay it ju≈øt the length and largene≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo let it remain three or four houres, becau≈øe it draweth like Boxing Gla≈ø≈øes, and ≈øo leaveth the Reins cold and ea≈øed: and ≈øo by that effect it doth great plea≈øure in tho≈øe kind of Fevers. It helpeth al≈øo in Ulcers if yee make a pa≈øte thereof with common lye, and lay it thereon eight or ten houres, and then change it, for of this I have ≈øeen ≈øtrange effects.

div.head: CHAP. XCVIII. Of the Stone called Lapis Amiante.
div.p:
THis Stone called Amiante, as all they which have written thereof ≈øay, is a ≈øtone like unto Cycile, or Allum du plum, but not ≈øo white, of the which ≈øtone there is found great quantitie in Cyprus, and there they ≈øpin it like as it were Flaxe, and doe make thereof Napkins and ≈øuch like, and when they are foul, in ≈øtead of wa≈øhing them, they make a great fire, and lay them thereon, and ≈øo make them clean and white, for the experience thereof I have ≈øeen, and that which I have ≈øaid, is in the Lapidarie of Dio≈øcorides and Plinie, and Petro Andrea, Mathiolus Sane≈øie. And hereof I will ≈øhew thee a marvellous ≈øtrange ≈øecret, the which I have proved, and is this. Take of the ≈øaid ≈øtone and make it in powder, and mix it with crude Lead being in powder, as I have ≈øhewed in my Caprici Medicinale, with Tutia prepared, the compo≈øition thereof is this. Take of the ≈øtone ‚Ñ•. iiii. Lead, ‚Ñ•. xii. Tutia ‚Ñ•. ii. Mix them and calcine them in the fire, and when they are calcined, beat them to powder, and lay them to ≈øteep in ≈øtrong Vinegar in a gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand a moneth ≈øtirring it every day once, and then at the moneths end let it boil on the fire a quarter of an hour, and then let it ≈øettle untill it come clear, then take of that Vinegar as much as yee will, and mix it with as much oyle of Ro≈øes, ≈øtirring it
untill it come to a bodie, the which is a precious linament and rare, for if ye annoint the white ≈øcall or ≈øuch like ≈øcabs on the heads of young children, it will heal them with great ≈øpeed. Al≈øo for Scabs and Itch in the legs it is excellent, if ye annoint them therewith every night when you go to bed. This Stone ≈øerveth al≈øo when it is di≈ø≈øolved by it ≈øelf in Aqua vitae and Sugar, for tho≈øe women that are troubled with the whites; for if they drinke thereof every morning a little, it helpeth them quickly. I beleeve this Stone hath many other vertues which I know not.

div.head: CHAP. XCIX. Of the Saphire, and his vertues in Phy≈øick.
div.p: SAphires are certain ≈øtones, like unto Azures, ≈ømall, and are tran≈øparent, the which if thou wilt u≈øe, it were nece≈ø≈øary to be cunning in the knowledge of them, for otherwi≈øe yee may be deceived. And furthermore, above that which many Philo≈øophers have written thereof, I have found two goodly experiences never known before, and are the≈øe. Fir≈øt to make the heart merrie, and to help the pa≈ø≈øions of the ≈øame, the which ye ≈øhall u≈øe thus.

Take thy Saphire, and ≈øtamp it very finely, and di≈ø≈øolve it in Vinegar, or with the juice of Limons, and when they are di≈ø≈øolved, take thereof í i. with as much of our Elixar vitae, and of Oyle of Honey ‚Ñà i. and a little of the Julep of Violets, and give it to drink unto tho≈øe that have the afore≈øaid infirmities, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee miracles of their operation. I hope ere it be long, to ≈øet forth a great and ≈øtrange ≈øecret of the≈øe Stones.

div.head: CHAP. C. Of Red Corall.
div.p:
REd Corall is a ≈øtone, the which mo≈øt commonly doth grow upon baked ≈øtones or bricks, and to approve it to be ≈øo, there is a certain I≈øland of Barbarie, the which is called Tobacco, the which was ≈øometimes inhabited, but ≈øithence the Sea hath over-run a great part thereof, and ≈øo the ≈øtones of the hou≈øes, and the Bricks were ≈øcattered in the bottome of that Sea, and
at this time the Genoes gathered a great quantitie of Red Corall, the faire≈øt in all the world. I call to remembrance that in the yeer 1549. I being in Me≈ø≈øina, a famous Citie in the Realm of Cicilia, I ≈øaw a Fi≈øherman ca≈øt his Net in the gate hard by the tower called Salvatore; and he took up a branch of red Corall that was grown upon a Brick, and was of ≈øuch greatne≈ø≈øe and beautie, as had not been ≈øeen in two hundred yeers before. So that by this I have proved, that the Corall doth grow upon Bricks, or baked ≈øtones, and the≈øe have great vertue in Phy≈øick and Chirurgerie, when they be di≈ø≈øolved in the juyce of Limons, or di≈øtilled Vinegar. For how≈øoever it be taken inwardly, it comforteth the ≈øtomack, and maketh the heart merrie, di≈ø≈øolveth the Fever, and not without great cau≈øe. For it is ≈øo good of nature, that our nature doth de≈øire it. Corall being calcined and di≈ø≈øolved with Aqua vitae, or with our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, helpeth very much again≈øt Ulcers, becau≈øe it taketh away the pain pre≈øently, and mundifieth, and incarnateth, and cicatrizeth. Of this Corall ye may make Lozenges, or ≈øuch like, the which are very Re≈øtorative.

div.head: CHAP. CI. A Di≈øcour≈øe upon the Stone Salt.
div.p:
THere is found a Salt in the Realm of Naples, in the Province of Calabria, in the ≈øtate of the Prince of Be≈øignano, in certain Mountains that are of the Mine of Salt: I doe verily beleeve that this Salt is a fifth Element, becau≈øe Salt would be called no other then wi≈øedome, as a man may ≈øay, ta≈øte. And to prove that which I have ≈øaid, yee may ≈øee that the world cannot live without it. Moreover this Salt ≈øerveth much in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, for they put it into Cli≈øters, and lay it al≈øo upon wounds. But I have found a way to prepare this Salt ≈øweet like Sugar, but yet Salt, and is of ≈øuch a plea≈øant ta≈øt, that it comforteth them that u≈øe it, and this is called Sal conditum Leonardo, the which Salt is good again≈øt Worms, and comforteth the ≈øtomack, cau≈øeth an appetite, purgeth the Urine, with a number of
other vertues. And the order to take it is thus. Yee ≈øhall take thereof half a ≈øpoonfull in the morning at one time, and al≈øo u≈øe it in ≈øtead of Salt to your meat, and ≈øea≈øon your meat therewith. Al≈øo if any have pains in any part of their bodie, annoint it with this Salt, and bind a cloth thereon, and it will be helped.

p.hi: Hereafter followeth the Vertues of certain Mineralls, and mean Mineralls. And fir≈øt of Vitrioll.

div.head: CHAP. CII. Certain Secrets of Vitriol.
div.p: IN Vitriol are many Secrets which untill this time have been hidden, by meanes of which there may be done many ≈øtrange and great matters in divers operations, not onely in Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, but in many other things. Ye ≈øhall therefore take Vitriol and put it in a pot; and make him ≈øweat untill yee ≈øee him weep; the which ≈øweat being taken from him, is a mortall enemie unto ≈øharp Fevers, when it is drunk with ≈øodden or di≈øtilled waters. Al≈øo if tho≈øe that have the Etica or Ti≈ø≈øick doe drinke it with Mel Ro≈øarum, it will doe them great plea≈øure, it ≈øerveth al≈øo to make the hair of the head or beard black. Then if that by force of fire yee cau≈øe him to vomit a black liquor, it will be a thing very apt to di≈ø≈øolve any humour, the which in ≈øhort time will di≈ø≈øolve any pain. For if ye put it into Gangrena, or other putrified Ulcer, it doth mundifie it with great ≈øpeed: It mortifieth Warts Chaps, Fi≈øtulaes, and any kind of tho≈øe humours. If it be drunken with Wine or other liquor, it is good again≈øt Fevers of any qualitie. Then his Feces being reduced into water with Vinegar, and his Salt being taken out, it is of ≈øuch vertue, that in a manner it will make men immortall. And above the afore≈øaid matters, in Alchymie it worketh ≈øtrange things, for by the meanes thereof they may make the great Amalgam of Mercurie and Mars, wherewith may be done great matters, and happie ≈øhall he be that goeth to work that way. For with Vitriol, Mercurie and Mars is made full glad the Ma≈øter of the Art.

div.head: CHAP. CIII. Strange ≈øecrets of Roch Allum.
div.p: IN Allum are great vertues, and e≈øpecially in Roch Allum; for the water being ≈øeparated from the Feces, and accompanied with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, worketh mo≈øt ≈øtrange cures, and e≈øpecially in de≈øperate di≈øea≈øes: And the Feces which cannot di≈ø≈øolve, when with fire they ≈øhall be brought to perfection, and accompanied with Mars, they ≈øhall be apt to heal any ≈øort of Ulcer inwardly, and with ≈øpeed take away the pain, and not without great rea≈øon: for the Roch Allum is Anima Terrae, a firm Element, and that which di≈ø≈øolveth and turneth all things into his nature. Mars al≈øo is Anima Terrae, and is that, in which is found all vertue and richne≈ø≈øe: But he that is not expert, let him not ≈øettle him≈øelf to this enterpri≈øe, lea≈øt it fall not out right; for he that cannot prepare, calcine, di≈ø≈øolve, and congeale, ≈øhall never doe any thing that is ought worth, therefore it were better to leave then meddle.

div.head: CHAP. CIV. Of Orpiment and his nature.
div.p:
THis Orpiment is a ≈øtone, as it were, made of ≈øcales, and is of divers colours; there is white, and yellow, and red like bloud; neverthele≈ø≈øe, they are all of Sulphurous matter, the which burneth vi≈øibly like Sulphur, of the which I know no u≈øe, neither in Phy≈øick nor Chirurgery, although that ≈øome Chirurgians doe lay it upon ≈øores to dry them, the which they doe for want of rea≈øon or knowledge: With this Orpiment, being mixed with Calx viva, and ≈øtrong Lie, and ≈øo made into an Unguent, they u≈øe to take away hair: It ≈øerveth al≈øo for Painters to make a yellow colour like Gold, the which if it be burned, it changeth into another colour.
