This ≈øerveth for infinite u≈øes in Alchimie; for his ≈øublimation being made with Sul niter, and Tartar, when it is white, and Amalgamed with Quick-≈øilver and fine Silver, and given in projection upon Venus purged, it will make it very fair and white, and much
like Lime. Orpiment is di≈ø≈øolved, by way of calcination with ≈øtrong Vinegar, until ≈øuch time as his ≈øub≈øtance be taken away; then let it ≈øettle and wax clear, and vapour away that clear part, and in the bottome yee ≈øhall find the whitene≈ø≈øe of Sulphur, the which being fixed with ≈øufficient order, it doth blanch all metals, and this is called the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Sulphur Minerall: This ≈øerveth for many other u≈øes in Alchimie, the which I will leave until another time: But this which I have written is mo≈øt true.

div.head: CHAP. CV. Of Cinaber Minerall, and wherefore it ≈øerveth.
div.p: THis Cinaber is of two kindes, Mineral and Artificial; the Mineral is a ≈øtone of the colour of Iron, the which being ground into powder it will be red like bloud, the which is of a great drying nature, by the rea≈øon that it containeth in it Sulphur, it drieth maligne Sores, and being made in a Perfume, it helpeth the mouth being ulcerated, and being made into an Unguent, it cooleth greatly; al≈øo being di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, it mittigateth the pain in maligne Ulcers, and healeth them in ≈øhort time; his ≈øublimation being made with Salt and Tartar, blancheth Copper and Lattin like to Silver.

This ≈øtone ≈øerveth al≈øo to burni≈øh Metal or Silver therewith. The artificial Cinaber is made of Sulphur and Mercury by way of ≈øublimation, the which ≈øerveth for divers u≈øes; as for the Painters, or to write with; al≈øo to make drying Unguents, and for fumes again≈øt the Pox, with divers other u≈øes, the which I leave at this time.

div.head: CHAP. CVI. Of the ≈øecrets of Salt, and his royall vertue.
div.p:
THere is in Salt a great vertue, and his ≈øecrets are of great force, for if Salt be di≈ø≈øolved in the mighty water of Vitriol, together with Mars, and then cau≈øed to vomit with great heat, until it remain in a dry powder, and then circulate it with our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine and Honey the ≈øpace of a moneth,
the which if the workman can doe, he ≈øhall make a miraculous Medicine, which by his vertue and hidden quality, will ≈øerve again≈øt divers great infirmities, becau≈øe his nature is to pre≈øerve the body in his ≈øtrength, and to di≈øcharge all evil humours that may offend Nature. But to ≈øpeak of ≈øome particular thing, I ≈øay, that this glorious Medicine doth help the Fever Hectick when they are new begun, giving thereof a little quantity with water of Vervane, Agrimonie, and Betonie; with the water of Fennel and Selandine, it re≈øtoreth the ≈øight unto tho≈øe that are ob≈øcure; it helpeth al≈øo the flux of the body, with divers other things, the which I will not utter in this place.

div.head: CHAP. CVII. Of the ≈øecrets of common Salt, and his vertues.
div.p: THere are three ≈øorts, or kinds, found of common Salt, the one is natural, the which is found in Mountaines, as in Naples in the Province of Calabria, where are great Mountaines of it, and al≈øo in Spain in the I≈øle of Anvi≈øa, and this is the Mineral Salt. The ≈øecond kind is Artificial, as is made in Germany in their Cauldrons. The third kind is al≈øo natural of the Sea, which is made upon dry ≈øands in pits, by force of the Sun; but the mo≈øt ≈øweet and ≈øavoure≈øt is that which is made with fire, becau≈øe it is purified and clean: The Salt of the Mountain is of more vertue then all the re≈øt in Phy≈øick; for when it ≈øhall be calcined forty dayes together in a Furnace, and then di≈ø≈øolved with our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Honey, ≈øo that there remain no Feces, it will be of ≈øuch vertue, that in manner it will revive the dead, if you give them thereof a ≈øpoonful. With this the antiente≈øt Doctors did marvellous things, and they called it the Salt of Wi≈ødome, for he that knew well his vertues would marvel thereat. This Salt ≈øerveth al≈øo again≈øt the infirmities of Oxen.

div.head: CHAP. CVIII. Certain ≈øecrets of Salt-Peter.
div.p:
SAlt-Peter is a certain kind of ≈øalt of Urine, the which is taken out of the earth by art, and is mo≈øt whol≈øome again≈øt
divers infirmities; for when it ≈øhall be calcined thirty dayes together in a Furnace, with as much Tartar, and then di≈ø≈øolved with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, accompanied with the ≈øpirits of Cinnamon, Ginger, and Cloves, it will be a mo≈øt whol≈øome Medicine, and will cau≈øe the Profe≈ø≈øors of the Art to be amazed at his operation, for it helpeth the Hectick, and Drop≈øie, and divers ≈øuch like infirmities, the which I will not ≈øpeak of in this place, fearing that they will not be credited: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, tho≈øe that are di≈øpo≈øed to travel on that matter ≈øhall find their de≈øire, and reap great fame in the world.

div.head: CHAP. CIX. Certain ≈øecrets of Allum du Fece.
div.p: THis Allum is made with the Feces of Wine, in this manner. div.head: CHAA. CX. A great ≈øecret of Gold.

div.head: CHAP. CXII. Certain Secrets of Saturn.

div.p: VVHen Venus ≈øhall be well prepared, and with art of fire ≈øhall be well calcined, and done thereunto what is convenient, it will be valiant in his operation. div.head: A great Secret of Copper, as concerning Chirurgerie.
div.p: Take Sal Niter lb. ii. Roch Allom half a pound, Sal Gem. four ounces, ∆≤itriol Romane one pound, Soot of the Chimney three ounces, mix the≈øe together, and di≈øtill thereof a ≈øtrong water according to art, that being done, put the water into a Retort, and for every pound of water, put thereto four ounces of Verdegrie≈øe finely cear≈øed, then ≈øet thereunto a Receiver, and give it fire according to art, untill all the fumes be come forth, then let it coole, and break the gla≈ø≈øe, and take forth that which remained in the bottome, and beat it to powder, then put that into another Retort, and put thereon as much di≈øtilled Vinegar as the powder weighed, and di≈øtill it againe, untill there come no more fumes, then let it coole, and break the gla≈ø≈øe, and take forth the matter, and grind it to powder, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe that it take no aire. For this is mo≈øt marvellous in ulcerated and putrified ≈øores, becau≈øe it mundifieth, clean≈øeth, and incarnateth, and with great ≈øpeed bringeth them to be whole with ≈ømall paine, or none at all: If ye make an unguent thereof with oyl of Ro≈øes, Wax, and Frankin≈øence, it helpeth all manner of ≈øores with ≈øpeed.

div.head: CHAP. CXIV. Of the Secrets of Jupiter or Tin.
div.p: I∆≤piter is a ≈øhining Metall, by the means of which all the other Metals become ≈øhining, and are pre≈øerved, and in this is found great vertue and experience, both in Phy≈øick and Chirurgerie, and al≈øo in Alchimie. div.head: CHAP. CXV. Certain Secrets of Iron.
div.p: IRon, which the Alchymi≈øts doe call Mars is a Minerall, the which is appropriate again≈øt divers and ≈øundry infirmities when it is well prepared and di≈ø≈øolved, the which is done in this manner.

And when that thou ≈øee≈øt it all di≈ø≈øolved into water, vapour away the Vinegar, and there will remain a ≈øtone blacki≈øh of colour, which take forth of the gla≈ø≈øe, and grind it to pouder, then di≈ø≈øolve it in rectified Aqua vitae, and then ≈øhall be fini≈øhed the ≈øolution of Iron Phy≈øically, the which thou mai≈øt give ≈øafely when need ≈øhall require, and chiefly again≈øt Fluxes of the body, again≈øt ≈øpitting of bloud, the Emeroids, Scabs, and al≈øo for the Lepro≈øie, and Ti≈ø≈øick, and Hectick. And this is the true ≈øolution of Iron devi≈øed by me, and I promi≈øe thee, that this is one of the greate≈øt Secrets that may be found in the world: and his vertues are ≈øuch and ≈øo many, that I cannot expre≈ø≈øe them. div.head: CHAP. CXVI. Of the Secrets of Mercurie.
div.p: QUick≈øilver is a liquid Minerall and Volatile, the which the Alchymi≈øts call Sulphur volatilis, and will accompanie with all other Mettals, but with ≈ømall fire they may bee ≈øeparated again, and will flie away in Fume, and for that cau≈øe the Philo≈øophers call it Servus fugitivus, as a man would ≈øay, it can hold friend≈øhip with none, but ≈øo ≈øoon as he hath done his ≈øervice he flyeth away, as it is ≈øeen by Gold≈ømiths that gild Plate. Take the ≈øaid Calx, and put it into a gla≈ø≈øe with a long neck, and put thereon di≈øtilled Vinegar, and ≈øet it in warm ≈øand four and twenty houres, and then give it one walm, and when it hath boiled, pour out the Vinegar, and then if there remain any Feces in the bottome, put thereon fre≈øh Vinegar, and doe as thou didde≈øt before; and this thou ≈øhalt doe ≈øo often, till it be di≈ø≈øolved into water, and when all is di≈ø≈øolved, evaporate away the Vinegar, that there remain but little in the bottome; then put thereto water of Honey made by di≈øtillation according to our order; and ≈øo the ≈øolution of Mercury ≈øhall be fini≈øhed, the which is miraculous in many infirmities: It ≈øerveth again≈øt the Cough, Catarhe, and for tho≈øe that have their ≈øtomacks putrified with the Pox, cau≈øing them to u≈øe it with other Sirrups or Potions: It helpeth tho≈øe who≈øe Milt is indurated; and al≈øo for tho≈øe, that have any ≈øort of Fi≈øtula in any part of the body: It is al≈øo good for divers other things, the which I will not write in this place, becau≈øe I would have other men to exerci≈øe them≈øelves in the practi≈øe thereof, whereby they may find out divers other ≈øecrets as I have done.

div.head: What Wounds are.
div.p: VVOunds are tho≈øe which in Latine are called Vulnus, and of the vulgar Vulnera, and they are of two kinds, that is, ≈øimple, and compound. The ≈øimple are tho≈øe that are onely in the fle≈øh, the compound are tho≈øe where are cut Sinewes, Veins, Mu≈øckles, and Bones, and the≈øe are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, And the difference that is among them is, by the variety of the place where they are wounded, and by the difference of the weapon wherewith they were hurt, for ≈øome goe right, ≈øome overthwart, ≈øome long, ≈øome broad, ≈øome are thru≈øts or ≈øtocate, that offend divers parts of the body. The ≈øimple are of ≈ømall importance, becau≈øe if yee keep them clean and clo≈øe ≈øhut, nature will heal them without any kind of Medicine. But tho≈øe, where Veins are cut, have need of ≈øome art or practi≈øe, with the which they may ≈øtop the bloud, and in any wi≈øe not to ≈øuffer the wound to remain open, but to ≈øow it up very clo≈øe, ≈øo that the Vein may heal. Al≈øo tho≈øe where Sinews are hurt are of great importance, and would be healed with great ≈øpeed, ≈øo that the Sinews may joyn with more ea≈øe. But tho≈øe where Bones are hurt, are of greater importance, for if the Bone be ≈øeparated from the other, of nece≈ø≈øity it mu≈øt be taken forth before the Wound be healed. So that by this means every one may know what Wounds are, and their kinds.

div.head: Of ∆≤lcers, and what they are.
div.p:
ULcers are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, and are ingendered of many cau≈øes, as hereafter I will ≈øhew. But fir≈øt I will write of tho≈øe kind of Ulcers that are cau≈øed of Wounds. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that Wounds, in what part of the body ≈øoever they be, being impo≈øthumated, or cancrenated, they change their names, and are no more called Wounds, although
the originall was a wound. For when it is cancrenated, it is called ∆≤lcera corro≈øiva, becau≈øe it goeth eating and creeping on the fle≈øh. But when the wound is impo≈øthumated and full of matter, it is called, ∆≤lcera putrida, that is putrified, and it is becau≈øe it is filthy and ≈øtinketh. But when it is neither cancrenated, nor yet apo≈øthumated, but that through ≈øome evill di≈øpo≈øition the wound is clo≈øed, and that there cometh in it evill qualities without alteration, then it is called ∆≤lcera ≈øordida, becau≈øe therein is evill qualitie, and it appeareth but a little, but it is evill to heal. There be other ≈øorts of Ulcers al≈øo, the which are cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry kinds of tumours, and the mo≈øt evill and mi≈øchievous are tho≈øe that are of tumours cau≈øed of the Pox, for unto tho≈øe there runneth abundance of evill humours that augment the Ulcer, and they be the wor≈øt ≈øort, for they cannot be healed by them≈øelves, except the body be well purged and evacuated of all the humours that are offen≈øive. There is another kind of Ulcer the which cometh of an Impo≈øthume, as well hot as cold, and tho≈øe are more gentle and ea≈øie to be helpt, if yee know the Medicines that are apt to help and di≈ø≈øolve tho≈øe kind of Ulcers.
The≈øe are the three kind of Ulcers that commonly happen unto men and women through divers cau≈øes, as it is ≈øaid before, ≈øo that the≈øe are the principall cau≈øes of tho≈øe malign Ulcers.

div.head: Of Impo≈øthumes, and their kinds.
div.p:
IMpo≈øthumes are a certain kinde of Tumour that are called after divers manners, becau≈øe they come in divers places of the bodie, as tho≈øe ≈øorts of Impo≈øthumes that come in the Groin, which in Venice are called Pannoche, in Rome, Tencone, in Naples, Dragon≈øelly, in Spain, Incordi, and the Ancients called them Buboni, and ≈øome with other names. There are other that come in all parts of the body, and when they come they cau≈øe great pain, and then they ripen and break of them≈øelves for the mo≈øt part, and the≈øe in Naples, are called Autrax, and in Rome, Chicholini, in Venice, ∆≤n-na≈øito, in Lumbardie, ∆≤n bungo, and in Spain, ∆≤n nacido mui viliaco. There is
another kind of Impo≈øthume, that is ingendered of a contu≈øion or brui≈øe, and is properly called Apo≈øtumatio pro Amacatura. In the Head there grow certain kinds of ≈øores that are called Talpae, or Topinare, the which are of ≈ømall Importance, for they may be healed in ≈øhort time, and the≈øe are ≈øeen in childrens heads, that are often troubled therewith, and ≈øometimes in their throats, and for the mo≈øt part about the eares.

div.head: Of Fi≈øtulaes, and their kinds.
div.p:
ALl manner of Sores that doe not ≈øiccatrize perfectly, and have communication with the inward parts, are called Fi≈øtulaes, and we term them in Italian Sofio, or Spiraculo, as yee may ≈øee by experience, and this is perillous, when a Fi≈øtula clo≈øeth, being in the body, and ≈øpecially tho≈øe Fi≈øtulaes that are in the Fundament, for Nature her ≈øelf doth ingender it for ea≈øe. But the≈øe Fi≈øtulaes that come in divers parts of the body are trouble≈øome, but not perillous: Al≈øo all ≈øuch ≈øores as tarry long before they be incarnated come to Fi≈øtulaes, and many times it cometh through their being long curing, by tenting with their tents, which are the cau≈øes that Nature maketh a Callow, and leaveth the ≈øore ≈øo hollow, that it will never be filled with fle≈øh, but ≈øo remain hollow, as it is ≈øeen ea≈øily by experience. There be other ≈øorts of Fi≈øtulaes in form of a ≈øore, and they be tho≈øe ≈øores that mo≈øt commonly come on the leggs, the which doe purge a long time, and are al≈øo very hard to heal, becau≈øe if yee heal one of them pre≈øently, there will ri≈øe another hard by it, and that is a kind of Fi≈øtula‚ñ™ There is another kind of Fi≈øtula that is cau≈øed of tho≈øe ≈øores that are upon the bone, the which by his continuance doe break and con≈øume the skin and the bone, and the≈øe many times remain Fi≈øtulated, but who ≈øo taketh away the cau≈øe of the ≈øore, nature it ≈øelf will prevail mightily, and will heal it, as may be ≈øeen daily by experience, in tho≈øe that be ≈øo troubled. The Fi≈øtulaes that come in the eyes, are called Fi≈øtula Lachrymo≈øa, and they have
≈øome communication with the inward parts, and are evill to be healed. Becau≈øe fir≈øt the cau≈øe mu≈øt be taken away inwardly, and then nature will heal it by it ≈øelf, as I have ≈øeen by experience, ≈øo that the≈øe are the kinds of Fi≈øtulaes mo≈øt known unto all men, and the cau≈øes of the≈øe Fi≈øtulaes are two, and for my part I am fully per≈øwaded it is ≈øo. The Fir≈øt is of wounds evill healed, that remain Fi≈øtulated. The Second cau≈øe, I find to be of ≈øores cau≈øed of the Pox, and to ≈øhew a truth, yee ≈øhall cure them of the Pox, and their Fi≈øtulaes will heal of them≈øelves without any other help, as it is daily to be ≈øeen. There may be many other cau≈øes the which as yet I know not, but the≈øe two are a ≈øufficient rea≈øon, and to be con≈øidered of the Profe≈ø≈øors of this Art, if they de≈øire to come to any excellency; and therefore I will rea≈øon no more of the matter, becau≈øe the Science, and my experience will reach no further.

div.head: Of all ≈øorts of Scabs.
div.p:
THere be divers kinds of Scabs, but I will onely treat of tho≈øe in which I have had mo≈øt experience, and will ≈øet them forth as plainly as I can, that every one thereby may have profit. The fir≈øt kind of Scab is that which is cau≈øed of Ripletion of the body, by eating much meat of great nouri≈øhment, and then not to dige≈øt it, ≈øo in that cau≈øe nature, to ea≈øe it ≈øelf, ≈øendeth forth that humiditie, and when it joyneth to the skin, it ingro≈ø≈øeth and cau≈øeth an Impo≈øthume, and pa≈ø≈øing to the outward parts, it is alreadie corrupted, and ≈øo cau≈øeth the Pu≈øtulaes, as by experience may be ≈øeen, and this kinde is a vi≈øcous and fat humour with great humidity. There is another kind of Scab that is alwaies dry with redne≈ø≈øe, and is ≈ømall, with great heat and Itching, and the ≈øame in my judgement is cau≈øed by much heat of the Liver; and adu≈øtion of blood, and may be healed ea≈øily. There is another kind of great ≈øcab that hath a great dry cru≈øt on them, and they grow big, and the ≈øame is of the French Pox being new taken. There is another kind like Serpigo, that goeth creeping, and
hath a dry cra≈øt, and hath no matter under it; and the ≈øame is al≈øo of the French Poxe inveterated. There are al≈øo divers other kinds, the which I will leave at this time, becau≈øe they are of ≈ømall importance, and may be helped with tho≈øe Medicines which are fit for the ‚Ä¢ inds afore≈øaid.

div.head: Of Formicola, and his Effects.
div.p: THo≈øe kind of Ulcers that are commonly called Mal di Formica, are ≈øo called, becau≈øe they are a kind of malign Ulcers and corro≈øive, that goeth creeping upon the fle≈øh, and maketh many holes that are lifted up on the ≈øides, and are red, and the≈øe for the mo≈øt part are cau≈øed of the Pox, as may be ≈øeen by experience, and the≈øe ≈øores are evill to be healed, becau≈øe thereunto runneth abundance of humours, the which cannot be re≈øolved but with inward Medicines, that is, with exqui≈øite Purgations that purifie the blood, and that cutteth away the evill humours that run thereunto, and cau≈øe great alteration with burning. This kinde of ≈øore cometh many times in the head, and when it cometh in that part, it is called Tigna, or the white ≈øcall, and to ≈øhew that this is the truth, yee may ≈øee that tho≈øe Medicines which heal Formicola, doth al≈øo heal the white Scall, for this is a kind of the Pox, as by the Effects yee may plainly ≈øee; for if any ≈øhould ≈øay the contrary, I would an≈øwer him again, that this may well be, becau≈øe the ≈øame infirmitie may be taken in the mothers womb, or as ≈øoon as the child is borne, it may take it of the Nur≈øe that giveth it ≈øuck, if ≈øhee be infected with that di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo that I conclude it may be ≈øo. But there are a number of that kinde of di≈øea≈øe, which I let pa≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe I have ≈øeen no experience of them.

div.head: A Di≈øcour≈øe of Wounds, and other kindes of Inward Sores.
div.p:
VVOunds that are within the body, as in the ≈øtomack, or belly, or Inte≈øtinals, in the bladder, reins, or guts; The Milt, Liver, Lungs, Heart or other Muskles or Arteries, as there be a number, I confe≈ø≈øe to know nothing therein, and
I will ≈øhew you the rea≈øon: You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that when a wound doth offend the Interior parts, the Phy≈øitian or Chrurgian, or great Anatomi≈øt what≈øoever he be, cannot know all tho≈øe parts offended in the body, for after the weapon is within the bodie, it may turn, and with the point hurt other parts afar off the wound, and offend divers particular parts one different from the other, and therefore I be≈øeech you, excellent Chirurgians, when ≈øuch a ca≈øe cometh, how doe you know or di≈øcern which parts are hurt? but to ≈øay the truth, I beleeve in that ca≈øe they know all alike, but what ≈øhould I ≈øay of the cure of ≈øuch a wound, if the Chirurgian know not where it is, nor of what importance, but worketh by imagination, and if that Nature doth prevail, and that the wound doth heal, it is by the good fortune of the Phy≈øitian, ≈øo that for wounds inwardly I, conclude no other at this time, but will leave it to tho≈øe that know more then I, and hereafter I will di≈øcour≈øe of Ulcers and Impo≈øthumes inwardly, what they are, and how to cure them with our order: yee ≈øhall under≈øtand that there are a number of kinds of Ulcers and Impo≈øthumes that may ingender inwardly, but it ≈øeemeth to me ≈øo hard to under≈øtand, that I can determine nothing that were true, and the cau≈øe is this, that we have ≈øeen an infinite of Phy≈øitians and Chirurgians that have vi≈øited one Impo≈øthumated, or Ulcerated, and the Phy≈øitian could not know the place, and particular of that Impo≈øthume or Ulcer, if that the Patient do not tell him and ≈øhew him, and cau≈øe him to feel with his hand, and this is mo≈øt true, and therefore if one cannot re≈øolve him of outward things, that he may ≈øee and feel with his hand, how can he re≈øolve him when one of tho≈øe accidents is within the bodie, where the Patient knows not him≈øelf, which is grieved? Truly, I would gladly know what judgement they would give of that matter, for becau≈øe if there be any Impo≈øthume or Ulcer in any part of the bodie, the ≈øick ≈øhall feel great offence and pain, neverthele≈ø≈øe he cannot tell where it is, nor what part is hurt, ≈øo that I conclude, if that the Patient know not, much le≈ø≈øe the Phy≈øitian knoweth, and of this I have made a large di≈øcour≈øe in Caprici medicinale, for as I have ≈øaid before, in this ca≈øe I know nothing. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, when
it ≈øhall come to his place, I will write a di≈øcour≈øe of the order to cure the mo≈øt part o ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ liters, and Impo≈øthumes, but touching wounds, I will promi≈øe no more then I have ≈øaid before. Al≈øo I will write excellent Remedies of great experience, with the which all wounds, ≈øo they be not mortall, may be helpt and healed, and al≈øo the rea≈øons convenient in that matter.

div.head: An order to u≈øe in healing all manner of Di≈øea≈øes appertaining unto the Chirurgian.
div.p:
VVOunds and all other ≈øorts of ≈øores, are of ≈øundry and divers kinds, as is afore≈øaid, neverthele≈ø≈øe the order to helpe them is not much different one from the other, if we ≈øhould ≈øay onely the truth without abu≈øe. For yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that Nature is the ma≈øter of all things created, and the Phy≈øitian and Chirurgian are helpers of that Nature, as the antient Profe≈ø≈øors of the Art have affirmed. Then ≈øeeing this is ≈øo, what need we to make ≈øuch adoe, having Nature that worketh ≈øo gently, if it be not hindered by the Mini≈øter, and therefore if we will ≈øpeak of Wounds, I ≈øay, that the Mini≈øter hath three operations to doe and no more, and the re≈øt leave to Nature that worketh gently. The three operations that the Ma≈øter hath to doe are the≈øe: To defend the Wound ≈øo that there runneth no humours to it, and that it putrfie not, and to keep it clean, and when the Mini≈øter hath done that, let Nature work that which ≈øhe will work well, and if any de≈øire to ≈øee if it will be ≈øo in effect, yee may ≈øee by a Dog, for if he hath a great wound upon his body, he healeth it without any Medicine, onely with diet, and keeping it clean with his tongue, and this is mo≈øt true, that tho≈øe which doe help Wounds by inchantment, doe nothing but keep the Wound clean, and cau≈øe the Patient to keep a diet, and ≈øo nature worketh as well on a Man as on a Dog, therefore let none marvell of this authority of a Dog, although I approve the like of a Chri≈øtian. But for ≈øo much as it would be good to help Nature, that it might work with more ≈øpeedine≈ø≈øe, as Husbandmen and Gardners doe, who becau≈øe they would have Nature to work the better, and quicker in their ground, doe ca≈øt thereon divers ≈øorts of dungs, &c. The which is done onely
to help Nature to work the quicker, and to conclude, I ≈øay, that the Chirurgian ≈øhould doe the ≈øame in helping of Wounds. But as for Ulcers of divers ≈øorts, it were nece≈ø≈øary to find out the cau≈øe, becau≈øe they come of divers cau≈øes, for when the cau≈øe is found, it will be more ea≈øie to be helped, becau≈øe Ulcers cannot come but by great di≈øtemperance of Nature in our bodies, as by great heat or cold, or by repletions of the body. Therefore in this ca≈øe it is nece≈ø≈øary to purge the body: Fir≈øt, to ea≈øe Nature which is offended, and to extingui≈øh the ≈øuperfluous heat or cold that is in the bodie: That being done, the mini≈øter or helper of Nature hath three things to doe. The fir≈øt is to mortifie or kill the ≈øore, the ≈øecond to mundifie, and the third to incarnate, and then Nature will cicatrize it, and the≈øe three operations are to be u≈øed in Ulcers. Al≈øo Impo≈øthumes are cau≈øed of divers accidents, in the which it is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øeek out the cau≈øe, whereby to know what purgations are fit to purge the body of the ≈øuperfluous humours, and then the Mini≈øter hath three things to doe in that ca≈øe. Fir≈øt to bring it to maturation quickly, then when it is ripe and broke, to mundifie it well, and thirdly to incarnate it, and the≈øe are the three operations that are to be done in an Impo≈øthume to help Nature to work well, and ≈øo following this order thy work ≈øhall prove well, and goe the right way, as hereafter I will ≈øhew in his place, the operations to u≈øe in the effect, with the order to help them, and al≈øo to make thy Unguents, ≈øhewing their quality and vertue, and will prove by rea≈øon tho≈øe things that are doubtfull, ≈øo that every one ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied in that matter.

div.head: Of Medicines to be u≈øed in all kind of Wounds outward, with ea≈øe and brevity.
div.p:
HAving declared what outward Wounds are, it is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øhew the order how to cure them, with as much ≈øpeed and ea≈øe as it is po≈ø≈øible, and therefore I will begin fir≈øt with ≈øimple Wounds that are onely in the fle≈øh, without offence of Veins, Sinews, or Bones, although the≈øe need no help, but onely to joyn the lips clo≈øe together, and if
need be, to ≈øtitch them clo≈øe, and then let Nature work, the which in ≈øhort time will heal them, but if thou by Art wilt help nature, thou ≈øhalt annoint them with oyle of frankincen≈øe once a day. But Wounds, where Veines are cut, have need of pre≈øent help, and artificiall meanes, and ≈øufficient remedies to help it, with as much ≈øpeed as may be, ≈øo that the Veins cut may joyn again together, without any great offence of the Wound, and that is done in this order. The fir≈øt thing is to joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and ≈øtitch it well, not as the common Chirurgians doe, but as they doe u≈øe to ≈øtitch bags, and when it is ≈øtitched clo≈øe, annoint it onely upon the Wound with our Magno l ‚Ä¢ quore, and lay thereon a cloth wet in the ≈øame Oil very warm, then take Hypericon with the ≈øeed, Millefolie, Viticella, ana and make thereof a powder, the which thou ≈øhalt ≈øtrew upon the Wound being dre≈øt, and round about it, for this Medicine doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate the matter that runneth unto the Wound, and taketh it forth with great ea≈øe, and without pain of the Wound, for this is the mo≈øt ≈øoveraign Medicine in that ca≈øe, that Nature with Art may make, and hath been proved a thou≈øand times by experience in divers places. But tho≈øe Wounds where Bones and Sinews are hurt, have need of great artifice and cunning, becau≈øe they be of importance; But when the Sinews be onely offended, it were nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øtitch them pre≈øently, as I have ≈øaid of tho≈øe where Veins are cut, but not to dre≈ø≈øe it with Magno liquore, but in≈øtead thereof to take our Ole ‚Ä¢ m Benedictum, and Oil of Frankincen≈øe, of each alike, for tho≈øe Oils doe exceedingly comfort the Sinews that are cut, and when it happeneth that a Sinew hath a puncture, or is cut half way, in that ca≈øe it were nece≈ø≈øary to cut it overthwart, becau≈øe it ≈øhall bring no Spa≈ømus to the Wound, but if ≈øo be then that the Bone be hurt, and that there be any part to come forth, it were nece≈ø≈øary to leave the Wound open untill the Bone cometh forth, and then to incarnate it, and this thou ≈øhalt doe with our artificiall Balm, for the ≈øame ≈øerveth for Wounds, and lay thereupon the Cerot of Gualtifredo di Medi, the which healeth it with ≈øpeed, and ≈øo with the≈øe orders thou maye≈øt help all the afore≈øaid ≈øorts of Wounds, and the defen≈øive to u≈øe in the≈øe
Wounds is this. Rec. Aqua vitae made of pure wine, and that will burne all away, and put therein Hypericon, Millefollie, Viticella, Betonica, and then wet a cloath in that infu≈øion and, lay it for a defen≈øive round about the Wound, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt have thine intent to the great ≈øatisfaction of the Patient. Wounds in the head are helped as tho≈øe are where the Sinews are offended, there are al≈øo divers other ≈øorts of Wounds which are helped with the Remedies by us formerly mentioned.

div.head: To help ∆≤lcers of all ≈øorts.
div.p:
SEeing that Ulcers are of divers and ≈øundry kinds, it were nece≈ø≈øary to know of what kind and qualitie they are, ≈øo that thou maye≈øt help them in form and order convenient, and fir≈øt I will write of the corro≈øive Ulceras of a wound cancrenated, mal di Formicola, and other ≈øorts of Ulcers that go creeping upon the fle≈øh. The cure of the≈øe kinds of Ulcers is to apply quickly our Cau≈øtike to mortifie the evill, the which thou ≈øhalt doe thus, wet a little bumba≈øte in our Cau≈øtike, and therewith wa≈øh all the ≈øore, and then leave it ≈øo open twentie four hours without binding it fa≈øt, and when twentie four houres are pa≈øt, wa≈øh the ≈øore with ≈øtrong Vinegar and water, of each a like quantitie, with charge, that there remain none of the Cau≈øtike in the ≈øore, then lay thereon butter wa≈øhed, with a colewort leaf untill the asker or dead fle≈øh fall away, then take our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, with a little Precipitate ≈øtrewed thereon, and then annoint it with Magno liquore, and lay it upon the ≈øore, for this Cerot helpeth all manner of corro≈øive Ulcers without any other help, and every Plai≈øter will ≈øerve three or four dayes, taking them off every twentie four hours, and make them clean, and then lay them on again, and as for the filthy Ulcer that I have ≈øhewed of in his Chapter, ye ≈øhall dre≈ø≈øe them onely with our ∆≤nguento magno, the which without any other help will heal them quickly: But ye mu≈øt every four dayes touch them with Aqua fortis drawn from Precipitate, the which water draweth forth the offen≈øive matter, and leaveth it putrified
and clean; and in all other ≈øorts of Ulcers, our Balm artificiall, our Magno liquore, Oyle of Waxe and Turpentine, the Black Cerot of Gualtifredo, di Medi, our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, with Precipitate, are able to help, be they never ≈øo evill.

div.head: The Order to be u≈øed in curing Impo≈øthumes of divers ≈øorts.
div.p: THere be many ≈øundry kinds of Impo≈øthumes that cometh to mans bodie, that are cau≈øed of divers and ≈øundry accidents, and therefore mu≈øt be cured by divers orders, and with ≈øundry Medicines according to his kind, becau≈øe ≈øome Impo≈øthumes are cau≈øed of a contu≈øion or brui≈øed fle≈øh, ≈øome are certain griefs, that Nature would di≈øcharge her ≈øelf of, and ≈øo ≈øendeth forth that matter, ≈øome are cau≈øed of cold, others of melancholy humours, and others are cau≈øed of corruption of the Pox, and the≈øe are the kindes of Impo≈øthumes that commonly come, and hereafter I will ≈øhew the order to cure them one after another.

And fir≈øt of tho≈øe that are cau≈øed of a contu≈øion, becau≈øe it is brui≈øed fle≈øh, for every contu≈øion mu≈øt be putrified and brought to matter, therfore make a maturative, and bring it to ≈øuppuration, and when you know there is matter, pre≈øently launce them, and dre≈ø≈øe them with this Medicine as well within as without, the which without any other help will heal any great contu≈øion. But you mu≈øt make the Unguent fre≈øh every day, and with new Eggs, yee ≈øhall mix the yoalk of an Egg with our Magno liquore, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe them. And as for tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes that come by indi≈øpo≈øition of Nature, are certain Sborine, a word ≈øo called in Italian, by the which Nature would prevail: it were nece≈ø≈øary to let tho≈øe have their cures according to Nature, untill they break of them≈øelves, and when they are broken, dre≈ø≈øe them within with this Unguent. ‚Ñû Oyle of Ro≈øes, ‚Ñ•. vi. Litarge of Gold in fine powder, ‚Ñ•. ii. Storax liquida, ‚Ñ•. i. Turpentine two ounces, yellow Wax, ‚Ñ•. iii. mix them and boyl them one the fire untill it be black, and if it be too hard, put thereto more oyle of Ro≈øes, and make it in form of an Unguent, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe tho≈øe kindes of Impo≈øthumes,
and lay thereon the Cerot Diapalma, and therewith will be wrought miracles. Al≈øo for tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes cau≈øed of cold, yee ≈øhall u≈øe hot Medicines and attractives: The Cerot of Oxicrocii is excellent in tho≈øe kind of Impo≈øthumes, our Balm artificiall, or the water, and ≈øuch like things as are temperate by Nature. But tho≈øe Impo≈øthumes that have their Originall of the French Pox, are evill and malign, becau≈øe their cau≈øe is malign and evill, and therefore their cure is with great purging, and to let the Impo≈øthume ripe of him≈øelf, and when ye launce it, dre≈ø≈øe it within with our ∆≤nguento magno, mixed thus, ‚Ñû. ∆≤nguento magno ‚Ñ•. ii. Magno liquore ‚Ñ• i. Precipitate, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. mix them well together, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe the Impo≈øthume, the which will heal quickly and well, and lay thereon our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, with this charge, that in all the cures afore≈øaid yee purge the body well, ≈øo that the humours run not unto the place offended, and u≈øe defen≈øives according to the kind of Impo≈øthume, as oyle of Frankincen≈øe, of Turpentine of Wax, of Honey, Aqua vitae: all the≈øe are excellent defen≈øives by them≈øelves, annointing them round about the Impo≈øthume.

div.head: The Order to cure all manner of Fi≈øtulaes.
div.p:
FI≈øtulaes, as I have ≈øaid before, are of divers kinds, and cau≈øed of divers accidents, and ≈øo likewi≈øe they have need of divers Medicines, and fir≈øt I will write of tho≈øe Fi≈øtulaes that come of Wounds evill healed, and that have made a callow in that order that Nature cannot ≈øiccatrize, and ≈øo remain Fi≈øtulated, and the cure of the≈øe kind of Fi≈øtulaes is to put therein a Rupture that doth cut and mortifie the callow, and cau≈øeth it to fall away, and then with incarnating Medicines, incarnate them, and ≈øiccatize them, and this is the true cure of the≈øe Fi≈øtulaes. But tho≈øe kind of Fi≈øtulaes that nature cau≈øeth to ea≈øe her ≈øelf of ≈øome accident, commonly come in the lower parts about the fundament, and they be very perillous, and and not to be healed as they before were. But they mu≈øt be with purging the body, ≈øtomack, and head, the which is to be done thus, Fir≈øt, purge them ten or twelve daies with our Magi≈øtral
Sirrup, then give them our Aromatico, and drink thereon a little white Wine, then purge the head with a perfume made of Myrrha and Cinaber, after the≈øe things be done yee ≈øhall rectifie the Liver with ≈øome decoction fit for that purpo≈øe, as of Lignum Sanctum, or Sar≈øa parilla, or ≈øuch like that work effect, for this Medicine doth al≈øo help Fi≈øtula lachrymo≈øa, that commonly come about the eyes or eares. There be other Fi≈øtulaes in form of a ≈øore, which mu≈øt be helpt with purging, and lay upon the ≈øore our Cerot Magi≈øtrale with Precipitate, and annoint it with Magno liquore, for with this Cerot onely may all Fi≈øtulated ≈øores be healed, for it doth mundifie and afterwards ≈øiccatrize it, there be al≈øo divers ≈øuch like matters that are ea≈øily cured, if ye apply thereunto tho≈øe Medicines that are appropriate.

div.head: To help all manner of Scabs.
div.p: THe kinds of Scabs be many, and cau≈øed of divers cau≈øes, and their cures are al≈øo divers wayes. Tho≈øe that are cau≈øed of repletion of the body, and of gro≈ø≈øe blood, the which are cau≈øed by eating abundance of ≈øuch meats as are of great nouri≈øhment, the which if thou wilt cure them, it were nece≈ø≈øary to purge them with our Sirrupo Solutivo, ten or twelve daies, then give him or her one drachm of our Aromatico in the morning fa≈øting, and drinke thereon a cup of ≈øweet Wine, then let him ≈øweat three or four times, and after annoint him with our ∆≤nguento magno two or three times, and it will heal him of tho≈øe kind of ≈øcabs.

Now to cure that kind of ≈øeab that is red and ≈ømall, and cau≈øeth great itching, you ≈øhall make a decoction of Hearbs, that cool the liver and purifie the blood, as Borage, Buglo≈ø≈øe, Endive, Maiden-hair, Liver-wort, Harts-tongue, Agrimony, Citrach, Succorie, and ≈øuch like Hearbs, then purge with Alves, the juyce of Elder roots, Hiera pigra ≈øolutiva, and ≈øuch like, as doth cool the Liver and Blood, and then annoint them with ∆≤nguento di Lithargirio, and therewith you ≈øhall help all tho≈øe kinds of ≈øeabs. There be al≈øo certain great ≈øcabs over all the body, the which are very thick, and tho≈øe
are a kind of the Pox, the which may be helpt with giving them our Pillole contra il mal France≈øe, the quantity is according to the di≈øcretion of the Phy≈øitian, and the≈øe Pills yee ≈øhall take three times every third day, and then annoint them with our ∆≤nguento magno, and he ≈øhall be helped. There is another kind of ≈øcab that goeth creeping with a dry cru≈øt like unto Petigine, and tho≈øe are the meer Pox inveterated, and and the order to cure them is thus, give them our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholie humour, becau≈øe it purgeth the blood and cooleth the Liver, and di≈ø≈øolveth that vi≈øcous humour that ingendereth that cru≈øt, that being done, give them our Aromatico, and annoint them with our Magno liquore, and he ≈øhall be perfectly helped in ≈øhort ≈øpace. There are other kind of Scabs that come through great cold, and tho≈øe are healed onely with annointing them with oyle of Frankincen≈øe three or four times.

div.head: To help Mal di Formica.
div.p:
THo≈øe be certain Ulcers which go creeping in the upper part of the fle≈øh, and have many orifices or mouthes, and the≈øe are cau≈øed of the Pox being inveterated, the which are cured in that order that the Poxe is, and that is this: Fir≈øt, purge the bodie with our Electuario Angelica, the which purgeth away gro≈ø≈øe and malign humours, and evacuateth the ≈øtomack of choler and flegm, this being done, cau≈øe the Patient to ≈øweat, for that will a≈ø≈øubtiliate the humours, and cau≈øe them to come forth, that being done, take our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, and ≈øtrew thereon Precipitate, and then annoint it with our Magno liquore, and lay it upon the ≈øore, and there let it lye twentie four hours before ye change it, then make it clean, and lay it on again, for that Plai≈øter may ≈øerve four daies, making it clean every 24. hours, and when the Plai≈øter will draw no more matter, you ≈øhall u≈øe our ∆≤nguento magno, the which will help it in ≈øhort time. But if it doe happen that this Order doe not cure them, then it would be nece≈ø≈øary for them to be annointed with the Unction for the Pox, and to annoint them ≈øo long till the mouth be ≈øore, and when that
≈øign doth appear, annoint them no more, for he will ≈øpit or vapour at the mouth for twelve or fifteen dayes, and as ≈øoon as he vapoureth make a Bath and wa≈øh him well, and wa≈øh the mouth with Wine, and without all doubt it ≈øhall help him God willing; now hereafter I will write of certain things which are u≈øed of common Chirurgians, with a brief di≈øcour≈øe upon them.

div.head: Of the Tow which is laid upon Wounds by common Chirurgians.
div.p: THe pleggits of Tow, which are laid upon Wounds when they are fir≈øt ≈øtitched is made in this order. ‚Ñû. The white of an Egge, Salt, and Ro≈øewater, and beat them together, and when the Wound is ≈øtitched then lay it thereon, becau≈øe the bloud ≈øhould ≈øtint, and the Wound remain ≈øhut, ≈øo that it may be helped with more ea≈øe. Now touching this, I will ≈øhew thee a rea≈øon why they u≈øe it in their fir≈øt cure, yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that every like de≈øireth his like to ≈øuccour him, or keep company with him, and therefore the Antients, our antient Profe≈ø≈øors of Art, willed the white of an Egge to be occupied in Wounds, becau≈øe it is a ≈øub≈øtance of fle≈øh like unto the other fle≈øh; and to declare the truth, I will prove it by naturall rea≈øon, for yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the white of the Egge is that part which ingendereth the fle≈øh, the skin, and the feathers of the Hen, and the yolk ingendereth onely the guts and other intrals of the Animall, then ≈øeeing the white is that which ingendereth the fle≈øh onely, it is like unto fle≈øh, as it is ≈øaid before; then the Salt is a materiall which pre≈øerveth all things from putrifaction, as is ≈øeen by experience daily, and for that con≈øideration it was put in this Compo≈øition to pre≈øerve the fle≈øh, the Ro≈øewater by nature is cold and dry, and by his coldne≈ø≈øe defendeth the inflammation, and by his drine≈ø≈øe is repercu≈ø≈øive, and mittigateth, ≈øo that the≈øe are the rea≈øons why the ≈øaid Tow is laid upon Wounds, but I would to God that ≈øuch things were u≈øed, as by their excellent operations would help and heal from the beginning to the latter ending and to leave of ≈øuch trifling orders.

div.head: Of the dige≈øtive with the which they dre≈ø≈øe wounds after the afore≈øaid Tow.
div.p: AFter that the Tow is taken away from the Wound they dre≈ø≈øe it with a Compo≈øition called dige≈øtive, becau≈øe it dige≈øteth the Wound, although this Medicine be ≈øomewhat ≈øcrupulous, and again≈øt Science, and the rea≈øon is this, yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that when a man is wounded, the place before was ≈øound, and therefore being wounded, our true duty is to help the ≈øame Wound, and not to dige≈øt or rot it, as commonly all Chirurgians doe, for by rotting of it in that order it is perillous, and more dangerous to be cured, as is daily ≈øeen by experience, and this no man can deny. But now I will follow our Regiment in ≈øhewing what this dige≈øtive is, the which is made thus.

‚Ñû The yolk of two Eggs, Turpentine wa≈øhed ‚Ñ•. i. Oil of Ro≈øes ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. mix them in an Unguent, and this is the dige≈øtive wherewith they dre≈ø≈øe it untill the ≈øore have made matter enough, and then they u≈øe to dre≈ø≈øe it with Medicines much differing from the ≈øame; but I marvell much at the diver≈øity of this matter, that this dige≈øtive being applyed to a putrified Ulcer worketh divers effects, for it healeth it divinely: and moreover, yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that if it be applyed unto when they be incarnated, it will ≈øicatrize them marvellou≈øly, for truly the≈øe are things worthy to be known, and he that under≈øtandeth the rea≈øon, I accompt him to be wi≈øe, for if this dige≈øtive be laid on fre≈øh wounds it putrifieth and rotteth them, again being laid on a filthy ≈øore it doth mundifie and heal, and then if it be applyed on a Wound incarnated, it ≈øicatrizeth and healeth it, for this I have done divers and ≈øundry times, the which is to be wondred at.

div.head: Of the mundificative ∆≤nguent wherewith they dre≈ø≈øe the Wounds after they are dige≈øted to mundifie them.
div.p:
VVHen Wounds are come to dige≈øtion, and that they purge, alwayes they change Unguents, and they
apply Unguents that have vertue to mundifie the Wound and make it clean, ≈øo that it may the better incarnate, and that Unguent is called properly a mundificative, the which is made of Barly flower, and Hony, or Hony of Ro≈øes, and Oil of Ro≈øes, and this is the mundificative they u≈øe eight or ten dayes together, for if the Wound were not well mundified, it would never incarnate well, ≈øo that this Unguent is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary in that operation, in re≈øpect of the ingredient.

div.head: Of their incarnative wherewith they dre≈ø≈øe the Wound after it is mundified.
div.p: VVHen that the Wound is mundified, ≈øo that thereunto cometh ≈ømall quantity of matter, then it is nece≈ø≈øary to apply Unguents that incarnate, ≈øo that they may ≈øiccatrize with more ea≈øe, and this kind of incarnative is in the mo≈øt u≈øe among the common Chirurgians, the which is made of Turpentine, Wax, and Frankincen≈øe, and a little Oil of Ro≈øes mixt on the fire, and this is their incarnative.

div.head: A rare ≈øecret, the which this Authour did ≈øend unto a ≈øpeciall friend of his, being in the warres in Africa, the which helpeth all Wounds, either by cut, thru≈øt, galling with Arrows, or harquibu≈øh-≈øhot, or otherwi≈øe.
div.p: THe fir≈øt thing that yee ≈øhall doe is, to wa≈øh the Wound very clean with Urine, and then dry it very well, then put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, and pre≈øently joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and ≈øtitch or ≈øow them well, but in any wi≈øe ≈øow nothing but the skin, for otherwi≈øe it would cau≈øe great pain, then put thereon five or ≈øix drops of our Bal≈øamo, and upon the Wound lay a cloth wet in our Magno liquore, as hot as he may ≈øuffer it, and this doe the fir≈øt day, then the next day follow this order, fir≈øt put thereon our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and a little Bal≈øamo, and then our Magno liquore very hot, and never change this Medicine untill it be whole.

div.head: Of tho≈øe ∆≤nguents that ≈øiccatrize Wounds.
div.p: THe Unguents that ≈øiccatrize Wounds after they are incarnated be of divers kinds, although they work one effect in ≈øiccatrizing, or cau≈øing a skin. The dige≈øtion that is written of before, being applyed upon a Wound incarnated, doth ≈øiccatrize it with ≈øpeed, the like doth Diachilon, and ∆≤nguentum de Tutia. The Cerot called Gratia Dei, although the≈øe be ≈øundry Compo≈øitions one differing from another, yet in effect they ≈øerve all to this ≈øiccatrization, as yee may ≈øee by experience, and this they doe, becau≈øe they be temperate and of good qualities, and ≈øo they help nature to work more quickly, and they are called helpers of nature. But the≈øe kind of Unguents that work by them≈øelves, as ∆≤nguento Apo≈øtolorum, the Cau≈øtick, Aegypciacum, the Rottery, and ≈øuch like Unguents as work with violence, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe nature, and doe that which nature cannot doe by it ≈øelf without help, but all tho≈øe Unguents that are not violent neither in heat or cold, are apt to ≈øiccatrize Wounds, and all ≈øores, that are mundified and incarnated.

div.head: A Remedy to help a Wound with great ≈øpeed, of our invention.
div.p: VVOunds of divers and ≈øundry ≈øorts are very perillous of life, but to help them quickly, becau≈øe the Patient may take no harm, yee ≈øhall u≈øe this ≈øecret, wa≈øh the Wound with our water of Balm, and clean≈øe it well, and lay thereon clothes wet in Oil of Frankincen≈øe made by di≈øtillation, and therewith thou ≈øhalt heal any great Wound in ≈øhort time, as I have proved divers and ≈øundry times, in ≈øundry cau≈øes.

div.head: An excellent ≈øecret to heal Wounds of Gun-≈øhot, or Arrowes, without any danger.
div.p:
IF thou wilt help the afore≈øaid Wounds, it were nece≈ø≈øary fir≈øt to joyn the parts clo≈øe too, and wa≈øh it with our
Aqua cele≈øtis, and lay thereon our Oleum Bal≈øami, and therewith thou ≈øhalt ≈øave the lives of many wounded per≈øons.

div.head: A Di≈øcour≈øe upon old Wounds that are not yet healed, and their ≈øoveraign Remedy.
div.p: VVHen that Wounds are evill healed, and that they impo≈øthumate, and that the Arme, or Leg, or other parts where they were wounded, is indurated and full of pain, thou ≈øhalt u≈øe this ≈øecret of our invention, never known before of old nor new Writers, for it is of great vertue, and many times proved: fir≈øt yee ≈øhall wa≈øh the Wound well, and make it clean round about, then wa≈øh the Wound with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and make it to fume, becau≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence doth open the pores, and a≈ø≈øubtiliateth the matter, and cau≈øeth the humour to come forth, that being done, annoint it all over with our Magno liquore, and thus doing, before three dayes end he ≈øhall feel great ea≈øe, and in ≈øhort time it ≈øhall be helped, becau≈øe this Medicine taketh away the hardne≈ø≈øe, and healeth the Wound, and comforteth the place offended.

div.head: To di≈ø≈øolve a Brui≈øe in ≈øhort time, when it is new done.
div.p: THe≈øe are called Contu≈øions, unto the which nature ≈øendeth quickly great quantity of humidity, and in that place it cau≈øeth Impo≈øthumation: But if our Chirurgians would be diligent and quick, all Contu≈øions might be helped with great ea≈øe in ≈øhort time, and therefore if thou wilt work miracles in the cure, u≈øe this our meanes, and it will turn to thy great honour, and the remedy is this.

‚Ñû. Liquid Verni≈øh three pound, yellow Wax ‚Ñ•. iv. common A≈øhes ‚Ñ•. vi. Aqua vitae rectified two pound. Put all the afore≈øaid matters in a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe, and di≈øtill it with a gentle fire untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, the which will be Oil and water, the which yee ≈øhall ≈øeparate, and keep them, and when occa≈øion ≈øerveth, annoint the Brui≈øe therewith, and lay thereon a cloth wet in the ≈øame, for this is a miraculous Medicine, experimented and proved by rea≈øon, for
an experiment without rea≈øon is as a man without clothes, and therefore if thou wilt know great and rare ≈øecrets never written before, looke in my Spechio del ≈øcientia univer≈øali, and in my The≈øauro del vita humana, and therein thou ≈øhalt find ≈øtrange things proved by rea≈øon and experience, the which books God willing, I mean to ≈øet forth in the Engli≈øh tongue to the profit of my Country.

div.head: To help a Wound quickly that is in perill of any accident.
div.p: VVOunds in ≈øome parts of the body are very dangerous of life; and e≈øpecially where Sinewes be cut or peirced, or Veines or Mu≈øcles hurt, or Bones broke, and by an infinite of other particulars, which being open or evill healed, the Patient may be in danger of life, becau≈øe the winde entereth in, and they cau≈øe pains and inflammation, and therefore to avoid all the≈øe afore≈øaid matters, ≈øo that the Wound ≈øhall have no detriment, u≈øe this remedy. Fir≈øt joyn the parts clo≈øe together, and put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and lay thereon a cloth wet in our Balm, and bind it fa≈øt that the air get not in, for it is very hurtfull; yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the≈øe are two of the excellente≈øt Medicines that may be found, becau≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate the bloud, and taketh it forth, and taketh away the pain, and the Balm doth warm and comfort the place offended, and will not ≈øuffer any matter to run thereunto by any meanes, for this is mo≈øt true, as I have proved divers and ≈øundry times, and alwayes have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: To ≈øtop the flux of bloud in Wounds with great ≈øpeed.
div.p:
VVHen there is any great flux of blood in Wounds, by rea≈øon of ≈øome vein that is cut, and that the Chirurgians would ≈øtop it, it were nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øtitch it well, but not as the common Chirurgians doe, with wide ≈øtitches, but ≈øtitch it very clo≈øe and hard, and put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and upon the Wound ≈øtrew the bloud of a man dried in powder, and lay upon the bloud a cloth wet in our Balm
artificiall very warm, and upon that bind the Wound with ligaments very ≈øtreight, and every day twice wa≈øh it with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and round about annoint it with our Balm, and al≈øo ca≈øt thereon our ≈øecret powder for Wounds, and that doe morning and evening every day, without opening of the Wound, and in that time the Wound will remain well, and the veins will be in a manner healed ≈øo that they will not bleed, giving you charge, that the Wounded man keep no diet, becau≈øe the vertue being weak relaxeth the veins, and that cau≈øeth the flux of blood.

div.head: Another Remedy to ≈øtay the flux of bloud in a Wound.
div.p: VVHen there is a great flux of bloud in a Wound, the perfecte≈øt remedy is to ≈øtitch it very clo≈øe, then take mans bloud being dried, and made into powder, and ca≈øt it upon the Wound, and bind it ≈øomewhat ≈øtreight, and ≈øo let it remain four and twenty hours, and when yee unbind it, take heed that yee remove nothing, and ca≈øt on more dried bloud upon the Wound, annoint it round about with our Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Turpentina & Cera, and bind it up again other four and twenty hours, and then bind it gently, and annoint the Wound with Oil of Frankincen≈øe, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time it will be whole, giving thee great charge, that yee put in no tent or ≈øuch like, and then thou ≈øhalt ≈øee miracles.

div.head: Of our Cerot Magno, that helpeth again≈øt all ≈øorts of Sores and Wounds.
div.p: THis Cerot is of great vertue, and healeth all manner of Sores and Wounds, if it be ≈øpread on a cloth and laid thereon, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Galbanum ‚Ñ•. i. Ammoniacum ‚Ñ•. ii. Oppoponax ‚Ñ•. ii. Ari≈øtolochia longa ‚Ñ•. i. new Wax ‚Ñ•. xviii. fine Mirrh, Olibanum, Verdiguieco, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Bdellium ‚Ñ•. ii. Gum of the Proin tree ‚Ñ•. ii. Lapis h ‚Ä¢ matites ‚Ñ•. ii. Turpentine, Frankincen≈øe, of each ‚Ñ•. iiii. Oil of Wax ‚Ñ•. iii. Beat all tho≈øe that are to be beaten,
and ≈øearce them finely, and keep every one by him≈øelf, then di≈ø≈øolve the Gums in di≈øtilled Vinegar, according to Art, and then vapour away the Vinegar again, and ≈øtrain the gums through a cloth, then take the Wax with as much ≈øweet oyle and melt them on the fire, and when they are melted, put thereunto ‚Ñ•. ii. of Litarge of gold finely ≈øearced, and ≈øtir them continually untill it be boyled, the which ye ≈øhall know by this token. Put a feather therein, and if it be boyled enough, it will burn ≈øtraightwaies, or el≈øe let it boil untill it burn it, then take it from the fire, and cool it a little, and then put in the gums and ≈øtir them well together, and ≈øet it on the fire again, and it will ri≈øe with a great noi≈øe, and therefore let it boyl untill it do fall down again, then take it from the fire, and put thereunto all the afore≈øaid powders, and ≈øtir it untill it be cold, and therewith thou ≈øhalt work marvellous cures, if it be made well, according to Art.

div.head: Of our Magi≈øtrall ∆≤nguent that helpeth divers ≈øorts of Sores.
div.p: THis Unguent is appropriate for many kind of ≈øores, becau≈øe it comforteth the ≈øore, and taketh away the pain, and draweth the matter from the lower parts or bottom of the ≈øore, the which matter is cau≈øe of the pain: It keepeth al≈øo from accidents, giving you charge that it be made artificially, for otherwi≈øe it will not be of ≈øo much vertue, and this is the Unguent.

‚Ñû. Litarge of Gold, four ounces, Oyle of Ro≈øes, two pound; boil them in a Copper pan ≈øo long, as if yee put a feather therein, it will burn it, then it is ≈øod, then put thereto of new Wax, ‚Ñ•. vi. Storax liquida, two ounces, common Honey, three ounces, then let it boil awhile untill they be well incorporated, then take it from the fire, and put thereto Olibanum, Myrrha, Mercurie Precipitate, Oyle of Wax, Oyle of Turpentine, Oyle of Frankincen≈øe, of each two ounces, mix them well till they be incorporated, then put thereto pure rectified Aqua vita, ‚Ñ•. iiii. and mix them well,

div.head: To make Oyle of Frankincen≈øe.
div.p: TAke a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and fill it half ≈øull of Frankincen≈øe, and for every pound of Frankincen≈øe, put thereunto ‚Ñ•. iii. of common A≈øhes finely ≈øearced, then di≈øtill it in ≈øand, and the fir≈øt that cometh forth will be water, the which will be clear, then increa≈øe the fire, and there will come forth an oyle of the colour of a Rubie, the which keep clo≈øe in a gla≈ø≈øe, the fir≈øt water is of marvellous vertue in divers operations, but one miraculous experiment I will not leave to write of, becau≈øe it is a thing very nece≈ø≈øary, and it is this. For tho≈øe that have chilblains, or kibes, or chops in the hands or feet that cometh through cold, yee ≈øhall fir≈øt perfume the parts that are ≈øore over the fume of hot water, ≈øo that they may ≈øweat, then dry them and wa≈øh them with the afore≈øaid water, and put on a pair of gloves, and in ≈øhort time they ≈øhall be whole, it helpeth al≈øo the white ≈øcall and ≈øcabs, and ≈øuch like things. The Oyle ≈øerveth in many operations, and ≈øpecially in all cold di≈øea≈øes; if they be inwardly, give thereof every morning one ≈øcruple to drinke, and if they be outward annoint. Al≈øo it helpeth all manner of wounds be they never ≈øo great: If yee annoint them therewith, and keep them clo≈øe from the ayre.

And in any wi≈øe u≈øe no tenting to keep them open, but wet a cloth therein, and lay it thereon, and in ≈øhort ≈øpace they will be healed, al≈øo it di≈ø≈øolveth a brui≈øe in ≈øhort ≈øpace if yee annoint it often therewith, this oyle ≈øerveth al≈øo for Painters to make Varni≈øh.

div.head: Of Oyle of Wax, and his Effect.
div.p:
THis Oyle of Wax is marvellous excellent, for ≈øo much as it ≈øerveth for the mo≈øt part again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes; which Oyle Raymond Lulli doth approve to be a more heavenly and divine Medicine then humane, and is mo≈øt rare for wounds, but
it is not good for common Chirurgians, becau≈øe it helpeth a great wound in ten or twelve daies at the mo≈øt, but as for ≈ømall wounds, it healeth them in three or four daies, annointing onely the wound therewith, and lay thereon clothes wet in the ≈øame. Al≈øo this oyle worketh miracles again≈øt divers di≈øea≈øes inwardly, if yee give thereof one drachm with white wine, and as for tho≈øe who≈øe hair and beard doe fall away, it is a rare thing and of great profit, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. A retort of gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and put therein what quantity of Wax you will, ≈øo that it be not half full, and for every pound of Wax, put thereunto four ounces of the powder of Bricks, then ≈øet it in a furnace, and give it gentle fire untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, the which oyle will be congealed hard, the which is his perfection, for if you will di≈øtill it ≈øo many times that it congeal no more, it will be too hot and ≈øharp, and not to be u≈øed within the body in any wi≈øe, but the fir≈øt di≈øtillation you may u≈øe ≈øafely inwardly, and make Unctions for any kind of di≈øea≈øe where need ≈øhall require, and alwaies it will be good, and doe no hurt in any wi≈øe in any di≈øea≈øe, and therefore this Oyle ought to be had in great regard of all men.

div.head: To help the Tooth-ach, that is cau≈øed of rotten teeth, or that cometh of a de≈øcention of the Head.
div.p: THe teeth being rotten or corrupted alwayes cau≈øeth great pain, and many times it cometh of a de≈øcention from the head and ≈øuch like humours, as Catarrs, Eri≈øipella, but let it come of what cau≈øe it will, I will ≈øhew a remedie of great importance, and it is very ≈øhort, yee ≈øhall take our Aqua reale, and hold it in your mouth a good while, and then ≈øpit it out again, and this yee ≈øhall doe for three dayes together every day once, then afterward it were nece≈ø≈øary to wa≈øh your mouth in like manner with our Aqua bal≈øami for the ≈øpace of a moneth, and ≈øo the tooth-ach ≈øhall be taken away with ea≈øe, for this is our Secret, and may be u≈øed in all times of the year.

div.head: Again≈øt a ≈øtinking Breath.
div.p: THe Breath may ≈øtink through many cau≈øes, as by Ulcers in the mouth, or by corrupt and rotten teeth, and ≈øometime it cometh of the ≈øtomack, and that is evill to be helpt, and therefore if thou wil ‚Ä¢ help the≈øe, thou mu≈øt u≈øe divers Remedies, and fir≈øt to help tho≈øe that have their mouthes ulcerated, yee ≈øhall give them a quantity of our Pillele aquilone, and then let them wa≈øh their mouthes with our Aqua reale, and ≈øo the Ulcers ≈øhall be helpt, and the mouth ≈øhall not ≈øtinke. But when the ≈øtench cometh of rotten teeth, u≈øe the afore≈øaid remedie or Medicine that is written for the tooth-ach, the which will make the teeth as white as ≈ønow, and will ake no more, but when the ≈øtink cometh from the ≈øtomack, it were nece≈ø≈øary to purge the body with our Sirrup Sclutivo, ≈øix or ≈øeven dayes, and then to take our Aromatico, that being done, take rectified Aqua vitae, and the water of Honey, and oyle of Turpentine, of each alike, mix them well together, and every morning drinke thereof ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. fa≈øting, for the ≈øpace of of a moneth or thereabout.

div.head: To help all ≈øuch per≈øons that have a great Cough in the Stomack.
div.p:
THe Cough doth come of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes, but let it come of what cau≈øe it will, it alwaies offendeth the ≈øtomack and the head, for alwaies when the ≈øtomack is offended, of nece≈ø≈øitie the head is offended, becau≈øe it hath communication with the Stomack, ≈øo that the Stomack ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cau≈øe of the pains in the head, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary to help the ≈øtomack fir≈øt, and that thou ≈øhalt doe with our Pillole aquilone, the which is written in this Book following, and if ≈øo bee you cannot take Pills, take our Aromatico, this being done, if there be no Fever, give him every morning, ‚Ñ•. i. of our Electuarie Magi≈øtrale per la to≈ø≈øe, and every night annoint his ≈øtomack with Magno liquore, and al≈øo his head and no≈øthrils, but if it happen that the afore≈øaid things help it not, then

div.head: To help tho≈øe that cannot hold their water.
div.p: THis proceedeth of two cau≈øes principally, the fir≈øt is, of ≈øuperfluous heat of the body, through the which heat, nature doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate too much that humid part, and continually doth ≈øend it down into the Bladder. The ≈øecond cau≈øe is, that the pores are too much relaxed or opened, by the which operation the Urine doth pa≈ø≈øe without retention, and the≈øe are the two cau≈øes why the Urine cannot ≈øtay, and this cometh commonly to young children, becau≈øe they are very hot of complexion, and the order to help them, is this.

Give them our Pillole Aquilone three times, the quantitie is from í. i. to one and a half; that being done, yee ≈øhall make them a decoction of Hy≈øope of the mountain, and put therein Sugar, and this they ≈øhall u≈øe ten or twelve daies at the lea≈øt, for this mundifieth the place offended, and di≈øpo≈øeth it to ≈øolution. Then after this is done, yee ≈øhall give him for ten daies together half a drachm of Ma≈øtick, with a little Plantain water, for this is hot and re≈øtringeth the pores, and ingro≈ø≈øeth the Urine, and ≈øo the Patient ≈øhall remain whole of that infirmitie, by the vertue of the afore≈øaid three Medicines, and it is a very ea≈øie cure, and ≈øoveraign for that purpo≈øe. But ≈øometime there happeneth a Flux of Urine ≈øomewhat like this, and it is not of the afore≈øaid cau≈øes, but of cau≈øes much different from them,, for this is in men and women of age, and thi ‚Ä¢ I find to be cau≈øed of the Pox that cau≈øeth the Flux, and they void certain threds which ≈øome call G ‚Ä¢ norea, and the remedie thereof is onely with great purging and ≈øweating, and then to annoint them five or ≈øix nights with our ∆≤rguento magno, and keep them warm in bed untill ye have ended to annoint him, and then go to the ≈øtow, and he ≈øhall be helpt of that infirmitie.

div.head: To help tho≈øe that cannot make water.
div.p: THe Urine is ≈øtaid through divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes, and the principall are three, of the which one is the Stone that ingendereth in the Bladder, for alwaies it hangeth down in the neck of the Bladder, and ≈øtoppeth the Meatus, or pores that the Urine cannot pa≈ø≈øe, the which grieveth the Patient marvellou≈øly. The other is cau≈øed of gravell, or gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours that cannot pa≈ø≈øe the pores, and ≈øo cau≈øe that retention of Urine with great pain. The third is cau≈øed of an ob≈øtruction or re≈øtriction of the pores or conduits, where the Urine doth pa≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo keepeth the Urine within with great pain, ≈øo that the≈øe bee the three chiefe≈øt cau≈øes of the retention of Urine

The cure of the fir≈øt cau≈øe which is the Stone, is to purge them well, and then to u≈øe our mo≈øt ≈øoveraign Remedie that is written in this Book following, the which is of great vertue to break the Stone, as I have proved many times, but when this Medicine is not able to break it, then it is nece≈ø≈øary to cut it forth, and this is all concerning the fir≈øt cau≈øe.

To help the ≈øecond cau≈øe, it were nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe Purgations that purge the Reins well, and then to give them our Aromatico, and then to annoint the Reins ≈øix dayes every day once with ∆≤nguento magno, and with this Medicine thou ≈øhalt help him perfectly.

To cure the third cau≈øe it were nece≈ø≈øary to purge with aperative things, and then to annoint his Reins, and under the members and belly with our Balm artificiall, and give him to drinke the powder of Hoglice, or Centum pedes, that are found under ≈øtones, and by the grace of God he ≈øhall be perfectly whole.

div.head: To help tho≈øe that have great burning of their ∆≤rine.
div.p:
THe burning of the Urine may come of divers and ≈øundry cau≈øes, but I find four principall, of which one is the Stone in the Bladder being great or ≈ømall. The ≈øecond cau≈øe
is a certain heat, the which corrupteth the place where it pa≈ø≈øeth and carrieth forth, as it were, certain long threds, the which cau≈øeth that burning. The third cau≈øe is a certain vi≈øcou≈øne≈ø≈øe, the which holdeth to the bottome of the Urinall, and it will not well break, and this is called Gonorrea. The fourth cau≈øe is certain fluxes of Urine cau≈øed of ≈øome kind of the Pox, as yee may ≈øee by tho≈øe that u≈øe company with evill women, and take harm, for pre≈øently this burning cometh, and therefore this ≈øheweth me plainly, that it is the Pox that cau≈øeth the burning of Urine.

But if thou wilt help the afore≈øaid four cau≈øes, thou maye≈øt doe it with ea≈øe having the true Art of a good Phy≈øitian, and the remedie of the fir≈øt cau≈øe coming of the Stone, is to take it forth of the Bladder.

The ≈øecond cau≈øe is to be helpt with purging with our Sirrupo Solutivo, and then after that, to u≈øe our oyle of Vitriall compound, taking thereof every morning, ‚Ñ•. i. and ≈øo they ≈øhall remain helped.
The third cau≈øe is helpt with taking every ‚Ä¢ en dayes a quantitie of our Aromatico, and ≈øo with this onely Remedie they ≈øhall be helped.
The fourth cau≈øe is helped with Medicines appropriate for the Pox, and to annoint them with ∆≤nguento magno.

div.head: To help tho≈øe that have great pain of the Gout.
div.p:
THe Gout is a corrupt and malign infirmitie, and properly ingendered of corruption, as it is plainly ≈øeen in tho≈øe that are troubled therewith, and to prove it to be true, Nature doth ≈øhew it well, becau≈øe you may ≈øee how great the alteration is of that accident, and ≈øeeing that humour is cau≈øed of a windie humour, and alteration of the bloud, as is ≈øeen by experience, I beleeve the ≈øame di≈øpo≈øition hath his originall and beginning of the ≈øtomack, for ≈øo much as all tho≈øe that are troubled with that di≈øea≈øe, the fir≈øt ≈øign that appeareth unto them, is a great pain in the Stomack, three or four dayes or more before the grief cometh, and then the pain increa≈øeth exceedingly, ≈øo that by the ≈øaid ≈øign, I judge
this accident cannot proceed of other place then the ≈øtomack, and to affirm it better, yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that tho≈øe which are troubled therewith can find no better remedy then to evacuate the ≈øtomack from all corruption, and therefore if thou wilt help them of that accident, the fir≈øt thing that yee ≈øhall doe is, to give them a quantity of our Aromatico in the morning fa≈øting, and drink thereon a little white Wine, that being done, it would be nece≈ø≈øary to make a fomentation with Nettles that be well boiled in water, and then to annoint them with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and ≈øo for that time the Gout will be gone, and will remain away for a long time.

But if God permit me life, I will hereafter ≈øet forth the order to help the Gout that it ≈øhall never come again, with a certain order to be ob≈øerved in the ≈øame, found out by this Authour, and hath been proved an infinite number of times in divers places, and on divers noble men, as yee may well under≈øtand in his The≈øauro della vita humana.

div.head: A remedy again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence, that pre≈øerveth tho≈øe that u≈øe it.
div.p:
THe Pe≈øtilence is a certain corrupt humour, which is the cau≈øe of the evill di≈øpo≈øition of the air that is corrupted and poy≈øoned, and it is ≈øo contagious, that in ≈øix and thirty hours it corrupteth the body, and cau≈øeth them to dye, and therefore if any will defend them from that infection, they may doe it by the help of God and the Phy≈øitian with the≈øe Medicines; the fir≈øt thing is to confe≈ø≈øe our ≈øelves unto Almighty God, and to pray heartily unto him, and then as concerning Phy≈øicall Medicines, three things are to be u≈øed, which may ≈øave the lives of many: The fir≈øt thing is to evacuate the ≈øtomack, the ≈øecond to ≈øweat, the third unction. And touching the fir≈øt, yee ≈øhall u≈øe every three dayes our Pillo ‚Ä¢ e Aquilone, for they evacuate the contagiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and will not let it corrupt the body. For the ≈øecond, yee ≈øhall cable them to ≈øweat by artificiall meanes, for that evacuateth a certain matter very apt to corrupt. And the third is, to annoint all
the body with our Balm artificiall, for that pre≈øerveth the body, and defendeth it from the contagiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that by the≈øe three meanes men and women may be pre≈øerved from that violent death.

div.head: To help Pellaria, that is a di≈øea≈øe which cau≈øeth the hair and beard to fall away,
div.p: THis Pellaria is a certain kind of fanta≈øticall infirmity, of the which we by practi≈øe doe know the cau≈øe, which is by u≈øing company with women corrupted with the Pox, and by the ≈øame practi≈øe we ≈øee, that tho≈øe who≈øe hair doe fall away, doe fall into great infirmities of the Pox, although not all, yet the mo≈øt part, and therefore if thou wilt help that accident, it were nece≈ø≈øary to purge them with our Sirrupo Solutivo eight or ten dayes together, that being done, give them our Arcmatico, and then annoint the place where the hair is fallen away every evening with our Balm artificiall, ≈øo that with the u≈øe of the≈øe three Medicines the Patient ≈øhall remain perfectly whole of that matter, becau≈øe the Sirrup purgeth the whole body univer≈øally, and the Aromatico purgeth the ≈øtomack and the head, and the Balm comforteth and defendeth the place where the hair is fallen, ≈øo that it ≈øhall fall no more, for this I have proved an infinite of times. You ≈øhall under≈øtand, that there be two other kinds of Pellaria, the which will not be helped in the afore≈øaid order, for the one cometh of a great fear, and the other cometh becau≈øe they have had Mal di Ma≈ø≈øuca, and their heads be corrupted by that meanes, and for the≈øe two I know no remedy, but to let nature have her cour≈øe.

div.head: To help a Carno≈øitie in the Yeard.
div.p:
THe Carno≈øitie that cometh in the Yeard hindereth the Urine ≈øo that it cannot pa≈ø≈øe, and groweth in the mouth of the bladder, and is a kind of matter ingendered in that place, the which is much like unto an Emerode that cometh in the neck of the inte≈øtine about the fundament, and becau≈øe it is a
gro≈ø≈øe and ulcerated matter, the urine pa≈ø≈øeth with difficultie and great burning, the which is very painefull unto tho≈øe that have it, but if thou wilt helpe that inconvenience, it were nece≈ø≈øary to purge the body well, and to keep a diet, and to drink the Decoction of Hypericon made with Hony, and u≈øe to eat dry meats as much as is po≈ø≈øible, and then make certain little wax Candles of Wax and Frankincen≈øe, and then make this Unguent.
