Butter ‚Ñ•. ii. white Wine as much as will ≈øuffice to incorporate them in a liquid form on a ≈øoft fire, and then take ten quills that hath bloud in them, out of the wing of a young Pigeon that is fat, and therewith ≈øtir the Unguent when it boileth, and when one quill is dried take another, and ≈øo change them untill the Wine be con≈øumed, and then it is made, and when thou wilt occupie it, take one of the ≈øaid Candles of wax, and upon the end put of this Unguent, and put it into the Yeard untill it touch the Carno≈øitie, and this thou ≈øhalt u≈øe day by day, untill the Candell pa≈ø≈øe without any impediment, and then the Patient ≈øhall be helped, for this is mo≈øt true, and I have proved it an infinite of times, to my great credit, and content of the Patient.

div.head: To help the white Scall.
div.p:
THis di≈øea≈øe being ≈øo odious is a corrupt humour, which is not onely in the head as many doe think, but it dependeth of the inward parts, and hath communication with the head, and this humour is like unto the Fume, for continually it vapoureth up, and when it can a≈øcend no more becau≈øe it is hindered in the skin, then it ≈øettleth, and ingro≈ø≈øeth, and cau≈øeth the head to break forth in that grievous order as is ≈øeen. But I will ≈øhew a ≈øecret to help it, ≈øo that it ≈øhall never come again, and the order to make it is thus. You ≈øhall give them our Sirrupo Solutivo eight or ten dayes together, that being done, give them our Pillole Aquilone three times, the which pills mu≈øt be taken every three dayes once, that being done, take Sinaber finely beaten ‚Ñ•. ii. Olibanum, Mirrha, ana. í. i. mix them together, and divide it into ‚Ä¢ ive parts, and make
thereof five perfumes in five mornings, and cover their heads with a cloth, ≈øo that it touch not the head, then let the powder be ca≈øt on by little and little untill it be ≈øpent, upon a chafingdi≈øh of coals, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand covered one hour without moving, and this doe every one of the times, that being done, annoint the head for the ≈øpace of a moneth with Oil of Wax, and Turpentine, and they ≈øhall be helped, for this is a remedy that cannot fail, for I have proved it an infinite of times, in Palermo, in Me≈øina, in Naples, in Rome, and in Venice, and alwayes I have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, to my great credit, and profit of the di≈øea≈øed per≈øon.

div.head: To help tho≈øe Carvoli that come upon the Yeard, and their cau≈øes.
div.p: THo≈øe Carvoli that come upon the Yeard are of divers kinds, as by rea≈øon and experience thou maye≈øt ≈øee, but the mo≈øt part are taken by u≈øing the company of lewd and corrupt women infected with the Pox, and tho≈øe are the wor≈øt kind, for they are the fir≈øt originall of the Pox, and of tho≈øe Carvoli come, Pannochi, or Botches, and certain great Scabs, Pellaria, Aches, and Tumours, and an infinite of other evill effects, and the≈øe are the fir≈øt kind. There are another kind, which commonly come of their own accord by rea≈øon of heat, and tho≈øe are ea≈øie to be helped, and are not perillous or painfull. There is another kind, the which is as though it were ≈øcorched or burnt, the which cometh through debility of the Yeard, and having company with women, and the≈øe are al≈øo of ≈ømall importance.

The fir≈øt kind are certain Ulcers that come upon the end, and ≈øome upon the proper ≈øub≈øtance of the Yeard, and ≈øome upon the skin, and the order to cure them is thus. Yee ≈øhall mortifie them within and without with our Cau≈øtick and when they are mortified yee ≈øhall dre≈ø≈øe them with our Magno liquore, and they ≈øhall be whole quickly.

But yee ≈øhall well note, that many times after they are healed before fifteen dayes doe pa≈ø≈øe, there will come a certaine alteration in the throat, ≈øo that they can ≈øcarce ≈øwallow their
meat, and this alteration many times endureth eight or ten daies, and then it re≈øolveth by it ≈øelf, and that is a certain ≈øign of Pe ‚Ä¢ aria.

And therefore if thou wilt avoid that inconvenience that the hair fall not off, a≈ø≈øoon as yee feel any of the afore≈øaid griefs, then pre≈øently take a quantitie of our Electuario Angelica, and then take our Sirrupo Magi≈øtrale, four or five dayes, and annoint thy head ten or twelve daies with our Magno liquore, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes the hair ≈øhall not fall. Becau≈øe our Electuario Ang ‚Ä¢ lica, doth evacuate the ≈øtomack, and clean≈øeth the head, and drieth up the matter, the which is already alterated by that di≈øea≈øe. Al≈øo our Sirrupo magi≈øtrale, doth evacuate the body, and purifie the bloud, and ≈ø ‚Ä¢ aketh the fury of the di≈øea≈øe. Our Magno liquore pre≈øerveth the hair from drying and falling.

There cometh many times, after tho≈øe Carvoli are healed, certain Impo≈øthumes in the groin, of the which we will ≈øpeak in another Book particularly. The other kind of Carvoli that come upon the Yeard, are helped onely by wa≈øhing them with ≈øome ‚Ä¢ ath, that is re≈øtrictive and comfortative. The other kind which are like ≈øcorching or burning, are helped by keeping them clean, and annointing them with a Liniment of Tutia camphorata.

And thus I make an end, giving to under≈øtand to tho≈øe that practice, how that they may avoid that di≈øea≈øe called Pellaria, or falling of the hair or beard, for this is one of my Secrets, whereof I mean to write a great number, if God permit me.

div.head: A Di≈øcour≈øe of tho≈øe Sores that come of the Pox, and how to help them quickly.
div.p:
THe Pox, as I have written of divers times, being a putrified and corrupt di≈øea≈øe, the ≈øores coming thereof of force mu≈øt be of his nature, that is corrupt and ≈øtinking, therefore if thou wilt help them, and take away their pain quickly, thou ≈øhalt u≈øe three operations, the fir≈øt is to give them our Pillole Aquilone, and then to wa≈øh the ≈øore with oyle
of Sulphur, and then lay thereon our Cerot magi≈øtrale, with Precipitate, and annoint it with Magno liquore, and therewith thou ≈øhalt help them quickly, becau≈øe tho≈øe Pills are appropriate for that di≈øea≈øe, and the oyle of Sulphur draweth forth the filth from the Center, and the Precipitate draweth forth the gro≈ø≈øe matter, ≈øo that of force it mu≈øt heal.

div.head: The cure of one that had the Pox in his head.
div.p: BEing in Naples, among all other that I cured, there came unto me a Spaniard called, Il Siegnior Diego di Menas, a man of the age of 36 years, of complexion cholerick adu≈øt, the which had the Pox, and in his forehead he had a certain tumour, the which had peri≈øhed a great part of the skull, and was open, and he had been taken in hand of divers men, and none could doe him good: I ≈øeeing that took him in hand, and gave him our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo eight or nine daies together, afterward I gave him our Aromatico, and then gave him the roots of Cina in decoction, and then perfumed him with Olibanum, Ma≈øtick, Myrrha, and Sinaber, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes hee was helped of that infirmitie, but the bone remained bare, and I laid thereon our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time, the bone did ≈øeparate of his own accord, and one day I took it off altogether, it was ≈øo great, that it covered the fourth part of the head, then pre≈øently this Seignior Diego went abroad, ≈øhewing what was taken from his head, as divers can te≈øtifie.

div.head: The cure of a Wound in the Head, and in the Hand.
div.p:
THere was a certain Gentleman called Gionan Jacobo Veniciane, the which had a great Wound one the head, and in one of his hands, the which being taken in hand of divers Chirurgians, was brought to a very evill ca≈øe by rea≈øon of great alteration in the Wounds; and the Phy≈øitian that had him in hand, was one called Realdo Polumbo cremen≈øe, the which dre≈ø≈øed his head with Wine and Oyle, and the hand with Turpentine and Oyle of Ro≈øes. Than I being in
company told him, that it were good to change tho≈øe Medicines, becau≈øe in wounds of the head, tho≈øe Medicines were not convenient, for the oyle being crude, putrifieth, and the Wine is repercu≈ø≈øive‚ñ™ and will not ≈øuffer the Putrefaction to come forth that the oyle ingendereth, and for that rea≈øon the ≈øaid Medicine would not be u≈øed.

And as for the Medicine for his hand, I ≈øay that the Turpentine is not convenient, for where there is offence of skin, veins, ≈øinnews, and bones, Turpentine is not good, becau≈øe it is hot and putrefactive, by means of the Oyle, and cau≈øeth inflammation, and therefore it ought not to be u≈øed.

Put if thou wilt help the head and hand both, yee ≈øhall u≈øe a kind of Medicine that comforteth the place offended, and that doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate the matter, and incarnate, to the which the ≈øaid Realdo an≈øwered and ≈øaid my rea≈øon was good, if I could find Remedies that will doe that Effect, the which I ≈øent for to my hou≈øe, and u≈øed them in this order.

Fir≈øt, I did put our Quinte≈ø≈øence into his wound in the head being cold, and then a little of our Bal≈øamo cold, the which ≈øeemed ≈øtrange to Realdo, and then I laid thereon our Magno liquore, and upon the cloth I laid a little of our ≈øecret Powder, and the like I did to the hand, and ≈øo in fourteen dayes the wounds were whole, to the great marvell of a number.

div.head: A great Secret particular for the Flux, and Di≈ø≈øenteria.
div.p:
THe Fluxes of the body are no other but a di≈øtemperance of Nature, and are of two kinds, the one is cau≈øed of an evill qualitie and di≈øtemperance of the Liver, and that is called Flu≈ø≈øo Epatico. The other is cau≈øed of great heat, Fever, and di≈øtemperament of Nature, and this is called Di≈ø≈øenteria, that is a di≈øtemperament of the guts, and both the≈øe ≈øorts are hard to be helped of the ancient Doctors, as it is well ≈øeen by experience of tho≈øe that practi≈øe, for they will help them with repre≈ø≈øion and re≈øtrictives, but that is not the way if wee ≈øhall beleeve Galen, the which writes, Fluxus Fluxum curat, the which is mo≈øt true, for I have cured a thou≈øand of the
Flux with giving them our Aromatico, and three or four do≈øes of our Si ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ≈øolutivo, therefore Galen ≈øaith true.

But the Di≈ø≈øenteria is cured with giving them our Electuario Angelica, and then every day after dinner ≈øtand in a bath of water of the Sea cold two hours at the lea≈øt, and ≈øo in this order thou ≈øhalt help any crude kind of Di≈ø≈øenteria in ≈øhort time, and with great ea≈øe, u≈øe this as a Secret.

div.head: The cure of one that was poy≈øoned with Ar≈øenick.
div.p: THere was a certain man poy≈øoned with Ar≈øenick given him in a me≈ø≈øe of Rice-pottage in an evening at ≈øupper, and as ≈øoon as it was in his ≈øtomack, he began to groan, and ≈øweat, and vomit, in ≈øuch order as it was ≈øtrange to ≈øee, and it happened that at the ≈øaid time there was a learned man in the hou≈øe, who ≈øeeing this man in that ca≈øe, ≈øu≈øpected him to be poy≈øoned, and ≈øo ≈øent for me, and when I came, the poor man was almo≈øt dead, then pre≈øently I called the wife of the hou≈øe, and told her that her husband would die, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould have the Law for poy≈øoning of him, but if that ≈øhee would tell him what poy≈øon ≈øhee had given him, perhaps he might recover him again, with many words more: ≈øo to conclude ≈øhee told him, that ≈øhee had given him two grains of Ar≈øenick in Rice-pottage, then pre≈øently I called for a cup of Sack, and cau≈øed him to drinke, and then he vomited and went to the ≈øtool, and then I annointed him with our oyle of Hypericon, and Scorpions, all the body over, and ≈øtill cau≈øed him to drinke that he might evacuate that poi≈øon, but all his mouth and throat remained ≈øwollen, and he did ≈øpit great abundance, and I cau≈øed him to u≈øe that Unguent, and every morning gave him Triacle with Wine, and every three dayes, I gave him a quantitie of Pillule Aggregative, and la≈øt of all I cau≈øed him to u≈øe Aqua vitae compound, and ≈øo ere fortie daies he was perfectly whole, and rid of a terrible di≈øea≈øe, the which he had before he was poy≈øoned.

div.head: The cure of an ∆≤lcerated Leg.
div.p: THere was a certain man of the age of ≈øix and thirty years, of complexion cholerick and ≈øanguine, the which had his left leg all ulcerated, in ≈øuch order that the Phy≈øitians and Chirurgians of the Citie would have cut it off, but in any wi≈øe I would not con≈øent thereunto, but took it in hand, and gave him fir≈øt our Magi≈øtrall Sirrup in the morning eight or nine daies together, and in the mean time I wa≈øhed the leg with Wine wherein was boyled Mallows, Con≈øolida majore, Carduus benedictus, and Honey, and then wet clothes therein, and laid them on twice a day, then I cau≈øed him to u≈øe a decoction of Lignum vitae, and the bark with Iva artetica, Carduus benedictus, Pollipodie, Ripontico, Wine and Sugar, and his common drink was wine and water boiled on the Fe≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame, and this he u≈øed four and twentie daies, then I perfumed him with Cinaber three times, and ere three monthes were pa≈øt, he was perfectly whole, for his di≈øea≈øe came of the Pox, and tho≈øe ≈øores are commonly called Mal di formica.

div.head: The Cure of the Gout on a certain Gentleman.
div.p:
IN the afore≈øaid year, in the moneth of Augu≈øt, I was called to vi≈øit a noble Gentleman called, Il ≈øeignior Don Chri≈øt of alo, della roca, a man of five and thirtie years, of complexion cholerick, and ≈øanguine, the which was ≈øore troubled with the Gout, and becau≈øe it was in the beginning of Augu≈øt, our ancient Doctors have forbidden to take any ≈øoluble Medicine in that time, in re≈øpect of the Canicular dayes. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I called Armellio, and Leonardo Te≈øta, two excellent Phy≈øitians, the which gave their coun≈øell to take no Medicine, neverthele≈ø≈øe I proved that the Gout was extream hot, and for that I ordained a cold Sirrup to mittigate the ≈øuperfluous heat, the which was made of Liverwort, Harts-tongue, Dates, Rai≈øins, Figs, Sugar, and Succorie water, and aromati≈øed it with Musk and Ro≈øewater, of the which he took every day four ounces,
and for the alteration of the Gout, I wa≈øhed it three or four times a day with our Aqua del Bal≈øamo, becau≈øe it penetrateth and openeth the pores, and a≈ø≈øubtiliateth and dry-the humour offen≈øive: al≈øo I ordained him bread of Barley, becau≈øe it cooleth the bloud, and is of good dige≈øtion, and cau≈øed him to refrain from all fat Brothes, and his drink was temperate, and to this one of the Doctors did agree, but the other would not, neverthele≈ø≈øe the Gentleman was content with my advice, then I began to give him the afore≈øaid decoction, with our Soluble Quinte≈ø≈øence, and therewith he had every day two or three Stools, and I wa≈øhed the Gout three or four times a day with our Aqua Bal≈øami, and the fir≈øt day he began to feel ea≈øe, and the ≈øecond he felt more, ≈øo that in ≈øeven daies all his pains were taken away, and then I applyed thereunto our Secret of Secrets for that kind of di≈øea≈øe, the which in three dayes delivered him; then I cau≈øed him to u≈øe certain Medicines to defend the Gout from coming again, and ≈øo he continued whole to his great ≈øatisfaction.

div.head: Of the cau≈øes of the Scyatica, and how yee may help it.
div.p: THe Sciatica is a di≈øea≈øe ≈øo called, becau≈øe it cometh in that place of the bodie called Sio, and is cau≈øed of an evill qualitie, and gro≈ø≈øe humours that are ≈øtaid in that place, becau≈øe they cannot pa≈ø≈øe down, and this is ≈øeen by experience daily, for where that pain is, there is alteration, and the cure thereof is with Gli≈øters, Vomits, Purgations, and Unctions, becau≈øe the Gli≈øter doth evacuate tho≈øe places next unto it, and ≈øo ea≈øeth the humour, the vomit clean≈øeth the Stomack, the Purgations doe evacuate the body downwards, the Unctions di≈ø≈øolve the Winde, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes thou maye≈øt helpe the Sciatica, as I have done many times to my great honour, and ≈øatisfaction of the Patient.

div.head: A mo≈øt excellent remedie to helpe the flux of the body, with a certaine di≈øcour≈øe thereon.
div.p: IF thou wilt helpe the flux of the body, it were nece≈ø≈øary to know fir≈øt from whence it proceedeth, for he that knoweth not the cau≈øe, is le≈ø≈øe to be credited to cure the effect, and therefore I will ≈øhew thee what the Flux is, and from whence it cometh, and then I will ≈øhew the order to cure it, and al≈øo to make the Medicines.

The Flux of the body is cau≈øed of a ≈øuperfluous heat conceived in the ≈øtomack, the which make a continuall ≈øolution inwardly, as yee may ≈øee by experience of tho≈øe that are troubled therewith, for ≈øo long as the cau≈øe is not taken away, all their meat doth turn into that matter, the which if it be ≈øo, that is true which I doe ≈øay, that the Fluxes are a di≈øtemperance of the body, cau≈øed of hot and corrupt humours in the ≈øtomack, and therefore if thou wilt cure it, it were nece≈ø≈øary to extingui≈øh the heat, and to take away the corruption, the which thou ≈øhalt doe with the redne≈ø≈øe of Marte Militare written in this book following; for that is the mo≈øt ≈øoveraign remedy that can be found But fir≈øt yee ≈øhall take twelve grains of our Petra Philo≈øophale, with ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of Mel Ro≈øar ‚Ä¢ m, and then take for four mornings together one ≈øcruple of the redne≈ø≈øe of Marte, with ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of Sugar Ro≈øat, and therewith thou ≈øhalt work miracles.

div.head: A di≈øcour≈øe as concerning Cornes in the feet or el≈øewhere, with their remedies.
div.p:
THis callous matter is a certain hot humour, of the which Nature would di≈øcharge her ≈øelf, and when that humour is driven forth of Nature, it goeth unto the lower parts into the end of the Toes, for in that extream part of the toes, that skin that is called Epiderma, is hard, and will not ≈øuffer it to pa≈ø≈øe or exalate, and there many times it ingendereth a tumour in the skin with great hardne≈ø≈øe, and many times that tumour doth increa≈øe and cau≈øe ≈øuch pain, that it doth not
onely hinder their going, but hindereth them from ≈øleep in the night, and this kind of tumour is called commonly Callo, or Corns in Engli≈øh, and I thought it good to call them Cre≈øte, becau≈øe they are alwayes growing, and are of great importance among the Chirurgians, for an infinite number of per≈øons are troubled therewith, and therefore I will ≈øhew thee our ≈øecret to help them quickly, and with great ea≈øe; which ≈øecret was never known before of any. Fir≈øt yee ≈øhall pare them with a ≈øharp knife unto the bottome, and there yee ≈øhall find a certain thing like matter, but if yee find no matter, yee ≈øhall pare it untill the bloud doth appear, then touch it once with Oil of Sulphur, and then dre≈ø≈øe it with our Bal≈øamo artificiato once a day untill it be whole. Keep this as a ≈øecret.

div.head: Of an Infirmity of Importance, that cometh upon the extremity of the toe upon the nail.
div.p: THere are many men that are troubled with a certain infirmity under the nail of their great toe, the which ≈øeemeth as though that the nail grew in the fle≈øh, which is not ≈øo, but the fle≈øh groweth over the nail, and although this ≈øeemeth to be a thing of nothing, and that the Ancients have had ≈ømall con≈øideration thereof: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, it is an infirmity of great importance, and to be con≈øidered of, becau≈øe many are troubled therewith, and e≈øpecially men of authority, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are troubled with the Gout. I call to remembrance, that in the time that I was in Naples, I cured a great number, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that were of great authority, to my great honour and profit. The fir≈øt thing that I did, I cut the nail on the part which was grieved and took it away, the which was done ea≈øily and with little pain, which thing being done, I touched it with our Cau≈øtick, and ≈øo let it remain three dayes together, and then I dre≈ø≈øed it every day with our Magno liquore untill it was whole, which was in ≈øhort time.

div.head: A di≈øcour≈øe upon the Emeroids, with the order to cure them with mo≈øt excellent Medicines of our invention.
div.p: THe Emeroids are a certain kind of evill tumour, cau≈øed of the bloud in the veins ‚Ä¢ merodiall, and the≈øe come alwayes in the extremity of the Inte≈øtinals about the Fundament, and ≈øome of them cau≈øe great pain, and ≈øome of them doe burn exce≈ø≈øively, or doe ≈øcald; the which cometh through the quality of the good and evill humours, as yee may ≈øee by experience, how that ≈øome have ≈øuch burning that they cannot re≈øt in the night, the other have ≈øuch pain that they cannot ≈øit, the other are ≈øo ≈øcalded that they cannot abide it, yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this infirmity is more painfull in one complexion then in another, and the cure thereof is difficile Neverthele≈ø≈øe it may be cured, and the order is this.

Fir≈øt take our Aromatico, then take our Sirrupo Solutivo three or four dayes, then take our perfume three or four times on the Fundament, that being done, annoint the place with our Balm artificiall, for that drieth and taketh away the pain altogether, and ≈øo the Patient ≈øhall remain perfect whole.

There is al≈øo a great ≈øecret in the tooth of a Hor≈øe-fi≈øh, if it be worn on a mans finger, to take away the Emeroids, the which tooth I have known proved at the lea≈øt ≈øeven or eight times, for I have a ring made thereof, and have u≈øed it.

div.head: A great ≈øecret to help tho≈øe that are bur≈øt, or have the Rupture.
div.p: THis is a rare ≈øecret, never known before of any man, and e≈øpecially for tho≈øe that have not been bur≈øt long time, and that the Rupture hath not yet made a Callow, and the order to cure it is thus.

Fir≈øt yee ≈øhall give them our Aromatico every ten dayes once, and every morning fa≈øting give them one ounce of
fine Tartar beaten into powder, with water or wine to drink, and likewi≈øe in the evening, two hours before ≈øupper give him as much, and his bread ≈øhall be Bisket made of Rye, al≈øo he mu≈øt wear a Tru≈ø≈øe made fit for that purpo≈øe, and u≈øe this remedy.

‚Ñû. Rectified Aqua vitae without flegm ‚Ñ•. xii. Ro≈øin of the Pine tree that is dry, Olibanum, Ma≈øtick Sarcocolla, ana. ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. Mix them altogether, and with this water wa≈øh the Rupture every day twice, and then ca≈øt thereon pre≈øently the powder of a hearb called Bi≈ølingua and Bal≈øamina, ana. and then wet a cloth in the ≈øaid water, and lay it thereon, and bind the Tru≈ø≈øe very hard, and keep thy hou≈øe with as much ea≈øe as thou maye≈øt, and ≈øtrain not thy ≈øelf in any wi≈øe, and thus within a hundered dayes thou ≈øhalt help any great Rupture, keeping the afore≈øaid order.

div.head: A rare ≈øecret and divine, to help tho≈øe that are troubled with the Spleen.
div.p: THe Milt is alterated and becometh hard, by rea≈øon of a ≈øuperfluous humidity, which it receiveth by the evill di≈øpo≈øition of the Liver and Lungs, and therefore if thou wilt help it, it were nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe Medicines ab≈øter≈øive and drying, and to give them our Aromatico once, and then to u≈øe this Electuary, the which is of marvellous vertue in that operation.

‚Ñû. Squamma ferri ‚Ñ•. i. Scolopendria ‚Ñ•. i. Spicknard, Lapis Lazuli, ana. ‚Ñà ii. Cinnamon ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. beat them fine, and make thereof an Electuary with purified Hony according to art, and take thereof every morning a ≈øpoonfull, and as much at night two houres before ≈øupper, and annoint the place where the Milt lieth with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and ≈øo by the grace of God, and meanes of the≈øe Medicines, thou ≈øhalt be helped quickly.

div.head: A great ≈øecret to help the Spleen with great ≈øppeed.
div.p: THe Milt, as is afore≈øaid, is grieved through abundance of humidity which it receiveth, and therefore thou mu≈øt onely ≈øeek to dry that humidity, and for that purpo≈øe I will ≈øhew thee two great ≈øecrets wherewith thou ≈øhalt work miracles, and are of great rea≈øon and experience, The one is to be let bloud under the tongue in one of the≈øe two veines, that is on that ≈øide where the Milt lieth, that being done, yee ≈øhall take Mu≈øtard, and mix it with the Urine of a Boy, and ≈øay it between two clothes, and lay it on the ≈øore place one night, and then if it be not well, u≈øe it ≈øtill untill it be helped, for this I have proved an infinite of times.

div.head: The cure of a certain Spaniard called Caraba≈øall di Cordonet, the which was troubled with the Pox.
div.p: THis Souldier, being of the age of two and thirty yeares, was mightily troubled with the Pox, with extream paines and ≈øores, among the which, he had all his thigh ≈øo eaten away, as though he had been gnawn with Dogs, with mo≈øt extream pain, and the way that I cured him was thus. I gave him twelve grains of our Petra Philo≈øophale, with Sugar Ro≈øate, the which cau≈øed him to vomit and to evacuate downward, of the which he found great ca≈øe: that being done, I prepared him our decoction of Lignum ≈øanctum ≈øolutivum, the which is written of hereafter, with a certain drink made with Wine, and Lignum vitae, and this he u≈øed five and twenty dayes, and then I annointed him with our ∆≤nguento magno, and in the ≈øpace of forty dayes he was perfectly helped to the ≈øight of all men.

div.head: The cure of the Stitch in the ≈øide with retention of ∆≤rine.
div.p:
THere was a certain Gentleman called, Marco di Chiuffunt of the age of ≈øix and thirty yeares, the which was troubled with a terrible ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and had proved many
Medicines, and none did him plea≈øure, the which, after I took him in hand, I gave him our Aromatico, and after that the pain ≈ølacked, than I cau≈øed him to annoint all tho≈øe parts with the oyle of Nutmegs, and the oyle of Eggs mixt together, and ≈øo he remained quite whole, for in this order I have cured an infinite of per≈øons to my great honour.

div.head: A cure of a certain Spaniard wounded in the head in Naples.
div.p: THere was a certain Spaniard called Zamora, of the age of four and thirtie years, of complexion cholerick and ≈øanguine, the which was wounded in the left ≈øide of the head, with inci≈øion of the bone; al≈øo you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that in Naples the ayre is mo≈øt evill for wounds in the head, by rea≈øon that it is ≈øo ≈øubtile, and for that cau≈øe the Doctors did fear the cure, neverthele≈ø≈øe I dre≈ø≈øed him with our Magno liquore, and Bal≈øamo artificiato, keeping the wound as clo≈øe as was po≈ø≈øible, annointing it onely upon the wound, and ≈øo in fourteen daies he was perfectly whole, to the great wonder of a number of Chirurgians of that Citie.

div.head: The cure of a certain Gentleman that had Mal' di formica.
div.p:
THere was a certain Gentleman Neopolitan, the which was called, Il Seignior Giovan Franci≈øco Gaetavo, of the age of thirty eight years, the which was marvellou≈øly tormented with a ≈øore arm, and a ≈øore leg, called Mal' di formica, and he was of complexion cholerick and melancholie, and the≈øe ≈øores went creeping upon the fle≈øh, healing in one place and breaking out in another, and in his arm he had nine ≈øores, and in the leg fourteen, and this Gentleman had ≈øought help the ≈øpace of two yeares, and could find none, and had twice taken the Diet, and yet could find no help, the which Gentleman I took in hand, and the fir≈øt thing that I gave him was this: ‚Ñ• i. of Hierapiera Galeni, with twenty grains of our Petra Philo≈øphale, the which provoked both vomit and ≈øeege divers times, that being done, I gave him our Sirrupo Solutivo 12. mornings together, that being done, I gave him a Medicine with our Petra Philo≈øophale and Eleborus niger, the which cau≈øed him al≈øo to vomit
and purge downwards, that being done, I cau≈øed him to make a Sirrup of Lignum Sanctum, and the Bark, Iva Artetica, and Carduus Benedictus, in the which I put ≈øeven pound of Wine, and one of Sugar, and then I cau≈øed him to make a drinke with water, and wine, and Honey, to drink continually, and that I cau≈øed him to u≈øe five and twentie dayes, and then I annointed him with our ∆≤nguento magno five times without fire, the which Unguent cau≈øed him to ≈øpit abundance of filthy matter, and at the la≈øt it cau≈øed him for to ≈øpit blood, after the which I cau≈øed him to make a Bath the which is written in our Regiment of the Pe≈øtilence, called the Joyfull Jewell, and I ‚Ä¢ aid on the Sores our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, and thus within thirty eight dayes he was perfectly whole.

div.head: Certain Cures that this Authour did when he travelled into Africa.
div.p:
IN the year 1550 he travelled into Africa, and there he was cho≈øen by Il. S. Don Pietro di Toledo viceroi di Napoli, to be Phy≈øitian unto the camp under Don Gracia his ≈øon, and ≈øo in the year 1551. in the moneth of May he departed from Naples with all the army of the Emperour, Carolo quinto D' Au≈øtria, and ≈øo having a pro≈øperous wind, arrived in Barbarie by a certain old citie called Mona≈øterio, and there gave an a≈ø≈øiege, and took it without any remi≈ø≈øion or ran≈øoming, and made ≈ølaves of all tho≈øe that were left alive, and it remained utterly de≈øtroyed, but not without great mortality of our Chri≈øtian Souldiers, and be≈øide tho≈øe that were killed, there was a great number wounded, the which were brought into the Gallies, and carried to the I≈øle of Sicilla, in a certain citie called Tarpano, the which ≈øay they, was builded by a great Idolater called Tarpos, and there in the Ho≈øpitall tho≈øe wounded per≈øons were left, with certain Chirurgians that were under my jurisdiction, and with certain Medicines of my invention, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time the mo≈øt part were helped, and then the Armie returned unto Naples again, and refre≈øhed them with new men and victuall. And then on the fifteenth of June, we ≈øet up ≈øail and failed, and
when we were in the mid≈øt of the gulf between Naples and Palermo, there happened a great mi≈ø-fortune, the which was thus.

In the Gallie of Si. Giordano Captain General of the Gallies Duke of Florence, it happened that he being at the table with divers Captains and Gentlemen, and as they were, at dinner, a certain Captain being grieved with another, multiplyed words, and took a loaf of bread, and threw it at his face, without any reverence or re≈øpect of the ≈øaid Generall Sig. Giordano. That being done, the ≈øaid Generall ro≈øe from the table, and took him by the bo≈øome, and gave him five ≈øtocadoes in the brea≈øt, the which pierced within the bodie, and there he fell for dead: that being done, the ≈øaid Generall repented him≈øelf of his ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and pre≈øently ≈øent for me being in the Gallie of Don Gracia to come and dre≈ø≈øe him, and ≈øo my Generall cau≈øed me to doe with all diligence, and when I came, this poor Captain lay as though he had been dying, neverthele≈ø≈øe I dre≈ø≈øed him with great diligence, and that Medicines which I u≈øed were the≈øe: Fir≈øt, I put into the wounds, of our Qiunte≈ø≈øence, and upon the wound I dre≈ø≈øed it with our Balm artificiall, and gave him a vomit, the which cau≈øed him to ca≈øt great quantitie of bloud, and then every morning I gave him half an ounce of our Aqua Bal≈øami, and thus within two days after we arrived at Palermo, the Captain was perfectly whole, to the great marvell of a number. After that we departed from Palermo, and went to the Citie of Trapano, where the re≈øt of the gallies were, and there continued four dayes, and then on Saint Johns even, we went to an I≈øland called Fanignana, and there kept the fea≈øt of Saint John, and then we departed with all the army, and went on the ≈øide of Africa, and on Saint Peters day we landed in the Gardens of that Citie, and there began to offer battell, and there remaining about 24. or 25. dayes, the army began to be infected with a certain kind of flux, whereof a great number dyed every day. My Generall ≈øeeing that called me, and asked if it were po≈ø≈øible to find ≈øome remedie for that flux, unto the which I an≈øwered willingly, and ≈øaid, I would devi≈øe by the help of God ≈øome remedie, becau≈øe it was my dutie, to labour for the health of
the Souldiers of the Emperour, the which thing I did in ≈øhort time thorow the whole camp; as I will write hereafter in the next chapter.

div.head: The cure of the Flux, wherewith I helped the Armie of the Emperour in Africa.
div.p: BEing as I have ≈øaid before in the camp, where they were marvellou≈øly tormented with a Flux, and many died thereof, and could find no help, although they had Medicines. Than I which had the experience in hand, began to laugh to my ≈øelf, and the remedie wherewith I helped them all, was this. Fir≈øt, I cau≈øed them to eat well, and then in the morning I gave them a vomit, and then every day after they had eaten, I cau≈øed them to go into the water of the Sea, and there to reremain four or five houres, and ≈øo doing within four or five daies they were helped, for I ≈øwear as I am a Knight, that if I had not been there, the whole Armie had died of that Flux, for of fourteen or fifteen thou≈øand that were there, there was not left two thou≈øand but they were infected with that Flux, or di≈øtemperance of the Liver cau≈øed of ≈øuperfluous heat, the which heat di≈øtempereth the Stomack, and cau≈øeth the continuall Flux; you ≈øhall under≈øtand that our vomit doth evacuate the ≈øtomack of the putrefied humour, and the ≈øalt-water cooleth the heat, and re≈øtraineth the Flux, ≈øo that by the≈øe meanes they were helped.

div.head: A goodly Remedy found out by me for Wound in the head.
div.p:
VVOunds in the head were very perillous in that place, ≈øo that if a hundered were hurt in the head, it was not po≈ø≈øible to recover ten, and that came through two things, the which were much contrary in that Region, for the day was ≈øo hot that it burned all things, and the night to the contrary ≈øo extream cold, that it was intolerable, and not to be credited, and ≈øo by this di≈øtemperance, when the Craneum was uncovered that the aire might touch it, pre≈øently they died without any help, then I ≈øeeing that, began to con≈øider of the
matter, de≈øiring to find ≈øome mean to help them, and ≈øo ≈øtudying, it came in my memorie, that the air was cau≈øe of their death, as it was in truth. Then pre≈øently I commanded all tho≈øe Chirurgians that were under my jurisdiction that they ≈øhould not meddle with any wound in the head without my pre≈øence, the which thing was done, and as many as were wounded, the fir≈øt thing that I did, in ≈øtead of cutting or launcing or di≈øcovering, according to the common order, I joyned the parts, and ≈øowed them clo≈øe, and dre≈ø≈øed them upon the wound with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and with Bal≈øamo, and Magno liquore, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time the mo≈øt part were helped, and there died none ≈øo de≈øperate as they did before, and therefore to my judgement, this was a good invention, and never u≈øed of any before, and this order of curing is very naturall, for Nature doth ≈øhew it in hearbs, plants and ≈øtones, how that they cannot ≈øtand di≈ø-united, then much more our fle≈øh cannot ≈øtand di≈ø-united, without great torment of the Patient, for untill it be joyned together again, it is unpo≈ø≈øible to be helped, then ≈øeeing that is true, it is mo≈øt naturall for the wound to be joyned together, and to u≈øe tho≈øe Medicines, that where they be applyed, will not ≈øuffer the humour to come thereunto, nor putrifie the place that is hurt, and ≈øeeing it is ≈øo, as by experience is ≈øeen, we mu≈øt beleeve this to be a naturall and mo≈øt whol≈øome remedie, ≈øo that I affirm that the joyning of the parts of the wound in the head, and other parts of the body is mo≈øt ≈øoveraign, and of great ≈øatisfaction to the ≈øick, for they never felt pain, nor have no Fever, nor other ≈øort of accident, for of tho≈øe I have cured a great number with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The cure of one that had his no≈øe cut off, and ≈øet on again.
div.p: IN that time when I was in Africa, there happened a ≈øtrange and that was thus.

A certain Gentleman a Spaniard that was called Il Seignior Andreas Gutiero, of the age of twentie nine yeares, upon a time walked in the field, and fell at words with a Souldier, and
began to draw, the Souldier ≈øeeing that, ≈øtruck him with the left hand, and cut of his no≈øe, and there it fell down in the ≈øand, then I happened to ≈øtand by and took it up, and pi≈ø≈øed thereon to wa≈øh away the ≈øand, and ≈øtitched it on again very clo≈øe, and dre≈ø≈øed it with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and bound ‚Ä¢ t up, and ≈øo let it remain eight dayes, thinking that it would have come to matter: neverthele≈ø≈øe, when I did unbind it. I found it fa≈øt conglutinated, and then I dre≈ø≈øed it onely once more, and he was perfectly whole, ≈øo that all Naples did marvell the real, as is well known, for the ≈øaid Sig. Andrea doth live yet, and can te≈øtifie the ≈øame.

div.head: The cure of an arme of S. Giordano Ur≈øino.
div.p: AT the ≈øame time the ≈øaid Sig. Giordano ∆≤r≈øino, and Si. Antamo Savello Romano, and Sig. A≈øtor Baglione, with divers others, took their Hor≈øes and rid about two miles from the Camp, and there perceived certain Mores on hor≈øeback, the which did a≈ø≈øault the≈øe Gentlemen, and one More with his Launce did thru≈øt through the arme from the elbow through the ≈øhoulder, then the ≈øaid Sig. Giordino returned to the Camp with great pain, and pre≈øently I was ≈øent for, and when I had ≈øeen it, I put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and upon the Wound I ≈øaid our Bal≈øamo, and Magno liquere, and bound it ≈øtreight, and ≈øo left it, and in five dayes it was whole and ≈øound, and then went to the a≈ø≈øault mo≈øt valiantly, as many can te≈øtifie, becau≈øe he was generall of Firenze.

div.head: A great chance that happened in the a≈ø≈øault in Africa.
div.p:
AT the ≈øame time there was a Gentleman Florentine, that was with the ≈øaid Si. Giordano ∆≤r≈øino, that was called Millematti, the which fought with his Sword and Target, and defended many ≈øhot of Calivers, and ≈øuch like, at the la≈øt one peirced his Target, and ≈øtruck him upon the brea≈øt, and brui≈øed him marvellou≈øly, and yet broke no skin, and therewithall he fell to the ground for dead, and the carrier of dead men, or Becamort, as they call them, would have buried him in a
Myne, I then being pre≈øent, cau≈øed him to be brought into the Tent of Sig. A≈øtor Baglione, and there I put our Quinte≈ø≈øence into his mouth, and that cau≈øed the blood to liquifie and come forth at the mouth, and laid upon his ≈øtomack a plai≈øter of A≈øhes and Oil as hot as he could abide, and that I changed morning and evening, and alwayes I gave him of our Quinte≈ø≈øence to drink, ≈øo that in ≈øhort time he was helped, and yet liveth in health: and this was one of the mo≈øt ≈øtrange≈øt things that ever I ≈øaw, that a pellet of a Caliver could not break the fle≈øh, and that came by certain words that the ≈øaid Millematti did carry written upon his brea≈øt, as he per≈øwaded me afterward, for he ≈øaid, In verbis, & in herbis, & in lapidibus ≈øunt virtutes, &c.

div.head: The cure of Wounds being poy≈øoned, and of ther Sores.
div.p:
VVHile that warres dured in Africa, many times the Chir≈øtians were poy≈øoned with venomous Arrows and ≈øuch like, for the Moores commonly when they fight again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, they ≈øtick the heads of their Arrows in a Squill, and poy≈øon it with the juyce, and when tho≈øe Arrow heads or other weapon goeth into the fle≈øh of a man, it cau≈øeth ≈øo great burning, that it bringeth Spa≈ømus, and ≈øo in ≈øhort time they dye. And untill this time there hath been no other Medicine found, but to cut away all the fle≈øh that the weapon hath touched, or el≈øe to cauterize it two or three times with a red hot Iron to extingui≈øh the venome, but I, through the grace of God, have found the true and perfect way to help them quickly, and with great ea≈øe, and without detriment of the wounded, and the remedy is this; yee ≈øhall put our Quinte≈ø≈øence into the Wound, and lay thereon our Magno liquore, the which are two Medicines that kill the poy≈øon of the Squill, and therefore if any will prove this to be true, to ≈øee the experience, take a peice of a Squilla, and ≈øcratch it with thy nail, and then put thy finger into thy ear, or ≈øcratch any other place that yee may touch the fle≈øh, and pre≈øently thou ≈øhalt feel a terrible burning, and to quench it, pre≈øently take of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and wa≈øh the place
therewith, and pre≈øently the pain will cea≈øe, and therefore u≈øe this as a ≈øecret, for therewith I have cured a great number.

div.head: A remedy found out by me again≈øt the poy≈øon of a Fi≈øh.
div.p: VVHen that I cau≈øed ≈øo many ≈øick of the Flux to goe into the ≈øea, whereby they were helped, there was a certain kind of fi≈øh, that as ≈øoon as they touched the fle≈øh of a man, pre≈øently it inflamed, and the poy≈øon ≈øo increa≈øed, that in two or three dayes it cau≈øed corro≈øive Sores, the which cau≈øed many to dye, and many were ≈øtung with that fi≈øh which never could find help: I then ≈øeeing that de≈øperate ca≈øe, upon a time vi≈øited a young man being a Romane, the which was hurt on the Codds and Yeard with ≈øuch a Spa≈ømus, that it was wonderfull to behold, and having a gla≈ø≈øe full of my Quinte≈ø≈øence in my hand, I opened the ≈øore and wa≈øhed it therewith, and pre≈øently the pain cea≈øed, then afterward I dre≈ø≈øed it with an Unguent made of the fat of the fi≈øh, and ≈øo therewith he and a great number more were helped in ≈øhort time, and the≈øe are ≈øecrets of my invention.

div.head: Of the taking of Africa and his de≈øtruction
div.p: IN the year 1551. the eleventh of September about the nineteenth hour the generall a≈ø≈øault was given to the City of Africa, and in the ≈øpace of two hours it was taken, and de≈øtroyed by the ≈øouldiers of Carolus Quintus Emperour, whereat was ≈ølain a great number of both parts, and there was ≈øuch a number hurt, that it was to be wondered at, the which were healed with our Magno liquore, and Bal≈øamo, and when the City was taken and all ended, the Gallies remained there all September, and the fourth of October every man went to ≈øerve at their ports appointed, and ≈øo we returned to Naples to pa≈ø≈øe the winter, but yet we remained but a while, for there was occa≈øion to goe to Siena, the which rebelled again≈øt the Emperour, and ≈øo we went with Don Pietro da Toledo the which died after at Firenza, &c.

div.head: The cure of a great wound on the head.
div.p: IN this yeare 1551. in the moneth of November, there came unto my hou≈øe a Spaniard, the which was called Giovan Ruiz di Zamora, the which had a great wound over the eare, on the left ≈øide that reached halfe over the head, with great fracture of the bone, the which I pre≈øently ≈øtitched with diligence, and put therein our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and upon the wound I dre≈ø≈øed it with Magno liquore, and Bal≈øamo, and made a gentle ligature with a piece of ≈øilke, and ≈øent him home to his lodging, and commanded him to come againe the next day about the ≈øaid houre, and tho≈øe that were about me, fell a laughing at my words, and ≈øaid that he would die of that wound, becau≈øe I let him goe forth in the ayr, to the which I an≈øwered that he might ≈øafely goe forth, and ≈øo the next day he came againe, and I took off the ligament, but not the cloth, and thereon I put of our Quinte≈ø≈øence and Balme, and ≈øo in three dayes I touched it not, and then I took off the Ligament againe, and dre≈ø≈øed it upon the cloath, and let it remaine untill the 8. day, and then I opened it, and took away the cloath, and found the wound ≈øo healed that yee could ≈øcarce perceive any ≈øcarre, and many ≈øaid that it was impo≈ø≈øible to be healed, for it would come to impo≈øthumation, neverthele≈ø≈øe it remained perfectly whole for five or ≈øix moneths that he remained in that Citie, in the which time I cured a great number in the ≈øame order that were wounded in the head, to the great wonder of tho≈øe that dwelt in Naples, for they count all wounds in the head to be mortall, becau≈øe the ayre is ≈øo pe≈øtilentiall-, for as ≈øoone as it toucheth the ≈øcull it corrupteth the wound.
But u≈øing our order thou maye≈øt ≈øafely helpe them, ≈øo that the wound be not mortall, for by keeping it clo≈øe ≈øhut it is pre≈øerved.

div.head: A very ≈øtrange thing that happened in the afore≈øaid year.
div.p:
THere was a certaine young Marriner of the age of 26‚ñ™ years, the which was called, Franci≈øco di Giovanni Ragu≈øeo, of the
I≈øle of Mezo, the which being in fight fell downe, and the other that fought with him out him over the ≈øide and backe a handfull long, in ≈øo much that a piece of the Milt was cut overthwart, then he was carried to a Chyrurgian, and he ≈øtitched him up, then the next day I was called, and there I found the Wound not well ≈øtitched, the which I ripped up againe, and found the belly full of blood, and when I ≈øaw that, I cau≈øed divers to make water, and therewith I wa≈øhed him, and with taking forth of the blood, there came a piece of the Milt that was cut, the which I wa≈øhed, and gave it to a Marriner that ≈øtood by, and the Patron of the ≈øhip tooke it from him and carried it away, then I ≈øtitched him up againe and left a little hole or orifice beneath, where the matter might come forth, and dre≈ø≈øed him with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, with Bal≈øamo, and Magno liquore, and in the ≈øpace of 22. dayes he was whole perfectly.

div.head: The cure of a Fi≈øtula in the lower parts.
div.p: IN the yeare, 1552. in the moneth of March, I was brought unto a man of the age of fourtie years, of complexion cholerick and melancholly, the which had a Fi≈øtula in the lower parts, the which was of this Nature, that it had alterated the cods, the member, and all the parts thereabout, with eleven holes infi≈øtulated, at the which holes he made water with great burning, and intolerable paine, and which are accidents of a Fever in manner continuall, the which Patient had beene taken in hand of divers, and none could doe him plea≈øure. Then the fir≈øt thing that I did, I gave him our Aromatico, that being done, I gave him xii. dayes together our Quinte≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutivo, that being done, I gave him a quantity of our Electuario Angelica, and then he u≈øed one of my ≈øecrets, the which I will not write in this place, that being done I cau≈øed him to ≈øpit with one of my confections, written hereafter, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes he was perfectly whole.

div.head: Of many that I cured in Naples.
div.p: IN that time that I remained in the famous Citie of Naples, untill the year 1555. in the Moneth of February, and then I thought it good to go to Rome, vvhere at this time I cured a number of per≈øons, and have helped ≈øo many by the help of God, vvhich if I ≈øhould record them, it vvould be ≈øufficient to fill a great volume, for there came ≈øuch a number to my door, that the people wondered thereat, and with four Medicines compounded by me, I helped in manner all of every di≈øea≈øe, and the Medicines were the≈øe, one Pill made with our Petra philo≈øophale, Elbero negro, Olio di ≈øulpho, Olio di melle, mixed with Marchpane, and made in Pils. The ≈øecond Remedy was ≈øoluble Pils, made with Aloe hepatico, Colloquintida, Siena, and oyle of vitrioll made in pa≈ø ‚Ä¢ e with ≈øugar, and common honey. The third Remedy was an unction, made with Sage, Ro≈øemary, Wormewood, R ‚Ä¢ w, Mint, Nutmegs, Cloves, Cinamon, Ma≈øtick, Trankincen≈øe, Turpentine and wax with common oyle. The fourth Remedy was our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and the≈øe four Remedies, I gave unto tho≈øe people to helpe their griefes: and I willed them that tooke the≈øe Medicines to eat well, and of good meats, and ≈øo alwayes they pray≈øed the≈øe Medicines, the which was not without great rea≈øon, becau≈øe the Pills fir≈øt evacuate the ≈øtomack of all Impediments, and leaveth nature ea≈øed, the ≈øecond Pills evacuate the body of the corruption.

The unction comforteth the ≈øtomack, and helpeth dige≈øtion, and mitigateth the paine. The Quinte≈ø≈øence comforteth the ≈øtomack, cau≈øeth good dige≈øtion, purifieth the bloud, and comforteth the head, ≈øo that by the≈øe afore≈øaid Rea≈øons, ye may under≈øtand that the≈øe foure Remedies may helpe again≈øt all indi≈øpo≈øitions inwardly, and for cau≈øe of tho≈øe Remedies tho≈øe people honour me like a Prophet, and alwayes have had me in great Reverence, as long as I remayned among them.

div.head: A cure of Ulcera putrida which was in the arm.
div.p:
IN the year afore≈øaid, and in the moneth of Augu≈øt, there came to my hand a certain Gentleman of the Emba≈ø≈øadors of Portingall, that was called Il ≈øignior Jari, a man of the age of two and thirtie yeares, of complexion melancholie, the which had a putrified Ulcer about the left ≈øhoulder, that he had carried above three yeares, and was as big as a hand, and very deep, which could not be healed of the common Chirurgians, nor yet be ea≈øed of his pain, then I rea≈øoning with this Gentleman, told him that the cau≈øe of that ≈øore, was corrupt and putrified bloud, and by that meanes the Liver received evill qualities, and that if he would be helped, the cau≈øe mu≈øt be removed, the which was hard to be done, becau≈øe the bloud mu≈øt be evacuated a little, and then the ≈øtomack mu≈øt be evacuated of moi≈øt matter that offendeth it, and hindereth dige≈øtion of the meat, and will not ≈øuffer good bloud to ingender; then will it al≈øo be nece≈ø≈øary to evacuate the body downwards, that the corruption ≈øend not up his vapours unto the upper parts of the body, and hinder the cure of the Ulcer, all this being done, it were nece≈ø≈øary to evacuate the humour between the skin and the fle≈øh by ≈øweat, ≈øo that all the parts of the body may remain purified, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes the Ulcer may ea≈øily mundifie, incarnate, and ≈øiccatrize, and ≈øhall be a perfect cure: to the which thing the Gentleman was willing, for he had as willingly dyed as lived, and ≈øo in the name of God I took him in hand, and the fir≈øt thing that I gave him was a vomit that purged the ≈øtomack, and took away great part of his pain: then I purged him with our Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutivo eight daies together, that being done, I made him a Fomentation that cau≈øed him to ≈øweat well, and to ≈øpit abundance, then I cau≈øed him to be let bloud under the tongue, and then I annointed all the Ulcer with our Cau≈øtick, the which mortified all the filthine≈ø≈øe therein, and then I dre≈ø≈øed it with Magno liquore, and our Cerot Magi≈øtrale, and ≈øo with the≈øe Remedies in ≈øhort ≈øpace the ≈øaid Gentleman was cured, to the great marvell of
the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øadour, and all tho≈øe that ≈øaw it: By rea≈øon of that cure came another of the ≈øame hou≈øe unto me, called Il Seignor diego Iaimes, the which was troubled with a difficulty of Vrine, which did trouble him mightily, to whom I gave three times our Petra Philo≈øophale, and once the juyce of Elder Barks, and he was helped: I cured another in the ≈øame hou≈øe of a Fever with our Oyle of Honey, and with Bal≈øamo: The Amba≈ø≈øadour likewi≈øe being troubled with the Gout, willed me to take him in hand, the which I did, and cured him, ≈øo that in three years after while I continued in Rome he never felt paine, and of the≈øe cures I helped an infinite in Spaine, as is well known to the Inhabitants thereof.

div.head: The cure of Ethe≈øia in the beginning.
div.p: IN the yeare 1555. in the Moneth of March, there came to my hands a young man of Millayne, the which was a Painter, of the age of five and twenty years, the which was fallen into a ≈øpice of Eti≈øie, and did ≈øpit much bloud with a continuall Fever, whom I cured in this order.

Fir≈øt, I let him bloud under the tongue on the right ≈øide, and after that I gave him a quantity of our Aromatico with Plantaine water, becau≈øe the bleeding taketh away the ≈øuperfluous bloud of the brea≈øt, which nature ≈øendeth forth by it ≈øelfe, and the Aromatico with Plantaine water is cold and dry, which are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for that di≈øea≈øe, for they evacuate the ≈øtomack, repercute and mitigateth the alteration, tho≈øe things being done, I cau≈øed him to u≈øe our Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive to evacuate the body in re≈øpect of the Putrefication already conceived within the inte≈øtinals, al≈øo I cau≈øed him to u≈øe the Quinte≈ø≈øence of the Flower of Flowers, and I annointed his ≈øtomack with Magno liquore, and al≈øo he u≈øed our Electuarie of Althea, and ≈øo by the≈øe meanes he was helped perfectly.

div.head: The cure of a certaine man wounded in thirteen places.
div.p:
IT happened that a certaine man called Ale≈ø≈øandro Orefice, was wounded before my lodging in thirteen places, and there fell
for dead, and then by a certaine friend was brought into my Lodging, and there I laid him upon a Table, and took off his clothes, and ≈øowed all tho≈øe wounds which were to be ≈øowed or ≈øtitched, and dre≈ø≈øed him with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and Bal≈øamo, and Magno liquore, and our ≈øecret Powder, and ≈øo by tho≈øe meanes in 15. dayes he was perfectly whole.

div.head: Of Remedies that helpe many di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: THere are divers and ≈øundry di≈øea≈øes, and they be helped with divers and ≈øundry Medicines; therefore I will make a note onely of tho≈øe which are mo≈øt u≈øed.

And fir≈øt I will write of tho≈øe Remedies that help the Fevers of all ≈øorts, which are the≈øe, the Sirrup of Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Endive, Cicory, Hops, Fumitorie, Rhabarb, Ca≈ø≈øia, Scamony, Sine, Barly-water, Sirrup of Scytrones, and ≈øuch like.

The Remedies that helpe the Pox are the≈øe, Aloes, Coloquintida, Turbit, Hermodactils, Scamony, Precipitate, Oriola, Olivella, the Unction of Mercury, Lignum ≈øanctum, Cina, Sal≈øa perilla, the perfume of Sinaber, a ≈øtove of hearbs, our Ceroto Magi≈øtrale, and ≈øuch like things. Tho≈øe Remedies that helpe the Cough, are Enula Campana, Garlike, Sulphur, Honey, Lapaciolle, the Oyle of Sulphur, and ≈øuch liket: Tho≈øe Remedies that help the Scabs, are the juyce of Aureola, Sulphur, Litarge, Aqua Reale, Roch Allome, tho≈øe that are troubled with paines in the body, may u≈øe Genciane, Nutmegs, Dictamus albus, Euphorbio: tho≈øe that are wounded ≈øhall u≈øe Turpentine, our Bal≈øamo, Magno liquore, Aqua Bal≈øami, Elixar vitae, Ceroto Magi≈øtrale, Oyle of Hipericon, of our invention, and ≈øuch like. Tho≈øe that provoke vrine, are the flours of Mallows, Alkekengi, Hogs life, Cantharides, and ≈øuch like, and therefore I will not trouble you further, becau≈øe I have written ≈øufficiently in my other Books in ≈øundry places, and hereafter I will write of divers; and ≈øundry Medicines of our invention never found out before of any man.

div.head: Here beginneth the order to make divers and ≈øundry Medicines of our invention never found out before by any man. And fir≈øt to make our Petra Philo≈øophale, that helpeth again≈øt all manner of di≈øea≈øes that happeneth unto man, or woman, or any other Animall terre≈øtriall.
div.p: THere hath alwayes been a great que≈øtioning among the Philo≈øophers, whether that one Medicine might help again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes or no. The which I affirm, and will approve with ≈øufficient rea≈øon, that the Petra Philo≈øophale made of our invention may help again≈øt all the infirmities that cometh unto mans body, and two onely rea≈øons I will ≈øhew thee with brevity, the fir≈øt of them is this, that all ≈øorts of infirmities have their Originall and beginning of the ≈øtomack, and to know the truth, yee may ≈øee manife≈øtly, that if the body be never ≈øo little infirmed, the ≈øtomack is al≈øo greived: For yee may ≈øee how the Animals terre≈øtriall never help them≈øelves of other infirmity then of the ≈øtomack, and when they will help them≈øelves, they eat hearbs, the which cau≈øeth them to vomit, and this doth ≈øignifie, that they have no other infirmity then the afore≈øaid, ≈øo by the experience of the Animals I approve that the infirmity is cau≈øed of the ≈øtomack, and this is the fir≈øt rea≈øon. The ≈øecond is, that all the Medicines, wherein our Petra Philo≈øophale is put, as ≈øoon as they are come into the ≈øtomack, it draweth unto it all the evill humours of the ≈øtomack, and al≈øo of the whole body, and mixeth with them, and ≈øo natrue ≈øendeth them forth by vomit, or by ≈øeege, or both, and ≈øo the ≈øtomack ≈øhall be evacuated of that matter, and the body remain free from all impediments of infirmities, ≈øo that by this rea≈øon I affirm, that our Petra Philo≈øophale may help again≈øt all ≈øorts of infirmities, and to know the truth, I have proved it by experience in all manner of infirmities, and alwayes have found it to doe much good unto all men, and hurt none unto my knowledge, and the order to make this Petra Philo≈øophale is thus.
‚Ñû. Sal niter, Roch Allum, Vitrioll Romain, of each two pound.

Fir≈øt, dry the Vitrioll in an earthen pan, and then beat it to powder, and mix it with the other matters, and put thereunto foure ounces of Sal gemma, then put it in a goord with his head, and a Receiver well luted, and di≈øtill it in a wind Furnace, ≈øo that yee may make fire with wood, and at the fir≈øt make ≈ømall fire, and ≈øo increa≈øe it according to Art, and alwayes lay wet clothes an the head and Receiver, and that thou ≈øhalt doe, becau≈øe the ≈øpirits of the water ≈øhall not flye away. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that in the beginning of your di≈øtillation, the Receiver will wax red like bloud, and then turn white; and at the la≈øt, when yee give it ≈øtrong fire, it will turn red again, and tho≈øe are the pure ≈øpirits of the Aqua fortis, and then at the end, the Receiver will turne white againe, and then it is ended, then let it wax cold, and then keep it in a Gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut to make our Petra Philo≈øophale.
Then take Mercury, lib. 1. Quick-lyme, ‚Ñ•. vj. Sope, ‚Ñ•. iiij. Common a≈øhes, ‚Ñ•. iij.

Mix them together in a Morter of ≈øtone, and then put them into a Retort, and di≈øtill it with a ≈øtrong fire untill all the Mercury be come forth into the Receiver, then take it forth, and keepe it in a Gla≈ø≈øe, to make thy compo≈øition, the which is made thus.

‚Ñû. The water that thou made≈øt fir≈øt, and put it into a goord of Gla≈ø≈øe being well luted, and then put in thy Mercury that thou didde≈øt di≈øtill before. After that, take Steel in thinne Plates, j. ‚Ñ•. Iron al≈øo in thinne Plates, ‚Ñ•. ii. Fine Gold in leaves, the weight of two French Crownes, and put them altogether in the Gla≈ø≈øe, and pre≈øently ≈øet on the head, for it will begin to boyle, and cau≈øe red fumes like bloud, the which thou ≈øhalt receive in a Receiver, and pre≈øently ≈øet thy Gla≈ø≈øe in the Furnace, and give it fire untill all the water be come forth with the fume. Then let it coole, and keep that water clo≈øe in a Gla≈ø≈øe, then break the other Gla≈ø≈øe that ≈øtood in the fire, and in the bottome thou ≈øhalt find our Petra Philo≈øophale, the which thou ≈øhalt grind finely, and ≈øearce it into mo≈øt fine powder, and then wa≈øh it well with Vinegar di≈øtilled, and dry it againe, and at the la≈øt wa≈øh it with Ro≈øe-water, and dry it very well, ≈øtirring it continually over the fire, then
keep it as a precious Jewell clo≈øe in a Gla≈ø≈øe.

For the order to u≈øe it, I will write hereafter, in ≈øundry places: Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand that the water which yee di≈øtilled away from the ≈øtone, will ≈øerve for the ≈øame purpo≈øe again: But ye mu≈øt take but halfe the quantity of the afore≈øaid matters, and when ye have di≈øtilled it again from the ≈øtone, yee ≈øhall pre≈øerve it for an infinite number of purpo≈øes, as I will ≈øhew thee hereafter.

div.head: To make our Balme artificiall, with the order to u≈øe it, and wherefore it ≈øerveth.
div.p: THis Bal≈øamum hath all the vertues of the natural Balme, although not in quality, yet in vertue, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Venice Turpentine, pound 1. Oyle of Bayes, that is perfect without mixture, ‚Ñ•. iiij. Galbanum, ounces iij. Gum Arabie, ounc. iiij. Olibanum Mirrha elect, Gum Hederae, of each, ‚Ñ•. iij. Lignum Aloes, Galingal, Cloves, Con≈øolida minore, Cinamon, Nutmegs, Zedoaria, Ginger, Diptamnum album, of each, ounce 1. Muske of Levant, Ambergriece of each one Drachme. Beat all tho≈øe afore≈øaid things together, and put them into a Retort of Gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and put thereto vj. pound of Rectified Aqua vitae without fleame, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand viiij. dayes, and then di≈øtill it by ≈øand, and there will come forth a white water mixed with Oyle, and ≈øo keep thy fire ≈ømall, untill there come forth a blacki≈øh Oyle, then change thy Receiver, and ≈øet thereto another, and increa≈øe thy fire untill all the ≈øpirits bee come forth, then ≈øeparate the Oyle from the black water, and keep them by them≈øelves and the like ≈øhall yee doe by the fir≈øt water. The fir≈øt vvater that is white, is called Aqua del Bal≈øamo, and the Oyle ≈øeparated from that is called Oleum del Bal≈øamo. The ≈øecond vvater that is black is called Mater Bal≈øami, and the Oyle ≈øeparated from that vvater, is called Bal≈øamo artificiato, which would be kept as a precious Jewel.

The fir≈øt Water is mo≈øt excellent to clear and pre≈øerve the ≈øight of the eyes, al≈øo if the face being wa≈øhed therewith, it maketh
it very faire, and pre≈øerveth it youthfully, it keepeth back age, it breaketh the gravell in the reines; and it provoketh Vrine, the which is ≈øtopped thorow carno≈øity; it helpeth all manner of Wounds, in what place of the body ≈øoever they be, if yee wa≈øh them with the ≈øaid vvater, and wet therein clouts, and lay thereon, for his operation is ≈øo ≈øtrange, that it ≈øeemeth rather divine then humane. It helpeth much again≈øt the Eti≈øie, and again≈øt all ≈øorts of of Catarres, and Cough. If ye wa≈øh a Sciatica therewith, and lay thereon a cloath wet in the ≈øame, it taketh away the paine pre≈øently.

The other water called the Mother of Balme, helpeth ≈øcalls in ≈øhort time if ye wa≈øh them therewith; ≈øo doth it helpe the white ≈øcall, Lepra, and all ≈øorts of Ulcers that are not corro≈øive mo≈øt miraculous to ≈øee, and without any trouble; it ≈øerveth al≈øo again≈øt a number of other infirmities, the which I will let pa≈ø≈øe at this time.

The Oyle of Balme, doth ≈øerve for an infinite number of things, and e≈øpecially for Wounds in the head, where the bone and pannicle is hurt, putting it therein. It pre≈øerveth the face if yee annoint it therewith. It is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt the Pluri≈øie, giving thereof j. í at a time with the water of Balm

The Balme artificiall is a mo≈øt miraculous Liquor, if any have the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and take two drachms thereof, it pre≈øently will helpe him. It is al≈øo good again≈øt the Cough, and Cattare, coldne≈ø≈øe in the head and ≈øtomack, and for Wounds in the head. It is a mo≈øt ≈øoveraign Remedy, if yee annoint all the head therewith once a day; becau≈øe it pierceth into the brains, and al≈øo unto the ≈øtomack beneath. It re≈øolveth all tumours in all parts of the body with ≈øpeed. It re≈øolveth a Quartaine in ≈øhort time, if yee annoint all the body therewith, leaving no part.

And to be ≈øhort, I know no di≈øea≈øe neither hot nor yet cold, but that this Bal≈øamum doth good unto, as well the hot di≈øea≈øes as the cold, becau≈øe it cooleth the hot, and heateth the cold, and this it doth by his quality and hidden vertue, ≈øo that I have found in this precious Liquor ≈øuch great vertues, that I am not able to declare them all; ≈øo that every one which is furni≈øhed with this precious Balme, may be kept from
infirmities, and ≈øhall not need to ≈øeek the naturall Balm with ≈øo much expen≈øes and danger of the life, as hath been many times ≈øeen.

div.head: To make our Aromatico, the which helpeth again≈øt all manner of infirmities, of what quality ≈øoever they be.
div.p: ARomatico Leonardo, is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it was compounded and made by his invention, and is a miraculous Medicine, that ≈øerveth again≈øt all manner of di≈øea≈øes of what quality ≈øoever they be, for it worketh this operation, that is, as ≈øoon as it joyneth to the ≈øtomack, it draweth to it all the evill humours of the body, and imbraceth them, and carrieth them forth of the body both by vomit and ≈øeege, and ≈øo leaveth nature unburthened, the which may prevail to his plea≈øure, becau≈øe it hath no impediment, and by this rea≈øon I approve, that our Aromatico helpeth again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes, as is ≈øaid before, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Fine white Sugar ‚Ñ•. iv. pure Pearles, Musk, Saffron, Lignum Alloes, Cinnamon, ana. ‚Ñà. i. Petra Philo≈øophale í. iv. Mix them together, and make thereof Lozanges with Ro≈øe-water according to art, the which yee ≈øhall keep in a box of wood clo≈øe ≈øhut, and the order to u≈øe it is thus, when the Phy≈øitian doth goe to vi≈øit any ≈øick per≈øon, and that he will prepare him ≈øome Medicine to take inward, the be≈øt and mo≈øt perfecte≈øt Medicine that he can ordain is our Aromatico, becau≈øe it evacuateth the ≈øtomack by vomit, and the body downward, and his operation is ≈øuch, that it doth in manner helpe any crude ≈øort of infirmity, and the quantity is from one drachm to two drachms, and may be taken in broth, in wine, in water, or mix it with any pills, or potion, giving you charge, that when yee put it in any potion, that yee leave none in the bottome of the cup where yee drink it out, becau≈øe the Petra Philo≈øophale is heavy, and will remain in the bottome, for if that remain, it will not work at all, giving you al≈øo charge, that the ≈øaid day that yee give this Medicine, that yee let the Patients drink as much crude water as they will, and give them
little meat to eat that day, and this is the order to u≈øe this Medicine.

div.head: To make our Electuario Angelico, and the order to u≈øe it, and in what di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: ELectuario Angelico Romano, is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it was compounded by me in the City of Rome, in the time of Pope Paulo quarto, and becau≈øe this Compo≈øition worketh ≈øuddenly, I called it Angelico, and is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt many di≈øea≈øes, it is good again≈øt all ≈øorts of Fevers, giving it Perminorativo, and for the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide it is mo≈øt rare, becau≈øe it taketh away the vi≈øco≈øity in the ≈øtomack, and openeth the pores, and is good again≈øt the Gout, for if they take it every third day once, in ten dayes they ≈øhall be helped, it is al≈øo good again≈øt the Cough, Catarre, and for the Milt, and for tho≈øe that have the Pox, or the running Gout, and ≈øuch like influences, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Saffron, Lignum Aloes, Cinnamon, red Corrall, ana. í. iii. Elleborus niger without preparation ‚Ñ•. ii. Electuario de ≈øucco ro≈øarum Me≈øue that is not too much boiled ‚Ñ•. vi. Sugar Ro≈øate ‚Ñ•. viii. Musk of Levant í. i. Petra Philo≈øophale ‚Ñ•. iii. our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine ‚Ñ•. ii. purified Hony as much as will ≈øuffice to make it in form of an Electuary, mix them on a ≈ømall fire in an earthen pan, and when it is made, keep it in a ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈ø≈øe, for any other ve≈ø≈øell will not be ≈øo good: This Electuary yee may mix with any ≈øoluble Medicine, but yee mu≈øt take it fa≈øting, the quantity is from two drachms to four drachms. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this in a manner reviveth the dead by his great vertue, as hath been ≈øeen many thou≈øand times in Venice, and in Rome, mo≈øt worthy of memory, and therefore if any Phi≈øitian de≈øire to get fame in the world, let them u≈øe our Electuario Angellico, which worketh miracles on the earth.

div.head: Of the vegetable ≈øtone of our invention, to tran≈øemute a body of one complexion into another, and to make him ≈øound for ever.
div.p: THe way to make the vegetable ≈øtone is rare, and his vertues are infinite, and without compari≈øon, and the cures that are done therewith are ≈øo miraculous, that the world will no ‚Ä¢ beleeve them, although it be the meer truth, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Tartar of white Wine that is thick and ≈øhining, Turpentine that is clear and pure: The hearb called Alloes, that hath leaves as long as an arme, and dented on both ≈øides, and ≈øome call it Semper-vive, take of each of the≈øe one pound, and ≈øtamp them together, and put them into a Urinall with a Head and Receiver, and di≈øtill them in a Wine Furnace untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, then take the Fe≈ø≈øes out of the gla≈ø≈øe, and grind them with the ≈øaid water, and then di≈øtill them as thou didde≈øt before, and alwayes at the la≈øt give it a ≈øtrong fire that the fe≈ø≈øes may remain well burnt, then take out the fe≈ø≈øes again, and grind them with the water as thou didde≈øt fir≈øt, and di≈øtill it again, and this thou ≈øhalt doe fifteen or twenty times, untill all that water be con≈øumed, and the fe≈ø≈øes remain white like ≈øalt, then lay that fe≈ø≈øes on a ≈ømooth ≈øtone in a moi≈øt place, and it will turn into water, the which keep in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, and that is the water of the vegetable ≈øtone, which water is of ≈øo much vertue, that one ≈øcruple thereof being put into two ounces of Julip of Violets, and given to drink to any that is infirmed or evill complexionated, in le≈ø≈øe then four and twenty dayes he ≈øhall be helped of any grievous di≈øea≈øe, and this mu≈øt be taken in the morning fa≈øting, when the ≈øtomack is empty, for then it worketh better his operation.

This is al≈øo an excellent remedy again≈øt the wormes, giving it in the afore≈øaid manner, it mundifieth the Liver, and drieth the humidity of the Milt, it di≈ø≈øolveth the Cough, and Catarres, it provoketh Urine where it is let, with divers other vertues, the which I will let pa≈ø≈øe untill another time, for if I ≈øhould
write them all, they would not be credited, and therefore we Phy≈øitians ≈øhould not re≈øt to practi≈øe in all things that ≈øeemeth to us convenient, and I promi≈øe thee truly, that hee which ≈øhall occupie this thing, ≈øhall work miracles on the earth, and win great fame and honour. Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that this is the ≈øtone that the Philo≈øophers have long ≈øought to fix their Medicine Minerall, ≈øo that making the projection they joyn the Medicine with metalling bodies, and not to goe away in fume, becau≈øe this ≈øtone re≈øi≈øteth all great fires without con≈øuming, and fixeth Sulphur and Orpiment, ≈øo that they ≈øhall abide the fire, and maketh them white: If yee make projection therewith on Copper, or on Lattin, it will turn it into the whitene≈ø≈øe of pure ≈øilver, and that I have ≈øeen with my eyes, ≈øo that yee may ≈øee of what importance this vegitable ≈øtone is, the which worketh ≈øuch goodly tran≈ømutations, as well in mettalling bodies as in humane bodies, and therefore it is to be accounted of, becau≈øe it may ≈øave the life of many that u≈øe it in their Medicines.

div.head: Our ≈øoluble Sirrup, with the order to u≈øe it.
div.p: SOluble Sirrups made in decoction are very whol≈øome, and of great faculty, and e≈øpecially in the crudity of humours, and the rea≈øon is this: becau≈øe it di≈øper≈øeth the matter, and evacuateth it with great ea≈øe, and without danger or trouble of the Patient, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Sage, Ro≈øemary, Wormwood, Cicory, Carduus ≈øanctus, Nettles, Organy, of each a handfull, Figs, Rai≈øins, Dates, ≈øweet Almonds, Sal gem, ana ‚Ñ•. iiii. Coloquintida, Aloes hepatica, Cinnamon, Mirabolani citrini, ana. ‚Ñ•. ii. common Hony two pound.

Stamp them all gro≈øly, and put them to infu≈øe in eighteen pound of fair water, then boil it till half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and di≈øtill it by a filter, and aromati≈øe it with two carets of Musk and a pint of Ro≈øewater, and then it is made, which yee ≈øhall keep in a bottle of gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, the quantity is from four ounces to ≈øix ounces.

In Winter you ≈øhall take it very warme. And in the Spring and Autumne, yee ≈øhall take it but warm. In Summer yee ≈øhall take it cold, for this purgeth the gro≈ø≈øe humours of the body, and hurteth not the ≈øtomack, yee may u≈øe it in a Fever, four or five dayes together, and it will helpe it. In crudity of humours, as the French Pox, Gouts, Catarres, Doglie, Artetica, and ≈øuch like matters, where there is no accident of Fever, yee may take it ten or fifteen dayes together, and cannot hurt by any means, for it purgeth mo≈øt excellently: it is given again≈øt the Cough, again≈øt Flux of the Vrine, and paines in the head, and Carno≈øity in the yeard, or the Hemeroids: And in ≈øumme it is good again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes cau≈øed of corrupt humours; for it hath ≈øuch vertue, that it draweth from all parts, and evacuateth the humours inte≈øtinal, for of this Sirrup I have had great experience, in ≈øuch per≈øons as were in manner bani≈øhed, and had lo≈øt their ta≈øte, and pre≈øently u≈øing this, they came to good temperature; and I have u≈øed it an infinite number of times, in per≈øons that were ulcerated, and full of ≈øores, evill handled of Fortune, and of the infirmity, and finding no means to cure them as they ≈øhould be, I gave them this Sirrup fourteen or fifteen dayes, and then they were cured, with a number of other things, the which would be too long to write; and therefore I would wi≈øh every one to u≈øe this, not onely in the afore≈øaid matters, but in all other di≈øea≈øes.

div.p: THis Sirrup is ≈øolutive, and very plea≈øant to u≈øe, and cannot hurt in any wi≈øe, which is ≈øeldome ≈øeene in other Medicines, and the order to make it is thus.

div.head: Our Potion of Lignum Sanctum, which is miraculous to di≈ø≈øolve crude, and maligne humours, with the order to u≈øe it in the French Pox, and ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: BEcau≈øe the Pox is a di≈øea≈øe contagious, putrefied, and corrupt, and worketh many evill effects, as I have written in my Caprici medicinale; therefore it were nece≈ø≈øary to prepare mo≈øt excellent and rare Remedies to di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øame, which Medicines are infinite.

But in this Chapter I will write one, that purgeth the crude and vi≈øcous humours downwards, and doth a≈ø≈øubtiliate the gro≈ø≈øe humours, and dryeth all ≈øorts of ≈øubtill humours that offend Nature, and ≈øendeth them forth by ≈øweat, it dryeth the melancholly humour, and di≈ø≈øolveth choller, and is mo≈øt whole≈øom for tho≈øe that are troubled with that di≈øea≈øe, becau≈øe it dryeth much and di≈ø≈øolveth the di≈øea≈øe, with many other good effects, as by experience thou maye≈øt ≈øee, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. The barke of Lignum ≈øanctum gro≈øly beaten lb. 1. and lay it to ≈øteep in lb. xiiii. of faire water 24. hours, then boyle it untill foure pounds be con≈øumed, then put thereto Pollipodie of the Oak, two ounces, Cicory one handfull, Aloe Epatike í. iiii. and let them boyle for an houre: Then put thereunto the leaves of Syve, Epitemum, ana, ‚Ñ•. j. Coloquintida, í. vj. Sugar, ≈øeven ounces, then let it boyle till halfe be boyled away; and that there remaine lb. vii. then ≈øtraine it, and put it in a Gla≈ø≈øe with 12. graines of Muske; and keep it very clo≈øe ≈øtopt; and this is the Sirrup which yee ≈øhall take twi≈øe a day, that is morning and evening; then make this drinke following, which ≈øhall be the common drink at all times to your meat.

‚Ñû. One pound of Lignum ≈øanctum, Ra≈øpead, and ≈øteep it in ten pounds of white Wine that is ripe; and let it boyle an houre, then put thereto lb. xv. of faire water, and let it boyle a little more; and then ≈øtraine it, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe bottle, for this is to be u≈øed all the day time; and the order
to u≈øe the≈øe is thus. Fir≈øt, when any feeleth him≈øelfe grieved with the Pox or any ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øe, he mu≈øt keep his bed at the lea≈øt twenty dayes, and u≈øe to take of the fir≈øt Sirrup or Potion every morning a good draught, being as warme as hee may ≈øuffer it, then cover him well with clothes that he may ≈øweat as much as he can; then take off the clothes by little and little, and dry him with warm clothes, and ≈øo let him repo≈øe for two hours, and then let him eat, and his meat mu≈øt be dry, as Bisket, ro≈øt-meat, Ray≈øins of the Sun, Almonds, and ≈øometime a raw egge, and his drink at meals, and all the day be≈øide ≈øhal be the la≈øt made with Wine and Water, then at night give him of the fir≈øt Sirrup as yee did in the morning, and cau≈øe him to ≈øweat; and then dry him; and this order thou ≈øhalt u≈øe twenty dayes together not comming forth of thy Chamber, and by the grace of God thou ≈øhalt be helped of any ≈øuch grievous infirmity; as I have ≈øeen the experience thereof an infinite of times, to my great honour; for it may be occupied in all complexions with ≈øafety, as by the ingredients thou mai≈øt ≈øee.

div.head: A mo≈øt marvellous water and rare, to cau≈øe a man to avoid the gravell in Vrine, and to mundifie the Reines.
div.p: THe gravell in the Reines of the back is cau≈øed, and engendered of great heat, and dryne≈ø≈øe in tho≈øe parts, as thou mai≈øt plainly ≈øee by tho≈øe which are troubled therewith; for their Reines are ≈øo hot that they cannot abide any heavy garment to lye thereon, and they alwayes make their water with great paine and burning: therefore if thou wilt helpe that infirmity, it were nece≈ø≈øary to refrigerate the Reines, and moi≈øten it with good juyce, and take away that burning of the Vrine; and ≈øo in that order the Patient ≈øhall be helped; and this thou mai≈øt doe in ≈øhort time, and with great ea≈øe with this Remedy.

‚Ñû The ≈øeed of ≈ømall Lemonds, the ≈øeed of Oranges, and one pound, Saxifrage, ≈øix pound, Balme, Scolopendria, Pellitory of the wall, Sparagus, Cri≈øoni, I≈øop, Fenel-roots, Par≈øly roots, ana. ‚Ñ•. vi. ≈øtamp them altogether, and make them in forme of a liquid
Unguent with the juyce of Lemons, then di≈øtill it in a common tin Stillitory being luted, untill the matter remain dry, then keep the water in a Gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and when yee will occupy this water, yee mu≈øt fir≈øt purge the body of the crude and vi≈øcous humours, and likewi≈øe evacuate the ≈øtomack of choller and flegm; that being done thou ≈øhalt take every morning and evening ‚Ñ•. vj. warme, and it would be nece≈ø≈øary for tho≈øe that take it, to u≈øe a dyet, and to refrain moi≈øt and cold meats, and u≈øe onely dry things, and ≈øo this water ≈øhall help tho≈øe afore≈øaid griefs; as I have proved divers times.

div.head: To make the water of Lignum Sanctum, mo≈øt whol≈øome again≈øt the Pox with a new order.
div.p: COmmonly they u≈øe to take the water of Lignum Sanctum, again≈øt the Pox; the which ≈øurely is mo≈øt whol≈øome, but it mu≈øt be taken in good order and form, and mu≈øt be made with great di≈øcretion, and not as they u≈øe it now adayes; for they give it ≈øome three or foure times, and never the better, although the wood be ≈øufficient enough to helpe them; and therefore I would wi≈øh every one that will u≈øe this water to take it in ≈øuch order as it ought to be, the which I will ≈øhew thee hereafter.

‚Ñû. Lignum ≈øanctum, Ra≈øped ≈ømall one pound, the bark being beaten ‚Ñ•. iii. infu≈øe them in twelve pound of fair water one night, and the next morning put therein one pound of Hony, the which is put in, becau≈øe it is aperative and warm, and helpeth to provoke ≈øweat, and cau≈øeth it to have a good ta≈øt, then boil it till half be con≈øumed, then put thereto Carduus ≈øanctus ‚Ñ•. iiii. ≈øtrong Wine three pound, then boil it untill a third part be con≈øumed, and then it is made, then ≈øtrain it, and take forth the Carduus ≈øanctus, and put therein twenty pound of fair water, and one pound of Hony, and let it boil untill four pounds be con≈øumed, and ≈øtrain it, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe bottle, for this is the common drink to drink all the day long, and the order to take it is thus: Fir≈øt before yee will take this water, it were nece≈ø≈øary to take our Sirrupo Solutivo ≈øeven or eight dayes, after that take of our Electuario Angelica ‚Ñ•. ≈øs.
that being done, in the name of God take this potion of Lignum ≈øanctum in this order, take in the morning at the appearing of the day ‚Ñ•. viii. very warm as yee may ≈øuffer, and pre≈øently lay
