le≈ø≈øe, and cau≈øe him to ≈øweat, and about the four and twentieth hour give him onely Bisket and Rai≈øins, and the other common drink that was made la≈øt, giving you warning, that yee make this weakening, al≈øo yee ≈øhall take very great bee ‚Ä¢ to one thing, and that is this, if it happen, that at the beginning of this cure there cometh a Fever, or other accident unto the Patient, that in that ≈øign appeareth, and is delivered, it is a certrin ≈øign of health: Al≈øo I will advi≈øe thee of another thing, and that is this, if the Patient cannot ≈øweat, yee ≈øhall annoint him all over div.head: Our vegetable Sirrup, which is miraculous and divine.
div.p: THis Sirrup is one of my ≈øeven ≈øecrets, with which I have done many miracles many times, in divers operations on many infirmities, and have been ≈øo chary of it, that I meant never to ≈øet it forth in my life time, but yet I con≈øidering what great benefit it might be unto the world, I thought good to ≈øet it forth, that every one might be ≈øerved according to his plea≈øure: and the like I will doe of many other ≈øecrets of great importance, which ≈øhall be di≈øper≈øed among my books, and the order to make this Sirrup is thus.

div.head: Electuario benedicto Leonardi, the which purgeth the body without any griefe, and is miraculous in his operation.

div.head: Our magi≈øtrall Electuary of Sulphur, the which ≈øerveth again≈øt divers ≈øorts of infirmities.
div.p: AS the fire hath vertue to heat and dry materiall things, ≈øo hath the Sulphur vertue to warme, and to dry the humidity and coldne≈ø≈øe of our bodies; for I have occupied it divers and ≈øundry times, and alwayes have ≈øeen divers and ≈øundry good effects; but for the better commoditie, and more ea≈øe to u≈øe it, I have compounded this Electuary, the which thou mai≈øt u≈øe with ea≈øe and benefit unto a number, and the order to make it is thus.

div.head: Our Electuario of Con≈øolida majore, that ≈øerveth for many di≈øea≈øes inwardly.
div.p: THis Con≈øolida majore is an hearb ≈øo called, becau≈øe of his effect that it doth in healing of Wounds, and other places of the fle≈øh ≈øeparated; for if yee eat thereof, it will help the Rupture, and all ≈øorts of Wounds penetrating, and Ulcers of the Lungs, it dryeth the Milt, and ≈øuch like effects; but becau≈øe thou maie≈øt u≈øe it more commodious, I have compounded an Electuary, the which is excellent and rare, and is made thus.

div.head: Our Imperiall Electuary for the Mother.
div.p: THis Electuary for the Mother, is by Nature temperate hot, and by his heat provoketh Men≈øtrua, and comforteth the Matrix, and all other weak parts, of what cau≈øes ≈øoever they be; and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Cinamon, elect, ‚Ñ•. j. Nutmegs, Maces, Cloves, Ginger, ana one Drachm, Ca≈ø≈øiae lignae, ≈øix Drachms. Marmalade ‚Ñ•. xij. Lignum aloes iiij. Drachms, red Sanders ij. Drachms, Aqua vitae well rectified ‚Ñ•. iij. fine Muske two Carrets, purified Honey lb. ij. then make thereof an Electuary according to art, which is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt the indi≈øpo≈øition of the Mother: But fir≈øt ere yee begin to take this Medicine, it were nece≈ø≈øary to take a quantity of our Pillole Aquilone, and then to take this Electuary in the morning fa≈øting thereon four or five houres, the quantity is from halfe to one ounce; al≈øo that time that yee eat this Electuary, yee ≈øhall eat no evill meats, as Hogs fle≈øh, fryed meats, or baked meats, or ≈øuch like as might hinder the operation of the Electuary: This Electuary yee ≈øhall u≈øe at the lea≈øt fourty dayes together; and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt ≈øee marvellous effects thereof, as I have done a thou≈øand times in Cicilia, in Naples, and in Rome; and al≈øo in Venice, and alwayes it fell out in one order, and yet the Regions are much different one from another, and the inhabitants are contrary of complexion; neverthele≈ø≈øe this Medicine wrought alwayes one effect in operation, as well in one place, as in another; and therefore I approve it to be a mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Medicine, and of great experience.

div.head: Pills again≈øt poy≈øon, the which are of marvellous vertue.
div.p: THe≈øe Pills are of ≈øuch experience again≈øt poy≈øon, as is not to be beleeved, and the order to make them is thus.

‚Ñû. Imperatrice, Bi≈øtorta, Tormentilla, Valeriana, Dittamobianco, Carlina, Ario≈øtogia rotunda, Gencyana, Agarico electo, Sal gemma of each alike quantity, beat them in fine powder, then take the juyce of Carlike, and of Onions as much as will
make it into a pa≈øte; al≈øo put into the juyce í. i. of Saffron, then let the ≈øaid pa≈øte being mixt dry in the ≈øhadow, and then beat it into powder again, and mix it with the afore≈øaid juyce in good forme, and keep it in a ve≈ø≈øell of Lead untill thou ha≈øt need, and when thou wilt occupy it, take thereof í. iiij. and make thereof Pills with Sirrup Aceto≈øo in good form; which thou ≈øhalt give unto him that is poy≈øoned; and in ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt ≈øee Miracles of that Medicine: for all the afore≈øaid ≈øimples in manner alone are ≈øufficient to deliver one that were poy≈øoned, but being mixed together it worketh greater effect.

div.head: ∆≤nguento magno Leonardo.
div.p: THis ∆≤nguento magno is ≈øo called by rea≈øon of his great vertue and operation; for it worketh ≈øo ≈øtrange in ≈øome di≈øea≈øes, that it in a manner reviveth the Patient, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Otnegra oviu, ‚Ñ•. vj. Oximel ≈øquilliticum halfe an ounce, mix them together in an earthen di≈øh untill the Otnegra oviu. be become like a≈øhes, then it is deifitrom, then put thereon ‚Ñ•. ij. of vinegar, and wa≈øh it well, untill it remain pure and cleare, then take Olibanum halfe an ounce, Ceru≈øae, ‚Ñ•. 1.

Beat them fine, and mix it in a ≈øtone Morter with as much Magno liquore, as will ≈øerve to incorporate them well, then put thereto the Otnegra oviu. and mix them very well together; that being done, put thereto Auxungia porcina, ‚Ñ• viij. And mix them all together, and then it is made, which keep in a ve≈ø≈øell well gla≈øed; for it will keep a long time without corruption, and is apt to help tho≈øe that are lame, full of paines, ≈øores and ≈øwellings, paines of the eyes, the ≈øtone in the reins, and ≈øuch like matters, It helpeth all manner of French Pox, if yee annoint them therewith untill their Gums be ≈øore, and then leave. But yee ≈øhall note that the body mu≈øt fir≈øt be well purged before yee annoint them. This Unguent cooleth all corro≈øive Ulcers, and helpeth them in ≈øhort time, it helpeth all paines in the eyes, if yee put it therein, and taketh away all burning with ≈øpeed; and to be ≈øhort, it helpeth tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes in mo≈øt ≈øhort time, ≈øo that it is to be wondred at.

div.head: Oil of Hypericon, which is mo≈øt miraculous for Wounds and Brui≈øes.
div.p: THis Oil of Hypericon compounded by us, is of great vertue in divers and ≈øundry accidents, and e≈øpecially in Wounds, for it helpeth them without any pain, although the Veins, Sinews, or Bones were hurt, or cut and that in very ≈øhort time, it pre≈øerveth the Wound from corruption, and taketh away the pain, and incarnateth, and ≈øiccatrizeth, as by experience thou maye≈øt plainly ≈øee. It di≈ø≈øolveth Contu≈øions, and is mo≈øt marvellous again≈øt poy≈øon.
It helpeth again≈øt any crude ≈øort of venomous Fever, if yee annoint all the body therewith leaving no part, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. The floures, leaves, and ≈øeed of Saint Johns Wort, as many as yee will, and ≈øtamp them together, and put them in a gla≈ø≈øe, with as much ≈øtrong white Wine as will cover it well, then ≈øet it in the ≈øun ten dayes together, then put thereto as much pure Sallet Oil as the Hearbs and the Wine doth weigh, then let it ≈øtand in the ≈øun other ten dayes, giving you warning, that yee weigh your Oil before yee mix them, that being done, put thereunto for every pound of Oil ‚Ñ•. ii. of Turpentine, and í. i. of Saffron, of Nutmegs, Cloves, Mirrha electe, of each ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. Frankincen≈øe ‚Ñ•. i. Viticella ‚Ñ•. ii. for every pound.

Stamp them altogether, and put them into a great gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øet it to boil in Balneo Mariae, with a Head and Receiver clo≈øe ≈øhut, and to know when it is boiled enough is, that there will a≈øcend no more vapours into the Head, and that will be within four and twenty houres or thereabout; then take forth the gla≈ø≈øe being yet hot, and ≈øtrain it, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut as a precious Jewell; yee ≈øhall note, that this Oil mu≈øt alwayes be occupied very warm, and in any wi≈øe tent no Wound, but wet clothes therein and lay it thereon, and thy cure ≈øhall pro≈øper well, for this I have proved a thou≈øand times in divers places.

div.head: To make our Oleum benedictum, which healeth Wounds divinely.
div.p: THis Oleum benedictum ≈øerveth chiefly for Wounds in all parts of the body, and e≈øpecially for Wounds in the head, if there were fracture of bone, and offences of the Pannicle, and in other places where Sinewes are hurt, or Muskles, or Veins, or in any other noble place of the body, with this Oleum benedictum, and with our vegetable Quinte≈ø≈øence thou maye≈øt help them ea≈øily, and in ≈øhort time, without any danger or detriment of the wounded per≈øon, as is ≈øaid before, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. The whites of Eggs being hard ≈øod in water ‚Ñ•. xii. clear Turpentine ‚Ñ•. xiv. pure Mirrh ‚Ñ•. iii. Mix them, and put it into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe, and give it gentle fire at the fir≈øt, and then increa≈øe it according to Art, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth of the Retort, which will be both Water and Oil, which ≈øeparate, and keep the Oil by it ≈øelf in a gla≈ø≈øe as a precious Jewell, for this worketh miracles in Wounds of what ≈øort ≈øoever they be, moreover it cau≈øeth hair to grow on the head or beard which is fallen away, and that it doth in ≈øhort time, by onely annointing the place therewith, al≈øo if any have a ≈øtitch in his ≈øide, and retention of Urine: let him take a Gli≈øter, wherein he ≈øhall put a little of this Oil and he ≈øhall be helped, and this effect it doth, becau≈øe it drieth mightily that alteration made in the ≈øecret parts of the Reines inwardly, where no locall medicine can be applyed.

div.head: A Magi≈øtrall Water, which pre≈øerveth the ≈øight a long time, and mundifieth the eyes of all ≈øpots.
div.p: IF thou wilt make a water that ≈øhall have vertue to pre≈øerve the ≈øight long, and to mundifie the eyes from all ≈øpots, that are therein, it were nece≈ø≈øary, that therein were ≈øimples that are pre≈øervative and mundificative, as I will ≈øhew thee hereafter.

‚Ñû. The be≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt white Wine that thou can≈øt
find lb. xii. new Bread well ri≈øen lb. iv. Celandine, Fennell, Cipolla ≈øquilla, ana. ‚Ñ•. iv. Cloves ‚Ñ•. ≈øs.
Stamp them, and then di≈øtill them altogether in a goord, in Balneo Mariae untill yee have received five pound, which keep by it ≈øelf, for that is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt pain in the eyes.
Al≈øo if any drink every morning for a moneth the quantity of one ounce, it will help him of any grievous infirmity. Al≈øo I never applyed this Water to any thing, but alwayes it did great plea≈øure.

div.head: To make Oyle of Vitriol compound, which pre≈øerveth nature in his ≈øtrength.
div.p: THe order to make this Compo≈øition is thus.
‚Ñû. Fine Sugar lb. iv. Riopontico lb. i. Rhabarbaro ‚Ñ•. i. the floures of Mercury lb. i.

Stamp them altogether, and make thereof a pa≈øte, that being done, take pure rectified Aqua vitae without flegm lb. iv. And put them altogether in a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, then ≈øet it in warm hor≈øe dung ≈øix dayes, then take it forth and di≈øtill it in Balneo Mariae, untill there will come forth no more ≈øub≈øtance, then take forth the fe≈ø≈øes in the Retort, and put it in a canvas, and pre≈ø≈øe it forth very hard: Then take Buglo≈ø≈øe water, Fumitory water, Scabious water, of each ‚Ñ•. vi. and with the ≈øaid waters wa≈øh well the fe≈ø≈øes, and pre≈ø≈øe it forth again as hard as yee can; then ca≈øt them away, and di≈øtill that water by a filter untill it be clear, then mix it with the fir≈øt that was di≈øtilled by Balneo, then take the be≈øt Oil of Vitrioll that yee can get, and for every pound of the ≈øaid matter, put thereunto ‚Ñà. ≈øs. of the ≈øaid Oil of Vitrioll, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut. This Compo≈øition I have cau≈øed to be u≈øed in the ≈øummer time, and yet continually doe u≈øe it, whereof I have ≈øeen great experience; it procureth a good appetite unto tho≈øe that have lo≈øt or ≈øpoiled it, it helpeth the Milt, it di≈ø≈øolveth the pains of the head and teeth, with many other vertues, which I will not write at this time, it pre≈øerveth old men in their ≈øtrength and lu≈øtine≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that it hath been a
thing to be wondered at, and the order to take it is thus. Yee ≈øhall take ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. in the morning fa≈øting as it is, and fa≈øt thereon four houres at the lea≈øt, and that day eat but little meat, but let it be of good nouri≈øhment, and who≈øoever followeth this order long, ≈øhall live in perfect health of body, as I have ≈øeen divers and ≈øundry times.

div.head: Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina, & Cera.
div.p: THis Oil of Turpentine and Wax is a mo≈øt precious Balm, and his vertues are infinite, becau≈øe it is made of Simples in manner uncorruprible, and is mo≈øt miraculous for tho≈øe that are corrupted or ≈øtricken with the Pe≈øtilence, becau≈øe it is mo≈øt penetrative, and of nature drying, and comforteth all weak parts in mans body, of what infirmity ≈øoever they be, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. New yellow Wax ‚Ñ•. xii. clear Turpentine ‚Ñ•. xviii. Benjamime ‚Ñ•. ii. fine rectified Aqua vitae ‚Ñ•. xxx. common A≈øhes ‚Ñ•. vi. Mix them, and put them into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe well luted, and then di≈øtill it in a wind Furnace, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, and in the Receiver thou ≈øhalt find three things, the fir≈øt is the Water, the ≈øecond Oil, the third flegm, which thou ≈øhalt ≈øeparate one from another, and keep them clo≈øe ≈øtopt in a gla≈ø≈øe, which is mo≈øt excellent in time of the Pe≈øtilence, as well for unction as for to help the ≈øores, for if yee put it in a ≈øore, or botch, that is broke, pre≈øently it taketh away the pain, and being mixed with other of our Medicines, as I have ≈øhewed in my Regiment of the Pe≈øtilence, it helpeth them with great ≈øpeed. If any annoint all his body with this Oil twice a moneth, it will pre≈øerve him youthfull, and in health a long time, it pre≈øerveth al≈øo dead fle≈øh or fi≈øh that is put therein from corruption, al≈øo if any be wounded in any part of the body, let him annoint it with this Oil four or five times and it ≈øhall be whole: Al≈øo if any cannot make water, give him í. ii. of this Oil to drink, and pre≈øently he ≈øhall make water, it is al≈øo good again≈øt the ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, and Pluri≈øie, and Worms, and the Cough, and Catarre, and again≈øt the pe≈øtilent Fever, and ≈øuch like indi≈øpo≈øition, if yee
drink a little thereof, it hath a number of other vertues, which I will leave unto the Experimentours.

div.head: Our Magno liquore which is of great vertue.
div.p: THis is of my invention, and the order to make it is thus.
‚Ñû. Sweet ≈øallet Oyle xx. lb. white wine lb. ij. boyle them together untill the wine be con≈øumed, then put it in a ve≈ø≈øell of ≈øtone, and put thereunto the≈øe things following.

‚Ñû. The flours of Ro≈øemary, lb. iii. Lignum alces, ‚Ñ•. vj. Olibanum, Bdellium, ana. ‚Ñ•. x. then ≈øtop it very clo≈øe, and bury it in the ground four foot deep, and this would be buried in the beginning of Augu≈øt, and there remain untill the moneth of March, then take it forth of the ground, and ≈øet it in the ≈øun, and put thereto the≈øe matters following. Sage, Ro≈øemary, Rew, Betony, Millifolly, Comfery roots, Tamaro, Viticella, ana, one handfull, Gallingall, Cloves, Nutmegs, Spikenard, Saffron, ‚Ñ•. j. Sarcocolla, Sanguis Draconis in graine, Ma≈øtike, ‚Ñ•. j. aloes epatike, Ra≈øa di pino, ana, ‚Ñ•. viij. yellow Wax, Auxungia, ana. ‚Ñ•. xviij. Colophonie., lb. j. Hipericon with the ≈øeed and all, lb. ij. Muske, í. j. Mix the≈øe all well together, and boyle them in Balneo untill the herbs become dry, and have no more ≈øub≈øtance, then it is boyled, then take it forth and ≈øtraine it; and put thereunto for every pound í. vj. of our Balme artificiall; and when the moneth of September commeth, put thereunto lb. ij. of the fruit of the herb called Bal≈øamina, which is red, and then it is ended, which thou ≈øhalt keepe in a Gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut; for the older it is, the better it is; and is of ≈øuch vertue, that it helpeth the Eti≈øie, and Hidrop≈øie, if yee give them every morning iiij. Drachms, with ‚Ñ•. j. of Sirrup of Ro≈øes warme the ≈øpace of xl. dayes, as I have proved: And this is the true and perfect Unction that helpeth the Petocchie, a di≈øea≈øe ≈øo called in the Italian: If any were wounded, and had cut veins, ≈øinues, and bones, let him joyne the parts clo≈øe together, and dre≈ø≈øe it with this Oyle very hot upon the upper parts; and in ≈øhort time it ≈øhall be whole, without any alteration; it helpeth al≈øo the white ≈øcall if yee annoint it therewith: It helpeth coldne≈ø≈øe in the head and Catarrs, if yee
annoint it within the no≈øtrils at night when yee goe to bed; if yee annoint the ≈øtomack therewith, it cau≈øeth perfect dige≈øtion of the meat, it provoketh Vrine where it is let thorow carno≈øity or Gonorrea, or ≈øuch like matter; it cau≈øeth hair to grow, it pre≈øerveth the beard black, and is good again≈øt worms; and all the≈øe experiments are true, and proved of me divers and ≈øundry times in the afore≈øaid infirmities, and al≈øo in divers other which I leave untill another time: Yee ≈øhall note, that if yee annoint any all over that is grieved with the Pox with this Oyle, it will increa≈øe his paine; and ≈øo by that means yee may know whether he be infected or no.

div.head: Pillole Angelica, which evacuate the body without any Impediment, and are mo≈øt profitable.
div.p:
IT is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary that all kind of Pills ≈øhould be well prepared, and artificially handled; becau≈øe they ≈øhall make no alteration in the ≈øtomack of tho≈øe that take them; and therefore I will write a kind of Pills of our invention, and are called Pillole Angelica Leonardo, which may be u≈øed in any kind of infirmity, and may be given to a woman with child without danger, for they di≈ø≈øolve the body without trouble, they purge choller and flegme, and purge partibus along, and are good again≈øt all paines, they dry up Ulcers in all parts of the body, di≈ø≈øolve the Catarrous humour, and in a manner all Fevers, and the order to make them is thus, ‚Ñû. Coloquintida, ‚Ñ•. iiij. and put it in j. pound of pure rectified Aqua vitae without flegm, and there let it remaine three dayes, then ≈øtraine it hard into a cleane ve≈ø≈øell, and put therein Aloes epatike, Mirrha, Eleborus niger, ana, ‚Ñ•. i. Beat them in fine powder, and mix them like a pa≈øte, then ≈øet it in the ≈øunne untill it be almo≈øt dryed: Then put thereto Saffron, Cinamon, yellow Sulphur, ana, í. iiii. and mix them well together, and let them dry altogether, then make it into a pa≈øte with white crude Honey, and keep it in a ve≈ø≈øell of Lead, for that is be≈øt, the quantity is from one Drachm to two Drachms, for the≈øe are Pillole preparate, that may be taken without keeping of dyet, and they doe purge all humours hanging in the body, and pre≈øerveth the body from
putrefaction, as I have ≈øeen the experience thereof divers times.

div.head: Pillole Aquilone of our Invention.
div.p: THo≈øe Pills are above all other in operation, as the Eagle is above all other birds; and therefore I thought good to call them Pillole Aquilone, and the order to make them is thus.

‚Ñû. Con≈øerve of Damaske Ro≈øes made with Honey three ounces, Lignum aloes í. i. Oyle of Vitrioll twelve graines, Cinamon elect. ‚Ñà. ii. Petra Philo≈øophale of our invention halfe an ounce, Sugar-candy, two ounces.

Mix them and make thereof a pa≈øte with Sirrupo aceto≈øo, and keep them in a Gla≈ø≈øe. The vertue of the≈øe Pills I will not write at this time, but onely I ≈øay they help again≈øt all ≈øorts of infirmities, and hurteth none in any wi≈øe; the quantity is from í. i. to í. ii. in the morning fa≈øting, but yee may not guild them in any wi≈øe, but drink after them a cup of water or wine, to carry them downe, then ≈øleep thereon, and that day eat little meat, and light of dige≈øtion.

div.head: Our Quinte≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, which is of marvellous operation in divers matters.
div.p: THis Quinte≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva evacuateth the body with great ea≈øe and without any detriment, and it purgeth all parts of the body that are troubled with gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, it re≈øolveth ≈øwellings, and taketh away the paines; it pre≈øerveth the ≈øight, and killeth worms, and cau≈øeth a good appetite, with many other good qualities, which I will leave at this time and the order to make it is thus.
‚Ñû. Lignum Aloes, Cinamon, Turbit, Aloes hepatica, ana, one ounce, Colloquintida, two ounces, Cloves, Saffron of each ‚Ñà. iii. Musk of Levant í. i. Julip of Violets, lb. i.

Mix all the afore≈øaid matters together in a Gla≈ø≈øe, and put thereon two pound of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand twelve dayes, and then ≈øtraine it, and put it into a ve≈ø≈øell of Gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut; this may be taken with broth, wine, or with
what Sirrup or Potion yee will; the quantity is from í. ii. to í. iiii. in the morning fa≈øting without keeping of any dyet at ll, and it ≈øhall worke well without trouble at all.

div.head: Our Sirrup of Quinte≈ø≈øence, which is of marvellous vertue.
div.p: THis Sirrup is of marvellous vertue, as is ≈øeen daily by experience, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Of that pure rectified Aqua vitae, whereof we make our Quinte≈ø≈øence ‚Ñ•. xii. Oil of Sulphur, Oil of Vitrioll, of each í. i. Oil of Tartar perfect ‚Ñ•. ii. Julip of Ro≈øes lb. iv. Musk two carrets, Saffron ‚Ñà. i. Cinnamon í. i. Mix them together, and keep them in a gla≈ø≈øe, for his vertues are innumerable, and in manner reviveth tho≈øe that are half dead. It helpeth the Fever in ≈øhort time if yee u≈øe it. This Sirrup may be mixed with any kind of potion that is given to the ≈øick, and may be given alone in broth, wine, or water, or in what ≈øort yee will, the quantity is from í. ii. to í. iv. and herewith I have done miracles, as thou maye≈øt read, in my The≈øauro della vita humana.

div.head: Pillole Magi≈øtrale, which is good again≈øt divers infirmities.
div.p: THe≈øe Pills are of great vertue, and e≈øpecially again≈øt all kind of paines coming of corrupt humours; for they purge the putrefied humours, and pre≈øerve the body from corruption, and the order to make them is thus.
‚Ñû. Olibanum, Ma≈øticke, Mirrha, Sarcocolla, Aloes hepatica, Elleborus niger, Saffron, Turbit, Colloquintida, ana, q v.

Stamp them finely; and for every ounce of the afore≈øaid matters, put thereunto two Carrets of Muske, and then incorporate it with Honey of Ro≈øes, and Aqua vitae of each alike; and this Pa≈øte thou maie≈øt keep for ≈øix moneths in a ve≈ø≈øell of Lead; the quantity is from two Dramchs to three Drachms in the morning fa≈øting, and drink thereon a little Wine. The≈øe Pills are mo≈øt excellent to take away the paines of the Gout, and to pre≈øerve a man from it; they are al≈øo good for tho≈øe that have the French Pox, becau≈øe they evacuate
the gro≈ø≈øe and vi≈øcous humours, and maintain the body in good temperature, and u≈øing them in tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes, it pre≈øerveth the body in good temperature. They are al≈øo good for women that are troubled with pains of the Mother, and retention of their Termes, for the≈øe are aperative and provoke them, and purgeth the Matrix of all impediments contained therein, they ≈øerve again≈øt the Megrum, and all pains of the head, and al≈øo again≈øt all kind of putrified Fevers, as I have ≈øeen the experience thereof ≈øundry times.

div.head: A compound Aqua vitae, which ≈øerveth again≈øt all cold di≈øea≈øes of the ≈øtomack.
div.p: THis Aqua vitae, aromati≈øed with ≈øimples of Levant, is of mo≈øt excellent vertue, as by the ingredient thou maye≈øt perceive, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Nutmegs, Cloves, Gallingall, Cardamomum, Cubebes, Mace, Cinnamon, Ginger, Saffron, Olibanum, ana. ‚Ñ•. i. Beat them finely, and put them in a goord of gla≈ø≈øe, and put therein lb. vi. of pure rectified Aqua vitae, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand ≈øix dayes, then di≈øtill it by ≈øand, and there will come forth a red water, which is mo≈øt precious again≈øt all infirmities cau≈øed of cold, it mundifieth all ≈øorts of Sores, and helpeth all Wounds without pain. It cau≈øeth a good memory, it helpeth the Cough, and maketh the heart merry, with divers other vertues, which I leave to the Experimentour.

div.head: A compound Oil again≈øt Poy≈øon, which is of a marvellous vertue
div.p:
IF thou wilt help tho≈øe that are poy≈øoned, it were nece≈ø≈øary to have remedies of ≈øuch vertue that are apt to the ≈øolution of the poy≈øon, for the poy≈øon worketh tho≈øe three effects, as is ≈øaid berore, in the Chapter of the effects of poy≈øon, wherein it is written, how that it is nece≈ø≈øary to keep the bloud liquid, ≈øo that it congeal not in the veines, and likewi≈øe to let or ≈øtay that water which cometh to the ≈øtomack, and to let that alteration, or inflammation as we may term it. And all the≈øe operations are nece≈ø≈øary to be done with mo≈øt excellent remedies,
in which there entereth part of poy≈øon, for the Proverb ≈øaith, that one poy≈øon killeth another, and that I will approve in this Chapter, and the order to make this Compo≈øition is thus.

‚Ñû. The olde≈øt Oil that thou can≈øt find lb. i. Aloes hepatica, Rhabarbaro, Spico nardo, Mirrha, Tormentilla, Dictamnum album, Gentiana, Bi≈øtorta, Con≈øolida majore, Rubia di titory, ana. half an ounce, Theriaca Methridata, ana, í. iii. quick Scorpions to the number of ≈øixty. Fir≈øt put the quick Scorpions into the oil, and let them boil in Balneo Mariae four hours then put thereunto the other matters, and let them boil altogether other four houres, then ≈øtrain it, and keep it in a ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, for truly this is a divine Oil for that accident, in which yee ≈øee entereth Scorpions which are venomous, and yet his poy≈øon is whole≈øome for tho≈øe that are poy≈øoned.

The like yee may ≈øee by tho≈øe that are burnt with fire, for the be≈øt Medicine that they can find, is to burn that place again: Al≈øo yee may ≈øee, that when great quantity of bloud cometh forth of a Wound, the Chirurgian pre≈øently letteth him bloud in another place to turn the ≈øame. Seeing then that the≈øe are true, it is al≈øo true, that one poy≈øon doth kill another poy≈øon. And by this rea≈øon I approve, that if yee extingui≈øh the poy≈øon, it were nece≈ø≈øary to be done with his kind, neverthele≈ø≈øe it mu≈øt be prepared ≈øo, that the matter be not alterated, and become hurtfull unto the poy≈øoned per≈øon, and the order to u≈øe this Oil again≈øt poy≈øon is thus.

When that a man is poy≈øoned, pre≈øently annoint all his body with this Oil, and give him thereof to drink two drachms with white Wine Vinegar morning and evening, and God willing thou ≈øhalt help any poy≈øon be it never ≈øo ≈øtrong: If he be poy≈øoned with Sublimate, or a Diamoud, this remedy will not be good, becau≈øe they are not poy≈øons, but are deadly Minerals, which by no meanes can be dige≈øted, ere their evill effect mitigated. Therefore when one is poy≈øoned with Sublimate, his remedy is no otherwi≈øe, but to make him bathes of Vinegar, and let h ‚Ä¢ m drink Milk enough, and eat Butter, and drink Siero, for this is the true remedy; as for example, when that a ≈øore is mortified with a rottery made of Sublimate,
or Ar≈øenick, pre≈øently it cau≈øeth great alteration, for which there is no excellenter remedies then Vinegar, Butter, and Milk: Then ≈øeeing that the≈øe remedies are ≈øo profitable to be u≈øed outwardly, there is no doubt, but that they will doe the ≈øame effect inwardly: Al≈øo it would be nece≈ø≈øary to cau≈øe them to vomit every day once at the lea≈øt, to keep the ≈øtomack evacuated of that matter, ≈øo that it come not to choke the infected per≈øon, or infect the ≈øinews, ≈øo that the party remain not lame for a long time after, as is daily ≈øeen in divers places.

div.head: A marvellous Sope that helpeth tho≈øe which cannot ≈øpit but with great pain.
div.p: THis Compo≈øition is called Saponea no≈øtra, becau≈øe it is made of Sope, but not of that Sope which is in the Apothecaries ≈øhops in Venice, but this is a confection, which being eat every morning a little quantity, it helpeth tho≈øe that ≈øpit with pain, it openeth the ≈øtomack, and breaketh that evill matter contained therein, and ca≈øteth it forth at the mouth with the ≈øpittle, and ≈øo leaveth the Patient well di≈øpo≈øed and merry, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. White Venice Sope, and beat it into powder ‚Ñ•. i. pure Ma≈øtick í. ii. Cinnamon, Licorice, ana. í. i. fine Sugar as much as will ≈øuffice to make it in tables according to art, the which are mo≈øt ≈øtrange, neverthele≈ø≈øe marvell not thereat, for I will ≈øhew the rea≈øon, ≈øo that every one ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied.

Yee ≈øhall under≈øtand, that the fir≈øt ingredient being the Sope, is made with the Lye of Soda and Calx, which things doe dry and mundifie all ≈øorts of Ulcers ≈øordid, and cooleth them: Al≈øo therein is Oil Olyfe, which is one of the mo≈øt excellente≈øt liquours in the world, for this of it ≈øelf is able to cut that matter from the ≈øtomack, and to mundifie it; then in this compound there is Ma≈øtick, which is mo≈øt excellent for the ≈øtomack, and draweth down from the head, then the Licorice and Cinnamon are aperative, and comforteth the ≈øtomack, ≈øo that all the≈øe being mixed together, of force it mu≈øt help again≈øt the≈øe infirmities of the brea≈øt, and the quantity thereof is from í. ii, to ‚Ñ•. ≈øs.

div.head: To make the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Hony.
div.p: THis Quinte≈ø≈øence hath all the vertues of the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, and is made in this order, and is rather to be counted a divine remedy then humane.

‚Ñû. The pure≈øt Honey that yee can get, which is not mixt with any thing lb. ii. and put it into a goord of gla≈ø≈øe with his Head and Receiver clo≈øe luted, and give it fir≈øt a gentle fire, untill there appear certain white fumes in the Head, which will turn into a red water by laying of clothes wet in cold water upon the Head and Receiver, then keep in thy fire according to art, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, which thou ≈øhalt keep in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, and in ≈øhort time it will turn into the colour of a Rubie, then di≈øtill it ≈øeven times in Balneo Mariae, and it will lo≈øe his red colour, and be of a very plea≈øant ≈ømell, and remain in the colour of Gold, and this Quinte≈ø≈øence di≈ø≈øolveth Gold and maketh it potable, and al≈øo all manner of Jewels that is put therein; al≈øo if yee give two or three drachms to any that lie a dying, pre≈øently it will recover him again, as the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine doth; if yee wa≈øh any Wound or Sore therewith it will heal it quickly; it is good again≈øt the Cough, Catarre, and paines of the Milt, and many other ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes which I will not write at this time, for few or none will beleeve his great operation or vertue. If yee di≈øtill it twenty times with fine Silver, it will re≈øtore the ≈øight unto tho≈øe that are almo≈øt blind. Moreover, I have given this ≈øix and forty dayes unto one that had the Pal≈øie, and he was helped quickly.

It helpeth al≈øo the Falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and pre≈øerveth the body from putrefaction, ≈øo that by the≈øe meanes we may ≈øee, that it is a cele≈øtiall remedy given unto us by the Almighty God, and therefore I would wi≈øh ≈øome vertuous men to take a little pains in making of this precious liquour, and they ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øuch wonders thereof, that the world will marvell thereat, as I have proved many times, to my great honour and profit of the Patient. For many times I have given it the ≈øick that no man did ≈øee me, and pre≈øently they thought I had wrought
by inchantment, by rea≈øon of his great vertue, and therefore all men that profe≈ø≈øe Phy≈øick and Chirurgery, ought to be provided of this liquour, and ≈øuch like for their commodity, and profit of the Patient.

div.head: To make our Elixar vitae, or Aqua Coele≈øtis.
div.p: THis Elixar vitae is a Medicine of ≈øuch vertue and ≈øtrength, that it helpeth in manner again≈øt all di≈øea≈øes that cometh to mans body, for tho≈øe that are hot, it cooleth, and tho≈øe that are cold, it warmeth, and that it doth by his proper quality and vertue, for this I have proved a thou≈øand times, and have u≈øed it again≈øt ≈øundry di≈øea≈øes, and alwayes have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and the order to make it is thus.

‚Ñû. Ginger, Zedoaria, Gallingal, long Pepper, round Pepper, Juniper berries, Citron pills, Orange pills, Sage, Ba≈øill, Ro≈øemary, Mint, Majorame, Bay berries, Penniroyall, Gentian, Calamint, the floures of Elders, red Ro≈øes and white, Spica nardi, Cubebe, Lignum aloes, Cardamomum, Cinnamon, Calamus Aromaticus, Germander, Staecados, Camepiteos, Meligette, Mace, Olibanum, Aloes hepatica, the ≈øeed of Mugwort, of each í. ii. Figs, Rai≈øins, Dates, Almonds, Grains of the Pine, ana. ‚Ñ•. vi. pure white Honey lb. i. Musk of Levant í. i. fine Sugar lb. iv.

Mix them altogether, and infu≈øe them in lb. v. of pure Aqua vitae without flegm, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand eight dayes, then di≈øtill it in Balneo Mariae untill the fe≈ø≈øes remain dry, then take that and ≈øercolate it in a Pellicane in hor≈øe-dung forty dayes, then take the gla≈ø≈øe with the fe≈ø≈øes, and di≈øtill it in ≈øand untill all the ≈øub≈øtance be come forth, which will be red like bloud, and ≈øtinketh of the fire, and is thick, the which mu≈øt be ≈øercolated as the fir≈øt, and this is the fiery part, which is of marvellous vertue, in≈øomuch that it reviveth tho≈øe that are at the point of death, and therefore I will write of ≈øome of his vertues which I have proved.

The fir≈øt water di≈øtilled by Balneo, being taken every third day í. i. pre≈øerveth the body in pro≈øperous ≈øtate, and defendeth it from many ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes It helpeth all ≈øorts of wounds
if yee wa≈øh them therewith three or four times, and is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt all impediments in the eyes, if yee put therein one drop, and pre≈øerveth the ≈øight a long time, ≈øo that yee ≈øhall not need to wear Spectacles. If a young woman doth wa≈øh her face therewith oftentimes, it pre≈øerveth her a long time in that ≈øtate. If yee u≈øe to drink this Elixar, it provoketh venereous acts; and di≈øpo≈øeth women to be delivered, with divers other vertues, which I leave to the Experimentour.

The la≈øt water, which is red, is excellent good again≈øt the pains of the Mother if it be drunk. It di≈ø≈øolveth al≈øo the Pluri≈øie, if yee give thereof í. ii. and annoint the parts grieved therewith. It helpeth the pains of the Collick, and hardne≈ø≈øe of the Milt. It is al≈øo good again≈øt paines in the teeth, and ≈øtinking breath, and many ≈øuch like things. It helpeth all manner of Fevers, and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it drieth up all the evill humours that offendeth Nature, as well within as without, ≈øo by this rea≈øon it is apt to help all ≈øort of di≈øea≈øes. If any were ≈øick and could not ≈øpeak, let him take í. i. of this with í. i. of the fir≈øt, and pre≈øently he ≈øhall ≈øpeak mo≈øt miraculou≈øly, for this I have proved a thou≈øand times, to my great honour and content of the Patient, and therefore I would wi≈øh all tho≈øe that profe≈ø≈øe Phy≈øick, or Chirurgery, to be prepared with this liquour, and ≈øuch like, for their own profit, and health of their Neighbour.

div.head: To make Aqua Reale vel Imperiale, which maketh the teeth white pre≈øently, incarnateth the gums, and cau≈øeth a good breath.
div.p: THe teeth being black, ru≈øty, and full of filth, and the gums putrified or corrupt, are the wor≈øt things that may be ≈øeen in man or woman, and are al≈øo very unwhol≈øome, and the remedy to make the teeth white, and to help the gums is thus. ‚Ñ•. iv. Put all the afore≈øaid matters in a Goord, with his Head and Receiver, and give it fire according to art, and at the la≈øt there will come forth a white water like Milk, which after it hath ≈øtood a while will wax clear. div.head: A kind of Pill mo≈øt convenient for the eyes, and comforteth the ≈øtomack.
div.p: THo≈øe Pills which comfort the ≈øtomack, by force mu≈øt help the ≈øight, for when the ≈øtomack is filled with malign humours, it di≈øtempereth tho≈øe parts that are about it, and the fumes that a≈øcend up to the head moi≈øteneth Neruos opticos of the eyes, and by this cau≈øe the eyes are offended, therefore it were nece≈ø≈øary for tho≈øe Pills that help the eyes al≈øo to comfort the ≈øtomack, which mu≈øt be done by evacuating the matter hanging by vomit, and the order to make the≈øe Pills is thus.

div.head: A di≈øcour≈øe upon a Compo≈øition that pre≈øerveth a man or woman in health a long time.
div.p: IF thou wilt make a pa≈øte that ≈øhall have vertue to pre≈øerve whole bodies, and to help the ≈øick, it were nece≈ø≈øary to look out ≈øimples that have vertue to doe it, and when thou ha≈øt found out tho≈øe drugs that have vertue to pre≈øerve, thou maye≈øt put thy tru≈øt in them: which I di≈øcour≈øing by the way of rea≈øon, and conferring it by experience, have found out a number of drugs that are friends unto our nature, and pre≈øerveth it, of the which I will ≈øhew thee ≈øome that are of great importance, which may be proved by rea≈øon and experience, and are the≈øe.

Beat them into fine powder, and make them into a pa≈øte like a ≈øalve with rectified Aqua vitae, then dry it in the Sun, then beat it into powder again, and make it into a pa≈øte with our Oleo del Bal≈øamo, and then thou ≈øhalt have a pa≈øt of mo≈øt marvellous vertue, for if yee take thereof every morming í. i. it will pre≈øerve him long in health, it is mo≈øt excellent for tho≈øe that be wounded, or have any ≈øore upon them, becau≈øe it keepeth the ≈øore from putrefaction, as by the ingredient thou maye≈øt perceive.

Cloves, long Pepper, Calamus Aromaticus, Saffron, ana. ‚Ñ•. ii. Almonds, Grains of the Pine, Dates, ana. ‚Ñ•. iv. Melegette, ‚Ñ•. i. fine Sugar lb. iv. Musk four carrets; let all the≈øe ≈øtand in a long necked gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped eight or nine dayes, and then di≈øtill it in Balneo untill yee have received lb. v. which keep clo≈øe ≈øtopped in a gla≈ø≈øe as a precious Jewell: then di≈øtill the re≈øt in ≈øand untill the fe≈ø≈øes be dry, and that will be a red Water, and will ≈øtink ≈øomewhat of the fire or ≈ømoak, which al≈øo keep in a gla≈ø≈øe, for in time it will loo≈øe his ≈øtinking ≈ømell, and be mo≈øt pretious. div.head: To make Oil of Antimony.
div.p:
REc. Antimony, and calcine it untill it will ≈ømoak no more, and that it be of a grayi≈øh colour, and alwayes as it cluttereth ≈øtamp it again, then take as much common A≈øhes as the Antimony finely ≈øear≈øed, and put them into a Retort well luted,

div.head: A precious Liquour above all other.
div.p: THis is the mo≈øt precious water that may be made in the world, and his vertues are ≈øuch, and ≈øo many, that they cau≈øe the world to marvell at them. div.head: A Secret of marvellous vertue.
div.p:
REc. A new Brick forth of the Kill, and break it in ≈ømall peices like a Nut, then lay them in the fire untill they be red hot, then take them forth, and quench them in ≈øweet Sallet Oil, then take them forth again, and lay them in the fire untill they be red hot, then quench them again, and this yee ≈øhall doe at the lea≈øt five times, and at the la≈øt time take them forth,

div.head: Our Secret of marvellous vertue in act and ≈øtrength
div.p: THis Unguent is of marvellous vertue, and was never made by any before, neither Antients nor of our time, which Unguent helpeth putrified Ulcers in the legs, ≈øo that it is to be wondered at: for it worketh divers operations, it mortifieth the evill, mundifieth, incarnateth, and ≈øiccatrizeth, which things to the Profe≈ø≈øours of the Art ≈øeemeth hard: Neverthele≈ø≈øe it is true, as I have proved an infinite of times; and becau≈øe the world ≈øhould have it, I have written here the receipt.

div.head: Of Lac Virginis, and the order to make it
div.p: THis Lac Virginis is a ≈øolution of Saturne, and Sal gemma, which is a thing mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the Chirurgian to u≈øe, and the order to make it is thus.

div.head: A Secret of Turpentine of Ciprus.
div.p:
THe Turpentine of Ciprus is a kinde more finer then our Turpentine, and without compari≈øon, and of more vertue then ours is, and this the Doctors ≈øay, doth di≈ø≈øolve pains and pre≈øerveth the body, if it bee taken inwardly, becau≈øe they ≈øay, That Turpentine is an uncorruptible Gum, the which is mo≈øt true. But in that Gum there is one part thick and gro≈ø≈øe that hindereth his operation, and he that can ≈øeparate this gro≈ø≈øe part from the noble parts, ≈øhall doe great wonders therewith: It is needfull then with the fire, and the means of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, to make the ≈øeparation of the Elements, the which are four, Water, Oyle, Liquor and Earth. and the Earth that remaineth, is ≈øpoiled, and of no ≈øub≈øtance, and with tho≈øe things thou maye≈øt doe high and great cures, when they are applyed according as they ought to be, becau≈øe many good and profitable things, through the want of perfect application in time and place, many times doe hurt, and to ≈øhew the truth, I will ≈øhew thee an example of wine, the which is a precious liquor, the which being drunk in the morning is hurtfull to many, to eat meat betwixt meals is not good, and many ≈øuch like things, that when they be not done with order doe hurt, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary for tho≈øe that will under≈øtand, that matter to be of a good intelligence, as well in making it, as in u≈øing or applying it to the ≈øick.

div.head: To the Freindly Reader, as much health as he wi≈øheth of Soul and Body.
div.p:
MEN many times meddle in ≈øome matters, wherein they take more toile then thank for their labours; and he, which thinks in the night that he hath plea≈øed all, ≈øhall find in the morning that he hath angered ≈øome. So many as know me wel, and whereto I was cheifly adicted within the≈øe eight or nine yeares, that is, unto the ≈øtudy and practi≈øe of the ≈øoul Phy≈øick, may now make a que≈øtion of my medling ≈øo long with bodily Phy≈øick. But my twofold an≈øwer they may take with them for their ≈øatisfaction: Fir≈øt, that I keep ≈øtill Depo≈øitum illud, which God hath committed unto me (and ≈øealed the ≈øame by mine own ≈øpirituall birth, and other mens ≈øanctification) till he that hath ≈øaid, Goe, points the time, and gives the occa≈øion of my further ≈øervice in that weighty Function. Secondly, as when I conver≈øed in that calling I was chargeable to none, ≈øo (not ≈øurcea≈øing the ≈øame of mine own accord) I have ≈øince, by God his ble≈ø≈øing of my labours herein, as not greatly inriched my ≈øelf, ≈øo not impoveri≈øhed any: That wherein I have thus continued, ≈øeeing it concerneth learning, and an hone≈øt mans maintenance, cannot, or ought not to offend any that are well in their wits. The≈øe few ≈øecrets contained in this Collection, and Appendix thereto adjoyning (which I have reduced into method for his ≈øake that gathered them here and there) cannot, or ought not to ≈øcandalize any, that have a ≈øanctified cunning in Phy≈øick or Chirurgery. I mu≈øt needs tell thee, that I lean more to that ≈øafe, ≈øpeedy, and plea≈øant kind of curation, with Medicines rightly prepared, then to the carele≈ø≈øe Compo≈øition, made by addition of other ≈øimples, clogged with more impurities then are in that ≈øimple which they labour to correct. I dare al≈øo avouch, that any poor body may better commit his cra≈øie body, to be healed or helped of any outward or inward malady, by the right prepared Medicines, for the value often Shillings (which he can hardly ≈øpare) then a wealthy man to their deceits (I would ≈øay receits) for ten Crownes, which he may well enough forbear: Many of the ignorant ≈øort have counted the Chymicall or Paracel≈øical Phy≈øick dangerous, and not without cau≈øe, for wofull experience
hath brought it into that ≈øu≈øpition. But (good Reader) hear me in that which Ile tell thee, and ≈øo take thine an≈øwer for this time: Some of the learned, and mo≈øt of the ignorant, have in generall de≈øpi≈øed them, but by your leave, after they have heard a particular of the excellent ≈øucce≈ø≈øe attained by many of them; they have adventured upon tho≈øe, without knowledge, experience, direction, and ≈øo have made many Patients to ≈ømart for it: Therefore I would not, that the fine fingered Phi≈øitian ≈øhould ≈øcorn to wear this Pearl, which is as fit for Sir John lack-Latine, for the Land-leaper, or cogging Quack≈øalver, as a Pipe for an A≈ø≈øe, or a Cage for a Cow. div.head: The Proheme or Entrance into this Collection, contained in the fir≈øt four Chapters.
CHAP. I. What the duty of an expert Chirurgian is.
div.p: A Good and true Chirurgian is no other, then a Mini≈øter, and helper of nature; who hath three operations to perform in curing of wounds: The fir≈øt is, that he joyn the ≈øeparated parts clo≈øe together: The ≈øecond, to pre≈øerve it from pain: The third, that he keep it from putrefaction; all the re≈øt he may leave unto nature, which will work with good expedition: And this is a ≈øure intention concerning the cure of Wounds; never keep the fle≈øh open with tents or pledgets; neither weaken nature by letting of bloud, or by purging, nor yet by ≈øtreight diet, to cau≈øe the pain to increa≈øe, but keep the wound alwayes clean, wa≈øhing it with Aqua Bal≈øami, and lay upon the wound clothes wet in Magno liquore: This is a good and an approved order, whereof who≈øoever will know more, let him look in Leonardo Phioravante his book of Rationall Secrets, where he ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied more at large.

div.head: CHAP. III. The cau≈øe why Wounds cannot heal quickly.
div.p:
THough there be many more, yet cheifly they may be reduced unto two cau≈øes: The one is, an immoderate and extream diet, which weakeneth the ≈øtomack and body ≈øo much,
that nature cannot prevail to conglutinate or ≈øoder the fle≈øh together; and thus, through want of natural heat, the wound falleth to Impo≈øthumation, Gangrena, Fi≈øtulaes, &c. and can hardly be cured. The ≈øecond cau≈øe is, the keeping of them too much open, by rea≈øon of their tents or pledgets, ≈øo that they cannot joyn together again, but grow to Cancers and Fi≈øtulaes, whereupon many times the Patient remaineth lame ever after, or el≈øe ≈øpeedy death is the end thereof.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of Wounds in the head, how they mu≈øt be dealt withall.
div.p: ALl wounds in the head mu≈øt be clo≈øe joyned and kept together, the bloud mu≈øt be cru≈øhed out, then wa≈øh it well with ≈øomething that hath vertue to liquifie the bloud, as the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, or ≈øuch like; then lay thereon lint wet in Oleum benedictum; this Medicine you ≈øhall change in four dayes, but every day once wa≈øh the wound round about with that Quinte≈ø≈øence, and annoint it with the ≈øaid Oil, and at the fourth dayes end dre≈ø≈øe it again, and let it remain two dayes more, and after that for a day more, and the wound (by the help of God) ≈øhall be cured in twelve or fourteen dayes: Thus may you deal with all wounds, ≈øave tho≈øe that are made in the belly; as for all other, either ≈øimple or compound wounds, you ≈øhall find their cure, methodically ≈øhewed, in the Rationall Secrets of Leonardo Phioravante publi≈øhed in Engli≈øh.

div.head: CHAP V. The healing of a greivous Wound on the ≈øide of the head.
div.p: THe wound was made on the ≈øide of the head, almo≈øt to dura mater, and it was healed in this manner: Fir≈øt there was put into the ≈øame the Quinte≈ø≈øence afore≈øaid, then a little Bal≈øamo, then there was applyed a cloth which was wet in Magno liquore, made very hot, upon which cloth was laid our ≈øecret powder, covered with lint, and thus he was dre≈ø≈øed once every day till he was whole. You mu≈øt note, that when≈øoever the skull is hurt unto dura mater, there mu≈øt be ca≈øt up at the no≈øtrils our bal≈øamo that the ≈ømell may pierce upward, and re≈øolve the offence. Sometime al≈øo in ≈øtead of a Defen≈øative, you may annoint round about the wound, with the fore≈øaid Balm, which pre≈øerveth from putrifaction and alteration.

div.head: CHAP. VI. A dangerous wound in the head, cured in five dayes.
div.p: IT was healed very quickly, by putting therein our Aqua caele≈øtis and bal≈øamo, and by applying unto the ≈øame very hot clothes wet in Magno liquore.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The cure of a wound on the eare to the skull.
div.p: A Sore wound was made on the eare, which was cut unto the skull of the head, and was healed in this manner; Fir≈øt, by annointing it with out Quinte≈ø≈øence, which cau≈øed it to wax very hot, the ≈øpace of two hours. After that there was put in our Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina & Cera, and ≈øo he dre≈ø≈øed it every day once.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. How three wounds in the head, with fracture of the bone or ≈øcull were healed by I. P.
div.p:
A Ceriain Miller in Buckingham≈øhire, called Peter Bull, being ≈øore wounded in the head, whereof one wound was in the mid≈øt of the head, with fracture of the skull, another within an inch of that ≈øix inches long, he had another wound over his eie brow two inches long. Be≈øides the wounds in his head, he had al≈øo a great wound in the bow of his arm be≈øide the elbow, ≈øo that a man might have laid his three fingers in it, divers of his fingers were al≈øo cut, and he lo≈øt two joynts. This man bled by the ≈øpace of ≈øeven or eight hours before it was ≈øtinted; nor was he dre≈ø≈øed untill the next day, but yet he was cured in this manner. Fir≈øt the hair was ≈øhaven away round about the wounds on his head, and the wounds were made clean, then was there dropped into the wound, Bal≈øamum ≈øulphuris, made very warm, and a fine cloth wet therein was applyed to the wounds, and round about the wounds there was a Defen≈øative applyed, thus he was dre≈ø≈øed once in 24 hours, and within the ≈øpace of 3. weeks, he was perfectly helped, that he wore no plai≈øter at all. Al≈øo you ≈øhall note that upon the wound next the cloth, there was laid cerotum magi≈øtrale, of Leon. Phioravante; Forget not, that this Bal≈øom mu≈øt alwayes be u≈øed warm, with a fine linnen cloth, or a peece of Cambrick, and not with any lint. This Bal≈øam did cau≈øe the hair to grow
≈øo fa≈øt about the wounds, that it was fain to be ≈øhaven away very often.

div.head: CHAA. IX. Of contu≈øed wounds on the head, or other parts of the bodie
div.p: THe ancient Practitioners have e≈øteemed contu≈øed wounds to be very dangerous. For they ≈øay contu≈øions mu≈øt fir≈øt be brought to putrifaction, and turned into matter which opinion is not to be allowed, for the brui≈øes are to be di≈ø≈øolved without maturation, which hath been a thou≈øand times proved in the wars, after this manner to have been performed. ‚Ñû. Magno liquore, Oleum benedictum, ana, mix them, and being very hot, wet clothes therein, and lay thereon twice a day, and in three or four dayes they will be re≈øolved. Al≈øo the oyle of Frankincen≈øe, or Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Tereb. & Cera, will re≈øolve any ≈øimple brui≈øe in three or four houres, onely by continuall annointing the place therewith, ≈øo fa≈øt as it drinketh in any. Provided, that the brui≈øe be not above ≈øix or eight hours old, for if it be, then will your work be ≈øomewhat the longer before it be fini≈øhed.

div.head: CHAP. X. A contu≈øed wound on the head healed by I. P.
div.p: A Young man of 28. yeers of age, that had a great contu≈øion on the head with a ≈øtaffe, was helped thereof in 9 daies, by applying thereunto Bal≈øamum ≈øulphuris before mentioned.

div.head: CHAP. XI. A wound in the head, with fracture of the skull, cured by I. P.
div.p: A Little boy with a fall from a hor≈øe, had a fracture in the skull, which was healed with Bal≈øamum ≈øulphuris, & Cerotum Magi≈øtrale Leonardo. The child did at his dre≈ø≈øing, vomit very often, which argued the breaking of his ≈øcull, yet was he healed in ≈øeven dayes.

div.head: CHAP. XII. To heal wounds ≈øpeedily.
div.p: FIr≈øt wa≈øh them very well with our Aqua bal≈øami, then joyn them very clo≈øe together, and lay thereon a cloth wet in Oleo ro≈øini pini, and (through Gods help) they ≈øhall be quickly healed.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. To heal Wounds, by ≈øhot, or launce.
div.p: HE that will cure Wounds that are made with ≈øhot, launce, Arrowes, &c. mu≈øt fir≈øt wa≈øh the Wound well with urine, and dry the Wound well, then let him put therein the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, and forthwith joyn the Wound clo≈øe and hard together, then let him put immediately therein, five or ≈øix drops of our Bal≈øamo artificiato, and lay a cloth upon the Wound wet in Magno liquore, which mu≈øt be applyed ≈øo hot as he may ≈øuffer it; thus mu≈øt he doe the fir≈øt day. That being done, he mu≈øt put thereon our Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, and then a little Bal≈øamo, after that ≈øome Magno liquore (as before was ≈øaid) and ≈øo let him hold on unto the end of his cure.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. A mo≈øt ≈øingular and wonderfull remedy to heal Wounds quickly.
div.p: VVOunds mu≈øt be helped with drying Medicines, (as was noted in the third Chapter) ≈øuch Medicines, I ≈øay, as have vertue to pre≈øerve the part offended from putrefaction. This will be performed with our Aqua Bal≈øami, and the Oil di≈øtilled from Vern ‚Ä¢ ce liquid; for the≈øe two are apt to heal all ≈øorts of Wounds, if yee wa≈øh them with the water, and annoint them round about with the oil, for they doe not onely keep the Wounds from putrifying, but they help to ≈øiccatrize quickly, and in ≈øuch manner, as it ≈øeemeth marvellous, not onely mo≈øt profitable for the wounded Patient, but be≈øt for the good and hone≈øt Chirurgian, who abhorreth in his work to play the Tinker, which in ≈øtopping of one hole is wont to make three, but with as much ≈øafety and ≈øpeed as Nature and Art will yeeld, to bring to pa≈ø≈øe all his hone≈øt intentions.

div.head: CHAP. XV. A wound in the eye with a ≈øplinter, healed by W. H.
div.p:
A Splinter of wood leaped into the eye of a certain Maiden as ≈øhe was chopping of ≈øticks. The wound was ≈øo grievous,
that the gelly of her eye came forth by the ≈øpace of a moneth; all this while ≈øhe could neither ≈øee, nor take any re≈øt. By the ble≈ø≈øing of God, within four dayes after ≈øhe could thred a needle, and was recovered in this manner. Fir≈øt there was dropped into her eye Bal≈øamum Sulphuris warm, and then a cloth wet therein was applyed thereunto, by which onely ≈øhe was cured: the Maid dwelleth in Nottingham≈øhire.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. A prick in the eye with a knife, healed by W. H.
div.p: A Child of ≈øeven yeares of age had a puncture in the eye with a knife, which was cured by dropping therein Bal≈øamum Sulphuris warm, and laying a defen≈øative round about it.

div.head: Another cure performed in like manner, by W. H.
div.p: ONe George Clarke, ≈øervant to the right wor≈øhipfull Mr Butler of Denham (then high Sheriffe of Bedford) was healed of a puncture in his eye with the afore≈øaid Medicine.

div.head: An hand flat ≈øquatted and contu≈øed, healed by W. H. CHAP. XVII.
div.p: AN old man, called Thomas Smith, of Carlton in North-hampton≈øhire, Husbandman, in lopping of a tree had his hand caught between two boughs, and was ≈øquatted in peices; this contu≈øed hand was pre≈øently put clo≈øe together, and annointed with Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina, & Cera, and through Gods goodne≈ø≈øe, was perfectly cured in eight dayes.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. A wound or puncture through the arme. I. P.
div.p:
A Young man, called Hud≈øon, a Carpenter of Carlton in Northampton≈øhire, being thru≈øt through the arme with a
Pitch-forke, was thus cured. Fir≈øt there was injected Magno liquore (as hot as he could abide it) into the wound; then was there a linnen cloth wet in the ≈øame oyle applyed unto the wound, upon the which cloth was al≈øo laid a pledget of Cerotum magi≈øtrale; this wounded man was healed in five or ≈øix dayes.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Five wounds in the brea≈øt.
div.p: A Certain man that had five ≈øtocadoes into the body was thus cured. Fir≈øt there was put into the wounds the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Wine, then were the wounds dre≈ø≈øed with Bal≈øamo artificiato, which cau≈øed him to vomit, and to avoid much brui≈øed bloud; after that he drunk every morning a little Aqua Bal≈øami, and in ≈øhort time by Gods help was perfectly cured.

p.hi: The manner to ≈øtay any flux of bloud, or vein, you ≈øhall find in the 17. Chapter of the ≈øecond part of this Collection, and in the Secrets of Leonardo Phioravante, where he treateth of Wounds.

div.head: The Second Part of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion.
div.p: VErbum ≈øapienti ≈øat e≈øt, and a man may know by the halfe what the whole means; by the≈øe few experimented ≈øecrets, you may proceed unto the cure of any Wound, Contu≈øion, or Puncture, in what part of the body ≈øoever they ≈øhall be. The things wherewith you are to work, as Bal≈øamum Sulphuris, Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina & Cera, Cerottum magi≈øtrale, &c. you may have of Mr. William John≈øon dwelling in Amen Corner. Now let us proceed unto the experimented ≈øecrets, concerning Ulcers and Sores, either ≈øimple or complicate with di≈øea≈øes, as they have been ob≈øerved by tho≈øe which have proved them.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The healing of ≈øore mouthes.
div.p: THe Ulcers and Sores that have been in the mouthes of young and old, have been healed by the lotion or gargari≈øme made with Plantaine water, Hony-≈øuckle water, and Barly water, mixed with Saccarum Saturni.

div.p: A Certain Porter of London having an Ulcer on his upper lip, which was like a Cancer (≈øome called it Noli me tangere) continually running, with filthy ≈øtinking ≈øanies, was thus cured. Fir≈øt he was purged with Turpetum minerale, then was the ≈øore dre≈ø≈øed with this Medicine.

div.p: A Young woman that was much troubled in the throat with a greivous Ulcer, was thus cured. div.p:
A Woman had all her head covered with a mo≈øt ≈øilthy ≈øcab, which was dry above and moi≈øt underneath, very

Once in a day Oleum ligni Guaiaci was applyed, and in ≈øhort time the ≈øcall fell away, like a ≈øcull of an head, and there began hair to grow underneath it; this cure was performed in twelve dayes.

div.p: A Maiden of eighteen yeares of age, having an huge great ≈øcall upon her head, was cured (after ≈øhe had taken one do≈øe of Aromatico) by often wa≈øhing the part affected with Mater Bal≈øami Phioravante

div.p: ONe had ≈øuch a filthy and ≈øtinking Ulcer on the Thumb, that the Chirurgians would have cut off the whole Thumb. This party was afterward cured by the application of Fodicationum empla≈øtri.

div.p: A Young boy that had an ulcerated leg wonderfully ≈øwoln, was thus cured. He received at two ≈øeverall times Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive, with Sirrup of Ro≈øes; then were the ≈øores wa≈øhed with ≈øalt of Vitrioll di≈ø≈øolved in Plantaine water, a cloth being wet therein and applyed thereto morning and evening.
