div.p:
FIr≈øt this Patient was purged with Aromatico Leonardo once or twice, then his Ulcers were dre≈ø≈øed with this Un ‚Ä¢ uent made of rubified Vitrioll, and a Cerot called the great Cerot:
this was applyed unto the Ulcers, with a pledget of Lint, and was ≈øuffered to lye four and twent ‚Ä¢ hours, which mortified the ≈øores; then was more of the ≈øame Unguent applyed, and with an In≈øtrument the e≈øcare was loo≈øed round about, and in three or foure dayes, the e≈øcare came away ea≈øily with a paire of Mullets: then he healed it up with Magno Liquore, and Saccarum plumbi, within a little while after.

div.head: CHAP XXVII. Three ∆≤lcers in the legs healed by W. H.
div.p: A Certaine woman of Bedford, had three Ulcers in her leg, who had ≈øought her cure at the hands of divers, the ≈øpace of four years, but could find no helpe, yet ≈øhe was afterward cured in this manner. Fir≈øt, ≈øhee took in the morning fa≈øting Aromatico Leonardo, which evacuated her ≈øtomack and belly. Then was there applyed unto the ≈øores Saccarum plumbi, three or foure dayes together, which cau≈øed every day a certaine thinne skinne to come upon the Ulcers, much like the filme of an egge, the ≈øame skin was taken away every day: with this Medicine following, it was dre≈ø≈øed the fourth day, which cau≈øed it to look faire and red the next dre≈ø≈øing: and ≈øo in ≈øhort time it was perfectly cured. To one ≈øpoonfull of Magno Liquore was put as much Saccarum Saturni, as would lye upon a three-pence; and ≈øo it was incorporated warme: the ≈øores were dre≈ø≈øed therewith every day.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. The cure of old rotten ≈øores by W. R.
div.p: A Certain old woman, did in this manner helpe divers old ≈øores in the body. Fir≈øt ≈øhe purged the Patients, and then ≈øhe applyed this unguent to the ≈øores. Take a pot of ≈øtrong Ale, and ≈øet it to boyle over a gentle fire, till it wax thicke like a ≈øalve, and then u≈øe it. At the fir≈øt this Medicine will ≈ømart, and be ≈øomewhat painefull to bear; neverthele≈ø≈øe it will clean≈øe and heale.

Note. Al≈øo a friend of mine told me, that the juyce of
Marigold leaves, or the leaves boyled with milke to an Unguent, will heal all Ulcers and Wounds.

div.head: CHAP XXIX. The healing of ∆≤lcers in mo≈øt parts of the body: but chiefly in the head by W. H.
div.p: A Certain man being full of Ulcers, coming of the Pox, in mo≈øt parts of his body ≈øhewing them≈øelves, but chiefly in the head, was cured in this manner. Fir≈øt, he was purged twi≈øe or thrice, with Panch ‚Ä¢ magogon, after that, hee kept his Chamber, (that had a good fire in it) and took ≈øix graines of Turpetum diaphoreticum, mixed with í. i. of Amul ‚Ä¢ tum Palmarij. Halfe an houre before he took a draught of fat broth, and kept his bed; and alwayes as he vomited, hee wa≈øhed his mouth with a convenient Gargari≈øme, and ≈øweat thereon one houre or two, and then was dryed with warme clothes: That done, he repo≈øed a day or two, and took the afore≈øaid Turpetum againe, in manner afore≈øaid: this he did three or foure times. In the mean while, he annointed his Ulcers with oleum Guaiaci, which did both clen≈øe, and heale. Al≈øo divers times, hee u≈øed this Potion in the morning, which cau≈øed him to ≈øweat. ‚Ñû. ‚Ñ•. ii. of the water of Lignum vitae, made by di≈øtillation, and as much of the Sirrup of Fumitorie, and ‚Ñà. i. of the ≈øalt of Lignum vitae, mix them warme, and drink it fa≈øting. Thus in very ≈øhort time he was cured. This one thing mu≈øt not be forgotten, that when there ≈øhall come any inflammation or ≈øorene≈ø≈øe in the mouth, you doe u≈øe this Gargari≈øme following. Take Plaintaine water, honey ≈øuckle water, ana, ‚Ñ•. iiij. Barly water, ‚Ñ•. vi. mel ro≈øarum ‚Ñ•. ii. ≈øs. Diamor ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ñ•. ii. Oleum vitrioli, as much as will make it tart: this will heale any ≈øore in the mouth. Remember al≈øo, that if the Ulcers be very corro≈øive and foule, you ≈øhall touch them once or twi≈øe, with Oleum vitrioli, or Oleum tartari faetentis, whereby they will heal the ≈øooner, this hath been often proved.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. The healing of ≈øcabs, like the Lepro≈øie, by G. M.
div.p: A Young man (which was thought to be infected with a Lepro≈øie) had on his head, and mo≈øt parts of his body, hard and dry ≈øcabs, but hee was cured in this manner. Fir≈øt, hee was purged with Aromatico Leonardo once or twi≈øe. Then every morning till he was cured, he took ‚Ñà i. of the extract of Camepiteos, either in a Pill, or in drinke as hee thought good. After that his ≈øores were dre≈ø≈øed with this Unguent. ‚Ñû. Succi ≈øempervivi ‚Ñ•. ii. Succi plantaginis, ‚Ñ•. iiii. ≈øs. Succi ≈øolani, ‚Ñ•. iii. Sacchari Saturni, ‚Ñ•. ii. ≈øs. mix them, and ≈øtirre them well together over a gentle fire, till all the Saccharum be di≈ø≈øolved, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe the ≈øores twi≈øe a day.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. The healing of a Child, that was full of ∆≤lcers, coming of the Pox.
div.p: A Young child four yeares old that was grievou≈øly tormented with the French di≈øea≈øe, having extreme paine in the body, and being full of ≈øores, was thus cured ‚Ñû. the di≈øtilled water of Lignum vitae, ‚Ñ• i, Salis eju≈ødem, í. i. mix them, and thereof the Child dranke, with Sirrup of Fumitorie or Hops, morning and evening, and ≈øometime the Child ≈øweat thereon. Al≈øo the ≈øores were annointed with this Unguent, ‚Ñû. Oleum guaiaci, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. Bal≈øamum Sulphuris, í. ≈øs. Saccarum plumbi, í. ≈øs. Oleum camphorae, five or ≈øix drops, the caput mortuum of Aqua fortis, ‚Ñà. i. Mix them well, and grind them on a ≈øtone with May butter, and therewith the ≈øores were annointed morning and evening.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. A Cancer cured by an old Empericke.
div.p:
A Certaine Empericke did help many Cancers, in divers people (that were troubled with them) after this manner. Hee took certaine wormes called in Latine Centumpedes, in Engli≈øh ≈øowes: they are ≈øuch as lye under old timber, or between the
barke and the tree. The≈øe he ≈øtamped, and ≈øtrained with Ale, and gave the Patient to drinke thereof morning and evening. This Medicine cau≈øed many times a certain black bugge, or worme to come forth, which had many legs, and was quick; and after that the Cancer would heale quickly with any convenient Medicine.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. The healing of pockie Pu≈øtulaes, with Serpigo by W.H.
div.p: A Certaine man having a number of ≈øores all over his body' and a Serpigo in the palme of his hand, ≈øo grievous, that a man might have laid great ≈øtrawes therein, was healed in this manner. Fir≈øt he was purged three times with ≈øix graines of Turpetum minerale Phadronis, mixed with halfe a Drachm of Amuletum Palmarij. That done, hee annointed all his ≈øores twi≈øe ot thri≈øe with Oleum Tartari faetentis; afterward with ∆≤nguentum ex Lithargirio Phioravante. Now touching his hands, which had the Serpigo, he held them morning and evening over a bath of oats, or ≈øome warme hearbs, that they might ≈øweat; and then annointed them with Bal≈øamum Sulphuris, and in ≈øhort time they were helped. An Unguent made with Saccarum Saturni, and oyle of Ro≈øes, will doe the like effect.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIIII. A Tetter or Ring-worme, cured by W. K.
div.p: THere is a certaine Worme or Tetter, which many times cometh on the back of the hand or arme, and doth corrode like a Serpigo, but it is none; which (after the u≈øe of many other Medicines) hath been cured in this manner. The place was annointed five or ≈øix times a day, with the Sirrup of Sugar, that the Worm might come to the upper place or skin; then within three or foure dayes after, hee annointed the place with Oleum Tartari faetentis; and in ≈øhort time he was cured, though his di≈øea≈øe had continued three years, coming and going. Some have killed the Worme with Oleum vitrioli.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. A man cured that was full of Tetters.
div.p: THis was the manner of his cure. He took the rennet of a Calfe, and dranke it in milke three or foure times, and ≈øweat thereupon; then he annointed the parts affected with Saccarum Saturni, mixed with oyle of Ro≈øes warme.

div.head: CHAP XXXVI. Totters in Womens brea≈øts, oftentimes cured as followeth.
div.p: THey took five ≈øpoonfulls of Madder, and boyled it in ale, and then ≈øtrained it clear, without pre≈ø≈øing it at all, and drank thereof three or four mornings; then with the fore≈øaid oyntmnet they u≈øed to annoint the parts grieved, and thereupon (with Gods help) were quickly healed.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. The healing of Shingles.
div.p: THey took for them Doves dung newly made, and barly meale, ≈øtamped them well, and mixed them with halfe a pint of Vinegar; they u≈øed it cold to the place grieved, and applyed vine leaves (to keep in the Liquor) round about it. Then they bound it up with clothes, and ≈øuffered it to lye three dayes, and then (if need were) refre≈øhed it againe with a new Plai≈øter, and at the mo≈øt, with the u≈øe of three Applications, it was perfectly helped.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. The breaking of a plague ≈øore, by W. K.
div.p: HEe took of Elder leaves, as much as was ≈øufficient, hee ≈øtamped them very well with dry figs, and put thereto auxungiae porcinae, and applyed it warme to the ≈øore, three or foure times a day, and quickly brake it.

div.head: CHAP XXXIX. Scabs, and Itch, with ≈ømall Pu≈øtulaes, taken quite away by I. H.
div.p: A Certain man greatly troubled with itch and pu≈øtulaes in his hands, proceeding of a di≈ø≈øolved ≈øalt in his body, could find no help till he u≈øed this cour≈øe. He took Panchimagogon twice in three dayes; that done, he wa≈øhed his hands with the ≈øalt of Vitrioll di≈ø≈øolved in Plantaine water, and ≈øhortly after they went quite away.

div.head: CHAP. XL. Three deep Fi≈øtulaes in the brea≈øt, cured by W. T.
div.p: THere was a certain man, called R. B. dwelling in London, which having three deep Fi≈øtulaes in his brea≈øt, had been long under the hands of unskilfull Chirurgians, con≈øuming both him≈øelfe and his ≈øub≈øtance; but afterward by Gods help, he u≈øing the cour≈øe that W. T. pre≈øcribed, was cured very ≈øpeedily. Fir≈øt he was purged every ≈øecond or third day, for five or ≈øix times together with Turpetum minerale Phaedronis, receiving thereof five or ≈øix grains in Amul. Palmarii; afterward he was cau≈øed to ≈øweat five or ≈øix times with this potion following.

‚Ñû. The di≈øtilled water of Lignum vitae ‚Ñ•. ii. Salis eju≈ødem ‚Ñà. i. water of Carduus benedictus ‚Ñ•. ii. which being mixed, he drunk it warm in the morning, and ≈øweat thereon two houres. After he was purged, he dre≈ø≈øed the Fi≈øtulaes two houres with this Unguent (untill they were mundified) upon tents of ≈øhoe-leather. When the Fi≈øtulaes were clean≈øed, he dre≈ø≈øed them onely with Empla≈øtrum Fodicationis (being made liquid to wrap up the tent with) till they were whole.

div.head: The mundificative Ointment was this.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Oil of Wax, of S ‚Ä¢ ccinum, of Guaiacum, Oleum Hypericon, Compo≈øitum, ana. í. ii. mix them without fire, and u≈øe it with the afore≈øaid tents. Al≈øo you ≈øhall note, that he drunk no other drink then this all the while. ‚Ñû. Lignum vitae, the bark, Sar≈øaparilla, ana. ‚Ñ•. iv. the roots of Tormentill, Bi≈øtorta, Virga pa≈øtoris, Licorice,
corice, ana. ‚Ñ•. ii, Juniper berries ‚Ñ•. i. Mallow leaves, Sanicle, Alchimilla, Mugwort, Hypericon, Brunella, Comfery, ana. M. ii. Bring the≈øe into powder, and for every gallon of new tunned drink, adde thereto two or three ounces of this powder in a linnen cloth; let it ≈øtand till it be ≈øtale, and let him drink thereof.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. The cure of Lichen, or Impetigo, by M. K.
div.p: A Certain Maiden 17. yeares old, had all the fle≈øh on her thumb and fore-finger eaten away with the afore≈øaid di≈øea≈øe, which was cured by ≈øtrewing thereon Saccarum Saturni, and applying thereto Cerottum magi≈øtrale Phioravante.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. A great Wen taken away, by W. H.
div.p: ONe that was troubled with a great Wen, had it taken away by wa≈øhing it with ≈øtrong lye made of oaken a≈øhes. I have been ≈øince told of a certainty, that if yee rub the Wen often with the hand of a dead man, untill the Wen wax hot, it will con≈øume away in ≈øhort time after. Some ro≈øt an Egge hard, and cut it in the mid≈øt, and lay it thereon, and u≈øing this often the Wen will wear away.

div.head: The Second Part concerning the Cures of internall di≈øea≈øes.
div.p:
Thus much breifly in the≈øe ≈øhort Chapters is expre≈ø≈øed and declared, concerning Wounds and ∆≤lcers, where≈øoever they be, or how≈øoever they ari≈øe; by which examples, the learned Arti≈øt may undertake other things which are not here mentioned: But in any ea≈øe let him be advi≈øed by the wi≈øe Phi≈øitian in his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, when there is any difficulty, and not run by and by to his receipt or
experiment. It followeth now (in manner afore≈øaid) to ≈øet down the ob≈øerved practi≈øes of tho≈øe that have cured internall di≈øea≈øes, which have taken effect, and brought forth ≈øymptomes outwardly or inwardly.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the cure of greivous Aches and pains, performed by W. H.
div.p: A Certain man was greatly afflicted with divers wofull Aches, and paines in his knees and ≈øhoulders, who was cured by receiving a do≈øe of Aromatico, and by application of Empla≈øtrum faetidum unto the greived parts.

div.head: CHAP. II. The healing of Aches coming of the Pox, by W. H.
div.p: ONe of a very dark and melancholy complexion, to whom ≈øome men in London had given the fume, and the unction three or four times; and yet left him po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with mo≈øt pittifull Aches, and paine in his joynts; who for want of maintenance, was inforced to goe into the country where he was born, and was there pittied of an hone≈øt Gentleman, which cured him in this ≈øort. Fir≈øt he purged him twice or thrice with Aromatico Leonardo, which done, he took, for four or five dayes together, í. ≈øs. of the extract of Hermodactiles with white Wine; then unto the articular parts that were greived, he applyed Empla≈øtrum faetidum, W. H. and thus in ≈øhort time he was healed throughly.

div.head: CHAP. III. A notable experience of a Medicine that hath brought great ea≈øe to any great Ach, or pain, as of the Gout, or otherwi≈øe.
div.p: TAke one or two of the foremo≈øt ≈øucking whelps of a Ma≈øtiff, or Bear-bitch, kill them, and take forth the guts, fill them with black Snails, ro≈øt them, and ba≈øt them with ‚Ñ•. xii. of oil of Spike coloured with Saffron; re≈øerve that which droppeth from them, and mix it with as much oil of Wax, and therewith annoint any ach or greife.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. A particular way, whereby the pain of the Gout is ≈øoon ea≈øed or prevented, S. N.
div.p: TAke Minium, the yolk of an Egg, oil of Tartar, oil of Ro≈øes, as much of each as you think ≈øufficient, and with a little Saffron make it in form of a plai≈øter, and lay it on cold. I knew another Gentleman greivou≈øly vexed with the Gout, who was in this ≈øort ≈øoon ea≈øed. Fir≈øt when he ≈øuppo≈øed that the pain would come, he took a do≈øe of Aromatico Leonardo, then the next day, unto tho≈øe greived parts he applyed this plai≈øter. Take a pickle herring and cut forth the bone, ≈øtamp it very ≈ømall with a little bole Armoniacke, and Ro≈øewater, and apply it cold to the greife, from place to place as it goeth. Many men after they have been well purged, have had great ea≈øe by annointing the place three or four nights together with Aqua Bal≈øami Phioravante, al≈øo Oleum Cerae is very profitable in that ca≈øe.

div.head: CHAP V. The cure of Gouts, and all Aches coming of heat, by L. F.
div.p: FIr≈øt the Patients were purged with Aromatico, then was this plai≈øter applyed, which is attractive, re≈øiccative, re≈øolutive, as being intentions farre better fitting that purpo≈øe, then any other. Take the marrow of the bones of a Calfe newly killed, lb. i. Vitrioll in manner rubified, lb. i. ≈øs. Cantharides, in fine powder, ‚Ñ•. i. the a≈øhes of the Vine, ‚Ñ•. vi. mix them all on a ≈ømall fire, untill they be incorporated, then with oyle of wax, make it in a liquid ointment, and ≈øpread it on a cloth, and lay it on cold; and when it waxeth dry chafe it till the pain be cea≈øed; this hath ea≈øed many in a ≈øhort time

div.head: CHAP. VI. The remedie again≈øt the Scorbute, or Scurvy, and the Gout, by W. T.
div.p:
A Young man ≈øix and twenty yeares of age, mightily troubled with the Gout and Scurvy, was after this ≈øort cured.
Fir≈øt he was purged with Aromatico Leonardo, then he u≈øed the purging drink following every morning, that he might have each day three or four ≈øtooles, at night he took ‚Ñ•. ii. of the di≈øtilled water of Lignum vitae with ‚Ñ•. i. of the Sirrup of Cow≈ølips; al≈øo he u≈øed to eat the≈øe con≈øerves following mixed together; ‚Ñû. Con≈øerve of Cow≈ølips ‚Ñ•. iiii. of Sage, of Ro≈øemary floures, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. of red Ro≈øes ‚Ñ•. i. the quantity which he took at once, was as much as a Walnut; al≈øo he annointed the greived parts with this Unguent; ‚Ñû. Auxungiae humanae di≈øtilled ‚Ñ•. ii. Oil of Turpentine ‚Ñ•. ii. of Wax ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. mix them together; al≈øo in his u≈øuall drink, which he drunk with his meat, was mixed Chamepiteos, Sage, Ro≈øemary and Betony, this was the purging drink; ‚Ñû. the ≈øtrong decoction of Lignum vitae, put therein of the leaves of Sena ‚Ñ•. iv. Epithemum ‚Ñ•. ii. Hermodactiles ‚Ñ•. iv. Turbith ‚Ñ•. i. Coloquintida ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. let them ≈øtand in warm ≈øand four and twenty houres, and ≈øtrain it, this he drunk in the morning fa≈øting.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Tumours in all parts of the body, taken away by R. A.
div.p:
THis was ≈øent me by a freind of mine, who had ≈øeen the experience thereof divers times. Fir≈øt he purged the Patients twice with Aromatico Leonardo, then he gave unto them ‚Ñ•. ii. of Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive, with ‚Ñ•. i. of Sirrup of Ro≈øes, four or five mornings together, and after it they drank a little good broth made ≈øweet with Sugar; that done, they drunk this water following: ‚Ñû. Hearb-gra≈ø≈øe, Sothernwood, Mugwort, Wormwood, ana. M. i. Juniper berries three or four handfull, cut the hearbs, and brui≈øe the berries, and infu≈øe them in a gallon of white Wine Vinegar four and twenty houres in a warme place; then di≈øtill it with a gentle fire; this done, take that di≈øtilled Vinegar, and infu≈øe therein fre≈øh hearbs and berries, and di≈øtill it again as before: Doe ≈øo the third time, and di≈øtill it as before. At the la≈øt infu≈øion you ≈øhall put therein ‚Ñ•. iiii. of good Mithridate or Triacle, and di≈øtill them together, and keep them clo≈øe to your u≈øe. Thereof the Patients took at four a clock in the morning four ounces very
warm, whereupon they layd them down and ≈øweat two or three houres, alway wiping it away with warm clothes. Every ≈øweating time they changed their ≈øhirts. When this medicine was mini≈øtred to a woman, ≈øhe took but two ounces thereof. To a child he gave two ounces. In this ≈øort he cured not onely Tumors, but Sores, Pu≈øtulaes, Fevers, Jaundies, &c.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Swelling of the Coddes, mittigated and re≈øolved by R. A.
div.p: A Certaine man riding on a trotting hor≈øe, had his ≈øtones ≈øwollen as big as ones fi≈øt, who was thus helped. Fir≈øt, he was purged once or twi≈øe with Panchimagogon, then this Catapla≈øme was applied warm unto the part twi≈øe or thri≈øe a day. ‚Ñû. the crums of Brown-bread, Bean-flower, ana. as mcuh as is ≈øufficient, boyl them with new wort; when it is almo≈øt boyled, put thereto a little Commin-≈øeed, and a di≈øh of fre≈øh Butter, and ≈øo applie it warm. I have ≈øeen the fat of an hor≈øe, to have cured the fore≈øaid griefe.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take a pint of pure honey, as much bean-flower, and two ≈øpoonfuls of vinegar, of Commin-≈øeed, ‚Ñ•. ii. mix them well together, and ≈øpread it on a cloth, and warm it a little again≈øt the fire, and apply it.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The cure of a painfull I≈øchiatica, by I. H.
div.p: A Certaine man that was grievou≈øly troubled with the I≈øchiatica, was healed in this manner. Fir≈øt, he was purged with Aromatico, then he took for five or ≈øix mornings together, two drachms of Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive with Sirrup of Ro≈øes, and after the taking thereof, he drank a little ≈øweet broth. That done, he drew a bli≈øter with Cantharides, and Oleum de terebinthina & cera; and in ≈øhort time he was helped. Since which time I have known three or four per≈øons helped in the ≈øame manner, by annointing the grieved parts with Aqua bal≈øami Phioravante.

div.head: CHAP. X. An excellent remedie again≈øt the Cramp, proved often by R. G.
div.p: THey that were affected therewith, did upon the bare skin and places grieved, weare the root of common flagg. Al≈øo the skins of twenty ≈øilver Eeles, new flaied, and chopped ≈ømall, boiled in two pound of May-Butter, and four handfuls of Rue, ≈øcumme it well, and annoint the place therewith, and this will work the ≈øame effect. A wor≈øhipfull Gentleman that had divers times proved the ≈øame, ≈øent the≈øe notes unto me.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Contraction or ≈øhrinking of ≈øinews, with Con≈øumption of the party, helped by W. H.
div.p: A Man ≈øix and twenty years old, having a ≈øore and grievous ulcerated leg, fell into the hands of inexpert Chirurgians, who with their Corro≈øives ≈øhrunk up his ≈øinews, that he could neither go nor ≈øtand, but in ≈øhort time after he was cured in this manner. He was once purged with Aromatico, then he took Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive two or three dayes together in ≈øirrup of Ro≈øes, and drank thereupon a little broth. Then did he u≈øe the Bath following divers times, and annointed him with the ointment again≈øt contraction of ≈øinewes, de≈øcribed by Leonardo Phioravante. Another man having his hand ≈øhrunk together upon the like occa≈øion, was healed in the ≈øame order. This is the de≈øcription of the Bath. Take two or three young whelps that cannot ≈øee, boil them in water with Mallowes, Hollihock, Mellilot, Wallwort, Cammomil. ana. one handfull: boil the Whelps till the fle≈øh fall from the bones, this done, ≈øtrain it, and u≈øe to bathe therewith very warm.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The cure of one who≈øe neck was drawn awry, performed by W. T.
div.p: A Child had her neck drawn awry with a kind of Convul≈øion, or Cramp, called Tetanus, and was thus cured. Fir≈øt ≈øhe drank every morning and evening a little Aqua bal≈øami Phioravante, then was her neck annointed with ≈øome of the ≈øaid water mixed with Magno liquore Phioravante, and in ten dayes ≈øhe was cured.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame, by W. T.
div.p: TAke Oleum de lateribus, ‚Ñ•. i, Oleum Terebinthinae, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. of Juniper Berries, í. ii. of Cloves, í. i. Nutmegs, Mace, ana. í. ≈øs. mixe them with Oleum Cerae, q.s. to make it in form of a liniment, and therewith annoint the parts.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The Squinancy cured by I. P.
div.p: THis Medicine following did help one that was ≈øo ≈øwoln and grievou≈øly pained, that he could ≈øcarcely eat or drink. ‚Ñû. Olei Philo≈øophorum de lateribus, ‚Ñ•. ii. Olei lini í. vi. Olei Cerae, ‚Ñ•. i. mixe them warm, and annoint the place affected oftentimes in the day. Al≈øo one drachm of the tooth of a wild Boare, being drunk with ‚Ñ•. iii. of oyle of Lin≈øeed, doth help it pre≈øently.
Al≈øo another man was forthwith cured thereof, which drank one ≈øpoonfull of Aqua bal≈øami, and wetting a cloth therein, applied it to his throate.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. The cure of Alopecia, by I. P.
div.p:
MAgno liquore Phioravente, being annointed on the head, cau≈øeth the haires to grow againe abundantly which are
fallen away, and to wax black. Bal≈øamum ≈øulphuris al≈øo doth the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. XV. A gargari≈øme to purge the head, by I. S.
div.p: TAke Spikenard, Ali≈øander ≈øeed, ana. ‚Ñ•. i. beat them into powder, and boile them in Vinegar till half be con≈øumed, Then ≈øtrain it, and put thereto lb. ≈øs. of Mu≈øtard, and ‚Ñ•. iii. of Ro≈øe water, boil it a little, keep it clo≈øe to thy u≈øe, and when you will, you may take a ≈øpoonfull warm in the morning, and gargle therewith.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. The Pinne and Web, cured by M. R.
div.p: HE took an handfull of Centumpedes, or Sowes, ≈øtamped, and ≈øtrained them with Ale, and gave the Patient to drink thereof three or four mornings, and willed the Patient to ≈øtop his no≈øe and mouth, and to hang down his head, and therewith he was healed, as I was credibly certified.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. A water for ≈øore eyes, prooved by M. E.
div.p: A Gentlewoman with this water hath cured a very great number of ≈øore eyes. She took an Egg hard ≈øodden, cut it in the midd≈øt, and took forth the yolk, and put thereto as much white Copperice as a Nut: Then ≈øhe clo≈øed it together, and wrapped it in red Fennell, and laid it to ≈øteep foure and twenty houres in Ro≈øe-water, then ≈øhe ≈øtrained it hard through a cloth, and dropped it into the eyes morning and evening; it was held for a great ≈øecret.

div.head: Another manner of way to heal the Pinne and Web in the eyes.
div.p:
TAke nine of the Wormes called Centumpedes, or Sowes, ≈øtamp and ≈øtrain them with the juice of Wood-bine, or Betony
for three or four mornings together warm: which being drank will con≈øume the Web in the eye.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. The ≈øtaying of the bleeding at the no≈øe, done by M. R.
div.p: TAke burnt Lome, M. ii. ≈øharp Vinegar, lb. ≈øs. mix them well, and lay it between a linnen cloth: and bind it to the forehead cold, and in ≈øhort ≈øpace it will ≈øtint.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame, I. H.
div.p: A Man of fifty yeares of age had a great flux of bloud at the no≈øtrill, which had continued a long time, and could find no remedie till he u≈øed this order and medicine following. Fir≈øt his ring finger was bound hard with a thread, then was this catapla≈øme following applied to his forehead and temples.

Take burnt lome made in powder, M. vi. ≈øtrong Vinegar, as much as will ≈øuffice to make it in form of a Catapla≈øme, to be applyed cold, thus in few hours the bloud ≈øtinted. Neverthele≈ø≈øe he took morning and evening the fume of Succinum album at the mouth and no≈øe, which ≈øtayed the flux, and comforted the vitall and animall ≈øpirits. His diet was cold and drying, his drink was water or red wine, wherein was put Crocus martis.

div.head: Another kind of curing the ≈øame performed by D. B.
div.p: ONe bleeding at the no≈øe a day and a night, was thus helpped. He made a tent of lint, and dipped it in Inke and put it into his no≈øtrils, and laid a defen≈øative over his eyes and no≈øe, made with Sanguis Draconis, bole armoniack, and a little Vinegar.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: MAny have been cured by applying unto their cods a linen cloath wet in Vinegar.

div.head: Another.
div.p: SOme have had the bleeding ≈øtinted, by applying the hearb Peruinca unto the no≈øe.

div.head: Other waies to do the ≈øame.
div.p: CArduus Benedictus brui≈øed and put up into the no≈øtrils, ≈øtinteth the bleeding at no≈øe. The ≈øame it performeth in a wound.
The hearb Geranium which hath a red ≈øtalk, being put into the no≈øtrils or wound, doth the ≈øame: very often prooved.
In like manner, and to the ≈øame effect, worketh Crocus martis.
Al≈øo the bloud of a man dried worketh after the ≈øame order: both for the ≈øtaying of bloud at the no≈øe and in a wound.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Spitting of bloud ≈øtayed by I. H.
div.p: A Certain woman ≈øpit bloud three or four dayes in great quantity, who was cured by drinking the decoction of mints in Vinegar.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: AL≈øo five or ≈øix drops of Oleum Ma≈øtick, drunk in Cinnamon-water, ≈øtaieth the ≈øpitting of bloud.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The falling down of the ∆≤vula, and the inflammation of the Almonds, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that they could not ≈øwallow their meat, nor fetch their breath well, cured by W. T.
div.p: TAke white Amber gro≈øly beaten í. i. and with a Funnell take the fume thereof ca≈øt on a few coales, morning, noon, and night; then take ‚Ñ•. i. of old leaven, and ≈øpread it plai≈øterwi≈øe on a cloth, ≈øtrew thereon a little Commin-≈øeed, and the powder of white Amber, and apply it half an hands breadth to the crown of the head the ≈øpace of a whole day, then at night lay on another, and in ≈øhort time it will take away the ≈øwelling, often proved.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. The cure of the Hicket, by W. B.
div.p: ONe that was divers times greivou≈øly troubled with the Hicket, was cured by applying a brown to≈øt warm to his ≈øtomack; the to≈øt was ≈øteeped in Triacle and Aqua vitae.

div.head: Another.
div.p: DIvers have been cured thereof, by taking four or five grains of Labdanum no≈øtrum in Wine or Malm≈øey.

div.head: CHAP XXII. The falling Sickne≈ø≈øe cured by W. H.
div.p: A Certain woman being a Barbers wife in Bedford≈øhire, which was greived therewith every change of the Moon, was pre≈øerved by taking each day three drops of Oleum Heraclei, with the extract of Peoniae.

div.head: Another performed by I. H.
div.p:
FIr≈øt you ≈øhall purge them with the extract of Helleborus niger; the do≈øe whereof is from eight graines to twelve, being
before well corrected, and then drunk in ≈øome convenient liquor or potion. That done, he gave them morning and evening of this compo≈øition: the which the longer that they u≈øe, the better it will be for them. ‚Ñû. E≈ø≈øentiae Peoniae, con≈øerve of Ro≈øemary flouers, of Betony, ana q. v. mixe them togegether in form of an electuary: then adde thereto for every ounce of that compo≈øition, of olenm cran ii humani ‚Ñà. i. and ‚Ñà. ≈øs. of oile of Ro≈øemary-flouers, and twelve graines of oleum vitrioli. Hereof let them take ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. at a time, either by it ≈øelf, or with ≈øome convenient liquor, broth, or potion. Al≈øo the nape of the neck mu≈øt be annointed with Oleum ca≈øtorei: when they do fall, you ≈øhall annoint their no≈øtrils with oleum ≈øuccinum, for that will in ≈øhort time recover them againe. It will be al≈øo very expedient to u≈øe tho≈øe things that comfort the brain and the heart.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. The cure of the Jaundi≈øe by I. P.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of pain in the head.
div.p: THe pain in the head is an infirmity, who≈øe cau≈øe untill this time hath not been ≈øufficiently known, as by mine own experience ≈øhall prove unto you.

All, or the mo≈øt part of Phy≈øitians in the world doe hold this po≈øition, that pain in the head is no other thing, then vapours ar ‚Ä¢ ≈øing from the ≈øtomack, and a≈øcending unto the head, which doe offend membrana, whereupon en≈øueth pain. Herein they ≈øpeak ≈øome part of the truth; but (in my judgement)
they are not yet come perfectly to know all the cau≈øe of this infirmity: for I ≈øee, that in the cures, which the≈øe Theoricks would perform, it falleth not out according to their expectation and de≈øire, for that they know not the whole, or the principall cau≈øe of the malady, therefore what certain Medicine can they find out to cure the infirmity? They may perchance (as the blind man hits the Crow) help they know not what; which thing I ≈øpeak not to back-bite or injury any of them, but to tell them, out of love that I bear to them and others, the whole and true cau≈øe of that, whereof heretofore they have been ignorant. The fir≈øt cau≈øe is putrified bloud in Leonichi: The ≈øecond is the vapours that a≈øcend from the ≈øtomack and offend the head: The third is the humidity or moi≈øture between the skin and the fle≈øh: So that the cau≈øes are three, and the remedies as many to di≈ø≈øolve the Antecedent cau≈øes. I have now ≈øhewed thee the originall and root of the pain in the head, about which thou ≈øhalt never more need to beat thy head, or break thy brains, either in ≈øeeking the Aphori≈ømes of Hyppocrates, the Commentary of Galen, or the Authority of Avicen, for in the≈øe four or few words I have ≈øaid all. Now of the cure of this di≈øea≈øe, as I have experimented the ≈øame an infinite ≈øort of times in my life, which way ≈øoever the cau≈øe cometh, work thou after this manner, and thou ≈øhalt never ≈øu≈øtain blame or di≈øcredit.

When the pain in the head is confirmed, and that thou can≈øt find no help by common Theorick or Practick doe the≈øe things following. Fir≈øt let them bloud on Leonichie, cutting it overthwart, and let the Patient ≈øpit as much as he can; then the next morning let them take our Aromatico fa≈øting; the next day let the head be ≈øhaven, and lay thereon an attractive plai≈øter, drawing out the humidity, whereof I have made mention in my Caprici medicinale; in the end, cau≈øe them to ≈øneeze, and hereby all the pain in the head will cea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Catarre, and rhume in the head.
div.p:
THe Catarre is a moi≈øt vapour which a≈ø≈øaulteth the head, and afterwards falleth down again into the ≈øtomack, where
it ingro≈ø≈øeth and corrupteth. This moi≈øture hath his beginning of the moi≈øture of the Lungs, and untill ≈øuch time as the Lungs be di≈øcharged thereof, the Catarre will continue in his force. This infirmity reigneth more in flegmatick and melancholy bodies, then in any of other con≈øtitutions: Such as are troubled with it are not long lived, becau≈øe their Lungs con≈øume by little and little, and thereupon they are troubled with the Pti≈øick, and con≈øequently they peri≈øh if they be not quickly releived. I will now ≈øhew thee a rare ≈øecret to cure the ≈øame.

Take Pulmonaria, and Sena, that is fre≈øh and new, infu≈øe them in wine and water over a ≈ømall or gentle fire, till the wine have drawn out the vertue; then ≈øtrain it, and put thereunto our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and keep it clo≈øe in a gla≈ø≈øe, let the Patient drink thereof every morning ‚Ñ•. iii. luke warm for twenty dayes together; let him eat good nouri≈øhing meats, for they agree well with this di≈øea≈øe: If the Patient be not too farre ≈øpent, you ≈øhall ≈øee your cure performed in ≈øhort time: In the mean while, if the Patient be weak, you ≈øhall give him new laid Eggs, and good white Wine: If the humidity be perceived not to be quite expelled and evacuated, then give him our Aromatico, afterward comfort him again with Re≈øtoratives and Cordials to make him ≈øtrong, and no doubt, by the help of God he ≈øhall be cured. This method of curing this infirmity, differeth from the common cour≈øe that Phy≈øitians take, which would cure it with diet, bleeding, and mollifying liniments, and cau≈øing them to ≈øpit, and ≈øuch like, which are meanes rather to augment the Catarre, then to dimini≈øh the ≈øame.

div.head: The ≈øecond cour≈øe to cure the de≈øcen≈øion, that cometh from the head to the ≈øtomack.
div.p:
USe the≈øe five things if you will cure this di≈øea≈øe; 1. our Electuario Angelica. 2. Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive. 3. our Pillulae pro de≈øcen≈øo. 4. ∆≤nguents for the ≈øtomack and head. 5. our Quinte≈ø≈øence vegetable. The Electuary clean≈øeth the head and ≈øtomack; the Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive evacuateth the body; the Pills take away the cau≈øe of the de≈øcen≈øion; the Unguents
dry; and the vegetable Quinte≈ø≈øence pre≈øerveth the body from all ill and noy≈øome infirmities. The Electuary mu≈øt be taken fir≈øt in the morning; of the Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive you mu≈øt take a ≈øpoonfull in the morning in a little broth and ≈øugar, keeping a rea≈øonable good diet, and doe this four or ≈øix dayes; then take the Pills in the evening, and in the mean time annoint the head and ≈øtomack with Oleum Cerae, and drink every morning a little of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, which if you doe u≈øe continually (by the ble≈ø≈øing of God upon it) there is no doubt, but the body ≈øhall be free from many trouble≈øome maladies.

There was a certain woman of the age of 58. yeares, who being greatly troubled with a Catarrhe, was cured by the u≈øe of our Aqua pre≈øervans morning and evening, and by annointing the ≈øtomack with Bal≈øamo.

One that was affected with a Catarrhe, and a ≈øtitch in the ≈øide, was thus cured. He took our Aromatico twice; then he took every morning a ≈øpoonfull of our Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive with the broth of a Capon, for ≈øeven or eight dayes together; and every night when he went to bed, he annointed his ≈øtomack with Oleum Incompo≈øtibile, and thereby was ≈øoon after cured.
A woman that had great pain in her head and ≈øtomack, and had her men≈øtrues ≈øtopped, with lo≈ø≈øe of her appetite, was thus helped.

Fir≈øt ≈øhe took two do≈øes of our Pillulae Angelicae; that done, ≈øhe took every morning a ≈øpoonfull of Quinta e≈ø≈øentia ≈øolutiva, with broth and ≈øugar, for five or ≈øix mornings together; after that ≈øhe took every morning one ≈øpoonfull of our Aqua pre≈øervans, whereupon in ≈øhort time after ≈øhe was cured.

div.p:
THis di≈øea≈øe is a windy moi≈øture, and a ≈øuffocation of bloud, as you may ≈øee by experience, that ≈øuch as are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed

div.head: CHAP. III. The de≈øcription, and manifold cures, of the di≈øea≈øe called Scrophulae, or forunculi, which ≈øome doe call waxing kernels, but rather the Kings Evill.
div.p: THe Scrophulae or waxing kernels (≈øo called of ≈øome) which u≈øe to come in the throat, or other parts of the bodies of young children, doe ari≈øe and are cau≈øed of great quantity of melancholy humours, becau≈øe that doth for the mo≈øt part reign in per≈øons that are weak of complexion; for you may ea≈øily ≈øee, that ≈øuch as are vexed with that infirmity, are not very quick ≈øpirited. The≈øe Scrophulae are a long time ere they will come to ≈øuppuration; and before they break, and when they are broken, they cau≈øe exce≈ø≈øive pain, and are hard to be cured: For all infirmities that come of melancholy, are trouble≈øome to cure, or re≈øolve, as you may ≈øee in the Quartain, and ≈øuch like. But here I will ≈øhew thee a ≈øecret to cure the≈øe Scrophulae. Fir≈øt you mu≈øt remove the cau≈øe, and then cure the effects, for otherwi≈øe it were impo≈ø≈øible to cure them with outward Medicines. This melancholy is purged with our Sirrup again≈øt melancholy, which you mu≈øt u≈øe eight or ten dayes, the do≈øe is about ‚Ñ•. iv. cold; that done, give them our Aromatico, which clean≈øeth the head and ≈øtomack, and purifieth the bloud. As touching locall Medicines to break it, you ≈øhall lay thereon our Cau≈øtick 24. houres, which mortifieth and dryeth, for it will draw forth a great deal of moi≈øture; after this annoint it with our Magno liquore untill the e≈øcare be fallen out, and when it is mundified, apply thereon the Cerot of Gualtifredo di Medi, and u≈øe no other Medicine, for it will incarnate, and ≈øiccatrize without ≈øcarre.

div.head: Another cure for Scrophulae.
div.p: A Certain young boy of 14. yeares, of complexion cholerick and melancholie, who had Scrophulae in his throat on both the ≈øides, was cured thus. The fir≈øt Medicine that he took was the Infu≈øion of Rhubarb, with the Trochi≈øches of Agarick, and acetum ≈øquilliticum, and water of Maidenhair mixed together, which he u≈øed by the ≈øpace of ten daies. Then was laid upon the Scrophulae, a plai≈øter of Cerot magi≈øtrale with Cantharides, which drew forth the malignitie of the Ulcer, and great ≈øtore of Sanies, being applied for 15 daies together. This done, I gave him the decoction of Sal≈øaparilla, with a good diet for twentie dayes together. Then I applyed unto the ≈øore a Cerot of Gualtifredo di Medi, which in a ≈øhort time cured him, that had been vexed with them four yeares before.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: ANother which was a maid of 13. years of age, was vexed with Scrophulae in her throat, which was al≈øo in this manner cured. Fir≈øt, gave her the extract of Elleborus niger, with mel Ro≈øarum, which doth very effectually purge the melancholie humour. That done, I gave her our Sirrup again≈øt the melancholy humour, for eight or ten dayes together, and applyed unto the ≈øores an Unguent of Litarge, boiled with the powder of Scrophularia, thus was ≈øhee in ≈øhort time perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Of Panaricium, or Panaricies, called the Whitblow.
div.p: THis grievous and intollerable maladie, (as tho≈øe know well that have felt them) cometh on the end of the finger, and is an infirmitie bred in the liver, whereof nature being willing to di≈øcharge her ≈øelf, ≈øendeth it to the extream parts of the fingers, and mo≈øt commonly it cometh to the finger next the thumb, but ≈øeldome in the other. The rea≈øon or cau≈øe whereof is hidden, ≈øave that we may conjecture (as wee have ≈øaid before) an accident in the Liver, which nature ≈øendeth forth unto tho≈øe parts to ea≈øe her ≈øelfe. When it cometh to the end of the finger, that it can go no further, it cau≈øeth a ≈øharp and exce≈ø≈øive pain; and the accident coming unto that place, not having pa≈ø≈øage, is ≈øo hot, that in ≈øhort time it putrifieth the ≈øinews, mu≈øcles, and cartilages, and in the end rotteth both fle≈øh and bone. The ≈øecret of this grief is not commonly known of the mo≈øt Chirurgians, who with all their learning cannot devi≈øe to cure it as it ought to be cured. The mo≈øt part of ≈øuch as have that infirmitie lo≈øe their finger; but if thou wilt quickly help them, follow this method.

Fir≈øt, let them bleed on the Liver vein, then let them be well purged. Afterward dre≈ø≈øe the finger, with Oleum Sulphuris, which will cau≈øe ≈øome pain, neverthele≈ø≈øe (to have ≈øome ea≈øe) you mu≈øt abide it. The next day dre≈ø≈øe it with Magno liquore untill it be whole, which will be in ≈øhort time, as I have often proved.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of grievous ∆≤lcers in Womens Brea≈øts.
div.p:
FIr≈øt they mu≈øt be touched with Oleum Sulphuris, then make this Unguent. Take the yolks of Eggs, ‚Ñ• ii. Turpentine, Butter, Barlie flower, Honey of Ro≈øes, ana, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. incorporate them all in a morter, and therewith dre≈ø≈øe them, untill they be whole. But if they come of any kinde, or ≈øpice of the
pox this unguent will be to very ≈ømall purpo≈øe. But then ≈øhall you dre≈ø≈øe them, with our ∆≤nguento magno, which is appropriate unto the di≈øea≈øe, and look that you purge them with our Aromatico.

div.head: CHAP VI. Of the di≈øea≈øe called A≈øtma, and the cure thereof.
div.p: THis di≈øea≈øe which is called the Pti≈øick, is a certaine infirmity contained in the lungs, which doth harden and dry them in ≈øuch manner, that ≈øuch as are troubled therewith cannot fetch their breath. It proceedeth of adu≈øtion of the bloud, that can not runne into the veines: and ≈øo the lungs lacking ≈øu≈øtenance wor≈øteth that effect. This di≈øea≈øe is cured four manner of waies. Fir≈øt, you ≈øhall let them bloud under the tongue, cutting tho≈øe veines overthwart, and ≈øuck them as much as they can: for it evacuateth and openeth the opilation of the bloud, and ea≈øeth the lungs of all that evill matter which offendeth. Secondly, you ≈øhall give them a do≈øe of Aromatico, which evacuateth the ≈øtomack of all evill qualities that offend the Lungs. The third is, to let them eat for a moneth together every morning ‚Ñ•. i of our Electuario de Althea. The fourth, to annoint the ≈øtomack every night with Magno liquore. But every ten daies you mu≈øt take a do≈øe of our Electuario Angelica, whereby thou ≈øhalt help them quickly. You mu≈øt al≈øo keep a ≈øober diet, refraining Fi≈øh, Porke, ≈ølimie things, ≈øpice, baked meats, chee≈øe, and ≈øuch like, which nouri≈øh gro≈øely, and do infect the bloud.

div.head: CHAP. VII. To know the Drop≈øie confirmed in a man, the cure whereof is ≈øhewed in xxxii. Chapter of the ≈øecond part of the Collection
div.p: THere are three ≈øignes or tokens of a confirmed Drop≈øie. Fir≈øt, look whether the tongue be white and cold: Then whether the yard be ≈øhrunk into the belly. And la≈øtly if there do any veines appear on the belly. If you perceive the≈øe they are infallible declarations of a confirmed Drop≈øie.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. An excellent remedie again≈øt Wormes.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall give the Patient two drachms of our ∆≤nguento magno to drink with Mel Ro≈øarum, three mornings together annoint the no≈øtrils therewith, and in three daies they will be expelled, were they never ≈øo many.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the hardne≈ø≈øe of the Milt, and the cure thereof.
div.p: THe Spleen or Milt is hardned by rea≈øon of ≈øuperfluous humidity, that it taketh from the Liver and Lungs. Therefore if you will help this infirmity, it were nece≈ø≈øary to u≈øe medicines ab≈øter≈øive and drying, which thou ≈øhalt do thus Fir≈øt give them our Aromatico, then let them u≈øe this Electuray, which is of mervellous vertue in that operation. Take Crocus martis, Scolopendria, ana. ‚Ñ•. i. Spicknard, Lapis lazuli, ana. ‚Ñà. ii. Cinnamon, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. mixe them, and make an Electuary thereof with purified hony, and take thereof every morning one ≈øpoonfull, and every night (two hours before ≈øupper) another ≈øpoonfull, and annoint the outward part where the grief is with our Bal≈øamo Artificiato, and in ≈øhort time the di≈øea≈øe ≈øhall be cured.

div.head: Another remedy very effectuall for the former di≈øea≈øe
div.p: LEt them bloud on the two veines under the tongue. That done mixe mu≈øtard-≈øeed with the Urine of a Boy, and lay it between two clothes, and apply it to the part affected one night, and then (if thou feele not good ea≈øe) u≈øe it againe till the di≈øea≈øe be gone. Al≈øo the decoction of Oak helpeth the ≈øwelling of the Milt.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Gonorrhaea or running of the reines, and the cure.
div.p:
THis di≈øea≈øe is a corruption cau≈øed of the ≈øuperfluous u≈øe of women, that are infected therewith: for ≈øuch men as have
knowledge of them, they receive the ≈øaid corruption, which afterwards cometh forth of the yard with great paine and difficulty in making water: and moreover in the night, when that part is erected, it cau≈øeth great torment: which for fifteen or twenty daies cau≈øeth extream paine. This is the beginning of the French-Pox, a fit ≈øauce for that ≈øweet ≈øin of Letchery. It bringeth mo≈øt commonly paine in the interior parts, or paine in the reines, arms, and legs: in≈øomuch that in fine it cometh to that fowle di≈øea≈øe. For ≈øuch as have this Gonorrhaea, never ≈øu≈øpecting or fearing the after-claps, ≈øuffer their di≈øea≈øe to grow on further and further till their cure will very hardly or never be accompli≈øhed. Therefore I wi≈øh every man to ≈øeek help in time, lea≈øt by letting it pa≈ø≈øe, in the end it turne to his de≈øtruction. The cure is as followeth.

Fir≈øt you ≈øhall give them our Aromatico once in white Wine; Then morning and evening for ≈øeven or eight daies u≈øe this potion following: annointing al≈øo the reines and tho≈øe parts with our Aqua faetida being cold, and in ≈øhort time they ≈øhall be healed.

‚Ñû. The whites of four or five new layd Eggs, of fine Sugar, ‚Ñ•. ii. of Ro≈øe-water, ‚Ñ•. iii. mixe them well, and drink it morning and evening. This is a rare ≈øecret, and often proved, the drink mu≈øt be drunk cold.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Emeroids, and their cure.
div.p:
THe Emeroides are an alteration in the Emeroidall veines, cau≈øed of a corrupt and putrified humor, whereof nature being willing to di≈øcharge her ≈øelf, ≈øendeth forth by tho≈øe veines unto the extream or outward parts, where it cannot pa≈øs through, and cau≈øeth the alteration and inflammtion that is caled the Emeroides. This corruption and putrifaction is cau≈øed of the evill quality of the Liver, which corrupteth the bloud, and is the cau≈øe of all this inconvenience. Commonly the originall and beginning thereof is cau≈øed of the Pox, a thing that mu≈øt be con≈øidered of in the cure. Now for the cure, it were nece≈ø≈øary to help the Liver, to purifie the bloud, to alter
the Emeroides, and to di≈øcharge nature of that impediment. Fir≈øt, therefore give them our Electuario Angelica, the next day they ≈øhall take our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo, whereof they ≈øhall take five or ≈øix do≈øes. Then let them annoint the Emeroids with our Cau≈øtick, once or twi≈øe, and they ≈øhall ≈øoone after bee cured.

div.head: Of the divers ≈øorts and divers effects of the Emeroides, and their cure.
div.p: BY rea≈øon of this di≈øea≈øe that cometh alwaies at the end of Inte≈øtino, or Longanon, ≈øome have marvelous paine about the fundament, ≈øome burn wonderfully, and others do ≈øcald: which commeth becau≈øe of the good or bad qualities in ≈øome, more then in other ≈øome, as experience ≈øheweth. For (as I ≈øaid) ≈øome have ≈øuch a burning, that they can take no re≈øt, ≈øome have ≈øuch paine as they cannot ≈øit, ≈øome have it ≈øo ≈øcalding hot that it is intollerable. Though this infirmity is more hurtfull in one complexion then in another, and the cure hard, yet you ≈øhall cure them in this manner.

Fir≈øt, give them Aromatico, then purge the body five or ≈øix times with our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo. Then give him our fume at the lower parts, three or four times, and then annoint the parts with our Bal≈øamo Arti≈øiciato, for that will dry and take away the paine altogether, and the Patient ≈øhall be ≈øurely healed.

There are divers kinds of Emeroides, but two in principall. The one ≈øort is in the fundament, and cau≈øeth great paine when they go to the ≈øtoole. The other ≈øort commeth forth of the fundament and are not ≈øo painefull as the fir≈øt. To cure tho≈øe within the fundament, you ≈øhall give the Patient eight or ten daies together our Sirrupo magi≈øtrale warm, then let them take our Aromatico once, and u≈øe Gli≈øters, wherein is put half an ounce of Aqua reale Phioravante at a time, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt help them. The be≈øt way for tho≈øe that are come forth, is to make inci≈øion, or to make a little hole in them, that the bloud which is putrified may come forth, and ≈øo by evacuation thou ≈øhalt help them. Al≈øo you ≈øhall under≈øtand that vomiting is very nece≈ø≈øary in the cure of both ≈øorts, becau≈øe it openeth
the veines. Al≈øo Oleum ovorum doth ea≈øe the paine of the Emeroides very greatly; ≈øo doth the oyle of Figs if you annoint them therewith. The tooth of an hor≈øe-fi≈øh being worn in a ring on the finger, after the body is purged, taketh them away by a ≈øecret and hidden quality, a thing proved more then an hundered times.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the cure of ≈øuch as were troubled with ≈øuffocation of the Matrix.
div.p: A Certaine woman affected therewith, having much paine and griefe in her ≈øtomack, was cured by taking a do≈øe of our Electuario Angelica. Then ≈øhe u≈øed our ≈øirrup again≈øt paines of the Mother eight or ten daies, and annoted her ≈øtomack with Magno liquore every night.

A certaine young woman afflicted in manner afore≈øaid, wanted al≈øo her naturall ≈øickne≈ø≈øe; and began to loo≈øe her naturall heat, ≈øo that nature could not dige≈øt, the ≈øuperfluous matter in her body was thus helped. Fir≈øt, ≈øhe took our Electuario angelica, and every night annointed her ≈øtomack, no≈øtrils, and pul≈øes with Magno liquore, and every morning drunk of our Quinte≈ø≈øence, and ≈øo was cured.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. To cure a rupture in the beginning.
div.p:
IN every ten daies, once, give them our Aromatico, and every morning fa≈øting give them one ounce of white Tartar in water or wine, and two hours before Supper you ≈øhall take the like: Let your bread be Rie, al≈øo you mu≈øt weare a tru≈ø≈øe fit for that purpo≈øe, and u≈øe this remedie following. Take of the ≈øpirite of wine, ‚Ñ•. xii. Frankincen≈øe, Olibanum, Ma≈øtick, Sarcocolla, ana ‚Ñ•. ≈øs: infu≈øe them in the ≈øaid Aqua vitae, and therewith wa≈øh the rupture twi≈øe a day, then pre≈øently ca≈øt thereon the powder of Bi≈ølingisa, and the hearb Bal≈øaminae, and lay thereon a cloth, wet in the ≈øaid water, and bind on the tru≈ø≈øe ≈øo hard as he may po≈ø≈øible abide it, and hereby ≈øhalt thou heal
any great rupture in an hundred daies, but ≈øee that you keep a diet accordingly.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke very ≈øtiffe and thick paper well gummed, chew it in thy mouth till it be ≈øoft: then lay it upon the rupture, and weare thereon a tru≈ø≈øe fit for the purpo≈øe.
Some u≈øe to ≈øteep the paper in lye, and wring the ≈øame out till it be dry, and apply it to the rupture, changing it once in twenty four houres.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. Of retention of ∆≤rine, and the cure thereof.
div.p:
THe retention of Urine ari≈øeth of many cau≈øes; one is gravell that ≈øtoppeth the Conduits where it ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe; another is the want or weakne≈ø≈øe of the vertue expul≈øive, ≈øo that nature cannot expell; another is a carno≈øity, which is an alteration cau≈øed of corrupt and putrified humours; which doe ≈øo re≈øtrain the pores and Urine, that it cannot pa≈ø≈øe; there is another, and that is vi≈øco≈øity of the reines, ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe, that it hindereth the Urine from pa≈ø≈øing: another cau≈øe, which is too too common, is the Gonorrhaea, when it changeth into Stranguria, that it is a ≈øtopping or choking of the Conduits that carry the Urine to the Bladder. All the≈øe afore≈øaid cau≈øes proceed of one originall, even of the di≈øtemperature of nature, whereof if you ask the rea≈øon, you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that it ari≈øeth of that filthy beginning the French Pox. That which moveth me to beleeve it, is the ob≈øervation thereof divers and ≈øundry times, for I have cured many that were infected with the Pox, which were troubled, ≈øome with Carno≈øity (before ≈øpoken of) ≈øome with gravell, ≈øome with debility of the vertue expul≈øive, ≈øome with Gonorrhaea: all which when I had cured of the Pox, the other di≈øtemperatures were therewith al≈øo cured. For that di≈øea≈øe is the cau≈øe of twenty mi≈øchiefs, and the rea≈øon why many Phy≈øitians make a long cure of the former di≈øtemperatures is, for that they know not the maine and
principall cau≈øe of them. But now I will ≈øhew thee a true and excellent manner of curing the retention of Urine, which way ≈øoever it cometh.

Fir≈øt give them a do≈øe of Aromatico, then give unto them our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo eight or ten daies, but in any wi≈øe keep no ≈øtreight diet, but a good government, as you do mo≈øt commonly u≈øe, and eat ≈øuch meat as plea≈øeth the ≈øtomack be≈øt: cau≈øe them al≈øo to ≈øweat, and in ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt throughly cure them,

div.head: CHAP. XV. A mo≈øt excellent remedy to cure the difficultie of ∆≤rine.
div.p: THe difficulty or retention of Urine, cau≈øed divers waies, as of gravell, vi≈øco≈øitie, exulceration, &c. is in this ≈øort very well and ≈øafely cured. When the cau≈øe of this difficulty of Urine is in the reines or kidnies, ≈øo that it be not a ≈øtone in the kidnies, or ≈øome great ≈øtore of gravell, ≈øee that thou work thus.

‚Ñû. Rognoni of a male Hare, boil it in good Wine, when it is well boiled, ≈øtamp it ≈ømall, and pa≈ø≈øe it through a ≈øtrainer with the ≈øaid liquor wherein it was boiled. Remember that when you boil it, there mu≈øt not remaine much liquor in the ve≈ø≈øell. Then take the ≈øaid matter that you ≈øtrained, and put thereto as much purified honey, and boil it on a ≈øoft fire untill it come to the form of an Electuary. When it is boiled, put thereto for every pound of that Electuary the≈øe things following made into fine powder; of Lignum Alo ‚Ä¢ s, of Cinnamon, ana. ‚Ñà. i. Cloves, Saffron, ana. ‚Ñà. i. Musk, four grains, Aqua Ro≈øar ‚Ä¢ m, ‚Ñ• i. our Quinte≈ø≈øence, ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øs. Incorporate the≈øe well together while it is warm, and keep it in a gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopped: And when you will u≈øe it, you mu≈øt fir≈øt take a do≈øe of our Electuario Angelico, and while you u≈øe the Electuary remember to annoint the reins with our Aqua faetida when you go to bed. Of the Electuary you mu≈øt take ‚Ñ•. i. in the morning, and fa≈øt thereon four hours, and u≈øe ≈øome exerci≈øe, and in ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt ≈øee a marvellous good work performed. For the Reines will bee ≈øtrengthned, the vi≈øco≈øity will bee re≈øolved, the pores will be opened, and the Urine will be expelled, and clen≈øed,
all which are effects nece≈ø≈øary for him to regard, that will with hone≈øty and credite, help the former mallady.

div.head: Another often proved.
div.p: If thou wilt pre≈øently help one that cannot make water, by rea≈øon of wind, vi≈øco≈øity, or other greivous cau≈øe, vexing the party, annoint their reines, and all the privie parts with our Bal≈øamo Artificiato, and keep them very warm, and forthwith they ≈øhall make water, to their great ≈øatisfaction.

div.head: Retention of the ∆≤rine, with ≈øtitch in the ≈øide.
div.p: ONe was in very ≈øhort time cured of the≈øe infirmities, after he had taken our Aromatico, and annointed him in manner above ≈øpecified, with our Bal≈øamo Artificiato.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. The ≈øwelling of the leg and foot, cured in manner following,
div.p: F ‚Ä¢ r≈øt, the Patient took one do≈øe of Aromatico, then he u≈øed our Quinte≈ø≈øence ≈øolutive three or four mornings together in a little broth; that done, he drunk every morning a little of our Quinte≈ø≈øence vegetable, fa≈øting, and every night he annointed his leg with Oleum Philo≈øophorum no≈øtrum: al≈øo now and then he took a do≈øe of Pillulae Angelicae to keep the body ≈øoluble, he kept a rea≈øonable good diet, he u≈øed not much walking, ≈øo that very ≈øhortly after he was well cured.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of Chilblaines and their cures.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall under≈øtand, that Chilblaines (as we term them) are cau≈øed of no other thing, then of humours dried and re≈øtrained in our bodies: For in the winter, when it is cold, the pores doe ≈øhut ≈øo clo≈øe together, that the humour cannot pa≈ø≈øe or come forth, neither by ≈øweat, nor other exhalation or expiration: For that cau≈øe, the humours in a young man (who is h ‚Ä¢ t of complexion) may not be kept in, for then nature (which would ea≈øe her ≈øelf) ≈øendeth that exhalation unto the extream
parts of the bodie, that is, unto the hands and feet; where remaining, there is cau≈øed that alteration, and in proce≈ø≈øe of time, the skin doth open, and the humour goeth forth, but cannot heal till the Spring, when warm weather cometh in. Howbeit I have found out a Secret to cure them quickly, and with great ea≈øe. Fir≈øt, let them bloud, then give them a do≈øe of our Electuario Angelico: After that let them take our Sirrupo ≈øolutivo ≈øix or ≈øeven daies together, not keeping any ≈øtreight diet or rule. After this, annoint them with Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Cera & Terebinthina, at night when they go to bed: and doe thus one week at the lea≈øt, and then no doubt thou ≈øhalt cure them as I have often proved. Al≈øo the oyle and water of Frankincen≈øe will do the like.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of Cornes on the Feet, and the manner to take them away.
div.p: THe Cornes that come on the feet, are a kind of hard Tumor, or thick excre≈øcence, cau≈øed of corrupt and putrified humours, whereof Nature being willing to di≈øcharge her ≈øelf, ≈øendeth them to the lower part of the feet, from whence, becau≈øe they cannot pa≈ø≈øe, there doe they make a re≈øidence: ingendering that kind of tough excre≈øcence, which is grievous and painfull. Many times the cau≈øe hereof ari≈øeth of that noy≈øome di≈øea≈øe, Morbus Gallicus, as ≈øome write, and then mu≈øt it be remedied with Medicaments appropriate thereunto. But if they come otherwi≈øe, then to take them away, follow this order. When they are in their greate≈øt ≈øtate, and cau≈øe mo≈øt pain, cut them untill they bleed, then annoint them with our Bal≈øamo artificiato, applying it ≈øo hot as you may ≈øuffer it; thereupon go to bed. Then touch them once or twice with Oleum ≈øulphuris, and annoint them with Oleum Philo≈øophorum de Terebinthina & Cera, untill they bee whole.

Some take the juyce of Sempervivum, and annoint the cornes therewith. Then they take wormwood, and lay it upon a hot tile ≈øtone, and ≈øprinkle it with ≈øtrong Vinegar, and being hot, bind it upon the cornes, and in three or four
times ≈øo doing (as I have been credibly certified) the cornes will be taken away.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of an Infirmitie that cometh on the fingers ends, and in the feet, under the nails, and the cure ‚Ä¢ of it.
div.p: MAny men are greatly troubled herewith, and in ≈øuch manner, as thereby they are made altogether unfit to goe. It cometh on the great toe, under the nail, or the ≈øide of the nail for the mo≈øt part; and a man would thinke that the nail grew in the fle≈øh, but it is not ≈øo, for the fle≈øh groweth upon the nail; though this infirmitie appear not to be a thing of great Importance (whereof the ancient writers have made little mention) yet is it a thing greatly to be regarded. For many great per≈øonages that live ea≈øily, and are tormented with the gout, have al≈øo this grief in tho≈øe parts, but the order to cure them is this. Fir≈øt, you ≈øhall cut the naile on that part where it mo≈øt grieveth them; then take it away, which you may doe ea≈øily without any great pain to the Patient: for the nail is already ≈øeparated from the grieved place. Thus when the naile is taken away, touch it with our Cau≈øticke, whereof mention is made in our Treati≈øe of the plague. Let it ≈øo remain three daies together, then dre≈ø≈øe it every day with Magno liquore untill it be whole, which will be in a very ≈øhort time.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of Eri≈øipela, and the cure thereof.
div.p:
THis di≈øea≈øe (as experience ≈øheweth) is cau≈øed of an hot and fiery moi≈øture, ari≈øing in the face, armes and legs, for where it is, the powers and pores are ≈øtopped that the ≈øaid moi≈øture cannot have expiration, whereupon cometh tumor, as al≈øo a ≈øhutting and clo≈øing up of tho≈øe pores, by meanes of the ordinarie annointing them with fats, oyles, &c. or other cold things, a common cour≈øe u≈øed of common Chirurgians. Again≈øt this there cannot be found a more pre≈øent remedy then the ≈øpirit of wine, or Aqua ardens, or bathing it
with hot water, and if you wa≈øh the parts affected with our Quinte≈ø≈øence, the Pores will be opened, and it penetrateth and a≈ø≈øubtiliateth that humiditie, cau≈øing it to come forth.
Al≈øo you ≈øhall find that by drinking our Quinte≈ø≈øence and annointing the ≈øtomack with Oleum cerae, divers are cured of a certain heat retained in the ≈øtomack.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. The cure of Warts.
div.p: THere is an Hearb called in the Italian tongue Herba di vento: in the juice wherof if you wet a cloth, and bind it upon the warts, they will wear away in ≈øhort time after.

div.head: The Second Part of the Appendix or Addition unto this Collection, containing the U≈øe and Vertues, of ≈øundry Vegetables, Animals, &c. gathered out of the Phy≈øicks of Sir Leonardo Phioravante.
CHAP. I. Of the ∆≤≈øe, and vertues of Ebulus or Danewort.
div.p: TAke the buds of this Vegetable, when they are young and green, perboil them in water, and make thereof a Sallad, and give it unto tho≈øe that have co≈øtive bodies, and it will provoke them to the ≈øtool. of an uncertain Authour, which doth explain many doubts in that ≈øacred Phy≈øick.

And becau≈øe that all nations, e≈øpecially the Germanes, have written books in their own language, I will al≈øo write two books in the French tongue, for the help of ≈øuch as are ≈øtudious of Philo≈øophy, wherein I will treat of many preparations and ≈øpeciall Medicines tried by me and others, al≈øo of divers Elixars of the Philo≈øophers, extractions of Mercuries and Mercuriall waters, of many and divers di≈ø≈øolutions, I will al≈øo add the interpretations of ≈øundry Characters, wherewith the books both of the old and new Writers are written to cover and hide the Art; al≈øo the expo≈øition of a certain Alphabet, without the which the work can hardly be under≈øtood: and two Treati≈øes, the one of the vertues of the vegetall and minerall Oils, the other of the ≈øalts and properties of many vegetals and minerals; whereunto I will al≈øo joyn two Treati≈øes of philo≈øophicall Mines, and of making of Vinegers, the which my labour and ≈øtudy, if I ≈øee it acceptable unto tho≈øe that are ≈øtudious of that Art, I will ≈øhortly ≈øet forth greater things, which many with their whole hearts doe wi≈øh and de≈øire; in the mean time, take in good part this little work. That which we have hitherto ≈øpoken, is ≈øpoken onely unto tho≈øe that doe ≈øo deadly hate the Chymicall Phy≈øick, which think nothing can be well or profitably taught in Phy≈øick that the old Harp ≈øoundeth not; as though that nature were not more then Galen, or that all the learning of Phy≈øick were to be drawn from the Heathen, or that they alone had publi≈øhed the Art, and e≈øtabli≈øhed it with ≈øuch ≈øound arguments. Why doe you not out of tho≈øe Authours confute tho≈øe excellent men which are followers of Paracel≈øus, among≈øt whom, that great Doctor Petrus Severinus a Dane is cheif, who in his Idea hath opened the invin ‚Ä¢ ible foundation of Paracel≈øus Phy≈øick? div.head: A Treati≈øe of certaine Particulars, whereof the fir≈øt treateth of the preparation of the Marka≈øite of Lead, as well for the tran≈ømutation of Metals, as for the alteration of Mans body, &c.
div.p: THe Philo≈øophers Saturn, is properly the Marka≈øite of lead, and indeed doth excell Sol and Luna, in≈øomuch that Raymond ≈øaith, that in this inferior world, there is no greater ≈øecret then that which con≈øi≈øteth in the Marka≈øite of Lead, in≈øomuch that they which have throughly ≈øought out the force and nature of it, have bound them≈øelves together by oath never to utter tho≈øe ≈øecrets of nature unto the end of their lives. For ≈øo much as his operation is of ≈øuch kind, as truely it hath many and ≈øundry u≈øes, which being duely prepared, doth not onely alter and change the filthy and corrupt humours of our bodies, but al≈øo can change and tran≈ømute by ≈øundry experiments, Luna into Sol.

Take of the Minerall Marka≈øite of Lead, xii. pound, and grind it into fine powder upon a Marble ≈øtone, as they grind colours with Vinegar: being well ground and tempered, put it into a ≈øtrong gla≈øs, and put thereon a good quantity of di≈øtilled Vinegar, and ≈øtir it well with a ≈øtick, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand in Balneo Mariae: then ≈øet thereon a blind head, and there let it ≈øtand eight daies together, ≈øtirring and moving it every day ≈øix or ≈øeven times, then let it coole, and the Vinegar will be of a yellowi≈øh colour, the which ye ≈øhall poure forth into another gla≈ø≈øe, taking heed that ye ≈øtir not the feces: then put thereon more Vinegar, and ≈øtirr it well with a ≈øtick, and ≈øet on the blind head, and ≈øet it in Balneo Mariae other eight daies, as yee did afore, then poure forth the Vinegar being coloured into the other gla≈ø≈øe. And this order ye ≈øhall u≈øe ≈øo long, untill you ≈øee the Vinegar no more coloured, for at the la≈øt the feces will remaine in a white ma≈ø≈øe, like white earth.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of the coloured Vinegar.
div.p: THen take all that Vinegar being coloured, and di≈øtill it in Balneo untill it will drop no more, and there let thy cucurbit ≈øtand three daies with the feces, that it may drie well, then take it forth, and thou ≈øhalt find in the bottome of the gla≈ø≈øe a white matter, the which take out, for in that whitene≈ø≈øe the redne≈ø≈øe of the Marka≈øite is hidden, which being prepared, availeth much to make Aquam Philo≈øophorum, that they call ardentem.

div.head: The preparation of the Feces.
div.p: Take the white Feces or matter, and put it into a di≈øtilling ve≈ø≈øell with a great recipient very well luted, that the ≈øpirits go not forth, and ≈øet it in the hot a≈øhes, and give it a gentle fire, and then increa≈øe it according to art a day or two, and there will come forth, fir≈øt a white water, and then a red or golden yellow oyle, the which is to be kept clo≈øe with great care.

div.head: The Feces to be taken againe.
div.p: Then take tho≈øe Feces, and ≈øet them in a calcining furnace eight daies: then take them forth and grind them finely, and put them in a gla≈ø≈øe with a good quantity of di≈øtilled Vinegar, and ≈øtir them well together; that being done, ≈øet it againe in Balneo eight daies together, and ≈øtir it every day ≈øeven or eight times, the more the better, then let it wax cold and ≈øettle, and pour away the clear part from the Feces, but take heed that ye ≈øtir not the dreggs or bottome. Then pour on fre≈øh Vinegar, and ≈øet it in Balneo againe, and do as ye did before, and then pour away the Vinegar againe, and ca≈øt away the Feces, for they are nothing worth.

div.head: The di≈øtillation of the Vinegar.
div.p:
Then take the Vinegar which you re≈øerved, and di≈øtill it
with a gentle fire, and in the bottome thou ≈øhalt find a ≈øalt, in the which remaineth all the force and ≈øtrength. Then calcine the ≈øaid ≈øalt againe in a reverberatory, four and twenty houres with a great fire, then take it forth, and put it in the the gla≈ø≈øe wherein it was before, and put thereon fre≈øh Vinegar, and ≈øet it in Balneo. And this thou ≈øhalt do ≈øo often untill the ≈øalt leave no feces in the bottome: that being done, di≈øtill thy Vinegar as at the fir≈øt, and thou ≈øhalt find it prepared, liquid, and clear as Chri≈øtall.

div.p: Take the afore≈øaid ≈øalt, and grind it upon a ≈øtone, dropping thereon his red oyle by little and little: that being done, put it into a cucurbit luted with Hermes ≈øeal, and ≈øo ≈øet it upon a trevet, in an Athanor twenty daies, and it will be fixed into a red ≈øtone, ≈øo that ye have the true government of the fire. It is a mo≈øt ≈øoveraigne medicine again≈øt all contractions, and you u≈øe it, as afore, according to the nature of the di≈øea≈øe. But the Patient mu≈øt u≈øe it ≈øix daies. If there appear any pu≈øtulaes, ye ≈øhall cure them by touching them with oyle of Sulphur. Moreover tho≈øe that have the drop≈øie, or ≈øuch like moi≈øt di≈øea≈øes in the body are cured by giving them ≈øix grains, in water of Carduus Benedictus, letting them ≈øweat thereon as is afore≈øaid, and keeping the order as is afore ≈øet down. Again≈øt the Pluri≈øie, ye ≈øhall give four graines in the ≈øaid water. And again≈øt the Plague in Ro≈øe-vinegar. Again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈ø≈øe with water of black Cherries or Pionie. Furthermore, if any have had the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe by nature, ye ≈øhall give them every day a little pill in Aqua Pionia, putting thereon ≈øix drops of the ≈øpirit of Vitrioll. If I would ≈øhew or expre≈ø≈øe all the virtues, I ≈øhould write a book thereof, but that which remaineth I will ≈øhew more at large in my book called Portus Ga≈øconicus, with the order to draw the ≈øpirit of wine.

Then take one part, and re≈øerve it for women without musk, for it hurteth them. div.head: Bernardus G. Penotus Landrada √† Portu S. Mariae Aquitanus unto the ≈øingular learned man John Aquila, the hammer of the Ethnicks, wi≈øheth much health.
div.p:
NOt onely in the≈øe our dayes (friend John) but al≈øo in the old time among≈øt the learned, this Proverb hath taken place, That Ignorance is the mother of marvelling: Who in the≈øe dayes would not marvell to ≈øee men utterly void of all manner of learning, to be preferred before learned men, and ≈øuch as are mo≈øt skillfull in the Latine and Greek tongues, and tho≈øe are to be imbraced of Kings and Princes, and rewarded with mo≈øt liberall gifts, and mo≈øt famous and learned men expert in all the tongues to be rejected and contemned? You, which excell in judgement and learning will an≈øwer, That every perfect gift cometh down from the Father of light. Therefore God doth in the≈øe latter daies ≈øtir up the≈øe Ideots and Empericks to ≈øtir up every Phy≈øitian, that he ≈øhould rightly prepare his own Medicines with his own hands, and being ≈øo prepared, with ≈øharp judgement apply them to their proper di≈øea≈øes, that the ≈øeed of the di≈øea≈øe may be pulled up by the Roots, and not to commit it to an unskillfull cook. And therefore of nece≈ø≈øity from hence mu≈øt both the Theorick and the Practi≈øe, the rea≈øon and the work concur and joyn together, becau≈øe judgement without practice is barren. The greate≈øt number of them will an≈øwer, we know not your works and preparations which require ≈øo great and hard lalabour, we are now old and Doctors, we will not bee made yonglings, and Schollers again. If this an≈øwer might take place, the Jew, the Pope and the Turk would not change their ≈øuper≈øtitions, which notwith≈øtanding we know to be mo≈øt contrary to the ≈øacred Scripture. But we ≈øufficiently and daily prove by calcining, ≈øubliming, di≈ø≈øolving, purifying, di≈øtilling, congealing and fixing, by this mo≈øt laudable Art of Alchymie, how the pure may be ≈øeparated from the impure, and the corruptible from the incorruptible, and that which is venemous and deadly, be changed and made whol≈øome
≈øome and good; and as Paracel≈øus ≈øaith concerning this Art, we ≈øhall fir≈øt con≈øider that all things are created of God, for he created of nothing ≈øomething, and that ≈øomething is the ≈øeed of all things, and that ≈øeed worketh that effect hereunto ordained and appointed. All things notwith≈øtanding are ≈øo created, that they ≈øhall come unto our hands, and begin to be in our power, but ≈øo as things not perfect, but to be made perfect, as things not fini≈øhed, but to be fini≈øhed. The matter in them truly is perfect, but the middle and la≈øt matters remain to de made perfect. As for example, God created Iron, Earth, and Clay, but not ≈øuch as they ≈øhould bee, for the clay groweth, yet not like a Pot or other earthen Ve≈ø≈øel: So he created Iron lying in a rude Ma≈ø≈øe, and hath given it ≈øo rude unto us, therefore we with our labour mu≈øt make thereof ≈øhoos for hor≈øes, ≈øythes, and ≈øpears. Even ≈øo is it in Phy≈øick, for that is al≈øo created of God, but not ≈øo that it ≈øhould be utterly perfect, but as yet hidden under the earth, not purged from his unclean matter, but that which remaineth to be made perfect in it, is committed to the Chymi≈øt, that is, to the Phy≈øitian to be purged and clean≈øed. For herbs, trees, ≈øtones, and iron, and what≈øoever is ≈øeen with the eyes is no true Medicine, but is rude and impure, wherein as yet the pure part lyeth hid. And therefore Alchymy teacheth to purge the Medicine, to di≈ø≈øolve it, and to ≈øeparate things of contrary kinde from things of the ≈øame kinde, otherwi≈øe rotten things would be mingled with rotten, and the corrupt with the corrupt, and ≈øo con≈øpire to one effect; ≈øo that of one di≈øea≈øe many other ≈øhould ≈øpring or ari≈øe. Briefly, every man loveth not that whereof he hath no under≈øtanding or knowledge, but flieth from it, contemneth it, and thinketh it not meet to be learned. to put his tru≈øt in him. For ≈øuch as every mans faith is, ≈øuch is al≈øo his knowledge.

And contrariwi≈øe, he that doth otherwi≈øe work about nature, worketh like a Painter that painteth an Image, in the which is neither life nor ≈øtrength, wherefore tho≈øe which you call Empericks ≈øhall ri≈øe even before your faces, and take in hand and help grievous di≈øea≈øes, the cures whereof are unpo≈ø≈øible unto you, and you together with your con≈øultations and rea≈øonings ≈øhall be made laughing ≈øtocks.
