div.head: A Fragment out of the Theoricks of John I≈øacacus Hollandus.
div.p:
AMong≈øt all things that were created of God, water was the fir≈øt, whereunto God joyned his proper earth, and of earth, what≈øoever hath e≈ø≈øence or life, hath his originall. Therefore there are two manife≈øt elements, that is, Water, and Earth; in which the two other lye hid, the Fire in the Earth, and the Aire in the Water: and they are ≈øo knit together, that they cannot be ≈øeparated. Two of them are fixed, as the Earth and Fire, two are flying, as Water and Aire. Therefore every element doth participate within other elements. Moreover,
over, in every element are two other elements, one decaying, Putrifying and combu≈øtible, the other eternall and incorruptible, as the heaven: be≈øides, in the≈øe natures lieth hid another nature which is called by the name of ≈øtinking Pheces, which hinder and take away the ≈øtrength of the re≈øt, ≈øo as they have very little force or none, and thereby make the other elements ≈øtinking and ≈øubject to putrefaction. There is al≈øo two kinds of Waters, the one elementall, the other of rain and riverwaters; as there is al≈øo two kinds of Earths, one elementall, clear, ≈øhining, and white, the other black, ≈øtinking, and combu≈øtible. Like as al≈øo there be two Fires, one elementall and naturall, the other ≈øtinking and combu≈øtible; the like is al≈øo to be ≈øaid of the aire. The ba≈øe things are ≈øo mingled with the re≈øt, that by and by they corrupt all things, ≈øo that nothing can continue long, for they bring death, and weaken all nature be it never ≈øo noble. This is to be under≈øtood of all things both vegetall, animall, and minerall. Therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary by Art to ≈øeparate the elementall nature from the corruptible, that the matter may be brought to a medicinall qualitie. There be three mo≈øt ≈øubtle ≈øpirits in all things, that is, colour, ta≈øte, and ≈ømell, the≈øe fly away invi≈øibly, the Philo≈øophers call them wild ≈øpirits, becau≈øe they are not fixible, yet the indu≈øtry of the Artificer may fix them. They alwaies grow in the bodily ≈øub≈øtance untill they come to perfection and end. The hearb therefore is to be taken when it is fully grown, and take heed that you loo≈øe none of tho≈øe three ≈øpirits, as the ignorant u≈øe to do with their putrifactions and ≈øeparations of elements. For none of tho≈øe ≈øpirits con≈øi≈øteth of the three elementall elements: but God hath adorned elements with tho≈øe three ≈øpirits, and of them the Fire is animall, the Water, aire elementall, and no man, but God can ≈øeparate them a≈øunder. But the water of the clouds may be ≈øeparated from them. Al≈øo all the feces may be ≈øeparated from them which are mingled with them, which are the ≈øtinking and corurptible elements, and the four elementall elements may be brought to a chri≈øtaline ≈øhining: but the≈øe three elements, Fire, Aire, and Earth, are un≈øeparable. My ≈øon, know this, that Mercurie is the fir≈øt of all things, for before time there was water, And the ≈øpirit of the
Lord re≈øted upon the water, but what was that water; the water of the Clouds, or a moi≈øture which might be poured out? No, but it was a dry du≈øtie water, and God hath joyned his earth unto it which is his ≈øulphur, and ≈øo the earth congealeth the water, and thereof ≈øprung the four elements included in the≈øe two, by the will of God. Therefore Mercurie congealeth ≈øulphur, and ≈øulphur Mercurie; neither can one of the≈øe be without the other, as al≈øo they cannot be without their ≈øalt, which is the chiefe≈øt meanes, by who≈øe help nature ingendereth and bringeth forth all vegetals, minerals, and animals. Wherefore the≈øe three, Mercury, Salt, and Sulphur, cannot be one without another, for where the one is found, there the other are found al≈øo, neither is there any thing in nature wherein the≈øe three are not found: and of the≈øe three, what≈øoever is in nature hath his originall, and are ≈øo mingled with the four elements, that they make one body, and the ≈øalt is drowned in the bottome of the elements, for it is nece≈ø≈øary that the ≈øalt ≈øhould keep them united by his ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe and drine≈ø≈øe, notwith≈øtanding it is a flying ≈øpirit, but becau≈øe it ≈øticketh in the bottome of the mixture, and is overcome of the fatne≈ø≈øe and combu≈øtible oyle, in which it is found: as the yolk within the white of the egg, and the combu≈øtible oyle liveth of earth with the ≈øalt and feces, and the ≈øalt is buried in the bottome of the feces of the combu≈øtible oyle and earth, but by great force of fire. The≈øe three ≈øpirits whereof we have ≈øpoken, are ≈øaid fir≈øt to be ≈øeparated from the mixture of the elements, which is the ≈øoul of all things, or their Quinte≈ø≈øence, which houldeth together the whole mixture of the elements; for when the ≈øpirits are gone out, then the mixture is di≈ø≈øolved by it ≈øelf and divided, neither is there need of fire to expell the ≈øalt from the earth; when the elements are ≈øeparated from the feces, then is the ≈øalt al≈øo ≈øeparated with it. This ≈øalt is unknown to the ignorant. Therefore ≈øalt is the meanes between the gro≈ø≈øe earthly parts, and the three flying ≈øpirits re≈øting in the naturall heat, that is, the ta≈øte, moi≈øt ≈ømell, and colour: which three are the life, ≈øoule, and quinte≈ø≈øence of every thing, neither can the≈øe three ≈øpirits be one without the other, as the Father, the Son, and the Holy Gho≈øt are one, yet three
per≈øons, and one is not without the other. The ignorant laugh, neither under≈øtand they the≈øe three ≈øpirits, when as they are tied to the gro≈ø≈øe, earthly fixed parts, and are made ≈øubtile, and their ≈øalt is joyned and mingled with them, it mu≈øt transform them altogether, and fix them into a Cri≈øtaline body, Diaphanes, and red of colour, whereof we will ≈øpeak hereafter; he that knoweth not this ≈øalt, ≈øhall never bring any to pa≈ø≈øe in Art. The Philo≈øophers call this ≈øalt a dry water, and a lively ≈øalt, but the ignorant thought they meant Mercurie, but the Philo≈øophers called the three ≈øpirits Mercurie, and the earth Sulphur, which the ignorant under≈øtand not. Either of them cannot be without the other, neither is there any thing in nature, in which the≈øe three are not, and they are ≈øo mixed with the four elements, that they make one body and mixture. What≈øoever God hath created is in the≈øe three ≈øtones, wherefore all may be reduced into a Cri≈øtalline clearne≈ø≈øe by Art, given by God unto the Philo≈øophers, for in the latter daies God will ≈øeparate all the unclean feces and corruption that is in the elements, and bring them to a Cri≈øtaline clearne≈ø≈øe, and redne≈ø≈øe of a Carbuncle. Afterward there ≈øhall be no more corruption, but they ≈øhall endure for ever. Do you think that all things, which God hath created in the≈øe lower parts, ≈øhould utterly peri≈øh in the latter day? No, not the lea≈øt haire of tho≈øe things which God hath created, no more then the incorruptible Heaven, but God by his Will will change all things, and make them Cri≈øtalline, and the four elements ≈øhall be perfect, ≈øimple, and fixed in them≈øelves, and they ≈øhall be all a quinte≈ø≈øence. Demon≈øtration of the≈øe things may be made here upon earth by Art, for what≈øoever God hath created may be brought to a Cri≈øtalline clearne≈ø≈øe, and the elements gathered together into a ≈øimple fixed ≈øub≈øtance, which being done, no man can alter them, neither the fire it ≈øelf burn or change them, but they ≈øhall continue perpetually as tho≈øe things which have attained eternitie.

But this heaven doth di≈øtribute and give unto the earth what≈øoever is nece≈ø≈øary for it, although that it ≈øelf be neither hot nor cold, moi≈øt nor dry, the which like Effects hath the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Sugar, the which in it ≈øelf hath the four Elements, as gold hath: as gold is pure, ≈øo Sugar is impure, gold outwardly is hot and moi≈øt, inwardly cold and drie, and white: ≈øugar is the contrary, for it is outwardly cold and dry, and inwardly hot and moi≈øt and red, and fixed both outward and inward. Neither is there any thing wanting, but that the inward qualitie may be brought, that his redne≈øs may appear outwardly, and that his Feces be ≈øeparated, then is it prepared, and ≈øhall not need to be fixed, for it is fixed already, and doth retain within it ≈øelf all outward and inward ≈øpirits, and what≈øoever is Volatile it doth retain.

Now what his kinde is I will tell thee, and from whence he hath his Originall, that is, even out of the red, but if thou wilt be further ≈øatisfied, read the three and thirty chapter of the generation of tho≈øe things that grow in the Seas, and other waters, where we write largely of the nature thereof. Here it ≈øhall be ≈øufficient for us to ≈øhew the order how to prepare it, and in what order it ≈øhould be u≈øed in Medicine, and al≈øo to other things where it may be applyed. His nature is to retain or hold all flying ≈øpirits, and to fix them into a ≈øtone, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed hereafter.

Fir≈øt ye ≈øhall under≈øtand that ye cannot ≈øeparate the Feces, except ye bring the inward parts outward, that is to ≈øay,
that his inward dark golden colour do appear, the vvhich when it is ≈øo di≈øtilled, his redne≈ø≈øe is ≈øeen, and this fire, pa≈ø≈øing the yellowne≈ø≈øe of his aire, or his incombu≈øtible oyle, then maye≈øt thou fir≈øt ≈øeparate the Fe≈ø≈øes from the Quinte≈ø≈øcence. Take therefore hard and white Sugar, for it is not needfull that ye travell much in di≈ø≈øolving and congealing of it, although there be much impuritie therein, that hindreth not, but that the inward part may be brought forth, for it mu≈øt be purged when as the redne≈øs doth ≈øhew it ≈øelf outward. Take therefore ten or twentie pounds of Sugar more or le≈ø≈øe as you ≈øhall thinke good, that being beaten, put it into a cucurbite of hard ≈øtone, and put thereon Aquavitae, that it may ≈øtand covered eight fingers, then di≈øtill it in Balneo with a ≈øtrong fire, untill it will di≈øtill no more, then let it wax cold, and pour on the ≈øaid Aqua vitae again, and di≈øtill it again, and this ≈øhalt thou doe ≈øix or ≈øeven times; At the la≈øt open the head and take forth the Sugar, which thou ≈øhalt put in a ≈øtrong gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øet it in fine ≈øifted a≈øhes, and put thereon the Aqua vitae, and di≈øtill it untill the half be come forth, then pour on again the Aqua vitae which thou di≈øtilled≈øt away, fir≈øt being made warm le≈øt the gla≈ø≈øe ≈øhould break; Yee ≈øhall note, that the head would have a hole in the top, by the which you may pour in the Aqua vitae with a Funnell, this thou ≈øhalt repeat often with a ≈øtrong fire, that the wine and the Sugar may boil in, and becau≈øe the half part of the wine will come away quickly, ye ≈øhall pre≈øently put on the other part, for if yee ≈øhould di≈øtill forth all the wine, the Sugar would burn through too much heat, becau≈øe it mu≈øt continually be boyling in the gla≈ø≈øe, and it would ≈ømell of the burning, for it hath alwaies his combu≈øtible Sulphur, wherefore ye mu≈øt alwayes have half the wine in the Ve≈ø≈øell, and when thou ≈øee≈øt the half is di≈øtilled forth, make the ≈øame warm, and put it in again with a Funnell, and that thou ≈øhalt ≈øo often repeat, untill the Sugar remain as red as blood, the which thou ≈øhalt perceive through the gla≈ø≈øe. Thou maye≈øt bring that to pa≈ø≈øe in eight or ten daies according as thou rule≈øt thy fire.

Note, that when thou perceive≈øt the matter to be red, let
it cool, and take away the ve≈ø≈øell with a≈øhes, and ≈øet the ve≈ø≈øell in Balneo, and with a ≈øtrong fire di≈øtill away the Aqua vitae untill the Sugar remain dry, and when it will di≈øtill no more, yet thou ≈øhalt let it ≈øtand four or five dayes very hot in the ≈øaid Balneo, that the Sugar may be perfectly congealed, then let it cool, and take out the matter or ≈øtone, the which will be like black Pitch, that is to be under≈øtood when it is congealed, then take the ≈øaid ≈øtone, and put it into a great quantity of common water twice di≈øtilled, and ≈øet it in Balneo five or ≈øix dayes with a great heat ≈ølightly covered, ≈øtirring it every day five or ≈øix times with a wooden ladle, then let it cool, and take it forth, and let it ≈øettle three or four dayes, then pour of that which is clear into another ve≈ø≈øell, and keep it clo≈øe, then pour on tho≈øe Feces the ≈øublimed water as before, and ≈øet it in Balneo to dige≈øt three dayes, ≈øtirring it with a ladle as yee did afore, then let it cool and ≈øettle, and pour of the cleare≈øt part, as yee did afore, and put it to the re≈øt, then pour on more water upon the Fe≈ø≈øes, and dige≈øt it in Balneo as afore, and this you mu≈øt ≈øo often repeat untill the water be no more coloured, then thou maye≈øt ca≈øt away the Fe≈ø≈øes, for they are nothing worth, for the Element of the earth is with the Element of fire and water, neither can they be ≈øeparated any more, but are fixed together. Make thereof a triall, for there will remain nothing but light a≈øhes; It will burn like oyle or fat, neither doth there any thing remain more then of oile or fat. Take the gla≈ø≈øe wherein is all the red of the Solution, and di≈øtill it in Balneo, or let it vapour away, if yee have ≈øtore of di≈øtilled water, untill it be dry, then let it cool, and take off the head, and pour thereon more ≈øublimed water, and ≈øet it in Balneo again, and ≈øtir it about with a woodden ladle as yee did afore, then let it ≈øettle as afore, and pour out of the cleare≈øt part, and that thou ≈øhalt doe ≈øo long, till there be no more Feces, then put it in a gla≈ø≈øe that may abide the fire, and boyl or vapour it away ≈øo long, till there appear a certain ≈øcum on it, then take it forth, and ≈øet it in a cold and drie, or hot and dry place, and it will grow into a great red ma≈ø≈øe or lump, and tran≈øparent like a Rubie, or other Philo≈øophers ≈øtone, which if thou wilt bring to pouder, ≈øet it in a warm dunghil in a large
wide gla≈ø≈øe open, and let it vapour away, untill it be come into a yellow pouder like unto gold, and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt have the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Sugar fixt, the which will retain all flying ≈øpirits. Neither is it ≈øweet, but a heavenly ta≈øte, the which, if yee put it in your mouth, it will melt without any feeling. If it be winter or cold, thou ≈øhalt ≈øeem to feel a certain natural heat throughout the whole bodie, and ≈øhalt ≈øeem ≈øo temperate and light, as though thou could≈øt flie. If thou be over-hot, ≈øwallow a little, and pre≈øently thou ≈øhalt cool ea≈øily, as though thou wente≈øt into a cold bath, and thus it worketh in heat, moi≈øt, cold, and dry, by an incredible Miracle: When yee will u≈øe it, drinke it with rectified Aqua vitae, or Ro≈øe-water, Endive or Scabios, or by it ≈øelf if ye will, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee marvels: If any be di≈øea≈øed outwardly with Scabs or Ulcers, let him drinke of this, and wa≈øh the ≈øores with Wine, wherein this Quinte≈ø≈øence is di≈ø≈øolved, and he ≈øhall pre≈øently wax whole mo≈øt mraculou≈øly. If any be wounded or thru≈øt in with any weapon, ≈øo that it be not deadly, let him drinke í i. of this E≈ø≈øence with warmed Wine, and wa≈øh the Wound with Wine, wherein the Quinte≈ø≈øence is di≈ø≈øolved, he ≈øhall be pre≈øently cured, ≈øo that tho≈øe which ≈øhall hear or ≈øee it ≈øhall be amazed thereat. It helpeth al≈øo the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, pe≈øtilence, and all ≈øuch di≈øea≈øes as may happen unto man; if yee have Aurum potabile, yee ≈øhall mix lb ii. with lb i. of this Quinte≈ø≈øence in a gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øet it on a Trivet, or in a dry Balneo 30 dayes in an Athanor, and they will be fixt together, and then it will work miracles in mans bodie; ye may al≈øo when you have drawn the Quinte≈ø≈øence of any hearb, coagulate and fix it with the ≈øame, as I ≈øaid before with Aurum Potabile, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee thereof Miracles. Furthermore if ye will have it to pa≈ø≈øe the helm, yee mu≈øt put thereon as much Vinegar or Aqua vitae, and di≈øtil it, and again pour on fre≈øh Vinegar or Aqua vitae, and draw it away again untill the Quinte≈ø≈øence doth a≈øcend in a red golden colour, as we have ≈øhewed in many places, how to di≈øtill tho≈øe matters that are fixed by Vinegar, or Aqua vitae, for when it is di≈øtilled by the Limbeck, his vertues are augmented a thou≈øand times, and will work ≈øtrange cures: keep this as a ≈øecret, for it is a great my≈øtery in nature.

div.head: Here beginneth a manuall or handy work, how the Quinte≈ø≈øence may be drawn out of Honey.
div.p:
NOw will I open unto you a great Secret in the Vegetall work of honie, to wit, a marvellous nature, for it is drawn out of the mo≈øt noble and pure part of the floures. The nature of Bees is ≈øuch, that they draw out the be≈øt of every thing, as in the Animall work is more at large de≈øcribed, wherein there is taught how to extract the nature of all bea≈øts, and ≈øpeciallly in the 84. Chapter. Wherefore (my ≈øon) know this, that all that God hath created good in the upper part of the world, are perfect and uncorruptible, as the heaven: but what≈øoever in the≈øe lower parts, whether it be in bea≈øts, fi≈øhes, and all manner of ≈øen≈øible creatures, hearbs or plants, it is indued with a double nature, that is to ≈øay, perfect, and unperfect; the perfect nature is called the Quinte≈ø≈øence, the unperfect the Peces or dreggs, on the venemous or combu≈øtible oile. Therefore you ≈øhall ≈øeparate the dregs and combu≈øtible oyle, and then that which remaineth is perfect, and is called the Quinte≈ø≈øence, which will endure continually, even as the heaven, neither can it be di≈ø≈øolved with fire or any other thing. For when God had created all things, and looked upon them, they were all perfect good, there was nothing lacking to any; and therefore for loves ≈øake I ≈øay unto thee, that God hath put a ≈øecret nature or influence in every creature, and that to every nature of one ≈øort or kind he hath given one common influence, and to every one of ≈øeverall kinds their ≈øeverall influence and vertue, whether it bee on Phy≈øick, or other ≈øecret works, which partly are found out by naturall workman≈øhip. And yet more things are unknown then are apparant to our ≈øen≈øes: What! doe you not think that an hearb that is appointed for one di≈øea≈øe, which it will cure, doth not contain in it many more vertues then are known unto us? Yes truly many more. This al≈øo I adde, that if the Feces and combu≈øtible oyle be taken away from this thing or hearb, which in all things is the poi≈øon that ≈øhould be taken away, that brings death unto us, and the
Elements ≈øhould be purified, and ≈øo burned together by Art, that they ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe together by a Limbeck, and be joyned together, as it were coupled in marriage, that it may root out all manner of di≈øea≈øe from every thing, be it hearb or living thing, or be drawn from his venome, as in the 14. Chapter of the Prologue of this Book is declared, and al≈øo in the Prologue of the Animall work, whereas the manner of drawing the Quinte≈ø≈øence out of all venemous bea≈øts, birds, worms, and flies, is plainly declared, that it may help all the griefs of man, but that ≈øpecially is drawn out of the bloud of man, and there is likewi≈øe declared, that there is no need of things without man or bea≈øt to help ≈øuch as are infected. For every creature contains in him≈øelfe the remedy of his di≈øea≈øe, which remedie may be drawn without the hurt of man or bea≈øt, that the di≈øea≈øe may be miraculou≈øly cured, as is there mo≈øt excellently taught in the Theorick and in the Practick. Therefore I would write this, that thou ≈øoon mighte≈øt under≈øtand what marvellous force is in Honey, which is taken out of all floures, and gathered into one Ma≈ø≈øe, which truly is indued with ≈øundry Vertues. For if God hath given unto other things the gift of healing, what then is there not in Honey, which is gathered out of ≈øo many floures, and every hearb indued with his own proper Vertue? Truly if it be brought to his height and excellencie, it will work marvellou≈øly. Now con≈øider what lieth hidden in this Quinte≈ø≈øence, and e≈øteem it not lightly, but keep it ≈øecret as the mo≈øt excellent thing of all the Animal work, the which being obtained, you ≈øhall need no other Medicines to put away all the accidents of the bodie.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p:
NOw I will ≈øet in hand with the practi≈øe. Take twelve quarts of the be≈øt Virgin Honey, and put it in a great earthen Ve≈ø≈øel with a Limbeck well luted, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and lute a Recipient to the neck of it, and di≈øtill that which will di≈øtill of it in your Balneo boyling. My ≈øon, know this, that there is no common water in Honey, but onely
Philo≈øophicall and Elementall, for the element of Aire doth fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øe with the element of fire, in the which the aire is contained, and the aire when it ri≈øeth, re≈øembleth the ≈øavour of Aqua vitae di≈øtilled, and at the fir≈øt can not be known from Aqua vitae, neither by ≈øight, neither by ≈øavour: di≈øtill it untill there will no more ari≈øe, then leave the ve≈ø≈øell in Balneo five daies with a Limbeck and receiver, let it boyl night and day, that the matter may be dried, then let it cool, and take it out, and take away the receiver and Limbeck, and that which is in the receiver pour into the ve≈ø≈øel again upon the dry matter, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and cover the mouth of the ve≈ø≈øel with a clean di≈øh well luted, and let your Balneum be onely luke warm. My ≈øon, under≈øtand that it may thus be done, for it is good that the fire be drawn with his proper aire, ≈øo as a man would ≈øtay ≈øo long, for it would be of the greater force. The ancient Philo≈øophers wrought in this ≈øort, but the danger is, when the ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhall be opened lea≈øt the water fly away, for it is as ≈øubtill as wine. For every time the aire is to be drawn away, and againe to be poured on, making putrifaction in a warm Balneo, but fir≈øt it mu≈øt be well luted, and a Limbeck being ≈øet on with a receiver, you mu≈øt reiterate the work, untill the fire ri≈øe like unto red bloud. There is another methode or rule of working found out in the≈øe our daies, which is in this ≈øort.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
THey are thus drawn out, and the matter dried, as is afore≈øaid, then take common water, twice di≈øtilled in Balneo, and pour on as much as is ≈øufficient, and ≈øet it in Balneo, cover the mouth of the ve≈ø≈øell: but let not the Balneum boyle, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand three daies and three nights, moving it day and night with a ≈øpattle of wood: let it coole, and be poured out and ≈øtrained. Then take a clean ve≈ø≈øell and pour out that which is clear, and pour upon the feces fre≈øh di≈øtilled water, as you did before, and ≈øet the ve≈ø≈øell in Balneo, and do as you did before: let it be cleared and put a≈øide with the fir≈øt water, and put on againe fre≈øh water di≈øtilled, and ≈øet it in Balneo as
afore≈øaid, and do this ≈øo often untill the water be no more coloured, for then have you the fire ≈øeparated from the earth, but re≈øerve the earth or feces untill I tell you further what you ≈øhall do with it, for there is yet a combu≈øtible oyle in it.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: TAke the ve≈ø≈øel wherein is the coloured water, and ≈øet it in Balneo with a Limbeck, and receiver well luted, and di≈øtill all the water with a boyling Balneo, and let the matter be well dried and coole, then take away the Alimbeck, and let the ve≈ø≈øell remaine in Balneo, and pour on the water again upon the matter, and make a fire, and ≈øet a di≈øh upon the mouth of the ve≈ø≈øell, and let it ≈øtand ≈øo in Balneo three daies, every day moving it with a ≈øpattle of wood three or four times, then let it coole, and be taken out and be ≈øtrained. Then take a clean ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øoftly pour out that which is clear into it, and upon the feces ≈øtraightwaies pour on fre≈øh di≈øtilled water, ≈øtirring it about with a woodden ladle, and let it ≈øtand to clear one day, and the feces which remain put unto the fir≈øt feces. Then take a ve≈ø≈øell, and ≈øet it in a boyling Balmeo untill it be dry, and reiterate this work untill there remaine no feces in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell, ≈øo ≈øhall you have the pure element of Fire: and the element of the Aire al≈øo mu≈øt be ≈øo often di≈øtilled, untill there remain nothing in the bottome: and in this ≈øort you ≈øhall have the pure Element. Separate then the water from the fire, and let it dry, ≈øo ≈øhall you have a clear ≈øhining matter like to Camphore: keep the fire well in a gla≈ø≈øe, and the aire with the water in another gla≈ø≈øe well clo≈øed, untill you have your earth prepared.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
TAke all the earth with the feces, and draw out the combu≈øtible oyle by a di≈øcen≈øorie, that is, with two ve≈ø≈øels joyned together and luted, untill the combu≈øtible oyle do pa≈ø≈øe, which is profitable for all cold di≈øea≈øes, and other pa≈ø≈øions, which were too long to rehear≈øe: if you de≈øire not the combu≈øtible oyle,
≈øuffer it to fly away. Then take your earth, and calcine it in a furnace of reverberation gently, untill it be all white as ≈ønow, then take a great earthen or ≈øtone ve≈ø≈øell, and put your white calcined earth into it, and pour out a good quantity of common water di≈øtilled, and ≈øtir it with a wooden ladle, and ≈øet it three daies in a boyling bath, and cover it with a di≈øh, and ≈øtir it every day ten or twelve times. Let it coole, and the ve≈ø≈øell take out, and let it clear one whole day: then take another clean ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øoftly pour out that which is clear, and upon the feces pour againe fre≈øh di≈øtilled water, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and do as you did before. Take it out againe, and let it clear one day and night, and that which is uppermo≈øt clear, pour out to the fir≈øt water: Then put to fre≈øh di≈øtilled water the third time unto the Feces, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and do as you did before, and pour out the clear the third time unto the fir≈øt water, then ca≈øt away the Feces of the third water, for they are of no value. Then take the ve≈ø≈øell into which the water was put, and ≈øet it in Balneo, with a Limbeck and a receiver: and with a boyling Balneo, draw out the water untill the matter be made dry. Let it coole, take away the Limbick, and pour in the water againe upon the Earth, or ≈øalt, and ≈øet it one day in boyling Balneo. Let it di≈ø≈øolve, and clear, and take out that which is clear; and put in a little di≈øtilled water upon the Feces, and let it ≈øtand two or three hours in a warm bath: take it out, let it clear by the ≈øpace of one hour or two, and pour out the upper part to the fir≈øt water, and ca≈øt away the Feces, for there is nothing in them. Let the ve≈ø≈øel be ≈øet againe in Balneo with the earth or ≈øalt, and di≈øtill away the water untill all be dry, and do as afore, reiterating the work, untill that no Feces remain in the bottom, then drein away the the water from the earth, and you ≈øhall find a faire earth like Cri≈øtal: and ≈øo you ≈øhall have pure elements.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p:
TAke a great gla≈ø≈øe that will bear the fire, and put into it your earth and your fire, and pour your aire upon it, and ≈øet it to di≈øtill in a furnace, in pot or with ≈øand or a≈øhes, with a Limbeck well luted, having a hole in the uppermo≈øt knottie
part, that a Funnell may be put in when there ≈øhall bee need of Infu≈øion: when as the humiditie that it hath received be half con≈øumed, then fortifie your fire by little and little increa≈øing it, untill you ≈øee the water boyl, and keep the fire in that ≈øtate ≈øtill, untill it be con≈øumed even to a pint. Take away the fire, let it cool, take away your Receiver, and open the hole of the Limbeck, and put in your gla≈ø≈øe Funnell, and pour in all the di≈øtilled water in the Recipient upon the Earth, and ≈øtop the hole of the Limbeck, and ≈øet the Receiver unto the neck thereof well luted, and di≈øtill again, and ob≈øerve the manner afore≈øaid of drawing and making infu≈øion, and do thus ten times. The tenth Di≈øtillation fini≈øhed, let all pa≈ø≈øe together; for then the earth is made flying. So the aire, the water, the fire, and the earth will a≈øcend together by the Limbeck, and be brought into one ≈øub≈øtance which were in four. One together in nature, and now ≈øimple as the incorruptible heaven, yet are they not fixed: but notwith≈øtanding they are ≈øo coupled together between them≈øelves, that by no means they can be ≈øeparated, but will continue one ≈øimple bodie for ever; even as the Chri≈øtalline and uncorruptible heaven, which notwith≈øtanding is compounded of the four Elements. What thinke you of this my Son? Cannot this Quinte≈ø≈øence help every di≈øea≈øe that doth infect man through his mo≈øt excellent temperature, whether it be in heat, cold, moi≈øt, or drie, for all are in it that he may di≈øtribute unto every one that which is nece≈ø≈øary, even as the heaven, when need requireth, giveth unto the earth all things, as coldne≈ø≈øe, heat, or moi≈øture: And yet it is neither hot, cold, moi≈øt, nor drie, but of one ≈øimple e≈ø≈øence, and that indued with ≈øuch a nature, that it giveth unto every thing that which is nece≈ø≈øary: In like manner doth this Quinte≈ø≈øence. Therefore my Son rejoyce, and give the Almightie God thanks which hath opened the≈øe things unto the Philo≈øophers.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p:
NOw my Son, if thou wilt bring this Quinte≈ø≈øence yet to a greater perfection: Take a great Circulatory, or Pellican,
that is, a gla≈ø≈øe that hath a great head like to a Limbeck, and in the top of the head a hole, by the which the matter may be poured in by a Funnell; let the hole be ≈øtopped; out of the head cometh forth two armes bending round unto the belly, by the which that which doth a≈øcend up may fall down again by tho≈øe armes of gla≈ø≈øe into the belly of the Pellican: This is the form of the Ve≈ø≈øels that di≈øtill one into another, or Pellican. 1. Take then your Quinte≈ø≈øence, and put it in a Pellican in a≈øhes, but better in ≈øalt prepared and dried, and make your fire like unto the extream heat in Summer, and the Quinte≈ø≈øence will ri≈øe like unto a red Oil, and fall down again by the armes of the Pellican; and by often a≈øcen≈øion, the Quinte≈ø≈øence will wax thick, that it will tarry in the bottom and ri≈øe no more; then fortifie the fire that it may a≈øcend and de≈øcend again; then keep the fire in that heat untill it a≈øcend no more, but re≈øt in the bottom; then make your fire ≈øtronger, that it may a≈øcend and de≈øcend again, and keep the heat in the ≈øame degree untill it ri≈øe no more. 2. Ob≈øerve this manner in augmenting your fire untill the water be fixed, and the gla≈ø≈øe be red hot four and twenty houres together; if the Quinte≈ø≈øence doe not then a≈øcend, it is fixed, and brought unto his highe≈øt vertue; and take it out of the gla≈øs, being yet hot, for if it be cold, it will wax hard, ≈øo that you mu≈øt break the gla≈ø≈øe; for at the fire it doth wax liquid, and being ≈øet open in the air, it doth congeal, and peirceth every hard thing, as Oil doth any dry leather, and in colour is like unto a Rubie, and through ≈øhining like a Chri≈øtall, it giveth light in the dark, ≈øufficient to read by. What doe≈øt thou think of this my Son? are there not many ≈øtrange bodies created of God? Truly he hath indued the Philo≈øophers with no le≈ø≈øe gifts; for they that can look into the ≈øecrets of nature, ≈øhall ≈øee it to be of an incredible operation, for this is gathered by the Bees of the ≈øubtile≈øt part of all Plants, Trees, Floures, and Fruits, and at that time, when Floures break out and Trees bud. It is worthily called the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone, for it is fixed and liquable as Wax, and as the minerall ≈øtone tran≈ømuteth the impure metall, ≈øo doth this alter di≈øea≈øes. Hereby it doth appear, that this doth bear the bell among≈øt all vegetals; whereas it being yet
in his gro≈øene≈ø≈øe and impute, it is but of ≈ømall value for any u≈øe in Phy≈øick, by what means ≈øo ever it be boiled or ≈øcummed, but doth alwayes retain his nature; for it con≈øi≈øteth of all the fruits of the earth, plants, and trees: Whereof one hearb is hot, another cold, another dry, another moi≈øt, one a≈øtringent, another laxative, ≈øome corro≈øive, others venomous; and ≈øo divers hearbs have their divers qualities. 3. It cometh to pa≈ø≈øe, if it help one di≈øea≈øe, by and by it hindereth another; for every thing worketh according to his property, when as there is ≈øeparation made in the body; and of this ≈øeparation it ingendereth bloud and other humours: And they are likened unto Gunpowder, which ≈øo long as it lieth ≈øtill there cometh no hurt of it, but if it be brought unto the fire, it ≈øtrait uttereth his ≈øecret nature, and is kindled with a venomous fire, which cannot be quenched with water; for the cold and dry, hot and moi≈øt, doe ≈øtrive among≈øt them≈øelves, a wind is ≈øtirred up, that breaketh all things that is near unto it. The like happeneth unto Honey, that when it cometh to the region of the Liver, that it ≈øhould be there ≈øeparated, then it ≈øheweth his nature to pa≈ø≈øe up, and ≈øwell with wind, that it is no marvell, if that through contention the veins of the Liver be broken, as oftentimes it happeneth, whereupon Impo≈øthumes are cau≈øed in divers places, and bringeth forth ≈øuch inflammations, that the veines are ea≈øily broken; although many doe greatly commend Honey, but they are not the children of Philo≈øophy, neither doe they under≈øtand the nature of it: But when it is brought to a ≈øimple, fixed as Wine, then is it the cheife≈øt Medicine among≈øt all the vegetables, neither is the like unto this found in all the world. Give God thanks, and be liberall unto the poor. The do≈øe of this is one grain, and it mu≈øt be taken every morning with an empty ≈øtomack, likewi≈øe in the evening, untill the end of the di≈øea≈øe. For every di≈øea≈øe will be cured in ≈øhort time, even after the ≈øame manner, as the Minerall ≈øtone maketh his projection upon metals: Prai≈øe God, and labour diligently.

div.head: The manner and order how to draw the Quinte≈ø≈øence out of the Hearb, called Ro≈øe ≈øolis.
div.p:
NOw my Son, I will teach thee the greate≈øt my≈øtery or ≈øecret among≈øt all vegetable things, who≈øe force and ≈øtrength hath been kept ≈øecret among≈øt all the antient workmen, and they have bound them≈øelves one to another by Oath, that they ≈øhould not utter, in their books or writings, the ≈øtrength of this Hearb, which is called Ro≈øe ≈øolis, and in the Germane tongue Sindawe. Who≈øoever therefore hath not the whole vegetable work, he cannot attain to the ≈øtrength of this Hearb; for in that work is comprehended all the force of medicinall things: And this work of vegetables is not come to the hands, but onely of the antient ≈øworn Artificers, which were skilfull in the liberall Arts. But now my Son, I will open it unto thee with adjuration, that thou ≈øhalt keep this hidden knowledge ≈øecret. Fir≈øt, my Son, you mu≈øt under≈øtand, that this Hearb is the Hearb of the Sun, upon the which the Sun ≈øpreads his beames and influences, as he doth upon Gold in the veines of the Mines; and he poureth out his influences more upon this Hearb, then upon any other which is created of God, as it is evidently known of the antient Philo≈øophers, and this Hearb doth ≈øo farre ≈øurmount all other Hearbs which ≈øpring out of the earth, as the Sun doth all other Planets in the Heaven, and hath greater force and power of influence then any other thing created of God in the Firmament. So this hearb doth excell all others in vertue, and therefore this hearb is decked with another colour, other leaves, and ≈øtranger ≈øhape then all other hearbs. And his nature is ≈øuch, that the hotter and drier the country is in the time of the year, and the heat of the Sun, and the more that the Sun doth heat and burn him, this hearb is the more moi≈øt and filled with dew, in≈øomuch, that upon one branch will hang above a thou≈øand drops. Make a triall, and ≈øtrike this hearb with a ≈ølender twig, that the drops which fall from it may fall into a large gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øell, and you ≈øhall ≈øee the ve≈ø≈øell filled with a marvellous dew, and if the Sun be vehement hot, tho≈øe
branches in ≈øhort ≈øpace, that is, within the ≈øpace of half an hour will be more full of dew then before, and if you ≈øtrike the dew twentie times with a rod, yet it will again bee laden with drops; it were enough if wee did ≈øee no other miracle then from whence this dewie humour ≈øhould ri≈øe, which in ≈øo ≈øhort ≈øpace doth ≈øo abundantly flow from it, and how much the more the burning ≈øun doth ≈øcorch up the other hearbs, ≈øo much the more is this moi≈øt, and filled with drops, even as though it had been ≈øprinkled over with water, hereupon may we gather his marvellous qualities, and judge that there is ≈øome ≈øecret operation hidden in it; if thou do keep this water thus gathered in a gla≈ø≈øe, therewith thou ≈øhalt cure all the di≈øea≈øes of the eyes, whether they come of Rheums, or of Inflammation: It helpeth moreover all the pains and di≈øea≈øes of the heart, it cooleth the Liver, and ≈øtomack that is inflamed, and doth mitigate all the pain of the head that cometh of heat, and driveth away all dreams and Phanta≈øies: It is good al≈øo to kill the Canker and the Wolf, again≈øt the biting of Venemous bea≈øts, again≈øt Poi≈øon drunke, if it be taken by the mouth, it helpeth al≈øo the Pe≈øtilence, it is good for many other di≈øea≈øes which were too long here to rehear≈øe.

This hearb hath the colour of the ≈øun, for his colour is red dark, divided with yellow lines, and his ≈øhape is like a Star, and his proportion like a heavenly Planet, and con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øeven branches, in the outward part broad, neer the ground narrow, and it is as though it were heavie, of a tender ≈øub≈øtance, outwardly hot and moi≈øt, inwardly cold and dry. The left ≈øide of it is cold and moi≈øt, the right ≈øide hot and dry, and it is mo≈øt temperate as gold. Wherefore his Elements cannot be ≈øeparated one from another as in other hearbs, but it may be purged from his Feces, for his fixing letteth that the Elements cannot be ≈øeparated, for the fire will a≈øcend with the aire by the Balneum, as we will hereafter teach. The earth may be ≈øeparated from his Feces, and the Feces likewi≈øe from the fire and aire, although it hath not many dregs. Some Latine Writers call it Lingua avis, or Birds-tongue; ≈øome call it Solaria of the Sun, of Lunaria it is called the Moon; the Fleming calls it Sindow. But the old
Philo≈øophers have kept ≈øecret the qualities as yet for the marvellous effect it worketh. And it is marvell, ≈øaith Arnoldus de Villa nova that a man ≈øhould die that eateth every day ≈øome of it in his gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance, what will it then work when it is brought unto his finene≈ø≈øe, and clean≈øed from his Feces? It hath this great vertue in it, that if it be put into a gla≈ø≈øe, wherein there is poi≈øon mingled with wine, or any other cup that is poi≈øoned, ≈øtraightwayes the gla≈ø≈øe will flie in Pieces, but if it be a ≈øtone pot of Alaba≈øter, or ≈øuch like, the Wine will ≈øo boil, as though there were a violent fire under it, and all the wine will run out untill there be nothing left in the ve≈ø≈øel: Al≈øo if any man carrie this hearb about him, and happen on his enemies, they ≈øhall have no power to hurt, but contrariwi≈øe to ≈øhew him all kind of dutie. Al≈øo if any man bee bewitched either in bodie, or in his art, that is in Cookerie, Brewing, or Baking, or by any other meanes, this hearb carried about him makes him free from the witchcraft. If it be al≈øo tyed upon the belly of a woman with child, ≈øhe ≈øhall ≈øtraightwayes be delivered, although the childe were dead and rotten within, as it hath been oftentimes proved by experience. This hearb carried about one, or a little thereof every day eaten as long as it is u≈øed, pre≈øerveth a man from the Falling Sickne≈ø≈øe. Moreover, if a man be taken with the Apoplexie, that his mouth be drawn a≈øide, and his ≈øpeech and ≈øen≈øes taken from him, they ≈øhall be all re≈øtored again, if the ≈øick drinke the juyce of this hearb ≈øtreined, as hath been oftentimes proved. Moreover if it be hanged about the neck of one that is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a ≈øpirit, ≈øo long as he carrieth that about him, he ≈øhall be quiet as a Lamb, and the power of the ≈øpirit ≈øhall be taken away. Make a proof, and you ≈øhall find it true. The bleeding at the no≈øe is by and by ≈øtayed, if you hold that hearb in your mouth. They that are wearied with travell, if they drink the juyce thereof in wine, they are by and by ≈øo refre≈øhed, as if they had not laboured or gone no journey, it doth comfort the Sinews, Mu≈øcles, Tendons, and all the whole nature. Wounds are al≈øo cured therewith, if it be drunk ten daies together in Wine or Ale, if the wound be wa≈øhed with the ≈øame drinke, and bound up with a cloth wet in the
≈øame. The pain of the teeth, is by and by appea≈øed, if that hearb be laid unto it. All the≈øe things have been often proved and found true. If it will doe ≈øuch things while≈øt it is yet hindred with his gro≈ø≈øe matter, what will it work when it is brought to his perfection? My Son, know this for a truth that there is no hearb that grows upon the earth to be compared unto this in ≈øtrength and goodne≈ø≈øe, therefore take heed that you doe not neglect it, but diligently remember and keep the ≈øecret clo≈øe from them that are not of the nature of our children, and from the ignorant. For if this hearb did not grow ≈øo plentifully, and the properties thereof were known, it would be more e≈øteemed then gold or precious ≈øtones, for the Effects of the Quinte≈ø≈øence are marvellous, as hereafter ≈øhall appear.

Now there remaineth that we mu≈øt teach how to bring this hearb to his highe≈øt degree, and to his Quinte≈ø≈øence. Fir≈øt, it is to be gathered, the ≈øame having his cour≈øe in his own hou≈øe, that is in the Lion, and the Moon behold him with a ≈øini≈øter quadrate A≈øpect. It is to be gathered whole, with roots, leaves and floures, ≈øo that there be neither earth, dirt, nor other hearbs mingled withall. Neither mu≈øt it by amy means touch any water or be made moi≈øt. Therefore you mu≈øt take heed that you gather it not in rainie weather, or moi≈øt weather: but rather when the Sun doth ≈øhine hotte≈øt upon it, gather great ≈øtore of it, and ≈øtamp it well in a morter of Marble, and put it in a Cucurbite of ≈øtone with a head and receiver luted, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and di≈øtil away all the water, untill it be ≈øo dry like pouder, and there will ri≈øe together with the water of the colour of mo≈øt fine gold, which onely happeneth in this hearb, and in none other, and when there remaineth no more liquor, yet leave the cucurbite for three or four dayes in Balneo, and boil it night and day that all the moi≈øture may be perfectly ≈øeparated and drawn away, then let it cool, and take away the receiver, and ≈øtop it diligently, then take off the head, and take out the matter and beat it in a Marble morter into mo≈øt fine powder that it may pa≈ø≈øe through a thick ≈øieve, put this pouder again into an earthen cucurbite, and pour on your water
and aire, and ≈øtir it with a woodden ladle, and cover the mouth of the cucurbite clo≈øe with a tile, and ≈øet it in a warm bath by the ≈øpace of nine dayes to putrifie, every day ≈øtirring it with a wodden ladle four or five times, and cover the cucurbite again with a tile, ≈øetting a weight of lead upon it, at the nine dayes end take your ve≈ø≈øel out of the Balneo, and that which is in it, ≈øtrein it into an earthen ve≈ø≈øell gla≈øed, and ≈øtrein it hard untill the matter drie. Then take this dry pouder, and put it into his cucurbite, and cover it with a tile, and keep it in a warm place untill I teach you what you ≈øhall doe with it.

1. The moi≈øt liquor which is drawn from it will be red, for the Element of fire is there pre≈øent with the air and the water, put that liquor into a cucurbite of ≈øtone, and put on a head, and lute it well, and ≈øet it in Balneo with a Receiver well luted, and di≈øtill away all the water, with the air ≈øeverally from the fire in a boyling bath, until there will no more di≈øtil, and the fire will pa≈ø≈øe away in the bottome, then take away the ve≈ø≈øel out of the bath and ≈øtop it well untill I teach thee what is further to be done.

2. Then take again the ≈øtone cucurbite wherein your pouder is contained, which I bad you before to keep, and pour on the fire and the aire, and ≈øtir it well with a wooden ladle, and ≈øet it in a warm bath nine dayes more, and cover it with a tile, and ≈øtir it four or five times every day with a ladle as you did afore. And when the nine daies are pa≈øt, ≈øtrein out that which is in the Ve≈ø≈øel, and pour the liquor into a gla≈øed ve≈ø≈øel, the re≈øidue of the pouder put into another ve≈ø≈øel, as you did before, and keep it ≈øo long untill I teach thee how to draw out the combu≈øtible oyle.

3. Then take again the Ve≈ø≈øel wherein your fire is, and mingle your liquor with it which you keep in your gla≈øed ve≈ø≈øel, where your fire and aire is, and ≈øet a head upon the ve≈ø≈øel where your matter is, and lute it, and ≈øet it in Balneo, and ≈øet a receiver to the bill of the head, then di≈øtill out the water and air with a boyling bath until no more will di≈øtill, and you ≈øhall have in the receiver water and aire, take them away, and take the Ve≈ø≈øel out of Balneo, and you ≈øhall find remaining in the bottome like thick Turpentine, and that is the Element
of fire mingled with many Feces. Now the fire is to be ≈øeparated from the Feces in this manner, pour on your water and aire upon that from whence you draw it, and ≈øtir it with a ≈øpoon, and cover it with a tile, and let it ≈øettle four dayes, and the Feces will fall into the bottome, and pour out ≈øoftly that that is clear into a clean cucurbite, that no Feces pa≈ø≈øe; withall ≈øtop the Ve≈ø≈øel wherein the Feces are, and ≈øet it by. But that Ve≈ø≈øel that containeth the water fire, and aire, ≈øet it in Balneo with a head and receiver fitted and well luted, and di≈øtill the water and aire in that ≈øame degree. And when it will di≈øtill no more, take away the receiver: Let the ve≈ø≈øel cool, and you ≈øhall find in the bottome your fire, which keep in his ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopped, and pour in your water and aire again upon the Feces, from whence you did draw them, and ≈øtir them with a ≈øpoon, and let it ≈øettle four dayes, then pour it out ≈øoftly from his Feces into the ve≈ø≈øell that holdeth your fire, ≈øo that no Feces be mingled withall, cover your ve≈ø≈øell wherein your Feces remain, and ≈øet it up. But your Ve≈ø≈øel, wherein your water, air, and fire, is ≈øet again in Balneo as I ≈øhewed you, and di≈øtill away the water and aire, for they two doe alwaies pa≈ø≈øe away together, and the fire remaineth in the bottome. Pour on the water and air again upon the Feces, and ≈øtir it with a ≈øpoon, then let it ≈øettle four dayes, (this is now the third repetition, whereby you have ≈øeparated the water and aire from the Feces,) and that which is clear pour out into the Ve≈ø≈øel that holdeth your fire. Then put your Feces unto the fir≈øt which I bad you keep, in the which your combu≈øtible oyle is. For now you have drawn your fire out of your Feces: therefore di≈øtill your water with the air, and when it will di≈øtill no more, take away your Ve≈ø≈øell, and you ≈øhall finde in the bottome the Element of fire not yet pure, but foul and full of dregs, pour on therefore the water and air again, and ≈øtir it well with a ≈øpoon or ladle, cover it, and let it ≈øtand, and ≈øettle four dayes, then pour out that which is clear into another clean ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øet a≈øide the Ve≈ø≈øel wherein your Feces are. But the Ve≈ø≈øel wherein your fire, water, and oyle are, ≈øet it in Balneo to di≈øtill as long as it will di≈øtil, then take it out, and pour the liquor di≈øtilled
into the ve≈ø≈øell where your feces are, and doe as I taught you to work with the feces, untill you have your element of fire without any feculent or gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance.

When you have di≈øtilled away the water and air from the fire, and ≈øuffered it to ≈øettle four dayes, and that all be clear without any feces, then ≈øhall you have your pure fire. Therefore put all your feces together unto your fir≈øt feces, where your combu≈øtbile oyle is. Afterward take a great Cucurbite of gla≈ø≈øe, and put all your three Elements into it, and ≈øet it in a≈øhes with a Limbeck and a Receiver fitted and luted, and kindle a gentle fire, fir≈øt in your furnace, and increa≈øe it more and more, untill the fire and air be pa≈ø≈øed, and that your Limbeck begin to wax red within. Then make the heat of your fire moderate, untill all your element of fire be pa≈ø≈øed, and the head red like bloud, and the water and air ≈øhall ≈øwim upon it like oyle: by this meanes the≈øe three Elements ≈øhall be brought to their highe≈øt e≈ø≈øence, and be perfectly rectified. Take away the Receiver, and ≈øtop it diligently, untill your earth be prepared, and know, that in the du≈øt and feces there remaineth yet a combu≈øtible oyle, which you may extract by a di≈øcen≈øory, if you will. It is good again≈øt the cold Gout, for Members benommed, and Sinews too much mollified. If thou be weary of this labour, put this powder or feces into a reverberatory, that they may be mingled with a gentle fire, untill it be as white as ≈ønow; which being done, put it into a large cucurbite of ≈øtone, and pour on a great quantity of water twice di≈øtilled, it is not materiall how much water you pour on, and ≈øtir it well with a woodden ladle or ≈øpoon five or ≈øix times, alwayes cover it diligently with a tile, and after four dayes ≈øuffer it to cool, and let it ≈øtand four dayes and ≈øettle, then pour out the cleer from the feces warily into another clean ve≈ø≈øell, and pour on fre≈øh di≈øtilled water as before, ≈øtir it with your ≈øpoon, and keep it two dayes in Balneo as before, then ≈øuffer it to cool and ≈øettle, and pour out the clear from the feces, and put it to the fir≈øt water; doe this the third time, and then ca≈øt away the feces, for they are good for nothing: All your waters that you have drawn, di≈øtill by Balneo, or, for the more ≈øpeed, by a≈øhes, that all the water may ri≈øe, and that there remain in the bottome a du≈øty matter, pour on di≈øtilled water again, ≈øtir it, and keep it in Balneo by the ≈øpace of four and twenty houres,
then let it cool and ≈øettle, and pour out that which is clear gently from the feces: Poure on again more common water upon them, and ≈øtir it, ≈øet it in Balneo ten or twelve houres, take it out, let it ≈øettle, and poure the clear unto the fir≈øt water, and ca≈øt away the feces, they are nothing worth. Repeat this work ≈øo often, untill there remain no feces after it hath ≈øetled. Then ≈øhall you have your earth rectified from all his feces, which you ≈øhall congeal and dry, that it may be like powder or du≈øt: Then joyn that with your other elements in the gla≈ø≈øe, and it will ≈øtraight re≈øolve into his element, for the element of water is there pre≈øent: ≈øet them all together in a furnace upon a≈øhes, put on a Head with a Receiver well luted; the head mu≈øt have a hole in the top, that with a funnell the liquour may be poured in, and alwayes ≈øtopped ≈øafely. Make your fire in your furnace fir≈øt gentle, afterward greater, untill that, that is fermented, doe pa≈ø≈øe; but all is not to be drawn out, but about half a ≈øextary of the liquour with the water, that the matter may remain moi≈øt; for if you ≈øhould drive out all, it would congeale into an hard ma≈ø≈øe, and break the gla≈ø≈øe in the furnace. Then open the hole which is in the top of the Head, and with a funnell poure in that which is in the Receiver; but fir≈øt it mu≈øt be made warm, lea≈øt by pouring in the cold liquour the gla≈ø≈øe doe break, but if you ≈øuffer the gla≈ø≈øe to cool, you may poure it in without any danger. Repeat this inbibition ten or twelve times, afterward di≈øtill out what≈øoever will be di≈øtilled, ≈øo long as any thing will pa≈ø≈øe by the neck of the Limbeck: For after this tenth di≈øtillation, the earth will be no more congealed, but will re≈øt in the bottome like a red golden Oil. Inbibe it again, pouring on the liquour, and di≈øtilling it untill all the elements pa≈ø≈øe together by the Limbeck, and that nothing at all doe remain in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell. Then give thanks to God for his marvellous gifts, which he hath di≈øtributed unto his Philo≈øophers, and hath given them ≈øo great knowledge of things as they uttered in this work, which is altogether heavenly, and rather divine then humane: For it is a great marvell in this life, that mans under≈øtanding can bring the≈øe inferiour things to ≈øo great perfection that they have attained, even to the highe≈øt degree of vertue. Truly it is the work of the Holy Gho≈øt, which hath put it into the mindes of men. For I doe affirm, that who≈øoever hath this hearb ≈øo prepared, that he
may help all the infirmities of mans body, whether they be curable or uncurable, except naturall death, which is ordained before unto every man of God. Yea, this I dare be bold to ≈øay, that if a man doe u≈øe daily the weight of one ≈øcruple of this Quinte≈ø≈øence, or the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Sugar, and potable Gold, wherein Pearles are di≈ø≈øolved, or the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Selandine, that man by Gods help ≈øhall not die before the day of the great judgement; for the humours in mans body can by no meanes predominate one over another, as in the thirty ≈øix Chapter of Vegetals is taught, where is treated of the Quinte≈ø≈øence of all Medicinall things, and there it is ≈øhewed, that by Gods help the life of man may be prolonged even untill that day, void and free from all di≈øea≈øes and ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. And further, that man may be pre≈øerved in the ≈øtate he was in at thirty yeares of age, and in the ≈øame ≈øtrength and force of wit; and upon that doe all the Philo≈øophers agree, that a man may continue in the ≈øame ≈øtate as long as in an earthly Paradi≈øe. This is ≈øo plainly and at large ≈øhewed in that Chapter, that will you, nill you, you ≈øhall be inforced to conceive it in your mind to beleeve it, and to confe≈ø≈øe it to be true: Therefore it is not needfull to rea≈øon much of the force and qualities of this Quinte≈ø≈øence, but what≈øoever di≈øea≈øe a man be infected withall, give him to drink with Wine ≈øo much of this Quinte≈ø≈øence as a nut≈øhell will hold, and in ≈øhort ≈øpace he ≈øhall be healed, as it were miraculou≈øly, according as the di≈øea≈øe is, violent or gentle. But if you give this Quinte≈ø≈øence to drink, mixed with the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Sugar, with potable Gold, wherein Pearles are di≈ø≈øolved, and with the Quinte≈ø≈øence of Selandine, within one day you ≈øhall cure all the di≈øea≈øes what≈øoever they be; hereby it doth appear, that it is rather a divine work then humane. Therefore give God the prai≈øe, and take heed that you doe not utter this ≈øecret, for Tyrants would by that means prolong their lives, that they might bring to pa≈ø≈øe their wicked purpo≈øes, whereof both you and I ≈øhould be the occa≈øion. Therefore keep it ≈øecret, for it is one of the greate≈øt ≈øecrets among≈øt all the vegetals, whereunto no trea≈øure may be compared. Work therefore, and di≈øtribute liberally unto the poor, and God ≈øhall give thee eternall felicity.

div.head: The Spagyrick Antidotary of the preparation and making of Medicines again≈øt gun-≈øhot, taken out of the Chirurgery of Jo≈øephus Quir≈øitanus.
div.p:
IT is an old and true ≈øaying of the Poet, that there is nothing more imperious than an ignorant man, which thinketh nothing well done, but that he doth him≈øelf, which thing, as it may be ≈øeen in many other Arts, ye ‚Ä¢ mo≈øt e≈øpecially in this, which is called the Spagyrick Art. For we ≈øee every where certain men, I know not what they be, puffed up with a certain barbarous and fooli≈øh pride, which with great ≈øcorne inveigh again≈øt tho≈øe Medicines which are drawn out of the metalline Mines: which notwith≈øtanding it is apparent were in u≈øe, and had in great e≈øtimation with the cheif antient Phi≈øitians, as we have declared in that book, which we have ≈øet forth of the Spagyrick preparation of Medicines. And what, I pray you, is the cau≈øe of this anger, or rather madne≈ø≈øe, but that (as they them≈øelves confe≈ø≈øe) they know not the preparation of them? O happy Arts, if onely Artificers might judge of them, as Fabius is reported ≈øometimes to have ≈øaid: Then are they unhappy, of whom the ignorant and unlearned fear not ≈øo ra≈øhly to give judgement, which never yet under≈øtood from whence, or why, this is called the Spagyrick Art, which learned men of two greek words have ≈øo named; becau≈øe by that Art a certain ≈øubtill and ≈øpirituall nature is drawn, gathered, and pre≈ø≈øed out, wherein the force and effect of the Medicine doth cheifly con≈øi≈øt; the great and incomparable commodity whereof, as it appeareth in many other di≈øea≈øes, ≈øo ≈øhall it cheifly be known in curing wounds by gun-≈øhot: As I tru≈øt (God willing) it ≈øhall much more happily be tried and found out, by the preparations of Medicines animall, vegetable, and minerall, and by other E≈ø≈øences drawn out of Mercury, Sulphur, Vitriol, Ar≈øenick, Iron, Copper, Lead, and Litarge, and al≈øo out of Antimony, and ≈øuch other minerals, as al≈øo out of the gro≈ø≈øe and fat bodies of ≈øimple metals, of whom it is farre off, that the force ≈øhould be ≈øo great (although the antient Phi≈øitians have u≈øed them to cure Wounds and Ulcers, as their Writings
doe te≈øtifie) as the force of their ≈øpirits, which may be called, as it were, their ≈øoules. But peradventure ≈øome of tho≈øe backbiters will ≈øay, why are not we content with tho≈øe Medicines and Remedies, which the learned Antiquity hath delivered unto us, and that Hyppocrates and Gallen, the antient Pillars of our Art, and others, have ≈øet forth in their Monuments? why ≈øeek we new wayes never heard of before, e≈øpecially unknown to the Apothecaries? But ≈øome of us will an≈øwer, that the onely remedy of Mercury precipitate, is the onely remedy (to pa≈ø≈øe over other) which very lately they have begun to u≈øe in curing of Wounds by gun-≈øhot, and other maligne Ulcers, were ≈øufficient to an≈øwer this their que≈øtion, yea, and to reprove their folly joyned with intollerable pride. But if authority be asked for, I think Ge≈øner, Guinter, Andernack, Severine, (to pa≈ø≈øe over a great many other) will be for us of great authority with the learned, as the≈øe ≈ølanderers; e≈øpecially, becau≈øe the learning of the≈øe famous men is confirmed by their learned Writings and Monuments, that tho≈øe tongues might count it a great honour unto them, to confe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves their Schollers. It were ea≈øie for me to bring forth many other arguments, if I did not ≈øee the folly of the≈øe back-biters to be ≈øo great, whereof truly I am a≈øhamed, e≈øpecially when I behold ≈øome of their books lately ≈øet forth, wherein, contrary to the purpo≈øe of the Treati≈øe, ≈øtrange things are inforced, that (as the old Proverb ≈øaith) the ointment ≈øeemeth to con≈øi≈øt in nothing, as though they pertain to the purpo≈øed treating of curing the Gout, certain invective digre≈ø≈øions I know not what of the beginning of things, of the originall of metals and Philo≈øophers ≈øtone (which of them is called Moro≈øophocus) or did in any point ≈øeem to agree with it. Therefore again and again I am inforced to cry out, O happy Arts, if onely Artificers might judge of them. How farre unlike was the purpo≈øe of many old men, the which if they were ignorant of any thing, which they under≈øtood was known of others, even in farre di≈øtant Countries, they ≈øpared no labour to goe ≈øee them. Plato inflamed with de≈øire to learn tho≈øe things which he knew not, went into Aegypt, and after to Tarentum, to Architas, and over all Italy, to hear the other Pythagorical Philo≈øophers:
Apollonius Tyanius travelled through the kingdome of Per≈øia, and pa≈ø≈øed over the Mountain Cauca≈øus, and vi≈øited the Albanes, Scythians, Ma≈ø≈øagets, and all the rich kingdomes of India; afterwards was carried unto the Brachmanes, and heard Jarehas in his chaire of gold di≈øputing of the hidden cau≈øes of things, and of the hidden my≈øteries of nature; from thence by the Elamites, Babylonians, Chaldees, Medes, A≈ø≈øirians, Arabians, and Pale≈øtines, he returned to Alexandria, and from thence went into Ethiopia to hear the Gymno≈øophi≈øts, and to learn their ≈øecret and hidden Arts. This vertue is truly to be followed, and not the ≈øluggi≈øhne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe ≈ølouthful followers, which having ≈øcarce once moved their foot from their country fires, yet will di≈øallow this Spagerick Art, and think no further labour to be taken in ≈øearching of the truth, when notwith≈øtanding, that Art doth make open unto us the marvellous and hidden ≈øecrets of nature; neither in my judgement are they unworthily contemned of tho≈øe, which with their manifold perils and travels have ≈øought out tho≈øe ≈øecrets of nature. But, I pray you, what fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe is this, to forbid us to u≈øe any other Medicines, then tho≈øe which were known in old time? As though Rhabarbe, then which no Medicine is more in u≈øe this day, then were known to the old Phi≈øitians: Further, to what purpo≈øe is it, that they object unto us the Sulphury metalline venomous ≈øtinks (as they call them) by who≈øe ≈ømell and drawn breath (for the≈øe are their contumelious words) they be almo≈øt ≈øtrangled that come into the dens of tho≈øe Cyclops? But is it unknown unto tho≈øe ≈ølanderers and Sycophants, that the old Phi≈øitians made very many Medicines of mo≈øt filthy things, as of the filth of the eares, ≈øweat of the body, of womens men≈øtrues (and that which is horrible to be ≈øpoken) of the dung of man and other bea≈øts, Spittle, Urine, Flies, Mice, the a≈øhes of an Owles head, the hoves of Goats and A≈ø≈øes, the Wormes of a rotten tree, and the ≈øcurfe of Mules, as may be gathered out of the Writings of Galen, A√´tius, Aegineta, Dio≈øcor. Marcel. Plin. Serap. to pa≈ø≈øe the metallines, which it is evident they did al≈øo u≈øe. Truly, when I con≈øider with my ≈øelf the pride of the≈øe fooles, which di≈ødain this metalline part of Phy≈øick, which after their manner contumeliou≈øly
they call Chymericam, and therefore can neither help their own, nor many other di≈øea≈øes. I call to minde a Storie, peradventure known unto them of Herachto Ephe≈øio, which being ≈øick of a drop≈øie, de≈øpi≈øing the help of Phy≈øitians, annointing him≈øelf over with cow-dung, ≈øet him≈øelf in the Sun to drie, and falling a≈øleep was torn in pieces of dogs: but the≈øe are more then ≈øufficiently an≈øwered unto the≈øe fools and ≈ølanderers.

Now I will declare what is my purpo≈øe and ≈øcope in the Treati≈øe; verily to pre≈øcribe plainly hereafter, not tho≈øe things which are already common, or (as it is commonly ≈øaid) known to blind men and Barbers, le≈øt I might ≈øeem to imitate tho≈øe that u≈øe to write Rhap≈øodias, and heaps, but the method and way of preparing Medicines by Spagerick art, that pertain unto Gun≈øhot, which I know are yet unknown unto many Phy≈øitians and Chirurgians. And this I can truly confe≈ø≈øe, that I am induced for two cau≈øes to doe it: Fir≈øt, to provoke tho≈øe that are better learned, if they have any better Medicines to utter them, as al≈øo that I might ≈øpecially help my countrie and mankinde: unto the which (the more is the grief) there is too much need of tho≈øe kinde of Medicines in the≈øe mo≈øt lamentable and cruell times, wherein it hath ≈øo long been bloudded with dome≈øtical and civil wars; but to incounter with their ≈ølanders which cry out, that the≈øe kind of Medicines doe not onely require long and difficile preparation, but al≈øo that they are ≈øo dear that every one cannot ea≈øily u≈øe them. I have thought good therefore fir≈øt to ≈øet down common Medicines, and then to come to tho≈øe which I doe far more e≈øteem, as indeed they are far more excellent then the other, as by their preparation you may know. Albeit al≈øo I have determined to have con≈øideration of the poor and common Souldier, and to ≈øet down them apart that ≈øhall help the rich.
Therefore the Chirurgians are to be admoni≈øhed, that when they goe into the warres, that they take with them the≈øe things ready prepared, which are to be had at mo≈øt Apothecaries.

div.p: Take of new Butter and oyle Olive, ana ‚Ñ• ii. wheat meal clean≈øed from his bran, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. fair water ‚Ñ• iiii. boil all together.

BUt the≈øe Medicines following are not ≈øo much u≈øed among the Apothecaries, neither known unto the Chirurgians, yet mo≈øt profitable for wounds by ≈øhot and all other, who≈øe fit preparation the Spagyrick art doth partly declare.

Turpentine five ounces, of common oyle of Hypericon eight ounces, good white wine half a pound, dige≈øt all eight dayes, after ≈øeeth them untill the wine be con≈øumed, then put to Colophonia and Wax, ana, iii, ounces, Mumia and Amber ana í. ii. melt them again at the fire, and make an ointment according to Art.

There be made other Remedies for the afore≈øaid intents, the making whereof we have de≈øcribed in their proper places, which I commit to the judgement of the skillfull Chirurgians to u≈øe wi≈øely, as the di≈øea≈øe and partie affected doth require. div.p: THe dregs of Wine or crude Tartar brought into pouder, put into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe or earth with his Recipient, make fire by degrees as is done to the making of ≈øtrong water, there will ri≈øe great plenty of white ≈øpirits, which will turn into water, and thick ≈øtinking oyle, ≈øeparate the oyle by a Funnel, and keep it to your u≈øe.

well prepared, untill it be utterly extinct; to this mixture pour Vinegar di≈øtilled, alcool ≈øated, that it may cover it four fingers; di≈øtil the liquor from the feces four or five times, until the Mercury be come into a very red powder, which you ≈øhall circulate with an alcool of Wine in a Pellican eight dayes, ≈øeparate the alcool by a Limbeck, and there will remain in the bottome, the mo≈øt pretious and ≈øweet Balm of Mercury: It healeth all de≈øperate Ulcers, and al≈øo carbunculam in ve≈øica, and greatly helpeth the≈øe Wounds by gun-≈øhot. All other preparations of Mercury, and the manner of u≈øing it, you ≈øhall gather out of the book which we lately ≈øet forth.

Upon the filings of Iron often wa≈øhed with ≈øalt water, pour ≈øharp Vinegar, that it may cover it four fingers, ≈øet it upon warm a≈øhes eight dayes, every day moving the matter, and ≈øeparating the Vinegar which will be coloured, and pouring on again new, and that ≈øo long, till the Vinegar be no more coloured, which being vapoured away, take the powder that remaineth in the bottome, and ≈øublime it with a like portion of Armoniack; the ≈øame ≈øublimate you ≈øhall return again ≈øo often upon his feces, and ≈øublime again untill there appear the colour of a Rubie; then ca≈øt all into ≈øcalding water, that the ≈øalt may di≈ø≈øolve them, by and by put to cold water, and the Balm of Mars will re≈øt in the bottome like the calx of Gold; pour away the water, and put to fre≈øh again, that the Balm may be made ≈øweet.

Of this with the ≈øpirit of Wine alcolizat by circulations, you ≈øhall make a red oyle, mo≈øt excellent for all inward Hemeroides, or I≈ø≈øues of blood, and to ≈øtrengthen the bowels, if one drop be mixed with con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, or Confery, or given with Wine.

The filings of Iron fir≈øt well wa≈øhed, you ≈øhall calcine with the flower of Sulphur, or di≈ø≈øolve with Strong Water, then pour on very ≈øharp Vinegar, and ≈øet it in a warm place certain dayes, then reverberate it with an open fire, as Art commandeth, one whole day, gathering alwayes the flowers which remain above, untill all be converted into a very red and light powder.

After the ≈øame manner you ≈øhall make the Balme, Oyle,
and Crocus of Copper, out of the which, with the four flame of Vitriol, circulating all artificially, you ≈øhall draw a blewi≈øh Vitriol, who≈øe qualities we have de≈øcribed in another place.

Out of Saturne calcined is drawn a ≈øweeti≈øh ≈øalt in Balneo with di≈øtilled Vinegar, pouring it ≈øo often upon the Feces untill it draw no more: The men≈øtrew evaporated, the ≈øalt remaineth in the bottome, which by often di≈ø≈øolutions, and coagulations, is made Chri≈øtaline, and afterward ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolved into oyle, being ≈øet in a moi≈øt place. But if you circulate this Chri≈øtaline ≈øalt in a Pellican, with the alcool of Wine fifteen dayes, and after take away the men≈øtrew by di≈øtillation, and put to new Wine and circulate it, putting to a fit do≈øe of chri≈øtaline ≈øalt of Tartar, you ≈øhall make a Balm ≈øweeter then Sugar, which will marvellou≈øly prevail again≈øt all maligne Ulcers and di≈øea≈øes of the eyes.

Decoct Antimony made in powder, with a capitall Lie preprepared of Tartar calcined, and Sope a≈øhes, and quick Lime, the ≈øpace of one hour, then let it cool, pouring upon it a little Vinegar, and there will appear a certain redne≈ø≈øe ≈øwimming upon it, which you ≈øhall gather; then again let it boil for one hour or two, again let it cool, and gather that which ≈øwimmeth up; doe this ≈øo often, until there appear no more redne≈ø≈øe; for it is the Sulphur of Antimony, which dried at a ≈øoft fire, you ≈øhall keep it to good u≈øes.

Mingle Antimony with Sugar and Allum, and put all into a Retort of gla≈ø≈øe, make a ≈øoft fire for four or five houres, afterward increa≈øe it, and there will come out an Oyle red like bloud: It is al≈øo done with Mercury ≈øublimate, but great heed is to be taken, le≈øt any errour be committed in the degree of fire.

Boil Sulphur prepared with oyle of Lin≈øeed, with a very ≈øoft fire, and it will be like bloud congealed: Let the matter cool, put it into a Retort, and give it fire, and there will di≈øtil out a very red oyle of Sulphur: It is al≈øo done, if you mingle Bran with your Sulphur and di≈øtil it.

Take of Sulphur Vivum P. i. with which mingle, with a ≈øoft fire, ≈øo much pure Vitriol molten, that it may be one body;
di≈øtil this by a Di≈øcentory, and there will de≈øcend a red oyle into the Receiver.

If lb. i. of the flower of Sulphur be mixed with ii. or iii. lb. of oyle of Turpentine in a dry heat, the flowers will di≈ø≈øolve into a red oyle; then the men≈øtrew rightly and artificially ≈øeparate, circulate the rubin of Sulphur with the Alcool of Wine eight dayes, and you ≈øhall have oyle of Sulphur that hath the qualities of the natural Balm.
The ≈øour oyle of Sulphur is made by Sulphur, by ≈øetting it on a fire, and hanging over it a bell, or a large gla≈ø≈øe head, to keep the vapours which are converted into that ≈øour oyle.

Take the Feces which remaineth in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øel, which is called Colcothar, ≈øtamp that, and if you mingle flints withal, with a violent fire, there will come out a red oyle.

It is al≈øo made with the ≈øimple Colcothar, driven out with a violent fire three dayes ≈øpace, and there will come forth a very hot oyle, which is made ≈øweet by circulation, with ≈øpirit of Wine tartarizated.

But if the Colcothar be di≈ø≈øolved in warm water, and the redne≈ø≈øe in it ≈øeparated, and the water evapourated, the Colcothar will remain ≈øweeti≈øh; that which remaineth, the redne≈ø≈øe being taken away, is called Creta Vitrioli.

But if Vitriol be drawn by the ninth, a Limbeck pouring on alwayes the liquor upon the dead head, and after circulating all by the ≈øpace of eight dayes, you ≈øhall have the ≈øpirit of Vitriol, very profitable for many things.
The flegm of Allum is made like the flegm of Vitriol.
But Allum is prepared, if the flegm be five times poured upon the Feces, out of which it was drawn and di≈øtilled, la≈øt of all dry out all the flegm until it be dry.

Make Brine of Salt, into which ca≈øt hot burnings ≈øtones that they may be imbibed, tho≈øe ≈øtones ≈øo imbibed, put into a Retort, giving fire by degrees, there will comeforth a very hot oyle of Salt.

I ≈øaid before, that there was great force in Butyro Ar≈øenici fixo to cure all venomous and Maligne Ulcers, it is made in this manner: Mingle chri≈øtaline Ar≈øenick fir≈øt ≈øublimed, with onely Colcothar (which doth keep back his poy≈øon) with like weight of Salt of Tartar and Salt-Peter, put all into two gla≈ø≈øes, and fix it, giving fire the ≈øpace of four and twenty houres, fir≈øt very gentle, then of the highe≈øt degree: You ≈øhall find the matter very white fixed, re≈øembling the colour of Pearles, which di≈ø≈øolve in warm water, that you may draw the Alcaly from it; and the powder which remaineth imbibe with oyle of Tartar, or of Talcum, which is better, and dry it at the fire, and doe this thrice: again di≈ø≈øolve the matter in warm water, that you may take away his ≈øalt, and there will remain a very white powder and fixed, which will di≈ø≈øolve in a moi≈øt place into a fat oyle, which is anodinum like Butter.
Out of Talcum rightly and artificially calcined is drawn the ≈øpirit with di≈øtilled Vinegar. This is di≈ø≈øolved into a precious oyle, being ≈øet in a moi≈øt place.

Take of the juyce of Ari≈øtolochia Rotunda, and Savin, ana, iii. ounces, Serpentaria, two ounces, ≈øpirit of Wine one pound, circulate them fir≈øt the ≈øpace of 24. houres, then di≈øtill them, of this water take lb i. of Elect Magnes made into pouder four ounces, circulate them together, and di≈øtill away the water from the Feces, reiterate this three times, and by this means you ≈øhall obtain the preparation of Magnes.
But becau≈øe (as we have ≈øaid) the noble≈øt parts are to bee ≈øtrengthened, and the heart, the principall organ of life, mu≈øt alway be defended, the≈øe preparations following are to bee u≈øed.

Take of Theriaca of Alexandria, two ounces and a half, the be≈øt Myrrh, one ounce and half, Saffron í ii. the ≈øpirit of wine ≈øix ounces, mingle all the≈øe, and in a≈øhes with a very ≈øoft fire di≈øtill it, circulate that which is di≈øtilled in Balneo eight dayes, and then di≈øtill it again. This water hath a mo≈øt excellent qualitie again≈øt the Plague, and all venemous things, and doth marvellou≈øly ≈øtrengthen the heart.

We have ≈øhewed the extraction of the tincture of Gold, Corals, naturall Balm, and the e≈ø≈øence of Pearl in the Book which
I wrote of Preparation; it now re≈øteth for us to ≈øpeak of the Gold of Life, which all ≈øhall know to be the mo≈øt excellent and extream Medicine in curing all di≈øea≈øes, which doe but con≈øider the ≈øingular excellencie of Gold in the cure of the Lepro≈øie.

Calcine gold made into thin plates ≈øo oft with Salt preparate (by a Philo≈øophical calcination) untill it be made unpalpable, the ≈øalt by di≈ø≈øolutions being ≈øeparate from the Alcool of gold, then calcine it again with very white ≈øugred ≈øalt, and to this mixture pour of the ≈øpirit of alcoolyzat, which is proper ≈øalt, according to the precepts of Art, that it may cover it over oely four fingers, then ≈øet on fire, that the Alcool may burn, and this you ≈øhall doe oftentimes, then pour on new Alcool of Wine, and circulate all rightly and decently the ≈øpace of four daies. Then ≈øeparate the men≈øtrew with competent di≈øtillation, and pour on new again, circulating and di≈øtilling as you did before, ≈øo often, untill all the ≈øub≈øtance of Gold be carried out by the Limbeck: The Men≈øtrew being ≈øeparated as it ought, the Gold of Life, will remain in the bottome the mo≈øt excellent, and be≈øt of all Secrets.

div.head: CHAP. I. What things are to be taken heed of in the two fir≈øt Moneths.
div.p:
SO ≈øoon as the woman ≈øhall begin to be with child, which ≈øhe ≈øhall ea≈øily know, by ≈øtopping of her monethly flux,
without di≈øea≈øe, or ancientne≈ø≈øe of yeares; ≈øhe ≈øhall ab≈øtain from all vehement motions and exerci≈øe, whether ≈øhe walk on foot, or ride on hor≈øeback, or in a Coach, or be carried in a Hor≈øe-litter; For where the body is too much ≈øtirred, the internall membrane of the Womb is either accu≈øtomed to be broken, or to be loo≈øly re≈øolved, and thereupon abortment pre≈øently followeth.

To the≈øe things the woman with child mu≈øt diligently beware, that ≈øhe lift not her armes up too high, nor carry great burthens, nor repo≈øe her ≈øelf on hard and unea≈øie ≈øeats: But in≈øtead of exerci≈øe, which may alwayes in ≈øome precede before meat, ≈øhe may walk on foot gently, or ≈øuffer her body and armes gently to be rubbed and ≈øtroked, or may ≈øtretch them forth with ≈øpinning or carding.

div.head: CHAP. II. Order for the third Moneth.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. From the fifth,, ≈øixth, and ≈øeventh Moneth,
div.p: FRom that time forward none of the before mentioned remedies is wont, or ought from thence to be u≈øed, becau≈øe the Babe being now become greater, ≈øtandeth in need of greater nouri≈øhment and bloud, and al≈øo can bear no commotion of phy≈øick.

And this is to be prohibited to all which are with child, that they give not way to take any bloud from the ancle bone of the foot, during the whole time of the womans going, but in ≈øtead thereof, if the di≈øea≈øe ≈øo require, an ounce of Manna in the broth of a Cock, or ≈øo much Ca≈ø≈øia fi≈øtula,

But ≈øharper Purgations, as al≈øo Suppo≈øitories made of Honey and Salt, are altogether hurtfull to great bellyed women, or ≈øuch as lie in childbed. But if ≈øhe will not take a Gly≈øter, either for mode≈øty or otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe ≈øhe was not accu≈øtomed to take it, one or two yolks of new laid Eggs, or a few Pea≈øe pottage warm, with a little ≈øalt and ≈øugar, ≈øupped up a little before meat, will be very convenient.

div.head: CHAP. V. The eighth Moneth
div.p:
IN the eighth moneth, which is u≈øually perillous, the better diets, rather than plentie≈øt, will be mo≈øt commodious. But as they mu≈øt abate their diet, ≈øo their bodily exerci≈øe mu≈øt increa≈øe. And becau≈øe then women with child, by rea≈øon of the ≈øharp humours alter the belly, are accu≈øtomed to weaken both their ≈øpirits and ≈øtrength; they may well take
before meat an Electuary of Diarrhodon, or Aromaticum Ro≈øatum, or Diamargariton, in the morning before meat, and ≈øometimes they may ‚Ä¢ ick a little Honey; even as they which loath and nau≈øeate their meat, may take green Ginger condited with Sugar, or the rindes of Citrons and Oranges condited; as al≈øo it is u≈øuall ≈øometimes to take ≈øpecificall Sirrups. Moreover, let the woman with child often u≈øe Honey for the ≈øtrengthning of the Infant. When ≈øhe is not farre from her labour, or bringing forth, ≈øhe ≈øhall eat daily ≈øeven to≈øted Figs before meat, lea≈øt the ≈øeconds may be bound up; but if they ≈øhall be re≈øtrained and ≈øtay firme, they may be re≈øolved: But the woman with child may not eat ≈øalt and powdered meats, lea≈øt the child be born without nails.

div.head: CHAP. VI. In the ninth Moneth.
div.p: IN the ninth moneth, being near their time, they mu≈øt not be idle, neither ≈øit much, nor ≈øtoop much, nor lie on their ≈øides, ≈øo that the child may not well turn it ≈øelf, but ought to lie with her face upward, neither ≈øhall ≈øhe bend her ≈øelf much, le≈øt the child be infolded and wrapped up in the umbilical ligaments and bonds, by which meanes it oftentimes peri≈øheth; but ≈øhe mu≈øt walk, and ≈øtirre often, and exerci≈øe her ≈øelf, rather by going upward than downward: Let her u≈øe light and ea≈øie meats of dige≈øtion, as damask-Prunes with Sugar, or Figs and Rai≈øins, before meat, and al≈øo the yolks of Eggs, fle≈øh and broth of Chicken, Birds, Patridges and Phea≈øants, and Fi≈øh living in ≈øtony places, with good broth.
And ≈øuch meats ≈øhall not onely be convenient for this moneth, but al≈øo for the two ≈øucceeding moneths, that the natural parts by them may be dilated.
