Al≈øo a≈øtringent meats, and roa≈øted meats, and al≈øo Ri≈øe, hard Eggs, Millet, and others of that kind will be very profitable. Baths of ≈øweet water, with emollient hearbs, u≈øed with intermi≈ø≈øion is meet: But the hot hou≈øe, which they call a ≈øtow, is hurtful. After the bath, let the belly be annointed
with oyle of Ro≈øes and Violets; but the natural parts with the fat of Hens, Gee≈øe, Ducks, with oyle of Lillies, and the decoction of Lin≈øeed and Faenugreek, boyled with oyl of Lin≈øeed, mar≈øh-Mallows, grains of Quinces, or with this which followeth.

div.head: A Liniment.
div.p: Take of Mallowes, Of mar≈øh-Mallowes, both of them cut and ≈øliced of each one ounce.

Of Lin≈øeed al≈øo one ounce. Let them be boiled from twenty ounces of water to ten; let them take three ounces of the boiled broth, of oyle of Flour-deluce, and of Almonds, of each one ounce, three ounces of Deer ≈øuet; Bath this from the re≈øt, and annoint her with it warm.
Al≈øo they may u≈øe, for fourteen dayes before the birth morning and evening, to bath and moi≈øten the belly with Mu≈øcadine and Lavender-water, that the child may be the more ≈øtrengthened thereby.
She may every day eat toa≈øted bread, that nothing may grow to the childe.
The naturall parts may al≈øo be gently ≈øtroaked down with this Fomentation.

div.head: The Fomentation.
div.p: Take three ounces of Lin≈øeed.
Of Mallowes, and of mar≈øh-Mallowes ≈øliced, of each M. i.

Let them be put in a bag and boiled moderately: Let the woman with child, every morning and evening, take the vapour of this decoction in a hollow ≈øtoole, taking great heed, that no wind or air come to her in any part; and then let her wipe the parts ≈øo annointed with a linnen cloth, that ≈øhe may annoint the belly and groins, as at the fir≈øt.
Being near her time to bring forth, ≈øo that ≈øhe be within ten dayes thereof, if the woman with child ≈øhall begin to feel difficulty and pain, let her daily u≈øe this Bath.

div.head: The Bath.

list.item: Take of Mallowes,
Mar≈øh-Mallowes, ana M. i.
Cammomil,
Mercury hearb,
Maiden-hair, ana M. ≈øs.
Of Lin≈øeed four ounces.

div.p: Let the≈øe be boiled in a ≈øufficient quantity of water, as may ≈øuffice to make a Bath therewith.

But let not the woman ≈øit too hot on the ≈øeat, nor higher than a little above her Navill, nor let her ≈øit longer on it than about half an hour, lea≈øt her ≈øtrength langui≈øh and decay; for it is better to u≈øe it often, than to ≈øtay too long at once in it.
But if ≈øhe cannot indure to ≈øit over the water, let her cheri≈øh her naturall parts, with a ≈øpunge or with clothes wet in it.
A Laconick and ≈øweating Bath is not convenient at that time but hurtful, though we think women may u≈øe it.

After the Bath ≈øhe ≈øhall alwayes annoint her natural parts of her loines, her flankes, navil, ≈øides, and other parts adjoyning thereto, with the ointment or fat made of the fore-pre≈øcribed thing, or cheri≈øh them with the fat marrow.
And al≈øo ≈øats melted ≈øometimes, and rightly put up into the natural parts, with a ≈øpunge or gli≈øter-pipe, if the womb be hot and dry, and the party with child be of a lean and ≈ølender body.
Fumes al≈øo u≈øed, applied to the womb, conduce to facilitate delivery.

div.head: S ‚Ä¢ ffumigations of the genitals, to facilitate delivery.
div.p: Musk, Ambergreace, Gallia Mo≈øcata, Aloes-wood, put upon hot coales, and al≈øo ≈øweet Hearbs, Mint, Penniroyal, Calamint, Origanum, Majoram, are of a plea≈øant and grateful ≈ømell, and open womens pa≈ø≈øages, and draw down conception.
But we mu≈øt beware, that ≈øuch ≈øweet ≈ømells of this kind be not u≈øed to the no≈øtrils, but rather Balls of Galbanum, A≈ø≈øa ≈øoetida, Mirrh, or Rue.

div.head: What Meat is mo≈øt u≈øefull.
div.p: Then Pottage of Hens, Capons, and ≈øuch like are mo≈øt in u≈øe; and I ≈øhould advi≈øe them then to drink thinne generous Wine allayed with water.

div.head: What manner of Chamber, the woman with child ≈øhould lye in.
div.p: It doth not a little avail to the happy delivery, that the Chamber, wherein the Child-bearing woman lyeth, be temperate, and be neither too cold nor too hot, for that ≈øhutteth up the mouth of the womb, and this di≈øper≈øeth and dige≈øteth the ≈øtrength. In Summer time therefore if heat ≈øcorcheth, the Chamber may be ≈øtrowed with Willow leaves, and Vine leaves, and Ro≈øe-water, with a little Vinegar. In Winter, a high or upper Chamber, moderately kept warm, ≈øhall be convenient, which ≈øhall be kept warm with a continued fire, as is accu≈øtomed to be done in Italy, France, and other hot Countries.
But this is expedient every where, that the natural parts, and tho≈øe neare≈øt unto them, be moderately rubbed with hot clothes.

div.head: CHAP. VII. What is to be done at the birth.
div.p: THe birth being at hand, and paines oppre≈ø≈øing them, it ≈øhall be fit, if the belly doe fall down of its own accord, but if it be bound, it mu≈øt be provoked with a gentle Gly≈øter; for the excrements being ca≈øt out, the womb and the pa≈ø≈øages, thorough which the Child i≈ø≈øueth, are le≈ø≈øe pre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo the birth followeth more ea≈øie
The≈øe things being well prepared, the child-bed woman mu≈øt be put into bed, if tender, weak, gro≈ø≈øe, and fle≈øhly; but it ought to be made ready after this manner.

div.head: How, and wherewith, the child-bed womans bed ought to be furni≈øhed.
div.p: A large boul≈øter made of linnen cloth, mu≈øt be ≈øtuffed with ≈øtraw, and be ≈øpread on the ground, that her upper part may lye higher than her lower; on this the woman may lye, ≈øo that ≈øhe may ≈øeem to lean and bow, rather than to lye drawing up her feet unto her, that ≈øhe may receive no hurt.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. To whom the ≈øeat may agree and be fit.
div.p: LEt the ≈øtrong and lu≈øty women be placed in a chair, which al≈øo mu≈øt have the lower part not upright, but ≈øtooping a little, that the child-bearing woman may ≈øit, as it were, bending backward, clothes, or clo≈øe compa≈ø≈øing garments, being ca≈øt about their backs.

In this the belly, together with the whole burthen, may ≈øooner goe down than in a bed; but it often cometh to pa≈ø≈øe, that the whole Babe lyeth at the mouth of the womb, before that it ≈øhall get forth, more loo≈øly and openly with the adjoyning places, and by that meanes is compelled to ≈øtick longer there, from whence ari≈øeth no ≈ømall danger of life,

div.head: CHAP. IX. What the Midwife ≈øhall doe in the very moment of the birth.
div.p: VVHen now the pangs of child-bearing women increa≈øe more and more, let the Midwife inwardly annoint the ≈øecret or natural parts with oyle of Cammomil, and white Lillies, nor let her ≈øet the woman in the ≈øeat, before ≈øhe perceiveth the womb to be loo≈øed and re≈øolved, and the humours to flow over more plentifully.

Moreover, ≈øhe may not bring her to labour and ≈øtrugling, before the birth ≈øhew it ≈øelf to her view; for they doe but labour in vain, and doe violently di≈øtort and wre≈øt away the ≈øtrength of the labouring woman, that afterward,
when ≈øhe ≈øhall have need, it will not be able to work it forth.

But ≈øhe ≈øhall ≈øit fitly over again≈øt the woman in labour, and ≈øhall diligently ob≈øerve on what part the birth moveth it ≈øelf; for if it come the right way, ≈øhe ≈øhall annoint and cheri≈øh the ≈øecret parts with odoriferous Oils; and if it declineth to the ≈øides, ≈øhe ≈øhall with both hands govern and di≈øpo≈øe the belly, that it may fall to the mouth of the womb.
And if the hand or feet ≈øhew it ≈øelf fir≈øt, the Midwife, with a ≈øoft and gentle hand, moi≈øtened with broth of Fenugreek and Lin≈øeed, ≈øhall gently reduce it into the place.

Certain women have the mouth of their womb ≈øo ≈øtreightned, that without great help, ≈øcarce or never they can part with the child. And that cometh to pa≈øs by rea≈øon of divers cau≈øes; for either ≈øome ≈øtrong heat coming from the natural parts, doth two much ≈øtreighten the inward parts, or the Creature is to big, or the child-bearing woman is to gro≈ø≈øe and fat, or the child is dead, who cannot by motion be furthering and helping to nature, or el≈øe cold for the mo≈øt part in the winter, e≈øpecially in young ones, who have a narrow pa≈ø≈øage of the womb, doth more a≈øtringe and bind it up; or ≈øometimes heat in ≈øome is ≈øo di≈ø≈øolved, that their ≈øtrength faileth them in the birth.

Therefore when there appeareth difficulty in bringing forth the Child, Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the onely pre≈øerver and ≈øaver in danger, is heartily to be called upon, that with his gratious favour he would be plea≈øed to be A≈ø≈øi≈øtant to the wretched party in travell.

div.head: CHAP. X. When the Infant is come into the world.
div.p:
VVHen now the Child, or I≈ø≈øue, cometh into the world either with the head or feet, the Mother mu≈øt be incouraged, that as much as in her lyeth, ≈øhe keep in her breath and re≈øtrain it, that by that indeavour ≈øhe may put forth the Child. And the Midwife, in the mean time, mu≈øt with he ‚Ä¢
hand gently compre≈ø≈øe and keep down the region of the womb, which is above the navill, and urge the Infant to the lower parts: And although the a≈øtriction of the womb cau≈øeth the bringing forth to be more difficult, the parturient woman is to be ≈øet in a Bath, in which Mallowes, Faenugreek, Lin≈øeed, and Barly are ≈øodden, and the ≈øides, hips, and flank, mu≈øt be annointed, with oyle of Ro≈øes and Violets: let the thighs be well rubbed, with Oxy≈øacchar. and half a drachm of Mint, and as much of Wormwood, be exhibited in drink to her: The woman bringing forth may gently be led to her bed; and they which a≈ø≈øi≈øt her at her labour, mu≈øt not look or gaze in her face, as ≈øuch who are a≈øhamed in their bringing forth, that after it, as it falleth out, ≈øhe ≈øtrive not to bring forth her young one with ≈øharper pain.

div.head: CHAP. XI If the Secondines break not readily.
div.p: BUt if the Skin containing the young one, called the Secondine, becau≈øe it is brought forth after the birth, be le≈ø≈øe ea≈øily broken, but ≈øtifly re≈øi≈øteth, the Midwife mu≈øt either break it with her nails, and laying hold on it with her fingers, cut it with a pair of Sizzers, taking care that the Child may be pre≈øerved ≈øafely in doing it: On the contrary, when the skins are broken or cut in peices, if all the humours pre≈øently ≈øhall overflow before the child come forth, and the naturall places ≈øhall be dried up, let Goo≈øe greace, with oyle of white Lillies melted, be poured in warm, or the white of an Egg with the yolk be put up.

div.head: What is to be done after the child is born, if yet the Secondine, or after-birth, be retained.
div.p:
If the Child being born, the Secondines be as yet pertinaciou≈øly retained, ≈øneezing mu≈øt be provoked, if it come not voluntarily, putting Ginger or ≈øome other ≈øharp thing up into the no≈øtrils; or a ≈øcruple of Unicorns horn beaten into powder ought to be drunk hot in white Wine (in want of Unicorns
horn u≈øe good Harts horn, or Bezar four graines) or the juyce of Borrage exhibited in drink bringeth them down, becau≈øe it ea≈øily moveth vomit, and they thereby are brought forth.

div.head: Another approved Remedy for drawing them forth.

list.item: Take of Se≈øely, Cinnamon,
Of Mirrh, and of ≈øweet Ca≈ø≈øia, of each equall parts.
Let the≈øe be exhibited with Mugwort-water.

div.head: Another Receit.
div.p: Take powder of the Jet ≈øtone exhibited in Mugwort-water, or el≈øe about a drachm of the powder of Mallowes ≈øeeds exhibited in hot water, or the ≈øuffumigations of Hor≈øe hoofes.

div.head: CHAP. XII. To draw forth a dead Child.
div.p: IF the child be dead, an equall quantity of Rue, of Mugwort, Wormwood, and black Pepper, being each of them reduced into fine powder, and boyled in Wine, mu≈øt be exhibited, or Vervain boyled in Wine, or Water, or Vinegar; or Savory brui≈øed and tied upon the belly bringeth forth the Child, whether it be yet alive or dead; or Butter with Honey boyled in Wine; or decoction of Hy≈øop well dryed exhibited in hot water: but if it yeildeth not, nor cometh away with the≈øe, let Rue, Mugwort, Oppoponax, and Wormwood dryed, with a little Oil and Sugar, be laid to the groin, or the navill; and moreover, the skin of a female Snake put about the woman in the manner of a girdle. Al≈øo the ≈øtone Aetites, tied unto the thigh, after the Child is brought forth, ought pre≈øently to be taken away, lea≈øt the womb, after the Child be brought forth, come forth al≈øo.

Moreover, ≈øneezing alone accellerateth delivery, but it ought to be u≈øed with the mouth and no≈øtrils clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and Ginger, or ≈øome ≈øuch thing, put up into them; for from
hence a great force of the ≈øpirits is thru≈øt thence unto the inward part.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. How the bellies of child-bearing women, being co≈øtive or bound may be loo≈øned.
div.p: IF the belly doe not evacuate the excrements, the fir≈øt dayes of her being brought to bed, bring a Fig, cut in the middle, into the form of a ≈øharp tent fa≈øhioned like a mans Yeard, and put it up into the Fundament in≈øtead of a Suppo≈øitory; or el≈øe put a grain of Coriander, confected with Sugar, up into that place; or put a peice of Swines fle≈øh powdered, or Lard, brought into the ≈øame form, up into the ≈øame place, or frame a Suppo≈øitory of white Sope, and apply it thereto.

About four or five dayes after the birth, you may u≈øe a gentle Gli≈øter of half a pound of Sallade oyle, with a quartern of Barly boyled in broth, with two ounces of Sugar, with the yolke of an Egg, beaten together.

But if at the eighth day the belly an≈øwer not their expectation in loo≈øene≈ø≈øe, let three drachms of Ca≈ø≈øia newly extracted, well confected with Sugar, be taken morning and at evening before ≈øupper in the manner of a bole, and pre≈øently let her eat thereupon.

div.head: CHAP. XIV What things are to be applied to the naturall or ≈øecret parts.
div.p: SO ≈øoon as the Child is born, let this a≈øtringent Fomentation be applied unto the naturall parts.

div.head: The Fomentation.
div.p: Take of red Ro≈øes two pugils; a pugill is the quantity you may take up at once between your fir≈øt three forefingers.

Let them be boyled to a third part, in high red Wine inclining to a blacki≈øh colour, with a fourth part of water put thereunto, then put into the decoction a whole Egg, and let
it be mingled together, and applied to the place, with flanen rowlers, and kept on for the ≈øpace of two dayes.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of oyle of Hypericon four ounces.
Of Ro≈øe-water two ounces.
Of the juyce of Solomons Seal one ounce.
Mingle the≈øe well together, and let the rowlers dipped in them be applied to the ≈øecret parts.

div.head: An Ointment.
div.p: Let the belly be forthwith annointed with this Ointment, lea≈øt it become wrinkled or deformed, and that it may be thereby better ≈øtrengthened, and may return to the old form.
Take two ounces of Ro≈øe-water.
An ounce of Mirtles.
Half an ounce of Cats fat.
The≈øe things ought to be melted, and mingled with the before recited Oyles.

div.head: A Girdle for the belly.
div.p: After the Unction, put on a Girdle of Dog-skin, well prepared by a Leather-dre≈ø≈øer, and annointed with two ounces of oyle of Mirtles, and one ounce of oyle of Ma≈øtick, and half an ounce of oyle of Hypericon mingled together.

But it mu≈øt be ≈øo large, as it may comprehend or compa≈ø≈øe the whole belly a little above the navill, even unto the naturall parts, and mu≈øt ≈øtreightly bind up the ≈øame, but without pain. And this will be fitly done, if it be ≈øowed together with thred on the left ≈øide, and be put hot enough to the belly, and be compa≈ø≈øed with four or five double linnen clothes, binding them with fit ≈øtrings together, that the belly may be kept warm.
But let linnen clothes, annointed with an equall proportion of oyle of Mirtles, and oyle of Hypericon, be applied unto the naturall parts, from the ≈øecond day untill the ≈øeventh.

div.head: CHAP. XV. The order from the ≈øeventh day after the woman is brought to bed.
div.p: SIx dayes being fini≈øhed or pa≈øt, on the ≈øeventh day let the naturall parts be fomented and cheri≈øhed with this Decoction.

list.item: Take of red Ro≈øes,
Of Agrimony,
And Cammomil, of each one handfull.
Of the leaves of Hypericon,
Of the leaves of Quinces,
And of Mirtle, of each two pugils.

div.p: Let them be boyled in red Wine thick and a≈øtringent, with a little water to a third part, and let the naturall parts be fomented therewith morning and at evening before ≈øleep.

div.head: On the eighth day.
div.p: It is convenient to put to the belly, a plai≈øter made with the white of an Egg, and a little Pepper, and taken with flaxen rowlers, or boul≈øters.

div.head: On the ninth day.
div.p: If this plai≈øter plea≈øe not, be≈ømear a Dogs skin again with oyle of Mirtles and Ma≈øtick, and apply it unto the belly, and it will avail and profit much, to keep it tied with ≈øwadling clothes unto the end of her child-bed.

div.head: A Liniment to ≈øcatter and di≈øper≈øe the Milk.
div.p: That the Milk flowing back to the brea≈øts, may without offence be di≈ø≈øipated, you mu≈øt u≈øe this ointment.

list.item: Take of pure Wax two ounces.
Of Lin≈øeed oyle half a pound.

div.p:
When the Wax is melted, let a Liniment be made wherein linnen clothes mu≈øt be dipped, and according unto their largene≈ø≈øe,
be laid upon the brea≈øts; but when it ≈øhall be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, and paineth no more, let other linnen clothes, dipped in di≈øtilled water of Acorns, be put upon them. But this I onely advi≈øe them which cannot nur≈øe their own children: And if ≈øwelling in them which give ≈øuck doe ari≈øe from abundance of milk in their brea≈øts, ≈øeem to threaten an inflammation, u≈øe the former Ointment, but ab≈øtain from u≈øing the di≈øtilled water of Acorns.

div.head: When, and what Bath they mu≈øt u≈øe.
div.p: From the twentieth day, if it be a male Child, if it be a female, from the five and twentieth day, this Bath may be u≈øed.

list.item: Take of Majoram,
Of Penniroyall,
Mellilot,
Hypericon, or Saint Johns wort,
Of Millefoile,
And of Pimpernel, of each M iii.
Of Bay leaves two pugils.
Three ounces of Pomegranades rindes.
Of old Bean meal five pounds.
Of Barly meal two pounds.
Of Cummin brui≈øed and beaten into powder, lb. iii.

div.p: Put the hearbs, ≈ømall chopt, into a bag, but the beans, and Barly, and Cummin, one upon another ≈øeverally: Let them be ≈øod altogether in a great Cauldron, which may contain two parts of Water, and one of Wine, let them be boyled the day before ≈øhe would u≈øe the Bath, and be poured forth into a tub, which mu≈øt be well covered: The next day heat the water of the Bath; but they mu≈øt take heed they ≈øit not on the Bath too hot; but two houres will be ≈øufficient to ≈øit before meat in the morning, and at evening.
But let the child-bed woman ≈øit on the bag, wherein the bran or meale is put, but not lower than the region of the mouth of the Ventricle.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Let a barrell, wherein the dregs of white Wine are yet ≈øticking, be filled with river water, and let it be ≈øtirred to and fro, that all may be well mingled together, then let the dregs ≈øettle, and boyle in this water,

list.item: Of Bay leaves,
Of red Ro≈øes,
With both the Comferies,
Of Hypericon,
Penniroyall,
And Pimpernel, of each p. ii.
Of old Bean meal lb. v.
Of Barly meal lb. ii.

div.p: Let the child-bed woman ≈øit on the bag, in which the meales are, or on another, which may contain the brans of wheat.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Again≈øt the gripings of the belly in child-bearing women.
div.p: THe gripings and gnawings of the belly, e≈øpecially tho≈øe which are contracted from the great ≈øtriving and labour of the belly in bringing forth, and ≈øometimes from a chollerick matter contained therein, and ≈øometimes of wind retained.

div.head: Outward Remedies.
div.p: Exceedingly therefore are u≈øefull Musk, and Civet outwardly laid to the navill; moreover, oyle of Dill, chafed on the belly as hot as well may be indured.

div.head: Inward helps in their meats.
div.p: In ≈øtead of meat, the broth of an old Cock or Capon is be≈øt, being well ≈øodden with a little Dill, and ≈øo taken.

div.head: A Drink.
div.p:
For the drink, a water made up with Cinnamon and
Sugar, which they call Hippocras, which is made after this manner.
Put unto water boyled, and hot, and drawn, unto ‚Ñ•. xx.

list.item: Of Cinnamon half an ounce,
Of Sugar three or two ounces.
Three grains of black Pepper.

div.p: Mingle them well, and infu≈øe them for ≈øix hours, and then ≈øtrain them in a bag, which the Apothecaries call Hippocrates ≈øleeve. Let the child-bearing woman u≈øe this potion warm, but very ≈øparingly; but if ≈øhe loath this, let her u≈øe thin, ≈ømall, and clear wine, unle≈ø≈øe a Fever ≈øhall hinder her.
A Potion al≈øo is made of Honey and white Wine, of each two ounces, to mittigate paine by rea≈øon of flatuous humours retained.
Some exhibite the jawes of the Pickerell, with Amber, and Ginger, ana. finely powdered to drink in white Wine.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. The government of the Nur≈øe.
div.p:
LEt there be given unto the Infant new born Honey to lick, after let it be nouri≈øhed with the Mothers Milk, which of all things be≈øt agreeth with it. But if by rea≈øon of ≈øome nece≈ø≈øity it cannot enjoy it, a ≈øound healthy Nur≈øe is to be cho≈øen, neither younger than four and twenty yeares, nor elder than five and thirty, of a white and ruddy complexion, which is not infected with other vices, nor yet hath too lately been brought to bed, nor hath not long given ≈øuck; let her not have ≈øore Dugs or Brea≈øts, nor to big, but a large Brea≈øt, and moderately fat. Let her u≈øe choi≈øe meats of ea≈øie and light concoction, engendring good bloud or juyce; let her ab≈øtain from hot aromaticall Spices, as Pepper, Ginger, Cardamome, and ≈øuch like; al≈øo from Leeks, Onions, Garlick, Salt, au≈øtere and tart things: Let her avoid ≈øtrong Wines, as al≈øo cold water: Let her e≈øchew immoderate eating and drinking, for that corrupteth the Milk, and begetteth in children lepry, or ≈øcurfe, and other contagious di≈øea≈øes: Let her
ab≈øtain from cares and vexations, and let her take heed, lea≈øt ≈øhe provoke her men≈øtruous di≈øea≈øe.

She mu≈øt not ≈øleep much, or be given to ≈øleep, for that maketh the Milk flegmatick; ≈øhe likewi≈øe ought not to watch more than is meet, for from hence the Milk cometh to be more hot, ≈øharp, and di≈øta≈øtfull to the Infant; ≈øhe ought moderately to excrci≈øe her ≈øelfe, e≈øpecially her armes, to wit, either in ≈øowing, ≈øpinning, or knitting, for by this meanes evill humours are con≈øumed, as by ea≈øe and ≈øloth they are augmented.

Al≈øo copulation of the Nur≈øe exceedingly offendeth, and hurteth the Child, as that which cheifly retracteth and dimini≈øheth the Milk, and maketh it of an un≈øavory ta≈øte, ta≈øting hot, and rank, or goati≈øh, which bringeth no ≈ømall inconvenience, and hurt to the Child. For which cau≈øe, in times pa≈øt, Husbands were driven away from their Wives, and re≈øtrained from their companies.
But if the Milk decrea≈øe, Pulte≈ø≈øes of Bean meal, and Ri≈øe, are meet to be u≈øed; al≈øo like paps made of Bread, with Milk, and Sugar, to which may be added a little Fennel≈øeed.

And if the Milk be thick, it mu≈øt be made thinne, with ≈ølender diet, and ≈øubtill Wine, and Sirrup of Vinegar, as al≈øo with exerci≈øes: But if it be too thinne, and wateri≈øh, gro≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtrong meats, and longer ≈øleeps will be convenient and meet. For the corruption of the Milk, a litile Mug vort gro≈øly brui≈øed, and put into a linnen cloth, and ≈øo into broth, with a little Honey added thereto, will doe very much good.

div.head: The care of the Infant.
div.p:
And if the Childes belly be loo≈øe, the food ought to be more gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øtrong, and her ≈øleeps longer: But children may ≈øuck ≈øo long, as till they have brought forth ≈øharp and great teeth: But if you ≈øuffer them to drink Wine, or ≈øtrong drink, or other Potions, before they have toothed them, they will be corrupted; but when they have gotten the≈øe teeth,
their armes, and back bones are gently to be rubbed after their ≈øleep.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. A Bath of ≈øweet water, very profitable for children, as by who≈øe meanes they may grow up and increa≈øe.
div.p: THey are, fa≈øting, to be bathed in water before meat, for the ≈øpace of a quarter of an hour, yet ≈øo, that the belly may fir≈øt goe down or be emptied, and then they are to be annointed with oyle of Olives made hot.

And it is not of little concernment, in what ≈øwadling clothes children are wrapped; for when they are not tied up at all, or the clouts are too loo≈øe, they are ≈øubject to Fluxes, Impo≈øthumes, apt to be crooked backt, and other di≈øcommodities; but e≈øpecially when their knees are too ≈øtrictly tied and bound up, and their thighs left at liberty, they are lamed.

When they cry, or feel pain, or will ≈øleep, they are to be pacified, either by ≈øhewing the brea≈øt, or by ≈øinging, or by rocking, either in Cradles, or hanging Beds, or by carrying up and down. But we mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that children may lie ≈øtrait when≈øoever they lie down, and ought not to be covered too much, or hot with coverings, nor yet with too few, lea≈øt they may catch cold. Moreover, let the linnen cloth, wherein they are wrapped, be neat and clean, for children are offended, and infected by foul and filthy excrements.

From three years of age till the ≈øeventh, they are to be educated gently and kindly, not to be ≈øeverely reprehended, chidden, or beaten, for by that meanes they be made throughout their whole life after too timorous, or too much terrified, a≈øtoni≈øhed, and ≈øotted.

Being yet in their fir≈øt years, they are not to be compelled to going, for ≈øeeing all their bones are ≈øoft as Wax, and the body fall the heavier, they either become lame, or univer≈øally re≈øolved in their feet.

Food mu≈øt be daily given them thrice a day, till they are
three years old; for if they be much filled, they are ≈øubject and accu≈øtomed to be troubled with Convul≈øions, and other di≈øea≈øes.
In the ≈øixth or ≈øeventh year of their age, they are to be ≈øent to ≈øchoole, and committed to the breeding and in≈øtruction of courteous and temperate Schoolma≈øters, who may not terrifie them.
Before the≈øe yeares they are not to be compelled or forced to harder labours; otherwi≈øe they will not thrive well, but ≈øtand at a ≈øtay, and keep little, or become Dwarfes.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. The Di≈øea≈øes of Infants.
div.p: VVHen as the Infant beginneth to grow ≈øick, as for example, from a cold di≈øea≈øe, the Nur≈øe is to be nouri≈øhed with hot and dry meat and drink, ≈øo that thereby forthwith it may grow well again; ≈øo al≈øo if it be taken with other di≈øea≈øes, as with an Ague, the Nur≈øe ≈øhall u≈øe plantain water, and ≈øuch like things, Paps made for children of crums or mor≈øels of bread broken or ≈øliced, are more whole≈øome, than made of meal or flour.
Till two years old give them Honey often, for that keepeth them from Convul≈øions, and co≈øtivene≈ø≈øe of the belly, and that the milk they eat hurt them not.
When Infants ca≈øt up their milk, a Corrall ≈øhould be hung about their neck down to their middle; for it is u≈øefull for them in teething, and Ivory al≈øo is good for the ≈øame purpo≈øe.

div.head: Di≈øea≈øes and Symptomes, proceeding from the birth, in women with child.
div.p: Gripings and pangs come often upon women from their birth, for the womb, as a wild bea≈øt, by rea≈øon of her ≈øuddain evacuation and emptine≈ø≈øe, by wandering up and down hither and thither, di≈øpo≈øeth it ≈øelf.

Therefore the belly mu≈øt be covered all over with Barly
meal, and the white of an Egg, mixed together, wirh juyce of Elder; al≈øo drinking of hot Wine wherein Cummin hath been boyled, is very convenient and u≈øefull
Al≈øo Suffumigations of Styrax calamita, Frankincen≈øe, and Smallage ≈øeed, of each one drachm, will very much availe.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Again≈øt the Rupture of the Cods and perinaeum, and the part between the ri≈øing of the Yeard and the Fundament, which proceedeth from difficulty of bringing forth.
div.p: TO help the Rupture of the naturall parts, which ari≈øeth from hardne≈ø≈øe in bringing forth, the powder of the great Comfery root dryed, with Cummin and Cinnamon, are very good, put up into the womb.

In ≈øome the wrinkled skin of the Cods is broken from the birth, ≈øo that there is but one hole between the womb and the fundament, and the ≈øame cour≈øe, whereby oftentimes the womb goeth forth and is hardened; therefore the di≈øea≈øed parts mu≈øt be cheri≈øhed with hot Wine, in which Butter hath been re≈øolved, untill the Matrix be ≈øoftned, and then it mu≈øt be gently put up: after the Cod skin is broken in three or four places, it mu≈øt be ≈øowed up with a ≈øilken thred; pre≈øently let a linnen cloth be put upon the belly, according to the largene≈ø≈øe of it; la≈øtly, let it be annointed with Tar, for the womb, by rea≈øon of the evill ≈øcent, is drawn in again. At la≈øt we heal the Rupture with powder of both Comferies, and Cummin, ≈øprinkled upon them. But a child-bed woman is to be put to bed, ≈øo that ≈øhe may have her feet lie the higher; let her lie there eight or nine dayes continually, and let her take her meat, ea≈øe her ≈øelf, and make water there.

She mu≈øt ab≈øtain from bathing ≈øo long as po≈ø≈øibly ≈øhe may, al≈øo from all tho≈øe things which may provoke coughing, and from meats which cannot ea≈øily be dige≈øted: And for preventing this danger in bringing forth, let a long ball of linnen cloth be made, and put up into her Fundament, and as often
as the child-bearing woman ≈øtriveth to bring forth the Infant, let her ≈øtrongly compre≈ø≈øe and keep in her belly, that no di≈øruption or rupture be made in the≈øe parts.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. For windine≈ø≈øe or Collick of the belly.
div.p: IF the ≈øecret or naturall parts receive wind in, which being kept in brings forth pain, a Fomentation made with the decoction of Mu≈øtard or Onions, is vety good.

Al≈øo ≈øometimes in others ≈øo great plenty and abundance of wind oppre≈ø≈øeth them, that they ≈øeem broken, or as tho≈øe troubled with the I≈øiack pa≈ø≈øion, for who≈øe ea≈øe, a Bath made of Mallowes, Pellitory of the wall, and the like, mu≈øt be u≈øed, and the belly often kept ≈øoluble.

But ≈øhe ought to ≈øtay the longer in the Bath, and when ≈øhe cometh out of it, a plai≈øter of the juyce of Mullein, or Turnup, and Barly meal, mu≈øt be laid on hot, and then let her u≈øe her Bath again,

div.head: CHAP. XXII. For the Itch.
div.p: IF tho≈øe parts itch, ≈øo that women by ≈øcratching take away the skin, whereupon bly≈øters ari≈øe, which greatly mole≈øt and trouble them, they ought to be annointed with the Ointment pre≈øcribed for burnings.

Take an Apple, Bol ‚Ä¢ armoniack, Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, Oyle, hot Wine, Wax, and Tallow, and thus you may prepare it. Purge the Apple from the outward rind, and the core, and put it in a pot to the fire, with the Oyle, Wax, and Tallow, and when it ≈øhall be hot, the Ma≈øtick and Frankincen≈øe, being reduced into powder, mu≈øt be put in, and then being mingled ≈øtrained through a cloth.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. For the Flux of bloud.
div.p: FOr tho≈øe unto whom an immoderate Flux of bloud happeneth, it ≈øhall be convenient to give the juyce of Mugwort, Sage, Pennyroyall, and of other hearbs of that kind, made up into the form of a Sirrup.
Al≈øo Baths made for the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe of the ≈øaid hearbs, are good; or by a plai≈øter made up with Clay and Vinegar, which mu≈øt be applied to the right ≈øide.

If the Flux of bloud come from the no≈øtrils, it mu≈øt be applied to the forehead and temples, having a re≈øpect to the contrary ≈øide: For bloud u≈øeth not to flow out of the no≈øtrils, unle≈ø≈øe a male Child be begotten.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. For the falling down of the Matrix from the birth.
div.p: A Bath made of Mugwort, Flea-bane, Juniper, Camphire, and Wormwood, boyled in water; let the child-bed woman ≈øit in this up to the brea≈øt, afterwards let her be gently put into her bed, and let her lie with her feet drawn backward, that the Matrix may return into its place.

The Womb being put into its place again, put powder of Penniroyall, of Galingale, Spikenard, Nutmegs, Avence, with oyle of Nutmegs, and Penniroyall into a fine thinne cloth, and in manner of a Ball or Pe≈ø≈øary bind it up, and put it into the Womb, and ≈øhut up the orifice of the Matrix, that it fall not down again: But have a care, that it may peirce backward toward the reins, and there it is to be bound up, but before that be performed, a plai≈øter of Bay berries, of Mu≈øtard, Frankincen≈øe, and of Cinnamon, of each as much as ≈øhall be ≈øufficient, being brought into powder, and being heated at the fire, mingled with Honey, and let it be laid to the back being yet hot, and bound up with a ≈øwath, wherewith the Pe≈ø≈øary, put up into the Matrix, is tied.

But let the woman brought to bed lie in her bed upward for the ≈øpace of nine dayes or more, if need require, ≈øo that ≈øhe may not move her ≈øelf up and down, unle≈ø≈øe great nece≈ø≈øity urgeth her; and ≈øuch meat ≈øhall be given her, which may not ea≈øily pa≈ø≈øe through her belly, or may not often provoke her to make water: But now going abroad after her delivery, we mu≈øt put on an intire garment that may keep it in, lea≈øt it goe out again, unle≈ø≈øe it be when ≈øhe maketh water. The third day we mu≈øt make ready a Bath, and then, lea≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øwell, powder of Ginger, Pellitory of the wall, and Cinnamon, of every one by equall parts mixed mu≈øt be blown up.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. For the Piles after the birth.
div.p: VVEe u≈øe to cure the Piles, ari≈øing from the fault of the bringing forth, with a Bath of Wormwood, Southernwood; Cinnamon rind, and the bark of Ca≈ø≈øia fi≈øtula, boyled well in Wine; when the woman delivered goeth forth of the Bath, put Bombace, or Cotton, with powder of Alloes mixed with oyle of Penniroyall unto her lower parts.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Again≈øt pain of the Brea≈øts, contracted by too much Milk.
div.p: CLay kneaded with Vinegar, after the manner of a plai≈øter, is available to a≈øtringe and keep back the Milk, but the place is fir≈øt to be ≈øuppled with hot water.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. For the Impo≈øthume of the Brea≈øts.
div.p:
A Plai≈øter of mar≈øh-Mallowes, Mallowes, Wormwood, Mugwort, and Swines greace, made up according to art is very profitable; when the ≈øwelling is come unto the height, lay Nut kernels brui≈øed to peices unto it: And if the
Impo≈øthume break not, let it be launced with a Launcet or Pen-knife, and ≈øqueeze it a little, lea≈øt by the ≈øuddain evacuation a wor≈øe mi≈øcheevious Impo≈øthume may come upon it; and when it is broken, put in a linnen cloth, twice or thrice a day, ≈ømeared with the yolk of an Egg and Turpentine, which ≈øtrengtheneth exceedingly: And if the Impo≈øthume chance to pa≈ø≈øe into a Fi≈øtula, put into it a root of black Hellebor dipped in Oyle or Honey; or ≈øprinkle powder of the colt-Bur upon it, for with the≈øe is every Fi≈øtula purged and de≈øtroyed, ≈øo as it be not between the bones; wherefore the≈øe Medicines are ≈øo long to be admini≈øtred, untill it dye, and be dried up, and afterward the Ulcer be cured.

div.head: Some few additionall Ob≈øervations, concerning the pa≈ø≈øages in ths former Treati≈øe.
CHAP. XXVIII. What is to be admini≈øtred unto the Child, after it is born, for the fir≈øt thing it taketh.
div.p: ARnoldus de villa nova, a mo≈øt learned Phi≈øitian, writeth, that if you give unto a Child half a ≈øcruple of Corrall finely powdered, with womans milk, fir≈øt, before it taketh any other thing, after it is born, that it ≈øhall never be troubled with the falling Sickne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Al≈øo,
div.p: I know per≈øons of good quality in this our Country of England (I pre≈øume, in≈øtructed by ≈øome able Phi≈øitians) who give unto all their own children (and advi≈øe all other women, where they are de≈øired to be a≈ø≈øi≈øtant at the birth) to exhibite unto the children new born, the fir≈øt thing they take, a little Salt well mingled in a ≈øpoonfull of Saxifrage, or Hy≈øop water, to prevent the trouble of frets, and other di≈øea≈øes in children following their birth.

Conceiving al≈øo, as they ≈øuppo≈øe, they have ≈øome ground for their action, from the fourth ver≈øe of the ≈øixteenth Chapter of Ezekiel, where the Lord, reckoning up the Midwives duties about children, at that time of their nativity, thus ≈øpeaketh.

p.hi: And as for thy nativity, in the day thou wa≈øt born, thy navill was not cut, neither wa≈øt thou wa≈øhed in water to ≈øupple thee, thou wa≈øt not ≈øalted at all, nor ≈øwadled at all.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. For Infants troubled with wind and flegm.
div.p: MAny Midwives advi≈øe the Nur≈øes, to give them a little pure Sugar-candie finely brui≈øed in Saxifrage water, or Scabious water in a ≈øpoon, well mingled together.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. A mo≈øt excellent Medicine to cau≈øe children to teeth ea≈øily.
div.p: TAke of pure Capons greace, very well clarified, the quantity of a Nutmeg, and twice as much of pure Honey, mingle and incorporate them well together, and three or four times in a day annoint the Childs gummes when they are teething, and they will break fle≈øh ea≈øily, and prevent torments, and Agues, and other greifs, which u≈øually accompany their coming forth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. For Agues in Children.
div.p: TAke a ≈øpoonfull of good oyle of Populeon, and put thereunto two ≈øpoonfuls of good oyle of Ro≈øes, mingle and incorporate them well together, and then warm it before the fire, annoint the Childs bowing places, his armes, legs ≈øoles of his feet, and al≈øo his forehead, and temples twice a day, chafing the ointment well in.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. For Worms in Children.
div.p:
TAke of Mirrh, and Aloes, very finely powdered, of each a penny-worth, and with a few drops of Chymicall
oyle of Wormwood, or Savine, with a little Turpentine, make the≈øe up into a plu≈øter, and ‚Ä¢ ay it to the Childes Navill.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. For Heart-Wormes.
div.p: HEber≈øtreit, Skonkius, Hollerius, and other Phi≈øitians affirme, they have ≈øeen them in per≈øons di≈ø≈øected: One in a Prince, another in a Citizen of Florence; and our London Phi≈øitians of late yeares have ≈øeen two in London (as appeares in Doctor Mayes book of Mr Pennant of Saint Giles in the Feilds) who dyed having a Worm like a Serpent in his heart.

div.head: The Cure.
div.p: Skonkius out of Stocherus affirmeth by certain experiment, that the juyce of Raddi≈øh, Garlick, and Mu≈øtard, killeth the≈øe Wormes, which breeding in the che≈øt of the heart, cau≈øe ≈øwoundings, Epilep≈øies, and many times death.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. To cau≈øe a young Child to goe to ≈øtoole.
div.p: CHafe the Childs navill with May Butter before the fire, then take ≈øome black Wooll, that groweth between a Sheeps legs, and dip it in the May Butter, and then dry it, and lay it unto the navill, and it will procure a ≈øtoole: This is al≈øo good for one in yeares, who can take no inward Medicine.

div.head: Another certain Experiment.
div.p: Take a good big green Mallow ≈øtrig, and ≈øtrip off the outward skin, and annoint the ≈øtrig well with fre≈øh Butter, and put it up into the Childes Fundament, and let it ≈øtay a while there, and in very ≈øhort ≈øpace it will procure a ≈øtoole.
I pray accept kindly of the≈øe few Additions.

THis Treati≈øe might have been inlarged farther out, by addition of other Experiments, but my Freind; being of the ≈øame opinion concerning Medicines, that Seneca the Philo≈øopher was of Bookes: Non refert quanta, ≈øed quam bona medicamina; hath confined them to their own limits, onely with a few nece≈ø≈øary Ob≈øervations in≈øerted.

div.head: Choi≈øe and ≈øelect Medicines, collected by a Phi≈øitian for his own private u≈øe, and Alphabetically dige≈øted by him, and from him communicated for publick u≈øe.
A
For the Ach in the bones.
div.p: REcipe. A pennyworth of good Aqua vitae, and as much of oyle of Bayes, and mix them well together warm in a Sawcer, and annoint the place grieved, and chafe it well in (but not by the fire) when it is well dryed in, wrap it up well.

div.head: For all Aches and lame Members.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Rye, and Ro≈øemary, ana. M. ii. put them into common oyle, and Malm≈øie, ana. one quart, let the≈øe things ≈øeeth half an hour together, then let the ≈øame Member be bathed therewith, being fir≈øt chafed with a cloth very well, and after bathing
wrap it up in a Lambs skin the woll ≈øide inward; doe this to bedward for the ≈øpace of three weeks together; this helped a man which could neither ≈øtand nor goe, Probatum.

div.head: An Ointment for all Aches which come from cold cau≈øes, ≈øhrunken Sinewes, ≈øtraines in man or bea≈øt, it is incomparable, and will keep fourty yeares, but it mu≈øt be made onely in May.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Mallowes, Ground≈øell, Strawberry leaves, Lavender-cotton, Birch leaves, Chickweed, Comfry, Par≈øly, Sage leaves, Bay leaves, Rue, Balm, Plantain, Sorrell, wild Briony, Betony, Wound wort, Carauus, Succory, Majoram, Lungwort, Cammomill, Adders tongue, Oxe eye, ana. M. iii. Chop the≈øe hearbs very ≈ømall, and beat them in a Morter, then take Ro≈øin four pound, May Butter clarified in the Sun eight and thirty pound, Sallade oyle a gallon, Turpentine four pound, Frankincen≈øe two pound: Melt the Ro≈øin and Frankincen≈øe together fir≈øt, then put therein the May Butter, and the re≈øt afore≈øaid, and twelve pound of Hogs grea≈øe, and half a pound of Verdigrea≈øe, and when all the≈øe are melted together, then put in the chopt and pounded hearbs, and let them boyle half a quarter of an hour, then carefully ≈øtirre it a quarter of an hour after, and when it is cold, put it into pots clo≈øe covered, and ≈øet them in a hor≈øe dunghill a yard deep for one and twenty dayes, then take them out, and put all the ingredients into a Kettle, and ≈øet it over the fire again, and boyle them a walm or two, then ≈øtrain it, and put thereto oyle of Spike two pound, and ≈øtir it well; and when you u≈øe it, warm it a little in a Sawcer, and rub it by the fire.

div.head: To counterfeit beyond-Sea-Azure.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Common Azure, and beat it very well with Vinegar, and annoint therewith a thinne plate of fine Silver, and put the ≈øame over a ve≈ø≈øell full of Urine, ≈øet it over hot a≈øhes and coales, and let it be ≈øtirred untill it be like beyond-Sea-Azure: This is the be≈øt way, Mizaldus ≈øaith, he had this out of an old written book.

div.head: To know good Azure and pure.
div.p: Lay ≈øome of it upon a hot burning Iron, and if then it will not be burned, nor any little ≈øtone is found therein, then it is pure and perfect, and not ≈øophi≈øticate and adulterate: Mizaldus.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p: When Je≈øus ≈øaw the Cro≈ø≈øe whereon he ≈øhould be crucified, the Jewes ≈øaid unto Je≈øus, Art thou afraid, or ha≈øt thou an Ague? Je≈øus ≈øaid, I am neither afraid, nor have an Ague: Who≈øoever ≈øhall wear the≈øe words, ≈øhall neither be afraid, nor have an Ague, Amen, ≈øweet Je≈øus, Amen.

div.head: For a Tertian, or double Tertian Ague.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A good quantity of Celandine, one ≈øpoonfull of Salt, and the bigne≈ø≈øe of an Egg of Leven, and as much Allicant, or Spani≈øh Sope; ≈øtamp them well in a Morter, and make a plai≈øter of them, and apply them to the Patients feet, one hour before the acce≈ø≈øe of the fit, adde thereto four or five yolks of Eggs.
‚Ñû. Of Anni≈øeed water the be≈øt you can get, half a pound of oyle of Vitriol, ≈øhake them well together, and drink one or two ≈øpoonfuls hereof one hour before the acce≈ø≈øe of the fit: Probatum.
This Medicine is excellent to cure all kinds of Agues that are.

div.head: B
For a ≈øhort Breath.
div.p:
TAke the roots of Hollyhockes lb. i. dry them into fine powder, clarified Honey four pennyworth ≈øet the≈øe on the
fire, and ≈øtir them well together untill it come into the form of an Electuary, whereof let the Patient take often.

‚Ñû. Of choi≈øe Manna called Manna Granata two ounces, flower of Ca≈ø≈øia newly drawn half an ounce, Penidios three ounces, oyle of ≈øweet Almonds newly drawn half an ounce, the Lungs of a Fox finely beaten to powder two ounces: powder what is to be powdered, then mix them all together, and make an Electuary with Sirrup of Hy≈øop.

div.head: An Electuary for the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of Breath.
div.p: Take a pint of the be≈øt Honey you can get, ≈øet it on the fire, and ≈øcum it very clean, then put into it a little Hy≈øop bound in a bundle brui≈øed a little, let it boyle till the Honey ta≈øte well of the Hy≈øop, then take it out, and wring out all the Honey, and put into it the weight of ≈øixpence of Angelica root grated, or cut very ≈ømall, as much of Elacampane root, of Ginger the weight of two pence, as much of gro≈ø≈øe Pepper, of Licorice eight penny weight cut very ≈ømall, of Anni≈øeeds eighteen penny weight, put the≈øe altogether after the Hy≈øop is taken out, and let it boyle a walm or two on the fire, ≈øtirring it a little; then take it off, and put it into a gla≈ø≈øe or pot, and put thereto three ≈øpoonfuls of Aqua vitae, and ≈øtir it well together, and take it on a tufted Licorice ≈øtick, at morning about ten, and at four in the afternoon, and when you goe to bed, letting it melt down out of your mouths.

div.head: For a Brui≈øe or Squat.
div.p: ‚Ñû. White Da≈øie roots, leaves, floures and all, pownd them, and ≈øtrain the juyce of them into ≈øtrong March Beer, or Sack, and give the Patient a good draught thereof: Or ≈øeeth them in Ale, and make a Po≈ø≈øet thereof, and let the Patient drink thereof as of the former, and let him eat the leaves if he can, and let him ≈øweat after.

‚Ñû. Of Comfry M. i. when it ≈øprouteth forth the younge≈øt leaves, wring them with your hands, and put them into fre≈øh
Butter out of the Churne unwa≈øht into a Frying-pan, and hold it a good way off the fire, and ≈øo let it boyle together till it be green, then ≈øtrain it, and keep it for your u≈øe: Probatum.

div.head: A Re≈øtorative for the Backe.
div.p: Take of ≈øtale Ale two pound, of Germander half a handfull, of un≈øet Hy≈øop, and of un≈øet Thyme, and of Clary, ana. M. i. a branch of Ro≈øemary, and a good quantity of Engli≈øh Saffron, a di≈øh of ≈øweet Butter, and a good peice of Sugar, then boyle all together till half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and let the Patient drink it morning and evening.

div.head: For Aches in the Backe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Bores grea≈øe, and Nerve oyle, ana. p. ae, and as much Turpentine, boyle them a little together, and annoint the greived place downward therewith.

div.head: For Bleeding at the No≈øe.
div.p:
Take a Toad and kill him, and take three Bricks, put them into fire, and then take out one of them, and put the Toad upon it, then take out another, and put him again on that, and when he is almo≈øt cold, take off the Toad and put the Brick into the fire; then take the third Brick, „Äà‚óä„Äâ doe ≈øo till the Toad be con≈øumed to a≈øhes, then take th ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ and put them into a Taffata bag, and when any one blee ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ pply the bag upon the heart, and it will in≈øtantly ≈øtay the ‚Ä¢ ing, either of the No≈øe, or any Wound,

div.head: For Burning, or Scalding
div.p:
‚Ñû. A ≈øpoonfull of Sallade oyle, and the white of an Egg, beat them well together, and annoint the burnt place with it often, then take a linnen rag, and wet it in the oyle, and lay it over the ≈øore, and keep it ≈øtill wet, till you find the fire be
drawn out of the Wound, then take away the rag, and annoint the place with a feather, and put Harts-tongue leaves to it, and ≈øo bind it up, and dre≈ø≈øe it thrice a day for two or three dayes, and after that but once a day, and this will cool it without any ≈øcarre.

2. ‚Ñû. The redde≈øt Onyon you can get, and take off the rinde, and beat the Onyon with Bay Salt in a wooden di≈øh, till it be made very ≈ømall: then put it very thick upon the burned place, and renew it three or four times, and this will take out the fire, and then you may apply any healing Medicine to it to skin it.

div.head: C
For a Cough of the Lungs.
div.p: REcipe. Of clear running water three pound, of good Sugar half a pound, with nine Figs ≈øliced, half a ≈øpoonfull of Anni≈øeeds brui≈øed, a ≈øpoonfull of Licorice brui≈øed, of great Rai≈øins, having their ≈øtones taken out, one handfull, of Maiden-hair one penniworth, boyle the≈øe together till one half be con≈øumed away, then ≈øtrain it thorough a fine linnen cloth, and every morning take two ≈øpoonfuls of it luke-warm, and you ≈øhall finde pre≈øent remedy: Probatum.

div.head: For purging of Colds, Coughs, and comforting the Lungs.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Rubarb two drachms, Sena half an ounce, Anni≈øeeds one ounce, ≈øteep them in a pint of white Wine, and put to it one ounce of brown Sugar-candy: ≈øet it over the fire to be kept ≈øtewing all night, ≈øtop the pot very clo≈øe that no water come out, and in the morning, when it is blood-warm, ≈øtrain it, and take a pretty quantity of it, and put two drops of oyle of Sulphur into it, and drink it fa≈øting, and fa≈øt two or three houres after, then take a little broth and keep you warm.

div.head: A Julep for a Cough.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A pottle of Spring water, and put into it ten branches of Hy≈øop, and two of Ro≈øemary, Licorice clean ≈øcraped and thinne ≈øliced two ounces, of Anni≈øeeds brui≈øed two ounces, French Barly which, hath been clean≈øed in one water, boyle the≈øe till half the water be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and put to it three drops of oyle of Sulphur: take two ≈øpoonfuls of this when you begin to Cough, this will loo≈øen the flegm, and cau≈øe you to bring it up ea≈øily.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Boyle three ≈øprigs of Ro≈øemary, and as much Maiden Hy≈øop in two pound of white Wine, of Mace two flakes, of Nut-Neg two or three ≈ølices, Saffron ≈øix or eight blades, burn the Wine, and after ≈øweeten it with brown Sugar-candy, and drink a good draught warm, mane & ve≈øperi, and two or three ≈øpoonfuls in the afternoon.

div.head: For Canker in the mouth.
div.p: Mingle the juyce of Agrimony with raw Honey, and annoint the lips with it, and it will heal it: Probatum.

Richard Jones cured a young man which had the Canker both in his tongue and lips, onely with good Romane Vitrioll di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øpring water, and making it as milk warm from the Cow, with a ≈øtick and a linnen cloth fa≈øtened to the end of it, he wa≈øhed his tongue, mouth, and lips herewith every morning and evening, and cured him in ≈øhort time.

But if it be in an old man let run too long, that it eat ≈øtill, and Vitrioll, Salves, nor other waters will cure it, there is no other way to ≈øave this man, but to wa≈øh carefully his lips, or mouth, with a very little oyle of Vitrioll, to cauterize the veins, and ≈øtop the malignant humours that comes from the brain and feeds it. But this cour≈øe mu≈øt not be taken unle≈ø≈øe the
Patient be in intolerable pain, and in a de≈øperate ca≈øe, for doe it herewith never ≈øo little, yet this oyle of Vitrioll will gnaw, and bite, and put the Patient to great pain, that was oppre≈øt with great pain before, unle≈ø≈øe you mitigate the pain by often & continual dipping of a linnen cloth kept wet in ≈øpring water; after a very little time that you have annointed the cankered veines and places, with very little oyle of Vitrioll upon a feather as may be, and ≈øo let him indure the pain as long as he well can, that this may cauterize and ≈øear up the veines the better, that ≈øo he may be cured, which otherwi≈øe will corrode and eat continually, although he may purge and vomit al≈øo, and ≈øo this at la≈øt will kill him.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption, and Cough of the Lungs.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Coltsfoot, Betony, Burnet, and red Ro≈øe leaves, ana. M. i. of Comfry roots ≈øcraped and ≈øliced; M. ii boyle all the≈øe in a gallon of Spring water till it be con≈øumed to a pottle, then ≈øtrain it, and ≈øet it over the fire again, then take a pound of double refined Sugar, and put it into it, and let it boyle over a ≈øoft fire about a quarter of an hour, then take it off, and put it up, and drink of it ≈øix ≈øpoonfuls, morning, and evening, and at four in the afternoon.

2. ‚Ñû. Of Saccharum Saturni one ≈øcruple in a quarter of a pint of Goats milk, and give the Patient mane & ve≈øperi two or three weeks together, and this will help them, but fir≈øt give the Patient ≈øome gentle diet-drink to purge them, before you give the Saccharum and Milk: Probatum.

div.head: For Collick, and paines in the backe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The tender tops of a Bucks horn which is Velvet headed, and cut it in peices, and put it into a new pot well covered, and ≈øet it in an Oven where it may be dryed and made into powder, of which give to the Patient with a little Pepper in good Wine a pretty draught, and this will pre≈øently relea≈øe the pain and give ea≈øe: Probatum.
2. ‚Ñû. The decoction of Hollyhockes, mix it with Honey and Butter, and drink thereof bloud warm: Probatum.

div.head: For the Cramp.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The leaves or little ≈øprigs of Ro≈øemary, and put them between every toe, and if you are much troubled with the Cramp, u≈øe it continually, and this will cure it.
2. Annoint the part cramped with ∆≤nguentum Brioniae, and this will help it: Probatum.

div.head: For a Canker.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Burnt Salt, burnt Egg≈øhels, burnt Copperas, burnt Bones, burnt Verdigrea≈øe, Wormwood, and Rue, burnt, ana. p. ae. make powder thereof, and mingle them well together, and ≈øtrow the powder into the Canker, and let no water come to it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Hog-lice, ≈øtamp them till they come to an oyle, and annoint the place therewith.

div.head: For a Canker in the lips.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The juyce of Agrimony, and mingle it with raw Honey, and annoint the lips with it, and it will heal them: Probat.

div.head: A Water for a Con≈øumption.
div.p: R. Ro≈øe-water three pound, of Mu≈øcadine three pound, of new Milk a pottle, of gro≈ø≈øe Pepper one ounce, of Cinnamon two ounces, of ≈øliced bread a penny loafe, the yolks of three new laid Eggs, of Sugar one pound: Di≈øtill all the≈øe as long as any water will come; take of this water with a little Pepper a draught fa≈øting, and you will find much good.

div.head: For the Cough.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of the be≈øt Flores Sulphuris, one ounce and half, as much white Sugar Candie finely poudered, mix them together, and take as much hereof as will lye upon ≈øixpence, mix them well in the yolk of an egg, and ≈øwallow it down; then walk upon it untill you ≈øweat, and keep your ≈øelf warm; and u≈øe it four or five mornings together, to take it, and walk after it.

div.head: For a Cough, or ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Aqua vitae or Anni≈øe-≈øeed water four ounces, mix it with white Sugar Candie finely poudered two ounces, boyl it in a peuter di≈øh, over a chafing-di≈øh, till it be di≈ø≈øolved, and indifferent thick like an oyle, and take a ≈øpoonful of this when you goe to bed for three or four nights together.

‚Ñû Elacampane roots cut into ≈ømall peeces, of Hy≈øop, Penniroyal, and Liquorice, ana M. ii. ≈øeeth them in a gallon of pure ≈øpring water, till it come to a pottle, then ≈øtrain it well, and keep it in a clean pot or gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and u≈øe this every day thrice; Fir≈øt and la≈øt, and one hour after dinner, for ≈øeven or eight dayes.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Three ≈øheeps hearts, ≈ølit them, and take out the ≈øtring, and bloud, and lay them in water to ≈øoke a night and a day, then wa≈øh them clean, and put them into a Pipkin, lay in the bottome of the Pipkin, ≈øtalks of Ro≈øemary in the manner of a Gridiron; then lay the hearts on them, every heart being ≈øtuck with three cloves, and half a quarter of Sugar being put into every heart: Then ≈øtop up the Pipkin very clo≈øe with pa≈øte, and put it in an Oven with hou≈øhold bread, and when you thinke it is ≈øufficiently ≈øtewed, take out the Pipkin again, then every morning and evening take a ≈øpoonful of this Sirrup.

div.head: D
For the Drop≈øie.
div.p: REcipe, Half an egg≈øhel full of the juyce of Ireos, of Mellicratum four ounces, with pouder of the be≈øt Rubarb, half a drachm: Take this hot in a morning once a week. This is held for an excellent help.

div.head: Another.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A lap-full of green Juniper tops, chop them ≈ømall, and take a great bathing tub, and put them therein, and ≈øet the Patient in the tub, ≈øo that he may not touch the water, wherein the≈øe tops were ≈øodden, but put a cricket under his feet, and cover him well up to the throat; let him ≈øweat ≈øo long as he is able, and when he cometh forth of the bath, take care he taketh no cold, but carefully put him into a warm bed.

div.head: E
For pains in the Eyes.
div.p: REcipe, brown Fennel, white Ro≈øe-leaves, or other Ro≈øe-leaves, Rue, Vervain, Celandine, and Eyebright, ana p. ae. di≈øtill it, and keep the water in a Violl.

div.head: For ≈øore Eyes by ≈øalt Rheum.
div.p:
Pound Hou≈øleek M i. in a morter, and take the juyce ≈øtrained through a linnen cloth, put it in a new laid egg≈øhel, and put a quantity of white Sugar-candie to ≈øweeten it: Set the Egg over ≈øome Embers, and let it ≈øtand, and as the ≈øcum ari≈øeth take it off with a feather; and being clear take it off the
fire, and when it is cold, wa≈øh your eyes herewith ever and anon.
Mr. Nepier commendeth Rulandi aqua opthalmica, to bee the be≈øt for ≈øore eyes, Pin and Web, of all waters.

div.head: To clear the Eye-≈øight.
div.p: ‚Ñû Rain water of the cleare≈øt you can get one gallon, let it ≈øettle and clear by it ≈øelf at lea≈øt one day and night, and after put it into a fair ba≈øon of earth gla≈øed, or of ≈øilver, then put thereto of Roch Allom, the bigne≈øs of a Pigeons Egg, and and a quarter of as much white Coperas, and let them ≈øtand 24 houres well covered, then ≈øcum it clean with a feather, and drein it into another ba≈øon; then take away the ≈øcum, and the grounds, and ≈øo doe it every 24 hours, till it be clear without ≈øcum or grounds, and when it is perfectly purified, put it into a full pint of the be≈øt Ro≈øewater which is white, and put it into a good big gla≈ø≈øe, then ≈øet it in the Sun thirty dayes or more. Afterwards take it in, and wa≈øh your eyes with it three or four times in a week, when you are in bed, or oftner till you bee ea≈øed; when you wa≈øh your eyes, lye upon your back, that it may the better ≈øoke into them, and if it be too ≈øharp, then abate it, by mingling ≈øome ≈øpring water with it. The be≈øt time to make it is in Aprill or May; but if need be at any time in the Summer.
If you take the rain-water in gla≈ø≈øes, or gla≈øed earthen pans as it falleth from heaven, free from durt, ≈øand, or other filth, that will be much better.

div.head: F
For the Flux.
div.p:
REcipe, A Ba≈øon, and ≈øet it forth in the rain, and ≈øave the rain that falleth therein, then take a few Violet leaves, and boyl them in the water, then boyl ≈øome Almonds, but blanch them not, and make Almond milk of the ≈øame water; If the
Flux be very ≈øore, boyle the Almond Milk, and put thereto a little Cinnamon, and Sugar, and drink it.

div.head: For the Flux.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The nether jaw of a Pike, and make it into fine powder, and put it into drink or broth, and it will ≈øtop the Flux.

div.head: For the bloudy Flux.
div.p: ‚Ñû. An old Cock, and dre≈ø≈øe him, put into his belly of Sowthi≈øtles M. i. and put him into a fair earthen pot, and put to it five peices of Gold, four Dates, ten Prunes, and a quart of Malm≈øey; then clo≈øe up the mouth of the pot as clo≈øe as you may; then put it into a bra≈ø≈øe Pot with fair water, let it boyle the ≈øpace of twelve houres, but take care that none of the water come into the earthen Pot; and when the fle≈øh is con≈øumed from the bones take it up, and let it run thorough a clean peice of lochram; then put it up into a clean Gallypot, and when it is cold it will be like jelly; put two ≈øpoonfuls hereof into broth or other meat which the Patient u≈øeth to eat.

div.head: For the bloody Flux.
div.p: Seeth a good proportion of Plantain in fair water, till it wax yellow, and all the ≈øtrength be boyled out of it, then ≈øtrain the water, and heat a clean peice of Iron red hot, and quench it in the ≈øaid water, doe ≈øo nine times, and give it the Patient.
2. Seeth a pint of Milk, and when it is boyled, put into it as much Allum as will make a Po≈ø≈øet, of which mane & ve≈øperi drink a good draught.
3. ‚Ñû. That which is ≈øhorn from Scarlet, make it to a powder, and give the Patient half a ≈øpoonfull thereof in a pretty draught of Tent, and u≈øe this five or ≈øix times.
4. Dry the powder of an Hare, and give it the Patient, in red Wine, and it will help him.

div.head: For the bloody Flux.
div.p: Cut Hollihock roots in ≈ømall peices, and boyle them in red Wine, ≈øtrain it well and give the Patient; and if he have a Fever, or Ague, ≈øeeth the roots in water with ≈øome Plantain leaves, and let the Patient drink it.

2. ‚Ñû. Yarrow, and Plantain, ana. p. ae. ≈øtrain them together, and put thereto old red Wine, called Hollock, or Tent, ≈øtrain it well, and let the Patient drink a good draught of it fir≈øt and la≈øt, for three or four dayes together.

3. ‚Ñû. Plantain, Ribwort, and Sheapherds pur≈øe, ana. M. ≈øs. ≈øtamp them ≈ømall in a Morter, then put thereto Bole armoniack, and Terra ≈øigillata, and ≈øtamp them again, and lay it plai≈øter-wi≈øe to the forehead cold.
4. Mingle Mint water with ≈øirrup of Mint, drink it cold fa≈øting; this will ≈øtop both flux and vomit.

div.head: For the bloudy Flux.
div.p: 1. ‚Ñû. Hay well boyled, and keep it over the fire, and every time the Patient goeth to ≈øtool, let a wi≈øpe thereof be put into the ≈øtoole.

2. ‚Ñû. Two quarts of Milk, and boyle in it of Sage four handfuls wa≈øhed; boyle the≈øe to a quart, then put to it a little beaten Cinnamon, and let the Patient take this bloud warm, in≈øtead of other drink when he is thir≈øty.
3. ‚Ñû. A Nutmeg, pare a great hole in it, and ro≈øt it in embers full of Sanguis draconis, and eat it all up: This was Colonell Hambletons Secret.
4. ‚Ñû. red Bryer leaves, and boyle them well in Milk, and ≈øweeten it with Sugar.
5. Give Dates ≈øtones beaten to powder in warm Wine fa≈øting.

‚Ñû. Of the be≈øt Treacle one drachm, in four ounces of Carduus benedictus water, give the Patient hereof three mornings or nights to drink bloud warm, and it will take away the
fumes of the head in the di≈øea≈øe of the Flux.

If the fumes of the head be not a≈ø≈øwaged, let the Patient take four ounces of Carduus water, and the yolk of a new laid Egg, and a little Salt, mix the≈øe, and drink it; this is al≈øo good for an Ague.

div.head: An Ointment for the Flux.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Two pound of May Butter, or a gallon of Cream; if or May Butter, take Lunaria ≈øanicle, Salomons Seal, Mou≈øeare, Plantain, Adders-tongue, ana. one handfull, ≈øtamp the≈øe ≈ømall, and put them into the May Butter, and boyle them half an hour with a ≈øoft fire, ≈øcumming it with a feather: If you u≈øe Cream, boyle it till it come to an oyle, which oyle as it ri≈øeth take off with a ≈øpoon, and put your Hearbs into it, as into the May Butter; when it hath boyled, ≈øtrain your Hearbs thorough a thinne cloth, and let it ≈øtand till it be cold, after which, ≈øet it over the fire again till it begin to boil, then put it up in pots.

This is al≈øo good for burning, ≈øcalding, or Aches, but e≈øpecially for the Flux, for which, when you u≈øe it, ob≈øerve this direction: Take the quantity of a Nutmeg of this Ointment, and melt it by the fire, and ≈øtroke down the reines of the back till it be dryed in, u≈øe this for ≈øeven dayes and nights together if your Flux continue.

div.head: For all Fluxes of bloud, and other Fluxes, pains in the Back or Liver, and for inward effects.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Cinnamon, Ca≈ø≈øia lignea, Opium, ana. two drachms, Mirrh, Pepper, and Ca ‚Ä¢ banum, ana. one drachm, ≈øtamp them, and mix them with a little clarified Honey, and make it into a lump or ma≈ø≈øe, give thereof at night two round pills about the bigne≈ø≈øe of a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in the pa ‚Ä¢ of a roa≈øted Apple, and let not the party drink for two ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ res after; and if his pain and greif be never ≈øo great it w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ him within one hour or two, and perhaps cau≈øe him to „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ oundly: you may give it two or three nights together in the Patient be ≈øtrong, but if they
be very weak, give it every other night three or four times; but if he be in extream pain give it when you li≈øt: If the ≈øtomack be full of meat or flegm, it will work le≈ø≈øe effectually. Probatum.

div.head: A powder for the Flux.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Half ripe Blackberries, dry them, and make them into powder, give the Patient a draught thereof in a little Tent, or old red Wine, in the morning and evening for five dayes if the Flux continue.

div.head: A Gli≈øter.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A quart of new Milk from the Cow, and put three or four gads of Steel into the fire red hot, and quench them in the Milk till half the Milk be con≈øumed; then ‚Ä¢ ake the weight of eight pence of Deeres ≈øuet, and ≈øtamp it into the Milk, and mix it well together, and put it in a boulter bag warm; this you may u≈øe four or five times if need require.

div.head: For Morphew, or Scurf of face or Skin..
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Brim≈øtone beaten into powder two ounces, mix it well with as much black Sope that ≈øtinketh, and tie the ≈øame in a linnen cloth, and let the ≈øame hang in a pint of ≈øtrong wine Vinegar, or red Ro≈øe Vinegar, for the ≈øpace of nine dayes; then wa≈øh any kind of Scurfe or Morphew, either in face, or body, dipping a cloth in the ≈øame Vinegar, and rubbing the face or body therewith, and let it dry by it ≈øelf: al≈øo drink the water of Strawberries di≈øtilled, or tincture of Strawberries, it certainly killeth Morphew or Scurfe: Probat.

div.head: To blanch the Face.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The meat of Lemons having taken away the kernels, and a quantity of fine pure Sugar, ≈øtill the≈øe, and keep the water to wa≈øh your face with every night.

div.head: To ≈ømooth the Skin.
div.p: Mixe Capons grea≈øe with a quantitie of Sugar, let it ≈øtand for a few dayes clo≈øe covered, and it will turn to a cleer oyle, with which annoint your face.

div.head: Morphew and Freckles.
div.p: Annoint the face with the bloud of a Hare, or Bull, this will take away Morphew, and Freckles, and ≈ømooth the skin.

div.head: G.
For the Gout, or Ache in the joynts, knobs, or knots in the fle≈øh. Probat.
div.p: REcipe, Of May Butter four ounces, of Cummin ≈øeed beaten into fine pouder, half a pound, of black ≈øope, four ounces, of Rue, M. i of clarified Mutton, M. ≈øs. ≈øtamp the≈øe in a morter together, and put to it an Oxe gall, and a ≈øpoonfull of Bay ≈øalt, and fry them together till it be thick, then lay it on a woollen cloth, and apply it hot to the ach as may be ≈øuffered, and let it lye a whole week unremoved: Then lay on another as long a time, and ≈øo lay on a third plai≈øter as long, which will be three weeks in the whole time; and this will give ea≈øe.

div.head: For Gout or Bone-ach.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Aqua vitae one penniworth, and another of oyle of Bayes, mix them well together, and annoint the place grieved therewith by the fire, warm the ointment by the fire, and then chafe the place till it be dryed in, then cloth it up warm. Probat.

div.head: For the Gout, or Joynt-ach.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The juyce of Sage, of Aqua vita, of oyle of Bayes, of Vinegar and Mu≈øtard, and of Oxe gall, ana p. ae. put altogether into a bladder, and chafe it up and down with your hand for the ≈øpace of an hour and half, and keep it for your u≈øe, and annoint the grieved place with it morning and evening.

div.head: For the Gout.
div.p: Stamp well lb iii. of Wallwort, then melt ten pound of May Butter, and put it thereto, and let it ≈øtand nine dayes together, then boyle them half an hour over a ≈øoft fire, then ≈øtrein it, and annoint the grieved place.

div.head: For Gout or Bone-ach.
div.p: Annoint the place grieved with very good Aqua compo≈øita by the fire, and let the ≈øame drinke in; doe this three or four times, and whil≈øt it is wet, ca≈øt upon it pouder of Olibanum, and ≈øow a cloth thereon, and let it lye on for four dayes. Probat.

div.head: H
Hermes Tree.
div.p:
FIr≈øt grinde to an Amalgame one ounce of Mercurie, with one ounce of clear Spring-water, then put a round viall gla≈ø≈øe, half full of Ro≈øe water, or cleer ≈øpring water; then put therein your afore≈øaid Amalgame, then drop therein one drop of the be≈øt Aqua fortis that can be gotten, and after a quarter of an hour another drop, and ≈øo every quarter of an hour one drop, till you have dropt therein ten or twelve drops; then with a very gentle heat, on ≈øand or hot embers, vapour
the water away ≈øoftly, and a brave tree of ≈øilver, ≈øhall grow in the gla≈ø≈øe to your admiration.

div.head: I
A Plai≈øter to help any Stitch, or Impo≈øthume where≈øoever.
div.p: REcipe, The roots of Hollihocks wa≈øhed clean, and cut in peeces, M. i. ≈øeeth them in fair water, untill the roots bee tender, then take out the roots, and put into the water, of Fenugreek, and Lin≈øeed, ana M i. being fir≈øt ≈øtamped or brui≈øed, and ≈øeeth them together in the water, untill the water rope like birdlime, then ≈øtamp the Hollihock roots before boyled, and put them to the Fenugreek, and Lin≈øeed, with a handfull of Barlie meal, and fry them together, and if need be, put to ≈øome Sheeps ≈øuet, and lay a plai≈øter thereof to the ≈øore, as hot as may be ≈øuffered; Let it lye twelve hours at lea≈øt, and then lay another to it, and within nine plai≈øters it will work the full effect: It di≈ø≈øolveth the Pluri≈øie al≈øo in applying of three Plai≈øters.

div.head: For an Impo≈øthume of the Stomack.
div.p: Who≈øoever ≈øhall dayly take in a draught of Ale or Beer, a ≈øpoonful of the pouder of Matfelon, or Scabios, it will de≈øtroy any Impo≈øthume within him. Probat.

div.head: A good Oyle to bring in joynts which have been out ≈øeven years, to give ≈øtrength to veins and ≈øinnews, and to keep them brought in, in their places.
div.p:
You mu≈øt fir≈øt bathe the place throughly that is out for three or four dayes, with Oyle of Cammomil, then again≈øt the Patient goeth to bed, you mu≈øt have two Neats-feet, or ≈øo many of them as may cover the di≈ølocation, with the peelings round about: then lay the in≈øides of the feet in thick and
broad flakes to the place, as hot as the party can indure it, and in the morning remove them, and after with it annoint the place and the flakes afore≈øaid with Oyle of Cammomil, and then apply fre≈øh peelings. This for certain hath brought in joynt, that which hath been out of joynt ≈øix years, and giveth ≈øtrength to the veins and ≈øinnews, and will keep the joynts in their fir≈øt place; and the effect will appear in three or four dre≈ø≈øings.

div.head: For the Black Jaundies.
div.p: Spread Wheat-≈øtraw abroad upon a clean floor in a clo≈øe hou≈øe, and put in Gee≈øe, and watch them when they dung: take their dung up with a knife, and ≈øcrape away the white about the dung, untill you have a good quantity of it, then dry this in an Oven, make pouder thereof, and drinke of it morning and evening warmed in Ale, and it will cure both the black and yellow Jaundies.

2. Dry the gall of a Raven, and grate it into powder, and take a quantity of it in a ≈øpoon, temper it with Beer or Ale, and drinke this fa≈øting three mornings together: Or take nine or ten ≈øeeds of Hemp, doe away the husks, and brui≈øe them, and put them in Ale, and drinke this fa≈øting, for eight or nine dayes.

div.head: For the black Jaundies,
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Hearb Ambro≈øe, Betony, Mugwort, ana. M. i. three or four Dock roots clean pickt, wa≈øht, and ≈øcraped, ≈øtamp all the≈øe together in a Morter, till they be beaten indifferent ≈ømall; then take Spicknard, Turmerick, and Gallingal, ana. p. ae. ≈øtamp them in a Morter likewi≈øe, then put the Hearbs into a clean cloth by them≈øelves, and tie them fa≈øt with ≈øtrings, and hang them in a gallon or two of good Ale newly ready to be tunned up, and after three or four dayes, drink a good draught thereof every morning next to your heart, and fa≈øt after it three houres, and doe ≈øo the like when you goe to bed.

div.head: To make Hart≈øhorn Jelly.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Two ounces of Hart≈øhorn being ≈ømall ra≈øped, and a pint of fair water, one Nutmeg ≈øliced, one race of Ginger, a branch of Ro≈øemary, boyle all the≈øe together in an earthen Pipkin over a ≈øoft fire, till it be very clammy, then ≈øtrain it into a Ba≈øon, and put to it Ro≈øewater and Sugar.

div.head: For the yellow Jaundies.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Celandine, Engli≈øh Saffron, and powder of Ivory, ≈øeeth them in white Wine, and drink thereof eight or nine dayes mane & ve≈øperi.
2. ‚Ñû. The Urine of the Patient, and drink it with the juyce of Horehound.
3. Seeth the juyce of Cammomill, Morrell, and Mou≈øeare, in white Wine twice, and drink of it fa≈øting.

div.head: For the yellow Jaundies.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The pap of a roa≈øted Pippin, and put as much powder of Saffron as will lye on a penny, and twice as much Harts-horn finely ≈øcraped, mingle them well together, and give the Patient three mornings together the quantity of a Nutmeg, and as much at going to bed.

2. ‚Ñû. Of the inner rind of Barberry bark, and Goo≈øe dung that feeds on gra≈ø≈øe, and wa≈øh the white of it, and a little Saffron, ≈øteep the≈øe in Ale, and let the Patient drink it in the morning fa≈øting.
3. ‚Ñû. Of red Nettle-tops M. i. ≈øeeth them in a pint of Ale, and drink the ≈øame four or five mornings together.

4. ‚Ñû. Alicant, or hard Spani≈øh Sope, and a little ≈øtale Ale in a Cup; rub the Sope again≈øt the bottome of the Cup till the Ale be white, then ≈øhave a little ivory, and let the Patient drink of this fir≈øt and la≈øt till ‚Ä¢ e be recovered: Al≈øo take Celandine leaves, and put them into your Stockings next to your feet.
5. Put a good handfull of Celandine leaves into a quart of white Wine, boyle them to a pint: in the winter u≈øe the roots, and drink thereof morning and evening.

6. Cut out the core of a good big Apple, put into the place ≈øome ≈øweet Butter, a little Turmerick, and Engli≈øh Saffron, cover it with the top you cut off, ro≈øt it tender, and let the ≈øick eat of this three or four mornings together.

7. ‚Ñû. One pennyworth of Turmerick, of the middle rind of the Barberry bark M. ii. of Celandine M. i. ≈øeeth the Celandine, and the bark, in Ale-wort, putting to it a gallon of new Ale at the tunning, and when it hath ≈øtood two nights, draw it at the ≈øpicket, and warm it with a gad of fine Steel, and put to it the powder of the Turmerick, and drink of it fir≈øt and la≈øt.

8. ‚Ñû. The juyce of Liverwort, and the ≈øcrapings of Ivory, and of Saffron, as much as you ≈øhall think fit, of French Sope as much as a Che≈øtnut, bind them all in the corner of a linnen cloth, and ≈øwinge them up and down in fair water, till all the vertue be gone into the water, and give the Patient to drink of it.

div.head: L
For a lame Leg.
div.p: REcipe. Aqua compo≈øita, and oyle of Ro≈øes, ana. p. a. mix them together well, and annoint the greived place with it morning and evening, but let the Patient fir≈øt be well rub'd with a warm cloth. Probatum.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Oyle of Exeter, oyle Olive, and Aqua vitae, and Bea≈øts gall, ana. p. ae. Mix them all well together, and annoint the lame leg therewith twice every morning and evening, for the
≈øpace of a fortnight; but alwayes u≈øe to rub the place fir≈øt very well with warm clothes.

div.head: For chopt Lips.
div.p: Rub them with your ≈øweat behind your eares, and this will make them ≈ømooth and well coloured.

div.head: A Drink for the Cough of the Lungs, and Con≈øumption.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Earth-wormes two pound, in a May morning, tho≈øe with black heads are be≈øt, you may gather enough; put the≈øe in white Wine for three or four houres, then ≈ølit and wa≈øh them in the ≈øame Wine, and in another Wine, and lay them in an earthen pan on ≈øtraw or ≈øticks laid a cro≈ø≈øe, and put them into an Oven after the bread is drawn, and ≈øo u≈øe them till they be ≈øo dry, that you may pownd them, then ≈øearce it, and beat it again till it be as fine as flower: then keep it for your u≈øe, which you mu≈øt take twice a day, in the morning when you wake, and at four in the afternoon, as much as will lye on ≈øixpence, or eightpence; take it in a ≈øpoonfull of warm Broth, or mulled Sack, or Mace Ale, and drink a pretty draught of the Broth to wa≈øh it down: if you take it in mulled Sack, or Mace Ale, take not above four ≈øpoonfuls, u≈øe this for a moneth, but be carefull of taking cold.

div.head: To make a Laxative Whey.
div.p: ‚Ñû. One pound and a half of clarified Whey, Sena half an ounce, four penny weight of Anni≈øe≈øeeds, of Hops half a handfull, of Borrage, and Buglo≈ø≈øe, ana. half a handfull, Fumitory p. i. ≈øeeth all the≈øe in the clarified Whey untill half be con≈øumed, drink of it two mornings together.

div.head: A good Laxative for a Child.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Of Violets three handfuls (if you cannot get them, as
much of the leaves,) ≈øeeth them in running water, from a pottle to a quart, then take of Almonds one pound, ≈øtamp them ≈ømall, and temper them with the water, and make an Almond Milk of it, and let the child eat and drink of the Milk, and al≈øo if need require, of the water by it ≈øelf with a little Sugar.

div.head: To cau≈øe Loo≈øene≈ø≈øe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Goloquintida and mix it with Honey, and Bulls Gall, then apply this plai≈øter-wi≈øe to the belly, and this will doe it: Al≈øo take Wool, or Silk, and dip it in the juyce of Sowbread roots, and Wine, and u≈øe it as you u≈øe a Suppo≈øitory.

div.head: For a co≈øtive by burnt Choller.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Mallowes, Mints, Wormwood, and Violet leaves, ana. half a handfull, ≈øeeth the≈øe in the water of the ≈øick, and when they are well ≈øodden, pre≈ø≈øe out the water from the Hearbs, and ≈øtamp the Hearbs in a Morter, and fry them in May Butter, or fre≈øh Grea≈øe, and make a plai≈øter of it, and apply it warm unto the belly, and change it once a day,

div.head: For Rheume procuring a Cough of the Lungs
div.p: ‚Ñû. A quarter of a pint of good Sack, of Elacampane roots half an ounce, as much Licorice, powder them very finely, of the be≈øt refined Sugar half a pound, boyle them together, till they rope in nature of a Sirrup, then take hereof the quantity of a big Filbert mane & ve≈øperi, and after as often as the Cough tickles you.
2. Take Virgin Honey, and old Con≈øerve of red Ro≈øes, ana. p. ae. mingle them well together, and take at morning and night three Pills as big as a Nutmeg, and keep warm after it.

div.head: A Drink for the Cough of the Lungs.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A pottle of ≈øpring water, put into it of Oak leaves, M. ≈øs. of Colts foot, of Butter burr, roots and leaves, ana M. i. of S. Johns wort, Mou≈øear, Maiden hair, ana p. i. 3 or 4 Harts tongue leaves, a little Liverwort, 6 branches of Maiden Hy≈øop, 3 or 4 branches of Ro≈øemary, pick and wa≈øh all the≈øe clean, 16 Figs ≈ølit in two: Set this over the fire, and let it boyl ≈øoftly, till half be con≈øumed, then take it off the fire, and ≈øtrein it, and put into it of loaf Sugar lb ≈øs. and when it is melted, put unto it ≈øix or ≈øeven drops of oyle of Sulphur, and put it into a gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øhake it well, and drinke every morning eight ≈øpoonfulls, which you mu≈øt drink lea≈øurably, that it may the better fall on the Lungs; about four of the clock in the afternoon you mu≈øt take as much: this will both clean≈øe, and heal the Lungs, and ≈øtop the coughing.

div.head: M
A cooling Almond Milk.
