div.p: TAke Lettice, Spinage, Succory, Violets, langde Beefe, Endive, and red Fennel, ana. half a handful, three ≈øpoonful of Anni≈øe≈øeeds, five whole Maces, and one Nutmeg cut into peices, ≈øeeth all the≈øe in a pottle of running water to a quart, then blanch your skins, and beat them with the cold ≈øeeds, and ≈øo draw it with this decoction, and put into it Sugar, and Manus Chri≈øti, to ≈øweeten it.

div.head: N
A Water to re≈øtore Nature.
div.p:
TAke of good new Milk three pound, of red Wine one pound, the yolkes of four and twenty new laid Eggs,
having their whites taken out, beat the Eggs well with the Wine and Milk, and put thereto as much fine Manchet as will almo≈øt ≈øuck up the liquour, di≈øtil this with a ≈øoft fire, take two or three ≈øpoonfuls of this u≈øually in your broth two or three times a day: this is rather to be u≈øed in Hectick Fevers then in other di≈øea≈øes, becau≈øe they are alwayes hot in the palmes of their hands, and in the ≈øoles of their feet, both after ≈øleep, and after meat, which ≈øhew the con≈øumption of the ≈øolid, and fle≈øhy parts of the body.

div.head: To re≈øtore Nature con≈øumed.
div.p: Steep the yolkes of two new laid Eggs in ≈øix ounces of Vinegar ≈øix houres, then take them out, and with four Dates, and a pint of Muskadine, or Alicant, make a Cawdle therewith as followeth: Take of Ro≈øewater one pound, a pint of Muskadine, boyle therein a di≈øhful of the Pithes of an Oxe back clean pickt, a large ≈øawcer full of good Currans clean wa≈øht, four yolkes of Eggs, ≈øix Dates, a ≈øtick of Cinnamon, and a good Nutmeg; make a Cawdle of this with Sugar, and having ≈øo done, ≈øtrain it, and drink thereof at morning fa≈øting, and at four in the afternoon: it is ≈øingular good for a weak back, and decaying of nature.

div.head: P
For the French Pox.
div.p:
REcipe, Of Lignum vitae, lb i. of Sar≈øaparilla, ‚Ñ• v. of Sena Alexandrina, ‚Ñ• iv. of Sa≈ø≈øafras ‚Ñ• iv. of Bole Armon. ‚Ñ• i. of Chalk, ‚Ñ• i. of Hermodactilis, ‚Ñ• ii. of French Barlie ‚Ñ• ii brui≈øed, of long Pepper a half penniworth, of Saffron one penniworth, of London Triacle ‚Ñ• i. Boil all the≈øe in four gallons of ≈øpring water till half be con≈øumed, when it is to be boyled put in the long Pepper, Saffron, London Triacle, Bole Armoniack, and the Hermodactilis: What is to be pounded, pound; and what to be
brui≈øed, brui≈øe; let it boil a good while after tho≈øe Ingredients are put into the pot, clo≈øe ≈øtopped: Then ≈øtrain it, and with the dregs you may make a ≈ømaller drinke for the Patient to drinke at meat, or when he is dry; but of the fomer drinke he mu≈øt drinke ‚Ñ• iiii. thrice a day: Viz. at eight of the clock in the morning, at noon, and at 10 at night: He mu≈øt eat dryed Bisket, and great Rai≈øins, and his meat mu≈øt be mutton, dry roa≈øted without Salt. The party mu≈øt al≈øo take this en≈øuing Purge twice, before he drinke the drinke: viz. ≈øix penniworth of Pulvis Sanctus, with ‚Ñ• i. of Sirrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, well mixed in lb ≈øs of white Wine, drinke it blood warm, fa≈øting two houres, and then take ≈øome warm broth.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Two or three do≈øes of Doctor Vanhocks Ro≈øa vitae, given at ≈øeverall times is very good in this di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: Another.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Diaphaenicon, ‚Ñ• ii. as much √® ≈øuceo ro≈øarum, drink this in the morning at ≈øix or ≈øeven a clock with ‚Ñ• iv. of white wine, bloodwarm, for three four or five dayes: It is an excellent purge, and will give you ≈øix or eight ≈øtools within two hours. Probat.

div.head: A Pe≈ø≈øet good in all cold Agues, or Pe≈øtilentiall Di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: Make a Po≈ø≈øet with ≈ømall Beer, with a quart of milk, as clear as you can, then take of Goats rye, M. 1. when you have taken off the curd from the Po≈ø≈øet put the Goats rye into it, and let it boyl a good while; then put three or four branches of Scordium into it, then take it from the fire, and cover it a while; then ≈øtrein it, and give the Patient neer a pint of it at a draught warm, an hour before his fit comes; then let him lye ≈øtill one hour to ≈øweat, or two, or longer if he can indure it, u≈øe this for three times; but let the Patient be carefull he take no cold.

div.head: The Plague Water.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Harts horne ra≈øped, ‚Ñ• i. one root of Saxifrage, the ≈øtems and ≈øeeds of red Sage, Rue, Elder leaves and berries, red Bramble leaves, one root of Angelica, or the leaves thereof, Tormentill the roots and Leaves, ana M. i. two Oranges, Engli≈øh ≈ønake-weed the roots and leaves, Virginia ≈ønake-weed a ≈ømall quantity, which is much better then ours, of Goats rue, ana, M. i. Butterburr leaves and roots, and Pimpernel, ana M. ≈øs. Scordium ≈øix branches, Marigold Flours, and borage flours, and Ro≈øemary flours, ana M. i. White Ginger í ii. dryed Figs eight, old Ivie Berries black, two ≈øpoonfuls, Walnuts fortie, ≈øtamp them all in a morter, and ≈øteep them twelve hours in White wine, lb ii. and white Wine Vinegar, lb ≈øs. then ≈øtrein it through a fine ≈øtrong linnen cloth, and adde unto it ‚Ñ• i. of Bole Armoniack finely poudered, and a little Pomecitrine rinds one penniworth, and di≈øtil it in a dry Still, and take morning and evening one ≈øpoonfull. This is good for any Fever, ague, ≈ømall Poxe, Mea≈øels, or any Infection: If it purgeth, as it will if there be any infection, you mu≈øt give the Patient two ≈øpoonfuls of this till it hath done his working.

div.head: An Antidote again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence, by Dr. B.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Three pints of good Mu≈øcadine, of Rue, M. i. of brown Sage as much, brui≈øe and boyl the Hearbs in the Mu≈øcadine till a third part be con≈øumed, then put to of Ginger ‚Ñ• ≈øs. of Nutmegs thirty two, a penniworth of long Pepper gro≈ø≈øely brui≈øed into the Wine, and let it boil one walm, then take it off and ≈øtrein it, then put into it a penniworth of Mithridate, two penniworth of London Triacle, and a quarter of a pint of Angelica water, drinke one ≈øpoonfull of this every morning fa≈øting one hour after; but if the partie be infected, then let him drinke two ≈øpoonfuls, and ≈øweat upon it.

div.head: For the ≈øhaking Pal≈øie.
div.p: Take of Cloves two or three ounces, as much of Nutmegs, pouder them ≈ømall, and mixe them with oyle of Lavender, to make them fit for a plai≈øter, ≈øpread it on Leather, and lay it to the nape of the neck, and wri≈øts of the hands; Or as I have proved, Take three penniworth of London Triacle, a pennie pot of Neat oyle, a pennie pot of Sherrie Sack, mix the≈øe three things together well, and eat a ≈øpoonfull or two every morning fa≈øting, and at any time of the day; after this once or twice a day if you plea≈øe take a ≈øpoonfull, or eat it upon new white bread. This will help the ≈øhaking Pal≈øie, and trembling of the heart, and make a man cheerfull and merrie. Probatum. I had the ≈øhaking Pal≈øie by working in Mercurie, no man more, and this in fourteen dayes cured me; God be prai≈øed.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Steep Mugwort in Ro≈øewater, wa≈øh the hands therewith, and it will cure their ≈øhaking and trembling.

div.head: To re≈øtore lo≈øt Speech.
div.p: Lay a thin peece of raw Beef to the forehead of them that have lo≈øt their voice, and let it lye one all night.

div.head: To re≈øtore ≈øpeech to an Apoplectick.
div.p: Beat the Kernels of Peach ≈øtones together into pouder, and give the Patient a good draught thereof in Renni≈øh Wine.

div.head: A Re≈øtorative Electuary.
div.p:
Take of great Rai≈øins clean≈øed from their ≈øtones lb ii. of Licorice ≈øcraped, and brui≈øed, ‚Ñ• i. put the≈øe in lb ii. ≈øs. of cleer water, ≈øeeth them well, and ≈øtrein them, and put into their
≈øtreining, of Mirabolans, Hebal, Citrine, and Indic. cleered from their ≈øtones, ana ‚Ñ• ii. of Emblick and Bellerick, ana í ii. boyl them, pre≈ø≈øe and ≈øtrain them, then put thereto of pure Sugar, lb i. and when they are boyled up to the thickne≈øs of a Sirrup; adde in the end of choice Cinnamon, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. Cloves and Galingal, ana í ii. of Nutmegs, num. ii. of Fennel, and Anni≈øe-≈øeed, ana í i. Make it into an Electuarie, and put it up into a clean Box, agreeable to the complexion of the Patient that ≈øhall u≈øe it; as for the ≈øpleen, in a Tamarisk, or A≈øh boxe, or Jumper for flegmatick per≈øons, and ≈øo accordingly of others.
In this Electuary are Medicines for principal Members, viz. the Heart, the Head, Stomack, Liver, Spleen, and Generative parts. It is fir≈øt hot, then moi≈øt, after cold, and la≈øt dry.

This Medicine was invented by Arnoldus de villa nova for hindering old age, con≈øervation of health, prolongation of life: it not onely comforteth, but purgeth ≈øuperfluities remaining from the nouri≈øhment pa≈øt, keepeth back gray haires ≈øtrengthneth the ≈øtomack, and giveth a good colour to the whole body.

div.head: A Re≈øtorative good in all di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: Take Elder flours, the Eve of S. John Bapti≈øt at Mid≈øummer, according to the Planet which is Jupiter, or according to the Sun diall at twelve a clock: Dry the≈øe in the Ea≈øt, ≈øtamp and pouder them, then take Borage water, and put into it ≈øeven or nine grains of the Pi≈øsle of a Deer, dryed and grated to pouder, with a ≈øpoonfull of the pouder of the flouers afore≈øaid: Infu≈øe them for 12 houres, in three or four ounces of the water for the Patient to drinke for 15. dayes together. It re≈øtoreth old age, and ≈øtrengthneth the back. In fine, this is miraculous for all di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: For the Rickets.
div.p:
Take of cream two pound, and boil it to an oyle or take
of un≈øalted Butter, lb ii. take three or four good handfulls of Cammomil, mince it ≈ømall, and put it into the oyle or Butter, and let it boil on a ≈øoft fire till the hearbs became cri≈øpe, and that it be very bitter; then ≈øtrein it, and annoint the childs ≈øides downwards, and the bottome of the belly and thighes morning and evening: Al≈øo to give the child thrice a day half a do≈øen ≈øpoonfuls of ‚Ä¢ arts tongue water, in which you have ≈øteped ≈øeven or eight Cl ‚Ä¢ ves, and ≈øome b ‚Ä¢ own Sugar Candie to ≈øweeten it: If the child mend not with this; ‚Ñû Of ≈øhoomakers ≈øhreds, two or three M. boil them in fair water, and take off the oyle, and annoint the child, as before pre≈øcribed: If the child be not weaned, you mu≈øt wean it, otherwi≈øe no Medicine will recover it: Al≈øo you mu≈øt carry it as little as you can in your armes, but when you doe, be ≈øtirring it, and make it try to u≈øe the legs, if it be of that bigne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Doctor Vanhecks Ro≈øa Vitae.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Mercurie ≈øublimate ≈øublimed with ‚Ñ• iv. of Roman or Danisk Vittriol, Antimonie crude, ‚Ñ• ii. grinde them well together an hour and half; retort the≈øe with ≈øand half way up the body of the gla≈ø≈øe, with a gentle fire five houres, and then increa≈øe the fire by degrees, till with a good fire red begins to come (into an Urinal half full of water) which precipitates that which is di≈øtilled out into a ≈ønow white pouder, which pouder wa≈øh three or four times with fair water till the ≈øharpne≈øs be gone. Then make an extract of Zedoarie, Cinnamon, and Galingale, ana, í i. and red Sanders í ii. with ≈øpirit of Wine ‚Ñ• vi. mingle this Extract with ‚Ñ• i. of the fore≈øaid white pouder, and grinde them together well, and it will dry it ≈øelf into a red pouder.

It is given for the French Pox about four grains in the pap of an Apple with butter, this will give ≈øome five or ≈øix vomits; It al≈øo helpeth Agues and Fevers, Drop≈øie and divers other di≈øea≈øes, and is con≈øtantly ≈øold for three ≈øhillings four pence the do≈øe, Probat per me T. S.

div.head: S
A Sear-cloth for divers cau≈øes.
div.p: REcipe, Of Oyle olive, lb i. ≈øs. red Lead, lb i ≈øs. of white Lead, lb i. Ca≈øtile Sope ‚Ñ• iiii. Oyle of Bayes ‚Ñ• ii. Put your Oyle olive in a Pipkin, and put thereto your Oyle of Bayes, and the Ca≈øtile Sope. Seeth the≈øe over a gentle fire of Embers till it be well mingled and melted together, then ≈øtrew a little red lead and white, being mingled together in pouder, ≈øtill ≈øtirring it with a great ≈øpatter of wood, and ≈øo ≈øtrew in more of your Lead by little and little, till all be in, ≈øtirring it ≈øtill by the bottome to keep it from burning, for an hour and half together; then make the fire ≈øomewhat bigger, till the redne≈øs be turned into a gray colour. But you mu≈øt not leave ≈øtirring it, till the matter be turned into a perfect black colour as ‚Ä¢ itch; then drop a little upon a wooden trencher, and if it cleave not to the trencher, nor your finger, it is enough: Then take long linnen clothes, and dip them therein, and make your Sear-cloths thereof, they will keep 20 yeares; let your pouder of your Lead be ≈øear≈øed very fine, and ≈øhred the Sope ≈ømall.

The Vertues of this Sear-cloth are; Being laid to the Stomack, it doth provoke appetite, and taketh away any pain in the ≈øtomack; being laid to the Belly, it is a pre≈øent remedie for the Collick: Being laid to the back, it is a pre≈øent remedie for the Flux, and running of the Reins, heat of the Kidnies, and weakne≈øs of the Back: It helpeth all ≈øwellings and brui≈øes, and taketh away Aches. It breaketh Felons, and other impo≈øthumes, and healeth them. It draweth out any running humour, and helpeth him without breaking of the skin, and being applyed to the Fundament, helpeth any di≈øea≈øe there: It helpeth all old Sores, and will be made in ≈øix houres.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The Clawes of a brown Pionie root, and the root, and Jet Beads, ana p. ae. dry the clawes and roots, and pouder them, and the jet al≈øo very finely, then mingle them, and in Ale or White wine drinke a little of the pouder.
2. Peel a red Onyon, ≈ølice him and put him into a pint of good white Wine, let him lye ≈øix houres, then ≈øtrein it, and drinke of it twice in a fit, and it will expell the ≈øtone.

div.head: For Stone, Strangurie, and Collick.
div.p: Take the inner rinde of the young branches of a Ha≈øell tree, boyle them in ≈ømall Ale till half be con≈øumed, and let him that hath the Strangurie, drink half of it at a draught, let the Patient drink a draught of it fir≈øt and la≈øt, for nine dayes together, for it never fails.

div.head: For the Stone in the Bladder.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Turpentine ‚Ñ• iiii. and burn it to pouder, then mix two drachms thereof with four ounces of Saxifrage water, and give it twice a week, in the morning to the Patient, and this will not onely pre≈øerve him from the ≈øtone, but drive it out, if any u≈øe this but two moneths. Probat.
2. Stamp two Bees in Beer and drinke it, and it will cau≈øe Urine to come.

div.p: ‚Ñû. The juyce or water ≈øtrained out of Raddi≈øh roots, mixe it with White wine, and the pouder of Turpentine, dryed in the Suri, and ≈øo drinke: This is an excellent Medicine to drive out the ≈øtone.

div.p:
Take Par≈øely, and ≈øtamp it in White wine, then ≈øtrain it well, and drinke a good draught thereof, and this will cau≈øe
you to make water, and break the ≈øtone; but you mu≈øt u≈øe this five or ≈øix times. Probat.
‚Ñû. Pouder of Brionie berries, and drink it in water, wherein Water-cre≈ø≈øes have been boyled, and it will both help you, and give you ea≈øe.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The bloud of two Hares, as much Sheeps or Goats milk, mingle them well together, and boil them in a new pot to a coal, beat it to pouder, and ≈øearce it finely, and give the Patient hereof a good quantity in a little fountain water, lukewarm, this will break the ≈øtone to du≈øt, and make it come away. To try this, put the ≈øtone into it, with a little water bloud-warm, and in half an hour it will di≈ø≈øolve it into peeces.
2. Take five Cloves of Garlick, and ≈øtamp, and ≈øtrain them in a draught of Rhenni≈øh wine, and ≈øo drink it. This being taken three times together is a ≈øure Remedie.

div.head: For the Stone in Reins and Bladder.
div.p: 1. Scrape Sea-hor≈øe pi≈øsle to pouder, and drinke thereof every morning with white wine, and a little oyle of Almonds, and this will cure the ≈øtone of the Kidnies and Bladder, being given four ounces at a draught.
2. Pouder of Manati, which is a ≈øtone growing in a Sea-cows head, being exhibited in the afore≈øaid manner, will doe the like. The white for the man, and the yellow for the woman.

3. ‚Ñû Spikenard, Carraway, Fennel, Anni≈øe, and Cummin≈øeeds, Cinnamon, and Galingale, ana, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. Gromwell ≈øeed, and Liquorice, ana ‚Ñ• i. beat them all into pouder, and take half a ≈øpoonful of this pouder in Ale or Beer warmed, and after walk an hour before you eat or drinke, doe this four or five times, and you ≈øhall finde a notable operation.

div.head: A Po≈ø≈øet for the Stone.
div.p: Make a Po≈ø≈øet very thinne and clear with a quart of Milk, and put into it eight or ten roots of Althea, and two Par≈øly roots, having their pithes taken out, and two A≈øparagus roots picked and wa≈øhed clean, ≈øo that no durt be on it, and let them boyle well in the Milk-Po≈ø≈øet; then ≈øtrain it clean, and let the Patient drink a good draught, put into it as much Sal prunellae as will make it ≈øomewhat Bracki≈øh; this is a ≈øafe and admirable Medicine.

2. ‚Ñû. The braines of a Magpy newly killed, and put it into a wine Gla≈ø≈øe of white Wine, and ≈øtir it well till it be throughly mixed, and then drink it, and this will pre≈øently cau≈øe Urine, and ea≈øe the pain.

div.head: For the Spleen.
div.p: Seeth the rindes, and keyes, of an A≈øh tree very tender and well in white Wine, and drink a good draught thereof for ≈øix or ≈øeven mornings together, it doth much ea≈øe the Patient: when you drink this, annoint the Spleen with Dialthea every morning and evening, applying Empla≈øtrum de Meliloto pro Splene to the place. Probat.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Put of oyle of Gold one drachm, into half a pound of Anni≈øe≈øeed-water, ≈øhake it well together every time you take of it, and take a ≈øpoonful at a time, and it will help you. Probat.
Heat a pair of Tongs ≈øix times red hot, and quench them in white Wine; drink this nine mornings together, and this will help the Spleen.

div.head: For Swelling of Armes, Legs, and Feet.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Lin≈øeed, Wheat, Bran, Brooklime, Chickweed, and Ground≈øel, anae. one handful, ≈øeeth them in a pottle of white Wine altogether till it be thick, then lay a plai≈øter thereof to
the ≈øwollen place as hot as you can ≈øuffer it, and it will help it with three or four plai≈øters.

div.head: For Sinewes, and Nerves, cut a≈øunder.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of Earth-wormes one handful, put them in a cloth, and clean≈øe them well from the earth, that done, take Sack half a pound, and of Sallade oyle half a pound, mix them together, and infu≈øe the Wormes in this untill they be ≈øuffocated, then ≈øtop the pot very clo≈øe, and lute it well, and ≈øet the pot in hot hor≈øe-dung for eight and forty houres, till the Wormes be rotten, then take them out and pre≈ø≈øe them, and adde thereto of common Oyle half an ounce, of Venice Turpentine two drachms, then relute your pot, and ≈øet it on a ≈øoft fire for three or four houres.

div.head: For Brui≈øes, or ≈øtreined Sinewes.
div.p: 1. Annoint the place greived with Aqua compo≈øita, and Neat-foot oyle luke-warm, laying hot clothes thereon.
2. Stamp live Earth-wormes, and apply them to Sinewes cut.

div.head: For ≈øhrinking of Sinewes.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Two Swallowes ne≈øts that are ready to fly, of Lavender Cotton, the tops of young Thyme, the ≈øtrings that run out of Strawberries, Cammomil, and Hollihock leaves, ana. one handful; ≈øtamp the Swallowes quick and the Hearbs together, till no feathers be ≈øeen, then put thereto of May Butter one pound or two, and ≈øtamp it again to a ≈øalve, and let it ≈øtand again clo≈øe for ≈øeven dayes; then ≈øeeth it the ≈øpace of two houres with a quick fire, ≈øtirring it ≈øtill; then ≈øtrain it thorough a cour≈øe cloth, and annoint the joynts therewith, or an other place where the Sinewes are ≈øhrunk, and u≈øe often to ≈øtretch out the joynts and ≈øplint.

div.p: ‚Ñû. Ro≈øemary, Thyme, Par≈øly, Hy≈øop, Bayes, Sage, Lavender Spike, Lavender Cotton, Balm, Cammomil, Roman Wormwood, Brooklime, Smallage, Yarrow, red Nettles, Lovage, Hearb Robert, Plantain, Rag-wort, Vervain, Adders-tongue, Dai≈øes, Night≈øhade, Comfry, Orpine, Strawberry ≈øtrings, Violet leaves, Walwort, Amber leaves, Southernwood, Knotgra≈ø≈øe, Vine tops, Valerian, Honi≈øuckle leaves, Polipodium of the Oak, Dill, Mallowes, Perwinckle, Rue, of the≈øe one handful, ≈ølice them a little, and ≈øtamp them very ≈ømall in a Morter, with powder of Cloves brui≈øed ≈ømall, put thereto oyle Olive, and Neats-foot oyle, ≈øo much that they may ≈øwim, mixing them together, ≈øet it on the fire till all the ≈øtrength of the Hearbs be boyled out, and take heed it doe not burn; then ≈øtrain out the Hearbs, and clarifie it over the fire, then put to it a little Wax to harden it withall: this Ointment ≈øhould be made between May and Bartholomewtide. div.head: To cure an old Sore.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of fre≈øh Butter one pound, put it into a pot in the moneth of Aprill, then take of Violets, of Ro≈øemary, red Sage, Buglo≈ø≈øe, Wormwood, Broom, Hy≈øop, Pennygra≈ø≈øe, Vervain, Selfeheal, Hypericon, and Speedwell, ana. one handful; gather them as they be ready, and put them into the pot with the Butter, and ≈øet them into the Sun until Michaelneas, then take it out of the pot, and beat it in a Morter, then make it up plai≈øterwi≈øe, and re≈øerve it for your u≈øe.

div.p: Chop ≈ømall the knotted place of a Pine Tree, and boyle it well in Ale or Beer, that the ≈øteem may come out, and drink of it, and it will cure the Scurvy: This was Colonel Hamiltons Secret.

div.p: ‚Ñû. Of oyle Olive one pound and a half, Wax ≈øix ounces, of Minium two ounces, Litharge of Gold two ounces, Ceru≈øe one ounce and a half, Camphire one ounce and a half; fir≈øt boyle your Oyle and Wax till it be melted, then take it from the fire, and put in all the afore≈øaid things, being beaten very ≈ømall and ≈øearced, and ≈øtir them together till they be cold, and as occa≈øion ≈øerveth annoint the ≈øore place.

div.p: ‚Ñû. Four graines of Ma≈øtick, Swallow them every night to bedwards; this pre≈øerveth the Stomack from all paines, and cureth the ≈øame.

div.p: ‚Ñû. Capons Grea≈øe five pound, Origanum, Wormwood, the tops of Ro≈øemary, Stomack Mints, ana. M. i. and a few Buds of red Ro≈øes pickt; chop the Hearbs very ≈ømall, and pownd them in a ≈øtone Morter, afterward boyle them in the Capons Grea≈øe, till you ≈øee the goodne≈øs of the Hearbs boyled out, then ≈øtrain them, and put ≈øo many more Hearbs as afore≈øaid, and let them lye all night, then boyle them all again, till the vertue of the Hearbs be boyled out, then ≈øtrain them, and take of Cloves, and Mace, ana. ‚Ñ•. i beaten very ≈ømall, and let it boyle a walm or two, keeping it ≈øtill ≈øtirring that it may not grow black, then take it from the fire, and put it into a pan, or broad di≈øh, and ≈øtirre it till it be almo≈øt cold, and put into it a pint of Aqua vitae, and a quart of the di≈øtillation of Vine leaves; this is good for any thing that lieth heavy upon the ≈øtomack, being annointed therewith.

div.p: REcipe. Of Violet leaves one handful, of Mallow leaves one handful, ≈øtamp them together, and take a quantity of Bores Grea≈øe, and of Wheat Bran one handful, ≈øet it on the fire in clean water, and make a plai≈øter thereof, and lay it to the greif.

div.p: Take a little Salt in the morning fa≈øting, and hold it under your tongue till it be melted, and rub your teeth with it. Probatum.

To take away a Wen.

A TREATISE CONCERNING THE PLAGUE AND THE POX,

div.head: A defen≈øative again≈øt the Plague. The fir≈øt Treati≈øe
CHAP. I. What the Plague is.
div.p: THe antient Phi≈øitians in times pa≈øt have greatly doubted, what the e≈ø≈øentiall cau≈øe of this di≈øea≈øe, which we commonly call the Plague or Pe≈øtilence, ≈øhould be; yet all doe agree, that it is a pernitious and contagious Fever, and reckoned to be one of the number of tho≈øe which are called Epidemia, chiefly proceeding of adu≈øted and melancholy bloud, which may be ea≈øily perceived, by the extream heat and inflammation, which inwardly they doe feel, that are infected therewith; fir≈øt a≈ø≈øaulting the heart, and a≈øtoni≈øhing the vitall ≈øpirits, as al≈øo by the exteriour Carbunkles and botches which it produceth; who≈øe malignity is ≈øuch, both in young and old, rich and poor, noble and ignoble, that u≈øing all the meanes, which by Art can, or may be devi≈øed, yet in ≈øome it will in no ≈øort give place, untill it hath by death conquered the party infected therewith.

div.head: CHAP. II. Cau≈øe of the Plague.
div.p:
THere are divers cau≈øes whereof this di≈øea≈øe may proceed, as ≈øundry Writers doe alledge, as by over great and unnaturall heat and drought, by great rain and inundations of waters, or by great ≈øtore of rotten and ≈øtinking bodies,
both of men and bea≈øts, lying upon the face of the earth unburied, as in the time of warres hath been ≈øeen, which doth ≈øo corrupt the air, as that thereby our Corn, Fruits, Hearbs, and Waters, which we daily u≈øe for our food and ≈øu≈øtenance, are infected: al≈øo it may come by ≈øome ≈øtinking dunghils, filthy and ≈øtanding pooles of water, and un≈øavory ≈ømels, which are near the places where we dwell, or by thru≈øting a great company of people into a clo≈øe, narrow, or ≈øtreight room, as mo≈øt commonly we ≈øee in Ships, common Gaoles, and in narrow and clo≈øe lanes and ≈øtreets, where many people doe dwell together, and the places not orderly kept clean and ≈øweet. But mo≈øt commonly, in this our time, it is di≈øper≈øed among≈øt us, by accompanying our ≈øelves with ≈øuch as either have, or lately have had the di≈øea≈øe them≈øelves, or at lea≈øt have been conver≈øant with ≈øuch as have been infected therewith: But for the mo≈øt part it doth come by receiving into our cu≈øtody ≈øome clothes, or ≈øuch like things, that have been u≈øed about ≈øome infected body, wherein the infection may lie hidden a long time, as hath been too too often experimented, with repentance too late in many places, It may al≈øo come by Dogs, Cats, Pigs, and Wea≈øels, which are prone and apt to receive and carry the infection from place to place. But how≈øoever it doth come, let us a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves, that it is a ju≈øt puni≈øhment of God, laid upon us for our manifold ≈øins and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions again≈øt his divine Maje≈øty: for as Seneca ≈øaith, Quicquid patimur ab alto venit, What cro≈ø≈øes or afflictions ≈øoever we ≈øuffer, it cometh from the Lord, either for a triall of our faith, or a puni≈øhment for our ≈øins. Wherefore to di≈øtingui≈øh any farther thereof I think it needle≈ø≈øe, for my intent is in breif ≈øort, ≈øo exactly as I can, to ≈øhew the meanes how to prevent the ≈øame, as al≈øo how to cure it when we are infected. But before I enter to treat thereof, I think it not ami≈ø≈øe, to ≈øhew what forewarnings and tokens are given us before hand of the coming thereof, thereby the better to prevent the ≈øame by prayer and repentance.

div.head: CHAP. III. Warnings of the Plague to come.
div.p: A Vicen, a noble Phy≈øitian ≈øaith, that when wee ≈øee the naturall cour≈øe of the ayre, and ≈øea≈øons of the year to be altered, as when the ≈øpring time is cold, clowdy, and dry, the harve≈øt time ≈øtormy, and tempe≈øtuous, the mornings and evenings to be very cold, and at noon extream hot, the≈øe do fore≈øhew the Plague to come. Al≈øo when we ≈øee fiery impre≈ø≈øions in the firmament, e≈øpecially in the end of ≈øummer, as comets and ≈øuch like, and that in the begining of harve≈øt we ≈øee great ≈øtore of little frogs, red toades, and my≈øe on the earth abounding extraordinarily: or when in ≈øummer we ≈øee great ≈øtore of toades creeping on the earth having long tailes, of an a≈øhy color on their backs, and their bellies ≈øpotted and of divers colours, and when we ≈øee great ≈øtore of gnats ≈øwiming on the waters, or flying in great companies together, or when our trees and hearbs do abound with Caterpillars, Spiders, Moaths &c. which devoure the leaves on the trees and hearbs on the earth, it ≈øheweth the ayre to be corrupt, and the Plague ≈øhortly after to follow. Al≈øo by the bea≈øts of the field we may perceive it (e≈øpecially ≈øheep) which will go mourning with their heads hanging down towards the ground, and divers of them dying without any manife≈øt cau≈øe known unto us. Al≈øo when we ≈øee young Children flock them≈øelves together in companies, and then will faine ≈øome one of their company to be dead amongs them, and ≈øo will ≈øolemnize the buriall in a mournfull ≈øort, this is a token which hath been well ob≈øerved in our age to fore≈øhew great mortality at hand. Al≈øo when we ≈øee rivers of water to overflow without any manife≈øt cau≈øe, or ≈øuddenly vani≈øh away and become dry: And when clear well-≈øprings do ≈øuddenly become foule and troubled. Al≈øo when the ≈ømall-Pox doth generally abound both in young and old people, all the≈øe do fore≈øhew the Plague to come.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Sheweth how to prevent the Plague.
div.p: THere are three principall meanes how to prevent this contagious di≈øea≈øe: The fir≈øt and chiefe≈øt is to acknowledge our manifold ≈øins and wickedne≈øs unto almighty God our heavenly Father, with a hearty repentance and amendment of our former ≈øins committed again≈øt his divine maje≈øtie.

The ≈øecond means is to fly far off from the place infected, and as Rondoletius ≈øaith, not over ha≈øtily to return thither again for fear of an after-clap: which ≈øaying is confirmed by Valetius in the≈øe words, Non enim morietur in bello, qui non e≈øt in illo: and the farther from it, the ≈øafer ≈øhall we be, yet were it a very uncharitable cour≈øe that all which are of abillity ≈øhould do ≈øo, for then how ≈øhould the poor be relieved, and good orders ob≈øerved: but for Children it were be≈øt to ≈øend them far off from the place, becau≈øe their bodies are mo≈øt apt to receive the infection, as al≈øo for that they cannot ≈øo continually u≈øe antidots and pre≈øervatives, which by their great heat may indanger them almo≈øt ≈øo much as the di≈øea≈øe it ≈øelf.

The third meanes con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in three points, which are the≈øe: Order, Diet, and Phy≈øicall helps. For the fir≈øt you ≈øhall have a care that your hou≈øes be kept clean and ≈øweet, not ≈øuffering any foule and filthy clothes or ≈øtinking things to remain in or about the ≈øame: and in ≈øummer ≈øea≈øon to deck your windowes, and ≈øtrow your floors with ≈øweet and whol≈øom hearbs, floures, and leaves, of Mints, Balme, Penniroyall, Lavender, Time, Majoram, red-Ro≈øes, Carnations, Gelliflowers and ≈øuch like for your windowes, your floors to be ≈øtrowed with green Ru≈øhes, and Mints, Oaken and Willow leaves, Vine leaves and ≈øuch like: your windowes which ≈øtand towards the North and Ea≈øt, do you alwaies keep open in the day time, if the ayre be clear, and that no infected and un≈øavory ≈ømell be near the ≈øame, as Fogs, dunghils, &c. and every morning before you open either your doors, or windowes, as al≈øo in the evening when you go to bed, cau≈øe a good fire to be made in your Chamber, and burn ≈øome odoriferous or
≈øweet perfumes in the midde≈øt thereof, as hereafter I will ≈øhew you, or in ≈øtead thereof ≈øome Juniper, Frankincen≈øe, Bay leaves, Ro≈øemary, Lavender, Majoram, or ≈øuch like, which you mu≈øt alwaies have dried in a readine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo in the fume or ≈ømoke thereof to breath and perfume the clothes which you are to weare.

div.head: A good perfume in ≈øummer ≈øea≈øon.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Ro≈øe water and Vinegar, of either ≈øix ≈øpoonfulls: Rinds of ≈øower Citrons and Lemons, Bay-leaves, of either the weight of two pence which is ‚Ñà. i. Camphire, the weight of three pence, which is í. ≈øs.
The hearbs and rinds mu≈øt be dried and put alltogether in a perfuming pan, or in≈øtead thereof a peuter di≈øh, ≈øet on a chafer of coles, will ≈øerve the turn.

div.head: Another good perfume in winter.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Red-Ro≈øes Majoram and Myrtles, of either a little handfull: Callamint, Juniper berries, Laudanum, Benjamin, Frankincen≈øe, of either í. i. which is the weight of ≈øeven pence.

The hearbs, berries, and Ro≈øes being dried, mu≈øt be made in gro≈ø≈øe powder, as al≈øo the gumms, and ≈øo mixed together, and when yee li≈øt, ca≈øt ≈øome part thereof on a chafer of coales, and receive the fume thereof.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
NOw having received the fume as afore≈øaid, before you go forth of your chamber, eat ≈øome Cordial electuary or pre≈øervative, as hereafter you ≈øhall find choi≈øe, which I have alwais u≈øed with good and happy ≈øucce≈øs, after taking of the Cordial wa≈øh your face and hands with clean water, wherein you mu≈øt put a little Vinegar, and then if you li≈øt, you may break your fa≈øt wirh ≈øome good bread and butter, and in winter ≈øea≈øon a potch'd Egg is good eaten with ≈øome Vinegar, and for plethorick
and melanchole bodies, it were good to drink a draught of wormewood wine, in the morning fa≈øting, becau≈øe it re≈øi≈øteth putrefaction in the plethorick, and purgeth bilous matter in the melancholie.

div.head: An excellent good pre≈øervative which I have alwaies u≈øed with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes and Borrage floures, of either two ounces: Minardus Mithridate, Andromachus triacle, of either half an ounce: Dio≈øcordium, two drachms, Dialkermes one drachme, Powder of the ≈øeed of Citrons pilled, one drachme, Sirrup of Lemons and ≈øower Citrons, of either halfe an ounce.

Compound all the≈øe together in the form of an opiat, you may eat hereof every morning the quantity of three beanes, and drink a draught of Renni≈øh wine, Beer, or Ale after it: but for Children and ≈øuch as are of tender years, ≈øo much as a bean thereof is ≈øufficient, and give them onely Beer or Ale after it: the taking hereof every ≈øecond or third day will ≈øuffice, if you go not into any ≈øu≈øpected company.

div.head: Another excellent good pre≈øervative.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Kernils of Wallnuts and Figs, of either four ounces: Leaves of Rue, one ounce and half, Tormentill roots, four drachms, Rind of ≈øowr Citrons, one drachme, right Bolarmoniak, ≈øix drachms, fine Myrrh, two ≈øcruples, Saffron, one ≈øcruple, Salt, half a drachm: Sirrup of Citrons and Lemons, four ounces.

The hearbs, roots, and rinds mu≈øt be dried, the nuts mu≈øt be blanched, and the bolarmoniack mu≈øt be made in fine powder, and then wa≈øh'd in the water of Scabios, and dried againe, you mu≈øt pound the figgs and wallnuts in a ≈øtone morter ≈øeverally by them≈øelves very ≈ømall, all the re≈øt mu≈øt be made in fine powder, and ≈øo mix them altogether in the morter, and then add thereto ≈øirrup by little and little, and ≈øo incorporate them altogether: you may give this in the ≈øame quantity, and in like ≈øort as the other before.

div.head: Another very good.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of the confection afore≈øaid made with Nutts ‚Ñ•. iiii. Minardus mithridate, four drachms, Andromachus Triacle, í ii. fine terra Sigillata, four ≈øcruples, Sirrup of Limons, ‚Ñ•. i.

Compound all the≈øe together in the morter, as the other before, you may give hereof the weight of a groat or ≈øix pence, every ≈øecond or third day, and drink a draught of Renni≈øh or white wine after it in Winter ≈øea≈øon, but in the heat of the yeer, Sorrel water is be≈øt, and in the Spring Scabios or Cardeus Benedictus water.
Al≈øo, ≈øo much Triacle of Andromachus de≈øcription eaten every morning as a bean, with a little con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, is a very excellent good pre≈øervative.
Valetius doth greatly commend the taking of three or four grains of the Bezar ≈øtone every morning, in a ≈øpoonfull of Scabios water.

I cannot here ≈øufficiently commend the Electuarie called Dio≈øcordium, which is not onely good to re≈øi≈øt the infection, but doth al≈øo expell the venemous matter of tho≈øe which are infected, being taken every morning and evening the quantity of a bean, and drinke a draught of Renni≈øh or White wine after it in winter ≈øea≈øon, but in Summer a draught of Beer or Ale is be≈øt.

In ≈øtrong and ru≈øticall bodies, and ≈øuch as are dayly labourers, Garlick onely eaten in the morning with ≈øome Butter and Salt at breakfa≈øt, drinking a cup of beer or ale after it, hath been found to be very good, which is greatly commended by Galen, who calleth it the poor mans Triacle, but in the ≈øanguine, daintie, and idle bodies it may not be u≈øed, becau≈øe it over-heateth the bloud, cau≈øeth head-ach, and univer≈øally inflameth the whole body.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p:
NOw when you have taken any of the fore≈øaid Pre≈øervatives, it were good and nece≈ø≈øary to wear upon the Region of the heart, ≈øome ≈øweet Bag or quilt that hath power to
re≈øi≈øt venome, and al≈øo to carry in your hand ≈øome ≈øweet Pomander, Nodule, or No≈øegay, that will comfort the heart, re≈øi≈øt venom, and recreate the vitall ≈øpirits, as here following is ≈øpecified and ≈øet down.

div.head: An excellent quilt or Bag.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Ar≈øenike cri≈øtaline, ‚Ñ•. i. Diamargaritum frigidum, ‚Ñà ii. Diambrae, ‚Ñà i.

You mu≈øt grinde the Ar≈øenike in ≈ømall powder, and then with ≈øome of the infu≈øion of Gum Dragagant in Ro≈øe water, you mu≈øt make a pa≈øte, then ≈øpread it on a cloth which mu≈øt be ≈øix inches long, and five inches broad, and ≈øpread it thick: then cover it with another cloth, and ≈øo quilt it together, which being done, fa≈øten it in another bag of crim≈øon taffetie or Sar≈øenet, and ≈øo wear it again≈øt the heart all the day time, but at night leave it off: and here you mu≈øt take heed, that when you ≈øweat, you doe take it away, for otherwi≈øe it will cau≈øe the skin to amper a little. There are ≈øome writers which doe utterly forbid the wearing of Ar≈øenike, but thus much I can ≈øay, that I have given this bag unto divers to wear, with mo≈øt happie and good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, for never did I yet know any one that hath worn this bag, and u≈øed any of the Electuaries afore≈øaid, that hath been infected with the plague, but for any inconvenience or accident that hath happened thereby, I never found any hitherto, other then the ampring of the skin as afore≈øaid.

div.head: Another Bag.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Ireos, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. Calamus aromat. Ciperus, ana. í. i. ≈øs. Storax Calam. root of Angelica, ana. í. iii. Cloves, Mace, ana í. i. Red ro≈øes dried, í. iii. Pellemountain, Penniroyall, Calamint, Elder floures, ana. í. i ≈øs. Nutmegs, Cinnamon, Yellow Sanders, ana í. i. Nardi Italicae; í. i. Amber greece and Musk, ana. ≈øix grains.
You mu≈øt pound all the≈øe in powder, and then quilt them in a bag of Crim≈øon Taffatie as afore≈øaid.

div.head: A Pomander good in the Summer time.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The rind of Citrons, Red Ro≈øes, Nenuphare Ro≈øes, Yellow ≈øanders, ana í. ≈øs. Storax liquid, Benjamin, ana. í. i. Myrrh, ‚Ñà. ii. Ladanum, í. i. ≈øs. Musk and Amber, ana. ≈øix grains.

Powder all that is to be powdered, and then work them together in a hot morter with a hot pe≈øtell, adding unto it in the working ≈øome of the Mu≈ø≈øelage of dragagant di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øweet Ro≈øe water, or ro≈øe vinegar, and ≈øo make your Pomander.

div.head: Another good one for the winter time.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Storax liquid, Benjamin, Storax calamint, Ladanum, and Myrrh, ana, half a drachm, Cloves one ≈øcruple, Nutmegs, Cinnamon, of each half a ≈øcruple. Red Ro≈øes, Yellow Sanders, Lignum aloes, and Ireos, of each half a dram. Calamus aromaticus, rind of a Citron, ana. four grains, Amber greece, Musk and Civet, of each ≈øix grains.
You may make up this as the other before with ≈øome Mu≈ø≈øelage of the infu≈øion of Gum dragagant, infu≈øed in Ro≈øe-water.

div.head: A good Nodule for the Summer ≈øea≈øon.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Floures of Violets, red Ro≈øes, and Nenuphare, of each one drachm, Red, White, and Yellow ≈øanders, of each half a drachm. Camphire, xii graines.

Cau≈øe all the≈øe to be beaten in gro≈ø≈øe powder, then knit them all together in a peece of Taffetie, and when you will u≈øe it, then wet it in Ro≈øe water and a little Vinegar, and ≈øo ≈ømell to it.

div.head: Another Nodule for the Winter ≈øea≈øon.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The dried leaves of Mints, Majoram, Time, Penniroyall, Lavender, Pellemountain and Balm, of each a little handfull. Nutmegs, Cloves, Cinnamon, Angelica roots, Lignum aloes, of each one drachm. Saffron, two ≈øcruples.

Cau≈øe all the≈øe to be infu≈øed in Ro≈øe-water and Vinegar one whole night, then wet a ≈øpunge in the liquor thereof, and knit it in a peece of Taffaty, or your handkerchief, whereunto you mu≈øt ≈ømell oftentimes.

div.head: A No≈øegay for the ≈øame purpo≈øe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Hearb grace, three branches: Ro≈øemary, Majoram, Mints, and Thime, of either one branch: Red-Ro≈øe buds and Carnations, of either three or four.

Make your no≈øegay herewith, then ≈øprinkle him over with Ro≈øe-water, and ≈øome ro≈øe-Vinegar, and ≈ømell often unto it. Al≈øo when you ≈øu≈øpect to go into any dangerous or infected company, do you alwaies carry in your mouth a peice of the root of Angelica, the rind of a Citron dried, or a great Clove, which mu≈øt be fir≈øt infu≈øed or ≈øteeped one whole night in ro≈øe-water and Vinegar.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p: FOr that there is not a greater enemy to the health of our bodies then co≈øtivene≈øs, both in the time of the Plague and otherwi≈øe, I have here ≈øet down how and by what meanes you may keep your ≈øelf ≈øoluble, which you mu≈øt u≈øe once four and twenty hours, if otherwi≈øe you have not the benefit of nature by cu≈øtome.

div.head: A Suppo≈øitory.
div.p: Take two ≈øpoonfulls of Honey, and one ≈øpoonfull of Bay-Salt ≈ømall pounded, boyle them together untill it grow thick, alwaies ≈øtirring it in the boyling, then take it from the fire, and if you li≈øt you may add one drachm of Ihera picra ≈øimplex unto it, and ≈øo ≈øtirre them well together, and when it is almo≈øt cold, make up your ≈øuppo≈øitories of what length and bigne≈ø≈øe you li≈øt: and when you mini≈øter any, you mu≈øt fir≈øt annoint it with Butter or Sallet oyle: you may keep the≈øe a whole year if you put them in Barrowes mort or grea≈øe, and ≈øo cover them up clo≈øe therein.

div.head: A good Gli≈øter.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Mallowes, Mercury, Beets, Violets, Red-Fennell, of either one handfull: Seeds of Fennell, Annis, Coriander, of either one drachm.

Boyle all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, untill half the water be con≈øumed, then ≈øtraine it, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopt untill you need, for it will keep a whole week. Take of the ≈øame decoction, a pint.
‚Ñû. Mel Ro≈øarum, or common Honey, one ≈øpoonfull: Oyle of Violets or oyle of Olives, three ounces, Salt, one drachm, The yolk of an Egg or two.
Mixe all the≈øe together in a morter and ≈øo give it warm in the morning, or two hours before ≈øupper: and if you add unto this one ounce of Diacatholicon it will be the better.

div.head: Rai≈øins laxative how to make them.
div.p: ‚Ñû. White-Wine, three pints and a half, Senuae, half a pound, Fine white ≈øugar, one pound, Currants, two pound. You mu≈øt infu≈øe the Senuae in the wine in a pot clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and let it ≈øtand in a warm place four and twenty hours, then ≈øtrein it and add to the ≈øtraining the Currants, being clean pickt and wa≈øht, and la≈øtly the Sugar, boyle all together on an ea≈øie fire, untill the wine be con≈øumed, having care that you do alwaies ≈øtirr it about in the boyling for feare of burning, then take them from the fire, and put them up into a clean galley pot, you may eat one ≈øpoonfull or two of them a little before dinner, at any time.

div.head: A good Oyntment to keep one Sollible.
div.p: The gaule of an Oxe, Oyle of Violets, of either one ounce: Sheeps tallow, ≈øix drachms.
Boyle them together on a ≈øoft fire untill they be incorporated, then take it from the fire and adde thereto Alloes cicatrine, one ounce. Bay-Salt half an ounce.

The Alloes and Salt mu≈øt be both made into fine powder before you put them into the oyle, then ≈øtirr them together untill it be cold, and when you are di≈øpo≈øed to have a ≈øtoole, then annoint your fundament therewith, both within ≈øide and without, and if you annoint your navell therewith, it will work the better.

div.head: Good pills to keep one ≈øoluble, and they do al≈øo re≈øi≈øt the Pe≈øtilence.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Alloes Cicatrine, one ounce, Cho≈øen Myrrh, three drachms, Saffron, one drachm and half, Amber Greece, ≈øix graines: Sirrup of Lemons or Citrons, ≈øo much as ≈øhall be ≈øufficient to make the ma≈ø≈øe.

You mu≈øt grinde the Aloes, Myrrhe, and Saffron into ≈ømall powder ≈øeverally by them≈øelves, then incorporate them together with the ≈øirrup: you may give half a drachme or two ≈øcruples thereof in the evening half an hour before ≈øupper twi≈øe or thri≈øe in a week: Ra≈øes would have you to take half a drachme or two ≈øcruples of the≈øe Pills every day, without u≈øing any other pre≈øervative at all, and he hath great rea≈øon ≈øo to e≈øteem of them, for Galen, Avicen, and all ancient Writers in Phy≈øick do hold opinion, that Aloes doth not onely comfort, but purge the ≈øtomack from all raw and chollerick humors, and doth al≈øo purge and open the veines called Mi≈øerayick, and re≈øi≈øteth putrefact on: Myrrh doth altogether re≈øi≈øt, neither will it ≈øuffer putrefaction in the ≈øtomack: Saffron doth comfort the heart, and hath al≈øo a propriety in it to carry any medicine that is given therewith unto the heart, but to conclude, the≈øe Pills will purge all ≈øuperfluous humors in the ≈øtomack, and principall members, and pre≈øerveth the bloud from corruption.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
div.p:
I Mu≈øt here give you to under≈øtand that the infection doth oftentimes lie hidden within us, without any manife≈øt ≈øign or knowledge thereof at the fir≈øt, and therefore were it good for ≈øanguine bodies, and ≈øuch as do abound with bloud, in the
≈øummer ≈øea≈øon to draw ≈øix or eight ounces of bloud out of the Ba≈øilica vein in the right arme, which is a good meanes to prevent a further danger, (as Avicen witne≈ø≈øeth) but for full and plethorick bodies, it were be≈øt to purge them≈øelves once in ≈øeven or eight daies with ≈øome ea≈øie and gentle purgation, as hereafter I will ≈øhew you: but for leane and ≈øpare bodies, once in fourteen dayes will be enough at mo≈øt: for wi≈øely ≈øaith Rondoletius, that it is not onely the venemous and contagious ayre which we receive that doth kill us, but it is the pre≈øent communicating of that contagion with ≈øome ≈øuperfluous humours in our bodies, as in his treati≈øe De Pe≈øte appeareth: therfore now will I ≈øhew you how to purge the body.

div.head: Pills good to purge.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Alloes Cicatrine, ten drachms, Agarick of the white≈øt, ‚Ñ•. iiii. Myrrh, Ma≈øtick, of either two drachms: Saffron two ≈øcruples.

Make the≈øe into fine powder, then compound them together in a morter, with ≈øo much Oximell ≈øimplex, Sirrup of Lemons, or of Staecados, as ≈øhall be ≈øufficient, you may give one drachm, or a drachm and half of the≈øe Pills, half an hour before ≈øupper: but for a cholerick body, you mu≈øt leave out two drachms of the Agarick in making of the receipt, and in place thereof add two drachms of Rubarb, and for the melancholie, two drachms of Epithimum, and give the ≈øame quantity in weight.

div.head: A good purging potion.
div.p: ‚Ñû Rai≈øins, the ≈øtones being pickt out and wa≈øht, of either one ounce: Polipode of the Oak, Elecampane root dried, roots of wild ≈ømall Sorrel, Succory roots clean≈øed, of either half an ounce: Leaves of Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Burnet, Scabios, Mor≈øus diaboli, of either a little handfull: Floures of Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Ro≈øemary, Violets, Broom, of either a little handfull: Seeds of Fennell, ≈øowr Citrons, of either two ≈øcruples: Shaving of Harts horn, half a drachm.

Boyle all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of faire water untill
half be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it. Take of the decoction afore≈øaid, three ounces.
Rubarb, two drachms and half, Cinnamon, half a drachm.

Slice them both, and put them with the liquor in a clo≈øe cup, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand to infu≈øe in a warm place twelve hours, then ≈øtrain it out ≈øtrongly, and add thereto one ounce of the Sirrup of Maiden-haire, and ≈øo drink it warm in the morning about ≈øix of the clock, and refrain from meat, drink, or ≈øleep two hours after it, this is good in lean and ≈øpare bodies: you may for the phlegmatick body, add in the infu≈øion, one drachm of Aggarick Tro≈øci≈øcated.

div.head: A purging powder for ≈øuch as cannot take Pills.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Alloes Ciccatrine, one ounce, Myrrh, Cinnamon, of either two drachms, Saffron, one ≈øcruple.
Make them all in fine powder, and give one drachm in a draught of White-wine.

div.head: Floures ≈øtopt, how to provok them.
div.p: For that women which have not their naturall cour≈øe o ‚Ä¢ them, are mo≈øt prone to receive and take the infection, I have here ≈øet down good Pills, which I have alwaies found excellent not onely for that purpo≈øe, but will al≈øo re≈øi≈øt the danger of infection.
‚Ñû. Alloes Ciccatirne, one ounce, Roots of Gentian, Ari≈øtolochia rotunda, Dittander, Saffron, of either half a drachm: Roots of garden Madder, Methridate, of either one drachm.

Cau≈øe them all to be ground in ≈ømall powder, then mix it with the Methridate and ≈øome ≈øirrup of Arteme≈øia, or Mugwort, give one drachm of the≈øe Pills every morning twelve dayes togerher, or untill her tearms break.

div.head: I≈ø≈øues commended again≈øt the Plague.
div.p:
IN plethorick and full bodies, I have found nothing more ≈øafer in the time of the Plague, then to make them an artificiall
I≈ø≈øue, either in the leg or arm, for never hitherto have I known any one which hath had an I≈ø≈øue, or Ulcer running on him that hath been infected with the plague. Palmarius and Fore≈øtus, doe both affirm it to be true and certain, but here ≈øome ignorant people doe hold opinion that having once an I≈ø≈øue, he mu≈øt be con≈øtrained to keep it alwaies, which is mo≈øt erronious, for then tho≈øe which have had Ulcers running upon them, ≈øome ≈øix, ten, yea ≈øixteen yeers, may not be cured without ≈øome I≈ø≈øue to be made in ≈øome other place, but therein they deceive them≈øelves, for my ≈øelf by good proof have often found the contrary in divers people which I have cured, ≈øome ≈øix, ≈øome ten, yea ≈øixteen yeers pa≈øt, and yet to this day doe remain in perfect good health without any I≈ø≈øues.

div.head: CHAP. IX. What Diet we ought to keep.
div.p:
FOr our diet as Hippocrates teacheth us, we mu≈øt have a care not to exceed in eating and drinking but to keep a mean therein, and in any ca≈øe to beware of ≈øurfeting and drunkenne≈øs, which are enemies both to the body and ≈øoule, but as we may not exceed in eating and drinking, ≈øo to endure great hunger and thir≈øt is mo≈øt dangerous, our meat ought to be of a facile and ea≈øie dige≈øtion, partly tending to a drying qualitie; as Cocks, Capons, Hens, Pullets, Partridge, Phea≈øants, Quailes, Pigeons, Rabbets, Kid, Veal, Mutton, Birds of the Mountains, and ≈øuch like; but Beef, Pork, Veni≈øon, Hare and Goats fle≈øh is to be refu≈øed, and ≈øo are all water fowls, as Duck, Swan, Goo≈øe, Widgen, Teal, and ≈øuch like, becau≈øe they are hard to dige≈øt, and do increa≈øe ill blood, and naughtie juyce in the bodie: Lambs fle≈øh, becau≈øe of his exceeding moi≈øture is al≈øo to be refu≈øed, Eggs in the Summer not good, but in Winter tolerable: All Fi≈øhes which are of a hard fle≈øh, whether they be of the Sea, or fre≈øh Rivers are to be allowed. In fre≈øh Rivers the Perch, Barble, Gudgeon, Loch, Cool, Trout, and Pike are good; and for Sea fi≈øh, the Gilthed, Turbet, Sole, Rochet, Gurnard, Lob≈øter, Crab, Praunes, Shrimps, Whiting, and ≈øuch like eaten with vinegar.
There are ≈øome Authors which hold opinion, that Fi≈øh is better to be eaten then fle≈øh in the great fervent heat of the year, becau≈øe they doe make a more cold bloud in the body then fle≈øh; another rea≈øon is, becau≈øe they doe live under the water, they are not infected with any contagion of the aire, as Bea≈øts and birds may be, and therefore more whol≈øome, but in my judgement fle≈øh is more whol≈øome, becau≈øe it doth-breed a more pure, and fine Juyce in the body then any Fi≈øh what≈øoever; your bread ought to be made of pure wheat, not too new, nor too old, but of one dayes baking, or two at mo≈øt is be≈øt: Rie bread is to be e≈øchewed, becau≈øe of his great moi≈øture: your drink is be≈øt beer or ale, not too ≈øtrong or new, but the ≈øtaler and clearer it is the better, at your meals a draught or two of Claret wine is tolerable, but in hot weather it were good to allay it with a little water, for wine doth warm the ≈øtomack, help dige≈øtion, and comfort the heart.

div.head: For your Pottage you may take in the Summer.
div.p: Par≈øly, Lettice, Sorrell, Endive, Succorie, Sperage, Hop-buds, Burnet, Burrage, Buglo≈ø≈øe, Thime, Mints, Hy≈øop, but in Winter, Balm, Bittanie, Thime, Marigold, Hy≈øop, Majoram, Mints and Rue are good. For your Sallets take Pimpernell, Pur≈ølane, Mints, Sorrell, Hore-hound, Yong cole, Hop-buds, Sperage, Thime, Tops of Fennell, Tarregon, Lettice, and Water-cre≈ø≈øes are good.
Capers are greatly commended being pre≈øerved in Vinegar, and eaten with a little oyle and vinegar, and ≈øo are Olives very good al≈øo.
For your ≈øauce, the juyce of a Limon, Citron, or Orange is be≈øt, the juyce of Sorrell and Vinegar is al≈øo good.

All raw fruits are to be refu≈øed, except tho≈øe which tend to ≈øour ta≈øt, as Pomgranates, damask Prunes, Pippins, red and ≈øour Cherries, and Wallnuts, Quinces, and Peares pre≈øerved are very good eaten after meals.
All kind of Pul≈øe is to be refu≈øed, as Beans, Pea≈øe, and ≈øuch like, becau≈øe they increa≈øe winde, and make raw humours and ill juyce in the bodie.
Refrain from Garlick, Onyons, Leeks, Pepper, Mu≈øtard, and Rocket, becau≈øe they doe over-heat the body, make adu≈øtion of the bloud, and cau≈øe fumes to a≈øcend into the head.
Chee≈øe is not good, becau≈øe it doth ingender gro≈ø≈øe and thick humors. Milk is al≈øo to be refu≈øed, becau≈øe it doth quickly corrupt in the ≈øtomack.

div.head: CHAP. X. Sheweth what Exerci≈øe and Order is to be kept.
div.p: YOu mu≈øt beware of all vehement and immoderate exerci≈øe, which doth provoke ≈øweat, as is Tennis, dancing, leaping, running, foot-ball, hurling, and ≈øuch like, becau≈øe they doe over-much heat the body, and open the Pores of re≈øpiration, whereby the infected aire hath the more ≈øcope to enter our bodies, but moderate exerci≈øe is very convenient, the u≈øe of hot hou≈øes at this time I thinke very dangerous, becau≈øe it doth too much open the pores.

Walk not into the open ayre in the morning before the Sun hath had ≈øome power to clean≈øe and clear the ≈øame, and in any ca≈øe goe not abroad when great fogs and mi≈øts are upon the earth, for it is dangerous: but if urgent occa≈øions move you, then before you goe forth of your doors be ≈øure to eat ≈øome pre≈øervative fir≈øt, and then take ≈øome good and odoriferous Pomander, Nodule, or No≈øegay in your hand, as before is ≈øhewed you. The extream heat of the day is likewi≈øe to be refu≈øed to walk in, becau≈øe it chafeth the bloud; as al≈øo in the evening after the Sun is ≈øet, for then un≈øavory and unwhol≈øome Fogs ari≈øe out of the earth, and in any ca≈øe if you can avoid it come not neer any any place infected, but u≈øe to walk in the open aire and dry ground.
U≈øe Venus combates moderately, but none at all were better, the be≈øt time to u≈øe them is three or four hours after ≈øupper, before you ≈øleep, and then re≈øt upon them.
Beware of anger, fear, and pen≈øivene≈øs of the minde, for by their means the body is made more apt to receive the infection.

U≈øe plea≈øant and merry recreations, either with mu≈øick,
plea≈øant company to talke withall, or reading ≈øome good books.
Bewar of ≈øleeping at noon, but ≈øpecially in the Winter ≈øea≈øon, but in Summer to take after dinner a nap of half an hour or an hour is tollerable in elderly bodies.
Watch not long in the evenings but two or three hours after ≈øupper is a good time to take your re≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Teacheth what orders Magi≈øtrates, and Rulers of Cities and Townes, ≈øhould cau≈øe to be ob≈øerved,
div.p: FIr≈øt, To command that no ≈øtinking dunghills be ≈øuffered near the City.

Secondly, Every evening and morning in hot weather to cau≈øe cold water to be ca≈øt in the ≈øtreets, e≈øpecially where the infection is, and every day to cau≈øe the ≈øtreets to be kept clean and ≈øweet, and clean≈øed from all filthy things which lye in the ≈øame.

Thirdly, And whereas the infection is entered, there to cau≈øe fires to be made in the ≈øtreets every morning and evening, and if ≈øome Frankincen≈øe, Pitch, or ≈øome other ≈øweet thing be burnt therein, it will be much the better.
Fourthly, Suffer not any Doggs, Catts, or Pigs to run about the ≈øtreets, for they are very dangerous, and apt to carry the infection from place to place.
Fifthly, Command that the excrements and filthy things which are voided from the infected places be not ca≈øt into the ≈øtreets or rivers which are daily in u≈øe to make drink, or dre≈ø≈øe meat.
Sixtly, That no Chirurgians, or Barbars which u≈øe to let bloud, do ca≈øt the ≈øame into the ≈øtreets or rivers.
Seventhly, That no Vauts or Privies be then emptied, for it is a mo≈øt dangerous thing.

Eighthly, That all Inholders do every day make clean their ≈øtables, and cau≈øe the dung and fi ‚Ä¢ th therein to be carried away out of the City: for by ≈øuffering it in their hou≈øes, as ≈øome do u≈øe to do, a whole week or a fortnight, it doth ≈øo putrifie that
when it is removed, there is ≈øuch a ≈øtinking and unwhol≈øome ≈ømell, as is able to infect the whole ≈øtreet where it is.
Ninthly, To command that no Hemp or Flax be kept in water near the City or Town, for that will cau≈øe a very dangerous and infectious ≈øavour.

Tenthly to have a ≈øpeciall care, that good and whol≈øome Victuals and Corn be ≈øold in the markets, and ≈øo to provide, that no want thereof be in the City, and for ≈øuch as have not wherewithall to buy nece≈ø≈øary food, that there to extend their charitable and godly devotion: for there is nothing that will more increa≈øe the Plague, then want and ≈øcar≈øity of nece≈ø≈øary food.

Eleventhly, To command that all tho≈øe which do vi≈øite and attend the ≈øick, as al≈øo all tho≈øe which have the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe on them, and do walk abroad, that they do carry ≈øomething in their hands, thereby to be known from other people. And here I mu≈øt adverti≈øe you of one thing more which I had almo≈øt forgotten (which is) that when the infection is but in few places, there to keep the people in their hou≈øes, not ≈øuffering any one of them to go abroad, and ≈øo to provide, that all ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øaries as they ≈øhall need may be brought unto them during the time of their vi≈øitation: and when it is ≈øtaied, then to cau≈øe all the clothes, bedding, and other ≈øuch things as were u≈øed about the ≈øick, to be all burnt, although at the charge of the re≈øt of the Inhabitants you buy them all new, for fear lea≈øt the danger which may en≈øue thereby, do put you to a far greater charge and grief: all the≈øe afore≈øaid things are mo≈øt dangerous, and may cau≈øe a generall infection, to the de≈øtroying of a whole City, and therefore I do wi≈øh that great care be had thereof.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Doth ≈øhew what you mu≈øt do when you go to vi≈øit the ≈øick.
div.p:
FIr≈øt before you enter into the hou≈øe, command that a great fire be made in the chamber where the ≈øick lieth, and that ≈øome odoriferous perfume be burnt in the mide≈øt of the chamber, and before you go to him, eat ≈øome cordiall pre≈øervative, and ≈ømother your clothes with ≈øome ≈øweet perfume, then wet
your temples, eares, no≈øe, and mouth, with Ro≈øe-water and Vinegar mixt together, then take in your mouth a peice of the root of Angelica, the rind of a ≈øower Citron, or a Clove prepared as before is ≈øhewed, and have ≈øome No≈øegay, Nodule, or Pomander, appropriate in your hand, which you mu≈øt alwaies ≈ømell unto, ≈øo may you the more bouldlier perform your intent: but herewithall you mu≈øt have a ≈øpeciall care, that during the time you are with the ≈øick, you ≈øtand not betwixt the ≈øick body and the fire, for that is dangerous; becau≈øe that the fire of his nature draweth all vapors unto it ≈øelf; but keep you alwaies on the contrary ≈øide, ≈øo that the ≈øick may be betwixt you and the fire: and for ≈øuch as are to let any ≈øick infected body to bleed, it were good they did cau≈øe the keeper of the ≈øick body to lay open that arme or legg which is to be let bloud before he approach near: the rea≈øon is, for that mo≈øt commonly all that are ≈øick in this contagious di≈øea≈øe, are for the mo≈øt part in a ≈øweat, and therefore ≈øuddenly to receive the breath thereof, would be very dangerous.

Now when you have been with any one ≈øo infected, before you go into the company of any whole and ≈øound people, it were nece≈ø≈øary you do ≈øtand by a good fire, having all the clothes about you which you did wear when you were with the ≈øick, and then turn and aire your ≈øelfe well thereby, ≈øo ≈øhall you be ≈øure the le≈ø≈øe to endanger others by your company. Thus have I as breefly as I can devi≈øe ≈øet down all the ordinary meanes which my ≈øelf have u≈øed, and by others known to be u≈øed for pre≈øerving you from this contagious and dangerous di≈øea≈øe, which in the mo≈øt part of people will ≈øuffice, but for ≈øuch as dwell whereas they may have the coun≈øell of a learned Phy≈øitian, I do wi≈øh them to take his advice, e≈øpecially for purging and letting bloud, becau≈øe none can ≈øo exactly ≈øet down in writing the perfect cour≈øe thereof (which may be under≈øtood rightly of the common ≈øort) ≈øo well as he which hath the ≈øight of the body: for that many bodies are oftentimes troubled with ≈øome one humour abounding more then another, which here to treat of would be too tedious, neither can it profit the common people, for who≈øe ≈øakes I have taken this paines: and now will I ≈øhew the ≈øignes to know when one is
infected therewith, as al≈øo which are the laudable ≈øignes, and which are the contrary, and la≈øtly the meanes (by God his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) how for to cure the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Sheweth the ≈øignes of infection.
div.p: THe ≈øignes and tokens hereof are divers, as fir≈øt, it is perceived by the ≈øuddain weakne≈ø≈øe, loo≈øing and overthrowing of our naturall ≈øtrength, without any manife≈øt cau≈øe thereof going before, and ≈øometimes it doth begin with a gnawing and biting in the mouth of the ≈øtomack, the pul≈øe will grow weak, feeble, and unequall, with a great ≈øtreightne≈ø≈øe and heavine≈ø≈øe about the heart, as if ≈øome heavie burthen or weight were layd thereon, with ≈øhortne≈øs of breathing, vomiting, or at lea≈øt a great de≈øire to vomit, great pain in the head: in≈øatiable thir≈øt proceeding of their great interior heat: ≈øluggi≈øhnes, and univer≈øal faintne≈øs of all the body, with a great de≈øire to ≈øleep, and an a≈øtoni≈øhment of the mind and vitall ≈øpirits: and for the mo≈øt part they complain of a great paine which is felt in ≈øome one place or places of their bodies, where the botch or blain is by nature intended to be thru≈øt forth, yet ≈øome at the fir≈øt have them appearing: and for the mo≈øt part, they are taken at the fir≈øt with a ≈øharp and rigorous feaver.

div.head: Good ≈øignes.
div.p: When the botch or Carbunkle cometh out in the beginning of the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe with a red colour, and yellowi≈øh round about it, and that it doth quickly come to maturation, the feaver to cea≈øe, and the party findeth him≈øelf ea≈øed of his grief, and quickned in his ≈øpirits, the≈øe are good and laudable ≈øignes of recovery.

div.head: Evill ≈øignes.
div.p:
When the botch at the fir≈øt commeth out blacki≈øh, or black in colour, al≈øo when the botch is opened, the fle≈øh within doth look blew, and that then there appear not any matter or quitture
in the wound, but as it were a ≈øpume or froth i≈ø≈øuing out thereof, are ill and deadly ≈øignes,

When the botch waxeth ≈øo hard that by no means it will come to ≈øuppuration, but re≈øi≈øteth what≈øoever is done unto it for the furthering thereof, and ≈øo returneth in againe into the inward parts ≈øuddenly, is a token of ≈øudden death at hand, and ≈øo it is if either before or after it is broken it look of a blewi≈øh colour, or of divers colours, like the Rainbow, round about it.

When the Carbunckle or Blain doth ≈øuddenly dry up, as if it were ≈øcorcht with the fire, and that the place round about it doth ≈øhew to be of a wanni≈øh blew colour, is a deadly ≈øign: if in the skin appear green or black ≈øpots, the excrements of divers colours with worms in it either dead or living, having a vile ≈øtinking ≈øavour, and ≈øpitteth ≈øtinking and bloudy matter, doth betoken death.

When the ≈øick complaines of great and extream heat in the inward parts, and yet cold outwardly, the eyes ≈øtaring or weeping the face terrible, the ≈øaid excrements or urin pa≈ø≈øing away, and the party not knowing thereof, are evill ≈øignes.

When in the fourth or ≈øeventh day they are taken with a fren≈øie, or do fall into an extream bleeding at no≈øe, or have a great flux with a continuall vomiting, or a de≈øire to vomit and do it not, extream pain at the heart, watchfullne≈øs, and the ≈øtrength clean gone, are deadly ≈øignes. When the party being very ≈øick, yet ≈øaith he feeleth him≈øelf well, his eyes ≈øunk deep in his head, and full of tears, when he thinks all things do ≈øtink, his nailes looking blew, the no≈øe ≈øharp, and as it were crooked, the breath thick and ≈øhort with a cold ≈øweat in the bre≈øt and face, and turning and playing with the clothes, the pul≈øe creeping or ≈øcarcely to be felt, and greivous unto him to ≈øpeak, the≈øe are infallible ≈øignes of death at hand. Some, before any of the≈øe ≈øignes are perceived, do dy, and ≈øome likewi≈øe which have divers of them appearing, and yet do e≈øcape, ≈øuch is the uncertainty of this di≈øea≈øe: there are many other ≈øymptoms which do happen in this contagious di≈øea≈øe, which would be too tedious to declare, but the≈øe as the chiefe≈øt may ≈øuffice.

div.head: The Second Treati≈øe, ≈øhewing the meanes how to cure the Plague.
CHAP. I.
div.p: VVHen we perceive any to be infected with this contagious di≈øea≈øe, we mu≈øt with all po≈ø≈øible ≈øpeed ≈øeek all the meanes we can how to prevent the malignity thereof, who≈øe property is at the fir≈øt to a≈ø≈øault the principall part, which is the heart, and therefore requires pre≈øent help; for unle≈ø≈øe ≈øomething be done within eight or four and twenty houres, little will it then prevail to attempt it, for by that time nature is either ≈øubdued, and clean overthrown, or el≈øe hath thru≈øt the ≈øame to the exterior parts, or otherwi≈øe dige≈øted it: yet may we not neglect at any time, to u≈øe all the meanes we can, in helping and furthering of nature to the uttermo≈øt of our indeavour, becau≈øe we doe oftentimes ≈øee nature ≈øo wearied, and weakened in expelling of this venemous matter, that unle≈ø≈øe ≈øome help be added to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and comfort her, the party, for lack thereof, dyeth, which otherwi≈øe might be ≈øaved: For I have oftentimes ≈øeen by diligent helping of nature, that to be effected and brought to good pa≈ø≈øe, which I have judged mo≈øt de≈øperate. There are foure intentions required for the curing thereof; that is, by bloud-letting, Cordials, ≈øweat and purging: but the manner how to execute the ≈øame, hath bred great contention both among≈øt the old and later Writers, which here to treat of were too tedious, for unto the learned it were needle≈ø≈øe, and for the commonalty little would it availe them, therefore in breif will I ≈øhew you what I have ob≈øerved touching the cure.

Fir≈øt, if it be in a Plethorick, ≈øanguine, and ≈øtrong body, and hath pain in the head, great heat at the heart, thir≈øtne≈ø≈øe, the pul≈øe ≈øtrong, and labouring, or beating ≈øtrongly, and hath great and large veines appearing; the≈øe ought pre≈øently to be let bloud in that ≈øide where yee perceive the greif doth proffer
it ≈øelfe to come forth, and not vi≈øibly appearing, tending to maturation: For then we may not draw bloud, but u≈øe all other meanes we can devi≈øe, in helping nature to expell it, neither may you draw bloud, if the party have a flix or lask (which is an evill ≈øign) in the beginning of the di≈øea≈øe, for by that meanes you ≈øhall hinder nature greatly, but onely give the party Cordials; neither may you ≈øtop the flix in the beginning, but if it be extream, and that it ≈øtay not the ≈øecond day, then mu≈øt you give ≈øome purgation, which may leave an a≈øtringency behind it, as hereafter in the cure of the flix ≈øhall be ≈øhewed. For as Hyppocrates, in his fir≈øt book and one and twentieth Aphori≈øme, doth admoni≈øh us, we mu≈øt con≈øider and mark, how nature doth incline her ≈øelf, for that will teach us what we are to doe.

Now if you perceive the botch or carbunkle to appear underneath the chin about the throat, then pre≈øently draw bloud in both veines under the tongue, and immediately after that apply a cupping gla≈ø≈øe; with ≈øcarification in one ≈øide of the neck next unto the fore, thereby to draw it from the throat, for fear lea≈øt ≈øuddenly it choke him up, and then apply Chickens rumps, or Hens rumps to the botch, the feathers being fir≈øt pluckt away from the rump, and a grain of Salt put into the tewell, and ≈øo hold the bare place to the greif untill the Chicken die, which will be within half an hour, and then apply another, and ≈øo continue in changing them ≈øo long as they doe die, and la≈øtly apply a mollificative Catapla≈øme or plai≈øter to the ≈øame place, as in the fift Chapter following is ≈øhewed, which is made with ∆≤nguentum ba≈øillicon, and to the botch apply the Epithemation and Catapla≈øme in the ≈øeventh Chapter following. But if it be in the neck, he doth complain, then let him bloud in the Cephallica vein in the arm, of the ≈øame ≈øide where he complaineth.

If in the groin or flanke he doth complain, then let him bloud in the foot on the ≈øame ≈øide, and open the vein called Maleola, or Saphena, the quantity mu≈øt be according as the age and ≈øtrength of the party requireth, but at mo≈øt draw not above ≈øix or eight ounces: For Avicen willeth us, to pre≈øerve bloud as the trea≈øure of nature.
But in a weak, ≈øpare, and cachochimious body (as Galen teacheth us) we may not draw bloud at all, for thereby ≈øhould you greatly indanger the Patient, but help ≈øuch by Cordials and ≈øweat.

And here you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that unle≈ø≈øe Phlebotomy be done at the fir≈øt, that is, within ≈øix or eight houres at mo≈øt, it will be too late to attempt it, neither may you doe it if the ≈øore doe appear up in height tending to ≈øuppuration, for then ≈øhould you hinder nature, which like a diligent workman, hath di≈øcharged and thru≈øt forth that venomous matter, which otherwi≈øe would have killed us.

And here touching Phlebotomy or bloud-letting, you mu≈øt have this ≈øpeciall care, that you draw not bloud on the oppo≈øite ≈øide, as if it be on the left ≈øide the ≈øore appear, then draw not bloud on the right ≈øide; if it appear in the flanke, then draw not bloud in the arme, but in the foot, for otherwi≈øe you ≈øhall draw that venomous matter from the ignoble unto the noble parts, and ≈øo kill the body.

And although the party complain not more in the one ≈øide then the other, yet by the pul≈øe ≈øhall you perceive on which ≈øide the venome lieth hidden, for on that ≈øide where nature is oppre≈øt, there ≈øhall you find the pul≈øe more weak, feeble, and uneven, greatly differing from the other ≈øide.

And here you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that in ≈øome it hath been ≈øeen, that nature of it ≈øelf at the fir≈øt, hath thru≈øt out that venomous matter in ≈øome place of the body, with a botch appearing high, and tending to ≈øuppuration, or a carbunckle, or ≈øpots called purples. Now here if you draw bloud, you doe then greatly indanger the body; but in this ca≈øe you mu≈øt onely give Cordials, and u≈øe all the meanes you can to bring it outward, either by maturation, or evaporation, as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed you.

And here you ≈øhall further under≈øtand, that where the age, con≈øtitution, nor ≈øtrength of the party will permit that Phlebotomy be done, yet for the better help of nature you mu≈øt apply Vento≈øes, with rea≈øonable deep ≈øcarification, unto the next place adjoyning, where the party complaineth, thereby the more ≈øpeedily to draw the venomous matter unto the ≈øuperficiall
parts, and there to apply the rumps of Chickens, as before is taught you, and ≈øo apply to the place ≈øome ≈øtrong maturative, and atrractive plai≈øter, or Catapla≈øme, as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed you. If the greif be in the head or throte, then apply Vento≈øes to the neck: If it be in the emunctuaries of the heart, then apply them to the ≈øhoulders: If in the emunctuaries of the liver, then apply them to the buttocks or thighs, now when this is done, either by Phlebetomy, or Vento≈øes, then within an hour or two at the mo≈øt after it, you mu≈øt give the ≈øick ≈øome good Cordiall Medicine, which hath power to comfort the heart, re≈øi≈øt the venomous matter, and al≈øo procure ≈øweat, whereof out of the following you may make choice as you li≈øt.

div.head: An excellent good Powder to expell the Plague, which al≈øo provoketh ≈øweat.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Roots of Gentian, Bittanie, Peta≈øitis, ana, í. i. Roots of Tormentill, Dittander, ana, í iii. Red Sanders í. ≈øs. Fine Pearle of both ≈øorts, ana, ‚Ñà. i. Fine Bolarmoniack prepared, fine Terra ≈øigillata, ana, í. vi. Rindes of Citrons, red Corrall, Roots of Zedoiar, ≈øhaving of Ebony, bone of a Stags heart, ana, ≈øixteen graines: Fragments of the five pretious ≈øtones, ana, ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Shaving of a Unicorns horn, Succini, ana, ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Leaves of Gold and Silver, ana, one and half in number,

Make all the≈øe in fine powder, every one ≈øeverall by him≈øelf, and then mix them all together, and give thereof í. i. or ‚Ñà. iiii. more or le≈ø≈øe as occa≈øion requireth, either in Sorrell, Scabios, or Carduus benedictus water two or three ounces, whereunto you mu≈øt adde a little Sirrup of Lemons, or ≈øour Citrons, and give it warm, the Bolarmoniack mu≈øt be pounded ≈ømall, then wa≈øhed in Scabios water, and ≈øo dryed.

div.head: Another good Powder.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Leaves of Dittander, called Dictami cretici, Roots of Tormentil, Bittanie, Pimpernell, Gentian, Zedoiar, ana, í. i. Terra lemnia, Alloes Cicatrina, fine Myrrh, Rinds of ≈øour Citrons,
ana. í i. Ma≈øtick, Saffron, ana, half a drachm. Bolarmoniack prepared as before≈øaid, í ii.
All the≈øe mu≈øt be made in fine pouder, and ≈øo mixt together, you may give two ≈øcruples, or one drachm thereof with any of the afore≈øaid waters.

div.head: A good Opiat to expell venome, and provoke ≈øweat.
div.p: Con≈øerve of the floures of Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Violets, Bittanie, ana, ‚Ñ•. ii. Venus Triacle ‚Ñ•. ii. Red Terra ≈øigillata, Terra lemnia, Mithridate, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Shaving of Ebonie, And Harts-horn, Orient Pearls, Roots of Tormentill, ana í i. Shaving of Unicorns horn, Root of Angelica, ana half a drachm. Sirrup of the Juice of ≈ømall Sorrell and Buglo≈øs, ana, ≈øo much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice.
Mix all the≈øe together in the form of an Opiat, then take of the ≈øame Opiat, one drachm and half. Scabios water, Balm water, ana ‚Ñ• ii.
Di≈ø≈øolve the Opiat in the waters, and drink it warm, then walk a little upon it, and then goe to bed and ≈øweat.

div.head: Another excellent good means to expell the venom, and procure ≈øweat.
div.p: Take a great white Onyon, and pick out the coar or middle of him, then fill the hole with good Venus Triacle, or Andromachus Triacle, and Aqua vitae, then ≈øtop or cover the hole of the Onyon again, and ro≈øt him in the hot a≈øhes untill he be ≈øoft, then ≈øtrein it ≈øtrongly through a cloth, and give it the ≈øick to drinke, and the re≈øt that remains, pound it ≈ømall, and apply it to the ≈øore, and ≈øweat upon it.

Now when he hath taken any of the afore≈øaid Cordials, if he chance to vomit it up again, then wa≈øh his mouth with Ro≈øewater and Vinegar, and then give him more of the ≈øame again, which mu≈øt be proportioned according to the quantitie vomited, for if all were vomited, then give ≈øo much more: (if le≈ø≈øe) then according to the quantity vomited, and if he vomit that al≈øo, then give him more, and ≈øo continue it
