to the third or fourth time, if cau≈øe ≈øo require, but if at no time he doe retain it, then is there ≈ømall hope of recovery; I have known divers, which have vomited their Cordials three or four times, and at la≈øt, giving the juyce of the Onyon as afore≈øaid, hath kept that, and ≈øweat upon it, and ≈øo recover their health.

Al≈øo Minardus Triacle, or Andromachus Triacle being taken two Scruples with one Scruple of Dio≈øcordium, and di≈ø≈øolved in two or three ounces of this water following, or Carduus benedictus, Sorrell, and Scabios water, hath been found excellent good and available, both to procure ≈øweat, and expell the venomous matter.

div.head: An excellent good water again≈øt the Plague, and divers other di≈øea≈øes, which is to be made in May or June.
div.p: Take Angelica, Dragons, Scabios, ana three handfuls. Wormwood, Sage, Salendine, Mugwort, Rue, Ro≈øemary, Varvein, Endive, Mints, ana one handfull. Tormentill, Pimpernell, Agrimonie, Bittanie, ana two handfulls. St. Johns wort, Fetherfew, and Pionie, ana a little handfull.

You mu≈øt mix all the≈øe hearbs together, then brui≈øe them in a ≈øtone morter gro≈øly, then put them into a clean ve≈ø≈øell of gla≈ø≈øe or earth, and add thereto a pottle of White wine, or three quarts, a pint of Ro≈øe-water, and a pint of Vinegar: then mixe them well together, and pre≈ø≈øe down the Hearbs clo≈øe together with your hands, then ≈øtop the pot clo≈øe, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand to infu≈øe two dayes and two nights, then di≈øtill it in a ≈øtillatorie, this water hath been found excellent good, both to pre≈øerve one from the Plague, being drunk three or four ≈øpoonfuls of it in the morning fa≈øting, as al≈øo to expell the di≈øea≈øe, being drunk with any of the Cordials afore≈øaid.

div.head: CHAP. II. Sheweth what is to be done after taking of the Cordiall.
div.p:
NOw ≈øo ≈øoon as the partie hath taken his Cordiall, (if he be able) cau≈øe him to walke upon it in his chamber a
prettie while, then lay him into his naked bed, being fir≈øt warmed if it be in cold weather, and ≈øo procure him to ≈øweat, but in any ca≈øe have a ≈øpeciall care to keep him from ≈øleep all that day, becau≈øe thereby the bloud and vitall ≈øpirits are drawn to the inward parts, and there doth hold in the venomous matter about the heart; but if the ≈øore appear, or be perceived to pre≈øent it ≈øelf in any place neer the heart, then to defend the malignity thereof before he ≈øweat, it were good to annoint the place betwixt the region of the heart and the ≈øore with Triacle, or with this Unguent following.

div.head: A good defen≈øative ∆≤nguent.
div.p: Take Triacle, ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. Terra i lemnia, Red ≈øanders, ana í. i. Mix them together with a little Ro≈øe-water and Vinegar in a morter, to the form of an Unguent, and ≈øo u≈øe it as afore≈øaid.

And unto the ≈øore place apyly chickens rumps, as before hath been told you, and then annoint the place grieved with Oyle of Lillies; and then Epithemate the heart with any one of the≈øe Epithemations following.

div.head: Epithemation.
div.p: Take the Powder of Diamargaritum frigidum, ‚Ñà i. Tria≈øandalum, í. vi. Ebeni, í ii. Saffron, ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Lettice ≈øeed, í i. Waters of Ro≈øes, Buglo≈øs, and Sorrel, ana ‚Ñ• vi. Vinegar ‚Ñ•. ii. boil them altogether a little.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the waters of Ro≈øes, Balm, Buglo≈øs, Carduus benedictus and white wine, ana ‚Ñ• iiii. Vinegar of Ro≈øes ‚Ñ• ii. Powder of red Ro≈øes, Cinnamon, Tria≈øandalam, Diamargaritum, Frigidum, ana í ≈øs. Mithridatum, ‚Ñ• i. Triacle, ‚Ñ• ≈øs. Boil them together a little, and being bloud warm, Epithemate the heart therewith, which being done, then procure him to ≈øweat, and after ≈øweat, and the body dryed, then apply this quickly to the heart.

div.head: A Quilt for the Heart.
div.p: Take the floures of Nenuphare, Burrage, Buglo≈øs, ana, a little handfull: Floures of Balm, Ro≈øemary, ana í iii. Red ≈øanders, Red corall, Lignum aloes, Rinde of a citron, ana, í i. Seeds of Ba≈øil, Citrons, ana í i. Leaves of Dittander, Berries of Juniper, ana ‚Ñà i. Bone of a Stags heart, half a ≈øcruple Saffron, four grains.

Mixe all the≈øe in gro≈ø≈øe powder, and put them in a bag of crim≈øon Taffetie, or Lincloth, and lay it to the heart, and there let it remain. All the≈øe things being done, then procure him to ≈øweat, having a good fire in the chamber, and windowes clo≈øe ≈øhut, and ≈øo let him ≈øweat three or four houres more or le≈ø≈øe, or according as the ≈øtrength of the ≈øick body can endure, and then dry the body well with warm clothes, taking great care that the ≈øick catch not cold in the doing thereof, and then give him ≈øome of this Julep following, and apply the afore≈øaid quilt or bag to the heart.

div.head: A cordiall Julep.
div.p: Take Waters of Endive, Pur≈ølane, and Ro≈øes, ana, ‚Ñ•. ii, Sorrell water, half a pint, Juyce of Pomgranats, and for lack thereof Vinegar, ‚Ñ• iiii. Camphire í iii, Sugar, one pound. Boil all the≈øe together in the form of a Julep, and give three or four ≈øpoonfuls thereof at a time.

div.head: Another Julep.
div.p: Take Sirrup of Ribes, Sorrell, Nenuphare, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Juice of Limons, ‚Ñ• i. Sorrell water, ‚Ñ• viii. Mix all the≈øe together, and take two or three ≈øpoonfulls thereof oftentimes, which will both comfort the heart, and quench thir≈øt.

And if in the time of his ≈øweat he be very thir≈øtie, then may you give him to drink a Ty≈øane made with water, clean Barly, and Licorice ≈øcrapt clean and brui≈øed, boil them together, then ≈øtrein it, and unto a quart of the liquor add three ounces of Sirrup of Limons, and give thereof at any time; ≈ømall
beer or ale is al≈øo tolerable, or you may give a ≈øpoonfull of this Julep following at any time.

div.head: A Julep to quench thir≈øt.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Sorrell-water, four ounces, Burrage-water, Scabios water, of either one ounce, Sirrup of Lemons and ≈øowre Citrons, of either one ounce.

Mix all the≈øe together and ≈øo u≈øe it as occa≈øion requireth at any time: and give oftentimes a cake of Manus Chri≈øti, made with Perls for him to eat. But if in the time of his ≈øweat you ≈øee the ≈øick to faint or ≈øwoun, then apply to his temples, and the region of the heart, this mixture following.

‚Ñû. Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Broom floures, of either one ounce: Mithridate, four ounces, Triacle, one ounce, Floures of Violets, Pellamountaine, Red Ro≈øes, of either one drachme, Roots of Ireos, one drachm, Musk, Sivet, of either eight graines.

Mix all the≈øe together with a quantity of Ro≈øe-Vinegar in the form of an Opiat, this mu≈øt be ≈øpread on Plai≈øters, and applied to the heart and temples, and to the ≈øoales of the feet apply this plai≈øter following.

Take of the afore≈øaid Opiat, ‚Ñ• ii. unto the which you mu≈øt put ≈øo much more of an Onyon, which mu≈øt have the middle part thereof taken out, and the hole filled with Mithridate, and Aquavitae, and ≈øo ro≈øted in the a≈øhes, and then mix it with the Opiat, and apply it to both ≈øoales of the feet.

Now when all this is done, and that one hour is pa≈øt after his ≈øweat and body dried as afore≈øaid: it were good you did give the ≈øick ≈øome good comfortable broth, although he vomit it up againe, then let him re≈øt two houres and then offer him more, which you mu≈øt do oftentimes, and but little at a time.

And if after all this done he continue ≈øtill weak and faint without any amendment, then give him another Cordiall, as ye did at the fir≈øt, and ≈øo cau≈øe him to ≈øweat again ≈øo long as his ≈øtrength can well endure it, and after ≈øweat give more of the Julep afore≈øaid, for by this meanes you ≈øhall oftentimes ≈øee
the ≈øore, which did offer it ≈øelf to come forth, will be clean di≈øcu≈ø≈øed and con≈øumed away: but if it do not by this means go away, then u≈øe all the means you can to bring it to ≈øuppuration, and then open it with ≈øome cau≈øtick or inci≈øion, as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed you at large.

The next day after his ≈øweat, you may tollerate him to ≈øleep one hour or two in the forenoon, whereby to prevent pain or lightne≈ø≈øe of the head, which may chance through want thereof: and if after his ≈øleep the party be ≈øick and faint, then immediately give him ≈øome good Cordiall, according as the ≈øtate of his body requireth, either in temperate or extream heat, as before is ≈øhewed: and in one hour after that give him ≈øome comfortable broth made with Veale, Mutton, Chicken, or ≈øuch like, wherein ≈øome Burrage, Buglo≈øs, Pimpernell, and a little Hy≈øop, with ≈øome Par≈øley roots, the inner pith being taken out, mu≈øt be boiled, whereof he mu≈øt take a little at a time, three or four times a day, and betwixt times in taking of his broth, give him three or four ≈øpoonfulls of this Julep following, which doth re≈øi≈øt veneno≈øity from the heart, and al≈øo quench thir≈øt.

div.head: A Julep to quench thir≈øt and re≈øi≈øt Veneno≈øity.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Water of Scabios, Burrage, Sorrell, ana ‚Ñ•. ii. Sirrup of Lemons, ≈øowre Citrons, and the juice of Sorrell, of either one ounce.
Mix all the≈øe together, and give thereof as cau≈øe requireth.

Then at night he may ≈øleep three or four houres more, and the next day, being the third or fourth day of his accubet, you may purge him with one of the purgations here following, but in any ca≈øe you mu≈øt take heed that you do not purge with any ≈øtrong or Scammoniate medicine, becau≈øe it may cau≈øe an extream flux, which will be mo≈øt dangerous, becau≈øe it will overmuch weaken the body, and hinder concoction, for mo≈øt commonly in this di≈øea≈øe the body of it ≈øelf is ≈øubject to fluxes.

div.head: A good Purgation in a ≈øtrong body.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Rad. Cichoriae, í. iiii. Rad. Peta≈øitis, í. ≈øs. Fol. Scabio≈øae, Card. Benedictus Pimpinellae, Aceto≈øae, ana M. i. Florum Cord. P. i. Prunorum damma≈ø no. x. Sem. Coriandri, í. ≈øs. Aquae font. ‚Ñ•. ix.
Boyle them untill a third part be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it.
‚Ñû. Decoct. col. ‚Ñ•. iiii. Fol. Sennae, í. iii. Rhab. elect. í. iiii. Spicae. G. iii.
Infu≈øe them together twelve hours, then ≈øtrain it ≈øtrongly, and add thereto the≈øe things.
Sir. de Cichoriae, cum Rhab. í vi. Oxi≈øacchari, Simp. í. ii.
Mix them altogether, and drink it in the morning refraining from meat, drink, and ≈øleep three houres after, and then eat ≈øome good broth.

div.head: Another in a plethorick and full body.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Fol. Scabio≈øae, Buglo≈ø≈øae, Card. B. ana M. i. Florum Cord. P. i. Rad. Tormentillae. í. iii. Rad. Fenic. licho. ana í. iiii. Pa≈ø≈øularum enucleat, ‚Ñ•. i. Prunorum damma≈ø. no. vi. Sem ani≈ø. Coriandri, Oxialidis, ana ‚Ñà. i. Sennae, Polipod. q. ana ‚Ñ•. i.
Boyle all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of water untill half the water be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and keep it.
‚Ñû. Rhab. elect. í. ii. Agarici, tro≈ø. í. i. Croci. ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Aquarum ≈øcabio≈øae, Borraginis, Card. B. ana í. iiii.
Infu≈øe the≈øe together twelve hours in a warm place, then ≈øtrain them ≈øtrongly, and add thereto Sir. ro≈ø. lax. Mannae. Calabriae ana ‚Ñ•. i. Decoct. col. ‚Ñ•. ii. vel ‚Ñ•. iii.
Mix all the≈øe together, and take it as the other before.

div.head: A good purgation for a weak body.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Fol. ≈øennae, í. iii. Rhab. elect, í. i. Sem. ani≈ø. í ≈øs. Schenanthi, ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Aquae Aceto≈øae, ‚Ñ•. v.

Boyle them a little, then take it from the fire, and let them ≈øtand infu≈øed together twelve houres, then ≈øtrain it out ≈øtrongly
and add thereto Sir. ro≈ø. lax. ‚Ñ•. i. and then drink it as the other before.

div.head: Another gentle purgation.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Aquarum ≈øcabio≈øae, Card. B. Aquae ad pe≈øtem, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Rhab elect, í. ii. ≈øs. Cinamomi, í. ≈øs.
Infu≈øe them together twelve hours, and ≈øtrain them ≈øtrongly; then add to the ≈øtraining Sir. ro≈ø. lax. ‚Ñ•. i. Sir. de limonibus, four ounces.
Mix them together, and ≈øo drink it as the other before, you may either add or dimini≈øh of the Rubarb unto any of the≈øe potions as you li≈øt.
Now when you ≈øee the purgation hath done working, then give the ≈øick ≈øome Cordiall thing, as hereafter followeth, which he mu≈øt al≈øo take the next morning following.

div.head: A good Cordiall to be taken after Purging.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Con≈øerva Burrag, Buglo≈øs, Mali Citri, ana í. iiii. Confect. Alkermis. í. i. Boli Veri, í. ≈øs. Specierum diarhod abb. ‚Ñà. ii. Diamarga. frigid. í. i. Manus Chri≈øti perlati, ‚Ñ•. i. Sir. de Lemon, í. iiii.
Mix all the≈øe together, and give the ≈øick thereof ≈øo much as a che≈øtnut at a time, you mu≈øt oftentimes eat thereof if the ≈øick be in no great heat.

div.head: Another good Cordiall to be given where great heat is.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Con≈øervae Borag, í. iiii. Con≈øervae fol. aceto≈øae, ‚Ñ• i. Bolarm. veri. í. i. Manus Chri≈øti cum perlis, ‚Ñ•. i. Sir. de Lemonibus. q. v. mi≈øce.
You mu≈øt oftentimes give of this where great heat is, ≈øo much as three beanes at a time.

div.head: A good Cordiall potion.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Aquarum buglo≈ø≈øae, Aceto≈øae, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Pul. diamarga. frig.
í. ≈øs. Confectio alkermis, G. ii. Sir. de aceto, Citri, vel de Lemon. ‚Ñ•. i. mi≈øce.
All this you may take after purging as afore≈øaid, at any time.
And here you mu≈øt under≈øtand, that if it be in a plethorick body full of ill humors, it were good that you purge him again the next day.

div.head: CHAP. III. Sheweth what ≈øymptoms often chance, and how to help them.
div.p: FOr that in this contagious di≈øea≈øe there are divers dangerous ≈øymptoms which do oftentimes chance, I will here ≈øhew you good meanes how to help the ≈øame.

div.head: For lightne≈ø≈øe of the head through want of ≈øleep.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Hordei mundi. P. i. Amigd. dul. depilatum ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øs. Sem. iiii. Frigid. ma. mund. ana ‚Ñà. i. Aqua font. q. 5. fiat decoctio. Decoct. col. l. i. Sir. de Lemonibus, de Papa, ana ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øs. Sacchari perlati, ‚Ñ•. i.
Boyl them together a little, and then keep it to your u≈øe, you mu≈øt often times give two or three ≈øpoonfulls thereof to drink, and anniont his temples with this ointment.

div.head: Oyntment to provoke ≈øleep.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Vnguent popillionis, í. iiii. ∆≤nguent. Alaba≈øtrini, Ol. Nenuphariae mi≈øce, ana. í ii.
This oyntment is not onely good to provoke ≈øleep but will al≈øo ea≈øe the pain of the head, if the place grieved be annointed therewith.

div.head: For raveing and raging.
div.p: If the party rave, then give him one ≈øcruple of the powder of Harts-horn burnt, with half an ounce of the ≈øirrup of Violets and Lemons, and apply this ≈øacculus following to the head.

div.head: A good Sacculus for raving and raging.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Florum Nenupharis, P. i. Cort. Pap. í. ii. Santali albi, Rub. Citri, ana. í. i. Florum ro≈ø. rub, P. i. Florum Viol. P. ≈øs. Florum camomil. Betonicae, ana í. i.
Shread them all ≈ømall, then pound them gro≈øly, and quilt them in a bagg, and apply it to the head, and it will help you.

div.head: Aphtham, to help it.
div.p: In this contagious di≈øea≈øe, there doth chance an ulceration of the mouth, which is called Aphtham, it cometh by means of the great interior heat which the ≈øick is oppre≈ø≈øed with in the time of his ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, which if it be not well looked unto in time, it will greatly endanger the body, for Remedy whereof u≈øe this Gargari≈øm.

div.head: A good Gargari≈øm for the mouth.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Clean barley, one handfull, wilde Day≈øie leaves, Plantaine leaves, Strawberry leaves, Violet leaves, of either one handfull: Pur≈ølane ≈øeed, one ≈øcruple, Quin≈øe ≈øeed, one ≈øcruple and half. Licorice brui≈øed, four drachms.

Boyle all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of water untill the water be half con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and take one pint and half thereof, and add thereto Sirrup of Ro≈øes by infu≈øion, and ≈øirrup of dried ro≈øes of either four drachms: Diamoron two ounces.
Mix the≈øe together, and gargarize and wa≈øh the mouth therewith oftentimes being warm, and it helpeth.

div.head: Vomiting extreamly, how to help it.
div.p:
If it come in the beginning of the di≈øea≈øe, as mo≈øt commonly it doth, there is no better means to ≈øtay it, then by giving of Cordials and by ≈øweating, by which meanes that venomous
matter which is the cau≈øe thereof is expelled, and breathed out, but if after Cordials given, and ≈øweat, it doth not ≈øtay, it is a very ill and dangerous ≈øigne: yet what means I have u≈øed to ≈øtay the ≈øame, I will here ≈øhew you.

div.head: A good bag for the ≈øtomack.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Dried leaves of Mints, Elder, Origanie, Wormwood, Calamint, Mugwort, Thime, Balme, Pellemountaine, tops of Dill, of either a little handfull: Seeds of Carduus Benedictus, Fennell, Annis, of either four drachms: Roots of Ciperus, Calamus aromaticus, of either four drachms: Nutmegs, Cloves, Mace, of either half a drachm.

Make all the≈øe in gro≈øs powder, then put it into a linnen bag, which mu≈øt be made ≈øo broad and long, as will cover the ≈øtomack: then take Ro≈øe-water and ≈øtrong Vinegar, of either ten ≈øpoonfulls, wherein do you di≈ø≈øolve one ounce of Mithridate, then mu≈øt you fir≈øt wet the ≈øaid bag in two parts of clean water and a third part of White or Claret-wine, and let him ≈øoak therein a little while, the liquor being fir≈øt warmed on a Chafer and coales, and then wet him in the Ro≈øe-water and and Vinegar being warm, and ≈øo apply it to the ≈øtomack, and when he waxeth cold, warm him therein againe, and let him remain half an hour in all, and then take him away, and dry the ≈øtomack with a warm cloth, and then annoint it with this ointment following.
‚Ñû. Chymicall oyles of Ro≈øemary, Sage, of either one drachm: Vinegar, Mithridate, of either one drachm.

Mix all the≈øe together, and ≈øo u≈øe it, and if the party be co≈øtive, then were it good to give him a gli≈øter, wherein di≈ø≈øolve two drachms of Mithridate, it is al≈øo good to apply Vento≈øes unto the buttocks and thighes.

div.head: Yoxe, or yexing, to ≈øtay it.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Dill ≈øeed, two ≈øcruples and half: White Poppy ≈øeed, Pur≈ølane ≈øeed, of either one ≈øcruple and a half.

Brui≈øe them a little, then knit them in a fine linnen cloth, and
let it ≈øoak in the drink which he u≈øeth, and when you give him drink, wring out the bag therein, and let him drink it, and that will ≈øtay it, al≈øo the order afore≈øaid to help vomiting, is good to ≈øtay the yoxe, or yexing, but if neither of them prevaile, then will the ≈øick hardly e≈øcape death.

div.head: Flix, how to ≈øtop it.
div.p: You mu≈øt fir≈øt give the patient this purpation following, which doth not onely purge away tho≈øe ≈ølim ‚Ä¢ e humors which is the cau≈øe thereof, but doth al≈øo leave an a≈øtringencie behind it.
‚Ñû. Rhab. elect. í. iii. Cinamoni, ‚Ñà. ii. Aquarum Endiviae, Borraginis, ana ‚Ñ•. ii.

Infu≈øe them together twelve houres, then ≈øtrain it out ≈øtrongly, and add thereto one ounce of Sirrup of ro≈øes laxative, and ≈øo drink it warm, refraining from meat, and drink, and ≈øleep three houres after it: and at night when it hath done working, give this confection following.
‚Ñû. Con≈øervae ro≈ø. í. iiii. Dio≈øcordii, ‚Ñà. i. ≈øs. Pul. Diatragag. frigid. ‚Ñà. i, Dialkermes, G. x. Sir. de Lemon. í. ii. mi≈øce.
When you have given this confection, then doe you Epithemate the region of the heart with this Epithemative following,

div.head: Epithemation for the heart.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Aquarum Buglo≈ø≈øae, Burrag, Ro≈øarum, Oxialidis, ana ‚Ñ•. iiii. Throchi≈øcorum de camphera, ‚Ñà. i. Pul. diamargarit. frigid. í. i. Aceti alb. ‚Ñ•. i. Offa de corde cervi, ‚Ñà. ≈øs. Santal. Rub. Coral. Rub. mi≈øce. ana ‚Ñà. i.

With this you mu≈øt Epithemate the Region of the heart warm a quarter of an hour, and if by this meanes it ≈øtay not, then the next day give ≈øome of this confection following, which I have found excellent good for the ≈øtopping of any flix what≈øoever.
‚Ñû. Con≈øervae ro≈ø. ≈øiccae. ‚Ñ•. i. Pul. Rhab. tro≈øchi≈øcat ‚Ñà. i. T√©rrae lemniae í. ≈øs. Lap. Hemattitis, Sang. Draco. Bolarmoni. ana í. ii. Mithridatii, mi≈øce, í. i.
You mu≈øt every morning and evening give two drachm hereof, and drink ≈øome Plantaine water after it.

Now here you mu≈øt under≈øtand, that if the flix come in the beginning of the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and that no botch, Carbunkle, nor ≈øpots appear in the body, then in any ca≈øe you may not goe about to ≈øtop it, but ≈øuffer nature to di≈øcharge it ≈øelfe, and onely help nature with Cordials, and Epithemations applyed to the heart, but if by the continuance thereof, the Patient grow very weak and faint therewith, then is it to be repre≈ø≈øed, as before is ≈øhewed, but it mu≈øt be the third day before you attempt to doe it.

But if this flix come when the botch or Carbunkle doth appear, and tending to maturation, then is it very dangerous, for by that meanes the venomous matter is drawn back again into the principall parts, and ≈øo killeth the Patient.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. Sheweth the generall cure of a botch when he appeares outwardly.
div.p: FIr≈øt, give Cordials, and u≈øe the defen≈øive before taught you in the ≈øecond Chapter, thereby to keep it from the heart, and then bring it to maturation as followeth.

div.head: A good Maturative.
div.p: Take a great Onyon and roa≈øt him in the a≈øhes, then pound him with ≈øome powder of white Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, and for lack thereof ≈øome Triacle, and pound them together, and ≈øo apply it to the greif warm, and renue it twice a day, which within three or four dayes at mo≈øt will bring it to ≈øuppuration.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take white Lilly roots, Enulacompane roots, Scabios, and Onyons, of either two ounces.

Roa≈øt all the≈øe together in a Cole leafe, or a wet paper, then pound them with ≈øome ≈øweet Butter, and a little Venice Triacle, whereunto doe you adde ≈øome Galbanum, and Ammoniacum
di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, and ≈øtrained from the fe≈ø≈øes and dregs, and ≈øo mix them altogether, and apply it, renewing it twice a day.

div.head: Another, where no inflammation is.
div.p: Take ∆≤nguentum ba≈øilicon ‚Ñ•. iiii. ≈øoure Leaven ‚Ñ•. ii. Oil of Lilies, ≈øweet Butter, ana. í. iiii. Triacle í. i. ≈øs. yolks of two Eggs.

Mix them together, and ≈øo apply it, and when it is come to ≈øuppuration, then open it in the lowe≈øt part, either with a potentiall Cau≈øtick, or by in≈øcition, but the Cau≈øtick is be≈øt, and when you have opened it, if no matter flow out, then apply the rumps of Chickens to the ≈øore, as before hath been ≈øhewed: after that put into the wound a dige≈øtive as followeth.

div.head: A Dige≈øtive,
div.p: Take the yolk of an Egge, clear Turpentine í. iiii. clarified Honey í. ii. Mithridate, or Triacle í. ≈øs.

Mix all the≈øe together, and u≈øe it in the wound untill it be well dige≈øted, which you may perceive by the great quantity of white and thick matter that will flow out of it, and upon the ≈øore lay this Catapla≈øme untill it be dige≈øted

div.head: A dige≈øtive Catapla≈øme.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Fat Figs, and Rai≈øins the ≈øtones pickt out, ana. ‚Ñ•. ii. Sal nitrum í. iv. ≈øour Leaven ‚Ñ•. iii. Honey ‚Ñ•. i. oil of Cammomill ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øs.
You mu≈øt ≈øhread and pound the Figs and Rai≈øins very ≈ømall, then commix it with the re≈øt in a morter, in form of a pultis, and u≈øe it.

And when it is dige≈øted, then you mu≈øt mundifie it with a mundificative, to which purpo≈øe ∆≤nguentum virid. or el≈øe Apo≈øtolorum mixt with ∆≤nguentum ba≈øilicon will ≈øerve, and when it is clean mundified, then to incarnate and heal it up, doe you onely annoint or ≈øtrike it over with a feather wet in Arceus linament, which mu≈øt be molten in a ≈øaucer, and over all lay a plai≈øter of Diaculum, or a plai≈øter of Kellebackeron, which is excellent
good in all Impo≈øthumes and tumours, and in this order doe you proceed, untill the greif be whole.

div.head: CHAP. V. Sheweth how to bring the botch out, that lieth deep within the body or fle≈øh.
div.p: FIr≈øt you mu≈øt con≈øider, that oftentimes the botch, or carbunkle doth offer it ≈øelfe to come forth in ≈øome place of the body, and yet no apparant ≈øign thereof, but lieth deep hidden within, becau≈øe nature is not of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to thru≈øt it forth; which is ea≈øily perceived by the great and almo≈øt intolerable pain, that by ≈øome is felt in the place where nature intends to expell it, which in the mo≈øt part of people, by bloud-letting, Cordials, and ≈øweat, is clean taken away and evacuated; but if after all this is done it goe not away, then unto the≈øe you mu≈øt u≈øe all the meanes you can to bring it to the outward parts. Fir≈øt, by giving to the ≈øick oftentimes ≈øome Cordiall Electuary to keep it from the heart, then (if no great pain be in the outward part) you mu≈øt apply a cupping-gla≈ø≈øe with ≈øcarification, directly again≈øt the place where the greif is felt, and let it remain thereon a quarter or halfe an hour, then take it away, and pre≈øently apply the rumps of Chickens, Hens, or Pigeons to the place (as before hath been ≈øhewed) that being done, then lay ≈øome attractive and maturative plai≈øter or Catapla≈øme to the place, which here following is ≈øhewed, and every ≈øixth hour you mu≈øt apply the cupping-gla≈øs, as al≈øo the re≈øt, untill ≈øuch time as you have brought the venomous matter to the outward parts, there to be vi≈øibly ≈øeen, or at lea≈øt, by feeling to be perceived, which commonly is effected at the ≈øecond time, then u≈øe no more cupping, but onely apply a maturative to the place.

div.head: A good Maturative Catapla≈øme.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Rad. ≈øimphyti, ma. Liliorum, Ceparum, Allium, ana, ‚Ñ•. i. Fol. Oxialidis M. i.

You mu≈øt pound all the≈øe together a little, then wrap them in a cole leafe, and ≈øo roa≈øt them in the hot embers, then pound them
in a morter, whereunto adde Ol. liliorum, Auxungiaepore. ana. ‚Ñ•. i. Fermenti acris í. vi. Mithridatii í. i.
Mix them altogether in form of a Pultus, and ≈øo apply it warm, and renue it twi≈øe a day.

div.head: Another
div.p: ‚Ñû. Galbani, Apopanacis, Ammoniaci, ana. í. iiii.

Di≈ø≈øolve the≈øe in Vinegar if the botch be hot and inflamed (but if it be not) then di≈ø≈øolve them in Aqua vitae, and being di≈ø≈øolved, then ≈øtrain it from the dregs, and adde thereto ∆≤nguent, ba≈øillici, Mithridat. Fomenti acris, ana, ‚Ñ•. iiii.
Mix all the≈øe together, and apply it.

div.head: Another which is ≈øooner made.
div.p: Take a great Onyon, make a hole in the middle of him, then fill the place with Mithridate or Triacle, and ≈øome leaves of Ru ‚Ä¢ , then roa≈øt him in the hot embers, and when it is ≈øoft, then pound it with ≈øome Barrowes greace, and apply it to the ≈øore, and that will ripen it in ≈øhort time, then open and cure it as in the Chapter before,

But if the pain and inflammation in the place be ≈øo great, that the party cannot indure cupping gla≈ø≈øes to be u≈øed, then mu≈øt you apply a Ve≈øicatory to the place, in the lowe≈øt part of the greife.

div.head: A Ve≈øicatory.
div.p: Take Cantharides brui≈øed in gro≈ø≈øe powder í. ≈øs. ≈øoure Leaven í. ii. mix them together in a morter with a little Vinegar, and apply it, which within twelve houres will rai≈øe a bli≈øter, which you mu≈øt open, and then lay an Ivie or Cole leafe to the place, and upon all apply any of the Catapla≈ømes afore≈øaid, and dre≈ø≈øe it twice a day, and once a day at lea≈øt, give the Patient ≈øome Cordiall, and when it is come to a ≈øoftne≈ø≈øe, and that you perceive it is impo≈øthumated, then open it, and ≈øo proceed to the cure, as before is ≈øhewed.

div.head: When the botch will not come to Maturation, but continueth alwayes hard.
div.p: Sometime it is ≈øeen that the botch, although it appear outwardly, yet will it not come to maturation, which commonly is accompli≈øhed within three or four dayes, but will re≈øi≈øt what≈øoever you apply to it, and remain and continue alwayes hard; now here you mu≈øt pre≈øently open it, either with a Cau≈øtick or by in≈øcition, for fear lea≈øt it ≈øtrike in again, or at lea≈øt grow to gangrena, but before you open it, you mu≈øt Epithemate the greif with this Epithemation following, and every morning and evening give the ≈øick ≈øome Cordiall, and betwixt the ≈øore and the heart annoint it with the defen≈øive before in the ≈øecond Chapter.

div.head: An Epithemation.
div.p: Take leaves of Mallowes, Violets, Cammomill, ana, M. i. Floures of Dill, Mellilot, ana. ‚Ñ•. i. Hollehock roots ‚Ñ•. iiii. Lin≈øeed ‚Ñ•. ii.

Boil all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of water untill halfe the water be con≈øumed, and then wet ≈øome Wooll or Flax therein, being fir≈øt well beaten and pickt clean, and lay it upon the ≈øore warm, and as it cooleth, doe you take it away, and lay on another warm ≈øtew≈øe, and ≈øo continue it half an hour together, and then open it as before≈øaid, and immediately apply to the wound Chickens or Hens, as before in the fir≈øt Chapter hath been ≈øhewed you: and if you cannot get Chickens nor Hens, then a Whelpe or a Pigeon cloven a≈øunder by the back, and ≈øo applyed warm will ≈øuffice, which mu≈øt be renued ≈øo oftentimes as cau≈øe requireth, and when that is done, then apply unto the wound a dige≈øtive, made as followeth.

div.head: A Dige≈øtive.
div.p: Take Turpentine ‚Ñ•. ≈øs. Honey í. ii. Mithridate, or Triacle í. ≈øs. the yolk of a new laid Egge.

Mix all the≈øe together and u≈øe it in the wound, and upon all lay
the dige≈øtive Catapla≈øme before≈øaid, which is made of Figs, or a plai≈øter of Kellebackeron, or of Diaculum magnum, and dre≈ø≈øe it twice a day, and every dre≈ø≈øing Epithemate the greif as before≈øaid, when it is dige≈øted, then mandifie, incarnate, and ≈øigillate it, as in the Chapter before is ≈øhewed you.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Sheweth what is to be done when the botch ≈øtrikes in again.
div.p: SOmetimes you ≈øhall ≈øee the ≈øore will appear outwardly, and ≈øuddenly vani≈øh away again, which is a very dangerous and deadly ≈øign; now when this doth chance, then pre≈øently give ≈øome good Cordiall that hath power to expell the venome, as in the fir≈øt Chapter of this Treati≈øe you may find choyce of, and immediately apply this Pultus to both the ≈øoales of his feet, which mu≈øt be made with Culver-dung, and Vinegar mixt together, and ≈øpread on a Cole leafe, and ≈øo applyed; you mu≈øt give the Cordiall every third hour, and immediately after the fir≈øt giving of the Cordiall, you mu≈øt Epithemate the heart with the Epithemation before expre≈ø≈øed, in the ≈øecond Chapter of this Treati≈øe; and when that is done, then cau≈øe the ≈øick to ≈øweat, if you may, and after his ≈øweat, and the body well dried, then give him an ea≈øie Gli≈øter, the next day purge him with ≈øome gentle purgation, as before is ≈øhewed you. And if by the≈øe meanes you prevail not, then ≈ømall hope of life is to be expected; yet Petrus Fore≈øtus willeth you, fir≈øt to give a Gli≈øter, and then within two houres after it, to draw ≈øome bloud in the ≈øame ≈øide where the greif is, and to annoint the place greived with ∆≤nguentum re≈øumptivum, mixt with ≈øome Oil of Cammomill, and then two houres after it to give a Cordiall, and procure ≈øweat upon it, and ≈øo following the re≈øt of the orders afore≈øaid, did recover divers.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Sheweth how to draw a botch from one place to another, and ≈øo to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe him without breaking.
div.p:
FIr≈øt you mu≈øt apply a cupping gla≈ø≈øe next adjoyning to the lower part of the ≈øore, on that ≈øide where you would have him to be
brought, and next unto that gla≈ø≈øe apply another, ≈øo neer the fir≈øt as you can, and if that be not ≈øo farre as you would have the ≈øore to be brought, then apply the third gla≈ø≈øe, and let them all remain a quarter of an hour, then take away the la≈øt gla≈ø≈øe, but ≈øuffer the fir≈øt to remain, then pre≈øently apply him again, and let it remain a quarter of an hour more, and doe ≈øo three or four times together, but alwayes ≈øuffer the fir≈øt gla≈ø≈øe next the ≈øore for to remain; now when you have thus done, then take all the gla≈ø≈øes away, and pre≈øently apply a Ve≈øicatory to the place where the la≈øt and uttermo≈øt gla≈ø≈øe did ≈øtand, ≈øuffering it to remain there twelve houres, then open the bli≈øter, and lay an Ivy or Cole leafe to the place, and upon all lay a plai≈øter of Kellebackeron, or Diaculum magnum, and dre≈ø≈øe it twice a day, the longer you keep it running, the better it will be, and at length heal it up as other Ulcers are cured.
Now ≈øo ≈øoon as you have applyed the Ve≈øicatory, you mu≈øt pre≈øently epithemate the botch with this Epithemation.

div.head: Epithemation.
div.p: Take Mallowes, Violets, Cammomill, Dill, and Mellilot, ana, M. i. Hollehock roots three ounces, Lin-≈øeed one ounce and a half.

Boile all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of water untill halfe the water be con≈øumed, in this decoction you mu≈øt wet ≈øome unwa≈øhed Wooll or Flax made clean and well beaten, then being wrung out a little, apply it warm to the place, and renue it every hour, during the time that the Ve≈øicatory is in working, and when you have opened the bli≈øter that is made thereby, then onely apply this Catapla≈øme to the botch it ≈øelf.
Take Mallowes, Violets and Cammomill floures, of either one handfull.

Boil them in water untill they be tender, then cut them very ≈ømall with a ≈øhreading knife, and add thereto Oil of Cammomill and Lillies, of either two ounces: Barrowes mort two ounces, Wax one ounce.

Melt the Wax in the Oiles, and then put it to the Hearbs, and boile them together a little, then take it from the fire, and adde thereto Barly and Bean flower, a handfull of either of them, and ≈øo
mix them altogether, and apply it to the greif, renuing it twice a day, which within three or four dayes will re≈øolve and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe the botch; but if it doe it not by that time, then u≈øe all the meanes you can to bring it to ≈øupparation, as before is ≈øufficiently ≈øhewed you.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Sheweth how to know a Carbunkle or blain, as al≈øo the cure of the ≈øame.
div.p: THe Carbunkle or blain doth fir≈øt begin with a little Pu≈øtula or wheal, and ≈øometime with divers Pu≈øtulaes or wheales together, with a great burning and pricking pain in the place, which Pu≈øtulaes are like a ≈øcalding bladder, ≈øeeming to be full of water or matter, yet when you open it, little or nothing will come out of it, and when they are broken, will grow to a hard cru≈øt or ≈øcarre, as if it had been burnt with a hot Iron or Cau≈øtick, with a great pondero≈øity or heavine≈ø≈øe in the place. In ≈øome it comes in the beginning, without any Pu≈øtula at all to be perceived, but with a hard black cru≈øt or a ≈øcarre; ≈øometimes it lyeth hidden in the inward parts without any outward appearance at all, as if it be in the lungs, then there is a difficulty of breathing, with a Cough and ≈øoul ≈øpitting.

If it be in the Liver or Spleen, then the party feeleth a great pain and pricking in the ≈øame ≈øide; if in the Kidneyes or Bladder it doth chance, then is there ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion or ≈øtopping of the Urine, or great pain in the making of water; if it be in the Brain, then a delirium followeth, but how≈øoever it chance to come, the party infected therewith hath a Fever, with other accidents, as before in the 13. Chapter of the fir≈øt Treati≈øe is declared; if it begin with a green, black, or blew colour, or of divers colours like the Rainbow, then is it a deadly ≈øigne, and ≈øo is it, if once it appear and then ≈øuddenly vani≈øh away; but if it be red or yellowi≈øh, ≈øo it be not in any of the principall parts, or emunctuaries of the body, as the heart, ≈øtomack, armpit, flanke, jawes, or throat, then it is laudable, otherwi≈øe in any of the≈øe places very de≈øperate and dangerous to be cured, but where≈øoever it doth chance, unle≈ø≈øe it may be brought to ≈øuppuration, it is deadly.

div.head: The cure of the Carbunkle.
div.p: Fir≈øt, the Univer≈øall means mu≈øt not be neglected, as bloud-letting, cordials, epithemations, ≈øweet and gentle evacuation by purging, as the time and cau≈øe requireth, which before in the beginning of this Treati≈øe hath been ≈øhewed at large, and the ≈øame order which is u≈øed for the cure of a Botch, is al≈øo to be kept in the cure of a Carbunkle, and to rectifie the ayre of the hou≈øe by ≈øtrewing it with vine and willow leaves, red Ro≈øes and ≈øuch like, as al≈øo to ≈øprinkle the floor with Ro≈øe water and Vinegar, and cau≈øe the ≈øick oftentimes to ≈ømell unto a cloth wet in Ro≈øewater and Vinegar is very good: the≈øe things being done, then u≈øe all the means you can to bring it to Suppuration, for which purpo≈øe this Catapla≈øm following is very good

div.head: A Maturative Catapla≈øm.
div.p: Take Fat Figs ‚Ñ• iiii. Mu≈øtard ≈øeed, ‚Ñ• i. ≈øs. Pound the ≈øeed ≈ømall by it ≈øelf, the Figs mu≈øt fir≈øt be cut very ≈ømall, and then pounded likewi≈øe, and then adde thereto ≈øo much Oyle of Lillies as will ≈øuffice to make it in the form of a ≈øtiffe Pultis, and apply it warm, renuing it twice a day, this mu≈øt be continued untill the ≈øcar begin to grow loo≈øe and moveable, and then apply this following to remove the ≈øcar.
Take un≈øalted butter, the yolk of an Egg, and wheat flour, mix them together, and apply it untill the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ar doe fall away, then doe you mundifie it with this mundificative.

div.head: Mundificative annodine.
div.p: Take clear Turpentine, ‚Ñ• iiii. Sirrup of red Ro≈øes, ‚Ñ• i. Honie of Ro≈øes, í iiii. Boil them altogether a little, then take it from the fire, and add thereto Barlie and wheat flour of each í. vi. the yolk, of a new laid Egg, and mix them altogether, and apply it three dayes, and then u≈øe this following.

div.head: Another Mundificative.
div.p:
Take clear Turpentine, ‚Ñ• iii. Honie of Ro≈øes, ‚Ñ• ii. Juice
of Smallege, ‚Ñ• ii. Barlie flowre, ‚Ñ• i. ≈øs. Boil them altogether ≈øaving the Barlie, untill the Juice be con≈øumed, then take it from the fire, and when it is almo≈øt cold, adde the Barlie thereto, and mixe them together, and u≈øe thereof to the grief untill it be clean mundified, and then incarnate it with ∆≤nguentum Ba≈øilicon, and la≈øtly ≈øigillate it with ∆≤nguentum de ceru≈øa decocted.
Sometime you ≈øhall find a little pu≈øtule to appear, without any elevation of the parts adjoyning, or outward hardne≈ø≈øe. Now here to bring it outwardly you mu≈øt apply this Catapla≈øm.

Take Lillie roots, Onyons, and four Leaven, of either one ounce. Boil them in water untill the water be con≈øumed, then brui≈øe them in a morter, and add thereto Mu≈øtard ≈øeed, Culver-dung, White Sope, ana í. i. ≈øs. Snails without ≈øhels, vi. in number. Mithridate, Triacle, ana, half a drachm, Yolks of four Eggs.

Mix all the≈øe together, and apply it warm to the grief, renuing it thrice a day, this order mu≈øt be continued untill you ≈øee the place elevated tending to ≈øuppuration, then apply a Maturative, and ≈øo proceed as next before this is ≈øhewed you, and during the whole time of the cure, I hold it better to u≈øe rather Poulti≈øes then plai≈øters, becau≈øe they do not ≈øo much ≈øtop the Pores, but give more ≈øcope for the venemous matter to breath out.

div.head: When the Carbuncle doth come with great pain and inflammation, how to help it.
div.p: You mu≈øt fir≈øt bath and ≈øoke the place well with this bag following, and then pre≈øently apply the Catapla≈øm en≈øuing, for by this means you ≈øhall not onely ea≈øe the pain and abate the Inflammation and Fever, but al≈øo prevent the danger of Gangrena which may chance thereby.

div.head: The Bag.
div.p: Take Mallowes, Violets, Plantain, Liblong, ana one handfull. Fat Figs, ‚Ñ• i. Hollihock roots, Lillie roots, ana ‚Ñ•. i. Lin-≈øeed, ‚Ñ• i.

You mu≈øt ≈øhred the hearbs gro≈øly, and cut the Figgs and roots ≈ømall, then brui≈øe them in a morter, and mingle them altogether, then put them into two little bags of linnen cloth, and boil them in a ≈øufficient quantitie of clean water, untill the water be half con≈øumed, then take out one of the baggs, and wring out the water a little, and apply it to the grief warm, and when it is cold, take it away, and lay on the other, and doe ≈øo half an hour together every dre≈ø≈øing, which mu≈øt be twice a day at lea≈øt.

div.head: The Catapla≈øm.
div.p: Take Mallows, Violets, Sorrell, Liblong, ana two handfuls, Henbane, a little handfull..

Wrap them all in a ball together, and roa≈øt them in the a≈øhes, then brui≈øe them in a morter, and adde thereto, Mel ro≈øarum, ‚Ñ• iiii. Triacle, í i. ≈øs. Saffron in pouder, half a drachm, Yolks of five Eggs.

Mix them together with the re≈øt, adding ≈øome Barly flower thereto to thicken it, and apply it warm, renuing it alwaies before it grow dry and ≈øtiffe, and every dre≈ø≈øing you mu≈øt Epithemate the grief fir≈øt with the baggs afore≈øaid, and this order mu≈øt be continued untill the pain and Inflammation be gone, then to bring it unto Suppuration, if you adde to the fore≈øaid Catapla≈øm ≈øome oyle of Lillies, and ≈øweet Butter un≈øalted, it will be very good, or you may make this Catapla≈øm following.
Take Soot of the chimney, ‚Ñ•. iii. Bay≈øalt, ‚Ñ•. i. ≈øs. Yolks of two or three Eggs.

Mix all the≈øe together in a morter, and apply it to the grief warm, which mu≈øt be alwaies renewed and changed before it grow dry and ≈øtiffe, this order mu≈øt be continued untill the ≈øore come to ≈øuppuration, then to remove the ≈øcar, and fini≈øh the cure, doe you follow the order pre≈øcribed in the beginning of this Chapter.

There are other dangerous accidents which doe ≈øometimes chance in the botch or Carbuncle, which here to treat of would little avail the unexpert people, becau≈øe they know not the means how to execute the ≈øame, but if any ≈øuch
thing chance, then doe I wi≈øh you to ≈øeek the help of ≈øome learned Phy≈øitian, or expert Chirurgion, who≈øe coun≈øell I doe wi≈øh you to follow.

div.head: A Short Treati≈øe of the Small Pox, ≈øhewing the Means how for to govern and cure tho≈øe which are infected therewith.
CHAP. I. Sheweth what the Small Pox and Mea≈øels are, and whereof it proceedeth.
div.p: FOr that oftentimes tho≈øe that are infected with the Plague, are in the end of the di≈øea≈øe ≈øometime troubled with the ≈ømall Pox or Mea≈øels, as al≈øo by good ob≈øervation it hath been ≈øeen, that they are fore-runners or warnings of the plague to come, as Salius and divers other writers doe te≈øtifie: I have thought it good and as a matter pertinent to my former Treati≈øe, to ≈øhew the aids and helps which are required for the ≈øame.

I need not greatly to ≈øtand upon the de≈øcription of this di≈øea≈øe, becau≈øe it is a thing well known unto mo≈øt people, proceeding of adu≈øted bloud mixt with flegm, as Avicen witne≈ø≈øeth, which according to both ancient and latter Writers doth alwaies begin with a Fever, then ≈øhortly after there ari≈øeth ≈ømall Pu≈øtulaes upon the skin throughout all the body, which doe not ≈øuddenly come forth, but by intermi≈ø≈øion, in ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe, according to the ≈øtate and qualitie of the bodie infected therewith: for in ≈øome there ari≈øeth many little Pu≈øtulaes with elevation of the skin, which in one day doe increa≈øe and grow bigger, and after have a thick matter growing in them, which the Greeks call Exanthemata or Exthymata: and after the Latines Variola, in our Engli≈øh tongue the ≈ømall Pox,
and here ≈øome Writers doe make a difference betwixt variola and exanthemata; for ≈øay they, that is called variola when many of tho≈øe Pu≈øtules doe ≈øuddenly run into a clear bladder, as if it had been ≈øcalled, but the other doth not ≈øo, yet they are both one in the cure, they doe mo≈øt commonly appear the fourth day, or before the eight day, as Avicen witne≈ø≈øeth.

div.head: What the Mea≈øels or Males are.
div.p: Avicen ≈øaith, That the Mea≈øels or Males is that which fir≈øt cometh with a great ≈øwelling in the fle≈øh, with many little Pimples which are not to be ≈øeen, but onely by feeling with the hand are to be perceived, they have little elevation of the skin, neither doe they grow to maturation, or end with ulceration as the Pox doth, neither doe they a≈ø≈øault the eyes, or leave any deformity behind them as the Pox doth, neither are they ≈øo ≈øwift in coming forth, but doe grow more ≈ølowly, they require the ≈øame cure which the Pox have, they proceed of cholerick and melancholie bloud.

div.head: The cau≈øe of the Pox and Mea≈øels.
div.p: The primitive cau≈øe as Valetius ≈øaith, is by alteration of the aire, in drawing ≈øome putrified and corrupt quality unto it, which doth cau≈øe an ebullition of our bloud.

The cau≈øe antecedent is repletion of meats, which do ea≈øily corrupt in the ≈øtomack, as when we eat milk and fi≈øh together at one time, or by neglecting to draw bloud, in ≈øuch as have accu≈øtomed to doe it every year, whereby the bloud doth abound.

The conjunct cau≈øe is the men≈øtruall bloud, which from the beginning in our mothers wombs wee received, the which mixing it ≈øelf with the re≈øt of our bloud, doth cau≈øe an Ebullition of the whole.

The efficient cau≈øe is, nature or naturall heat, which by that men≈øtruall matter mixing it ≈øelf with the re≈øt of our blouds doth cau≈øe a continuall vexing and di≈øquieting thereof, whereby an unnaturall heat is increa≈øed in all the body, cau≈øing an Ebullition of bloud, by the which this filthy men≈øtrual matter
is ≈øeperated from our natural bloud, and the nature being offended and overwhelmed therewith, doth thru≈øt it to the outward pores of the skin as the excrements of bloud, which matter if it be hot and ≈ølimie, then it produceth the Pox, but if dry and ≈øubtil, then the Mea≈øels or Males. But Mercurialis an excellent writer in Phy≈øick, in his fir≈øt Book, de morbis puerorum, cap. 2. agreeing with Fernelius in his Book De abdit is rerum cau≈øis, c. 12. doth hold opinion, that the immediate cau≈øe of this di≈øea≈øe doth not proceed of men≈øtrual bloud, but of ≈øome ≈øecret and unknown corruption, or defiled quality of the aire, cau≈øing an Ebullition of bloud, which is al≈øo verified by Valetius, and now doth reckon it to be one of the hereditable di≈øea≈øes, becau≈øe few or none doe e≈øcape it, but that either in their youth, ripe age, or old age, they are infected therewith. The contention hereabout is great, and mighty rea≈øons are oppugned on both ≈øides, therefore I will leave the judgement thereof unto the better learned to define; but mine opinion is, That now it proceedeth of the Excrements of all the four humours in our bodies, which ≈øtriving with the pure≈øt, doth cau≈øe a ≈øupernatural heat and ebullition of our bloud, alwaies beginning with a Fever in the mo≈øt part, and may well be reckoned in the number of tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes which are called Epidemia: as Fraca≈øtorius in his fir≈øt Book, De morbis contag. cap. 13. witne≈ø≈øeth this di≈øea≈øe is very contagious and infectious, as experience teacheth us: There are two ≈øpeciall cau≈øes why this di≈øea≈øe is infectious: The fir≈øt is, be cau≈øe it proceedeth by ebullition of bloud, who≈øe vapour being entred into another bodie, doth ≈øoon defile and infect the ≈øame, the ≈øecond rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it is a di≈øea≈øe hereditable; for we ≈øee when one is infected therewith, that ≈øo many as come neer him, (e≈øpecially tho≈øe which are allyed in the ≈øame bloud) doe a≈ø≈øuredly for the mo≈øt part, receive the infection al≈øo.

div.head: CHAP. II. Sheweth to know the ≈øigns when one is infected, as al≈øo the good and ill ≈øigns in the di≈øea≈øe.
div.p:
THe ≈øigns when one is infected are the≈øe, fir≈øt he is taken with a hot Fever, and ≈øometime with a Delirium, great
pain in the back, furring and ≈øtopping of the no≈øe, beating of the heart, hoar≈øne≈ø≈øe, redne≈øs of the eyes, and full of tears with heavine≈ø≈øe and pain in the head, great beating in the forehead and temples, heavine≈øs and pricking in all the body, dryne≈øs in the mouth, the face very red, pain in the throat and brea≈øt, difficulty in breathing, and ≈øhaking of the hands and feet with ≈øpitting thick matter.

When they doe ≈øoon or in ≈øhort time appear, and that in their coming out they doe look red, and that after they are come forth they doe look white, and ≈øpeedily grow to maturation, that he draweth his breath ea≈øily, and doth find him≈øelf ea≈øed of his pain, and that his Fever doth leave him, the≈øe are good and laudable ≈øignes of recovery.

When the Pox lye hidden within and not appearing outwardly, or if after they are come forth they doe ≈øuddenly ≈øtrike in again and vani≈øh away, or that they doe look of a black, blewi≈øh, and green colour, with a difficultie and ≈øtraitne≈ø≈øe of drawing breath, and that he doe often ≈øwoun, if the ≈øick have a flix or lask, when the Pox were found double, that is, one growing within another, or when they run together in bli≈øters like ≈øcalding bladders, and then on the ≈øudden do ≈øink down and grow dry with a hard black ≈øcar or cru≈øt, as if it had been burnt with a hot iron, all the≈øe are ill ≈øigns.

Avicen ≈øaith, there are two ≈øpeciall cau≈øes which produce death unto tho≈øe that have this di≈øea≈øe: either for that they are choaked with great Inflammation and ≈øwelling in the throat called Angina, or having a flix or lask which doth ≈øo weaken and overthrow the vitall ≈øpirits, that thereby the di≈øea≈øe is increa≈øed, and ≈øo death followeth.

div.head: How to know of what humours this di≈øea≈øe cometh.
div.p: If it come of bloud, then they appear red, with generall pain, and great heat in all the body.
If they come of choler, then will they appear of a yellowi≈øh red and clear colour, with a pricking pain in all the bodie.
If they come of flegm, then will they appear of a whiti≈øh colour and ≈øcaly, or with ≈øcales.
If they come of melancholie, then will they appear blacki≈øh with a pricking pain.

div.head: CHAP. III. Sheweth the meanes to cure the Pox or Mea≈øels.
div.p: THere are two ≈øpeciall meanes required for curing this di≈øea≈øe, the fir≈øt is to help nature to expell the ≈øame from the interior and principall parts unto the exterior: the ≈øecond is to pre≈øerve both the interior and exterior parts, that they may not be hurt thereby.

For the fir≈øt intention, if the age and ≈øtrength of the ≈øick will permit, and that the Pox or Mea≈øels appear not, it were then good in the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, or third day to draw bloud out of the Ba≈øilica veine in the right arme, if he be not under the age of fourteen years, but the quantity mu≈øt be at the di≈øcretion of him that draweth it, either more or le≈ø≈øe as occa≈øion is offered: but for children and ≈øuch as are of tender years, and weak bodies, it were not good to draw bloud out of the arme, but out of the inferior parts, as the thighes, hams buttocks, and the Emeroidall veines, e≈øpecially if the party be melancholie, or el≈øe to apply vento≈øe; to the loynes, buttocks, or hams, which may boldly be u≈øed both before and after they do appear, either with ≈øcarification, or without, as cau≈øe requireth, which is a ≈øpeciall good meanes to draw that Ichorous matter from the interior to the exterior parts; but for ≈øucking Children, it were be≈øt to apply bloud-≈øuckers unto any of the fore≈øaid places, which is a thing that may be u≈øed with more ea≈øe then vento≈øes, neither do I wi≈øh either of them to be u≈øed unle≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øity require it, which is, when the matter lieth lurking in the interior parts, not offering it ≈øelf to appear outwardly: otherwi≈øe I hold it better to leave the whole work unto nature, ≈øpecially in ≈øucking children: for when we ≈øee that nature is ready, or doth endeavour to expell the malignity which is in the interior parts to the exterior, which may be perceived by reviving of the Spirits, and mitigating of the Fever: here we ought not to u≈øe any meanes at all, but leave the whole operation to nature, which we mu≈øt onely help by keeping
the ≈øick body in a rea≈øonable heat, being wrapt in a ≈øcarlet, ≈øtammell, or red cloth, which may not touch the skin, but to have a ≈øoft linnen cloth betwixt them both, and then cover him with clothes in rea≈øonable ≈øort, and keep him from the open ayre and the light, except a little, and al≈øo from anger, u≈øing all the meanes you can to keep the ≈øick in quietne≈ø≈øe, and if the body be very co≈øtive, then to give an ea≈øie Gli≈øter.

div.head: A Gli≈øter.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Barley, two handfuls, Violet leaves one handfull: Boyle the≈øe in three pints of water untill half be con≈øumed, and ≈øtrein it: then take of the ≈øame decoction twelve ounces.
Oyle of Violets three ounces, red Sugar and Butter, of either one ounce,

Mix them together and give it to the ≈øick warm; you may encrea≈øe or dimini≈øh the decoction or ingredients according as the age of the party requireth: but if the ≈øick have great heat, then may you add one ounce or four drachms of Ca≈ø≈øia newly drawn unto it, and when he hath expelled the Gli≈øter, then rub the armes, hands, legs, and feet, ≈øoftly with a warm cloth, which is al≈øo a very good meanes to draw that chorous matter from the interior to the exterior parts, when all this is done, then if the body be inclined to ≈øweat, you mu≈øt further the ≈øame by covering him with warm clothes, having a care that you lay not more on him then he can well endure, for otherwi≈øe you may cau≈øe faintne≈ø≈øe and ≈øwouning, which are ill in this ca≈øe, yet mu≈øt you alwaies keep the ≈øick warm, and ≈øuffer him not to ≈øleep, or permit very little untill the Pox or Mea≈øels do appear: and here you mu≈øt have a ≈øpeciall care to pre≈øerve the eyes, eares, no≈øtrels, throat and lungs, that they be not hurt or offended therewith, as hereafter ≈øhall be ≈øhewed you, which you mu≈øt u≈øe before he ≈øweat and al≈øo in the ≈øweat if need be.

div.head: Eyes, how to pre≈øerve them.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Ro≈øe-water, Plantaine-water, of either two ounces, Sumack, two drachms.

Let them boyle together a little, or ≈øtand infu≈øed a night, then mixe therewith half a ≈øpoonfull of the oyle made of the white of an Egg, then wet two clothes five or ≈øix double therein, then lay them upon either eye, cold, which mu≈øt bee alwaies kept upon the eyes untill the Pox be all come forth, and as they grow dry, wet them in the ≈øame liquor againe, and apply them, but if there be great pain and burning within the eye, then mu≈øt you al≈øo put a drop of this mu≈ø≈øelage following into the eye: take quin≈øe-≈øeed, half a drachm, brui≈øe it a little, then let it ≈øtand infu≈øed in three ounces of Ro≈øe-water a whole night, then ≈øtrein it, and put one drop thereof into the eye three or four times a day at lea≈øt, or take of this water.
‚Ñû. Ro≈øe-water, ‚Ñ•. ii. Womans milk, ‚Ñ•. i. Myrrh finely powdered ≈øix graines.
Mixe them together, and u≈øe it in the eye as before is ≈øhewed: this doth ea≈øe the paine, re≈øi≈øteth putrefication, and pre≈øerveth the ≈øight.
For the cares, you mu≈øt put a drop of oyle of Ro≈øes warm into them before he ≈øweat.
For the no≈øtrels, cau≈øe him oftentimes to ≈ømell to the vapour of Ro≈øe-vinegar, or el≈øe Vinegar, red-ro≈øes and Sanders boyled together.
For the throate, let him alwaies hold a peice of white ≈øugar-candy in the mouth, and as it melteth ≈øwallow it down.
For the Lunges give the ≈øick oftenimes ≈øome ≈øirrup of quin≈øes, or con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, a little at a time.

And for his drink, the decocted water of barley, boyled with a little licorice is be≈øt, being mixed with the juice of a Lemon, Citron, Pomegranate, or Rybes: which the ≈øick be≈øt liketh, for either of them is very good.

And for his diet, he mu≈øt refrain from all ≈øalt, fat, thick and ≈øharp meats: and from all ≈øweet things either in meat or drink, his meat mu≈øt be of a facile and ea≈øie dige≈øtion, and that hath a cooling property in it, as broth wherein burrage, buglofs, ≈øorrell, and ≈øuch like are boyled, and for ordinary drink, ≈ømall beer or ale is be≈øt.

div.head: CHAP IIII. Teacheth what is to be done when the Pox or Mea≈øels are flow in coming forth.
div.p: NOw when you perceive the Pox or Mea≈øels are ≈ølow and ≈ølack in comming forth, then mu≈øt you help nature, with cordials, and by ≈øweat to thru≈øt it out from the interior and principall parts, unto which purpo≈øe I have alwaies found this drink to be excellent good here following.

‚Ñû. Hordei mund. M. i. Lentium. excort. P. i. Ficuum. No. x. Fol. capil. v. Lactucae. ana M. ≈øs. Fol. aceto≈øae. M. i. Florum cord. P. i. Semen fenic. í. ii. Semen. 4. frigid. ma. ana í. ≈øs. Aqua font. lb. iiii.
Boyle all the≈øe together untill a third part of the water be con≈øumed, and then ≈øtrein it.
‚Ñû. Decoct. col. lb. i. Succus granatorum vel ribes, ‚Ñ•. iiii.

Mix all the≈øe together, and give the ≈øick four or ≈øix ounces thereof to drink every morning and evening, which will provoke ≈øweat, and expell the di≈øea≈øe, and if you cannot get the juice of Pomegranats, nor Rybes, then you may take ≈øo much of the ≈øirrup of either of them.

div.head: Another good drink to expell the Pox or Mea≈øels.
div.p: Take a quart of po≈ø≈øet-ale, a handfull of Fennell ≈øeed, boyle them together till a third part be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrein it, and add thereto one drachm of Triacle, and one ≈øcruple of Saffron in powder: mix them together, and give two, three, or four ounces thereof to drink every morning and evening as cau≈øe requireth.
But if it be for a ≈øtrong and elderly body, you may give any of the expelling electuaries which are u≈øed to expell the Plague, as in the fir≈øt Chapter for the curing of the Plague doth appear.
But if the ≈øick be ≈øo weak that he cannot expell the di≈øea≈øe in convenient time, then it is good to epithemate the heart with this epithemation following.

div.head: Epithemation for the heart.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Aquarum ro≈ø. Meli≈ø≈øae, Card. b. Buglo≈ø. Mor≈øus diaboli, vini alb. ana ‚Ñ•. iiii. Aceti Ro≈ø. ‚Ñ•. ii. ≈øs. Pul. Ro≈ø. rub. Trium ≈øantal. Cinamoni, Elect. diamarg. frigid. ana í. ≈øs. Mithridati, ‚Ñ•. i. Theriacae, í. iiii.

Mix all the≈øe together, and let them boyle a little, and ≈øo warm Epithemate the heart: and when you have done it, then give ≈øome expul≈øive drink or electuary as cau≈øe requireth, and then cau≈øe him to ≈øweat upon it, for by this meanes you ≈øhall obtaine your de≈øire by Gods permi≈ø≈øion.

div.head: Thir≈øt, how to quench it.
div.p: Now if in the expelling of the pox, the ≈øick be very thir≈øty and dry, then give this Julep to drink morning and evening, which I have found very good.
‚Ñû. Sirrup of Jujubes, Nenuphare, and Burrage, of either four drachms: Water of Burrage, Cichore, and Buglo≈øs, of either two ounces.
Mix them together and give the ≈øick one half thereof in the morning, and the re≈øt at night, and cau≈øe him oftentimes to lick of this mixture following.
Take the con≈øerves of Nenuphare, Violets, and Burrage, of either ≈øix drachms: Manus Christi made with Perles, four drachms: Sirrup of Nenuphare and Ribes, of either one ounce and half.
Mix them together: and with a Licorice ≈øtick clean ≈øcrap'd, and a little brui≈øed in the end, let the ≈øick lick thereof.

div.head: CHAP. V. Sheweth what is to be done when the Pox are all come out in the skinne.
div.p:
FOr that oftentimes the face and hands, which is the beauty and delight of our bodies, are oftentimes disfigured thereby, I will ≈øhew you what meanes I have u≈øed with good and happy
≈øucce≈ø≈øe for preventing thereof: which is, you may not do any thing unto them untill they grow white, and that they are come to maturation, which when you perceive, then with a golden pinne, or needle, or for lack thereof a copper pinne will ≈øerve, do you open every pu≈øtulae in the top, and ≈øo thru≈øt out the matter therein very ≈øoftly and gently with a ≈øoft linnen cloth, and if you perceive the places do fill againe, then open them againe as you did fir≈øt, for if you do ≈øuffer the matter which is in them to remain over long, then will it fret and corrode the fle≈øh, which is the cau≈øe of tho≈øe pitts which remaine after the Pox are gone, as Avicen witne≈ø≈øeth: now when you have thus done, then annoint the places with this oyntment following.
Take Elder leaves, one handfull, Marigolds, two handfulls, French Mallowes, one handfull, Barrowes morte or grea≈øe, ≈øix ounces.

Fir≈øt brui≈øe the hearb in a morter, and then boyle them with the grea≈øe in a pewter di≈øh on a chafer and coales, untill the juice of the hearbs be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrein it, and keep it to your u≈øe, the be≈øt time to make it is in the middle or the latter end of May.

div.p: Sometimes the eye-lids are ≈øo fa≈øtened together that you cannot open them without great pain and danger: then to open them you mu≈øt foment or bath them well with a decoction made of Quince ≈øeed, Mallowes and water boyled together, wherein wet ≈øome fine linnen clothes five or ≈øix double, and apply them warm, and continue it untill you may ea≈øily open them, and then if you perceive any web or filme to be grown over the ≈øight, then thrice a day do you put ≈øome powder of white ≈øugar-candy into the eye, or if you li≈øt, you may di≈ø≈øolve the ≈øugar in Ro≈øe-water, and ≈øo u≈øe it in the eye, which will fret it away, and pre≈øerve the ≈øight.

div.head: CHAP VI. Teacheth how to help divers accidents which chance after the Pox are cured and gone. For redne≈ø≈øe of the face and hands after the Pox are gone, how to help it.

div.head: Some other few additionall ob≈øervations concerning the pa≈ø≈øages in this latter Treati≈øe.

But to di≈øcover what opinions other Phi≈øitians have held of that and the like, I have annexed hereunto their ≈øeverall judgements hereafter, that among≈øt ≈øo many choi≈øe Medicines, they may ≈øelect out the be≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt for their own pre≈øervations, when need ≈øhall require.

div.head: Severall opinions again≈øt wearing of Ar≈øenick Amulets, as Pre≈øervatives again≈øt the Plague.
div.p: THe poy≈øonous vapours of Ar≈øenick being ≈øucked or drawn into the body, when they find no contrary poy≈øon with whom to wre≈øtle with, as with an enemy, (for in an infected body there cannot be health; but we ≈øuppo≈øe him to be well, whom we de≈øire to pre≈øerve ≈øo) tho≈øe vapours mu≈øt needs imprint a malignant and venomous quality on the ≈øpirit and heart, mo≈øt adver≈øe and pernitious to nature.

And by Galens own doctrine, all Alexiteries doe in a manner, if they be u≈øed too liberally, greatly offend and weaken our bodies; how can we then think, that ranke Poy≈øons and Dilaetories, (≈øuch us Ar≈øenick is) being applied, as to penetrate into the noble≈øt region of all other, will no whit violate and wa≈øt our naturall, vitall, and radicall heat? Galen libr. de ‚Ä¢ mp. cap. 18.

Nor did Galen, or any of the antient Fathers and Profe≈ø≈øors of Phy≈øick, u≈øe to pre≈øerve from the Plague, or any other poi≈øon, by admini≈øtring ≈øome other poi≈øon inwardly, or
pre≈øcribing outwardly Applications, but proceeded by Antidotes, and Alexiteries, as will appear in libr. de Theriaca ad Pi≈ø. cap, 16. Wherefore, unle≈ø≈øe we will utterly di≈øclaim or relingui≈øh the method and pre≈øcripts of the≈øe worthy Antients, and pro≈øecute new wayes and inventions, to oppo≈øe this man-yelling Mon≈øter, we mu≈øt attempt it not with Poy≈øons but Antidotes. And Galen defineth tho≈øe to be Poy≈øons, which agree not with nature, either well or ill affected at any time; for though there are ≈øome Poy≈øons, which if they meet in the body with a contrary venome, ≈øo fight with it, and oppo≈øe it, that both doe peri≈øh in the conflict betwixt them; ≈øo that the party, by their colluctation and ≈øtrugling together, e≈øcapes with his life: yet all of them agree in uniform opinion together, that where they meet with no oppo≈øition, they ruine the party: And therefore conclude, that Ar≈øenick, worn by a healthy man, finding not onely no contrary Poy≈øon to make conflict with, but no Poy≈øon at all, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily thwart, and oppo≈øe, and make an on≈øet on nature her ≈øelf.
And to confirme their opinions, I have purpo≈øely introduced the judgements of other learned Phi≈øitians concurring with them.

Gerardus Columbus, a learned Phi≈øitian, reporteth, that it hath been ob≈øerved, that the wearers of the≈øe Amulets, upon unu≈øuall heating their bodies, have fallen into ≈øudden Lipothimies, and Swounings, with other fearfull accidents, which continued upon them till the Amulets or Placents were removed from them; and that others, though not in≈øtantly, yet after ≈øome time, have by late and wofull experience di≈øcovered their malignity, by falling into malignant and pe≈øtilent Fevers, ≈øome of them ending with death.
Franc. Alphanus, a Phi≈øitian of Salerne, relateth of one, who wearing Ar≈øenick, and heating him≈øelf with playing earne≈øtly at Tenni≈øe, fell down ≈øuddenly dead.

Mattheus He≈ø≈øus al≈øo thus writeth, As Cordiall Bags or Amulets ought not to be di≈øavowed, ≈øo empoy≈øoned Amulets can be no way commended; nor doe I remember, that ever any received good from them, who ab≈øtained from other
Antidotes: But this I certainly know, that divers per≈øons, who carry about them Quick-≈øilver in a Nut≈øhell, by the vain per≈øwa≈øions of ≈øome Impo≈øters, have died of the Plague, and the coun≈øellours and advi≈øers of ≈øuch like Amulets, have been the fir≈øt have betaken them≈øelves to their heeles, confiding more in their running than cunning: and yet the≈øe Quacks per≈øwaded the ignorant people, with glorious promi≈øes and prote≈øtations, that who≈øoever carried Quick-≈øilver or Ar≈øenick about his neck, ≈øhould be as ≈øafe, as if he had purcha≈øed a protection from the King of Heaven
Hi≈øtorians al≈øo report, that Caracalla, though he were a wicked Emperour, prohibited by publick Edict or Proclamation, that no man ≈øhould wear about him ≈øuper≈øtitious Amulets.
And Theophra≈øtus the great (not without cau≈øe) e≈øteemed Pericles to have a crazed brain, becau≈øe he ≈øaw him wear an Amulet about his neck.

And hereunto Doctor Francis Herring, an able Phi≈øitian, as a Corollary to what hath before been written, addeth the experience of ≈øome London Phi≈øitians, who report, they have ≈øeen foul holes made in the brea≈øts of tho≈øe that have worn tho≈øe Amulets, and have ob≈øerved divers to die, who have religiou≈øly worn them about their necks, as well as others.

And whereas the venters and ≈øetters out of the≈øe deceitfull wares, make them as a ≈øcout, to di≈øcover the infection when it beginneth to ≈øeize on a man, by clapping clo≈øe to the heart, to guard that principall part, as the cheif Tower: It is a meer deceit and collu≈øion: for when≈øoever the body is heated, this event followeth nece≈ø≈øarily, though no other infection be near, but the poy≈øonous and venomous Ar≈øenick it ≈øelf, who≈øe ≈øalutation is rather Joabs imbracing, or Juda's ki≈ø≈øing, than friendly pre≈øervatives.

div.head: Cau≈øes of the Plague.
div.p: There are two ≈øpeciall cau≈øes of the Plague.
Fir≈øt, An infected, corrupted, and putrified air,
Secondly, Evill and corrupt humours ingendered in the body.

The air is infected, when the temperatene≈ø≈øe of the air is changed from his naturall ≈øtate, to exce≈ø≈øive heat and moi≈øture, which is the wor≈øt temperament of the air, the vapours drawn up by the heat of the Sun being uncon≈øumed, rot, putrifie, and corrupt, and ≈øo with the venome infect the air: Al≈øo dead Carka≈øes lying unburied, as it often chanceth in Warres, evaporations of Pooles, Fens, Mari≈øhes, ≈øtinking and noy≈øome ≈øents and Kennels, and A≈øtronomers ≈øay, A≈øpects, Conjunctions and Oppo≈øitions of ill Planets, and Eclip≈øes of the Sun and Moon.

Al≈øo di≈øordering ones ≈øelf, either in diet or exerci≈øes bringeth one into the Pe≈øtilence; therefore in time of contagion, outrages and ≈øurfets are to be avoided, as al≈øo all exce≈ø≈øe of eating, drinking, ≈øweating, bathing, lechery, and all other things that open the pores of the body, and enter thereby ill aires, which invenome the lively ≈øpirits.

div.head: Signes of the Plague.
div.p: The ≈øignes which declare one infected already are many; but the ≈øecret token of all to know the infected of the Plague is, if there ari≈øe botches behind the eares, or under the armeholes, or about the ≈øhare; or if Carbunkles ≈øuddenly ari≈øe in any member, for when they appear, they betoken ≈øtrength of nature, which being ≈øtrong, laboureth to drive the poy≈øon out of the body; but if botches doe not appear, it is more dangerous, for it ≈øheweth, that nature is weak and feeble, and not able to expell and thru≈øt forth the venomous humours, and then you mu≈øt have re≈øpect to the ≈øignes before rehear≈øed.

div.head: The infection of the Plague entereth into a man after this ≈øort.
div.p:
In a man are three principall parts (that is) the Heart, Liver, and Brains, and each of the≈øe hath his clean≈øing place:
If they appear in the neck, they ≈øhew the Brains to be cheifly vexed, if under the arme-holes the Heart, but if they appear in the ≈øhare, the Liver is mo≈øt infected,

For when a man hath taken infection, it pre≈øently mingleth with the bloud, and runs to the heart, which is the cheif part of man, and the heart putteth the venome to his clean≈øing place, which is the arme-holes; and that being ≈øtopt, putteth it to the next principall part, which is the liver, and it pa≈ø≈øeth it to his clean≈øing place, which is the ≈øhare, and they being ≈øtopt, pa≈ø≈øe it to the next principall place, that is, the braines, and to their clean≈øing places, which are under the eares, or under the throat, and they being ≈øtopped, ≈øuffer it not to pa≈ø≈øe out, and then it is moved twelve hours before it re≈øt in any place, and if it be not let out within the ≈øpace of four and twenty hours by bleeding, it brings a man into a pe≈øtilentiall Ague, and cau≈øeth a botch in one of tho≈øe three places, or near unto them

div.head: The Cure of the Plague.
div.p: When thou feele≈øt thy ≈øelf infected, bleed in the fir≈øt hour, or within ≈øix hours after, drink not, and tarry not above twelve hours from bleeding, for then when the bloud is flitting too and fro, the venome is then moving, and not yet ≈øetled, and after it will be too late; tho≈øe that are fat may be let bloud, or el≈øe not.
If the matter be gathered under the arme-holes, it comes from the heart by the Cardiacall vein, then bleed on the ≈øame ≈øide by the Ba≈øilica vein, the innermo≈øt vein of the arme,

If the botch appear behind the eares, above the chin, or in any other part of the face or neck, bleed out of the Cephalica vein on the ≈øame ≈øide; you may bleed with cupping Gla≈ø≈øes, and Scarification, or Hor≈øeleeches.
If the botch appear in the ≈øhare, bleed in the ankle on the ≈øame ≈øide, in any ca≈øe not in the arme, for it will draw up the matter again.
But if no botch appear outwardly, draw bloud out of that ≈øide where you feel greate≈øt pain and heavine≈ø≈øe, and out of that vein, the greif of the members affected ≈øhall point thee out.

If you perceive the Plague invade you at meat, or on a full ≈øtomack, vomit ≈øpeedily, and when your ≈øtomacK is empty, take ≈øome Medicine that may re≈øi≈øt Poy≈øon, as Mithridate, or Triacle, or ≈øome of the≈øe following, which, as choi≈øe Medicines, I have in≈øerted, as being Doctor Edwards Experiments.

div.head: For the Plague.
div.p: Infu≈øe two peices of fine pure Gold in the juyce of Lemons four and twenty hours, and drink that juyce with a little Wine, with powder of the Angelica root: It is admirable, and hath helped divers pa≈øt all hope of cure.

div.head: The Cure of Di≈øea≈øes in Remote Regions.
The Calenture,
div.p: HAppeneth to our Nation in intemperate Climates, by Inflammation of bloud, and proceedeth often of immoderate drinking of wine, and eating of plea≈øant fruits, which are ≈øuch nouri≈øhers thereof, as they prevent the meanes u≈øed in curing the ≈øame.

div.head: To know the Calenture.
div.p: At the fir≈øt apprehen≈øion it afflicts the Patient with great pain in the head, and heat in the body, which is continuall or increa≈øing, and doth not dimini≈øh and angment, as other Fevers doe; and is oft an Introduction to the Taberdilla or Pe≈øtilence, but then the body will ≈øeem very yellow.

div.head: To cure the Calenture.
div.p:
So ≈øoon as you perceive the Patient po≈ø≈øe≈øt of the Calenture, (except the Chirurgion, for danger of the ≈øign defer it) I have ≈øeen the time of the day not re≈øpected, open the Median vein of the right arm, and take ≈øuch quantity of bloud, as agreeth with the ability of the bodie; but if it a≈ø≈øwage not the heat by the next day, open the ≈øame vein in the left arme, and take ≈øo much more like quantity of bloud at his di≈øcretion; and if the body be co≈øtive, (as commonly they are) give him ≈øome meet purgation, and ≈øuffer him to drink no other then water cold, wherein Barley and Anni≈øe-≈øeeds have been boyled with brui≈øed Liquorice. And if within 4. dayes the partie amend not, or being recovered, take it again, open the vein Cephalick in one or both hands, bathing them in
warm water, untill there come ≈øo much more bloud as cau≈øe requires. Suffer not the Patient to drinke ≈øeven dayes after he is perfectly recovered, any other drinke, then ≈øuch water, as is before herein directed.

div.head: The Taberdilla,
div.p: IS a di≈øea≈øe ≈øo called by the Spaniards, by the Mexicans, Cocali≈øta, and by other Indians is named Taberdet, and is ≈øo exceeding pe≈øtilent and infectious, that whole Kingdomes in both the India's have been depopulated by it, for want of knowledge to redre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves of it.

div.head: To know the Taberdilla.
div.p: It fir≈øt a≈ø≈øaults the Patient vehemently with pain in the head and back: and the body ≈øeeming yellow, is ≈øome ≈øign thereof, and within 24 hours it is ≈øo torturous, that the po≈ø≈øe≈øt thereof cannot re≈øt or ≈øleep, turning him≈øelf on either ≈øide, back or belly, burning in his back mo≈øt extreamly. And when it growes to perfection, there will appear red and blue ≈øpots upon the Patients brea≈øt and wri≈øts. And ≈øuch per≈øons as have not pre≈øently requi≈øite means applyed to them to prevent it, will be, by the vehement torment thereof, deprived of their wits, and many to cea≈øe their pain by lo≈ø≈øe of their lives have de≈øpairingly ≈ølain, and drowned them≈øelves.

div.head: The Cure of the Taberdilla.
div.p:
When you perceive it afflict the Patient, permit him not to lie very warm, nor upon feathers (for of what quality ≈øoever he bee in Spain, having this ≈øickne≈øs he is laid upon wheat-≈øtraw:) Then immediatly open the Median Vein, fir≈øt in one arm, and the next day in the other, taking a good quantity of bloud: Let him have water cold, wherein Barlie and Anni≈øe-≈øeeds have been ≈øodden without Liquorice (for the Spani≈øh
Phy≈øitians hold Liquorice to bee hurtfull unto them) ≈øo much as he will de≈øire, which will be every moment; but no other drink, nor any raw fruits: A≈ø≈øoon as the ≈øpots appear, give him ≈øome Cordiall potion: and laying him upon his belly, ≈øet ≈øix Vento≈øes together on his back, between and beneath the ≈øhoulders; and ≈øcarifying them, draw out (if it be a body of ≈øtrong con≈øtitution) 18 ounces of bloud. After which, and that he hath ≈ølept, he will find ea≈øe within twenty four hours, and ≈øuch alteration in him≈øelf, as he will thinke he is delivered of a mo≈øt ≈øtrange torment. Then give him moderately nouri≈øhing meats, (for he will de≈øire to eat much) the fourth day, give him ≈øome convenient Purgations. And if in the mean while he is co≈øtive, provoke him every day by Cli≈øters; and warn him to forbear 15 dayes all other drink then what is ordained: And be very carefull of his diet, for if this Taberdilla, which we call here in England Gods Tokens, come againe unto the Patient, he can hardly e≈øcape it. And it is no le≈ø≈øe Infectious, then the u≈øuall Engli≈øh Plague.

div.head: The E≈øpinlas
div.p: IS a ≈øtrange ≈øicknes, u≈øuall in tho≈øe parts to ≈øuch as take cold in their Brea≈øts, after great heat or travell. It comes mo≈øt times to tho≈øe that lye with their brea≈øts upon the ground (e≈øpecially) in the night.

div.head: To know the E≈øpinlas.
div.p: The Party having it, will be giddie in the head, and have pain and pricking at his brea≈øt, as with many thornes; from whence I thinke it is called, for E≈øpina in Spani≈øh ≈øignifies a thorn; and there will be upon the Focell, being the upper bone of his arm, a hand breadth above the wri≈øt, a little kernell by the which it is certainly known: He that hath this di≈øea≈øe, will have appetite neither to meat, nor drinke, nor can dige≈øt meat, though he be invited and moved to take it.

div.head: To cure the E≈øpinlas.
div.p: The E≈øpinlas appearing by the former ≈øigns, take pre≈øently oyle Olives, and therewith cha≈øe the kernell upon the Patients arm, u≈øing ≈øo to doe twice every day, untill it be di≈ø≈øolved; and laying oyle likewi≈øe upon his brea≈øt, ≈øtroke it upward ≈øomewhat hard with the hand; then ≈øpread fine flaxe upon it and the kernel, making it fa≈øt with a rowler, and within two or three dayes the di≈øea≈øed will be recovered thereof, whereas el≈øe it is very dangerous to deprive them of life.

div.head: Camera de Sangre.
div.p: LAxativene≈øs, or Bloudy Flux, proceed in tho≈øe parts of divers cau≈øes: As by eating Grapes, Oranges, Limons, Melons, Plantains, and e≈øpecially a great fruit growing in the We≈øt Indies called Pina, like a Pine-apple, but bigger then four of the greate≈øt which I have ≈øeen, which the Spaniars hold for the mo≈øt delicate fruit that is there, and many other fruits. Al≈øo by ≈øudden cold, or ≈øitting (being very hot) upon a cold ≈øtone, or being hot by drinking water abundantly. And al≈øo eating of Butter, Oyle, and Fi≈øh is ≈øo hurtfull to the parties that have it, that they mu≈øt refrain to eat thereof, and what≈øoever el≈øe, that may ingender any ≈ølimie ≈øub≈øtance in the Intrals.

div.head: The Cure of the Bloudie Flux.
div.p:
There is more po≈ø≈øibility of cure, by how much more expedition the medicine is mini≈øtred: and detracting it, the Patients often die ≈øuddenly, without feeling much grief. For ≈øpeedy and a≈ø≈øured remedie, the Patients bodie mu≈øt be clean≈øed of the ≈ølimine≈øs, ingendred in the pa≈ø≈øages of the nutriments, before any ≈øu≈øtenance can remain in his bodie. To that purpo≈øe purge him in the morning, with halfe a pint of white wine cold, wherein half an ounce of Rubard being ≈ømal
cut hath been ≈øodden, putting ≈øome Sugar Candie to it, to ≈øweeten it, and immediatly after he hath ≈øo purged, keep at his navell Ro≈øemary ≈øod in ≈øtrong Vinegar, applyed in the morning and evening very hot, untill it be ≈øtayed; giving him often Quinces brui≈øed, and rouled in Marmalade like Pills, which he ≈øhould ≈øwallow whole, and none of the fruits or meats before recited, nor any more white wine, but red wine of any ≈øort: And if it be one the land u≈øe the Livers of Goats, (e≈øpecially) Sheeps, or Bullocks ro≈øted; not willingly permitting the Patient to eat any other meat: And if at Sea, Rice onely ≈øodden in water, rather then any thing el≈øe u≈øuall there, untill the infirmitie bee perfectly a≈ø≈øwaged.

div.head: The Eri≈øipela,
div.p: REigneth much in tho≈øe Countries, proceeding from the unwhol≈øome aires and vapours tho≈øe hot Countries doe yeeld, whereof many peri≈øh; and if it bee not prevented by Medicines pre≈øently mini≈øtred to the Sick Patients, it proveth incurable.

div.head: To know the Eri≈øipela.
div.p: Hee will be ≈øwoln in the face, or ≈øome part of him, and it will be of yellow colour mixed with red. And when it is pre≈ø≈øed with the finger, there will remain a ≈øign or dint of the ≈øame, and then by degrees it will fill again to the former proportion. It ≈øpeedily infecteth the inward parts, becau≈øe ≈øuch ≈øwellings come ≈øooner unto perfection in hot places, then in temperat Countries, and therefore the di≈øea≈øed thereof, mu≈øt immediatly be provided of remedie.

div.head: To Cure the Eri≈øipela.
div.p:
The Savage people fir≈øt found out perfectly how to cure this di≈øea≈øe, (though it is the Spani≈øh name of the Maladie) by brui≈øing ≈øo much Tobacco as will yeeld four ≈øpoonfuls of
