The juyce of Tobacco is very excellent to expell poi≈øon, and is the ordinary remedie u≈øed by the Indians, and other Savages when they are poi≈øoned, and bitten with Scorpions, or other venemous creatures: But they make pre≈øently ≈øome inci≈øion where they are bitten or ≈øtung, and wa≈øh it with the juyce of Tobacco, then applying the ≈øame brui≈øed thereunto two or three dayes, they heal it up with dried Tobacco.

div.head: The Tino≈øo or Scurvie.
div.p: IS an infecting di≈øea≈øe ≈øufficiently known unto Sea-fayring men, who by putrified meats, and corrupted drinks, eating Bisket flourie, or foul cru≈øted, and wearing wet apparrel (e≈øpecially ≈øleeping in it) and ≈ølothfull demeanour, or by gro≈ø≈øe a humours contained in their bodies get the ≈øame,

div.head: To know the Scurvie.
div.p: Many have peri≈øhed when they returned out of hot Regions into cold Climates, where they have had the parts of their bodies, which with heat, were nimble and tractable to every motion of the Spirits, dulled and benummed with cold, which is a token that this di≈øea≈øe is ingendring in their joynts; and ≈øoone≈øt appears by ≈øwelling of their ankles, and knees, and blackne≈øs of their gums, or loo≈øene≈øs of their teeth, which will ≈øometimes come forth, when there is no remedie u≈øed in ≈øea≈øon.

div.head: Pre≈øervatives again≈øt the Scurvy.
div.p: You mu≈øt have a care to pre≈øerve tho≈øe things before rehear≈øed well conditioned, the badne≈ø≈øe whereof, in part breed this di≈øea≈øe; they mu≈øt u≈øe exerci≈øe of body, and ≈øuch as are exempted from doing of labour, mu≈øt hang or ≈øwing by the armes twice or thrice every day; they mu≈øt not have ≈øcarcity of drink in hot climates, and coming into the cold, mu≈øt be daily releeved with Aqua vitae or Wine: It is al≈øo an a≈ø≈øured Medicine again≈øt this di≈øea≈øe, to have ≈øuch quantity of Beer brewed with graines and long Pepper, as in the morning, twice every week, there may be given a good draught to a man, proportioning three quarters of a pound of graines, and three quarters of a pound of long Pepper, to a Hog≈øhead of Beer: Al≈øo white Wine, or Syder, boyled and brewed with graines and long Pepper in like quantity, is very ≈øingular good: And it is not fit to ≈øuffer the gummes to abound with fle≈øh, and therefore ≈øometimes let them bleed, and cleer them with ≈øtrong Vinegar.

div.head: To cure the Scurvy.
div.p: If the Scurvy be ≈øetled in his mouth, the corrupted and black fle≈øh mu≈øt be taken away, and his mouth wa≈øhed with ≈øtrong Vinegar, wherein graines and long Pepper have been infu≈øed and brewed, and give him daily the drink that is before pre≈øcribed; and as well ≈øuch as have it in their mouths, as tho≈øe that are ≈øwoln in their limbs, mu≈øt have ≈øome meet Purgation pre≈øently; but tho≈øe ≈øo ≈øwoln or ≈øtiffe (for ≈øo ≈øome will be without ≈øwelling) to ≈øcarifie the parts infected, and to apply thereto a Poultis or Catapla≈øme of Barly meal, more hot than the Patient will willingly ≈øuffer it; ≈øo doing every morning, permit him not to re≈øt two houres after, although being nummed or faint, he be ≈øupported to walk, and ≈øuffer him not to eat any ≈øalt meats, if other meats may be had.

My ≈øelf having eighty men, eight hundred leagues out of

div.p: Take Calamus Aromaticus, Galingale, and a little Fennel ≈øeed, Cloves, and Cinnamon, grate or beat them together, and take them in pouder, or drink them with ale.

div.head: For the Small Pox.
div.p:
Take Almonds, and make Almond milk, and take the cream
thereof, and bath the face twice or thrice, though all the Pocks be pulled away, it ≈øhall not be Pock fret.
Annoint oft the Patients eyes with a linnen cloth wet in the juyce of Sengreen, and it will ≈øave them from the Pox.

div.head: For a ≈øtroke in the eye.

div.head: Bloud≈øhed in the eye.
div.p: Five leaved gra≈ø≈øe, ≈øtampt with Swines grea≈øe, and with a little ≈øalt bound to the eye.

div.p: Sint calida quae aure imponuntur, & frigida quae in oculo.

div.head: For a Venomed ≈øore.
div.p: Take Lavender, Marigolds, Sengreen and Betonie, and ≈øtamp them together, and lay them to the ≈øore.

div.p: Take pi≈ø≈øe and Vinegar, and Sage M. i. ≈øtamped, and flour, and boil them together, and lay it hot on a cloth to the ≈øore.

div.head: For the Squin≈øie.
div.p: Bray Sage, Rue, and Par≈øely Roots, and lay them hot to the throat.

div.p: Stamp Mint, and clear Leeks, and lay it to the ≈øore.

div.p: Make a Plai≈øter of Woodbine leaves, and lay to the ≈øore.

div.head: For gnawings.

div.head: To increa≈øe Milk.
div.p: Pouder of Anni≈øe, and the juice of the bark of Fennell root drunke.

div.head: If milk be thick.
div.p: Eat mints, and boil mints in wine and oyle, and lay on the brea≈øts.

div.head: For Botches, Wounds, and Sores, a ≈øalve.
div.p: Boil black Ro≈øin, red Lead, and oyle Olive together; & fiat empla≈øtrum.
Qui bibit novem dies ≈øimul propriam urinam, nec habebit epilep≈øiam, paraly≈øin, nec colicam.

div.head: Venenum.
div.p: 1. Qui bibit propriam urinam, ≈øanabitur a ≈øumpto veneno.
2. Garlick, Rue, Centaury, graines of Juniper, valent contra venenum.
3. Pouder Hemp≈øeed, and mingle it with Goats milk, and let them boyle a little, and u≈øe this drink three dayes, valet contra inflationem, venenum, Bubonem, Felon, & ≈øquinanciam.

div.head: Pro Auribus.
div.p: Green A≈øh leaves burnt, and the liquor that drops out of them impo≈øitum valet.
Euphorbium pounded with Oil Citron, and laid hot on the eares, cureth ≈øounding of the eares, tingling, and Fi≈øtulaes.

div.head: Caput-purgium.
div.p: Take the juyce of Ivy, and powder of Pepper, mingle them, together, and drink it.

div.head: For the bloudy Flix.
div.p: The yellow that groweth in red Ro≈øes put into pottage, and ≈øo eaten, is good for the bloudy Flix.

div.head: Vermes Stomachi.
div.p: The ≈øame yellow drunk in Ale. valet contra Vermes.

div.head: For a Felon.
div.p: Scabious ≈øtamped ≈ømall, a good quantity of Tar, and greace ana temper them together, and all raw, lay them to the ≈øore place.

div.head: For the Reines of the back.
div.p: Boyl your own water well, ≈øcum it, then take a quart of that water, oyle of bayes one ounce, oyle of Ro≈øes one ounce, boyle all in a pot, and therewith annoint well the reines in the hot ≈øunne, or again≈øt the fire.

p.hi: ∆≤nge renes, cum na≈øturtio & propria urina jejunus ≈øaepe, & juvatrenes.
Coque mel & butyrum ≈øimul & unge renes coram igne.

div.p: Seeth Smallage, and temper it with Wine, and drink it fa≈øting, and you ≈øhall be healed.

div.head: For them that cannot goe upright for pain in their back and reines.
div.p: Take a fat Hen, and ≈øcald her, and draw her, and fill her with Sena coddes 1d weight, and Polipody of an Oak, and of Annis, Id weight, boyl her well, and ≈øtrain her into a ve≈ø≈øell, and take two ≈øpoonfuls thereof, and give it the ≈øick fir≈øt and la≈øt.

div.head: For the Stitch.
div.p: Take three handfuls of Mallowes, ≈øeeth them in a litte raw Milk, and put thereto a handfull of wheat bran, and let them boyle together, and then wring out the Milk, and lay it hot to the Stitch, apply it often.
Take a few leaves of Rue, and Yarrow, ≈øtamp them together, and wring out the juyce, and drink it with a little Ale.

div.head: For the Stitch in the ≈øide.
div.p: Make Balls of red Wortes ≈øodden, and burne them in a new pot, and then grind them to powder, and mingle them with Honey and old Greace, and make a plai≈øter, and lay it thereto when it is well ≈øodden.

div.head: To heal Wounds.
div.p: Take Ribwort, Plantain, Smallage, ana. take well nigh as much May Butter as of the juyce, mingle it together, that it be ≈øtanding, and put it in a Box that no air come thereto, and make an Ointment, and this is the ≈øecure≈øt Medicine for healing Wounds.

div.head: For ≈øwelling of Joynts.
div.p: Bray Mallowes, and boyle them in new Milk, and make it into an emplai≈øter, and apply it to the place.

div.head: To knit Sinews or Veins that are kickt or broke.
div.p: Take two Onions in ≈øummer, when thou finde≈øt two Wormes knit together, cut off the knots, and lay them to dry again≈øt the Sun, and make thereof powder, and ca≈øt it in the Wounds, and it will doe as afore≈øaid.

div.head: Ut virga hominis nunquam erigatur.
div.p: Formicas i≈øtas pulveri≈øabis, mi≈øce cum vaccinio lacte & da cuivis in potu &c.

div.head: Verrucae, Porri, ficus.
div.p: Cortix ≈øalicis combu≈øtus & temperatus cum aceto, & appo≈øitus, verrucas, porros & ficus tollit. Portulaca fricata tollit verrucas, Agrimonia trita & empla≈øtrata cum aceto verrucas tollit
Sterous ovis ≈øi mi≈øceatur cum aceto, & fiat emplai≈øtrum, tollit varielas & verrucas.

div.head: For Cornes.
div.p: Take Beanes and chew them in thy mouth, and lay them to the Corn, doe this at night.

div.head: For Warts.
div.p: 1. Pur≈ølane rubbed on the Warts maketh them fall away.
2. The juyce of the roots of Ru≈øhes applied, healeth them.

div.head: For a Wound that bleedeth inwardly.
div.p: Take Filago, and temper it with Ale or Wine, and give it him, and anon the bloud ≈øhall goe out by his mouth; and if the Patient cannot open his mouth, open it with a key, and put it in, and he ≈øhall receive his ≈øpeech, this hath been proved.

div.head: If men have any blood within them of any hurt.
div.p: Let them drink Eufra≈øe ≈øodden with water, and anon they ≈øhall ca≈øt it out by vomit.

div.head: Aqua pro≈øcabie, tumore, & prurita.
div.p: A≈øhes made of green A≈øhen wood ≈øifted clean, and mingled with clean water, and often ≈øtirred, all a whole day, the water thereof, that is clear gathered, and mingled with a little Vinegar, and a little Allome, and ≈øodden together, is a pretious water to wa≈øh with, ≈øores of ≈øwellings, and for itchings, and clean≈øing of divers ≈øores.

div.head: An vulneratus vivat, vel non.
div.p: The juyce of Pimpernell drunk with water, if it come out at the Wound of a wounded man he ≈øhall dye, if it come not he ≈øhall live.
Al≈øo give him Trefoile to drink, if he ca≈øt it out he ≈øhall die

div.head: To de≈øtroy an Impo≈øthume, in what place ≈øoever it be.
div.p:
Take the roots of mar≈øh-mallowes, wa≈øh them and boyle them, afterwards take the ≈øame water, and boyle it with the
≈øeed of Fenugreek, and Line, then bake it with the bran of Barly, afterwards fry it with Bores greace, make thereof an emplai≈øter, and apply it hot, and within a ≈øhort time the Patient will be cured.

div.head: For Warts.
div.p: 1. Agrimony ≈øtampt with Salt, and tempered with Vinegar, and laid on the Warts, within four dayes doth take them away.
2. Take the yolk of an Egg well roa≈øted, ≈øtamp it with oyle of Olive, or oyle of Violets, and make it in manner of a plai≈øter, and this will doe away the Warts in a night.
3. Rub them oft with oaken Apples, and bind a plai≈øter thereof on them, and bray blo≈ø≈øomes of Golds, and Agrimony with Salt, and lay them to as a plai≈øter.
4. Burn Willow tree rind, and temper the A≈øhes with Vinegar, & utere.

div.head: Oleum Nucum.
div.p: Take Nuts whole, ≈øeeth them in water, and then break them, and take out the kernels and ≈øtamp them, and then wring them through a cloth, and that Oyle is noble and mollificative.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Dialaehaeae optimum pro podagra.
div.p: Take Brocks greace, Swines greace, Ducks groace, Capons greace, Ganders greace, ≈øuet of a Deer, Sheeps tallow, ana. p. ae. melt them in an earthen pan, then take the juyce of Rubarb, mar≈øh-Mallowes, Morrel, Comfrey, Day≈øie, Rue, Plantain, Mace, Heyrif. Matfelon, and Dragons, ana. p. ae. fry them in a pan with the fore≈øaid greace, ≈øecretum pro podagra.

div.head: For the Collick and Stone.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Cepas Rubras, pi≈øta commixta cum mulva≈øceto, & bibe ealide.

div.p: ‚Ñû. Aquam fabri potell. i. ≈øalviae, cuprifolii na≈øturtii & modicum mellis, coque ad medium, & lava locum.

‚Ñû. Celidoniam, pi≈øta & coque cum butyro ver≈øus dolorem capitis et≈øi cranium cecidit de loco, &c. & lava cum decoctione ejusdem herba.

div.p: Pulvis ≈øtercoris caprae po≈øitus ≈øupra dentem, facit cadere: cave alia.

div.p: Take pouder of a linnen cloth when it is well burnt, and take the yolks of eggs, and mingle them well together, and therewith annoint the ≈øore, and put the pouder into the hole.

div.head: A Drink that healeth all Wounds without any Plai≈øter or Ointment, or without any taint mo≈øt perfectly.
div.p: Take Sanicle, Milfoil, and Bugle, ana, p. ae. ≈øtamp them in a morter, and temper them with wine, and give the ≈øick that is wounded to drinke twice or thrice in a day till he be whole. Bugle holdeth open the wound, Millfoil clean≈øeth the wound. Sanicle healeth it, but Sanicle may not be given to him that is hurt in the head, if the brain-pan be broken, for it will ≈ølay him, and therefore it is better in another place: This is a good and tryed Medicine.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum geni≈øtae.
div.p: Take Flores geni≈øtae, floures and leaves of Woodbind, ana, p. ae. ≈øtamp them with May Butter, and let them ≈øtand ≈øo together all night, and in the morning make thereof an ointment, and melt it, and ≈øcum it well: This Medicine is good for all cold evils, and for ≈øleeping of hand and foot.

div.head: Unguentum Augu≈øtinum is good for all ≈øore legs that be red and hot.
div.p:
Take Ground≈øell and Petty Morrell, and ≈øtamp them, and
temper them with May Butter, and put them in a pot fa≈øt clo≈øed, and let them ≈øtand ≈øo nine dayes, and then frie it over an ea≈øie fire, and ≈øtrein it through a cloth, and put it in a box for your u≈øe.

div.head: Unguentum viride is good pro erectione virgae, and for the mormale; no ointment worketh ≈øtronger then this.
div.p: Take a pound of Swines grea≈øe, one ounce of Verdigrea≈øe, half a ≈øcruple of Sal gemmae, this ointment may be kept 40. winters: Valet contra cancros, and for running holes, it fretteth away dead fle≈øh, and bringeth new, and healeth old wounds; put it within the wound that it fe≈øter not: Put to this ointment, Pitch, ro≈øin, and waxe, and it will be a fine heat for old brui≈øes, ≈øwellings, and Mormales.

div.head: Unguentum nigrum, for wounds, heating and burning.
div.p: Take a quart of oyle of Olive, and boil it well, then ca≈øt in a quart of red lead, and ≈øtir it well with a ≈ølice, and boil it till it be black, and then let it cool; and keep it for drawing and healing.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Rubrum.
div.p: Take a pint of honey, half a pint of Vinegar, and a portion of Verdigrea≈øe, boil them together, and it is good for all manner of ≈øores.

div.head: Contra vemitum.
div.p: 1. ‚Ñû. Ro≈øewater, pouder of Cloves, and Ma≈øtick, and drinke it hot.
2. Take Mints thre ounces, Ro≈øes half an ounce, Ma≈øtick one ounce, Barlie meal, and a cru≈øt of bread to≈øted, and this manner of Plai≈øter apply to the ≈øtomack.
3. Rutae cochleare i. bibe cum vino vel cerevi≈øia, multum valet.

Note, He mu≈øt eat no meat whil≈øt he ca≈øteth (ut virtus maneat.

div.head: Fluxus ≈øanguinis narium.
div.p: 1. Hens feathers burnt, and the ≈ømoke thereof applyed to the no≈øtrils ≈øtinteth it.
2. A pigs turd burnt, and made into pouder, blown into the no≈øtrils.
3. The juyce of Smallage drunk re≈øtraineth bleeding. Probat.
4. Succus menthae & rutae mixtus curat fluxum narium.

div.head: Contra Sciaticam.
div.p: Stercora leporis temperata et calido vino applica forma empla≈øtri dolori.

div.head: Freckens of the face.
div.p: 1. Grea≈øe your face with oyle of Almonds, & bibe ≈øuccum plantaginis.
2. Annoint your vi≈øage well and often with Hares bloud.

div.head: To know if a man be a Leper or no.
div.p: Let him bleed, and put the bloud into water, and if the bloud ≈øwim above, he is a Leper, and if it de≈øcend, he is clean.

div.head: For ache in the loins.
div.p: Take Waybread, and Sanicle, ≈øtamp them, and put thereto Bores grea≈øe, & forma ‚Ä¢ mpla≈øtri calide dolori applica.

div.head: For a ≈øcald Head.
div.p: 1. Wa≈øh thy head with Vinegar, and Cammomil ≈øtampt and mingled together, there is no better thing for the Scall. Probat.
2. Grinde white Hellebor, grinde it with Swines grea≈øe, applica capiti.
3. Take Culver dung, with Salt, and a little Vinegar, and ≈øtirre them well together, and therewith wa≈øh thy head, & ≈øanabit capitis faeditates.

div.head: Ad ornatum faciei.
div.p: Take fre≈øh Bores grea≈øe, and the white of an Egg, and ≈øtamp them together, with a little pouder of Bayes, and therewith annoint the vi≈øage, and it ≈øhall clear the skin, and make it white.

div.head: If the Liver rot.
div.p: Eat raw Par≈øely 9. dayes, and 6. dayes after eat Sage, and that will clean≈øe that the Par≈øely hath wrought.
Note, All Hearbs who≈øe roots be medicinable, are be≈øt in Aprill.

div.head: For ≈øtopping of the Pipes.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Leaves and tender ≈øtocks of Horehound, ≈øtamp them and
≈øeeth them well in Butter, then wring it through a cloth, cool it, and adde to that pouder of Liquorice, and of Hy≈øop, mixe them together, and keep it in a Box, and when thou wilt, take a ≈øpoonfull, and temper it with hot wine, and u≈øe it when thou goe≈øt to bed.

div.head: Aliud.
div.p: ‚Ñû. A good quantity of Hy≈øop, ≈øeeth it in half a gallon of good wine, till half bee ≈øodden away, and let the ≈øick u≈øe it fir≈øt and la≈øt, at evening hot, and at morning cold. Probat.

div.head: Aliud.
div.p: ‚Ñû. The juyce of Cinquefoil ≈øtamped, and drinke a ≈øup thereof with wine or ale, and it ≈øhall clear thee of much flegm, above and beneath.

div.head: The Plague Water.
div.p: TAke a handfull of Sage and a handful of rue, and boil them in three pints of Maim≈øie, or Mu≈øcadine, untill one pint be wa≈øted, then take it off the fire, and ≈øtrain the wine from the hearbs, then put into the wine two penniworth of long Pepper, half an ounce of Ginger, and a quarter of an ounce of Nutmeg, all gro≈øly brui≈øed, and let it boil a little again: This done, take it off the fire, and di≈ø≈øolve it in half an ounce of good Venice Triacle, and a quarter of an ounce of Mithridate, and put to it a quarter of a pint of ≈øtrong Angelica water; ≈øo keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped for your u≈øe: For pre≈øervation you ≈øhall take every morning a ≈øpoonfull warm, and lay you down to ≈øweat upon it, and ≈øo continue to take it twice a day untill you perfectly recover. This water likewi≈øe cureth the ≈ømall Pox, the Mea≈øels, Surfets, and Pe≈øtilentiall Fevers.

div.head: A Cordiall Water good for the Plague, Pox, Mea≈øels, all kind of Convul≈øions, Fevers, and all pain of the Stomack.
div.p:
Take Sage, Ro≈øemary, Rue, Celandine, Scabios, Agrimonie, Mugwort, Woormwood, Pimpernel, Dragon, Carduus benedictus, Ro≈øa ≈øolis, Betonie, Marigold leaves and flowers, Centurie,

Polipodium, Scurvie gra≈ø≈øe, of each a handfull, wa≈øh them and ≈øwing them in a clean cloth till they be dry, then ≈øhred them ≈ømall, and take the roots of Zedoarie, Tormentill, Enula campana, Angelica, Licorice, of each half an ounce ≈øcraped, and ≈øliced, then take of the be≈øt white wine eight pints; put them all into an earthen pot well leaded, let them ≈øtand two dayes clo≈øe covered, and ≈øtirre them once in the day, then ≈øtill them in a Limbeck, with a temperate fire; it will be two dayes and a night in the ≈øtill: keep the fir≈øt pint by it ≈øelf; of which you may take a ≈øpoonful at a time; of the next quart take twice ≈øo much; of the next pint you may give to little children a ≈øpoonful at a time: Lute the ≈øtill well, that no aire come forth, and keep it in clo≈øe gla≈ø≈øes.

div.head: For a Child that hath the Ague.
div.p: Take the Hearb called Hart≈øhorn, ≈øtamp it, then mingle it with bay Salt, and three or four houres before the fit come apply it, ≈øpread upon a linnen cloth, to the Childs wri≈øts, and when the fit is pa≈øt, apply a fre≈øh one before the next fit, and in a few fits, God willing, ≈øhe ≈øhall be cured.

div.head: For a burning Fever.
div.p: Take red mints two handfull, boyle them in a quart of running water, to the con≈øumption of half, ≈øtrain it, and put thereto four or five ≈øpoonfuls of white Wine Vinegar, and as much Honey, boyle it to the height of a Sirrup.

Take of Endive two handfuls, boyle it in a quart of water, to the con≈øumption of half, take two ≈øpoonfulls of this, and one of the Sirrup, in the morning fa≈øting, and at any other time you plea≈øe.

div.head: For the Jaundies black or yellow.
div.p:
Take of White Wine one pint, ≈øteep therein of the root of Caelidon, the weight of twelve pence, of Saffron one pennyworth, a ra≈øe of Turmatick; brui≈øe all, and bind them in a fine peece of Laun, and let it infu≈øe in the Wine a night, drink
a part thereof in the morning, one other part at noon, and the re≈øt at night.

div.head: To bring down the Flowers.
div.p: Take of Alligant, or Muskadine, or Clarret, a pint, burn it, and ≈øweeten it well with Sugar, put thereto two ≈øpoonfulls of Sallet oyle, then take a good Bead of Amber in pouder in a ≈øpoon with ≈øome of the wine after it, take it evening and morning.

div.head: To ≈øtay the Flowers.
div.p: Take Amber, Corrall, Pearl, Jeat, of each alike, grind them to a fine pouder, and ≈øear≈øe them; take thereof as much as will lye upon ≈øix pence with con≈øerve of Quinces, and drink after it a draught of new milk, u≈øe it every morning.

div.head: For the Mother.
div.p: Take a brown to≈øt of ≈øour bread of the nether cru≈øt, and wa≈øh it with Vinegar, and put thereto black Sope, like as you would butter a to≈øt, and lay it under the Navill.

div.head: For the Stone.
div.p: Take Saxifrage, Pellitorie, Par≈ølie, Eyebright, wild Thime, of each two handfuls; of Raddi≈øh roots two or three, ≈øteep all in a pottle of red cowes milk a night, then ≈øtill it, make of this quantity two ≈øtillings.

You mu≈øt take at a time nine ≈øpoonfuls, as much Reni≈øh or White wine, and the juice of a Lemon, ≈øweeten all with Sugar, and take it fa≈øting, if your ≈øtomack be cold, ≈ølice a little Ginger, and put into it.

div.head: For a cold, cough, Pti≈ø≈øick, or any defect of the Lungs.
div.p:
Take Horehound, Maiden hair, Liver-wort, Harts tongue, Germander, Hy≈øope, Agrimonie, of each a handfull, wa≈øh them and boil them in ≈øix pints of running water in a pipkin, till four pints be con≈øumed at lea≈øt, ≈øtrain it, and put the liquor into another clean Pipkin, put thereto of the root of Enula campana in pouder and ≈øear≈øed one ounce, of Licorice ≈øo u≈øed two ounces, of pure honie eight or nine ≈øpoonfulls;
boyl it till it wax ≈øomewhat thick, then ≈øet it to cool: Take the quantity of half a nut at a time, as often as you plea≈øe.
The be≈øt time to make it is in May.

div.head: For a Stitch.
div.p: Take of ≈øtale Ale, two pints, clarifie it, and boyl therein of the tops of green broom a handful, then ≈øweeten it with Sugar, and give thereof to the ≈øick warm to drink.
Al≈øo take Beer, make it very Salt, put a little Nutmeg thereto, and drinke thereof bloud-warm.
Apply upon the grief outward, Fennel ≈øeed, and Cammomile made wet with Malm≈øie, as hot as can be ≈øuffered, three or four dayes together.
Or take a to≈øt of Rie bread to≈øted on a gridiron, and ≈øpread Tar thick thereon, lay it hot next the skin, and let it lye 9, or 10 houres, and if the pain be not gone at fir≈øt, apply it again.

div.head: For a Con≈øumption.
div.p: Take a Leg of ‚Ä¢ eal, cut away the fat, and take a red Cock, ≈øcald him, and wa≈øh him clean, then let the Cock and Veal lye in water the ≈øpace of three houres, ≈øeeth them with two pottles of fair water, and ≈øcum it clean: as the fat ri≈øeth, take it off, and ≈øeeth it till half be con≈øumed, then put in a pottle of the be≈øt Claret wine, and let it ≈øeeth together till it come to a quart, clarifie it with three or four whites of Eggs; let it run through a Jelly bag; then ≈øet it on the fire again, and put to it of Sugar a pound, let it ≈øeeth a little, then drinke of it warm three or four ≈øpoonfuls at a time, as often as you plea≈øe.

div.head: For the Green ≈øickne≈øs.
div.p: Take an Orange, cut off the top, and pick out ≈øome of the meat, then put therein a little Saffron, ro≈øt it gently, when it is ro≈øted, put it pre≈øently into a pint of white Wine, keep it covered, and drink thereof fa≈øting.

div.head: A ≈øpeciall Water for all Sores.
div.p:
Take of running water four pints, of Sage, Smallage, of
each three handfulls, of Hou≈øleek a handfull and a half, ≈øeeth them together to the con≈øumption of half, then ≈øtrain it, take of Allum two ounces, of white Copperis an ounce and a half, of Camphire two drachms, beat all ≈øeverally into fine pouder, put all into the water, and let it boyle a little, then put thereto of clarified Honie half a pint, and let it ≈øimper a while, then re≈øerve it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped.
Wa≈øh the ≈øore therewith, and wet a cloth therein, and lay thereto; if it heal too fa≈øt, lay dry lint therein.

div.head: For the trembling of the Heart.
div.p: Take a ≈øpoonfull of the ≈øpirit of Tartar when you find your ≈øelf troubled.

Or take Lignum aloes, Riponticum, Eupatorium, red Sanders, of each two ounces, beat them, and boyle them in ≈øix pints of fair water till two pints be con≈øumed; of the four pints that remain, being ≈øtrained, make a Sirrup with Sugar, and while it is hot, put thereto of Saffron one ≈øcruple, of Ginger one drachm, of Musk two carets, Cloves, Nutmegs, of each a ≈øcruple and a half, keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øhut, take thereof a drachm at a time in a little Broth, or Burrage water, fa≈øting.

div.head: For a Flux of the Womb.
div.p: Take Chalke finely ≈øcraped, ≈øtir thereof in whites of Eggs till it be thick, ≈øpread thereof on brown paper, and lay it on a Gridiron on the fire untill it ≈øtiffen a little, bind it hot upon the Navill.
Take Milk and ≈øet it on the fire, when it ≈øeeths, throw in a peice of Allum, which will turn it to a Po≈ø≈øet, of the thin thereof, give a Gli≈øter in the morning, and at four in the afternoon.

div.head: A purging drink for ≈øuperfluous humours, for Aches in the joynts, ≈øinewes, and for Agues.
div.p:
Take Sar≈øaperilla, Sa≈øafra≈øs, Polipodium, of each a handfull,
Hermodactiles the third part of an ounce, Licorice one ounce, cut and ≈ølice the abovenamed, and put them into a new Pipkin gla≈ø≈øed, and having a cover, and put thereto five quarts of ≈øpring water, let all infu≈øe four and twenty houres, then put thereto of Fennell ≈øeed two ounces, Rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned and picked four ounces, Carduus benedictus, red Sage, Agrimony, Maiden-hair, of each a handfull, put all into the Pipkin, and clo≈øe it with pa≈øte, ≈øet it within a pan of warm water on the fire, and let it boyle two houres, then put thereto of Sena one ounce, let it boyle again half a quarter of an hour, and take it out, letting it ≈øtand covered two houres, then ≈øtrain it without wringing, and keep it in a gla≈ø≈øe or ≈øtone bottle.
You mu≈øt take at a time half a pint in the morning, and fa≈øt one hour after, it will not purge in five or ≈øix houres, you may u≈øe it at any time in the year, but in extream heat, and in fro≈øts.

div.head: A pretious Eye-water for any di≈øea≈øe of the Eyes, often proved.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt white Wine two little gla≈ø≈øe fulls, of white Ro≈øe water half a pint, of the water of Selendine, Fennell, Eyebright, and Rue, of each two ounces, of prepared Tutia ≈øix ounces, of Cloves as much, Sugar ro≈øate a drachm, of Camphire, and Aloes, each half a drachm.

div.head: The Tutia is thus prepared.
div.p: In a Cru≈øible (≈øuch as the Gold≈ømiths u≈øe) put your Tutia and with a charcoale fire let it be made red hot ≈øix ≈øeverall times, and every time quenched in Ro≈øe-water and Wine mixt together; the la≈øt time ca≈øt the water away, and grinde the Tutia to very fine powder.

div.head: You mu≈øt mix the Aloes with the water after this manner
div.p: Put the Aloes in a clean Morter, and pour upon it of the mixt waters, with the Pe≈øtill grinde it too and fro, and as it mixeth with the water pour it off, putting more water to it, till it be all di≈ø≈øolved.

div.head: To bring the Camphire to powder.
div.p: In a clean Morter beat one Almond, then put in the Camphire, and beat it to a fine powder, without which it will not come to a powder.

Likewi≈øe beat all the Cloves to a fine powder, then mix all together in a ≈øtrong gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øtop it clo≈øe and lute it, that no air enter, and let it ≈øtand forty dayes and nights abroad in the hotte≈øt time of ≈øummer, and ≈øhake it well thrice a day.

div.head: The u≈øe.
div.p: Drop a drop of the water into the eye thrice a day with a black Hens Feather, the infirm lying on their back, and ≈øtirring the eye up and down.

div.head: If there be any thing grow upon the eye.
div.p: Take four drops of oyle of Amber rectified, and mix with half an ounce of the water, dre≈ø≈øe the eye as before.

div.head: For any Ague.
div.p: Take a quarter of a pint of Canary Sack, put into it a pennyworth of oyle of Spike, a pennyworth of Sirrup of Poppyes, and one grain of Bezar, mingle the≈øe together, and let them ≈øtand infu≈øed all night, and exhibite it next morning to the Patient fa≈øting.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p: Boyle two ounces of Roch in a Pipkin, in a pint of Ale, about a quarter of an hour or better, then give the party grieved to drink of it pretty warm, ≈øome two houres before the fit cometh, about half of it, and what the party cannot drink at the fir≈øt draught, let it be warmed again≈øt the ≈øecond fit, and give it as before, after two houres be pa≈øt, let the party drink as much po≈ø≈øet drink as he can.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take the quantity of a Wallnut of black Sope, and three times as much crown Sope, mix them together, then ≈øhred a pretty quantity of Rue, and half a ≈øpoonfull of Pepper finely beaten, and a quarter of a ≈øpoonfull of fine wheat flour; mingle
all the≈øe together, then take as much ≈øtrong Beer as will make it ≈øpread upon a linnen cloth, whereof make two plai≈øters, and lay to each wri≈øt one, and ≈øow them fa≈øt on for nine dayes; this mu≈øt be applied as the cold fitt beginneth to come upon them.

div.head: To make Pills to clean≈øe the backe.
div.p: Boyle Venice Turpentine in Plantain water, then take the Turpentine, and bray it in a Morter to very fine powder, take the powder and mingle it with powder of white Amber, powder of Oculorum cancrorum, and powder of Nutmeg, of each half a drachm: mix them up into Pills, and take three of them in a morning.

div.head: A Bath.
div.p: Take Mallow leaves, Violet leaves, Endive, Motherwort, Mugwort, Ro≈øe leaves, Lettice, Cammomill, Bay leaves; boyle of all the≈øe one handfull, in a ≈øufficient quantity of pure running water, and ≈øet in the Bath about an hour, then goe into a warm bed and ≈øweat awhile, and when you come out of your ≈øweat, and are pretty cool, eat Strawberries and Sugar, this will clear the body and purifie the blood.

div.head: For the Cough of the Lungs, and defluxions.
div.p: You may take ≈øometimes of Sirrup magi≈øtrall, of Scabious and of Oxymell Jutianizans, of each one ounce, and of Diacodium half an ounce, and of Sirrup of Dia≈øereos half an ounce: Mingle the≈øe all well together, and mingle with it al≈øo a drachm of pure flower of Sulphur finely ≈øearced; and take of this the quantity of a large Nutmeg three or four times in a day, at morning, an hour before dinner, an hour before ≈øupper, and la≈øt at night; it will cut the flegm, and carry it gently away, without any perturbation or violent trouble of coughing, and cau≈øe quiet re≈øt.

div.head: To cau≈øe a woman to have her Flowers.
div.p: Take of Gladwin Roots about a handful, boyle them in Vinegar, or in white Wine till they be very tender, and after put this into a Ve≈ø≈øel on the ground in a clo≈øe ≈øtool, ≈øo that the woman may ≈øit over it very clo≈øe ≈øtopped, ≈øo that the heat may ≈øtrike up into her body: This Medicine is reported never to fail, but to bring them down: But you mu≈øt have a ≈øpeciall care that no woman being with child have this Medicine admini≈øtred to her.

div.head: For the Cough of the Lungs.
div.p: Take of Coltsfoot two handfuls, of Hy≈øop, and the tops of red Nettles, of each one handful, of Horehound, and Maiden-hair, of each half a handfull, of Rai≈øins of the ≈øun, having their ≈øtones taken out three ounces, of Liquorice ≈øliced half an ounce, and of Elecampane roots ≈øliced one ounce, of Anni≈øe-≈øeeds half an ounce gro≈øly brui≈øed, boil all the≈øe together in a gallon of water in an earthen Pipkin with a gentle fire, till the third part be boyled away, then ≈øtrein it, and take a quart of the decoction, and put to it two ounces of Sugar-Candie beaten, and let it boil a little over the fire again, till the Sugar Candie be melted, then take it off the fire, and put it up into a gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, and drinke of it three or four ≈øpoonfuls morning and evening ≈øo long as it la≈øteth, a little warmed.

div.head: For Cramp or Numne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take a penniworth of Saffron, put it into a little bag, then put it into three ounces of Ro≈øewater, and ≈øtir it well in the Ro≈øewater, then take four penniworth of Camphire, and infu≈øe that in the Ro≈øewater, and being ≈øo infu≈øed and mixed; chafe the place with it warm, and ≈ømell to it, as he bathes the place.

div.head: For a Cough, Winde, and a cold Stomack.
div.p: Take four ounces of good Anni≈øe-≈øeed water, mingle it with one ounce of ≈øpirit of Mint, and di≈ø≈øolve it with two ounces of pure white Sugar candie, beaten into very fine pouder; ≈øet it upon a chafingdi≈øh of coals in a peuter di≈øh, and when it beginneth to walm, burn it with a paper as you doe wine, ≈øtirring it well together with a ≈øpoon, then take it off the fire, and evening and morning, take a good ≈øpoonful of it fir≈øt and la≈øt. It will comfort the ≈øtomack, and is good again≈øt cough and winde.

div.head: For a Cough and Con≈øumption.
div.p: Take of Lungwort, Liverwort, Hy≈øop, Violet, and Strawbrrie leaves of each one handful, Licorice ≈øliced, and ≈øcraped, Anni≈øe-≈øeeds, and Fennel-≈øeeds, of each one penniworth a little brui≈øed, a Par≈øly and a Fennel root clean ≈øcraped, pithed, and cut into ≈ømall peeces, twelve figs ≈øliced, four ounces of good great Rai≈øins having their ≈øtones taken out; boyl all the≈øe together in a pottle of clear running water, till it come to three pints, then put into it two ounces of pure white hard Sugar, di≈ø≈øolve it upon the fire with the other decoction, then take it off, ≈øtrein it, and drink thrice a day of it, that is in the morning, about four in the afternoon, and la≈øt at night, three or four ounces of it at a time, and it will a≈ø≈øwage the drine≈øs and thir≈øt, and open the ob≈øtructions and ≈øtoppings of the Liver and Spleen, and cau≈øe your Flegm to com away with more ea≈øe.

div.head: For a Cold Drop≈øie.
div.p: Take Olibanum, and ro≈øt it in a Fig, and apply it to their great Toe: But if they be ≈øwelled in their face or head; then take a new layd Egg roa≈øted hard, take out the yolk, aend put into the hole ≈øo much Cummin Seed as will fill it, and apply it as hot as it may be endured to the nape of the neck.

div.head: For the Drop≈øie.
div.p: Take a pottle of White or Rheni≈øh Wine, an ounce of Cinnamon, and a pint of green Broom a≈øhes, put them together in an earthen pot eight and forty houres, the Cinnamon being fir≈øt brui≈øed; ≈øtirre them all often, and then put them up into a white Cotten bag, and let the liquor drain out of them, put it up again twice upon the lees, and then u≈øe four times a day of it, drink it cold, in the morning, one hour before dinner, one hour before ≈øupper, and when you goe to bed, at each time drink a quarter of a pint; if the greif be not fully removed, u≈øe a ≈øecond or third pottle ≈øo made up, but with mo≈øt per≈øons one pottle ≈øufficeth.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p: Take as much black Sope as a Wallnut, and three times as much crown Sope, and mingle them together, then ≈øhred about a pugill of Rue, and put thereto half a ≈øpoonfull of Pepper very finely beaten, and with a quarter of a ≈øpoonfull of fine wheat flour, or as much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice; mingle all the≈øe together, then take as much ≈øtrong Beer as will make it ≈øpread upon a linnen cloth, and make it up into two plai≈øters, and apply to each wri≈øt one, and keep them fa≈øt on for nine dayes together; you mu≈øt apply the plai≈øters ju≈øt as the cold fit beginneth to come upon them.

Sweat is held by all experienced Phi≈øitians, to be very good to cure an Ague, but they mu≈øt be put into their ≈øweat before the cold fit come upon them; you mu≈øt u≈øe this twice or thrice before the Ague will be quite cured; and let them drink no other drink during their ≈øweat but Aqua vitae and ≈ømall Beer mingled together, but you mu≈øt not make it too ≈øtrong of the Aqua vitae.

div.head: To comfort and ≈øtrengthen the Joynts and Sinewes.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Of the flowers and ≈øeeeds of Saint Johns Wort three
ounces, ≈øteep them three dayes in ≈øufficient Wine, and then ≈øeeth them in a brazen Ve≈ø≈øell till the Wine be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain them, and put to the ≈øtraining as much of fre≈øh Saint Johns Wort ≈øtamped, and ≈øteep it again three dayes, and afterward add thereunto, of Turpentine three ounces, of old Oyle eight ounces, of Saffron one ≈øcruple, of Ma≈øtick í. ≈øs. of Myrrh, of Frankincen≈øe, ana. í. ii. ≈øs, afterward put in the ≈øtraining the ≈øpace of a moneth, of the flowers and ≈øeed of Saint Johns Wort one handfull and half, of Madder brayed, of fine grain wherewith Scarlet is died, ana. three drachms, of the Juyce of Yarrow two ounces, ≈øeeth them to the con≈øumption of the Juyce, with earth Wormes wa≈øhed with Wine two ounces, and a little Wine odoriferous.

div.head: For ob≈øtructions of Liver and Spleen.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Flowers of Burrage, Buglo≈ø≈øe, Marigolds, Violets, Endive, of each a handfull, Dates ≈øtoned three ounces, of the be≈øt blew Currans two ounces, ≈øweet Fennell-≈øeed half an ounce, Graines and Coriander, of each one drachm, whole brown Watercre≈ø≈øes nine leaves, Hy≈øop ≈øtripped downwards nine little branches, of french Barly three ounces; boyl all the≈øe together in a pottle of ≈øpring water till a third part be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain it, and when it is ≈øtrained adde of the con≈øerve of Barberries three ounces, Sirrup of Lemons and of Quinces, of each three ounces, this is to be taken morning and evening, nine ≈øpoonfuls at a time.
The Flowers are to be had at the Apothecaries, dry all the year.

div.head: For the Pal≈øie in the head.
div.p: For the Pal≈øie in the head, take of the oyles, of Amber, Fox, and Beaver, and mingle them together, and annoint the nape of the neck with them evening and morning, chafe it in with a warm hand, and chafingdi≈øh of hot coales.

And take of the oyle of Amber alone, and with your finger
put ≈øome of it every morning into your no≈øe, and take two or three drops of it, and rub it into your head upon the mould thereof.
And take two or three drops of the ≈øame Oyle, and put it into your Beer or Ale for your mornings draught, e≈øpecially at the change or full of the Moon, for four or five dayes together.
Be ≈øure to keep warm, and avoid going abroad in rain, mi≈øty, or moi≈øt weather.

div.head: Oyle of Saint Johns Wort for ache and pain.
div.p: Take a quart of Sallet oyle, put thereto a quart of flowers of Saint Johns Wort well picked, let them lie therein all the ≈øummer, untill the ≈øeeds of that hearb be ripe, the gla≈ø≈øe mu≈øt be kept warm, either in the Sun or in water, all the ≈øummer untill the ≈øeeds be ripe, then put in a quart of Saint Johns Wort ≈øeeds whole, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand twelve houres, the gla≈ø≈øe being kept open, then you mu≈øt ≈øeeth the oyle eight houres, the water in the pot full as high as the oyle in the gla≈ø≈øe, when it is cold ≈øtrain it, that the ≈øeed remain not in it, and ≈øo keep it for your u≈øe.

div.head: For the knitting together and ≈øtrenthening of bones.
div.p: Give inwardly Knotgra≈ø≈øe, Plantain, or Ribwort water, with Sirrup of the greater Comfrey, to three ≈øpoonfuls of the water exhibit one of the ≈øirrup, ≈øo often as they u≈øe it: There are al≈øo vulnerary Potions pre≈øcribed for this purpo≈øe in the Di≈øpen≈øatories.

div.head: For the Cour≈øes.
div.p: You may di≈ø≈øolve your powder of Lapidum cancrorum, either with juyce of Lemons, or with di≈øtilled Vinegar, and ≈øpirit of Vitrioll; If you put a greater proportion of Vitrioll, then of the other, it will ≈øooner di≈ø≈øolve, you need but cover it with the juyce or ≈øpirits, and after ≈øome few houres poure off the ≈øpirits from the powder.

div.head: A Cordiall excellen ‚Ä¢ t good for melancholy, panting and trembling of the heart, ≈øwounding, fainting, coldne≈ø≈øe, and rawne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtomack, and al≈øo for many other greifs ari≈øing from a cold and moi≈øt complexion, often proved with happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of Saffron half an ounce, of Angelica roots finely ≈øliced one ounce, of Cloves ≈øix drachms, Balm two handfuls, Ro≈øemary tops four handfuls, ≈øhread the hearbs and roots, and beat the ≈øpices gro≈øly, then put them, with half a pound of Sugar, into three pints of ≈ømall ‚Ä¢ innamon water, or of ≈ømall Aqua vitae, and let them ≈øtand infu≈øed three or four dayes together, after boyle them, and let the Aqua vitae burn, ≈øtirring them well together, till near a pint thereof be con≈øumed away, then ≈øtrain it, and when it is ≈øettled poure off the clear from the bottome; keep the clear for your own u≈øe, and re≈øerve the bottome, which you may give away unto poor people, for it will be good and comfortable, though not ≈øo ≈øtrong: The way to u≈øe it, is to take every morning fa≈øting a ≈øpoonfull, and after every meal, at each ≈øeverall time, a ≈øpoonfull.

div.p: Mingle all the≈øe together, and with as much ≈øirrup of pure Sugar as ≈øhall ≈øuffice mingled, make it up, and put into either of the≈øe two Medicines, of Musk and Ambergrea≈øe, of each a grain. Both the≈øe are excellent Cordials for all the greifes before rehear≈øed.

div.head: Pills to purge flegm and Wind.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Aloes ≈øuccotrina nine drachms, of Rubarb, Jallop, and Agarick, of each ≈øix drachms, of Ma≈øtick four drachms, of red Ro≈øe leaves three drachms, let all the≈øe be beaten ≈øeverally into very fine powder, and ≈øcarced, then mix them well, and beat them up into a pa≈øte, with ≈øirrup of damask Ro≈øes as much as ≈øhall ≈øuffice, at the end add unto it twenty drops of oyle of Anni≈øeeds: when you have occa≈øion to u≈øe the≈øe Pills, take about two ≈øcruples thereof for one do≈øe made up into three Pills.

div.head: For the Gout.
div.p: Take of new extracted Honey two ≈øpoonfuls, a pennyworth of red Nettle ≈øeeds finely brui≈øed, mingle them well together, and apply it to the Gout: Let the party drink every third day for a ≈øevennight in the morning in his bed half a pint of new Milk, of a red or black Cow.

div.head: For the Gout, My Lord Denni's Medicine.
div.p:
Take Burdocks leaves and ≈øtalks, cut them ≈ømall, and ≈øtamp them very ≈ømall, then ≈øtrain them, and clean≈øe them, and when you have ≈øo done put them into gla≈ø≈øes, and put pure oyle of Olives a top of them, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe from the air, and when you would u≈øe it for the Gout, poure it into a porrenger and
warm it, and wet linnen clothes in it, and apply it warm to the greived place, warming your clothes one after another, as they grow cold that are on.

div.head: Another, very good for the Gout.
div.p: Take the Ye≈øt of Ale, and ≈øpread it upon brown paper, and apply it upon the greived place pretty warm, the ≈øpace of twelve houres: ≈øome fir≈øt warm the pickle of Olives, and then bath the greived place therewith, putting their feet into it, and after u≈øe the former Medicine.

My Lord Denni's Medicine mu≈øt not be taken till three dayes after the change of the Moon, then after it mu≈øt be taken ≈øix dayes together, then ≈øix dayes before the full it mu≈øt be taken twice a day.

div.head: To ≈øtay the Cour≈øes when they come down too violently.
div.p: Take half a drachm or a drachm of Dia≈øcordium, di≈ø≈øolve it in a drachm of po≈ø≈øet Ale, wherein formerly hath been boyled half a handfull of Shepherds pur≈øe, and as much knotgra≈ø≈øe, and of the greater Comfrey, and drink thereof a good draught at a time morning and evening.

div.head: For the Whites.
div.p: Take a quarter of a handfull of white Archangell, Plantain, Sheaphards pur≈øe, and of the greater Comfrey, of each half a handfull, of the hearbs Hor≈øe-taile, and Cats-taile, of each half a handfull, boyle all the≈øe in two quarts of Milk till half be con≈øumed away, then ≈øtrain it, and ≈øweeten it with good white Sugar Candy finely beaten, and drink of it twice a day for ten or fifteen dayes together.

div.head: To keep the body ≈øoluble, and to purifie the bloud.
div.p:
Take Maydenhair, wild Germander, wood-Sorrell, and
Balm, of each a pugill, of wild Mercury half a handfull, of damask Ro≈øes two handfuls, of clarified Whey ≈øix pints, let it ≈øtand ≈øcalding hot for an houre ≈øtirring it ≈øometimes, after an hour is pa≈øt ≈øtrain it, and drink it twice or thrice a day a good draught of it; and if you wa≈øh your hands in Beef broth after your taking it, it will take away all roughne≈ø≈øe and haires of the hands, it may be taken ≈øafe of a woman with child

div.head: For the green Sickne≈ø≈øe, or yellow Jaundies.
div.p: For cure hereof fir≈øt purge univer≈øally with this or the like purgation. ‚Ñû. of Hiera picra four ≈øcruples, of Rubarb, and Trochi≈øces of Agarick, of each half a drachm, of ra≈øped Ivory, and Hart≈øhorn, of each half a ≈øcruple, of Cinnamon ≈øix graines, of Saffron four graines, of Diacatholicon half an ounce; infu≈øe the≈øe things in the Whey of Cows Milk, or in the di≈øtilled water of Alkakengie, or in Dodder water, or Endive water, you may adde Oxymell thereto.

div.head: An Electuary for the green Sickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of Diatrion ≈øantalon, and Diarrhodon abbatis, of each one drachm, of Diacurcuma, and confection of Alkermes, of each half an ounce, of Diamargariton frigidum, and Calidum, of each two drachms, of ra≈øped Ivory, and Hart≈øhorn, of each one drachm, of all the≈øe make an Electuary, and give it evening and morning by it ≈øelf, or with Dodder or Endive water, the do≈øe is one drachm, pro tempore uno.

div.head: An excellent Powder for the green Sickne≈ø≈øe.
div.p: ‚Ñû. four ≈øcruple of Gentian made into fine powder, of ra≈øped Ivory, and Hart≈øhorn, of each two ≈øcruples; make the≈øe into a fine powder, and give a ≈øpoonfull thereof with white Wine, or the like, at once.

div.head: Another Medicine.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Three or four ≈øpoonfuls of flemi≈øh Madder, boyle it in two quarts of white Wine, with a peice of Sugar, to the con≈øumption of half of it, ≈øtrain it, and let the Maiden drink thereof morning and evening a good draught warm, and walk, or u≈øe ≈øome exerci≈øe to heat the body, but take no cold; u≈øe this for eleven or twelve dayes together.

div.head: A ≈øingular purging Potion again≈øt the green Sickne≈ø≈øe, and all opilations of the Liver, and cau≈øeth young Maids to look fre≈øh, and fair, and cherry-cheek'd, and will bring down their Cour≈øes, the ≈øtopping whereof cau≈øeth this greif, and it is good again≈øt all manner of itch, ≈øcabs, breaking out, and mangane≈ø≈øe of the body, purifying the blood from all corruption.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of the roots of Monkes Rubarb, that is red Dock, and of red Madder, ana. half a pound, of Sena four ounces, of Anni≈øe≈øeed, and Licorice, of each two ounces, of Scabious, and Agrimony, of each one handfull; ≈ølice the roots of Rubarb, and brui≈øe the Anni≈øe≈øeed and Licorice, break the hearbs ≈ømall, and put them all into a pot with four gallons of ≈øtrong Ale, and infu≈øe them all the ≈øpace of three dayes, then drink of this drink, for your ordinary drink, for three weeks at the lea≈øt, the longer the better, and make new as need requireth; it cureth the Drop≈øie, and yellow Jaundies al≈øo, if you put in of Cammomill one handfull.

div.head: For the green Sickne≈ø≈øe, or Jaundies.
div.p:
‚Ñû. Of white Briony root ≈øliced half an ounce, boyle it in a pint of Ale gently a quarter of an hour, and drink a good draught thereof, and ≈øweat, and in your ≈øweat drink it all, or as much as you can, the next day make new and drink again, but without ≈øweating, and u≈øe ≈øome exerci≈øe to keep the body warm; u≈øe this la≈øt order twelve dayes together, u≈øe
good Cordials and Re≈øtoratives, with ≈øirrup and con≈øerve of Fumitory.

div.head: For the green Sickne≈ø≈øe, and Jaundies.
div.p: Boyle of Rue, and Sage, of each a bundle, in a quart or three pints of Ale, with one ≈øcruple of Saffron.

To cure this di≈øea≈øe, the Electuary of Steel is excellent, if the body be fir≈øt purged, for it doth open all ob≈øtructions: but the Patient mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øome exerci≈øe after the taking it, to ≈øtirre up naturall heat the better; the do≈øe is half an ounce at a time to take of it.

div.head: The Steel for the Electuary is thus prepared.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of the filings of the be≈øt Iron, or Steel, as much as you plea≈øe, grinde it ≈øubtilly and finely, upon a Porphiry, or red Marble ≈øtone, with Vinegar, then dry it at the Sun, or at the fire, and grinde it again with Vinegar as at the fir≈øt, and doe thus ≈øeven times one after another, and thus you have the Steel prepared fit for you.

div.head: The Electuary of Steel is made up thus.
div.p: ‚Ñû. Of the filings of Steel ≈øo prepared half an ounce, Cinnamon, Nutmegs condited, of each three drachms, of cho≈øen Rubarb two drachms, of the ≈øpecies of Aromaticum ro≈øatum half a drachm, of cho≈øen Honey, and of fine white Sugar, of each one pound and one ounce; mingle the≈øe all together over a ≈øoft fire, and make it up into an Electuary. After the taking of this Electuary, let the Patient in all ca≈øes u≈øe ≈øome bodily exerci≈øes, being fir≈øt univer≈øally purged, for this Electuary is mo≈øt excellent again≈øt all ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, or other di≈øea≈øe, and for the green Sickne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: For the green Sickne≈ø≈øe, or green Jaundies.
div.p:
The green Sickne≈ø≈øe, or Jaundies cometh of yellow choller,
mixed with corrupt or putrified flegm, and corruption of bloud, deb ‚Ä¢ lity of nature, and faintne≈ø≈øe of heart; it happeneth al≈øo when the Liver is weakened that it cannot convert the nouri≈øhment into bloud, but the dige≈øtion is raw and crude, ≈øo that the whole body is filled with water and flegm in≈øtead of good bloud; it is cheifly found in young Maidens, who de≈øire to abate their fle≈øh colours, and, as they conceive, to be fine, and fair, and fooli≈øhly feed upon tra≈øh (which altereth the colour and ≈øtate of their bodies) as of unripe Apples, Peares, Plums, Cherries, and raw Fruits, and Hearbs, or Meale, Wheat, Barly, raw Milk, Chalk, Lime, and the like, and they that have this di≈øea≈øe are very pale and greeni≈øh; if they chance to cut their finger, no bloud, but water, will follow; they feele great pain in their head, with continuall beating, are faint, ≈øhort-breathed, and their naturall Flowers are ≈øtopped and ≈øtayed, to the prevention and cure whereof, the body mu≈øt fir≈øt be well and orderly purged, as by the Medicines before pre≈øcribed.
